title: Helping the World's Poor. to Help Themselves

As Africa's strongest economic powera multiethnic society building a constitutional and pluralistic democracyNigeria is a nation whose friendship and understanding are central to American purposes. Mr. Carter is conferring due recognition on an influential force on the continent, just as he did on a prior stop in Brazil.

title: March Without Madness
description: It may not be fair to complain about March. It did, after all, bring in spring right on the dot at the equinox and it did melt away all the leftovers of winter. But something was missing. It was a month in search of identity. January and February, though not attractive, had their own unrelenting character. March produced a big snowstorm, the kind that usually lands winter's last knockout punch. But this one had slush in its soul and surrendered as it hit the pavements. March had no madness in it, either: it never raged. Though it froze the St. Patrick's Day marchers and rained on the Easter parade, that was perversity, not wrath. It failed its reputation. The daily wind velocities were pitiful: NE 14 or SW 10; even a few calms. That was the real trouble with March 78: It was bland in a time that needed bluster.

title: Notes on People
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Russian leader, has been on a whistlestop train tour of Siberia and the Far East since Tuesday. Yesterday he visited an army missile base near Novosibirsk, Siberia, about 1,800 miles east of Moscow and 400 miles from the Soviet Union's tense border with China. Mr. Brezhnev was accompanied by Defense Minister Dmitri F. Ustinov, a fact apparently not lost on Chinese diplomats, who were understood to be watching the Brezhnev tour with uncommon interest. Mr. Brezhnev said, after watching an exercise of a missile unit, The Soviet Union will never be an arms race instigator, has never armed itself for the sake of arms.

title: Gotham, Comedy Vocal Trio
description: Swishy, limpwristed humor has never been to this observer's taste, whether performed by heterosexuals as mockery or by homosexuals as selfparody. Gotham, the comedy and vocal trio, has always been a welcome exception. Start- ing up a few years ago on the homosexualcabaret circuit in New York, the threeGary Herb, Michael Pace and David McDaniel, who replaced the original third member a couple years backhave created a genuinely witty, refreshing act that pushes the campy bawdiness of a Bette Midler or a Peter Allen right up to the limits of vulgarity. Yet they have generally seemed so buoyant and pleasant that they avoid offensiveness. And their musicparticularly with, the addition of Mr. McDanielwas a charming potpourri of novelty numbers, nostalgic oldies, clever medleys and ballads.

title: Deaths
description: ACK ERMANBertha. The family of Mrs. Bertha Ackerman, age 94, mourn her death on March 28, 1978. She was a person of unusual will Power, wisdom, compassion, with loving devotion to her late husband, David Ackerman, and her children, Gertrude Benson, Isabel Cohen, Har rv, Dr. Bernard, and the late Dr. Nathan VJ. Loving grandmother of Sheila Okin, Jean Curhan, Jonathan Benson, Amy Cohen and Deborah Ackerman; caring great-grandmother to Jeffry and Jon Curhan, Claude and Paul Okin. Loving mother-in-law to Dr. Leon Cohen and Mrs. Gwendolyn Ackerman and caring grandmother-in-law to Barry Curhan and Leslie Okin. She was greatly loved and respected by all who knew her. Services will be held at the Park West Chapels, 115 West 79th Street on Sunday 10AM April 2, 1978. Members of the Makin Society are requested to attend. Memorial donations may he sent to the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged, 2545 University Avenue, Bronx, New York, 10468 or the Ackerman Institute for Family Therapy, 149 East 78th Street, 10021. Memorial week will not be observed.

Some administrators here say perhaps; a school boar'l member says yes, and the high school valedictorian weighs in with a resounding no.

description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., March 31Every year Mark Roth returns to New York hoping to _prove that Thomas Wolfe was wrong. This year the 26y/oarold Brooklynborn Staten Islander appears to be showing he can come home.

description: Tom Kole, a former president of REA Express Inc., was sentenced in Manhattan yesterday to two years in prison on a Federal charge of conspiracy to embezzle S100.000 from his company.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: ORIENT EXPRESS With its doublebill presentation tonight at 8, the Yeh Yu Chinese Opera Company celebrates a milestone. For 20 years New York's oldest and most active group in traditional Chinese opera, also known as Peking or royal opera, has staged these shows combining music, song, dance and pantomime and acrobatics, with love themes enhanced by colorful, native costumes. Printed English translations are also provided.

No new agreement is in sight.

title: Officers of The Bond Buyer Sue; Charge Chairman Seeks Control
description: The president and the vice presidentsecretary of The Bond Buyer Inc., a company that produces financial publications and owns a financial news wire, have filed suit against the chairman, alleging that he is attempting to obtain control of the corporation.

title: Lessons of a Coal Strike
description: The coal miners have been back on the job less than a week, and their new contract has already become the pretext for a variety of inflated claims. The steel industry cites higher coal costs to justify messive, inflationary price increases. The Teamsters president claims that the miners 37 percent increase in wages and benefits sets standard for other unions, beginning with his own. These claims should not distract us from the more basic lessons of the marathon coal strike.

description: WASHINGTON, March 31President Carter was in another battle today, this ! time over farm aid, and it was difficult to see how he could get out of it without 1 making all the warring sides unhappy. 1

title: Weizman Ends Talks With Sadat; Reports to Premier on Outcome
description: JERUSALEM, March 31  Defense Minister Ezer Weizman returned from Egypt today and immediately reported to Prime Minister Menachem Begin on his talks with President Anwar elSadat.

description: TRENTON, March 31It may one day be as easy as reading from a menu for patients in New Jersey to learn how much a prospective hospital stay will cost.

description: Opening This Week

title: Laotian, After Years of War, Likes the Peace of Montana
description: WOODSIDE, Mont., April 1In the Bitterroot Valley, black Angus calves are trying out their wobbly legs. Creeks, reborn with melting snow, are tumbling down the mountainside. And Vang Pao is plowing his land, getting ready to piant.

title: Mayor in Israel
description: MAYOR TEDDY KOLLEK'S relation to Jerusalem is not merely that of an elected official to his community; not only that of a Jew the city of his fathers. The connection is intensely symbiotic. Jerusalem without Teddy is as inconceivable as Israel itself would be without Jerusalem. The highenergy brightness with which he sparkles is the result of this symbiosis. Approaching his 70's, he rushes about the city, a vigorous executive, forceful and bullish, more often than not on some delicate errand having to do with kindergartens or roses or park for the blind. It sometimes seems that he labors for needs he himself understands better than he feels. He says in a recent article in Foreign Affairs that Jerusalem is a beautiful place set in the mystical Judaean hills, conducive to meditation and thought and wonder at the meaning of life, and he speaks also the great monotheistic religions that claim and share the city.

title: Soil Preparation Is the Most Important Job
description: APRIL SHOWERS alone are insufficient for May flowers. Success will depend a great deal upon the important tasks accomplished this month.

title: Cleaning Up the Garbage Problem
description: IT was perhaps inevitable that a society that in recent years has generated between 136 million and 195 million tons of garbage a year would one day find some better way to use this waste than as underpinning for golf courses. But few, no matter how visionary, could have predicted that communities in the area might one day be competing to get one another's garbage.

title: Declining Membership Plagues League of Women Voters
description: THE Connecticut League of Women Voters  the organization that nurtured Governor Grasso, Secretary of the State Gloria Schaffer, the Mayors of Greenwich and West Hartford and many other elected state officials  is in crisis.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: THE people who commmit crimes for a living, then solve them  on paper convened in Manhattan recently for the Second International Congress of Crime Writers, under the auspices of the Mystery Writers of America. If there was what author Stanley Ellin called a spirit of gloom and doom abroad, it was not from the shop talk about the latest techniques of murder and mayhem, but a situation that novelist Brian Garfield summed up in a succinct phrase: Crime does not pay  enough.

title: U.S. Has Lost An Agency, But Gained a New Voice . . .
description: WASHINGTON  Yesterday, the United States Information Agency vanished, to be replaced tomorrow by a new, more powerful International Communication Agency. Funct Tonally, that means that one central Government organ will now have both external and internal, domestic and foreign, responsibilities. On the one hand, it will inform the rest of the world about the United Stales, and on the other, manage cultural exchanges with other countries.

title: Japan Sops Up Billions of Dollars to Protect Yen
description: Fewer and fewer Americans, it appears, will know the medieval charms of Kyoto, the mists over Mt. Fuji, or the glories of the Ginza. These wonders, and a tempting array of Japanese cars, television sets, stereo equipment, and cameras are steadily receding beyond the reach of American consumers, as the value of the dollar against the Japanese yen continues to drop dramatically.

title: THE TROUBLE WITH EUROPE
description: PARIS. The cities of Western Europe gleam with vitality and comfort. The old glories and the modern conveniences support a bustling, shiny daily life. Shops are filled, highways are clogged, vacations are sacrosanct, and the countryside retains its soothing beauties. But instead of feeling a move toward constructive culmination as the century and the millenium draw to a close, Europeans have a sense of being at the beginning of a downhill slide.

title: PRESIDENT, IN SHIFT, WILL TRY TO END BAN ON ARMS FOR TURKEY
description: WASHINGTON, April 1  The Carter Administration, in a major policy shift, has decided to urge Congress to end the threeyearold arms embargo against Turkey without waiting first for concessions toward ending the Cyprus dispute, officials said today.

title: A Primero Especial Journey To the Grand Canyon of Mexico
description: I feel as though I've crossed the plains in a covered wagon, said Katherine Costley, a retired teacher from San Marcos, Tex., as she and her husband, John, got off the Chihuahua al Pacifico Railway in Los Mochis at 1:30 A.M. It had been 17 hours since the Costleys and 800 other passengers, including my friend and me, had begun a 400mile ride on a rail line that couldn't be built through the rugged Sierra Madre Occidental range of northern Mexico.

title: Of Commas and Teachers
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.The other day I confessed to my brother, a lawyer, that until last June, one month after I graduated from college, I did not know the difference between that and which. Whenever. I had to decide which relative pronoun to use, I simply took my chances: Heads it was that, tails it was which; I didn't take the time to fuss.

title: CRIME
description: Ncvels about surgery have a builtin audience. Who does not thrill to the exploits of those daring technicians whose expert hands cut, probe and sew? Novels about atomic blackmail also are a big thing these days, and the public cannot seem to get enough of them. So take a novel about surgery, mix it up with atomic blackmail, and the result, in theory anyway, should be highly successful.

title: World News Briefs
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan. April 1 (AP)The Supreme Court of Pakistan agreed today to hear an appeal by former Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto to set aside his death sentence for murder. The court set May 6 as the date for the hearing.

title: Joan Kreitler, J.B.GoodwinJr. Set June Bridal
description: Mrs. Carl J. Kreitler of Short Hills, N.J., and Lost Tree Village, Fla., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Joan Carol Kreitler, to John Bryant Goodwin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Goodwin of Norwalk. Conn. Plans have been made for a June wedding in Christ Episcopal Church in Short Hills.

title: E.P.A.'78 Figures Say Diesel Rabbit Gets Best Mileage
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP)  The Environmental Protection Agency has issued its final listing of fuel mileage figures for 1978 model year automobiles, and the results show that the dieselpowered Volkswagen Rabbit provides the best fuel economy.

title: WhoopingCrane Flock Is Expected In Nebraska for Its Yearly Visit
description: LINCOLN, Neb., Apr. 1 (UPI)  A flock of whopping cranes is expected to make its yearly swing through Nebraska early this month.

title: Chile Questions 2 Men on Washington Assassination
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 1A Chilean judge began questioning two men today in the investigation by the United States of the assassination in Washington of Orlando Letelier, a Chilean exile leader.

title: Television This Week
description: Today

title: Richard ThomasPlaying the Worshipper and Not the Hero
description: In his five years as star of the TV series The Waltons, Richard Thomas received his share of fan lettersmost of them expressing what he calls that urgency, that desperation, that need to communicate and to reach out across that space and touch somebody who's acting for you. He explains: If you find a character or performer or personality who speaks to you in a way that no other performer speaks to you, who somehow through his or her work defines your mind and your heart, you invest in them an enormous amountfrustration, hope, longing, romance. They live, through their screen life or musical life or whatever, much of what you wish to live. I think I understand that feeling very, very well.

title: Michi Shan Tuchman Wed
description: The marriage of Michi Shan Tuchman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Tuchman of New York, to James Oliver Wexler, son of Dr. and Mrs. Louis Wexler, also of New York, took place yesterday at the St. Regis. Rabbi Ascher Reichel performed the ceremony.

title: McComb, Miss., Absorbing Changes Born of Bombs and Burning Crosses
description: McCOMB, Miss.Spring comes early to this pinecircled town of 12,500 people nestled in the southeast corner of Mississippi. The dogwoods and azaleas are just ready to flower, the redbuds and the quince and the forsythia have already burst into bloom, and the bloodred and pale pink camellias that dot every lawn are sprinkling blossoms onto the newly greening grass.

title: In California, a Real Estate Salesman for Every Block
description: LOS ANGELES  When Richard R. Conant, a Manhattan advertising executive, moved to Los Angeles last year, he found that the topic of conversation on the beach and in the boardroom was the same: real estate.

title: Response to Carter: Urban Isn't Just City
description: IWALKED away with the impression that the Carter AdminIstration has the view that the growth of the suburbs is bad and that it is going to stop it, said John Y.N. Klein, the head of one of the country's prototypically suburban counties.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: They are the last of their line. They are not chorus girls, chorines or showgirls. They are so different that they have, among themselves, always been the same. They are the Rockettes, exponents of the dying art of precision dancing. In the land of individualism, the Rockette is queen. All 30 of her, as dependable and precise as ever, can be expected to go down, kicking should her taps be finally heard at the scheduled closing of Radio City Music Hall on April 12.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: SPRING is with us at long last, really with us. But if you need affirmation, I would point out to you two separate indicators that come to us from disparate parts of the statethe Mayor's office in the historic farming community of Vineland and from the constantly changing topographical profile of the Hackensack Meadowlands.

title: Some New Products for Boaters
description: The offshore survival jacket from Stearns is designed to help combat hypothermia, lengthening survival time even in icy waters. The jacket's outer layer is lined with ensolite, which provides buoyancy and insulation. The inner layer is made of stretch neoprene, which adds thermal protection. When wet, the jacket hugs the body, acting as a wetsuit to minimize loss of body heat. Available in international orange or navy blue. Suggested retail price $222. Stearns Manufacturing Co., P.O. Box 1998, St. Cloud, Minn. 56301.

title: Cinda V. Lewis, Peter McGraw To Wed June 3
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Wilson Murphy of Red Bank, N.J., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Murphy's daughter, Cinda Vera Lewis, to Peter Schuyler McGraw, son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Cushing McGraw Jr. of Wianno, Mass.

title: 1,466 Billion Miles of Driving
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP)Automobiles, trucks and buses traveled an estimated 1,466 billion miles in the United States in 1977, the Federal Highway Administration reported today. That is equal to about 3 millon round trips to the moon, and it is 4 percent more than the estimate of 1,409 billion miles in 1976. The figures are based on data compiled by each state highway agency.

title: Classical Music on WNCNFM Soothes Once Savage Breasts
description: In the 21 months since radio station WNCNFM returned to its classicalmusic format, after a ninemonth switch from Bach to rock, veterans of the struggle to force a turnabout are pleased with the outcome. Some still don't quite believe that it will last. But most seem to agree with Robert Schack, former president of the principal listeners' group that fought the rockmusic format, who said: I'm gratified with what they're doing. The programming is very, very good.

title: Headliners
description: Columbia Pictures forgave him, but the law in its majesty is still miffed. David Begelman, president of Columbia until October, was charged last week with four counts of forgery and grand theft, allegedly involving three checks written to actor Cliff Robertson, director Martin Ritt and a restaurant owner. Mr. Begelman admitted diverting $61,000 in Columbia funds it is not clear whether the checks at issue in the criminal complaint are a portion of the same money  but pleaded emotional disturbance. Columbia, substantially enriched by his lawful endeavors, reluctantly accepted his resignation and made him an independent producer.

title: Fairfield Historical Group Shows Off 178 Years of Finery
description: TUCKED away behind closed doors most of the year are the 400 items of clothing, some dating to around 1800, in the collection of the Fairfield Historical Society. It's not lack of appreciation, but limited space that prevents the display of more than a few items at one time, according to the curator, Elizabeth Johnson.

title: Political and Economic Advisers Don't Exactly Agree
description: WASHINGTON  Only 10 weeks after a volley of Presidential messages that were to set the Adminstration's broad strategy for the year ahead, the White House has been jarred by economic misjudgments and reverses that are causing it to rejigger its fundamental policies. The reassessment has already involved a veering on farm policy, and may mean an import levy on oil because of Congress' reluctance to accept the Administration's proposal for an oil equalization tax. But most of all, it raises questions about the Carter economic team and its effectiveness.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: In a culture that still tends to think of progress as a convulsion of growth, Joseph Papp has been demonstrating the usefulness of shrinking. It may be a reluctant demonstration. Certainly it is a paradoxical role for this inveterately expansive figure, and perhaps a frustrating one. But it has turned out to be remarkably productive.

title: Eric Kaiser, Law Student, Marries Kim Ball, Lawyer
description: Kim Ball, a lawyer, was married yesterday in the Infant Jesus Roman Catholic Church in Port Jefferson, L.I., to Eric J. Kaiser, a student at St. John's University Law School. The Rev. Terence Attridge, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Welfare Search for Absent Parents Is Criticized
description: A civic group has reported that its monitoring of New York. City's federally mandated program to find absent parents of welfare families and to get court support orders from them has found that it is still not costeffective.

title: Topics
description: Up in Alaska, where the winters are long and the nights are cold, the state's Child Support Enforcement Agency, also known as daddy, grabbers, has been putting questions like the following to some women who apply for funds under the Federal Aid to Dependent Children Program:

title: Flemingway
description: By Lawrence Sanders. 308 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $9.95.

title: Italian Press Is in a Quandary Over Moro's Captors
description: ROME, April 1Is it the business of newspapers, radio and television to give prominence to selfserving statements by terrorists? If they do, do they become tools of the terrorists? If they do not, do they undermine the people's right to know?

title: Clever Are the Ways to Foil the Furry Invaders
description: KATONAH TO AN outsider, backyard vegetable gardening seems to be a peaceful, bucolic activity. Actually, it is bloody warfare. Superficially viewed, those who call themselves home farmers appear to have, in addition to loam under their fingernails, tomatoes on their window sills, and zuccini to burn, a special and enviable air of serenity about them. Actually, they have murder in their hearts.

title: DINING OUT
description: IF you go to La Villetta, you may wonder at first just what we have let you in for. The little villa stands apart in a somewhat isolated section of Larchmont. Even inside, though you are cordially welcomed, the plastic plants and imitation stone wall may give you pause. But disregard these, and disregard too the occasional overfamiliarity of the waiter. Pay attention. instead. to the food.

title: The World
description: The combination was truly incongruous: Japanese farmers in straw hats and rubber boots and young Japanese men and women in red helmets who hurled firebombs at the police. Six youths crawled through a sewer, made their way to the top of an airport control tower and wrecked every piece of equipment in sight.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON
description: NEW JERSEY'S relatively small population increase between the 1970 census and mid1975 consisted of three times as many blacks as whites, according to new figures disclosed by the Census Bureau. This marks the first population breakdowns by race since 1970.

title: INTERVIEW
description: I BELIEVE there is really something in history to interest almost everyone, said Dr. Clifford L. Lord, the new director of the New Jersey Historical Society. He sees his job as one of revitalization of the society, which has been on the scene since 1845.

title: Authors' Queries
description: For a biography of the Evanston architect, Thomas Eddy Tallmadge (18761940), any information on Mr. Tallmadge or his partner, Vernon S. Watson, would be greatly appreciated.

title: Judicial Paychecks
description: IRECENTLY resigned from the Connecticut Superior Court bench to resume the practice of law as a partner in one of our major Connecticut law firms. While many considerations enter into such a decision, the low pay and poor working conditions for our trial bench were certainly a factor.

title: Beauty and Chivalry
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., April 1The beauty and chivalry of the lively stable set descended upon Gulfstream Park today to celebrate All Fools' Day in the manner of their kind. They were here, mainly, for three reasons: To look upon horses whose owners have designs on the American Triple Crown; to look upon one another in springtime plumage; to be looked up. The vehicle for the horses was the $150,000 Florida Derby, the last major competition in this area for 3yearolds en route to the Kentucky Derby, the Preakness and the Belmont Stakes. As expected it was a match between two of the early favorites for the Triple Crown series, Calumet Farm's Alydar, the winner, and Believe It, who finished two lengths back for second money. These two left their five rivals on the far turn, and as they went around the bend Believe It caught and passed Alydar. The latter had plenty left, though, and drew off handily in the stretch.

title: Meet the April Fool
description: FIERY RUN, Va., April 1The April Fool held his annual press conference here in the foothills of the Blue Ridge Mountains today and took a highly optimistic view of the state of human affairs. Following is a partial transcript of his remarks:

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW
description: To whom or to what do we owe those charming photographs in fashion magazines of welldressed, wellcoiffed ladies leaping over puddles, striding purposefully through snowstorms, cavorting with elephants, running breathless with joy and delight through Central Park or the Bois de Boulogne, climbing sand dunes and bravely facing the wind on the dangerously listing deck of a racing yacht?

title: UPPER VOLTA LEADER SEEKS REELECTION IN FIELD OF
description: OUAGADOUGOU. Upper Volta, April 1 (Agence FrancePresse)The head of state, Gen. Sangouie Lamizana, will contest the presidential election on May 14, he has announced.

title: Deaths
description: ALEXANDERArchibald G., of 44 Woodbine Rd, Stamford, Conn., on Sat, April 1, 1978. Son of the late Sir Douglas and Lady Alexander. Husband of Margery Griffith Alexander. Father of Mrs. Fred J. (Margery) Ramsey. Brother of Helen and Douglas Alexander. Pour grandchildren also survive. Funeral service at St. John's Episcopal Church, Stamford, Tuesday at 11:00 A.M. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts to the Stamford Hospital Memorial Fund or to the Rector's Fund of St. John's Episcopal Church would be preferred.

title: Man, 47, Is Found Shot to Death In a Queens Apartment Parking Lot
description: A 47yearold Queens man was found shot to death yesterday afternoon in a station wagon parked in the rear parking lot of an apartment building in the Jamaica section, the police reported.

title: Burn Center Sets Up First Skin Bank in New York
description: The burn center at New York HospitalCornell Medical Center has opened New York City's first skin bank to assure a ready source of skin covering for badly burned patients.

title: Most Popular Pastime in Baseball: Making Excuses
description: Spring training excuses are usually just wannup exercises for midseason excuses, but Bill Lee of the Boston Red Sox came up with a good one this spring when he accused Commissioner Bowie Kuhn of bending the pitcher's elbow the wrong way.

title: The Camera Follows
description: IN one of his masks, Gore Vidal is a literary critic. In that role, he has always been strikingly sober and serious and, well, highminded about the art of writing novels. The collection of essays he published last year, Matters of Fact and of Fiction, was for most of its pages predictably obnoxious/amusing; but in places, wherever Mr. Vidal touched on contemporary novelists or, with disdain, on academic Novel Theory, he showed himself still to be the earnest devotee of the form that he was 20 years ago, when he wrote, in this Book Review, of the novel as preeminentlythe humane art. His point then was the benign paradox that the shrinking audience for fiction was really a good thing, because it left the novel only the best things: that exploration of the inner world's divisions and distinctions where no camera may follow, the fine, the difficult, the private. With the masses addicted to television, and even the serious small elite more alive to film than to prose, one could hope that the hacks, the meretricious and the ordinary [would] desert entirely, leaving only the devoted lashed to the mast. It's fair to presume that the young novelist thought of himself as so lashed, safe from the siren call of the mass market.

title: Seeing the Universe Whole
description: OF the 30 books of fiction and nonfiction that he has published in his distinguished career, Arthur Koestler is best known for his political novel, Darkness at Noon, which first appeared English in 1941. In that book Mr. Koestler, who joined the Communist Party in 1931 and left it seven years later, wrote about an Old Bolshevik caught in the 193738 purges. His devastating portrait of Eastern European Communism could have been written only by someone who had once been a believer; the novel drew its enormous power from a deeply felt sense of personal betrayal.

title: Nigeria Reacts To Carter Visit With Reserve
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, April 1Nigeria is responding to President Carter's visit with the attitude that the attention is flattering but overdue and still somewhat suspect.

title: TV VIEW
description: In evaluating Between the Wars, a 16week series going into syndication this week (Wednesdays at 7:30 on WNEW/Channel 5 in the New York area), dispassionate observers would be hard put to decide which is more creative: the programs or the commercials. The Survey of American Diplomatic History From Versailles to Pearl Harbor has been produced by Alan Landsburg Productions for Mobil Oil as part of a project called Mobil Showcase. In fact, the series was created by Herb Schmertz, a Mobil vice president. How and why has a major oil company gone into the business of television production?

title: Let There Be Less Light, Expert's Tell Office Workers
description: Offices are getting dimmer as the lighting industry introduces new advances in technology and experiments with new standards for measuring light.

title: Gaston Miron, Poetic Voice of Quebec Nationalism
description: MONTREALIf Quebec had a poet laureate, he would probably be Gaston Miron, a forceful leader of its highly vocal and nationalist community of arts and letters.

title: Reorganizing Queens Operation Of Detectives Being Considered
description: An experimental reorganization of the detective operation in Queens, which would place all investigators under the authority of the uniformed borough commander, is being studied by New York City police authorities.

title: L.I.R.R. UNION HEAD EXPECTSRATIFICATION
description: Raymond J. Mills, the general chairman of the United Transportation Union, said yesterday that he was confident the membership would ratify a tentative contract settlement with the Long Island Rail Road because of the way the touchy issue concerning the size of train work crews was resolved.

title: Jayne Mellenthin Plans To Wed Robert Rogers.
description: Mr. and Mrs. George H. Mellenthin of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Jayne Elizabeth Mellenthin, to Robert Hastings Rogers, son of Eleanor Nenstiel of Clemson, S.C., and Robert Rogers of Plymouth Meeting, Pa.

title: Sylvia Page Ober Wed
description: Sylvia Page Ober, daughter of Anne Tillery Ober of Palm Beach, Fla., and Robert Barclay Ober of Baltimore, was married yesterday to Andre Picard, son of Michel Picard of West Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Mrs. Picard. The ceremony was performed in the BethesdabytheSea Episcopal Church in Palm Beach by the rector, the Rev. Dr. Hundson Cary Jr.

title: In Monet's Gardens
description: In 1883 the French Impressionist master Claude Monet settled in Giverny. Using nature as his palette. he composed a luxuriant floral world which gradually came to dominate his art. Now restored after years of neglect. Monet's gardens are opening to the public, and the paintings they inspired are the focus of an upcoming exhibition at New York's Metropolitan Museum.

title: Miss Ingraham To Be a Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sears Wilson Ingraham of Darien, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Laura Grosvenor Ingraham, to Peter V. Justinius, son of Dr. and Mrs. Ivan Justinius of Greenfield Hill, Fairfield, Conn.

title: POINT OF VIEW
description: We in the chemical industry are deeply concerned about the direction of the Tokyo round of multilateral trade negotiations now going forward in Geneva. And we are having trouble conveying this concern to the United States officials involved.

title: Rosemary Harvilla Married To James Golia, an Engineer
description: Rosemary A. Harvilla and James J. Golia were married yesterday in St. Arms Roman Catholic Church in Binghamton, N.Y. by the Rev. Paul Slavetskas. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Harvilla of Binghamton. Her husband is a son of Mrs. Michael Golia of Flushing, Queens, and the late Mr. Golia.

title: A Spring Tonic For the Ailing House
description: ALTHOUGH the wise automobile owner recognizes the need for periodic tuneups, most homeowners do not realize that it is just as important to give their homes the same sort of preventive maintenance. And now that one of the rougher winters in recent years is over, giving the house that tuneup can go a long way toward preventing major breakdowns later on.

title: Doctors' Listings Disputed
description: Trenton NEW JERSEY law strictly limits the form in which physicians can list themselves in the telephone Yellow Pages, a limitation that makes it difficult for prospective patients to select a doctor. A proposed change in the law to make life easier for consumers is expected to be major issue on April 12, when the state's Board of Medical Examiners meets here.

title: The Saudi Connection, Fred Dutton
description: WASHINGTON  Several weeks ago, Frederick G. Dutton flew to Houston on a business trip with a special client  Ghazi Algosaibi, Minister of Industry for Saudi Arabia. During their stay, they heard several lengthy presentations from AmeriCan companies hoping to build petrochemical plants for the Saudis.

title: Carved Decoys Drawing Collectors To Attics of Hunters on South Shore
description: With the recent recognition that its shorebird decoys are among the finest in the world, Long Island now has another cultural asset that is the equal in its field to the paintings of William Sidney Mount and the poetry of Walt Whitman.

title: Pay Rise to Be Costly for New York
description: It will cost New York City $800 million over two years to give its employees the same settlement that the transit workers have won, people familiar with the city's computations said yesterday.

title: The Nation
description: Followers of the world economy had an acute and depressing case of jet lag by the end of last week.

title: The Region
description: The roof of the Hartford Coliseum should have been strong enough to support the heavy snow under which it collapsed in January, a consulting engineer said last week. In fact, it was not strong enough to support even its own weight and eventually would have caved in anyway because of an error so gross and obvious that it is difficult to see how it could have been overlooked.

title: ART VIEW
description: Giovanni Battista Tiepolo (16961770) was the last of the great Venetian painters. But he did not have at all that elegant but faintly extinguished quality that the French call the end of the line. He was robust, tireless and endlessly resourceful. He could excel in any place and on any scale and he set about every new commission with a godlike assurance.

title: Ellen Ava Deutsch Fiancee Of Jon E. Quint, a Lawyer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alvin Deutsch of Long Beach, LI., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Ellen Ava Deutsch, to Jon Edward Quint of Brooklyn, son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Quint of Ventura, Calif.

title: Renault's the One
description: The beleagured American Motors Corporation, which had been negotiating to affiliate with a foreign partner, made its choice known last week  Renault. The companies announced an agreement for joint car and truck manufacturing and distribution. The plan includes consideration of manufacture of Renaults in A.M.C. plants and sales of Jeep vehicles through Renault dealerships abroad.

title: Crew of 500 Working Overtime To Fill New York City Potholes
description: New York City's Transportation Department rallied its forces for a special all borough drive against potholes yesterday, putting 500 men on overtime to fill an estimated 10,000 of them in roadways pockmarked from an extreme winter.

title: France and the World
description: WASHINGTONWhen the French failed to give the parties of the left a popular majority in the first round of last month's election and then again in the second round, and gave the centerright Government coalition a substantial majority of seats in the National Assembly, they voted, among other things, against potential major changes in France's relations with the outside world.

title: Basic Ground Rules for Repairing Winter's Damage
description: EASTHAMPTON THE SNOW may have melted, but memories Long Island's worst winter in decades linger on especially as homeowners begin to survey what snow, ice, winds and freezing temperatureshave wrought. With trees and shrubs broken and bent, with lawns suffering under the burden of longlasting, heavy snows and with shorefront properties bearing the brunt of erosion, the spring cleanup this year threatens to reach major proportions.

title: Best Sellers
description: NONFICTION

title: SHOP TALK
description: OYSTER BAY PERHAPS it's a case of the more things change, the more we yearn for the way they were. And so we return intensively to our beginnings via natural foods, herbal cosmetics, handmade crafts. The trend is increasing, and here, at 43 West Main Street, in a onestory wooden dwelling built in 1899, is the Printerywith all the sounds, smells and flourishes of fine oldfashioned printing.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: Following a laboratory finding in Canada that consumption of enormous quantities of saccharin could cause cancer in rats, the United States Food aqd Drug Administration proposed banning the sugar substitute and the maker of Sweet n Low prepared to dose a factory in Brooklyn.

title: Old Burlesque House Has One Final Fling
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 1 (AP)One of the nation's oldest burlesque houses was on its last financial legs, but for two nights this week, the Troc regained a touch of its glittery past.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: WESTFIELD, Mass., April 1The biggest and oldest white water canoe racing event in North America was held today, after attempts to have the races canceled because of spectator control costs to towns adjacent to the Westfield River failed.

title: Service for Ray M. Thompson
description: A service will be held today for Ray Mack Thompson, codirector of the Walking Tours of the Museum of the City of New York, who died on March 21. The ceremony will he held at 12:45 P.M. in the Rotunda of Federal Hall National Memorial at the corner of Wall and Nassau Streets, in Manhattan. Mr. Thompson became director of tours in 1966. He is survived by his wife, Lillian; a son, Ray, and a sister, Hilda Menter.

title: POLITICS
description: THE musician playing Irish songs at Jerry Lynch's Erin House of Belmar the other weekend stopped long enough to allow a tall, welldressed, grayhaired man to say a few words of Welcome in voice so low that it didn't carry to the end of the bar.

title: A Teacher's Lesson
description: CHAPEL HILL, N C., April 1It was in 1935 and the depth of the Depression that Walter Spearman began teaching journalism students something about their craft and more about themselves. He's still going strong and so are some of them; but somebody must have misinformed the computer, which delivered an obviously mistaken report that Walter Spearman has turned 70 years old, retirement age at the University of North Carolina.

title: Senate's Vote to Cut Funds for Abortions
description: ALBANY, April 1  Following is the roll call by which the State Senate voted last night to cut off state Medicaid funds for most abortions:

title: SPY FILMS ON SOVIET TV SHOW 5 WESTERN NEWSMEN
description: MOSCOW, April 1 (Reuters)Soviet television today showed films and photographs about alleged espionage that repeated charges against five former American correspondents in Moscow. The pictures had apparently been taken by the security police without the correspondents' knowledge.

title: Dr. S. L. Gerson to Wed Dr. Deborah Levitan
description: Dr. Deborah Anne Levitan and Dr. Stanton Laurence Gerson, interns at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, will be married June 18.

title: Firmani Confident for Cosmos Opener
description: When Coach Eddie Firmani of the Cosmos repeatedly says hey and rubs his nose when he says it, it is a sign that he is sure of what he is talking about.

title: J.S. Pyne to Wed Ann Sherrill
description: Mr. and Mrs. Hugh Virgil Sherrill of New York and Southampton, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ann Wilkinson Sherrill, to John Sloane Pyne, son of Mr. and Mrs. Percy Rivington Pyne 3d of Far Hills, N.J.

title: What Makes Hockey Different? The Pleasure of Violent Contact
description: In trying to describe the nature of Hockey, it is well to begin with the final major distinguishing elementthe skatingand move back to others. The kating, with its speed and grace, provides both the aesthetic pleasure for audiences and the exhilaration for players.

title: The Spirit of Spessivtzeva Inspires a New Pas de Deux
description: Several springs ago Gerald Arpino decided to pay a visit to Olga Spessivtzeva, the legendary Russian ballerina who, after a long battle with mental illness, now lives at the Tolstoy Farm, a Nyack refuge for displaced Russians. Mr. Arpino. the resident choreographer and associate director of the Joffrey Ballet, boarded a bus with two of his dancers and they set out to meet the dancer about whom they'd only read. It was almost like going back in time, he recalled recently. Her era was not that far back actually, when you think about it. Anton Dolin, Alicia Markova and Alexandra Danilova were part of it, too.

title: No Welfare for Farmers
description: Hours before Easter recess, the Senate passed a gigantic agricultural relief bill designed to appease protesting farmers. Now, hoping to head off hastily conceived legislation that would raise food prices sharply and risk serious grain shortages, the White House has put forth a more modest relief plan of its own.

title: Cavaliers 113, Pistons 99
description: RICHFIELD, Ohio April 1 (AP)Austin Carr tallied a seasonhigh 25 points as the Cleveland Cavaliers posted a 11399 triumph over the Detroit Pistons tonight.

title: City Limits
description: WASHINGTON  The seven Texans were determined be heard. Led by Mayor Jim McConn of Houston, they were gathered several weeks ago in Representative Bob Kreuger's office, their attention focused on Stuart Eizenstat, the intro spective young lawyer who is President Carter's chief domestic adviser.

title: Of Special Interest
description: The Royal Ballet of Flanders (so named by Belgium's King Baudoin in 1976 will give the penultimate performance of its first coasttocoast American tour at Brooklyn College's Whitman Hall on Saturday. Three of the four dances on the program, choreographed by company members, will also be New York premieres. (See Dance)

title: Carey Urges Legislation to speed Site Selection for Power Plants
description: ALBANY, April 1  Governor Carey asked the Legislature this week to speed the process used to decide where to put power plants by imposing a twoyear limit on the time the siting board would have to rule on an appiication. He also recommended scrapping several current provisions in the law that build delays of more than six months into the siting procedure.

title: The Onion for Gourmets: Shallots
description: During the past decade or so, America has gone through a culinary revolution. International cuisine of the gourmet genre has captured the palates of many hitherto uninitiated. Foods relatively unknown in this country are now available and in demand.

title: It's Time to Plant Dwarf Fruit Trees
description: DURING the past 10 years or so, there has been a minor revolution in home gardening, as more and more people are discovering the joy of growing fruit on their own dwarf fruit trees.

title: Steel Prices Rise
description: The United States Steel Corporation surprised the Carter Administration last week with an increase of $10.50 a ton on its basic steel products, saying it needed to cover the cost of the new union contract in the coal industry. The move, which was followed by the WheelingPittsburgh Steel Corporation, spelled trouble for President Carter's antiinflation plans.

title: When the Hobby Horse Is a Beautiful Arabian
description: A white stallion stands against an indigo sky. His tail is held high; his head, with its wide cheeks, tapering muscle and large dark eyes, Seems sculptured. Behind and above him are slender gold spires and, minarets, and a crescent moon that he nervously watches. He looks like a horse someone has imagined.

title: Letters TO THE EDITOR
description: In The Mondales: Making the Most of Being Number 2 (Feb. 26), Martin Tolchin discusses the criticism of Mrs. Mondale's influence and what some call interference in the area of Government policy for the arts. In itself, it is not particularly significant that her candidate  Livingston Biddle  was appointed director of the National Endowment for the Arts. However, Mr. Tolchin has ignored, or was not aware of, the fact that the new deputy chairman for programs at the Endowment, Mary Ann Tighe, was most recently arts adviser in the Vice President's office. When this is considered in the context of other appointments to the Endowment, there may be reason to believe that Mrs. Mondale wields much more influence than Mr. Tolchin has led us to believe.

title: New Hampshire Hunts For Radioactive Disks
description: SANDOWN, N.H., April 1 (AP)Civil Defense and law enforcement officials were searching today for several small markers, containing radioactive material. that were taken by young children.

title: A Live Question
description: SOMETHING like five million children are conceived each year in America. Spontaneous miscarriages kill perhaps a million. Of the remaining four million, one million are deliberately aborted.

title: An Appalachian Travail
description: MARTINSBURG, W.Va.  When the Economic Development Administration lent $1 million to an Appalachian area veneer plant here 12 years ago, it adopted a problem child.

title: New Tokyo Airport Brings Good Luck to Rural City
description: NARITA, Japan, April 1For more years than anyone can remember, the 1,038yearold Naritasan Buddhist temple here has done a brisk business selling goodluck charms.

title: Adelphi Loses in Lacrosse
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 1Roy McAdam scored four goals and made four assists as he led Hobart's lacrosse team to a 2410 victory over Adelphi today. Rick Blick, an allAmerica goalie from Syosset, L.I., had 17 saves for the winners whose wonlost record is 11. Kevin Miller scored four goals for Adelphi, 12.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLER
description: Way Bandy likes to call himself a face designer. At rates of $100 an hour and up, he has developed a national reputation as a man who can make almost any woman look beautiful  even if her cheekbones are nonexistent and her pores are cratersized. He transformed the late Martha Mitchell into a near raving beauty, and he has also improved on the likes of Elizabeth Taylor, Farah FawcettMajors, Catherine Deneuve, Barbra Streisand, Lauren Hutton, Gloria Vanderbilt Cooper and Lee Radziwill He has made Cosmopolitan cover girls look seductive and Vogue models look expensive.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: WE hardly ever hear about the nonfiction novel anymore. This was a coinage made famous in the 1960's by Truman Capote on the publication of In Cold Blood, and its vogue coincided with the advent of the New Journalism, which likewise appropriated the methods, or at least the mannerisms, of fiction while ostensibly dealing with factual materials. In recent years, however, the term nonfiction novel has virtually disappeared from literary discourse, but the genre it describednovels, or at least narratives, alleged to consist of actual rather than imagined characters, conversations and events  is still very much with us, and has become less and less distinguishable from the kind of New Journalism in which it is the state of the author's feelings that is at all times paramount. Only now there are more and more of these books that no longer bother with such fussy labels. They are allowed to pass as straight nonfiction.

title: FEDERAL PLAN URGED TO SHAPE UP ROADS
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP)Many of the streets and the highways in the United States are going to pot, and the freezes and the thaws of the last winter have made them worse. A highway trade organization estimates that there are 116 million potholes around the nation, in addition to cracked and fractured pavements, worn out shoulders, rough rural roads and thousands of defective bridges.

title: Garbage Crisis: After Landfills, What?
description: KEARNY

title: The Lessons of Spring Training: Contenders, Pretenders Emerge
description: Twentyfive of baseball's 26 major league teams spent the spring preparing for the season and registering greater advance ticket sales than last year. The 26th team, the Oakland A' s, spent the spring wondering where they would play this season, not knowing 24 hours in advance of any day what city they might call home.

title: Lyrical Readings
description: Yeats, Pound, and Eliot. By M. L. Rosenthal. 224 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $10.95.

title: Sandra Post, With 211, Leads by a Shot
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 1JoAnne Canner, who had a 66 yesterday, took an 11 on the par4, 397yard third hole today on her way to a 79 today in the third round of a $240,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association tournament.

title: Madame Rosa in Charge
description: WITH Emile Ajar, we are, thank goodness, far from the New Novel. One thinks of Saroyan rather than Sarraute, of Aigren rather than RobbeGrillet  for that matter, of Zola rather than Proust. In short, a good read and a good cry, if you're so inclined. And something more: a tour de force on several levels.

title: Petraglia, Starting Fifth, Wins L.I. Bowling Final
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 1Johnny Petraglia, a Brooklynborn Staten Islander, advanced from fifth place to the championship of the $70,000 Long Island open pro bowling tournament today at the Garden City Bowl. He defeated Jeff Mattingly, of Tacoma, Wash., 197177 in the final game, which turned out to be almost an anticlimax.

title: DINING OUT Morristown: Lovely to Look At
description: THE GREENHOUSE, which is appropriate in name and decor to the seat of the state's annual Flower and Garden Show in Morristown, is typical of many small new restaurants that are lovely to look at. If only the food were as delightful as the atmosphere.

title: Author's Query
description: For a book on T.S. Eliot's The Criterion, the quarterly review he edited from 1922 to 1939, I would appreciate letters or personal reminiscences. I welcome responses from contributors to The Criterion or editors and staff from other magazines.

title: Around the Nation
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 1 (AP)Quakers participating in a regional meeting here have endorsed the proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution, something they thought they did 55 years ago when a Quaker wrote it.

title: ART
description: AS museum habitus will have noticed, collectors often like to remain incognito when lending their art  for reasons that may or may not include modesty. Still, it is unusual to see an entire show that has been lent anonymously, as is the case with The Eye of the Collector: Contemporary Art, at the Stamford Museum and Nature Center (through May 21).

title: Carter's Aid Plan Mirrors State's Own
description: TRENTON IT is no accident that President Carter's plan to revise and enlarge Federal aid to distressed cities fits New Jersey like a glove.

title: CHESS
description: In the 1934 World Championship match, the challenger, Efim Bogolyubov, tried the gambit 1 PQ4, PQ9; 2 PQB4, PxP; 3 NKB3, NKB3; 4 NB3. PQR3; 5 PK4 against the great Alexander Alekhine, who rebuffed it savagely and won. Afterward, Alekhine described White's gambit move, 5 PK9 (instead of 5 PQR4), as an adventure which only one who has nothing to lose can undertake.

title: I stayed in an English Manor House and Took a Couse
description: Anyone for calligraphy or cornhusk dolls, ornithology or astro navigation? How about Buckinghamshire lacemakling or lifesaving strategies for stressf These are samplings of more than 1,000 short residential courses that are taught in Britain and listed in an 80page calendar published twice a year by Britain's National Institute of Adult Education.

title: POLITICS
description: While numerous Democrats and Republicans maneuver for the nomination to succeed Representative Otis G. Pike in Suffolk's First Congressional District, the strong bargaining hand of the Conservative Party is evident in the behindthescenes maneuvering over a possible RepublicanConservative coalition.

title: COOKBOOKS
description: FOOD FOR THOUGHT

title: A.M.C. HOPES TO SELL RENAULTS THIS FALL
description: SOUTHFIELD. Mich., April 1Officials of the American Motors Corporation said today that they hoped to begin distributing the Frenchmade Renault automobile through A.M.C. dealers this fall and to start manufacturing one or more Renault models with its own vehicles as early as the model year 1980.

title: Susan Miller Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. J. Wade Miller of New York and Ogunquit, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter Susan Elizabeth Miller, to Jeffrey Michael Werthan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Werthan of Bergenfield, N. J. Miss Miller and her fianc, who are students at the Boston University School of Law, plan to be married next August.

title: FOOD
description: THERE is very little that a gourmet cook could ask for and not find at Cooktique, 9 Railroad Avenue, Tenafly. The reason it is stocked so carefully is that Sylvia Lehrer, who operates the venture with her husband, Fred, is herself a gourmet cook.

title: Nigerian Students Protest
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, April 1 (Agence FrancePresse)Students from the universities of Ibadan and Ife staged a combined demonstration in Ibadan today to protest President Carter's visit to Nigeria. They carried placards blaming American investments and arms for keeping white minority governments in power in southern Africa.

title: Pupil, Teacher Dance at Pace
description: Dancers are students all of their lives. The mirror, the open floor, the insistent demands are an ongoing accompaniment, and the teacherpupil relationship in dance can be a peculiarly exhilarating one. That it is also a symbiotic relationship was touchingly illustrated in a concert by Kelly Hogan and Linda Lee McAndrew at Pace University's Schimmel Center on Friday.

title: Wadi Haddad, Palestinian Hijacking Strategist, Dies
description: Dr. Wadi Haddad, the strategist behind the Palestinian guerrilla movement's hijacking of airliners and a shadowy figure linked to international terrorist groups, has died of cancer in a hospital in East Germany, the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine announced in Lebanon yesterday.

title: Accuser of Chicago Mayor Will Run
description: CHICAGO, April 1Just when a special committee of the City Council thought it had pretty much laid to rest charges that Mayor Michael A. Bilandic had greased the way for a taxi fare increase last summer, Jane Byrne came back from her honeymoon and stirred the whole thing up again.

title: INTERVIEW
description: CRESTWOOD IN her brown leather briefcase, along with legal documents, her house keys and an appointment book, Isabella M. Pernicone has a small library of published materials on abortion. Stored in her head are memories of her 22year fight against abortion.

title: SAFEGUARDS URGED ON MENTAL PATIENTS
description: An investigation of 10 suspicious deaths of mentally ill persons living in private homes for adults in Brooklyn has disclosed that six committed suicide, a seventh apparently committed suicide and the other three died of pneumoniarelated causes.

title: $1 MILLION IN CUTS URGED FOR HEALTH DEPARTMENT
description: A task force of social service executives has suggested $1,045,000 in possible Health Department budegt cuts, while recommending services that should get department priority. The group expressed regret that lifeenhancing services have been almost totally eliminated in the city's budget crisis since 1975.

title: By Bike on the Malay Coast
description: The easiest and most scenic way to begin a bicycle tour of the Orient is to ride up the east coast of the Malay Peninsula from Singapore as far as the Thai border. Most of the 600milelong paved highway follows the whitebeach coastline of the South China Sea, offering yearround swimming and a chance to watch giant leatherback turtles clam ber ashore to deposit eggs in the sand. Since it passes through few important towns (Kuantan, Kuala Trengganu and Kota Baru are the best known), traffic is light and the localities retain some of their traditional activities such as topspinning competitions, shadowplay performances and batik and silver manufacture.

title: Israelis Rally to Urge Return of Land to Arabs
description: TEL AVIV, April 1About 25,000 Israelis rallied outside City Hall here tonight in favor of Israel's return of land to the Arabs as a way of achieving peace.

title: INTERVIEW From the Classroom to the Courtroom
description: NEW HAVEN IN retrospect, my life looks wellplanned. But really things just happen, said Ellen Ash Peters, whose appointment to the State Supreme Court was confirmed a few days ago by the General Assembly.

title: DINING OUT
description: NORWALK CHINESE chow hounds will find the twoyearold Mandarin Inn a welcome addition to the southern Connecticut scene. This pleasant restaurant on the Post Road near Bradlees proclaims its specialties to be Pekingstyle and Szechuanstyle cooking. Several visits suggest it is more comfortable with Peking dishes.

title: POLITICS
description: WHITE PLAINS INn a highly unusual public display of differences between top officials of the same party, Samuel G. Fredman, the county Democratic leader, has objected strenuously to an appointment made by Alfred B. DelBello, the County Executive, to a top post in his administration.

title: Farmland Bill May Add Up to More Losses Than Gains
description: THE Connecticut General Assembly seems destined to enact legislation this session that will set up an initial $5 million program to buy development rights from owners of farmland. The proposal, HB 5051, reflects the finding of the Governor's Task Force for the Preservation of Agricultural Land, namely, that Connecticut should preserve 325,000 acres of the state's remaining 500,000 acres of farmland by purchasing development rights.

title: Big PAF Benefit Is Drawing Big Talent
description: THE last time that Peter, Paul and Mary appeared as a trio, it was politics  the 1972 McGovern campaign  that brought the folk singers together. Next Sunday, when they star at the Nassau Coliseum, the cause will be cultural. The Performing Arts Foundation, which operates the PAF Playhouse in Huntington Station and an extensive Islandwide artsineducation program, will benefit from the group's latest excursion into togetherness.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: Principals Now Have Got The Score on Testing

title: McNamara on The Largest Issue: World Economy
description: Congressional criticisms of the World Bank's operations have been growing. The grounds range from human rights concerns to protectionist impulses to demands that the bank be subjected to closer Congressional control. The Carter Administration, worried about the implications for restricting the bank's activities. has begun jawboning Congress.

title: Is the mater Safe? A Question of Health
description: A story is told of a group of middleaged American tourists who were having breakfast in a hotel in Calcutta. One of them complained that she had not slept all night because of diarrhea. Didn't you take your Lomotil? a companion asked, referring to a commonly prescribed antidiarrheal medicine. Well, I was going to, the ailing woman replied, but I needed something to swallow it with, and I was afraid to drink the water.

title: Bertram Ross Dancers Appearing at the Theater Lab
description: The Beriram Ross Dance Company, which performs this afternoon and tonight, offered a more unusual program than expected Friday night at the American Theater Laboratory, 219 West 19th Street.

title: LEARNING TO BE YOUR OWN M.D.
description: The last time Jenny A., age 4, woke up with a croupy cough, her mother. Claire, whipped out her trusty stethoscope ($5 from Sears, Roebuck & Company) and put the diaphragm to Jenny's chest. Claire detected the clear rattle of bronchitis in her daughter's lungs, phoned their family physician and discussed the case with him. The doctor asked Claire about fever, swollen glands, color of sputum and pulse rate, then prescribed a decongestant and an antibiotic. Because he himself had taught Claire how to examine her daughter the first time Jenny came down with bronchitis, he confidently phoned a local pharmacy and ordered the necessary medications to be delivered to Jenny's bedside. Call me in a week, he told Claire, and bring her in in two or three days if she doesn't better.

title: Everything They Were Afraid to Ask
description: DARIEN LOUISE KOLB believes that sex education belongs in the home her home. Mrs. Kolb, a former Utica, N.Y., school teacher and now a Darien mother of three, has researched and prepared what she calls a course in awareness.

title: CAMERA
description: Ask a photo contest judge what type of picture is most often submitted, and the answer is very likely to be the scenic. That word covers a lot of ground (pun intended), including as it does landscapes, seascapes, and cityscapes, plus details from all those categories. The reason, of course, is that the visual appeal of these forms is universal. When we're traveling, most of us are not satisfied with merely buying a handful of slides or postcards to show where we've beennot that you can't find a decent shot of the Roman Forum or an Hawaiian volcano erupting, but slipping purchased slides into one's home showing makes many people uncomfortable.

title: Goolagong, Navratilova Reach Final at Oakland
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 1By winning the first set of her match with Virginia Wade tonight, 60, Evonne Goolagong advanced to the Virginia Slims championship final against Martina Navratilova, to be played tomorrow. Miss Goolagong went on to win the match, 60, 76.

title: Tibetan Captures Honors in Chicago
description: CHICAGO, April 1Silver balloons rose from a ringside concession and cheers went up from a crowd of thousands tonight at the International Kennel Club of Chicago's dog show in the Amphitheatre as Ch. Kontan's Shazan BuTsa Lhor, a Tibetan terrier, was presented a 65th nonsporting group rosette.

title: Bus Company Serving 3 Counties In Jersey Is Struck by Its Drivers
description: ELMWOOD PARK, N. J., April 1 (UPI)Bus drivers and maintenance workers today struck the Manhattan Transit Company, which serves 20,000 riders in Bergen, Hudson and Passaic Counties.

title: The Official National League Baseball. Schedule for the 1978 Season
description: *Night game. (2) Double header. (TN) Twllight-nlgh double header.

title: For the Eager, April Can Be Tricky
description: THERE'S SO much garden work to do in April  planting, transplanting, sowing seeds, feeding trees, shrubs, perennials, hardy bulbs and lawns, no wonder eager gardeners are likely to rush out on the first warm sunny day and do a great cleanup job. And. alone with broken branches and other clutter left over from winter storms, you should remove all the protective winter mulch that you so carefully applied last autumn, right? Well no, not really.

title: Martin Filler Fiance Of Rosemarie Bletter
description: RosemarieHaag Bletter. an author and Martin Myles Filler, an associate editor of Progressive Architecture magazine, published by Reinhold publications Company in Stamford. Conn., will be married June 3 in St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University.

title: David Ermer to Wed Lyn Feinsilber June 4
description: The engagement of Lyn Feinsilber to David M. Ermer, son of Mr. and Mrs. John K. Ermer of East Haven, Conn., has been announced by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jacob Feinsilber of Trenton, N.J.

title: Dtente Has Suffered a Few Cuts and Abrasions
description: MOSCOW  The United States and the Soviet Union still distrust and fear each other so thoroughly that it may be time to ask just what they have achieved in the relationship known as dtente and what they can realistically expect in the way of cooperation and conflict with each other.

title: Franz Beckenbauer Takes the Torch
description: For the Cosmos, life after Pele begins today. Franz Beckenbauer is the soccer player America will look to now. And it is a tribute to soccer's rising sophistication in America that it no longer requires a scorer to spark the public's imagination, that Franz Beckenbauer's subtle artistry as a midfielder will be understood and appredated. Giorgio Chlnaglia, Steve Hunt and Dennis Tueart will score more goals for the Cosmos, but Franz Beckenbauer will do more things, beginning today in their North American Soccer League opener at Giants Stadium against the Fort Lauderdale Strikers. In the ceremonies, Pele will be there to pass the torch, but Franz Beckenbauer will accept it somewhat reluctantly.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: Lou Howard is right (What the Island Owes to One Man's Vision, Opinion Page, March 5] that it's high time the people of Nassau and Suffolk took occasion to say thanks to Bob Moses, whose creative leadership saved Jones Beach from the fate of Coney Island, Atlantic City, Miami Beach, Waikiki and the French Riviera.

title: Washington Crew Beats Penn to Take Copley Cup
description: SAN DIEGO, April 1The University of Washington's heavyweight varsity eight prevented a Pennsylvania sweep of the sixth annual San Diego Crew Classic today by defeating the Quakers in the final. race of the day.

title: Alydar Triumphs in Florida Derby
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., April 1Alydar's credibility as a Triple Crown contender remained intact today at Gulfstream Park as he won the $150,000 Florida Derby in nearrecord time.

title: A Talk With Teddy Kollek
description: JERUSALEM Mayor Teddy Kollek was showing a visitor his collection of historic maps of Jerusalem. The visitor inquired about some Roman antiquities that looked like dominoes lying on top of the map case. Not dominoes exactly, Mr. Kollek said, fingering the white bone rectangles, but some sort of game Roman soldiers played in the first and second centuries.

title: In an Age of Nations, Tribalism Still Counts
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa  Alfred Kauraisa, an unemployed garage hand, dragged on a cigarette as he looked out across the the bleak landscape of Katutura township, the black ghetto outside this territorial capital. They'll kill us all, he said, referring to the dominant Ovambo tribe, who account for 390,000 of the territory's 850,000 inhabitants. If they take the government, we will disappear.

title: Bitter Over Erosion, Farmers Along the Ohio River Sue Engineer Corps
description: LEAVENWORTH, IND.As an icy wind whipped between the bluffs, Jim Cole stood at the edge of his land at Mile 663 of the Ohio River and pointed across the claycolored water to the opposite bank a halfmile away.

title: Mums Are Easy To Grow From Seed
description: Several years ago seed catalogues offered seed of chrysanthemum Autumn Glory, the first Fl hybrid cushion mum that stays dwarf. We tried it and liked it. The plants were only eight to 14 inches tall with a spread of 15 to 18 inches.

title: BRIDGE
description: Freedom of information has been an integral part of bridge long before it became a political issue. Any agreements you have with your partner, whether they concern bidding, leads or defensive signaling, your opponents are entitled to know about.

title: Kim Hamilton Is Married
description: Kim Hamilton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon C. Hamilton of New York and East Hampton, L. I., was married yesterday in St. James' Episcopal Church to John Frederick Gottshall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Gottshall of Boyertown, Pa. The Rev. William Howard Melish, assisted by the Rev. Carol Anderson, performed the ceremony. A reception was held at the Cosmopolitan Club.

title: Islanders Beat Capitals On Goal in Last 5 Seconds
description: UNIONDALE, L.I., April 1Feeling the pressure of their stretch run in the National Hockey League race, the Islanders trailed the Washington Capitals by a goal tonight with only 8 minutes left to. play. Also under big pressure to score 50 goals in his first year, Mike Bossy had been stalled at 49 for six games.

title: Newspapers Appear Again in London After Settlement of Pay Disputes
description: LONDON, April 1 (Reuters)Pay disputes that have deprived Londoners of national newspapers for the last week were settled today.

title: Cynthia Kybal Plans Wedding
description: Elba Gmez del Rey de Kybal of Washington and Buenos Aires has made known the engagement of her daughter, Cynthia Vera Kybal, to Byron Alexander Grant, son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Grant of Oyster Bay, L.I., and Boston.

title: Demand for Exotic Birds as Pets Is Found Threatening Some Species
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP)A hundred million wild birds are being trapped each year to satisfy the growing worldwide craze for exotic household pets, pushing several of the most popular and costly species toward extinction, according to a private study.

title: Marriage Announcement 7 -- No Title
description: Engagements

title: Oh Opens With Grand Slam
description: TOKYO, April 1 (AP)Sadaharu Oh hit a basesloaded home run in the opening game of the 1978 Japanese professional baseball season today. The 38yearold lefthanded first baseman's grand slam, the 757th homer of his career, droppd into the rightfield bleachers of Tokyo's Korakuen Stadium in the bottom of the third inning. The homer helped the defending Central League champion Yomiuri Giants beat the Hanshin Tigers, 76, before 50,000 fans.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: By Joseph F. Goodavage. 302 pp. New York: Simon and Schuster. $10.

title: A Shot of Prevention
description: IN 1969 the Center for Disease Control, with the advice of the National Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices, began a campaign to immunize all children in the country against rubella (sometimes called German measles). This campaign came in response to a massive epidemic in 1964 and 1965 that left 20,000 infants in the United States with congenital rubella, a disease that causes deformities, retardation and even death in infants whose mothers acquire rubella during pregnancy.

title: Life in Beirut  Neither Peace nor War
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 1Rich and poor apartment dwellers alike dare not sneak out for a cup of coffee in Beirut these days, because if they leave their homes vacant for even 10 minutes they risk intrusion by charitable gunmen helping to settle some of the 250,000 refugees front southern Lebanon.

title: Teresa J. Ernst Is Wed To William Waterman
description: Teresa Jane Ernst, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank H. Ernst of Buffalo, was married at noon yesterday to Wliliam McCormack Waterman, son of Mrs. Allen Greenough of North Salem, N. Y., and Rodney H. Waterman of St. Petersbure. Fla.

title: It's Showtime For Youngsters
description: NEW BRUNSWICK THEY fracture fairy tales, interrupt a play to talk to the children in the audience and introduce themselves (Hi, I'm your king).

title: Picture Credits
description: ISTEPHEN SHORE; NICKOLAS MURAY, PRAKAPAS GALLERY/INTERNATIONAL MUSEUM OF PHOTOGRAPHY, ROCHESTER

title: Los Angeles Times Names Editor
description: LOS ANGELES, April 1 (AP)George Cotliar, senior assistant managing editor of The Los Angeles Times, has been named managing editor effective today, according to William Thomas, executive vice president and editor. Mr. Cotliar, 46 years old, will replace Frank Haven, who is retiring after serving as managing editor for 17 of his 37 years with the newspaper.

title: Milwaukee Defends  Its Charging Just $1 a Year for Stadium Lease
description: MILWAUKEE (UPI)Two weeks ago Senator William Proxmire, the chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, chastised New York City for permitting a knuckleheaded contract with the New York Yankees that brought in little or no rent for the use of Yankee Stadium in recent years.

title: Visitors to U.S. Given Longer Time to Stay
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP)The Immigration and Naturalization Service has changed its rules to allow tourists and other visitors to the United States to stay longer.

title: Radio
description: 66:30 A.M., WNBC: Focus on Youth. Benjamin Hooks, guest.

title: Cable TV: It Has to Go Through Channels
description: CABLE television is making its way across southern Westchester through forests of red tape. The wire that carries as many as three dozen channels, including television stations from other cities and the highindemand Home Box Office channel of movies and sports, will hook onto thousands homes in the county this year and next. But many Westchester residents will have wait several years more, perhaps until 1981 or even longer, for access to the cable.

title: State Officials Say Carter Plan Is a Start in Helping Cities
description: FOR Connecticut's major cities, the real importance of President Carter's proposed urban policy may not be in how many extra Federal dollars may eventually trickle down from Washington to places like Bridgeport, Hartford and Waterbury.

title: Deaths
description: FABERHelen C.,of Miami,Fla. (formerly of Hunt ington).On March 31, 1978. Beloved wife of Richard C. Devoted mother of Nina Cashin, Richard C.,Jr., and Gerard E. Also survived by 6 grandchildren. Reposing at A.L. Jacobsen Funeral Home, Inc.. 1380 New York Ave, Huntington Station, L.I. Mass of Christian Burial Tuesday, 9:45 A.M. at St. Patrick's R.C. Church, Huntington. Interment Mount St. Mary's Cemetery. Visitation 2.5, 7.10 P.M. Donations to American Cancer Society appreciated.

title: Surf Beat Timbers, 10
description: ANAHEIM, April 1 (AP)  Danny Counce scored in the 79th minute to give the California Surf a 1.0 victory over the Portland Timbers in a North American Soccer League opener last night. Steve Moyers assisted on Counce's goal.

title: Fukuda Lost More Than Just an Airport
description: NARITA, Japan  More than airport instruments were damaged when radical youths rammed their way into the New Tokyo International Airport last week. Prestige and face also took a beating, and in Asia, they are far more important, and harder to repair. The Prime Minister, Takeo Fukuda, had formally announced the opening to a world that the Japanese believe is always watchine. He couldn't deliver.

title: GREAT HOLE FOUND IN A DISTANT GALAXY
description: Astronomers have found what they believe may be a black hole containing five billion times more material than that forming the sun. It is in the core of the galaxy known as Messier 87, or M87, an assemblage of several hundred billion stars in the constellation Virgo.

title: Deaths
description: HATCHERRodney Neville. Age 69, Darien Conn., died of cancer on March 26. Survived by wife,Katherine, sister Mrs Gertrude Parker. Memorial service Saturday. April 29 at 11 :00 A.M. West Norwalk Chapel, West Norwalk Road, Darien, Conn. Family requests no flowers.

title: Prescription Law Yet to Be Fulfilled
description: New York State's new law requiring pharmacies to make much more use of cheaper drugs when they fill prescriptions went into effect yesterdaysort of.

title: Tour Earnings
Mr. Fried's Journey
description: THIS is the age of selfexposure. The celebrity ap ears on a television talk show to broadcast secrets he formerly whispered into his psychoanalyst's ear. The journalist in his early 30's rushes publish his autobiography, revealing all. The novelist interrupts his story to remind the reader that he could have writinn a very different ending to the tale. Now we have tht. ultimate in selfdisclosure, a young historian's account of his emotions and personal experiences while thinking about a book he decided not write.

title: Cable TV Grows in Northern Jersey
description: CABLE television is sweeping Northern New Jersey as fast as governmental red tape and plant construction will allow, and informed estimates are that, by the fall of 1979, virtually all Jerseyans in the New York metropolitan area will, have access to televisionbywire.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, APRIL 2, 1978

title: Births.
description: Birnbaum

title: Why Carter Means Business in Helping the Cities
description: A small group of businessmen and bankers were discussing economic development in New York City over lunch recently, arguing about whether they would put any more productive facilities into the decaying city. The talk turned quickly toward crime, and to the problem of stealing in plants.

title: Physician Admits Fraud
description: Dr. Jerome Rotstein, a physician from Hollywood, Fla., has pleaded guilty in, Manhattan to a Federal charge of submitting false statements regarding clinical research that he was conducting on drugs, for treating rheumatism and arthritis. Raymond A. Levites, an assistant United States Attorney, said Dr. Rotstein admitted he had not performed some of the research that he supposedly carried out for three pharmaceutical companies. The doctor could face up to five years in prison and a $10,000 fine when he is sentenced on June 16.

title: Farmers Seek Protection fora Valuable Crop: Land
description: DURHAM

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Welcome to the Club, Bud
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SPORTS
description: New Brunswick THERE was always a cold, indestructible air about Frank Burns, an impression that somehow he was cast in iron. The fact that Rutgers University owned the nation's longest winning streak in college football only heightened the aura around Burns, the school's head coach.

title: Newspaper Delivery Drivers End Short Walkout in St. Louis Area
description: ST. LOUIS, April 1 (UPI)Newspaper delivery drivers ended a short strike today after a Federal judge ordered them to resume distribution of The St. Louis PostDispatch.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
