description: SLEEP IT OFF, LADY, by Jean Rhys. (Popular, $1.95.) The novels of Jean Rhys were among the most gratifying literary rediscoveries of the 1960's. In these 16 short pieces, an written during the last few years but set in 1890 Dominica, 1910 London and 1920 Paris, she displays the quick, astonishing strokes of a gifted shortstory writer.

title: The Past Recaptured: Childhood Summers At Westport Point
description: A rare balmy day in March offered relief from winter's cabin fever. It made me think of green grass and warm breeies and sunny beaches. The yellowwhite sands of my childhood beach at Westport Point, a fishing village just south of New Bedford, Mass., filled my mind, and I wondered, Why not go back and see if it's still there?

title: Viennese Performance Calendar
description: The Spanish Riding School occupies a small complex of buildings in the center of Vienna, in and adjacent to the Hofburg, once the imperial palace. The Lippizan stallions perform in the socalled Winter Riding School, a handsome baroque building designed by Fischer von Erlacht ; their stables are directly across a narrow street on the ground floor of a building called the Stallburg. When the horses are led from one building to another before a performance, traffic backs up until all are safely across.

title: Paying Jobs Luring Volunteer Workers
description: FRED MILES takes delinquent youths bowling on Saturdays. Nancy Moore goes camping with a White Plains Girl Scout troop. Earnest Allen is a director for the Phelps Memorial Hospital. Joan and Eric Polk teach preschoolers rhythmic exercises at Greenberg's Union Day Care Center.

title: Legislature: Resisting Revolution
description: JUST before last fall's general election, Senator Matthew Feldman, Democrat of Teaneck, proudly described in this space a quiet revolution in the Legislature. He noted that major improvements have made the Legislative branch of government capable of fulfilling its vital public responsibilities.

title: Women's Role in Sailing: Equality Is a Long Way Off
description: AROUND the turn of the century, when hardy men sailed the squareriggers around the oceans, it was considered had luck for a woman to step aboard a boat. Bad luck, obviously, is a matter of definition. And today the only misfortune involved is in the eyes of male opponents who have been forced sometimes to take a hack seat to leading women skippers.

title: Barbara Levy Sets Nuptials
description: Barbara Ellen Levy, assistant controller for financial planning in the new division of CBS Inc. in New York, plans to be married June 4 to Mark Andrew Landes, a vice president of William Adams, the china, crystal and silverplate importing division of Sigma Marketing Systems Inc.

title: Fall Fashion Preview
description: PARIS: Starting tomorrow, and continuing for 10 arduous days, the fashion professionals of the world will make one of their twice yearly pilgrimages to this city, still considered the mecca of fashion. This time, what they will see, in the clothes designed for next fall, is the heavy influence of politics. The recent French legislative elections jolted the imperturbable French into a new appreciation of themselves and their lives. Fashion designers are always quick to pick up on the undercurrents in society and this year is no exception. In the exclusive previews that the top Paris designers gave The New York Times Magazine, it quickly became clear that each collection carried its subliminal message, from revolution to conservatism, economic upheaval to ecological survival.

title: Food
description: There are times when, for one reason or another, a recipe for which we feel a special enthusiasm may go unnoticed or be passed over lightly by a multitude of readers, even the most faithful. In such cases, we feel happily obliged to reprint such recipes to give them the prominence we feel is their due. The recipe on this page is a case in point. It is a delectable, elegant dessert which was served us in the home of Mr. and Mrs. Donn Chappellet, owners of the Chappellet Vineyards in the Napa Valley. Molly Chappellet refers to it as a forgetit meringue torte for the simple reason that you place meringue in a very hot oven and turn the oven off. Forget it overnight. When the meringue comes from the oven, it looks like a disaster. But once unmolded and decorated all over with whipped cream and bits of crumbled meringue crust, the torte is an irresistible beauty.

title: What's Doing in OTTAWA
description: QUEEN'S CHOICE  When Queen Victoria selected the obscure logging town of Ottawa to be the capital of the then Province of Canada back in 1857, there were those who swore that she had made the choice by closing her eyes and jabbing a pin into a map. A subArctic lumber village converted by royal mandate into a political cockpit, sneered visiting English writer.

title: Tomatoes: Making
description: TOMATO lovers will no doubt be jubilant to hear that American agriculture is about to launch a square tomato. With a thicker skin than the current storesold varieties, more solid flesh and less pulp, it can be machinepicked greener and packed much more tightly in its plastic tray, reducing storage and shipping costs.

title: 7 Temples Celebrate Life at Israeli Fair
description: L'CHAIM  a salute to the good life, Israelistyle  is the theme of the Israeli Fair being celebrated today and tomorrow at the County Center in White Plains.

title: Many Transit Workers Voice Disappointment on Pact
description: Morgan McMahon stepped out of his motorman's cab on the IRT Flushing line train at Times Square yesterday afternoon onto the busy platform.

title: Sunday Observer
description: Financial news item: After 14 months in office, President Carter has still failed to restore business confidence.

title: LEADERS SEEK AN END TO BUDGET DEADLOCK
description: ALBANY, April 1Legislative leaders were seeking a way today to separate the highly charged issue of state Medicaid funding of abortions for the poor from the state's localaid budget, in an effort to resolve a deadlock over the $7.2 billion appropriation.

title: The Paradox Of Ibsen: Famous But Unknown
description: An artist may be world famous and still remain unknown. Henrik Ibsen, who was born 150 years ago (March 20, 1828), is a case in point. After years of poverty and struggle it could be said of him, as his English biographer, Michael Meyer, does, Drama owes more to him than to any other dramatist since Shakespeare. Success has its price. With the passing of the years, the man thus celebrated becomes a byword and a bore: A dust of cliches encrusts and defaces the real person. That is what has happened with Ibsen.

title: For Some Sailors, Ice Is Thicker Than Water
description: ESSEX NEVER ask a frostbite sailor why he wants to brave the worst winter weather to race in a small boat that provides little cover from the blowing winds and freezing water and is sometimes built so that it capsizes quite easily. He won't understand the question. He does it because it's there.

title: Poll Finds Most Favor Auto Checks
description: Paterson DESPITE the tedium of long waits while having their automobiles checked annually, most New Jersey motorists favor continuation of the inspection system, according to a survey just completed by the North Jersey Automobile Club.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly stated last Sunday that national party organizations are allowed to spend $330,000 for individual Congressional candidates. Up to $30,000 in national party expenditures are allowed for a Congressional candid date, and an additional $20,000 may be transferred by the national party to a state party, for the same candidate.

title: F.B.I. Is Reported to Have Interviewed President on Rep. Eilberg's Call About Marston
description: WASHINGTON, April 1The Federal Bureau of Investigation has interviewed President Carter as a witness in an investigation into whether efforts to unseat a United States Attorney in Philadelphia constituted an obstruction of justice, Justice Department sources said today.

title: European Arms Exports Growing
description: PARIS, April 1During the year since President Carter called for a reduction in the trade in conventional arms, Western European countries have increased their exports of armaments and, in some cases, are rushing to fill the gap in places where the United States has sought to limit its sales.

title: Carey Is Drawn Into Tristate Fight
description: AS electionyear politicking begins to accelerate, Long Island Republican leaders are clashing with Governor Carey on the sensitive issue of who should control local distribution of Federal funds  the Tristate Regional Planning Commission or Long Islanders themselves.

title: All Those Riches in the Sea
description: WE SHOULD, of course, take all precautions to protect our beaches and the quality of our water, but I must say that these are great times. We have got over the last hurdle: The United States Supreme Court says we can search for oil and gas off our coast.

title: All Washington's Gone AVOL . . . Voluntarily
description: Of nothing are Americans more aware than the importance of organization. With it, everything is possible; without it, nothing happens and certainly not in Washington. Accordingly, the emergence of AVOL in the nation's capital is a development of the utmost importance in our time.

title: Sponges to Grow
description: All natural sponges come from the sea, right? Not true. An entirely natural sponge plant grows on terra firma. The luffa (Luffa aegyptiaca) sometimes spelled loofah and nicknamed dishcloth gourd may be started from seeds and grown similarly to cucumbers and squash.

title: On the Track of Indian Dances
description: What do you want for your next birthday? I asked my 6yearold grandson across 3,000 miles of telephone relays to San Francisco.

title: E.D.A., Quiet Lender of Last Resort
description: WASHINGTON  President Carter's proposed National Development Bank, the core of his package to revitalize distressed areas, both urban and rural, has its prototype in a littleknown businessloan program that the Commerce Department's Economic Development Administration has run as a lender of last resort for businesses in areas of high unemployment..

title: Deaths
description: Alexander, A.

title: MINERS UNION GROUP MEETS IN OUTSTMILLER MOVEMENT
description: GALLIPOLIS, Ohio, April 1 (AP)A group of United Mine Workers met here today to try to start a movement that they hope will result in the ouster of the union's president, Arnold R. Miller.

title: Quake Shakes San Bernardino
description: REDLANDS, Calif., April 1 (UPI)An earthquake registering 4.1 on the Richter scale shook a mountainous section of San Bernardino County this morning. The seismology laboratory at the California Institute of Technology said the quake struck at 2:52 A.M. The police said they had some phone calls but no damage was reported.

title: WASHINGTON REPORT
description: WASHINGTON The Supreme Court has on its doorstep a case that threatens as much divisiveness for the construction industry as the Bakke case has brought to higher education.

title: MONET AND HIS GARDENS
description: Though Claude Monet grew up by the sea (at Le Havre) and was an inveterate traveler, he belonged to one place, Giverny. For a halfdozen years he had explored up and down the Seine, looking for a place with the right combination of elements: water, fields, interesting effects of light. When he discovered Giverny he was elated. Once settled, he wrote the dealer DurandRuel, I hope to produce masterpieces, because I like the countryside very much.

title: 10 Hurt as Circus Bleachers Fall
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif., April 1 (UPI) Bleachers with more than 90 persons sitting on them collapsed before the opening performance of the Circus Vargas last night, injuring 10 persons. The performance went on after the accident in the 4.500seat tent.

title: Berle Names Legal Aide
description: ALBANY. April 1 (UPI)Philip Gillen of Srencertown. N.Y., has been appointed general counsel for the state's Departmeat of Envircnment al Conservation, Commissioner Peter A. A. Berle announced. The 30yearold Columbia County resident has been serving as compliance counsel For the department since last June. His appointment to the $35,000ayear post is effective immediately.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: Most New York debut recitals are not often as polished and artistically accomplished as the one given by Steven Kimbrough on Monday night in Alice Tully Hall. But then, Mr. Knnbrough is hardly a debutante singer, for the baritone has been pursuinran active opera and concert career in Europe for the last eight years.

title: C. R. Tunnard Fiance Of Elizabeth Sullivan; June Wedding Is Set
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Ferree Sullivan to Christopher Russell Tunnard has been announced by Dr. and Mrs. James R. Sullivan of Buffalo, and Rose Hill, Ontario, parents of the future bride. Mr. Tunnard is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Christopher Tunnard of New Haven and Falls Village, Conn.

title: Miss Stanley Plans Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Justin Armstrong Stanley of Winnetka, Ill:, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Melinda Fletcher Stanley, to Lewis William Douglas Jr. of Los Angeles. He is a son of Mrs. Douglas of Tucson, Ariz., and the late Mr. Douglas, who served as Ambassador to the Court of St. James's from 1947 to 1952. The wedding is planned for July.

title: U.S. Assists Farming in Mali
description: BAMAKO, Mali, April 1 (Agenc?? FrancePresse)The United States has agreed to grant Mali 600 million Malian francs ($1.3 million) for a veterinary laboratory and rice production.

title: Trout Shun Opening of Fishing Season
description: BREWSTER, N.Y., April 1Rotting ice filled many of the coves of the Croton and Croton Falls Reservoirs, and patches of snow were visible in shady places, but crocuses were blooming in dooryards, willows were wearing the pale yellow of spring, and by noon the temperature was in the high 60's, one of the balmiest opening days for New York state trout fishermen in the last decade.

title: A Tidy Herb Corner for the Gourmet Gardener
description: THE PERFECT spot for an herb garden is a sunny site, facing south or east, sheltered by house walls, a fence or shrubs. The nearer the kitchen door, the better. In my seashore herb garden, shown in the planting diagram, the herbs are sheltered on two sides by house walls.

title: POLITICS
description: THIS is psychologicalwarfare time for Connecticut's gubernatorial candidates, and a time of confusion for an average voter trying to figure out who is ahead and what is going on.

title: Freighter With Marijuana Towed After Crew Tries to Burn Her
description: MIAMI, April 1 (AP)A Venezuelan freighter was under tow toward Miami today from the Caribbean after what the Coast Guard described as an unsuccessful attempt by crewmen to burn the ship and her 10ton cargo of marijuana.

title: Diane Nix. Nutritionist, Married to Michael Dennis
description: Diane Fisher Nix and Michael Laurence Dennis, both of Boulder, Colo., were married there yesterday at the home of John F. Nix, the brides's brother. The Rev. Homer Page, a Methodist minister. performed the ceremony.

title: Bank's Dog Show to Star Cede Higgens
description: Ch. Cede Higgens is billed for a return engagement in New York the week of April 1014.

title: ANTIQUES
description: This April is the month rare book collectors will undoubtedly talk about for years to come, so rich is the fare they will be offered at auctions and in book fairs.

title: STAGE VIEW
description: I think it was Oscar Hammerstein Sr. who said that there is no end to the number of people who will stay away from a bad show. Conversely, there's obviously no end to the number of people who will go again and again and again to a good one, sometimes including me. Having just returned from a stolen midwinter week's vacation, I thought it might be a good idea to touch home base, or get back in the swing of things, or pick up exactly where I left off, by returning to the returned Hello, Dolly! And so it turned out to be, on the double.

title: Notes: Tax Proposal Would Benefit Trails
description: If a proposal being pushed by the International Backpackers Association becomes law, America's outdoorsmen, 70 million strong and climbing, would be taxed on equipment purchases in order to pay for hiking trails.

title: MUSIC
description: LAST week I was telling you about some of the remarkable aggregations of highschool musicians performing in Connecticut, and I should have included word of the upcoming spring concert by the Greater Hartford Youth Chorale.

title: Patricia Linger Affianced
description: Mrs. Homer W, Linger of New Canaan, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Patricia Ann Linger, to Bennett E. Lawhorn, son of Mrs. Joseph W. Bear Jr. of Roanoke, Va., and Bethel E. Lawhorn of Richmond. The future bride is a daughter also of the late Mr. Linger.

title: Barbara B. Weyher Fiancee
description: Barbara Brandon Weyher, an aissociate with the New York law firm of Beekman & Bogue, and Lemuel Hardy Gibbons 3d, who is with the Wilson, N. C., law firm of Carr, Gibbons & Cozart, plan to be married Aug. 19 in Quogue, L. I.

title: Doctor Cites Slight Polio Risk Arising From Sabin Oral Vaccine
description: ATLANTA, April 1 (AP)Many of the few remaining cases of polio in the United States apparently resulted from the vaccine itself, Dr. John Z. SullivanBolyai, a physician from the national Center for Disease Control, says.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACE Equus, by Peter Shaffer. Thursday to Saturday at 8 P.M., next Sunday at 2. Through April 16. $5.50, except Saturday, $6.50, discounts for students and the elderly. Reservations. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, Rte.6.6281169.

title: Mets Lose Apodaca For Season
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 1Medical miseries continued to riddle the New York Mets today when Bob Apodaca, the team's allpurpose relief pitcher, tore a ligament in his right elbow and was lost for the season.

title: Dancin' Performer Injured
description: Ann Reinking, a leading performer in the new Broadway musical, Dancin', injured an ankle at the close of last night's performance hut the seriousness of the injury was not immediately known. According to Phil Friedman, the production stage manager, Miss Reinking had just finished her final dance of the evening, and the stage had blacked out, when she felt the injury. The performer was helped offstage hut, according to Mr, Friedman, was not hospitalized. It's probably a sprain, he said.

title: Eichelberger, Armstrong And Renner Tied at 211
description: GREENSBORO, N.C., April 1 (AP)Dave Eichelberger came from three shots off the pace with a scrambling 71 today and moved into a threeway tie for the lead at 211 in the windblown third round of the $240,000 Greater Greensboro open golf tournament.

title: The Official American League Baseball Schedule for the 1978 Season
description: April

title: Combating the Problem of Depression
description: AT first, Susan B. thought it was cabin fever. Too many snowy days in the house too long with too many children. Then came the sunshine; but the blue feeling remained. She was jittery and weepy. Her former husband, visiting the children for the weekend, suggested she see a psychiatrist.

title: Lobbyits in Albany Last Year Spent Record Sum of $4.3 Million
description: ALBANY, April 1A record sum of $4.3 million was spent by lobbyists here last year, according to Secretary of State Mario M. Cuomo. But Mr. Cuomo's report was incomplete because 25 employers of lobbyists failed to file information on their lobbying activities by the deadline of this month.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: Harrison, Scarsdale and Greenburgh, whose borders are contiguous with those of White Plains, can raise as much school tax monies [Schools Fear Court's Decision Means Cutbacks, Feb. 19] as their voters will allow, inasmuch as they are either Central School Districts or Union Free School Districts.

title: How a Dying Sport Was Revived in the Year 2000
description: After the baseball season in the year 1999, the owners of the 62 major league teams decided to call it quits because fans had stopped going to games.

title: PAUL IGNOTUS, A WRITER, OPPOSED NAZIS IN HUNGARY
description: LONDON, April 1 (AP)Paul Ignotus, a Hungarian writer who opposed Nazism in the 1930's and later was imprisoned by Hungary's Communist regime, died today in a London hospital. He was 76 years old.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Future Events
description: Thimble Winners

title: NUMISMATICS
description: Cartoon jibes on paper are bad enoughbut what if they are stamped onto metal to be handed around like a coin? That's the way it was in the days of Jack son and Van Buren, as explained in the standard work on such pieces: Hard Times Tokens, by Lyman Haynes Low, which has just been reprinted by Sanford Durst.

title: 141 Lucius Wins Rugged Grand National
description: LIVERPOOL, England, April 1 (AP)Lucius, a 14 to 1 shot, edged Sebastian V in a close finish today and won a roughandtumble Grand National steeplechase. Drumroan, a 501 shot, was third.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: Your article on trapping [Lure of the Woods Captures State's Trappers, March 12] by Walter D. Wetherell angered me as it must have angered many others who are dedicated to the welfare of animals.

title: Miss Johnson Wins College Fencing Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 1  Stacey Johnson of San Jose ,State won the National Intercollegiate Women's Fencing Association individual championship today at the University of Pennsylvania, and regained the title she had won in 1976.

title: A Case for Metal
description: When a collection of Italianmade clothes for men was shown recently at the WaldorfAstoria, the aluminum luggage used as props almost stole the show.

title: Carter Promises to Help Africans In War on Racism and Colonialism
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, April 1President Carter committed his Administration today to an Africa that is free from colonialism, racism and military interference by outside nations.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Tomorrow night will see a concert by Sousa's Band in Carnegie Hall. Well, not exactly Sousa's Band. But the young players of the Yale University Band will be wearing uniforms copied from those worn by Sousa's players. Keith Brion, the conductor, will be wearing a white wig and mustache, will be wielding an actual baton used by the great bandmaster, and will be attempting to copy Sousa's beat and mannerisms. The program will be a replica of an actual Sousa program, cut down somewhat from its original threehour length. And, inevitably, The Stars and Stripes Forever will end the program. It should be great fun.

title: Law Clerk Is Fiance Of Susan C. Whilton
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frederick W. Whilton of Warren, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Currie Whilton, to Filiberto Agusti, son of Mr. and Mrs. Filiberto Agusti of Danville, III. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Pleasure Boating: New York Lags
description: ALMOST every major city has a waterfront, and of all of them in the United States, which one has done the least in developing access to the water for recreational purposes? The answer, shamefully, is New York.

title: Pressure on Andretti in Grand Prix Race
description: LONG BEACH. Calif., April 1Mario Andretti has had his American dream so long now he is beginning to look as if he is not getting enough sleep.

title: Dairymen Vote to Tax Themselves To Promote New York Milk Sale
description: ALBANY, March 30New York State dairy farmers have voted to tax themselves $5.3 million a year for the next three years to promote the sale of milk to consumers.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: PEOPLE who live in ridiculously cold places, such as North Dakota, Ontario or Syracuse, N.Y.inhabitants of the Ultima Thule of our known worldspeak of their weather with the braggadocio of explorers or pioneers. They boast of having four seasonsJune, July. August and Winter.

title: State Unit Certifies Nurserymen
description: ACUSTOMER came to a nursery and said, Would you recommend a rhododendron maximum for a screen on a high windy hill? The nursery man on duty said, no. The customer, pleased with the answer, said, at last, I've found a place to shop.

title: 82 High Falls Short Of Record by Degree
description: The mercury hit 82 degrees in New York City at 2:45 P.M. yesterday, one degree below the record high temperature of 83 degrees, set in 1917.

title: Home Style
description: It's not exactly easy to find an acre of land complete with a generous portion of evergreen and larch on a private hill with a magnificent view and a landmarked lighthouse to call home  all within the limits of New York City. But it's not impossible either.

title: Lebanese Leader Says Arafat Vows to Honor Truce
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 1  Prime Minister Selim alHoss said today that Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian guerrilla leader, had assured him that the guerrillas would continue to observe a ceasefire in southern Lebanon, a confidencebuilding move that the Lebanese leader hopes will encourage thousands of refugees to return to to their homes.

title: Miss Milburn, L. B. Morris 3d To Be Married
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Devereux Milburn of Old Westbury, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Hinckley Milburn, to Lawrence Booker Morris 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Jr. of Darien, Conn.

title: SELECTION
description: THE following list was provided by Leo Tolstoy to a Petersburg publisher who had asked Tolstay and many other famous people for the books that had most influenced them. It was Tolstoy's idea to divide the list into phases of his life. The list was attached to a letter written from Yasnaya Polyana on Oct. 25, 1891 and appears in Tolstoy's Letters, edited by R. F. Christian, which will he published by Scribner's next month.

title: Deaths
description: BLAULou. Beloved brother of Israel, Emanuel, Edward and Pauline Cohen. Devoted brotherinlaw, uncle and great uncle. Funeral services at Norman L. Jetter Community Chapel, 4620 Ft. Hamilton Pkwy, Bklyn, at 12:00 Noon, Sunday, April 2.

title: 6 Great Snug Harbors on L.I.
description: IN WESTERN Long Island Sound, the north shore of Long Island is featured by peninsulas and deeply indented bays forming large bodies of sheltered salt water. These are great for sailing, swimming, beachcombing, fishing, picnicking, gunkholing. There are interesting towns, good seafood restaurants and fine cruising.

title: COST AT $97 MILLION
description: Transit Authority and union negotiators agreed eariy yesterday on a twoyear contract giving New York City subway and bus workers a 6 percent raise and other wage gains in a settlement that Mayor Koch said would save the 50cent fare through 1979.

title: Diane R. Murray, Nurse, Is Wed to Dr. Martin Nydick
description: Diane Ruth Murray, a head nurse at the New York HospitalCornell Medical Center, was married yesterday to Dr. Martin Nydick, a New York internist. Judge of Probate Robert Anstett of Westport, Conn., performed the ceremony at the Saugatuck Harbor Yacht Club in Westport.

title: Friend Of Poets
description: THIS book could have been called The Truth About Trelawny. William St. Clair, whose That Greece Might Still Be Free shocked a number of sentimental Grecophiles because of its frank portrayal of the mixed motives and performance of both Philhellenes and Greeks in the war for independence, has here laid to rest many legends concerning the eccentric Cornishman who boasted of his long intimacy with Shelley and Byron. He has dug deeply into all the factual evidence published and unpublished, and has exposed the fantasy and romancing with which Trelawny embroidered his experience. And he has done this without malice and with amusement and compassion.

title: Princeton to Offer The Magic Flute
description: PRINCETON LARGE opera productions are something of a rarity in New Jersey, even at those colleges where concert halls and orchestras are available. In recent years, only a few smallscale productiodt have taken place in the state, an exception being the performances staged by the New Jersey State Opera at Symphony Hall in Newark.

title: Reporter's. Notebook: Odd Moments From the Florida Season
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla.Summer, fall, winter, spring, the standard four seasons are just terms in the Farmer's Almanac here. Two seasons are all there are in south Floridabaseball and other. The baseball season lasts while the major league camps are open, from midFebruary through the first week in April. Everything else is other.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Editors Choice
description: THE HUMAN FACTOR, by Graham Greene. (Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) Masterful spy novel, in which character is central.

title: Cluett: It Shot an Arrow Into the Air
description: What better example of business survival than Cluett, Peabody & Company? Seemingly overnight, demand for its product  an elaborate and successful line of stiff, detachable shirt collars had dried up. Its survival at stake, Cluett responded by introducing the Arrow shirt  and invented Sanforized to make it work.

title: STAMPS
description: The contribution of dance to the nation's culture is being graphically underscored for Americans with a block of four new commemoratives, the first stamps ever put out by the United States in tribute to the dance.

title: James Halsey Dies; Former Chancellor Of U. of Bridgeport
description: Dr. James H. Halsey, chancellor emeritus and former president and chancellor of the University of Bridgeport, died Friday at the Park City Hospital in Bridgeport, Conn. He was 71 years old.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayOx Ridge Hunt Club, Middlesex Road, Darien, Conn. Children's, Junior and Local Working Hunters; Ponies, Equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: Landscape Architects: Designers and Then Some
description: NEW BRUNSWICK TIME WAS when the layman thought of landscape architects  if he thought of them at all, as people who designed gardens for the wealthy. That image, according to Professor Roy DeBoer who heads the Cook College landscape architecture program Rutgers University, still persists but is beginning to change as people become more concerned with the envilonment.

title: Judge Orders Company to Work On Missile Cruiser for the Navy
description: NORFOLK, Va., April I (AP)The Newport News Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company has been ordered to oatinue work on a halfbuilt nuclear guidedmissile cruiser for the Navy under terms similar to those agreed upon in the original contract.

title: 1,400 on QE2 to Visit China in '79 When She Docks There First Time
description: The largest single group of Western tourists to visit China since the Commufist takeover will arrive next March when the Queen Elizabeth 2 docks in Dairen, Manchuria, the Cunard Line announced last week.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: BRIDGEPORTPaintings and serigraphs by Jack Farkas, wood sculpture by Mario dal Fabbro, Tuesdays through Sundays, 2 to P.M. Museum of Art, Science and Industry, 4950 Park Ave. Phone 3723521.

title: Hofstra Lacrosse Victor
description: HEMPSTEAD, April 1Hofstra won its first game of the lacrosse season, after suffering three defeats, by beating Harvard, 10.9, today at John Cranford Adams Field. Bob Gilmartin's tiebreaking goal with two seconds left in the game was decisive. The goal was Gilmartin's fourth of the game.

title: A Planting Plan For a Shady Site
description: SHADE is often a nuisance and frustration to the suburban gardener. Plantings must be handled differently from those in sun. When this is understood and accepted. then success and pleasure result.

title: Vorster Criticizes Carter
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 1  Prime Minister John Vorster, anticipating the criticism of South Africa in President Carter's speech in Lagos. Last night accused the President of attacking South Africa for alleged shortcomings in the field of human rights while ignoring practices that were similar or worse in other countries, including Nigeria.

title: Ways to Bridge The Industry Gap
description: TO a devoted Long Islander, the article When Big Companies Move, It's Not to L.I., published on Feb. 5, was painful reading, spotlighting as it did the fact that no Fortune 500 company has ever relocated here. But it may end the crying and dying and spur action to repair our negative image. I urge consideration of the following principal problems:

title: FILM VIEW
description: The man with the tape recorder stopped by the office for his quarterly report. He wasted no time with preliminaries.

title: Carter's Plan for The Cities Is Not Just Money
description: It was a far cry from the $50 billion Marshall Plan for cities that many black leaders were talking about a few years ago. The national urban policy laid out by President Carter last week was merely a whisper  an extra $4.4 billion in budget requests and only $742 million more in actual spending for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1.

title: Headley Bell Fiance Of Nancy H. Beach
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gardner Decoursey Beach of Frankfort, Ky., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Hieronymus Beach, to Price Headley Bell, son of Mrs. John Andrew Chandler and Reynolds Wait Bell, both of Lexington, Ky.

title: Chinese Characters
description: AS a child, Margaret Gaan was terrified of going with her nurse to Shanghai's Big Park, which had on its gate the sign Dogs and Chinese not allowed. Because she was part Chinese (her paternal grandmother was from Ningpo) and her nurse was Chinese, she was afraid that the truculent British park superintendent would one day chase after them, shouting, Get out of here, you yellow barstuds!

title: INDIA TAKES BIG STEP TOWARD PROHIBITION
description: NEW DELHI, April 1Bars and liquor stores in several parts of India are closing their doors this weekend as the country moves a big step toward total prohibition.

title: PEOPLE
description: All week long the expected battle for control of the Kennecott Copper Corporation unfolded. As the week began, the CurtissWright Corporation unveiled its candidates to displace Kennecott's current directors.

title: Correction
description: The capsule description of Graham Greene's The Human Factor in the Best Seller List of March 26 included the comment NORMAL DEPTH EXCEEDS SPECIFIED VALUE, which represents a computergenerated typesetting instruction, not the computer's critical evaluation of Mr. Greene's latest novel.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: This Week:

title: COSMOS 1,000, A MILESTONE, IN ORBIT TO MONITOR SHIPS
description: MOSCOW, April 1 (UPI)The Soviet space program reached a milestone today with the announcement of the launching of Cosmos 1,000, a highaltitude satellite to watch Soviet ship movements worldwide.

title: Miss Shasha Bride Of Barry Kaplan
description: In the Harrison (N. Y. Jewish Cornmunity Center last night, Virginia Shasha. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Shasha of Scarsdale, N.Y., became the bride of Harry Kaplan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Monte Kaplan, of Dallas. Rabbi Maurice Davis performed the ceremony.

title: The Executive Suite Moves
description: PLEASANTVILLE THE old brewery was in trouble. While local beer drinkers were imbibing more than ever, the company's market share was decreasing. Two national brands were moving in on the territory, and the company's president wondered whether his organization could survive.

title: Long Island/This Week
description: ALBERTSONSculpture by Ruth Lee Siegel; paintings, drawings by Jay Chollick; through May 2; Shelter Rock Library, 165 Searingtown Rd. For hours, call CH 87363.

title: Montana Begins an Experiment To Permit Cameras in Courts.
description: HELENA, Mont, April 1 (UPI)Montana is beginning a twoyear experiment in letting reporters with tape recorders and cameras into courtrooms.

title: Panel Tells Koch How to Restore Quality to New York's Libraries
description: By taking better advantage of Federal funds and other assistance programs, the city could bring its crippled library system up to precutback standards for an additional $5.5 million a year, a task force has told Mayor Koch. The present library budget is $70 million a year.

title: NursingHome Negotiations Stalled
description: Both sides in negotiations for 90 private nursing homes in New York City reported no movement yesterday in the fifth day of talks for a new labor contract, with a Tuesday strike deadline approaching.

title: HOPE SHIPPEE WHITMAN
description: Hope Shippee Whitman, a puppeteer, died Friday in New York Hospital. She was 70 years old and lived in Patterson, N.Y.

title: Pumpkin Moonshine Triumphs
description: Howard Tesher thought Pumpkin Moonshine could win the $53,570 Westchester Handicap as the trainer saddled the 4yearold colt yesterday at Aqueduct. Dave Borden, the colt's jockey. thought so too. And so did many in the crowd of 26,841. They were rinht.

title: Laura Gay Miller Bride Of James Alleyn Duncan
description: Lauri Gay Miller and James Alleyn Duncan were married yesterday in St. David's Episcopal Church in Wayne, Pa., by the Rev. Laurence C. Maud.

title: THE MARKETS
description: The stock market ended the final week of its disappointing first quarter with a token gain in active trading. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.86 point to 757.36. The best movers continued to be the second. ary issues, which have been outperforming the quality and glamour issues this year.

title: Nassau's Public TV News Team Is Doing the Job on a Shoestring
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I.With a little more than an hour until WLIW's nightly news program, Long Island Newsmagazine, goes on the air, the news director, reporter, anchorman, technical crew and camera operators are caught up in the typical bedlam that characterizes any television newsroom before a live broadcast.

title: IN BRIEF
description: From Russia with caution. United States trade with the Soviet Union shrank to $1.9 billion last year, the first drop since the Nixon Administration pressed dtente in 1972. American exports to Russia fell to $1.6 billion from $2.3 billion in 1976. Soviet exports to the United States, primarily of raw materials, were only $234 million, almost unchanged from past levels. But this year Moscow is expected to buy more grain to make up for a disappointing 1977 harvest.... Overall the United States had $4.5 billion trade deficit in February, its 21st consecutive monthly deficit and up sharply from the previous record of $3.6 billion.

title: When to Buy Or When to Sell? Timing Is All
description: Buying a new house and selling an old one is a juggling act in which timing means everything and a mistake can cost thousands. The homeowner has to decide whether to buy first or sell first, and many have two nightmares as they contemplate the choice.

title: Flynt Lawyer Home From Hospital
description: LAWRENCEVILLE, Ga., April 1 (AP)Gene Reeves Jr., the lawyer who was shot, along with Larry Flynt, the owner of Hustler magazine, as they walked down a street here March 6, returned to his home today from a hospital. Mr. Reeves was wounded in the arm and stomach. Mr. Flynt, who is his client, was also shot in the stomach and re. mained in serious condition in another hospital. There have lbeen no arrests the shootings.

title: ENGINEERS' ACADEMY PICKS NEW MEMBERS
description: The National Academy of Engineering yesterday announced the election of 100 engineers to membership in the academy and the election of 19 foreign associates. The election brings the total number of academy members to 857 and foreign associates to 58.

title: Shura CherkasskyA Pianist Who Follows His Intuition
description: When two seasons ago Shura Cherkassky performed in New York for the first time in over a decade, he might have arrived in a time machine. Playing for a sparse, largely unsuspecting Hunter College audience, the gnomelike, Russianborn pianist nonchalantly exhumed a species of Romantic keyboard wizardry many people insist is as extinct as the music of Thalberg and Kalkbrenner.

title: Last Word in Strident Rent Fights Is Spoken Softly
description: Every Thursday, usually at around 2 P.M., about 15 people, mostly men, gather in a conference room in a 10thfloor office at 666 Fifth Avenue. The doors are closed, there are no windows, and before long the room becomes stuffy with cigar and cigarette smoke.

title: Stars and Stripes in His Eyes
description: SANCHE DE GRAMONT, the distinguished French writer, has undergone an extraordinary transformation. He has left his homeland, become an American citizen and changed his name to Ted Morgan, an anagram of de Gramont. (He rejected, among other anagrams, Tom Danger, Rod Magnet, Mo Dragnet and Grand Tome.) As a New Englander, I regret to report that he has chosen to settle in California, displaying that excess of zeal Talleyrand deplored in his countrymen, but perhaps it is appropriate. Among other institutions cherished by Mr. Morgan, ne de Gramont, are McDonald's hamburgers, shopping centers and California wines, whichau secours!  he prefers to French vintages.

title: Kodak Drops Berkey Case Lawyers
description: The Eastman Kodak Company last week dropped the law firm that had been handling its defense in a monopoly case brought by I3erkey Photo Inc. Berkey has won a Federal Jury award of $37.6 million, which would be tripled under antitrust law.

title: Shelter Aid for Battered Women
description: WHITE PLAINS WHEN State Senator Manfred Ohrenstein introduced legislation recently for establishing a statewide reporting system to determine the extent of the abuse of wives, he included statistics showing that 83 percent of the state's social services commissioners reported no specific services for bat: tered women in their counties.

title: Consolidation of Disaster Relief Is Urged on Carter by Governors
description: WASHINGTON, April 1 (AP)The National Governors Association has asked President Carter to consolidate Federal disaster relief programs into one agency.

title: Wine
description: Some years back, before wine really meant anything to the airlines, I had occasion to fly to San Francisco. Fate gave me one of those middle seats  no window, no aisle. I forget who had the window seat, but I remember vividly the chap who came on just before the doors shut and plunked himself into the space on my right.

title: Heading for the Exit in South Africa
description: The campuses are astir again and the issue is South Africa. Students and teachers want to attack that nation's racist policies through the power of American corporations doing business there. The protester are asking the universities to use their influence as stockholders to force the corporations to reduce or abandon operations in South Africa. That failing, they want the universities to sell the stock. Similar demands have come from church groups, foundations and major pension funds whose portfolios include the shares of many of the 350 corporations with investments in South Africa worth $1.7 billion. They have made it the hottest issue at this season's shareholder meetings.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: IT was an unlikely car pool we formed one recent Tuesday morning: a young, pregnant mother, three middleaged housewives and a fatherly obstetrician carrying not a medical bag but a lunchbox.

title: Air Ceylon Ends Foreign Services; New International Line Is Planned
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka. April 1 (AP)Air Ceylon. Sri Lanka's 30yearold state :airline. ended international service today apart from regional flights to south India and the Maidive Islands, the Government announced.

title: Selling Out In Springtime
description: You may keep your crocuses, your robins, your April showers, and yes, even your running shoes and tennis sneakers. Springtime in the suburbs is most characteristically heralded by the rite known as the tag sale.

title: ART
description: LINCROFT THERE are art shows and there are art shows. However, the one at the Monmouth Museum is a show of shows. It has dash and flash, glitter and glamor. It has the kind of spectacle that appeals to everybody.

title: Canadians End Search for Debris of Soviet Satellite
description: Canadian military forces last week abandoned their active search for debris of the Soviet satellite that disintegrated over northern Canada in January. But scientists are expected to continue for at least a year investigations of possible radiation aftereffects from the satellite's nuclear reactor.

title: Rangers Fail to Clinch Berth In Playoffs as Flames Win, 60
description: ATLANTA, April 1Bulldozed into a pile like so many shavings of ice. the New York Rangers had no opposition to offer the big Atlanta Flames this afternoon and took a 60 beating. Having scored an average of more than six goals a game over a six game unbeaten streak and fivegame winning skein, the Rangers failed to penetrate Dan Bouchard, the Flames goalie, on 23 shots and were held to four shots on five powerplay opportunities.

title: ART
description: ELMONT JAPANESE print shows have abounded in recent years, but the current exhibition of Japanese graphics at the Elmont Public Library has something very special about it.

title: ART
description: PURCHASE MEMORIES to most of us are illusive, vague recollections incongruously amassed in our minds. But in the art of use Getz, currently on view at the Neuberger Museum, memories take on a much more substantial reality. They are given a tangible form and life, causing the artist's thoughts, experiences and feelings of the past to live, sometimes very quietly and sometimes more dramatically, in the present.

title: Crafts Project Is a Friend in Deed
description: SETAUKET THE Neighborhood House is a massive white early19thcentury building facing a lake on a street where only the loud honking of geese disrupts the silence.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Guggenheim Foundation Announces 1978 Awards
description: The John Simon Guggenheim Memorial Foundation has announced fellowship awards for 1978 totaling $4,569,500. The grants were made to 292 scholars, scientists and artists chosen by the foundation's committee of selection from among 3,050 applicants in the 53d annual competition.

title: Israeli Journalists Go on Strike, Closing Newspapers, Radio and TV
description: TEL AVIV, April 1(AP)Israeli journalists went on strike for higher pay today, silencing the statecontrolled radio and television and shutting down newspapers and the domestic news agency.

title: . . .While the White House's Has Shrunk
description: In its seven years, the White House Office of Telecommunications Policy produced important reports and legislative proposals on cable television, satellites and the security and privacy questions created by computers and other electronic innovations. Yet for all its work, the agency got almost no public recognition  and even less support from the last two Presidents. Last week it vanished altogether.

title: Schools Without Walls
description: YEARS ago, some educational geniuses decided to tear down the walls of education  literally. Their idea was to build school without walls.

title: A Recourse For Battered Wives
description: DOMESTIC immunity for assault and battery became extinct when the New York Domestic Relations Law was amended by the State Legislature in 1937. This will come as a surprise to police officers in Nassau and Suffolk Counties, intake departments in our Criminal and Family Courts, social workers and some legal advisers.

title: Anne Donnelly Betrothed to John Warren Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs John Charles Donnelly of Grosse Pointe, Mich., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Anne Roberts Donnelly, to John Buel Warren Jr., son of Mrs. Frederick Clifford Ford Jr. of Grosse Point Farms and the late Mr. Warren.

title: Australian Swimmers Dominate in Japan
description: TOKYO, April 1 (AP)  Australian swimmers won four of five events on the second day of the Japan indoor swimming championship today.

title: We'thy Fisher: Woman With a Mission
description: LOS ANGELES  Welthy Honsinger Fisher, who first went to China as a Methodist missionary in 1906, didn't allow her 99 years, subzero temperatures, or a broken knee to interfere with a recent trio to China.

title: LIFE OF A SALESMAN
description: A legend among his colleagues, Ben Feldman is probably the greatest lifeinsurance salesman of all time. He has sold more than $858 million worth of life insurance, and almost all of that in and around the unlikely small town of East Liverpool, Ohio.

title: The Key Figures Debate New York City Schools
description: ayor Koch's dissatisfaction with the New York City public schools and his legislative proposals to gain control over the appointment of the Chancellor and the Board of Education have touched off the liveliest  and perhaps the most significant  dispute over city education policy since the system was decentralized in 1969. At the invitation of The Week in Review, three of the principal figures in the debate recently discussed their views at The Times. They were Deputy Mayor Herman Bodin, who has been given the responsibility to put through the changes Mr. Koch wants; Irving Anher, the Chancellor of the public school system, who leaves office at the end of June; and Albert Shanher, president of the 60,000member United Federation of Teachers. Following are excerpts from the session.

title: Fake Iceberg Towed Into Sydney as Prank
description: SYDNEY, Australia, April 1 (UPI)Dick Smith, an electronics millionaire, pulled an April Fool's prank on Sydney today by sailing into the harbor towing what appeared to be an iceberg.

title: Bulls 110, Braves 102
description: BUFFALO, April 1 (UPI)Wilbur Holland and Artis Gilmore had big secondhalf scoring sprees as the Chicago Bulls kept alive their playoff hopes with a 110102 victory tonight over the Buffalo Braves.

title: High Winds Fan Fire in Jersey Burning 200 Meadowlands Acres
description: Strong winds fed a brushfire in North Jersey that consumed about 200 acres of marshes and brambles in the Hackensack Meadowlands, according to officials in East Rutherford.

title: New Look for The Merry Widow
description: I want The Merry Widow to be a beautiful, romantic entertainment, recreating the overall atmosphere of the 1905 period: the elegance, the snobbism, the tempo of the waltz, when every one drank chainpagne and visited one's mistress in the intermissions.

title: U.S. House Delegation Completes WeekLong Visit to Soviet Union
description: MOSCOW, April 1 (AP)Members of the House Armed Services Committee ended a weeklong visit to the Soviet Union today after talks with officials and meetings with dissidents. The Soviet press agency Tass reported that the delegation had left Kiev for Geneva.

title: Deaths
description: SANTANGELOAlfred E. of The Bronx, N. Y. on March 30, 1971, beloved husband of Betty. lather of Mary Jo Nocero, Eileen Hutt, Betty Jane, Patricia and Charles Santangelo. Brother of Robert, George, Louis, Eugenia Fabbri, Louise Pizzutello, Vera Melarano, Eleanor Rosefelt. Also surviving are five grandchildren. The The family will be present at the Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, N. Y. between the hours of 2 to 4 and 7 to 9PM Saturday and Sunday. Funeral mass at St Lucy's Church, 833 Mace Ave, Bronx. on Monday, April 3 at 9:45AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: Oil Leaks Into Cape Cod Canal
description: BOSTON, April 1 (AP)An estimated 6.000 gallons of oil leaked into the Cape Cod Canal area today from a ruptured tank on a barge that went aground, the Coast Guard said. Some of the oil spread through the canal and into Buzzards Bay, leaving a sheet two to three miles long, an official said.

title: Nicklaus, a Businessman, Turns to Golf This Week
description: Jack Nicklaus runs a multimilliondollar conglomerate that, among other things, builds golf courses, promotes credit cards and slacks, sells automobiles, leases real estate, teaches golf and breeds cattle. He hunts, fishes, skis and plays tennis and pickup basketball. In priorities he puts his wife and five children ahead of golf and business.

title: It's Time to Plant Dwarf Fruit Trees
description: DURING the past 10 years or so, there has been a minor revolution in home gardening, as more and more people are discovering the joy of growing fruit on their own dwarf fruit trees.

title: Knicks Gain Playoff Spot When Jazz Lose to Celtics
description: BOSTON, April 1 (AP)  Kevin Stacona scored a career high 22 points and Dave Cowen chipped in with 19 in pacing the Boston Celtics to a 119108 victory over the New Orleans Jazz tonight.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayInternational Kennel Club of Chicago benched show continues in International Amphitheatre, 4300 South Halsted Street, Chicago; 3,606 dogs; sporting, hound and working breeds and groups and best in show today, plus obedience Open and utility; 9 A.M.7 P.M.

title: INTERVIEW
description: WE see Senior Citizens Month as an opportunity to really educate the public, said Adelaide Attard, the Commissioner of Nassau County's Department of Senior Citizen Affairs. We really want to concentrate the attention of the public on the elderly what their Kole in society is, what they have contributed to society.

title: Douglas K. Roberts And Sara B. Glenn To Wed in August
description: Sara Brooke Glenn and Douglas Kent Roberts, graduates of Duke University, will be married there in August at the Duke Chapel. Their engagement has been announced by the bridetobe's parents, Dr. and Mrs. James Francis Glenn of Durham, N.C., where Dr. Glenn is chairman of the urology department at the Duke Medical Center. Mr. Roberts is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Otto Roberts of Telford, Pa.

title: Notes: The Syracuse Symphony Is Coming To Town
description: The Syracuse Symphony Orchestra is feeling its oats, and well it might. In 17 seasons it has gone from a semiprofessionaL community ensemble giving four concerts for 1,700 subscribers to a major organization with a budget of over $2 million. The city that ranks 78th in size in the United States has the 28th largest budget among those of the country's symphony orchestras. It is now heard by some 300,000 people a season. It has new home in the local Civic Center. Its concerts are syndicated for broadcast in major cities. It is scheduled to make its first recording and first television show.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE chef at the new Hunam in Levittown formerly tended wok at a prestigious place on Second Avenue in Manhattan, also called Hunam. They've been trying to clone restaurants for years by implanting chefs in new locations. (We might be better off if science concentrated on cloning Hunams instead of humans altogether.)

title: Disease Control Center Reports Decline in Flu Outbreak Reports
description: ATLANTA, April 1 (AP)Only 15 states and territories ate reporting influenza outbreaks and 25 states are reporting sporadic activity, the national Center for Disease Control said yesterday.

title: FOOD
description: HUNTINGTON STATION ALBERT'S DAIRY is an anachronism that has managed to survive. It may be the only dairy on the Island where retail customers can buy milk in bottles. Not any milk, mind you, but oldfashioned unhomogenized milk with the top cream filling the shoulders and neck of the once familiar squarish glass bottle with its pleated paper cap.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: THE Portuguese were once among the world's greatest explorersgenius adventurers who left their mark in almost every corner of the globe (even though globe has no corners), from Newfoundland to Macao, from Goa to Honolulu. Portuguese ships and seamen visited every port in the civilized world and perhaps as many in what Europe was pleased to call the uncivilized world.

title: Boy, 15, Fails in Attempt to Hijack Plane From Richmond to Newark
description: A 15yearold boy with a 22caliber rifle boarded a Piedmont Airlines jet at Richmond yesterday and demanded to be taken to Newark. But the attempted air piracy never got off the ground and the wouldhe hijacker surrendered after finding himself alone on the plane.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books said at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Mobutu Turning Harsher to Control a Diverse Zaire
description: KINSHASA, Zaire, April 1 (Reuters)The eight army officers snapped to attention as their insignia were stripped from their uniforms and a military judge pronounced the. death sentence on them and five civilians. All appealed for clemency and some declared their innocence.

title: It's Time to Plant Dwarf Fruit Trees
description: DURING the past 10 years or so, there has been a minor revolution in home gardening, as more and more people are discovering the joy of growing fruit on their own dwarf fruit trees.

title: B. H. Nemmers, Sherry Jacobs To Wed May 6

description: ANOTHER significant step in the protection of Long Island pleasure boatmen has been taken by the Nassau County Police Department.

title: Decoys: A Rediscovered Art
description: WITH the recent recognition that its shorebird decoys are among the finest in the world, the Island now has another cultural asset that is the equal in its field to the paintings of William Sidney Mount and the poetry of Walt Whitman. As collectors from across the country scour the Scruth Shore bay towns hoping to discover a forgotten rig of decoys in some hunter's attic, official notice the artistic ability of the Island's carvers has come in the form Federal grants to pay for a permanent decoy exhibition at the Museums at Stony Brook.

title: County Weighs Carter Aid Plan
description: WHITE PLAINS PRESIDENT Carter's new urban policy was introduced in Washington last week the way Detroit used to bring in new carsunder a cover that offered an indication of the shape without revealing the details.

title: Jane Condon Fiancee Of Kenneth Bartels
description: Mrs. Joseph E. Condon of Brockton, Mass., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Jane Frances Condon, to Kenneth Gilbert Bartels, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry E. Bartels of North Haven, Conn. The wedding is planned for August.

title: This Week in Sports
description: The major league season opens with one game (Minnesota at Seattle) on Wednesday and three on Thursday. The Yankees play exhibition games in the South today through Thursday, then start the season against the Texas Rangers Saturday and next Sunday at Arlington, Tex. The Mets, after exhibitions in Florida today through Tuesday, open against the Montreal Expos with 2:05 P.M. games Friday, Saturday and next Sunday at Shea Stadium.

More recently, concern has focused on foreign lending, poor domestic loan demand and squeezed profit here and abroad.

description: New York City's Health Department was accused yesterday by Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin of lax enforcement of the requirement that landlords pay for rodent extermination performed by its Bureau of Pest Control.

title: A Spring Tonic For the Ailing House
description: ALTHOUGH the wise automobile owner recognizes the need for periodic tuneups, most homeowners do not realize that it is just as important to give their homes the same sort of preventive maintenance. And now that one of the rougher winters in recent years is over, giving thelouse that tuneup can go long way toward preventing major breakdowns later on.

title: HighStepping Into Stardom

But last Monday night, when Dancin  opened at the Broadhurst Theater, there could be no doubt that Miss Reinking had joined the ranks of Broadway's brightest stars. With her long legs, mane of silky, flying hair and feline intensity, Miss Reinking is a standout in some very fast company.

Even those who take a Tolstoyan view of history, or who see nationbuilding as the product of blind collective forces, must be tempted to concede that here was an occasion when the will power and capacity of a single individual formed the hinge on which events of great and lasting importance turned.

description: SCARSDALE THE ninth annual Metropolitan A.A. Championship 15Kilometer Road Race, considered by some who qualify as a warmup for the Boston Marathon, begins at 1:30 P.M. sharp today at Scarsdale High School. It's not too late to line up with the startersexpected to number 800 to 1,000if you can register at the high school before 12:30 P.M.

title: Under Light, What You See Isn't Necessarily What You Get

He was seeing me because his boss wouldn't. We first spoke in a small partitioned room, and then toured the downstairs floors before going out the side door. We came back in and took the escalator down to the paintselection section in the basement.

title: RATE FOR OPERATIONS FELL SLIGHTLY IN 1976
description: The rate at which Americans undergo surgery, which had been steadily soaring since 1971, appears to have dropped slightly in 1976, according to the National Center for Health Statistics.

title: D. C. Harman Fiance Of DeLys D. Brown
description: The engagement of DeLys Diane Brown to Douglas Chase Harman has been announced by ner parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard Farrow Brown of New Canaan, Conn. Mr. Harman's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John Robert Harman, also reside in New Canaan. The wedding is planned for June.

title: JONES NEW YORK
A NEW CLUE IN THE CANCER MYSTERY
description: Although it strikes children and young adults, too, cancer is predominantly a disease Of advancing age. It is as if the middleaged or older body, bowing to the vicissitudes of time, relaxes its guard or grows tired and permits the rebellious cancer cells to have their way at last.

title: Rachel Hall Is Engaged
description: Dr. Robert E. Hall of Pound Ridge, N.Y., and Mrs. Francis M. Dymnicki of Riverdale, the Bronx, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Rachel Hall, to Max Sherman 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sherman Jr. of Centreville, Md. A fall wedding is planned.

title: Italian Captures Slalom
description: CHIESA VALMALENCO, Italy, April 1 (UPI)Italy's Peter Mally won the special slalom in the third Valmalenco International Skiing Week today after another Italian, Leonardo David, and Liechtenstein's Paul Frommelt were disqualified. David left the starting gate too late and Frommelt was disqualified on a technicality. Mally was clocked in 1 minute 17.26 seconds for both legs. Switzerland's Christian Hemmi was second and third went to Gustavo Thoeni of Italy.

title: TOUGH JOB FOR CUBA IN ERITREA IS SEEN
description: WASHINGTON, April 1Government specialists said today that they believed the Soviet Union and Cuba would have a more difficult time helping Ethiopia to crush armed rebellion in Eritrea than they encountered in driving Somali troops out of the disputed Ogaden area.

title: FISHING
description: GENTLE breezes and mild weather have caused flounder fishing to blossom, and a fine season seems to be shaping up for Long Island anglers. Along the South Shore, some contend it's the best flounder fishing in years, while the spring run of cod offers an offshore alternative. Cod fishing generally remains hot off Montauk, with the first pollack starting to show.

title: A Professional's View on the Art of Landscape Design
description: WESTPORT AS WITH the proverbial cobbler who neglected mend his own shoes, Eloise Ray, the landscape architect, was hesitant when we first asked to come to her Westport home, a quaint, converted carriage house, to talk about Connecticut gardens. We might discover, she feared, that her own backyard was hardly as she would have preferred us to see it  not at all representative of her work.

title: Make an Issue of Rights in China?
description: WASHINGTONThe nation is putting before itself a practical question: Should we make Peking's record in handling what Americans call the human rights of the Chinese people an obstacle to normalizing diplomatic relations between the United States and the People's Republic of China?

title: Sophia Loren Faces Rome Charges
description: ROME, April 1 (AP)A Rome prosecutor today filed charges against Sophia Loren and issued an arrest warrant for her husband, Carlo Ponti, the film producer, accusing them of illegal transfer of money abroad.

title: Shelton, Kupchak Fined $1,500
description: Lonnie Shelton of the New York Knicks and Mitch Kupchak of the Washington Bullets were fined $1,500 each yesterday by the National Basketball Association Commissioner, Larry O'Brien, for their altercation in Thursday night's game at Madison Square Garden.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Pop art. I have enormous respect for the comic strip as a potential story and art form, Edmund Wilson told a freelance writer named Bill Blackbeard back in 1966, although far too few of its productions have realized that potential. If those few could be gathered into some sort of complete collection, the effect on those who have scorned the comics as a whole might well be devastating.

title: ThreeStory Mansion Near the United States Merchant Marine Academy on L.I. to Become Museum
description: KINGS POINT, L.I.An ornate three. story mansion next to the Merchant Marine Academy here will be converted by fall into the nation's first museum devoted entirely to its merchant marine.

Presbyterian Church to Bronislaw Edward Grala, an associate with the New York law firm of Cadwalader. Wickersham & Taft. The Rev. David Watermulder performed the ceremony. He was assisted by the Rev. Edward Doherty, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Albany's Top Scofflaw Is State of New York
description: ALBANY. April 1 (AP)The State of New York, whose Department of Motor vehicles has helped the City of Albany collect more than $500.000 in unpaid parking fines, owes more for parking tickets than anybody else, according to city officials.

description: ALL of us who live in the county can rejoice that such a dazzling array of distinguished international artists includes our towns in their ports of call. Today alone, for instance, London's noted Chilingirian String Quartet gives a 3 P.M. concert at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers; the Belgrade Jewish Chorus of Yugoslavia has a 7:30 engagement at the Y.M.Y.M.H.A. of Lower Westchester; a joint recital by the violist John Graham and the pianist Robert Levin is at 8 at the State University College at Purchase, and at the Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck, also at 8, Doriot Anthony Dwyer, first flutist of the Boston Symphony, will share the stage with the pianist and composer Yehudi Wyner.

title: ECONOMIC SCENE

For that and other reasons, there seems to be legs apprehension here that another recession may be tnnmine either late this year or early in 1979.

title: Exxon Begins First Atlantic Drilling
description: It was a big week for the Exxon Corporation. Most eventful, on Wednesday, after three days of battling high seas, its drill ship, Glomar Pacific, finally spudded  actually began drilling the first exploratory well in United States Atlantic waters, 95 miles due east of Atlantic City. The day before, the company had dominated a lease sale in Savannah, Ga., for the first tracts off the Georeia and Florida coasts.

title: China Starts Flighti to Africa
description: ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, April 1 (Agence FrancePresse)A 21member Chinese goodwill delegation arrived here today on the first flight of China's national airline to an African capital. Ethiopian aviation and Foreign Ministry officials greeted the group. Ethiopian airlines began service to Peking in 1973.

title: PAPER TALKS RECESS WITHOUT AGREEMENT
description: Nearly 47 hours of continuous bargaining ended with a recess yesterday morning but still no final agreement between newspaper deliverers and representatives of The Daily News and The New York Times.

title: Dr. Kenneth Allen Weds Carol Glasser, Law Aide
description: Carol Joan Glasser, a legal assistant with the New York law firm of Kurzman & Frank, was married last evening to Dr. Kenneth L. Allen, a New York dentist. Rabbi Stephen C. Lerner, the bridegroom's cousin, performed the ceremony in the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue.

title: LEON A. WHEELER, OFFICIAL OF U.S. POSTAL SERVICE, 64
description: Leon A. Wheeler, director of mail operations for the New York City District of the United States Postal Service, died in New York Hospital on Thursday after a long illness. He was 64 years old and lived at 10210 66th Road, Forest Hills, Queens.

title: Jocelyn Clark Marries Andrea Weigel in South
description: Andrea Lee Weigel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. H. Bourke Weigel of Athens and Tupper Lake, N.Y., was married yesterday afternoon to Jocelyn Clark of Ridgeland, S. C., and Burlington. Vt. The Rev. Holland Clark performed the ceremony in Holy Trinity Episcopal Church in Grahamville, S.C.

title: Expectant Fathers Join in Natural Births
description: ACROSS the street trom Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, a quiet revolution in childbirth education is taking place  it is more than just having a baby. The LamazeLeboyer Childbirth Education Center at 344 Main Street, the first in Westchester, is dedicated to advancing the role of the father in the birthing process.

title: SHOP TALK
