I usually work in Cabbages and Kings, and I'm only helping out here for the day.

title: A Capital Enterprise
description: WASHINGTON  James E. Adkins, a 44yearold Harvard graduate turned produce marketer, often brooded as he passed Washington's historic Farmers' Market. Partially burned and vandalized in the 1968 riots, it was shut down. Could he bring it to life?, Mr. Adkins wondered.

title: Realty News
description: Seven companies have leased a total of 139,000 square feet of office space at Rockefeller Center, either as new tenants or in expansion of their existing facilities, at an aggregate rent of more than $22 million.

title: 4 TELEPHONE CABLES CUT NEAR NEW TOKYO AIRPORT
description: TOKYO, April 1 (AP)Vandals cut four telephone cables and set a fire near the New Tokyo International Airport in what the police said was another round in the campaign by radicals to prevent the facility from opening.

title: Trissotin Exposed in English
description: A YEAR before he died, all too early by our tolerance, at the age of 51, Molire, the wit supreme of 17thcentury France, wrote The Learned Ladies (Les Femmes Savantes), a retrospective exhibit of his seasoned skills in the theater: his neoclassical esprit de gomtric, his pronounced mastery of comic speech in rhyme, his talent for crystallizing the dominant traits of mankind  at least of mankind as he observed it in the society of Louis XIV  in crucial situations of sustained ridicule. Principally because the obsessions at which this late comedy is aimed  pedantry and quasiPlatonic chastity  are less destructive than paranoia or avarice, The Learned Ladies is a more temperate exercise than Tartuffe, Le Misanthrope or L'Avare. The plot, in that convenient nutshell designed to contain all such plots, is constructed essentially to bring to their senses the ridiculous women, Philaminte and her daughter Armande, by exposing the base motives of their grotesque mentor, Trissotin, a poet with the intellect of a woodpecker  with the exposure ultimately freeing the other daughter, Henriette (wooed by Trissotin), to marry the liberal young man of her choice, Clitandre.

title: Mark Segall to Wed Karen Elkin, Teacher
description: Dr. and Mrs. Milton Elkin of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Karen Ann Elkin, to Mark E. Segall, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold A. Segall of Harrison, N.Y.

title: Digging Up The Past
description: SIR MAX MALLOWAN states that a sense of humor is an asset for any archeological dig. He is right, and happily has a splendid English wit. Mallowan's Memoirs is an inadequate and misleadingly dull title for a book that describes with lucidity and fervor some of the principal archeological excavations undertaken in the Middle East between 1925 and 1960. These adventures begin with the worldfamous excavations at Ur of the Chaldees, where the magnificent Royal Cemetery was discovered under the direction of Sir Leonard Woolley, to whom the young Mallowan was apprenticed. In Ur Sir Max met his future wife, Agatha Christie, with whom he had 45 happy years of exploring mysteries in a concert of mutual interest and support.

title: David Kalow Fiance Of Janet L. Samuels
description: The engagement of Janet L. Samuels to David A. Kalow, lawyers in New York. has been announced by Miss Samuels's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Emerson Samuels of Pittsburgh. The wedding is planned for June 18.

title: A Museum for the Merchant Marine
description: KINGS POINT AN ornate threestory mansion next to the United States Merchant Marine Academy here will be converted by fall into the nation's first museum devoted entirely to its merchant marine. The 20room house, which sits on more than eight acres overlooking the Sound, will become a repository for scores of paintings and artifacts, some of them stored at the academy and others to be obtained as gifts.

title: Decade of Black Struggle: Gains and Unmet Goals
description: ATLANTA, April 1A decade after the death of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., blacks in the South find their lot not greatly different from the lot of blacks elsewhere in the United States.

title: Home Turf Of Those Great White Horses
description: The landscape changed dramatically as my wife, Tony, and I drove into Styria, southeasternmost province of Austria, after days of High Alps. From wild arrays of sawtooth peaks, some still wearing last winter's tattered snow, we came to a gentle land where everythingfields, orchards, gardens, neat stands of treesseemed cultivated. As our rented Volkswagen topped a ridge and nosed down into a small valley, the vista was bathed in afternoon light and shadow, a. study in shades of green.

title: The Voice of a Prison Poet
description: RAHWAY INSIDE the giant concrete dome of Rahway State Prison, iron gates are clanging open and shut, voices are being raised above the din and footsteps are echoing in the long corridors. But outside the massive walls: silence.

title: Sports Guide
description: Hunters and target shooters who need New York State certification for handling rifles, pistols and long bows can take advantage of a sevenhour safety course at Mitchell Park in Uniondale, L.I. The Nassau County Department of Recreation and Parks is offering the classes on the first and second Wednesdays of each month from 7 to 10:30 P.M. A huntersafety expert from the state will instruct students 14 years of age or older. Equipment, including long bows, will be supplied. The price of the course is $2.50. For information, call (516) 2222464.

title: Market Place
description: It is fair to say that mutual funds generally did better in the latest quarter than did index funds, which attempt to mirror the results of leading market average.

title: Martin Marietta Makes Bid for Airco
description: It now controls about 56 percent of total Airco shares.

title: Board Asks Koch to Ban New Microwave Facilities
description: In response to growing public concern over the longterm effects of microwave radiation, the Board of Standards and Appeals has asked Mayor Koch to impose a temporary moratorium on the construction or installation of microwave transmission facilities in the city until realistic guidelines are established for their approval.

title: Rates Turn Up in Credit Markets
description: The credit markets changed direction dramatically last week. After two months of declining short rates and stable longterm bond yields, interest rates across the spectrum of maturities climbed sharply as fixedincome prices registered their most pronounced declines since midJanuary.

title: PlayoffBound Knicks Win
description: LANDOVER, Md., April 2The playoffbound Knicks defeated the Washington Bullets, 114109, today at the Capital Centre in a game they tried to give away. Several times they built up leads as high as 13 points, but each time they let the leads slip away.

title: Dr. Stephen Stein Weds Emily Fine
description: Emily Allison Fine, daughter of Verna Fine Gordon and the late Irving Fine, was married yesterday to Dr. Stephen Alan Stein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Stein of Waterbury, Conn. Rabbi Robert E. Goldburg of Hamden, Conn., performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home in Woodmont, Conn.

title: A School Says Thanks for Lunch
description: Laura Senie, age 9, insists that it's the best place in the world to get a grilled cheese sandwich ; Emily Ehrenfeld, 10, loves to go there because High and Mel let me work the cash register and make change; Bradley. Jankowitz, 10, says that he likes to stop in for my Milky Way every morning at 7:30 on my way to school.

title: Dollar Falls to 218 Yen During Early Trading
description: TOKYO, Monday, April 3 (Reuters)The dollar plunged to a new record low on the Tokyo foreign exchange market this morning following, the announcement Friday, that the United States had its worst monthly trade deficit on record in February.

title: Carol Masius Bride Of Stuart Zuckerman
description: Carol Masius, assistant director of subsidiary rights at G.P. Putnam's Sons, publishers, was married yesterday to Stuart Gerald Zuckerman, an account executive with Metromedia Television. Rabbi Daniel S. Wolk, of Rye, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the St. Regis Sheraton.

title: Commodities
description: Traders in gold futures contracts, normally a steelnerved group, have suddenly begun to display symptoms of extreme nervousness. They are becoming more responsive to technical market factors (such as price and volume figures) than to fundamental influences (such as inflation, the value of the dollar and supply and demand for gold).

title: Rightists in Madrid Dispersed
description: MADRID, April 2 (UPI)Policemen on horses dispersed thousands of Madrid rightists celebrating the 39th anniversary of Francisco Franco's victory in the civil war today, but elsewhere in Spain the day was virtually ignored.

title: Researchers Say New Drug Kills Millions of Cancer Cells in Mice
description: HOUSTON, April 2 (AP)With the help of a computer, a team of California scientists has produced what it calls the most potent anticancer drug ever madean agent so lethal that a single dose kills hundreds of millions of cancer cells in laboratory mice.

title: Topics
description: The Court of Appeals has upheld the constitutionality of New York City's local law requiring full financial disclosure by all city officials earning more than $25,000 a year. Although disclosure laws are a modern innovation, the city law reflects a somewhat antique view of the relations between husbands and wives. The officeholder covered by the law must reveal not only his or her assets but also the assets of the spouse. Have you or has your spouse a safe deposit box? the form asks. Where is it? What, in effect, is in it?

title: Israeli Cabinet Regrets Sadat's Stand Against Talks,
description: JERUSALEM, April 2Defense Minister Ezer Weizman briefed the Israeli Cabinet today on his talks with President Anwar elSadat of Egypt, and later statement was issued expressing regret that Egypt had refused to reconvene direct negotiations with Israel,

title: Deaths
description: ALEXANDERArchibald G., of 44 Woodbine Rd, Stamford, Conn., on Sat, April 1, 1978. Son of the late Sir Douglas and Lady Alexander. Husband of Margery Griffith Alexander. Father of Mrs. Fred J. (Margery) Ramsey. Brother of Helen and Douglas Alexander. Four grandchildren also survive. Funeral service at St. John's Episcopal Church, Stamford, Tuesday at 11:00 A.M. In lieu of flowers, memorial gifts to the Stamford Hospital Memorial Fund or to the Rector's Fund of St. John's Episcopal Church would be preferred.

title: His Courage Brings Changes in Spirit of U.S. Blacks
description: Now, 10 years after the death of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., it is possible to look back and see clearly that his legacy to blacks and to the nation was considerably more than the residue of sentiment for a martyred leader of

title: DELIVERERSIN ACCORD AT TIMES AND NEWS
description: Douglas LaChance, president of the newspaper deliverers' union, said yesterday, we have an agreement in principle completely with the Daily News and The New York Times, including wage raises totaling $68 a week over three years.

title: Carter Will See in Liberia A Lot of the Signs of Home
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, April 2When President Carter stops here tomorrow for a brief and symbolic visit at the end of his sevenday South American and African tour, he will probably feel very much at home.

title: Ballesteros Triumphs by Shot
description: GREENSBORO. N.C., April 2 (AP)Severiano Ballesteros, one week short of his 21st birthday, emerged from the peck with a sixunderpar 66 today to score an upset victory in the $240,000 Greater Greensboro open golf tournament.

title: Israel Denies Responsibility
description: TEL AVIV, April 2 (Reuters)An Israeli military spokesman tonight denied that Israeli troops had planted mines inside Syria, killing a dozen people.

title: Jose Molina And Spanish Dancers
description: SPANISHDANCE buffsand they were out in exuberant force to see the Jose Molina Bailes Espanales at Carnegie Hall on Saturdaydon't often get a chance to see that art form these days. What is left of it in New York is on the concert stage, far removed from the open squares and cafes where Spanish region& and flamenco dance flourished for so long.

title: Rock: Bootsy and the Rubber Band
description: BOOTSY and the Rubber Band, which was at the Felt Forum on Saturday night, is a roadseasoned funk band, and what It does it does very well indeed. The band's rhythm section, which features Bootsy Collins on bass, has been playing together since 1968, and the experience shows in the effortless way it lays down an entire set of danceable grooves. Like the rhythm section, several of the horn players used to be with James Brown. One, Maceo Parker, the saxophonist, is a gritty and imaginative soloist, and the horn section is as crisp and biting as one could wish.

title: FIRST CASINO HOTEL GIRDS FOR OPENING
description: ATLANTIC CITY, March 31The gold casino sign on the new white marble entrance to Resorts International Hotel is taped over today, but Resorts executives expect the tape to come off some time the week before Memorial Day for a gala opening of the country's first casino east of Nevada.

title: Itinerary of State U. Chancellor: 12 Campuses Down and 52 to Go
description: Albany on Monday, Buffalo on Tuesday, Syracuse on Wednesday, Stony Brook on Thursday, New York on Friday. Shaking hands, flashing smiles, listening to problems, jotting down names, waving at crowds.

title: Celtics Out of Playoffs in N.B.A
description: The pride of the Boston Celtics burned brightly over the last 21 National Basketball Association seasons when they won the league championShip 13 times and gained an aura of invincibility in the playoffs. Only two years ago they tacked championship banner No. 13 to the rafters of Boston Garden after defeating the Phoenix Suns in the final.

title: Sports Today
description: HARNESS RACING

title: LEONORE BOE
description: Leonore Boe, who for many years created Christmas tableaux and holiday figurines for windows in many Fifth Avenue department stores, died Friday at New York Hospital. Miss Boe, who had a studio in Greenwich Village, was 67 years old.

title: ALICE WANAMAKER HANLEY
description: Alice Wanamaker Hanley, a lecturer and collector of antiques, specializing in Americana, died Saturday at the Queens Hospital Center. She was 87 years old and lived at 82.64 170th Street in Jamaica, Queens.

title: Car and Van Carrying Local Band Collide on Texas Highway
description: PETTUS, Tex., April 2 (UPI)A car and a van transporting a south Texas band home from a latenight engagement collided on a rural stretch of highway today and exploded into flames, seven persons died and one was critically injured.

title: In South Lebanon, All Sides Dig In For What Looks Like a Long Stay
description: SAKRA, Lebanon, April 2Israeli occupation troops, Palestinian guerrillas and United Nations peacekeeping forces all were observed digging in today for what appeared to be a long stay near this strategic area overlooking the Litani River.

title: CARTER SEEKS TALKS INCLUDING ALL SIDES IN RHODESIA CONFLICT
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, April 2President Carter said here today that the United States, responding to the urgings of black African leaders, was moving as quickly as possible to convene a peace conference on Rhodesia that would involve all parties to the conflict.

title: California Court Cases Imperil Political Reform Act and Agency
description: SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 1Four years after it was accepted by 69.8 percent of California's voters, the California Political Reform Act of 1974 faces court actions that could wipe it out, strengthen it, or alter, up or down, the public image of its chief enforcement officer.

title: Egyptian Hostility Toward Begin Mounting
description: CAIRO, April 2Egyptian distrust of Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel has grown so intense that officials have generally concluded that no real progress in peace negotiations can be achieved as long as he remains in office.

title: Calif. Five Triumphs In A.A.U
description: ALLENTOWN, Pa., April 2Anna's Bananas, a team of California women who look as if they just came in from surfing, won their second consecutive Amateur Athletic Union basketball championship last night by defeating the Sophisticated Ladies of Maryland, 10095.

title: Two Policemen and Gunman Killed, Suspect Shot on Brooklyn Street
description: Two highly decorated police officers and a 26yearold former convict were shot to death early yesterday during an exchange of gunfire on a street in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: Two U.S. Soldiers Killed
description: HEIDELBERG, West Germany, April 2 (Reuters)Two American soldiers were killed and two others seriously injured when their tank was hit by a live shell during a firing exercise at Grafenwohr in Bavaria, a United States Army spokesman here said today.

title: Reformdemocrat Meeting Called Surprise
description: EAST ORANGE, April 2The convention of more than 1,300 reformminded Democrats at the Upsala College gymnasium yesterday was remarkable more for the fact that it occurred than for what accomplished.

title: Two Policemen and Gunman Killed, Suspect Shot on Brooklyn Street
description: Two highly decorated police officers and a 26yearold former convict were shot to death early yesterday during an exchange of gunfire on a street in the BedfordStuyvesant section of Brooklyn.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Partial list of scheduled meetings for week follows:

title: Congress to Act on Cancer Bills Of Special Importance to Jersey
description: WASHINGTON  Concern that not enough money is being spent to combat the environmental causes of cancer is giving rise to legislation that would be of special importance to New Jersey and other states with unusually high cancer rates.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
Rodgers Wins 10Mile Run
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP)Bill Rodgers, the favorite, led a field of 2,600 in the 10mile Cherry Blossom Classic run along the Potomac River today and set a course record of 48 minutes 57 Seconds.

title: Regina Marsikova Beats Miss Liess
description: STUART, Fla., April. 2 (AP)Regina Marsikova, a high school senior from Prague, defeated 18yearold Zenda Liess of Daytona Beach, Fla., 16, 63, 63, today and won the $15,000 Women's Tennis Association championshin.

title: Lorene E. Russell, a Model, Is Married to Allan G. Sarn
description: Lorene Elaine Russell, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph L. Russell of Ridgewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Allan G. Sarn, son of Mrs. Leo Sam of Belle Harbor, Queens, and the late Mr. Sarn.

title: Curare Trial Marked by 3Way Courtroom Strife
description: HACKENSACIC, N.J.From the beginning of the fiveweekold curare murder trial here of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, the prosecuting attorney, Sybil R. Moses, has been taunted, insulted and mocked by the defense attorney who, in her view, has been implicitly encouraged by the judge.

title: Satellite to Transmit InStore Radio Spots
description: The death rate for new instore media for super markets has been tremendous. But there's no stopping the entrepreneurs who bubble with ideas on how to reach shoppers at almost the very moment of the purchase decision.

title: Romance of the Rails
description: NEWPORT NEWS, Va.I am sick and tired of people telling me wistfully of their love for trains the way they used to be. The implication is that if the waiter were smiling broadly over steaming pancakes and there were still a barber aboard the Super Chief, these people would be riding the rails, listening to the lonely whistle across the prairie. Baloney!

title: World News Briefs
description: LUSAKA, Zambia, April 2 (Reuters)Rhodesia ryas reported today to have made its second big raid in a month against Zambia, heightening the urgency of efforts to set up new Westernspansored peace talks.

title: At the Track: Gotham Stakes
description: Some top 3yearold colts whose owners have aspirations of running them in the Kentucky Derby will test their credentials at Aqueduct on Saturday in the S50,000added Gotham Stakes. This mile test is the third of four races staged for 3yearold hopefuls by the New York Racing Association. Sigmund Sommer's Piece of Heaven, a frontrunning sprinter, captured the Swift and the Bay Shore, each at six furlongs, last month. He is expected to be out of the gate quickly again. Strong challenges may come from Chinright Stable's Just Right Classi, Geoffrey Huguely's Shelter Half and August Belmont's Quadratic. The ninerace program will start at 1:30 P.M. Admission to the clubhouse costs $2.50, and to the grandstand $1.50. The Gotham can be seen on delayed tape over WORTV (Channel 9) at 6 P.M.

title: The Halls of Ivory
description: WASHINGTONWhat do the regimes of Ferdinand Marcos, Muammar elQaddafi, and the Shah of Iran have in common?

title: Obtaining Maps of the Good Streams
description: Every canoeist should make at least one run down Maine's famed Allagash River. For a map of the Allagash wilderness waterway, write to the Bureau of Parks and Recreation, State Office Building, Augusta, Me. 04333. With the map will come a list of registered Maine guides and outfitters who specialize in Allagash trips. For a sportsman's map of the entire northwestern Maine region, write to Ben Pike, International paper Company, Jay, Me. 04239.

title: Rhode Island Steel Pact Ratified
description: PAWTUCKET, R.I., April 2 (AP)Steelworkers at two Rhode Island cable plants voted yesterday to ratify a new contract, ending a two and onehalf week strike. William Foley, New England district director for the United Steelworkers of America, said the vote on the new pact, details of which were not available, was 425 to 125. The Carol Cable Company plants in Pawtucket and Warren are to resume production tomorrow.

title: Koch Hopes Other Unions Settle For Less Than Transit Contract
description: Mayor Koch's goal in negotations with the city's labor unions is to get them to settle for less than the transit workers got, a strategy that was decided on when he agreed to the transit pact, people close to the Mayor said yesterday.

title: Waltrip Captures Stock Car Race
description: BRISTOL Tenn., April 2 (AP)Darrell Waltrip took the lead with 102 laps remaining today and then pulled away from Benny Parsons at the end to take an easy victory in the Southeastern 500 grand national stock car race at Bristol International Raceway.

title: Itinerary of State U. Chancellor: 12 Campuses Down and 52 to Go
description: Albany on Monday, Buffalo on Tuesday, Syracuse on Wednesday, Stony Brook on Thursday, New York on Friday. Shaking hands, flashing smiles, listening to problems, jotting down names, waving at crowds.

title: Hijacking Suspect Free on Bond
description: RICHMOND, April 2 (AP) Richard Carlisle Bland, 15 years old, who allegedly tried to hijack a Piedmont Airlines 737 airliner to Newark yesterday, was released in the custody of his parents last night under $2,000 bond. After the passengers and crew escaped, the youth, who carried a.22caliber rifle, was talked out of the plane by the authorities.

title: Koch, an Opponent of Westway, Now Telling Aides It Is Inevitable
description: Mayor Koch, who says he is a strong opponent of the Westway and who vowed, during the mayoral campaign that it would not be built, has lately been telling trusted aides and politicians that the superhiway is inevitable. At a meeting recently with the Manhattan delegation to the State Assembly. Mr. Koch was asked about the Westway, which would run along the Hudson River from the Battery to 42d Street. The Mayor responded, If Governor Carey wants Westway to be built, it is inevitable.

title: Sinatra Draws 800 to the Waldorf To Erase Carey's Campaign Debt
description: Usually a solo act,'Frank Sinatra shared the spotlight last night with Governor Carey, who is known as something of a loner himself.

title: Racing: Affirmed Easy Victor
description: ARCADIA, Calif., April 2Affirmed asserted himself as a top contender for the Kentucky Derby today with an eighthlength victory in the $195,300 Santa Anita Derby.

title: Yonkers Teachers Face 2d Revision Of Pact Because of Fiscal Crisis
description: Like New York City, Yonkers, which nearly defaulted three years ago and hit since accepted strict state financial controls, is making its ownalbeit lesspublicizedefforts at coping with the requirements of fiscal rehabilitation.

title: Proposed New Parole Board Rules Held Widening Chairman's Power
description: TRENTONProposed new regulations of the State Parole Board will tighten the chairman's control of the threemember panel and will enable him to prevent a return of the parole chaos that existed in New Jersey last year, the board's chairman, Christopher V. Deitz, said.

title: Taiwan Golfer Wins
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 2 (AP) Kuo Chiehsiung of Taiwan scored three birdies on the last five holes for 69 and won the Indonesian open golf tournament by three strokes today with a 72hole total of 275, nine under par. Two Americans, Mike Krantz and Gayford Burrows, tied for sixth with 280's.

title: Tennis: Navratilova Wins
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 2Martina Navratilova completed her domination of women's tennis in the first part of the year by beating Evonne Goolagong, 76, 64, for the championship of the professional tour today, The victory in the Oakland Coliseum was worth $50,000.

title: Fearless Queen Victor at Big A
description: The groundwork for an unexpected success by Mike Venezia was laid yesterday while the veteran jockey was on his way to his Rockville Centre, L.I., church with his 5yearold son, Mike.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: OIL GLUT IS CREATED BY ALASKA PIPELINE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 2Less than a year after its opening, the transAlaskan pipeline has produced a vast oversupply of oil on the West Coast.

title: S.I.Transit Line Shut Down by Strike
description: Electricians and some other nonoperating employees of the Staten Island Rapid Transit Operating Authority stopped work in what a union official called a wildcat strike shortly after 2 o'clock this morning. The 14mine line serving 20,000 commuters was shut down.

title: Courage, Compassion of 2 Slain Officers Recalled
description: Around this time of the year, Norman Cerullo, already well liked by his fellow police officers, would find himself becoming particularly popular at the 79th Precinct station house in Brooklyn, where he had worked for the last eight years.

title: Flyers 4, Kings 2
description: LOS ANGELES, April 2 (AP)Bill Barber scored two shorthanded goals in a span of 27 seconds in the first period and Bobby Clarke had three assists to lead Philadelphia to a 42 victory over Los Angeles last night.

title: Borzoi Judged Best at Chicago Show
description: CHICAGO, April 2When a psychiatrist goes to dog shows for a rest and to escape from people, he doesn't always manage to achieve his objectives.

title: Bus Strike Affects 20,000 Commuters
description: A strike by the Transport Workers Union against the Manhattan Bus Transit Company has forced some 20,000 commuters in Bergen, Hudson and Passaic Counties to find other ways to get to work today.

title: G.M. Image Assailed in New Cases
description: Continued from Page D1

title: Western Pacific Is Stepping Up Drive Toward Diversification
description: The sagging fortunes of the railroad industry, which in 1977 suffered its worst year since the Depression, have from time to time convinced rail executives that the best way to earn a good return on a railroad is to sell it.

title: At Shea, Hitting Gets Emphasis
description: ST. PETERSBURG, FLA. WHEN the New York Mets posed for their annual team picture last month at the start of spring training, it was noticed that 21 of the 37 faces in it were not there a year ago. When the Mets take the field Friday at Shea Stadium, for the season opener against the Montreal Expos, the public will notice that seven of the nine players in the lineup were not there a year ago.

title: Music: Miriam Fried and Ohlsson
description: THE ACCOMPANIST generally find his name in small print on the program of a violin recital, but there were two good reasns why Miriam Fried, violinist, and Garrick Dhlsson, pianist, shared equal billing yesterday afternoon in Alice Tully Hall.

title: Vance Urges Carter to Seek Ban On Making Nuclear Arms Material
description: WASHINGTON, April 2In a move that has provoked furious criticism from the Pentagon, Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vanee has asked President Carter to expedite a proposal by the Arms Control and Disarmament agency calling for an international ban on the production of material used in nuclear weapons.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter said in Lagos, Nigeria, that the United States was moving as quickly as possible to convene a peace conference on Rhodesia and was doing so in response to the urging of black African leaders. The conference would involve all parties to the conflict, Mr. Carter said, and that we will being now to explore the earliest date when this might be accomplished. He proposed such a meeting at a Washington news conference three weeks ago. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Sports World Specials
description: One week from today, Lord Killanin and his assistants on the International Olympic Committee will sit across the table from Los Angeles city officials and interrogate them in a confrontation that could determine the tate of the 1984 Games.

title: Syria Blames Israel for Death of 12 on Golan Heights
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 2Syria today charged Israel with responsibility for the death of 12 Syrian soldiers and civilians in mine explosions in the worst incident in the Golan Feights since the two countries signed a troop disengagement agreement four years ago.

title: Vance Urges Carter to Seek Ban On Making Nuclear Arms Material
description: WASHINGTON, April 2In a move that has provoked furious criticism from the Pentagon, Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance has asked President Carter to expedite a proposal by the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency calling for an international ban on the production of material used in nuclear weapons.

title: 2 BodieS Wash Ashore on Island
description: DELAWARE CITY, Del., April 2 (AP)The bodies of a Delaware man. and his son, missing since yesterday, washed ashore on Pea Patch Island and were discovered by a coastguardsman today. Aaron Sponsal, 29 years old, end his two children, Steve, 10, and Rick, 8, left here on a fishing expedition yesterday, the Coast Guard said. The youngest boy is still missing.

title: Whites Gain Release From the Burdens of Past Racism
description: News Analysis

title: Auto Racing: Prix To Reutemann
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., April 2In a race that turned out to be somewhat of a crashing bore, the third Long Beach Grand Prix was won today by Carlos Reutemann of Argentina.

title: ARAB TERRORIST LEADER WILL BE BURIED IN IRAQ
description: BAGHDAD, Iraq, April 2 (AP)Radical Palestinian guerrillas and representatives of leftist Arab groups gathered in Baghdad today for the funeral of Dr. Wadi Haddad, planner of many terrorist operations for the militant Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine.

title: Cosmos Roll, 70, Over Strikers in Season Opener
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N. J., April 2The Cosmos, with Pele little more than a memory, opened defense of their North American Soccer League title today with an impressive 70 victory over the Fort Lauderdale Strikers before a crowd of 44,442 at Giants Stadium.

title: F.A.A. Defends Data On Landing Systems
description: With a showdown world meeting on the subject to open tomorrow, the Federal Aviation Administration is making.a maximum effort to countermounting criticism of its handling of a battle with Britain over a new system for landing planes in bad weather.

title: Mary Ann Restivo Wed
description: Mary Ann Restivo. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Restivo of South Orange, N.J., was married yesterday to Saul Rosen, son of Mrs. Isaac Rosen of Petersburgh, Fla., . and the late Mr. Rosen. Judge Isaac Rubin of the State Supreme Court performed the ceremony at the Plaza. The bride is a designer of Christian Dior blouses with Cisco Casuals Inc. in New York. Her husband is manager of the WestchesterRockland district of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: TV Violence Down, Health Study Shows
description: CHICAGO, April 2Television violence dropped sharply in overall programming last year from its 1976 peak, but rose during the family viewing hour, the American Medical Association said here today.

title: Snooping and Sniping
description: WASHINGTONDo you ever get any sleep? asks a reader in Hamilton, N.Y. I'm sure you don't, for I expect you lie awake nights thinking up mean things to say about President Carter . . . quite worthy of Westbrook Pegler in his heyday.

title: Opera: Lully's Akeste Given U. S. Premiere
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 Jean Baptiste Lully was one of the most influential figures in operatic history, but until recent years all that most people knew about him were legends and anecdotes. The court composer of Louis XIV, the Sun King, Lully is credited with being the first man to stand before an orchestra to conduct it. It was a fatal decision. His technique was to beat time loudly on the floor with a staff, and in 1687 he hit himself in the foot, contracted blood poisoning and died.

title: RATE AND TRADE DATA SPUR DEBATE ON FED
description: The steady rise in the Federal funds rate last week, faster money supply growth and the record February trade deficit disclosed Friday morning intensified debate about Federal Reserve policy. The upshot of all the discussions seemed to be that it was premature to think the Fed had already tightened but not to be surprised if the Fed tightens soon.

title: Pope Paul in Appeal To Moro's Captors
description: ROME, April 2Pope Paul VI made a personal appeal today to the kidnappers of Aldo Moro, the Christian Democratic leader, to release him, but denied that the Vatican had been in contact with them.

title: Pitchers' Health Is Crucial
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, FLA. THE New York Yankees first World Series championship in 15 years was only minutes old, but there was Lou Piniella sounding an ominous note for 1978.

title: U.S. Has Delicate Task to Arm Somalia and Not, Roil Its Neighbors
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 The United States is now engaged in the delicate task of deciding what defensive arms it can furnish Sothalia without enraging friendly Kenya or destroying recently restored communications with Ethiopia.

title: Man Found Slain in Queens Car; Police Seek Link to Other Killings
description: A 36yearold Brooklyn man was found shot to death yesterday in a parked car in Jamaica, Queens. The police said he might be the latest victim of a series of killings that were being investigated as the possible result of a fallingout among car thieves.

title: Midwest Triumphs In Platform Tennis
description: MONTCLAIR, NJ., April 2The Midwest regional squad, led by its No. 1 ranked team of Del DeWindt of Bloomfield Hills, Mich. and Dan McLaughlin of Rochester, Mich., swept to four more victories today and easily captured the first Presidents' Cup national platform tennis team championship at the Montclair Golf Club.

title: Chess:
description: Seeing ghoststhreats that, seeming to be there, really are notis a chess affliction responsible for numerous disasters. And one must be especially wary of seeing them in uncomfortable positions where the opponent can make several attempts to exploit a loose or awkward location of several pieces.

title: Gottfried On Top
description: DAYTON, Ohio, April 2 (AP)Topseeded Brian Gottfried overcame slow start and defeated Eddie Dibbs today in the final of the $75,000 Dayton Pro Tennis Classic, 26, 65, 76. Gottfried picked up $15,000 for his victory and Dibbs won $7,500.

title: United Way Accused of Monopoly In Fight Over Charitable Funds
description: LOS ANGELES, April 2A bitter feud, with billions of dollars in charitable donations at stake. is being fought between United Way, the nation's dominant volunteer charity, and scores of smaller charities across the country.

title: Cosmos Girls: Show Biz on the Sidelines
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 2  The Dallas Cowboys have their Cowgirls, the Denver Broncos have their Broncoettes, and as of today, the New York Cosmos have their Cosmos Girls.

title: Two U.S. Soldiers Killed
description: HEIDELBERG, West Germany, April 2 (Reuters)Two American soldiers were killed and two others seriously injured when their tank was hit by a live shell during a firing exercise at Grafenwohr in Bavaria, a United States Army spokesman here said today.

title: Golf: Miss Post Wins Playoff
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif., April 2After 10 years in the wings, the bridesmaid has become the bride.

title: Advertising
description: Is it possible that Walter Cronkite, one of the bestknown figures in all of broadcasting, is returning to the print media after all these years?

title: G.M.'s Image Under Fire In New Type of Lawsuit
description: DETROIT, April 2The Omit General Motors Corporation, often a target of antitrust cases challenginb its very size, is again the subject of legal briefsbut this time with a difference. The theme of cases brought in the last 18 months appears to be: What is going on inside G.M.? Recent legal actions hammer at the company's credibility as never before.

title: Hollywood's Sign of Dreams
description: LOS ANGELES IN THE REAL WORLD, the names of places are not spelled out in 50foothigh letters that seem to float, as if by magic, over the hills of the city. But Hollywood has never been altogether part of the real world, and mat may be why this part of Los Angeles has its name spelled out in an enormous sign, constructed of sheet metal panels nailed to a framework of pipes, wires and telephone poles, that proclaims HOLLYWOOD from high on a mountainside.

title: At Home at the Olympics
description: LAST June, Lennie Dervbinsky, a recent migr from the Soviet Union, paid his fare to Portland, Ore., to compete in the national championships of the Amateur Fencers League of America. Two days later he returned to New York as the youngest national champion (21 years 3 months) on record.

title: Credit Unions Attract More Assets and More Critics
description: Credit unions have, so to speak, come out of the closet. Once operated in a quiet way as a cooperative means of encouraging savings and offering cutrate loans to members, typically employees on the same payroll, they have become the fastest growing of financial institutions.

title: Rich Foreigners Buying Estates in Beverly Hills
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., April 2This city, which once absorbed an influx of newcomers that included Will Rogers, Gloria Swanson and Douglas Fairbanks, is experiencing a new wave of migrants. These newcomers are foreigners, many of whom are very rich, and they are buying large pieces of Beverly Hills.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: TOKYO, April 2 (AP)Sadaharu Oh, Japan's home run king, blasted his second homer of the season today, leading the Yomiuri Giants to a 21 victory over the Hanshin Tigers before 50,000 spectators at Korakuen

title: Yanks Blank Orioles; Tidrow Stands Out
description: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla., April 2Total attendance reached at the Yankees' springtraining games reached a record level today as New York defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 50, before a crowd of 6,436 at Fort Lauderdale Stadium.

title: Dollar Falls to 218 Yen During Early Trading
description: TOKYO, Monday, April 3 (Reuters)The dollar plunged to a new record low on the Tokyo foreign exchange market this morning following the announcement Friday that the United States had its worst monthly trade deficit on record in February.

title: Inflation: Mr. Carter's Time Is Short
description: The Carter Administration's concern about inflation appears to be moving out of the Chicken Little phase. Instead of continuing to about like that famous fowl, warning that the sky is falling in, the President and his top economic advisers plan to announce a new antiinflation policy this Week.

title: Ballet: Winnipeg Finale
description: THE MORE the Royal Winnipeg Ballet danced, the better looked. Just before closing its oneweek engagement at the City Center yesterday, the Canadian company presented a third new program with two New York premieres on Saturday night.

title: Memories of Springs Past
description: WHEN T. S. Eliot wrote that April is the cruelest month, was he thinking about men of a certain age who once had close attachment to baseball? This is a time of year when Ed Charles and Joe Pepitone and hundreds of other retired ballplayers are teased by the renaissance of spring, reminded that there is no longer a uniform and a locker waiting for them in a sunsplashed stadium.

title: Flames 4, Sabres 2
description: BUFFALO, April 2 (UPI)Boh MacMillan's goal in the second period, his 38th of the season, helped the Atlanta Flames take a 42 victory over the Buffalo Sabres tonight.

title: Recalling the Past After 5 Decades On a Switchboard
description: In those days she had to have the Social Register in her lap as she worked at the St. Regis Hotei's switchboard; a lot of the hotel's guests wanted to reach numbers listed only the register.

title: American Woman Preaches inWestminster Abbey
description: LONDON, April 2 (UPI) The Rev. Mary Michael Simpson, a Canon Residentiary at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in New York, today broke centuries of tradition as she became the first ordained woman to preach in Westminster Abbey.

title: Beverly Schmidt and W.H. Brough, Jewelers. Wed
description: Beverly Ann Schmidt, daughter of Henry Schmidt of South Salem, N.Y., and the late Doris Schmidt of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday at the Provincial House of the Sisters of the Congregation de Notre Dame in Ridgefield, Conn., to William Herbert Brough. He is the son.of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Brough of Destin. Fla.

title: DavenportHowe Take Squash Racquets
description: Joyce Davenport of King of Prussia, Pa., and Ralph Howe of Locust Valley, L.I., defeated Barbara Maltby and David Page of Philadelphia, 1510, 1215, 157, 1511, yesterday in the final of the national mixeddoubles squash racquets championship at the Manhattan Squash Club.

title: Opera: Beverly Sills As Merry Widow
description: FRANZ LEHAR's The Merry Widow is as foolproof a work as operetta has to show, what with one hit tune following another, and no insuperable difficulties for the singers. But from a major company a certain amount of style is expected; and style was exactly what was missing from the New York City Opera's new production last night.

title: Danny the Red Homesick for France After 10Year Exile
description: FRANKFURT, West Germany, March 30Ten years ago this spring, Daniel CohnBendit led a student revolt in Paris that left French society shaken and baffled. This week, as the weather softened into April, he was on an unemployment line in Frankfurt, still thinking of how to change society.

title: The Hour of Grace
description: BOSTON, April 2Golda Meir, speaking to the Knesset as Prime Minister on May 26, 1970, put in a few words what Israel's leaders had long considered the key to peace:

title: Golden Fleece in 3 Operas
description: GOLDEN FLEECE, now in its second season as one of New York's newest little leag?? opera outfits, specializes in chamber operas by contemporary composers. This weekend the group presented a triple bill of oneacters at the Hotel Ansonia's Three Muses Theater: Canticle II by Benjamin Britten, Three, Sisters Who Are Not Sisters by Ned Rorem and the world premiere of The Specialist by Lou Rodgers.

title: Maharajahs, Shorn of Power, Are Finding New Roles in India
description: JODHPUR, IndiaNow that he has grown accustomed to the foreign tourists who troop through his 250room palace, the Maharajah of Jodhpur has decided to give them access to his grandfather's two oldworldly private railway cars and the ancestral hunting lodge as well.

title: Credit Markets
description: Rise in rates, plus trade data, spur debate on possible Federal Reserve efforts to tighten money supply. Page D2.

title: Conspiracy Charged, and Denied
description: The legal jousting between bankers and credit unions heated up again last week as the bankers were charged with conspiracy by Lawrence Connell Jr., the administrator of the National Credit Union Administration.

title: Symbolic Fences a Boon to Orthodox Jewish Communities
description: Marian Friedlander has not attended her synagogue on the Sabbath in more than a year, because Orthodox Jews are forbidden to push a baby carriage or carry any object on the Sabbath.

title: Hortense Alden, 76, LongTime Actress Toured With Lunt
description: Hortense Alden, an actress and the former wife of the novelist James T. Farrell, died yesterday in Tucson, Ariz. She was 76 years old.

title: The Joy of Bill Veeck
description: FIRST Bill Veeck wqs sitting in the wooden bleachers at Payne Field, chattering with customers. Then found him drinking beer and swapping stories with scouts from a halfdozen clubs. Early the next morning he stood near the backstop of a practice field, making his own judgment on a young righthanded pitcher. The compleat owner, I thought, at home anywhere in baseball.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: What is the difference between Rugby Union and Rugby League?

title: 78 Forest Fire Season: Is Underway in State
description: The recordshattering temperatures that helped ignite spring forestfire season over the weekend have given way to cool weather, but the threat of fire remains.

title: A Small Massachusetts Town Searches Aggressively for Public Grants
description: WAREHAM, Mass., April 2Selectman Carleton D. Hammond Jr. is fond of saying, If some other town gets something we don't get, I want to know why.

title: John Wayne Leaves Hospital for Dinner
description: BOSTON, April 2 (AP)While doctors studied the results of his medical tests, John Wayne, the actor, left a hospital here and had dinner at an elegant French restaurant.

title: TV SPORTS
description: TUESDAY

title: Martin Marietta Enters Bidding On Airco Stock
description: Airco Inc., which has been resisting an effort by BOC International Ltd. of London to acquire more of its shares for $43 apiece, has announced that it has a $50 a share proposal from the Martin Marietta Corporation.

title: Koch Hopes to Keep Other Unions Below Transit Pact
description: Mayor Koch's goal in negotations with the city's labor unions is to get them to settle for less than the transit workers got, a strategy that was decided on when he agreed to the transit pact, people close to the Mayor said yesterday.

title: Hamlet at Arena Stage
description: WASHINGTON  There is much more to Hamlet than Hamlet. We have stared so fixedly and so long at his solitary figure that he has become hard to see. There is hardly an actor who can sustain the concentration. of expectancy that has grown up around him or, who can cut loose from the morass of interpretation, analysis, thesis and counterthesis that tangles his feet.

title: Where You Can Soar
description: Soaring sites convenient to residents of the New York area are listed here. For further information, write to the Soaring Society of American, Box 66071, Los, Angeles 90066.

title: Rangers Crushed By Bruins, 8 to 3
description: BOSTON, April 2The Boston Bruins smacked the New York Rangers with their second hard lesson in reality this weekend, dominating the Rangers tonight, 83. Wayne Cashman, the Bruins' 32yearold captain, had the first fourgoal game of his career. Among the other Bruin scorers was Pete McNab, who put in goal No. 40.

title: Islanders Win and Lead by 5 Points
description: DETROIT, April 2Who says the Islanders depend solely on Bryan Trottier, Mike Bossy and Clark Gillies? Although that Trio Grande went scoreless until the final minutes tonight, New York got four goals from makeshift lines and turned back the Detroit Red Wines. 52. at Olympia Stadium.

title: Outdoors: Canoeing's Allure
description: IF you relish challenge and danger, running rampaging rivers is likely, to be satisfying. If you are a contemplative naturalist, quiet water will undoubtedly please you.

title: Wrestling Cup Goes To Soviet
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, April 2 (UPI)Jimmy Jackson, heavyweight, defeated the Soviet Olympic champion, Soslan Andiev, in the final match, but the United States couldn't stop the Soviet Union from winning its sixth straight World Cup wrestling championship.

title: Borg Conquers Gerulaitis
description: MILAN, Italy, April 2 (AP)Secondseeded Bjorn Borg of Sweden defeated topranked Vitas Gerulaitis of Kings Point, L.I., 63, 63. in 70 minutes today and won the $30,000 final of a pro tennis tournament.

title: Julian B. Beaty, Lawyer, Dies at 97
description: Julian B. Beaty, a retired president and chairman of the Granby Mining Corporation of Vancouver, British Columbia, and a former Mayor of Rye, N.Y., died Friday (night in Doctors Hospital in Manhattan. Mr. Beaty, a former senior partner in the Manhattanlaw firm of Reeves, Todd, Ely 8i Beaty, was 97 years old and lived at 200 East 66th Street.

title: Judy Bernard Is Bride Of Ronald Baron, Broker
description: Judy Bernard, a systems specialist with the Chase Manhattan Bank, was married yesterday to Ronald Stephen Baron, a stockbroker with Herzfeld & Stern. The ceremony was performed at the Harmonie Club by Rabbi Sidney Schulman of Deal. N.J.

title: TV: Portrait of Rudolf Serkin
description: WITH ABC presenting Hollywood's annual Oscar ceremonies at 10, the question of tonight's ratings dominance is automatically settled. The Academy Awards are traditionally in the charmed blockbuster circle.

title: Yet Another Prison. Stirs Protest in Orange County
description: GOSHEN, N.Y.They aren't building as many houses as they did in the boom days of the late 1960's and early 1970's in suburbanrural Orange County, but the area still has at least one growth industry: prisons.

title: Edward Bliss, Engineer Who Designed Equipment For '69 Lunar Landing
description: Edward Bliss, who designed the transmitter for the Lunar Excursion Module, used during the first moon landing in 1969, died Saturday at Memorial SloanKettering hospital. Mr. Bliss, who lived in Mountain Lakes,. N.J., was 47 years old.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Violin: Zeitlin's Recital
description: ZVI ZEITLIN was clearly not aiming to lull the audience with a program of familiar violin staples during his recital Saturclay night at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.WH.A. Nearly everything he played made special demands on the listener but on the whole his off beat choices proved to be rewarding.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Amy Makes Air Force One More Like Home
description: BADAGRI. Nigeria, April 2The people of this western Nigerian town poured out of their thatchedroof huts and into the dirt streets today to stage an exuberant and affectionate welcome for two guests from abroad: Rosalynn and Amy Carter.

title: Columbia Oarsmen Win From Marist
description: The Columba varsity heavyweight crew, rowing into a 35mileanhour wind, defeated Marist College yesterday by seven lengths on the Harlem River.

title: A Colt Built For Two
description: HALLANDALE, Fla., April 2When the field for the Florida Derby left the paddock. Jorge Velasquez spoke to Sammy Renick, a jockey of earlier vintage standing in the walking ring. Want to get up, Sammy? Alydar's rider asked. He'll carry both of us.

title: Curare Trial Marked by 3Way Courtroom Strife
description: HACKENSACK, N.J.From the beginning of the fiveweekold curare murder trial here of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich, the prosecuting attorney, Sybil R. Moses, has been taunted, insulted and mocked by the defense attorney who, in her view, has been implicitly encouraged by the judge.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TOLSTOY TONIGHT No, it's not Anna Karenina on television but the revival of an acclaimed program,of selected writings of Leo Tolstoy, as read by professional actors some 20 years ago in the Master Institute's Round Table Series. The free event tonight at 6 features five performers, among them Michael Higgins, who appeared opposite Tammy Grimes in Molly, and Yusef Bulos.

title: Board Asks Koch to Ban New Microwave Facilities
description: In response to growing public concern over the longterm effects of microwave radiation, the Board of Standards and Appeals has asked Mayor Koch to impose a temporary moratorium on the construction or installation of microwave transmission facilities in the city until realistic guidelines are established for their approval.

title: 5 Children Die in Blaze at House That Firemen Thought Was Empty
description: BATON ROUGE, La., April 2 (UPI)Five children who had been left alone and asleep while their mother ran errands died last night in a fire at the house, which firemen delayed entering because they thought it was empty.

title: In Baseball's Best Interests
description: AS opening day fast approaches, let us not forget that organized baseball remains the best argument around for the existence of the antitrust laws. Baseball, of course, is exempt from antitrust legislation. The Supreme Court affirmed that in the Curt Flood case several years ago. Flood, you will remember, was a wonderful outfielder for the St. Louis Cardinals who was traded against his wishes to the Philadelphia Phillies. He was a proud man who had the revolutionary thought that a human being should not be bartered. So he sued the commissioner of baseball, Bowie Kuhn, et al.

title: Sporting Gear
description: Sailors can now add sun power to their energy arsenal. Solar panels that can charge a battery and produce electricity for navigation lights, instruments, radio, refrigeration and other amenities are built into or mounted onto a hull without affecting the boat's speed. The largest panel available measures 15 inches by 46 inches, the smallest one square inch. The size and the number of panels depend on how much energy you need. A sevenwatt unit produces onehalf an ampere for a 12volt system, supplying enough electricity for a small boat, and costs about $600. The panels work during daylight hours, even when the sun is hidden, and are encased to keep out moisture and corrosion. From Solar Power Corporation, 20 Cabot Road, Woburn, Mass. 01801.

title: Gregg and Frisselle First at Talladega
description: TALLADEGA, Ala., April 2 (AP)Peter Gregg and Brad Frisselle teamed to win the $58,000 Six Hours of Talladega road race today at Alabama International Motor Speedway.

title: Fight Over Reservation Divides 2 Indians
description: SAULT STE. MARIE, Mich.Verna Lawrence likes her local nickname, the Indian Martha Mitchell because it fits her uninhibited style, her reputation for picking up the phone and blasting away at anyone who disagrees with her. She is a Chippewa Indian, and she is fighting mad these days.

title: United Way Accused of Monopoly In Fight Over Charitable Funds
description: LOS ANGELES, April 2A bitter feud, with billions of dollars in charitable donations at stake; is being fought between United Way, the nation's dominant volunteer charity, and scores of smaller charitivs across the country.

title: Greeks Criticizing U.S. on Turkey
description: ATHENS, April 2Leading Greek political figures reacted with rare unanimity today in deploring the Carter Administration's plan to ask Congress to end the arms embargo against Turkey without waiting for Turkish concessions on Cyprus.

title: Floating Among the Clouds
description: It soars, it glides, it lifts, it floats. Up in the atmosphere, sometimes the stratosphere. Over mountains, through clouds. Without an engine, without fuel. A 600pound symmetrical bird.

title: New Fiscal Woes in Albany?
description: Once again, New York State faces this week still another potential fiscal crisis, this time brought on by Republicans in the State Senate who have now held up approval of the state's $12 billion budget over their insistence that Medicaid funds for abortions be deleted. The resulting Impasse has occurred despite what appeared to be the best efforts of the Republican Senate majority leader, Warren M. Anderson of Binghamton, to keep the abortion dispute from getting out of control.

title: Maharajahs, Shorn of Power, Are Finding New Roles in India
description: JODHPUR, India  Now that he has grown accustomed to the foreign tourists who troop through his 250room palace, the Maharajah of Jodhpur has decided to give them access to his grandfather's two oldworldly private railway cars and the ancestral hunting lodge as well.

title: Rock: Suicide, a TwoMan Novelty Band
description: SUICIDE, which was at CBGB's over the weekend, is a twoman Sick band that has been around for several years but has just nowwith most of the leading New York underground bands signed to major labels and distinct signs that people are looking for novelties beyond punk basicsbegun to attract attention, particularly in Britain.

title: What Price Labor Peace?
description: It is good to find New York City riding to work as usual this morning. But that is not to say that the deal Governor Carey and Mayor Koch have struck with the transit workers is necessarily good for the city. Labor peace is precious, to political leaders and to the economy of New York, but it cannot command any price. The people of the city, state and nation who are being asked to help rescue New York from financial disaster must know the price before they can reach a fair judgment.

title: De Gustibus: More on Those Guests Who Want to Help With the Dishes
description: In an essay on manners, the proposition was recently put forth that the greatest blessing my guests can offer me is to maintain their places around my table at the end of a meal and not stand, jump or otherwise get onto their feet to give a hand in the kitchen. It was implicit that people who try. to help out are a postprandial blight on order and sanity.

title: CARTER SEEKS TALKS INCLUDING ALL SIDES IN RHODESIA CONFLICT
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, April 2President Carter said here today that the United States, responding to the urgings of black African leaders, was moving as quickly as possible to convene a peace conference on Rhodesia that would involve all parties to the conflict.

title: Commodities
description: Traders in gold futures contracts, normally a steel nerved group, have suddenly begun to display symptoms of extreme nervousness. They are becoming more responsive to technical market factors (such as price and volume figures) than to fundamental influences (such as inflation, the value of the dollar and supply and demand for gold).

title: Courage, Compassion of 2 Slain Officers Recalled
description: Around this time of the year, Norman Cerullo, already well liked by his fellow police officers, would find himself becoming particularly popular at the 79th Precinct station house in Brooklyn, where he had worked for the last eight years.

title: COMMISSION IN SRI LANKA TO INVESTIGATE EXPREMIER
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, April 1Sri Lanka's Government has appointed a presidential commission of inquiry to look into allegations of abuse and misuse of power during the sevenyear rule of former Prime Minister Sirimavo Bandaranaike.

title: Rock: The Good Rats
description: THE GOOD RATS has been heard of, and sometimes heard around New York, for 10 years now. Occasionally it has surfaced, made a record and appeared at showcases s like the Bottom Line. More often, it has been the suburban bar band par excellence, playing loud and hard through long, bleary nights. With its new Aristadistributed album and last weekend's Bottom Line engage merit it seems to be entering another of its overwound phases.

title: Hetty Magill, Gary Dolgins Are Married in Bridgeport
description: In Temple B'nai Israel in Bridgeport, Conn., yesterday afternoon, Hetty Lynn Magill, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Philip Magill of Bridgeport, was married to Gary Howard Dolgins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Dolgins of Chicago. Rabbi Arnold Sher performed tie ceremony.

title: PRESS AND BROADCASTERS STRUCK 2D DAY IN ISRAEL
description: TEL AVIV, April 2The Israeli press, television and radio were silenced by a wage dispute for the second day today.

title: A TAX ON OIL IS SUGGESTED FOR SOCIAL SECURITY COSTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 2  Representative Al Ullman, the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, said today that a proposed tax on crude oil could be used, on at least an interim, basis, to relieve the pressure of added Social Security taxes.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY TransAtlantic

title: Pop: Love of Life Band
description: THE Love of Life Orchestra, also known as LOLO, which appeared at the Kitchen Friday and Saturday nights, represents an interesting development on the Salo music and arts scene. This is a band that makes music to entertain, but uses not only elements of popular music and jazz, but also of avantgarde music, poetry and video. It is a dance band by artists for artists, and Saturday night, with the normally austere loft space festooned with balloons and otherwise tricked up with nightclubish accouterments, and a varied assortment of SoHo denizens dancing away glee, fully, it certainly accomplished its primary task.

title: OIL GLUT IS CREATED BY ALASKA PIPELINE
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 2  Less than a year after its opening, the transAlaskan pipeline has produced a vast oversupply of oil on the West Coast.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (AP)Americans lost about SI billion through mailorder schemes last year, the Post it Service has found. That was nearly double Ithe loss the previous year. $514 million.

title: I.B.M.'s Minicomputers Capture A Share of an Expanding Market
description: The international Business Machines Corporation, the giant maker of computers, has established a beachhead in the swiftly growing market for minicomputers.

title: EXENVOY TO SEOUL CONFIRMS BUGGING
description: WASHINGTON, April 2A former Untied States Ambassador to South Korea, William J. Porter, has confirmed that an American intelligence agency placed an electronic listening device in the executive mansion of President Park Chung Hee in Seoul.

title: DELIVERERS IN ACCORD AT TIMES AND NEWS
description: Douglas La Chance, the president of the newspaper deliverers union, said yes. terday that an agreement with The Daily News and The New York Times would mean a wage increase of $68 a week over three years.

title: U.S. Court Rules Out Deafness as a Bar to College's Nursing School
description: WASHINGTON, April 2A Federal appeals court has ruled that a nursing school could not deny admission to an applicant who suffered from a severe hearing disability, even if the applicant night require expensive special training techniques.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter said in Lagos, Nigeria, that the United States was moving as quickly as possible to convene a peace conference on Rhodesia and was doing so in response to the urging of black African leaders. The to would involve all parties to the conflict, Mr. Carter said, and that we will being now to explore the earliest date when this might be accomplished. He pruposed such a meeting at a Washington news conference three weeks ago. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: CoOp Aid, Not Rent Subsidies, Is Clinton Hill's Goal
description: Residents of the Clinton Hill community, one of Brooklyn's urban revival areas, are fighting a proposal for a Federal rentsubsidy project in their neighborhood, even though it would mean the longsought rejuvenation of a blighted, abandoned hotel.

title: Revolution in South: Blacks at the Polls and in Office
description: James 0. Eastland, Mississippi's Senator for 36 years and the owner of a vast Delta cotton plantation, had never been accustomed to hearing bad news from black men. But bad news was what he heard in January from Aaron E. Henry, state president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, when they met to discuss Mr. Eastland's prospects for reelection.

title: Outbreaks of Disease Among Cattle Spur Strict Controls in Colorado
description: DENVER, April 2A highly contagious and itchy parasitic skin infection among cattle has reached epizootic proportions in Colorado and has cost the state's cattle industry more than $4 million, officials say.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 3, 1978

title: Books of TheTimes
description: THE LIFE OF THE MIND. By Hannah Arendt. Volume One: Thinking: 258 pages. $12:50. Volume Two: Willing, 272 pages. Harcourt Brace Jovanavich. $12.50.

title: Arias and Praises Sung at State Opera Ball
description: NEWARK, April 2A passageway in United Airlines Terminal A at Newark International Airport was transformed into a glittering avenue of attractions for the eye, ear and palate last night at the New Jersey State Opera's annual ball.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, ?? Don Giovanni, 8.

title: TransitAccord Pattern Rejected By Leader of Firefighters Union
description: The presideqt of the Uniformed Firefighters Association Union, Richard J. Vizzini, yesterday echoed the Patrolman's Benevolent Association in rejecting the tentative contract settlement reached with New York City's transit workers as a pattern. He termed the agreement totally inadequate and wholly unacceptable to firefighters.

title: Reds Beat Koosmar
description: TAMPA, Fla., April 2For a change, the New York Mets didn't suffer any disabling injuries today. But they also didn't win a ball game, as the Cincinnati Reds tagged Jerry Koosman with a 31 defeat that sent the Mets to their 12th loss in the last 17 exhibition games.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Soccer Fans Revel in a BigTime Atmosphere
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 2 Steaks sizzled and liquor flowed from the tailgates. Longlegged cheerleaders cheered as their pornpons futterecl it the sharp breeze. The day was crisp and clear in an autumnal setting perfect for college football.

title: Bridge:
description: The old problem of what to do when a strong foursome is reduced by illness to a strong threesome just before the start of a major team event was solved in a successful fashion by some New York experts in Pittsburgh Saturday. Lawrence Berkley, John Washington, Charles Ferguson and Fred Jones, all of New York, planned to play in the Swiss team championship at the American Bridge Association's spring nationals.

title: NEW CLUES SOUGHT TO TROPICAL DISEASES
description: BALTIMOREWhat are 30 different kinds of mosquitoes native to the tropical islnds of Polynesia doing buzzing around the confined spaces of a windowless room in Baltimore?

title: Revolution in South: Blacks at the Polls and in Office
description: James O. Eastland, Mississippi's Senator for 36 years and the owner of a vast Delta cotton plantation, had never been accustomed to hearing bad news from black men. But bad news was what he heard in January from Aaron E. Henry, state president of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, when they met to discuss Mr. Eastland's prospects for reelection.

title: Steel Output Rose 2.5% in Week Ended April 1 to 2.55 Million Tons
description: Steel production for the week ended April I rose 2.5 percent to 2.55 million tons, according to the American Iron and Steel Institute. The industry produced 2.49 million tons the week before.

title: Suspects in Killing of 2 Policemen Were Indicted in Attica Murders
description: The two men the police say killed two highly decorated police officers Sunday had each been charged with slaying fellow inmates during the 1971 uprising at Attica state orison.

title: Suspects in Killing of 2 Policemen Were Indicted in Attica Murders
