title: Canada Raises Prime Rate to 8%
description: OTTAWA, April 3 (Reuters)  The Bank of Canada announced today it was increasing its prime lending rate to 8 percent from 8 percent, effective tomorrow. It was the second time in less than a month that Canada's central bank had increased its prime lending ratethe rate banks charge their most creditworthy customersand came as the Canadian dollar fell below 83 United States cents on exchange markets for the first time since 1933.

title: JOURNALISM GROUP NAMES SIGMA DELTA CHI WINNERS
description: CHICAGO, April 3 (UPI)The Society of Professional Journalists announced today the winners of the 46th annual Sigma Delta Chi awards for distinguished service in journalism.

title: AIDES REPORT CARTER BANS NEUTRON BOMB; SOME SEEK REVERSAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 3Administration officials said today that President Carter had decided against producing the controversial neutron bomb.

title: Events Today
description: METROPOLITAN OPERA, Lincoln Center, Puccini's Testa, 8.

title: Churches Ship Wheat to Vietnam
description: HOUSTON, April 3A ship loaded with 10,000 tons of wheat, much of it donated by American farmers, left Houston last night for Vietnam.

title: Saturday Review's New Owners Taking Over With April 15 Issue
description: The new guard is taking over at Saturday Review, the 54-year-old magazine that started life as the Satruday Review of Literature and now covers a variety of issues and the arts including, secondlarily, the world of books.

title: Dividends
description: MONDAY, APRIL 3, 1978

title: TV Networks Announce Casts For Some of Next Fall's Series
description: Casting communiqus from various camps in television yesterday were heavy with notable names being brought to the fore in an effort to carry the dayand nightin the competitive and continuous audiencepopularity ratings wars of the medium.

title: Palestinian Guerrilla Chief Buried
description: BAGHDAD. Iraq, April 3 (AP)Dr. Wadi Haddad, the Palestinian guerrilla leader, was buried in an Anglican cemetery here today. Dr. Haddad, who was Greek Orthodox, died last Tuesday in an unnamed North African country of what the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, which he helped found, described as an incurable disease. Palestinian sources believe it was leukemia.

title: Notes on People
description: John Wayne underwent successful open heart surgery at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston yesterday. A spokesman for the cardiac surgeons who performed the operation said that his condition is satisfactory. The 70yearold actor's surgery was for replacement of a mitral valve, which had erupted, with similar tissue from a pig. The mitral valve is between the left atrium and right ventricle of the heart. The spokesman said: The operation came after Wayne's own physicians in Newport Beach, Calif., concluded he could be helped by replacement of the valve. There was full agreement among the Massachusetts General cardiology team that mitral valve surgery should be carried out. Mr. Wayne entered the hospital last Wednesday. Two of his sons had denied for several days that he faced. heart surgery.

title: A.M.C.'s Pact With Renault Brightens Mood of Workers
description: KENOSHA, Wisc., April 3  For months, the unemplcyment line in this. eastern Wisconsin industrial town has been long, end the aces en it ???ordingly grim. The jobless rate last month was 11 percent.

title: Britain and U.S. Dispatching Envoys
description: LONDON, April 3 (Reuters)United States and British envoys will start tour of southern Africa soon in an intensified attempt to win adoption of the BritishAmerican peace plan for Rhodesia, the Foreign Office announced today.

title: May Homers in Japan
description: TOKYO, April 3 (AP)A former New York Yankee, Carlos May, playing his first year in Japan, hit his first home run for the Nankai Hawks today in 43 loss to the Hankyu Braves.

title: Mrs. Boglioli Swims Despite Pregnancy
description: Wendy Boglioli has been swimming competitively so long that friends and rivals call her mom. When the 23-year-old Oympic champion competes in the Amateur Athletic Union national shortcause meet starting tomorrow in Austin, Tex., there will be another reason for the nickname: She is five months pregnant.

title: Unrest Spurs New Canadian Investment in Florida
description: MIAMI, April 3Canadian investors, alarmed by economic and political trends at home, ere rushing to buy Florida real estate as a hedge against an uncertain future.

title: Dr. Kendall A. Elsom, Professor At U. of Pennsylvania Hospital, 73
description: Dr, Kendall A. Elsom, professor emerituS of clinical medicine at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania and former medical director of the Scott Paper Company of Philadelphia, died yestarday of cancer at his home in Haverford. Pa. He was 73 years old.

title: Three Confirmed for ArtsCouncil
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (UPI)The Senate today confirmed the nominations of three members of the National Council of the Arts. Confirmed by voice vote, without opposition, were Theodore Bikel, Maurn Dees and Jacob Lawrence.

title: Around the Nation
description: HOUSTON (UPI), April 3Two Governmentsponsored studies are schedule:i to begin soon to determine if heroin more effective than morphine in relieving the severe pain experienced by cancer patients, cancer specialists said today. The studies would be the first in the United States to see if the drug, long associated with street addicts, has a role in controlling the pain produced by cancer.

title: New York State Willing to Ease Truck Ban on 9W
description: New York State transportation officials have expressed willingness to case the monthold ban on 10ton trucks along a 5.8mile stretch of Route 9W in south ern Rockland County, officials disclosed yesterday in United States District Court in Manhattan.

title: Unrest Spurs New Canadian Investment in Florida
description: MIAMI, April 3Canadian investors, alarmed by economic and political trends at home, are rushing to buy Florida real estate as a hedge against an uncertain future.

title: Workers of Struck S.I Rapid Transit .Ask Higher Pay
description: A wildcat strike shut down the Staten Island Rapid Transpit Line early yesterday morning.

title: Advertising
description: Since consumer testimonials are popular TV commercial form and since the consumers of motor oil are automobiles, what could be a more natural form of a motor oil commercial than car-on-the-street interview.

title: Orioles Defeat Yankees, 32, on Dempsey's Home Run
description: MIAMI, April 3 (AP)Rick Dempsey and Lee May hit home runs tonight to account for all the Baltimore runs as the Orioles edged the New York Yankees, 32,

title: Park Testimony: A Study in Green
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 The room where Tcngsun Park is making his public debut is, appropriately, a study in clashing greens: the walls are mine green, the draperies olive velvet, the carpet is two shades of chartreuse and the preoccupation is with the green of money.

title: Georgia Tech Joins A.C.C.
description: ATLANTA, April 3 (UPI)Georgia Tech officially joined the Atlantic Coast Conference today and will become an eligible participant in conference sports as of July 1. 1979. The action puts the Yellow. Jackets back in a major conference again after 14 years as an independent. They will begin to play in one of the country's top basketball conferences as of the 197980 season. The other members of the conference are Clemson, Duke, Maryland, North Carolina, North Carolina State, Virginia and Wake Forest.

title: Opera: Met's Don Giovanni
description: Several Key Roles Are in the Hands of Newcomers as Company Gives 8th Performance of Work

title: 10 ORGANIZATIONS SHARE DEADLINE CLUB AWARDS
description: Ten news organizations were named yesterday by the Deadline Club in New York to share in the club's annual awards for journalistic excellence in the categories of publicservice reporting, television, radio, financial news, science writing and photography.

title: Going Out Guide
description: ALL IN THE FAMILY One of the country's major dancetheater units. the Dance Theater Workshop, tonight initiates a group of weekly concerts by prominent contemporary com- posers, each of whom has been creatively involved in dance. The experimental and avantgarde series called Tuesday Music, ranges from instrumental and environmental scores to synthesizer and electronic tape work.

title: CHARLES J. KERN, AT 65; LED WYETH LABORATORIES
description: Chaiiles J. Kern, who retired as chairman of Wyeth Laboratories March 31, died yesterday of pneumonia) at Bryn Mawr (Pa,) Hospital. He was 65 years old and lived in Berwyn, Pa.

title: Parents Ask State To Force L .I. District To Pay for Busing
description: MINEOLA, LI, April 3 (UPI)A group of parents in Lakeview, a predominantly black community, today asked State Education Commissioner Gordon M. Ambach to order the Malverne School District to pay the cost of busing their chilldren to two elementary schools in Malverne.

title: New Con Edison Electricity Rates Posted By P.S.C. to Vary in Summer and Winter
description: A new electricrate structure that increases charges for the highdemand summer months and lowers them in the winter was posted yesterday for nearly 3 million customers of the Consolidated Edison Company.

title: Odds on Yanks, DodgersReds
description: RENO, Nev., April 3 (UPI)Harrah's RenoTahoe Racebook picked the New York Yankees today to win the American League pennant and made the Los Angeles Dodgers and Cincinnati Reds cofavorites to win in the National League. The Yanks are a 57 choice, followed by Kansas City and Texas, both at 72. The Dodgers and the Reds are both 75, followed by the Philadelphia Phillies at 21.

title: TexasSized Gift Sent by Lemons
description: Mike Manuche, the restaurateur, said he got the biggest, heaviest and most astonishing present in 28 years in the business last weekenda 500pound brown and white steer.

title: BROOKS T. KELLER
description: Brooks T. Keller, a special agent in charge of liaison with lawenforcement agencies and the news media for the New York office of the United States Secret Service, died yesterday of an apparent heart attack at his home in Manhattan. He was 44 years old.

title: HERMAN H. ANGEL
description: MERIDEN, Conn., April 3 (UPI)Herman H. Angel, former city editor and state political columnist for The Morning Record in Meriden, died yesterday at the age of 78 in the MeridenWallingford Hospital.

title: Irony And Conversion
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  Irony is a fre. quent fruit of politics, as was seldom better evidenced than when Patricia Roberts Harris made the featured address to the South Carolina State Democratic Convention here this past week- end. It wasn't just that Mrs. Harris, the black woman who is Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, came to Republican Senator J. Strom Thurmond's home grounds and pitched into him with bare knuckles. His past, the Secretary declared, must not be forgottendespite his recent conversion to shaking black hands now that they can vote.

title: Most Say They Treated Park Money as Campaign Gift
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (UPI)Current and former members of Congress who were named today as having received cash from Tongsun Park, the South Korean rice merchant, said later that the money was campaign contributions often given without their knowledge.

title: Deaths
description: REICHELMinnieBeloved wife of the late Julius. Devoted mother of Anna Harris. Elsie Hirsh and the late Dr. E. Lawrence Reichel. Adored grandmother of Dr. Jeffrey, Dr. Joel, Richard, Denise and Toby. Truly a gracious lady who will be missed by everyone. Services Gutterman's Chapel, Rockville Centre at Greystone, Wed April Sat 2PM.

title: ASPHALT CONTRACTS AWARDED AFTER SUIT
description: Contracts for more than $10 million worth of asphalt that New York City declined to award two weeks agoafter charges of past collusion by asphalt bidderswere awarded yesterday.

title: China and the Common Market Sign a Five-Year Trade Accord
description: BRUSSELS, April 3 (AP)China and the European Economic Community signed their first trade agreeinent today, a fiveyear pact with few specific commitments but considerable political significance.

title: FORD CALLS FOR A TAX CUT OF $70 BILLION IN 197880
description: CHICAGO, April 3 (Reuters)Former President Gerald R, Ford called today for a Federal tax cut of $70 billion over three years and said President Carter's tax reduction and reform proposals were inadequate to stimulate the economy

title: White House Would Allot Oil Levy To Offset Social Security Tax Cut
description: WASHINGTON, April 3The Carter Administration is prepared to go along with a Congressional proposal that revenues from a new crude oil tax be earmarked to pay for a cut in Social Security payroll taxes, qualified sources said today.

title: Japan Sets Airport Opening
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, April 4 (Reuters)The Japanese Cabinet formally approved a Government decision today to open Tokyo's controversial new airport at Narita on May 20, with flights to begin the following day. The airport's opening was postponed after leftists smashed control tower equipment

title: An Anatomy of Fiscal. Woes At Logan Hospital
description: Despite evidence of growing financial and management problems at Arthur C. Logan Memorial Hospital in Harlem, city, state, and Federal authoritiesreportedly influenced by community pressurescontinued for years to subsidize mounting debt without proper monitoring, according to investigators.

title: N.B.A. Entering Its Final Week With Playoff Matchups Unclear
description: Although eight of 12 teams have clinched National Basketball Association playoff berths, none of the pairings has been decided. Firstround playoff games are scheduled to begin next Tuesday and. Wednesday, but the games in the final week of the season will determine opponents.

title: President Cautions The South Africans; Ends 4Nation Trip
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, April 3President Carter warned South Africa today not to reject a Westernbacked United Nations plan for bringing majority rule to SouthWest Africa.

title: Hillside Strangler Suspect Is Freed
description: LOS ANGELES, April 3 (UPI)Peter Mark Jones, a 37-year-old handyman held as a suspect in two of the hillside strangler murders, was released today because of lack of evidence against him.

title: Murdoch to Face Trial Thursday
description: Don Murdoch, the New York Ranger's 21-year-old right wing, will stand trial Thursday morning in Brampton (Ontario) Provincial Court on charges of possession of cocaine.

title: Nigeria Again Frees American Executive
description: WASHINGTON, April 3Louis LeFevre, an American who was held in a Nigerian prison without charge during President Carter's visit, was freed and returned to his home in Lagos today, the State Department said.

title: AIDES REPORT CARTER BANS NEUTRON BOMB; SOME SEEK REVERSAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 3Administration officials said today that President Carter had decided against producing the controversial neutron bomb.

title: 2 Dead, 1 Lost in FamilyBoat Mishap
description: DELAWARE CITY, Del., April 3 (AP)An 8-year-old boy was still missing today after a weekend boating accident in which his father and 10-year-old brother drowned in an apparent search for the mother, who leaped off the Delaware Memorial Bridge in February. Local volunteer firemen continued to search the Delaware River near here for Rick Sponsel, the missing boy. The bodies of the boy's father, Aaron Sponscil, 29, and the boy's brother, Steve, 10, washed up on a small island in the river yesterday.

title: Johns Hopkins Lacrosse Team Is Strong on Defense
description: Johns Hopkins's lacrosse team is midway through its campaign, and Coach Henry Ciccarone could not be more pleased by the results.

title: G. Schmidt in Pact For Schaefer Bonds
description: C. Schmidt & Sons, which brews Schmidt hoer at plants in Philadelphia and Cleveland, has signed an agreement in principle to acquire $20 million worth of convertible debentures in the F. & M. Schaefer Corporation. The debentures, due in 1998, are convertible. into 769,232 shares, oil 20 percent, of Schaefer.

title: Annie Hall Wins 4 AcademyAwards
description: LOS ANGELES, Tuesday, April 4Woody Allen's Annie Hall, was named best picture of the year and took three other prizes as the Hollywood film industry staged the 50th anniversary award ceremonies of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

title: Behind Foreign Aid
description: WASHINGTONOne billion people in the developing world are surviving without adequate food, shelter or health care, yet it is increasingly difficult to justify. to the American people our contributions for foreign economic assistance.

title: Painting is Slashed By Vandal in London
description: LONDON, April 3 (AP)A man slashed and tore to pieces Nicolas Poussin's 17th - century masterpiece Adoration of the Golden Calf at London's National Gallery today.

title: F.T.C. Upheld on Listerine's Ads As Supreme Court Bars a Review
description: WASHINGTON, April 3The manutacturers of Listerine must spend $10 million advertising the fact that their mouthwash will not help prevent colds or sore throats or lessen their severity or stop advertising altogether, under a ruling the Supreme Court left standing today.

title: KOCH, IN SHIFT, SAYS T.W.U. PACT WON'T SET PATTERN FOR OTHERS
description: In a surprise reversal from both his own previous statements and the history of municipal labor relations, Mayor Koch declared yesterday that there is no linkage between the transit workers contract and the contracts of municipal employees.

title: Steinbrenner at Peace With Racing Manager
description: HIALEAH, Fla., April 3George Steinbrenner didn't find a left fielder today at Hialeah Park, but he did get to see his favorite race horse.

title: Kentucky Breeders Curbed
description: The United States Department of Agriculture issued a quarantine order yesterday banning the shipment of thoroughbred breeding horses out of the state of Kentucky. The order. which is for an unlimited time. was prompted by the outbreak last month of contagious equine metritis, a venereal disease that has been found at 14 breeding farms in the state.

title: People and Business
description: L. B. Maytag, chairman of National Airlines Inc., said yesterday that the airline industry's profits would be hurt by what he called excessively discounted airline fares, even though these fares are bringing a substantial increase in traffic.

title: Stock Prices Decline Amid Anxiety Over Inflation and Interest Rates
description: A combination of negative factorsranging from fears of increased inflation and higher interest rates at home to renewed weakness in the dollar abroadsent stock prices lower yesterday across a broad front.

title: Met Planning For Crowds At Tut Show
description: Although Treasures of Tutankhamen will not arrive  at the Metropolitan Museum of Art until next Dec. 20, museum officials are already making plans to handle the. anticipated large crowds. During the exhibition fourmonth stay, the museum will be open 82 hours a weekthe greatest number in its historyand will operate on a sevenday schedule. This replaces the usual sixday 45hour week.

title: To Africa With Promises
description: President Carter's visit to Africa was no mere courtesy call. His Administration's positions, shaped and articulated by advocates like Andrew Young, have led African governments to expect much from the United States. The President's own statements in Africa have added to those expectations and will increase the pressure to see them realized.

title: A Suspect Is Accused of Throwing Acid At Columbia Student, Imperiling Her Eye
description: A former Massachusetts Institute of Technology student from Hong Kong has been charged with throwing acid in the face of a Columbia University student who apparently had rejected his efforts to rekindle their friendship.

title: News Summary
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 4, 1978

title: Dayan, Visiting Rumania, Confers With Ceausescu On Middle East Issues
description: BUCHAREST, Rumania, April 3 (Reuters)Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan explained Israel's negotiating position today in three hours of talks with President Nicolae Ceausescu and other officials.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter has decided that the United States will not produce the neutron bomb, Administration officials said. The decision was reported to have been made against the advice of the President's principal foreign policy advisers. Mr. Carter, they said, concluded that the production of the weapon would be contrary to the stand he has taken on nuclear disarmament. The officials said that, in a formal announcement this week, Mr. Carter would likely say that he expected the Soviet Union to show similar restraint in the deployment of new nuclear weapons. [Page 1, Column 6.3

title: Chile Allows Exile to Return
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 3Chile's military Government tonight authorized the return of Jaime Castillo Velasoo, a promiineit Christian Democrat who has been living in exile in Venezuela. Mr. Castiklo, a lawyer who championed the civil rights of dissidents and criticized the secret police, was expelled in October 1976.

title: Parcel Room Lost  & Found; Grand Central Finds Treasure And Trash Left By Commuters; What Was In the Bag?; False Teeth and Crutches; Systematized Cartons; Commuter Goes Hungry
description: In the windowless storage room of Grand Central Terminal's lost-andfound area, the fluorescent lighting obscures the time of day. But it cannot shut out the grand progression of the equinoxes.

title: Business Records
description: Monday, April 3, 1978

title: CORRECTION
description: The National Endowment for the Arts was incorrectly listed in the Week end section last Friday as a sponsor of the American tour of Pompeii A.D. 79, a comprehensive exhibition of rel, ics recovered from the ruins of Pone peii. It should have been the National Endowment for the Humanities.

title: One Refugee's Story: Hope Turns to Ashes
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 3Scarcely three weeks ago, Samira Eid was looking forward to a new life of peace and security. Her husband, Mohammed, who had emigrated to Kuwait, had come to take her and the family away from southern Lebanon.

title: Suit Fights Censorship of a Play
description: PRINCETON, April 3. (UPI)Two drama students at Princeton High School who are fighting to keep vulgar words in their class play, persuaded a judge today to allow them to use the words during rehearsals.

title: $6 Billion Is Misspent by H.EW
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)The Department of Health, Education and Welfare misspent $6.3 billion to $7.4 billion in the fiscal year 1977 because of waste, fraud and abuse, the Office of Inspector General said today.

title: A Maverick's Guide to SelfEducation
description: Gail Thain Parker, the former president of Bennington College who resigned two years ago amid an uproar that involved an extramarital affair with professor, a vote of noconfidence by the faculty, and charges that she made bad lasagna, was in town the other day to promote her new book, College on Your Own.

title: Without Martin Luther King
description: Who knows where Martin Luther King Jr. would have stood this morning had he not been gunned down Memphis ten years ago. His struggle for desegregation in the cities and towns of the Deep South was close won. The drive for economic justice had just begun. The trek to Memphis to support a strike of garbage workers seeking higher wages was symbolic of a new situation.

title: In Milan, the Classic Prevailed Over the Romantic
description: MILAN The week of Italian fashion shows ended with a flourish as tailored, paireddown clothes for next fall and winter vied for store buyers attention with mad, fantastic ones. In fashion's version of the traditional battle between classics and romantics, the classics won, hands down. The purpose of the showings is, after all, to sell clothes. It is easier to sell a tailored suit than whoosh of ruffles.

title: Hatfield Faces Montanans Angry Over His Vote on Panama Pact
description: BUTTE, Mont, March 31Senator Paul G. Hatfield was sitting around the teamsters union hall, sharing coffee and donuts and talk with several dozen. members Then a tall, lean man in the back of the room said he wanted to ask about the Senator's vote in favor of the Panama Canal treaty.

title: European Flight From Dollar
description: PARIS, April 3The flight from the dollar gathered speed on European money markets today. following news of February's record United States trade deficit, which had already sent the American currendy tumbling in late trading last Friday.

title: Corporation Affairs Jewel and Skaggs to Swap Stock And Merge Into a New Company
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 3 (AP)  A Utah judge today lifted a restraining order against the CurtissWright Corporation in its announced efforts to take control of the Kennecott Copper Corporation. District Court Judge David K. Winder lifted the ban he had imposed March 21 and extended last Thursday against CurtissWright's purchasing, voting or seeking proxies for its recently acquired 9.9 percent interest in Kennecott. Kennecott officials in New York had no immediate comment.

title: Radio
description: 69 A.M., WKCR. Second Sympin. ny; Gayne Ballet, Rhapsody Concerto for Cello and Orchestra, Khatchaturian.

title: Spoilin4 Court Reform
description: It is hard to tell from the maneuverings in Albany that New York's voters wanted court reform when they approved amendments to the State Constitution last fall. The state legislators are supposed to give body to the constitutional change, which was billed as a streamlining of the judiciary's disciplinary, administrative and selection processes. Against that measure, many of their proposals are retrogressive.

title: Braila
description: LOENGARDRichard Otto. On April 1st at home in New York City. Beloved husband of Margery Borg Loengard; devoted father of Ursula Berens, Richard Otto, Jr., John Borg; loving grandfather of Charles, Maranda, Jennifer, Anna and Philippa. Services at Frank E Campbell Madison Avenue at 81st Wednesday April 5th at 11:30am. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Jacob A. Riis Neighborhood Settlement would be appreciated.

title: Municipal Unions to Resume Bargaining Today
description: The coalition of unicns that represents 200,000 municipal employes will resume bargaining today in an effort to win a contract that matches the new transit agreement despite Mayor Koch's assertion yesterday that there was no linkage between the two.

title: CARTER SAID TO PLAN TOUGH STATEMENT SOON ON INFLATION
description: WASHINGTON, April 3White House sources said today that President Carter would probably issue a tough anti-inflation statement in about 10 days.

title: Kennedy Asks I.R.S. Crackdown On Sports Event Business Trips
description: WASHINGTON, April 3 (AP)Senator Edward M. Kennedy wants the Internal Revenue Service to crack down on businessmen who use corporate planes for business trips that take them to sites of events such as the Masters Golf Tournament and the Kentucky Derby.

title: Gains of the President's Trip
description: MONROVIA, Liberia, April 3While specific differences emerged with the governments at each stop in President Carter's sevenday trip to South America and Africa, Mr. Carter and his aides flew home today feeling that he had established considerable personal rapport with several important and influential thirdworld leaders.

title: Strange Doings in Albany
description: The foes of abortion have succeeded in blocking approval of New York State's budget, holding $7.2 billion aid to local governments hostage to the cause. The budget has been passed by the Assembly but a Senate amendment would prohibit the use of Medicaid funds for abortions except to save the life of the mother. Unless the deadlock is broken quickly, money for all statefunded local programs will cease to flow, and the ability of the state and localities to borrow vitally needed cash will be jeopardized.

title: Judge in Curare Case Turns Down Request to Disqualify Himself
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., April 3The judge in the murder case of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich said today that he saw nothing in the record to convince me that justice was not done and rejected a prosecution motion that he disqualify himself on the ground that he was incapable of conductine a fair trial.

title: Unions Say They Will Insist on Matching T.W.U. Pact
description: The roalition of unien: that represents 200,000 municipal employees said yesterday it would insist on a contract that matches the new transit agreement despite Mayor Koch's assertion yesterday that there was.'no linkage between the two

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 4. 1978

title: Vigil On in Memphis To Mark King Death
description: MEMPHIS, April 3 (UPI)Followers who marched beside the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. in the 1960's and others who know him only by legend gathered today at the site of his assassination for an allnight vigil to commemorate the 10th anniversary of his death.

title: Court Ruling Could Raise Costs Of Large ClassAction Lawsuits
description: A decision that could increase the costs for people who file large classaction lawquit; was issued in Manhattan yesterday by the United States Court of Appeals.

title: Dispute Over Navy Role Termed Biggest Defense Fight Since 1949
description: WASHINGTON, April 3A smoldering rebellion by the Navy's leadership against President Carter's effort to limit the Navy's role at sea is turning into one of the biggest defense battles in decades and is threatening to increase the military budget sharply.

title: Trading in Stock Options; Chicago Board; American; Midwest; Midwest; Philadelphia
description: Sales In 100s. Last Is premium (purchase price).

title: 3 Guests at Eglevsky Ballet
description: The Eglevsky Ballet imported three guest artists for its Sunday afternoon performance at the John Cranford Adams Playhouse of Hofstra University. From the Pennsyl- vania Ballet came Alba Calzada and from American Ballet Theatre came Karena Brock and Ted Kivitt. All three were welcome, yet in nice way unnecessary: welcome because they brought glamour to the proceedings, unnecessary because the company is strong enough that it does not require guests to make a favorable impression.

title: Workers of Struck S.I. Rapid Transit Ask Higher Pay
description: A wildcat strike shut down the Staten Island Rapid Transpit Line early yester day morning.

title: U.S. STEEL TO TRIM PRICE RISE OF $10.50, POSSIBLY TO $5.50
description: The United States Steel Corporation, bowing to pressure from its competitors and the Carter Administration, announced yesterday that it would roll back its price increase of $10.50 a ton on most products.

title: Television
Alexander Mintz, Professor Emeritus In Psychology at City College, 75
description: Alexander Mintz, a professor emeritus at City College of New York, died Friday at the Abbot Manor Nursing Home in Plainfield, N.J., of Parkinson's disease. He was 75 years old and his home was at 21 Pleasant Avenue, Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y.

title: Japan Sees Need for U.S. Talks As Dollar Falls to a Low Again
description: TOKYO, Tuesday, April 4The dollar, which has been falling to new postwar lows here almost as regularly as the sun rises, did it again yesterday, closing session of moderate but intense trading at 218.20 yen to the dollar, up slightly from the day's low of 218.15.

title: Princess Margaret's Way of Life Provokes Protests
description: LONDON, April 3Princess Margaret's conduct of her private and public lives, after providing grist for the popular press for months, has come under sharp attack from leftwing members of Parliament and an Anglican bishop.

title: U.S. COURT ORDERS ADAMS TO TESTIFY ON TIRE STUDY
description: WASHtNGTON, April. 3Transportation Department officials, including Secretary Brodk,Adains, have been ordered to appear in person on Wednesday in Federal Disyrice Court in Cleveland to answer chargts, they defied a court order by allegedly releasing the results of an owner survey on radial tires that was especially critical of Firestone tires.

description: Trying Psychic Opening Bid May Confuse Your Partner

title: Jersey Town Finds 11 Cases of Cancer, Six in One School
description: RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 3 (AP)Eleven cancer cases in this Bergen County community in the last three years, including six involving children at the same elementary school, have frightened residents and prompted an investigation by local and state health officials.

title: About Newyork
description: When the Canal Street trade fell off at Magoo's Cafe about 13 years ago, Tom Chaipis, the owner, let a limited number of highprice prostitutes into the place to attract a John trade of executive types who started taking quick cab rides over from the finan- cial canyons for special refreshment.

title: Books of The Times The Saint as KillJoy
description: FINAL PAYMENTS. By Mary Gordon. 297 pages. Random House. $8.95.

title: YaleUniversity Band Recreates A Concert by John Philip Sousa
description: Out they came, the young men and women of the Yale University Band, dressed in a replica of the uniforms worn by the men of the Sousa Band. Out came Keith Brion, the conductor. He wore a white wig, sported a white mustache, wore white gloves, was liberally bemedalled, and carried in his hand. a baton actually used by John Philip Sousa.

title: PAN AM NEAR CHOICE OF A WIDEBODY JET
description: The Pan American World Airways board of directors is expected to decide today which Americanmade widebody jet to order to replace its obsolescent Boeing 707's on longrange routes with modest passenger demand.

title: Aide to ExG.M. Executive Defends Change She Made in His Insurance
description: Helene Barak, the longtime secretary of Paul W. Garrett, a former vice president of General Motors, said yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan that she had made her daughter the beneficiary of his $48,000 insurance policy on instructions from Mr. Garrett. She insisted that he was competent to make the decision.

title: Neutron Bomb Designed for Use in Europe
description: The neutron bomb is a nuclear warhead designed principally to thwart any Soviet tank attack in central Europe.

title: Jawbone Connected To the Headbone
description: Better economists than I are saying President Carter is going to have to start jawboning if he wants to Stop inflation. All very well for a President who can jawbone like a champion, but veteran jawbone writers doubt that Mr. Carter has what it takes.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I. April 3 (AP)Joe Mullaney, who put Providence College on the nation's basketball map, said today he welcomed the job as Brown University's coach.

title: Can Yanks Front Office Win
description: In evaluating the New York Yankees opportunity win the World Series again, the natural emphasis is on all their millionaire players and on Billy Martin, the manager who must tame those lions of finance. But as the season develops, the emphasis might be transferred to the Yankees relatively inexperienced front office. If a trade or a quick purchase is necessary to bolster a struggling team, George Steinbrenner, Al Rosen and Cedric Tallis might not be inspired as Gabe Paul was last season. in having made two deals, once the season began, that kept the Yankees in the American League East race. Gabe Paul obtained Mike Torrez from the Oakland A's in exchange for Dock Ellis, Larry Murray and Marty Perez last April. and he acauired Cliff Johnson From the Houston Astros in exchange for three minor leaguers hours before the June 15 trade deadline. He also rented Dave Kingman for the final week of the division race. Without both Mike Torrez and Cliff Johnson, the Yankees might not have won last year. And without Gabe Paul, now the Cleveland Indians president, the Yankees might not win this season, if their front office turns into a tempestuous troika.

title: NURSING HOME STRIKE IS THREATENED TODAY
description: The president of a union representing 12,000 nursing home employees said yes, terday it appeared the union had no alternative but to strike the Metropolitan New York Nursing Home Association at 6 A.M. today. Sixty nursing homes and about 18,000 patients would be affected and a nursinghome official said steps were being taken to move some patients and to provide care for the others.

title: Pace Gallery Will Sell Rothko's Art
description: The estate of Mark Rothko, eagerly sought by dealers since resolution of the celebrated lawsuit that removed the Marlborough Galleries as its selling agent, has been placed with the Pace Gallery, one of the country's leading dealers in contemporary art.

title: Opera: Society Offers Mose, Early Rossini

title: AMY GOLDIN, 52, ART CRITIC KNOWN FOR INDIVIDUALISM

title: Hershey Contract Approved
description: Workers at the Hershey Foods Corporation's chocolate plant in Hershey, Pa., approved a new 31month labor contract by 1,053 to 410 over the weekend, union spokesman said yesterday. The average wage increase was put at about $1.31 an hour over the contract's life.

title: Russians See Longer Space Trips After Tests on 2 Who Set Record
description: MOSCOW, April 3After examining the two Soviet astronauts who spent record 96 days in space, scientists and physicians believe that longer flights are possible, the Soviet press has reported.

description: ALBANY, April 3For eight long years; Senator James H. Donovan said today, he has been restlessly waiting for a chance to take action against the state's unconscionable expenditure of public funds for abortions for Medicaid recipients.

title: The President and Inflation: Politics Versus Economics
description: President Carter returns from his, South American and African journey to a country beset with worries about its own economic problems, especially inflation, The President has been warned by his economic advisers that inflation will accelerate if he does not produce a stronger program to check it. His political advisers, however, are loath to permit him to alienate labor. business, farm and other interest groups that would be affected by the kinds of action that his economic advisers want.

title: Issue and Debate; Should N.B.A. Legalize the Zone?; The Background; For Zone Defense; Against Zone Defense; Prospects
description: The zone defense has been forbidden in the National Basketball Association since the league began in 1946. For many years, there has, been disagreement within the league about the necessity or wisdom of that ban, but in practice, some elements of a zone defense have been used widely by many teams. This season the issue has been raised more dramatically than ever before by the actions. of Richie Powers, one of the N.B.A.'s oldest and most respected referees.

description: WASHINGTON April 3The Supreme. Court agreed today to decide whether a public school teacher can be discharged because, she complained privately to her principal about practices in the school that she considered racially discriminatory.

title: Film: 'Pretty Baby' By Louis Malle
description: IN a high panoramic shot we look over the roofs of a city at night. The opening title card tells us it's Storyville, New Orleans, 1917. From the far distance we hear a steam-boat's whistle, followed by a few notes on a blues trumpet. The mood is of impending loss, of the kind of bonedeep loneliness that is particular to the middle of the night.There's a sudden cut to the rapt face of a little girl. Just off-screen there are moans that could be either of pain or of ecstasy. Violet, the child, watches with both terror and excitement as her mother gives birth. The mother screams. The midwife gives reassuring instructions, and downstairs the nightly parties go on.The setting is Nell's place, one of the fancier brothels in the New Orleans tenderloin, and the bed might be the same one where Violet herself was born 12 years before, the daughter of Hattie, one of Nell's best "girls," and of a father no longer known. Like her new half brother, Violet is what used to be called a "trick baby."In this fashion Louis Malle takes us inside the hermetic world of "Pretty Baby," an almost incredibly romantic, autumnally beautiful movie that looks at life in a Storyville whorehouse with the unsurprised curiosity and boredom of a child who's never known anything else. Mr. Malle, the French director ("The Lovers," "Murmur of the Heart" and "Lacombe, Lucien"), has made some controversial films in his time but none, I suspect, that is likely to upset convention quite as much as this oneand mostly for the wrong reasons.Though the setting is a whorehouse, and the lens through which we see everything is Violet, who, in the course of the film, herself becomes one of Nell's chief attractions, "Pretty Baby" is neither about child prostitution nor is it pornographic.The film, which opens today at the Coronet, is about the last days of Storyville, just before the New Orleans city fathers bowed to the reformers and closed down one of the most notorious redlight districts in the country. It is also a sad, essentially tender memoir about Violet's brief liaison and marriage with an obsessed photographer named Bellocq, a character basedbut very looselyon Ernest J. Bellocq, the physically misshapen, hydrocephallic photographer whose portraits of Storyville whores are now recognized as the work of a unique artist.Mr. Malle and Polly Platt, with whom he collaborated on the screenplay, have largely avoided judgmental attitudes by looking out at the world through Violet's eyes. They've also softened the contours of what was probably very sordid history by making a film of dazzling physical beauty. Sven Nykvist's camera is as obsessed as Bellocq's with texture, light, shade, line, expression.When one realizes that Keith Carradine's Bellocq is actually the center of the film, "Pretty Baby" becomes a parable about art and life, about the artist who makes the mistake of falling in love with his subject, a creature who is, in effect, his own creation. Mr. Carradine gives a haunting and haunted performance, as someone sentenced by his obsession always to be observer and interpreter, never a full participant.I've no idea whether or not Brooke Shields, the breathtakingly beautiful 12-year-old model who plays Violet, can act in any real sense, but Mr. Malle uses her brilliantly. As Gloria Swanson said of silent stars in "Sunset Boulevard," "We had faces then," and Miss Shields has a face that here transcends the need to act.She is, in quick succession, willful and funny, sly and stupid. At one minute she's a child with her first doll. Next she is grotesque in full makeup as she repeats by rote lines meant to excite a customer"Why, I can feel the steam inside me, right through my dress!"or pathetic as she excitedly awaits the outcome of a whorehouse auction, the highest bidder to win her favors.The consistent coolness of Mr. Malle's view prevents the movie from seeming to be exploitative. There is one key shot that, I think, defines this method, when, during the auction for Violet, the camera stays on the not quite impassive face of "the Professor" (Antonio Fargas), the black pianist who entertains Nell's drawing-room guests. As Mr. Fargas listens to the bids, we have, for just a fraction of a moment, a glimpse of what all this means in terms of life in the outside world, which is infinitely sad but far, far removed.Both Mr. Fargas and Susan Sarandon, who plays Violet's mother, give fully realized performances but Frances Faye, who plays old Nell, the madam, is so bad that you can't believe it's not intentional. Has her dialogue been postsynchronized? It has that disconnected sound. Miss Faye seems properly tough, but it's a toughness of another era. Toward the end of the film, too, the narrative continuity seems to go astray. Have key scenes been cut to assure the film's R-rating?These, though, are niggling questions to ask of something that is in every other way the most imaginative, most intelligent and most original film of the year to date.

title: CARTER IS REPORTED RECONSIDERING A BAN ON THE NEUTRON BOMB
description: WASHINGTON, April 4The Adminis, tration, amid growing controversy over American plans for the neutron bomb, indicated today that President Carter was reviewing his decision not to produce the controversial weapon.

title: Personal Health

title: Voters Reject Town Shift to City
description: FRAMINGHAM, Mass., April 4 (UPI)Voters in this town of 60,000 population I have for the third time rejected .a proposal to become a city. The vote yesterday was 7,306 to 4,409 against changing the town to a city form of government and 7,066 to 3,605 against a fulltime town manager form of government.

title: Islanders and Flyers Play to 33 Deadlock
description: UNIONDALE, April 4  No champagne flowed at Nassau Coliseum tonight, where the Islanders and Philadelphia Flyers tied, 33, M both clubs biggest. game of the National Hockey League season.

title: Iranian Envoy Held in Teheran
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 4 (Reuters)The Iranian Ambassador to the Sudan has been arrested here on charges of having embezzled $140,000 while at the embassy in Khartoum, officials of the civil service tribunal said today. They said the ambassador, Mostafa ElmMotlaq, had repaid $24,000. Mr. ElmMotlaq, whose previous posts included London and Ankara, has been in the foreign service for 20 years.

title: West Germany Plans Vietnam Oil Search
description: A West German company signed an agreement with Vietnam for offshore oil exploration, the Agence France- Presse reported yesterday from Hanoi. The news agency said thp aereement was signed by Nguyen Van Bien, director general of the Vietnam state oil company, and by E. E. Hotz, president, and G. Schurmeyer, vice president, of Deminex, a West German oil company.

title: Youth Crime Protested by Elderly Pickets
description: While 70 elderly residents of the Parkchester apartment complex in the East Bronx, demonstrated outside the Bronx Family Court building yesterday, a 15yearold boy pleaded guilty to robbery and attempted rape.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: The STP Corporation, a maker of motor oil additives, said that the antitrust division of the Justice Department had sent both it and Esmark Inc. requests for information concerning their previously reported merger agreement. STP said both concerns intend to cooperate fully and promptly with the request.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of an editing error, it was stated incorrectly in The Times yesterday that Federal District Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr. had achieved black representation on the City Council of Montgomery, Ala., by gerrymandering election districts. The judge ruled against gerrymandered districts.

title: New Moro Letter Pleads for Exchange of Prisoners
description: ROME, April 4As Prime Minister Giulio Andreotti was telling Parliament today that the Government would not yield to blackmail to secure the release of Aldo Moro, the kidnappers of the former Prime Minister were distributing photocopies of a letter in his handwriting pleading with Italian leaders to agree to exchange him for other'political prisoners.

title: 20,000 in Manila Burn Marcos in Effigy
description: MANILA, April 4 (UPI)More than 20,000 workers burned effigies of President Ferdinand E. Marcos today in one of the biggest antiGovernment demonstrations in five and a half years of martial law.

title: Conferees Vote Bill That May Increase Food Prices by 3%
description: WASHINGTON, April 4Ignoring the threat of a veto; a SenateHouse conference committee today agreed on a flexible farm subsidy plan that would raise grain and cotton supports and could cost taxpayers $2.1 billion this year.

title: Rhodesia to Receive Envoys
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 4 (Reuters)Rhodesia's new Executive Council will give a hearing to American and British representatives when they arrive later this week seeking an overall Rhodesian settlement, a Government spokesman said today.

title: Tuition at Some Private Colleges To Exceed $5,000 for First Time
description: The annual tuition at some of the naltion's most prestigious colleges and universities will exceed $5,000 for the first time next fall, and the total costs, including room and board, will amount to more than $8,000, according tothe College Entrance Examination Board.

title: U.S. Aide at U.N. Flies To SouthWest Africa
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 4 (Reuters)Donald F. McHenry, the United States deputy representative on the United Nations Security Council, flew to South.; West Africa today for talks with local leaders on the latest Western proposals! for a peaceful independence settlement in the territory, known also as Namibia.

title: New York Ban on Nuclear Wastes Is Said to Be Accepted by U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 4The Department of Transportation has reportedly decided to let stand a two-year-old New York City ban on nuclear waste shipments, saying that the lack of Federal regulation in the area leaves the matter open to local control.

title: Music: Zamir Chorale
description: OTTFRIED WAGNER, a greatgrandson of the immortal Richard, is working on a biography of the composer Kurt Weill that considers Weill's indebtedness to the svnaeogue chant. One won- ders what filr. Wagner will have to say about Kiddush, Weill's delightfully incongruous setting of the tradition Sabbath prayer over wine.

title: Communists Are Finding Naples a Tough City to Rule
description: NAPLES, April 2When a factory dismissed 30 workers here the other day, the men threw up a roadblock and poured Out an acid used in the plant. Sulfur fumes blanketed the area and some 150 workers at nearby factories had to be taken to the hospital.

title: TONGSUN PARK DENIES O'NEILL SOUGHT FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON, April 4The House ethics committee caused a stir this morning wherl it released a document identified as a Korean intelligence report that asserted that the House Speaker, Representative Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., had asked for Korean campaign contributions for his Congressional followers.

title: The News From All the Northern Cities Is, To Understate It, Grim
description: ST. PAUL DE VENCE, FranceI can scarcely believe that I first met Martin Luther King Jr. 21 years ago, in Atlanta. I find it nearly impossible to believe that my stocky younger brother, which is the way I thought of him, has been dead for 10 years. Ten years!

title: Wall Poster Assails Peking Mayor Over Riots
description: PEKING, April 4 (Reuter)A wall poster attacking the Mayor of Peking, Wu Teh, has gone up on the ere of tomorrow's second anniversary of riots in the city's main square.

title: Sacred Music Society Sings a Rare Rossini
description: MONDAY night in Avery Fisher Hall the Sacred Music Society unearthed a real piece of bel canto arcane, Rossini's Mose in Egitto. Composed in 1818, the work had not been performed. according to the sociptvc founder, the musicologist Randolph Vlickelson, since 1836.

title: NURSING HOME STRIKE AFFECTS 18,000 AGED
description: Volunteer workers tended 18,000 to 20,000 patients in nursing homes in New York yesterday after nurses, orderlies and. kitchen helpers went on strike at 6 A.M.

title: A TAX CUT IS SOUGHT FOR SOCIAL SECURITY
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)The House Budget Committee voted today to recommend a $7.5 billion rollback in Social Security taxes as part of an overall $20 billion tax cut. The reduction would be $5 billion less in tax relief than President Carter had proposed.

title: Carey to Seek to Channel U.S. Aid Through Local Long Island Board
description: STONY BROOK L. I., April 4Governor Carey sad today that he would .ask the Federal Government to channel aid to Nassau and Suffolk Counties through a local planning board instead of a regional one.

title: Angola Drive Reported Against Guerrillas
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 4 (UPI) Western diplomatic sources said today that Cuban troops backed by Angolan forces, Soviet jet fighters and napalm bombs had started an offensive to wipe out the remnants of proWestern guerrilla forces in Angola.

title: Governor, Praising Rose At a Memorial, Deplores Influence of Conservatives
description: Speaking at a memorial meeting for Alex Rose, the late Liberal Party leader, Governor Carey last alight accused the Conservative Party of exercising undue influence on the Republican Party and on legislative deliberations on such issues as the death penalty and abortion. Those issues are being dealt with by the current Legislature.

title: STATE'S SAFETY PLAN IS FOUGHT BY CONRAIL
description: NEWARK, April 4The state and Conrail clashed today over a plan by New Jersey to impose special safety regulations on transportation by rail of hazardous materials.

title: M-G-M EARNINGS CLIMBED BY 52% IN FIRST QUARTER
description: Metro - Goldwyn - Mayer Inc. whose earnings from hotelcasino activities con- tinue to exceed those from films, reported yesterday a profit gain of 52 percent in the quarter ended Feb. 28 and a 30 per- cent in the halfyear.

title: Mr. Carter's FullCourt Press
description: WASHINGTON, April 4Jimmy Carter is giving the impression here these days that he is determined to take on every tough foreign policy issue in the book, regardless of the political consequences.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BY A WATERFALL Lunchtime cabaret seems a fine idea for the Big Apple. The dominant Ingredient of the new midtown, 40minute show per- formed by four young people is cheer, not originality. If you don't mind ,blithe reprise of songs and sketches that distinctly echo tried-and-true predecessors, from earlier cabaret revues to Noel Coward and even the Marx Brothers, the energetic cavorting of Mary Murphy, Marjorie Burren (the best voice), Lee J. Copenhaver and James Klein is a reasonably pleasant midday interlude.

title: Jews in America Now Worried By Both U.S. and Israeli Policies
description: WASHINGTON, April 4As rarely before, American Jews are confused, uneasy, distressed or even angry about the Middle East policies of the American and Israeli Governments.

title: Carey Defends Pardon of Suspect Charged in Killing of 2 Policemen
description: Governor Carey yesterday defended his December 1976 pardon of Cleveland Davis. the 35-year-old former convict charged with murdering two police offi cers in a street shootout in Brooklyn Sunday.

title: Cyprus Sentences 2 Gunmen to Death In Killing of Editor
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, Aprli 4 (AP)A court today sentenced two Palestinians to hang for the assassination of Yousef elSebai. a prominent Egyptian editor.

description: BONN, April 4The United States made significant changes in its portrayal to West Germany of the value of neutron weapons during the last few weeks and no longer referred to them .as the decisive element in the EastWest balance of power, political sources said today.

title: 2 Books and Article Revive Dispute on Hiss's Guilt
description: The Alger HissWhittaker Chambers dispute, which became a national issue and trial in 1949 and 1950 and helped to propel Richard M. Nixon in the role of Congressional prosecutor to the Vice Presidency in 1952, has broken out again in the books and magazines.

title: House Rejects a White House Bill Fixing Staff Size and Salary Scale
description: WASHINGTON. April 4With gibes at President Carter over his campaign promise to cut the White House staff, the House today rejected legislation to.. fix the staff's size at 354 and almost double the number of aides at the top salary levels.

title: Witness in Curare Trial Says Evidence Disappeared
description: HACKENSACK, April 4A prosecution investigator who seized the contents of Dr. Mario E.Jascalevich's locker at Riverdell Hospital testified today under crossexamination in the doctor's murder trial that some key items shown in a picture of the contents taken the night before were not in the locker when he cot there.

title: BMW Recalling 32,500 Cars
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (Reuters)..... BMW of North America is recalling about 32,500 of its 1977 and 1978 cars because of stalling problems, the Transportation Department said today. The agency said the recall involves BMW's 3201 and 320IA models manufactured through Feb. 28.

title: U.N. Weighs Expansion of Force
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 4Expansion of the peacekeeping force in Lebanon from its authorized strength of 4,000 to at least 6,000 is being considered here, according to wellplaced sources.

title: Yance to Visit Moscow
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (AP)Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance will go to Moscow to arrange talks on a new nuclear weapons limitation agreement after his trip to Africa, the State Department announced today.

title: MILLER PROJECTING 69 TO 7% INFLATION, HIGHER THAN CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, April 4G. William Miller, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has forecast a slightly higher rate of inflation than the Carter Administration has predicted and a slightly lower rate of economic expansion.

title: Notes on People
description: THE soprano Martina Arroyo, who has been plagued by a painful back problem for many years, said in London yesterday that she was cancelling all engagements for the next six weeks and will undereo spinal surgery this weekend. . The chronic complaint has forced Miss Arroyo to miss many performances. Most recently she was unable to sing Il Trovatore Monday night with the Royal Opera in Covent Garden. The 42-year-old opera star will miss several American appearances, including those in Cleveland and Dayton, Ohio. She hopes to be able to sing in Madrid and Vienna at the end of May.

title: Five Die in Mine Shaft
description: BUCU, Va., April 4 (UPI)Five men died today in a mine shaft, apparently from lack of oxygen, officials of the Clinchfield Coal Company. said.

The first next month, the second will be September and the third in October.

description: ALAMEDA, Calif.,April 4 (UPI) Ray mond E. French, who played shortstop for three major league teams in the early 1920's and later starred in the Pacific Coast League, died at his home yesterday at the age of 82.

title: State Department Pleased
description: WASHINGTON, April 4 (Reuters)The State Department welcomed today's convictions in Cyprus. The department spokesman, Hodding Carter 3d, said, I would like to reiterate our view that anything which serves to curb or penalize terrorism, we welcome. Clearly this is such a step, and therefore we welcome it.

title: Let the Charity Fit the Crime?
description: Generally, penalties levied In Federal courts end up the Miscellaneous Account of the United States Treasury, to be spent as Congress directs. This year, there will be $510.000 less less than there might have been. That is the amount the Olin Corporation might have paid in fines for illegal arms sales to South Africa. Instead, United States District Judge Robert Zampano in New Haven has ordered the company to devote that sum to charities New Haven. That is necessary, he said, as a form reparations, to make amends for the unhappy light cast on the community, in which Olin is the largest industrial employer.

title: Dollar's Gain Lifts Dow by 4.33; Amex Index Highest Since Start
description: An improved showing by the United States dollar in foreigncurrency trading currently the most sensitive lead indicator for the stock market on Wall Street sent prices slightly higher yesterday after a sound drubbing on Monday.

title: Studying the Woes Of Working Nights
description: EARLY TO BED and early to rise makes a man healthy, wealthy and wise, what happens when he keeps cockeyed hours instead? Ben Franklin may have suspected the answer, but only recently are scientists beginningio prove that the hour people get to bed has a great deal to do with their health and wisdom, at the very least.

description: In the Ramble in Central Park yesterday, the swamp maples sported bright red buds and the willow branches waved gracefully in lacy chartreuse, but John Bull, a staff ornithologist of the American Museum of Natural History, was looking for the more movable and audible symbols of spring that are closest to his heart: birds.

title: How to Get There
description: Visitors interested in watching the sugaring off may visit any of three Sullivan County farms, about 120 miles from Manhattan, during the next several weeks. Visitors must telephone in advance to be sure the sap is running. To reach Asthalter's (914-292-8569) or Muthig's (914-292-7838) from Manhattan, take the Palisades Parkway north to the New York Thruway, Route 87. Take 87 to Harriman, then go west on the Route 17 quickway to exit 100 at Liberty. Off the quickway pick up Route 52 West, turning left at the entrance to Grossinger's. Continue on Route 52 into the village of Liberty, then turn right onto Route 55 East for four miles and turn left onto Men Road. Travel on Aden Road for about three miles to the Asthalter farm, on the right. The Muthig farm is just a few hundred yards beyond Asthalter's. To reach the Cole Sugar House in Ferndale, take Route 17 to Exit 102, continue to Harris, pass the Harris Post Office, turn right on Bushville Road (Country Road 75). Continue on . Bushville Road, crossing Lt. Brender Highway onto Bushville SwanLake Road, and continue to the red

title: Deaths
description: EOELMAN Seymour.The Greatek, New York Committee for Israel Bonds notes with deep sorrow the passing of the beloved husband of Marjorie Edelman, a dedicated leader of it's Five Towns Division & A Pioneer in the effort to build & support Israel's economy.We extend our profound sympathy to her & the family.

title: CAROLINE HART
description: SAN ANGELO, Tex., April 4 (AP)Caroline Harte, widow of Houston Harte, one of the founders of the HarteHanks communications chain, died yesterday. She was 84 years old. Edward H. Harte, publisher of The Corpus Christi CallerTimes, and Houston H. Harte, chairman of the board of HarteHanks Communications Inc., are her sons.

title: Police in Los Angeles Again Suffer Embarrassment in Strangler Case
description: LOS ANGELES, April 4Seven months After the first of 13 possibly related murdes, the socalled hillside strangler is still eluding capture here, frustrating police department that, with the help of television, had managed to cultivate an international image of faultless skill and professionalism.

title: Deaths
description: MEGATHLIN--Evelyn (nee Bantamin) of Cohasset. Mass. April 3. Age 68. Wife of Norman Francis Megathlin of 59 Joy Place. Mother of Dr. Keith Norman Megathlln of Portland, Maine. Sister of Mrs Chester Clemens of Shoreham, Vt. Also survived by 3 grandchildren, Craig S., Shawn R. B. Mark K. Megathlin, all of Portland, Maine. A memorial funeral service will be held In the Second Congregational Church, Cohasset, Friday April 7 at 2PM. At therequest of the family calling hours are to be omitted. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Second Congregational Church, Cohasset, or the Mass. Audubon Society, Lincoln.

title: Trenton Topics
description: TRENTON, April 4During the last three months of 1977, the New Jersey economy grew faster than that of the nation as a whole for the first time since the spring of 1975, the State Economic Policy Council said today.

title: 2 in Chile Said to Deny Slaying Link
description: SANTIAGO, Chile, April 4Two men wanted for questioning about the assassination in 1976 of a Chilean political exile in Washington have reportedly testified here that they were in the United States before the killing but that they had no connection with it. Both were described by the judge who questioned them as members of Chile's secret police.

title: POST SETS DEADLINE ON GUILD AGREEMENT
description: The New York Post yesterday set midnight of April 14 as the deadline for agreement with the Newspaper Guild of New York on all issues in a new union contract.

title: A's Sell Radio Rights To a University Station
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 4 (AP)The Oakland A's have sold their radio broadcast rights to a University of Californiaowned, studentoperated station. the team said today.

title: Flaubert on Fashion
description: In 1854, when Gustave Flaubert was 33, a stillunpublished author struggling in the country to write Madame Bovary, his 44-year-old mistress, Louise Colet, a muchpublished poet and journalist living in Paris, asked him what she might say in articles for a Parisian fashion magazine.

title: Pretzels: Humble Delights
description: AMONG the most unforgettable gastronomic experiences have ever had while traveling was my introduction to homemade pretzels. As plebeian as that soft, vet crisp. saltencrusted twist may have been, it shares top honors with memories of far more luxurious firsts, such as fresh foie gras, whole roasted truffles, ripe green figs picked from a tree on sunny morning along the Adriatic and raspberries swathed in crime fraiche.

title: Deaths
description: ALLENRev. Cady H. Died Mairb 26, 1978. He was a distinguished missionary to Iran for over 40 years and Minister of Visitation of Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church. He Is survived by his wife, Huldah, his daughter Dorothy (Mrs. Robert Frese) and sons Robert; Theodore and Paul, and grandchildren and niece, Or. Frances L Zoeckler. A Memorial Service will be held on Friday, April 14, at 11:30 AM in the Chapel of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, 7 West 55 Street, N.Y.C. Interment will be at Stony Point, N.Y. at 2:30 PM.

title: Two Candidates Enter Contests for Attorney General
description: The competition for the Republican and Democratic nominations for New York State Attorney General Intensified yesterday as Rita E. Hauser and Nicholas Scoppetta announced their candidacies a hall hour and two blocks apart.

In the week that ended March 31, the cost of the 41 items used by the department in Its weekly price survey was calculated at $78.65, or 69 cents less than during the preceeding week.

title: Witness Says He Balked At Last Minute on a Deal To Kill a Man in Queens

title: Students Find State Full of Wonders, 14 of Them

title: UTILITY BOND YIELDS HIGHEST IN 2 YEARS

The yield was the highest for a mediumgrade utility bond issue since May 1976, when the same company did a $70 million financing.

title: A Promising Prescription for New Drugs
description: It's not easy to get a new drug marketed in the United States these dayseven when the drug seems to be safe and effective. For example, sodium valproate, a drug control epileptic seizures, has been used in Europe for a decade and was warmly endorsed by experts here. But American drug companies were slow to test it because the potential market is small, and the Food and Drug Administration was slow to approve it until it had been thoroughly tested. Only after a crescendo of complaints did the F.D.A. finally allow it to be offered on the market in March.

title: View From the Sunburst Sire

The advantage of a wellsituated office in the behemothlike Pan Am Building is that the Chrysler's spectacular Art Deco top is right there at eye level, its stainless steel gargoyles and hubcap frieze affording an incomparable vista of skyscraper art.

title: Wheat Futures Prices Rise Sharply on Reports of Purchases by China
description: Wheat prices jumped sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade on rumor that China had bought a million bushels here and another million in the world market. Prices later receded from the high, and May wheat closed at $3.21 3/4 a bushel. up 3 3/4 cents.

title: New Grease for the Oil Tax
description: Al Ullman has an audacious idea. Generally, Washington's way of solving big problems is to try breaking them up into more manageable parts. But Mr. Ullman, the Democrat from eastern Oregon who chairs the House Ways and Means Committee, now proposes doing just the opposite. He would try to solve two of the biggest problems in Congresshow to deal with the costs of energy and of Social Security--by joining them. The idea more than audacious; it is constructive; and it deserves to be tried.

title: Louisianian Contradicts Testimony of Tongsun Park
description: WASHINGTON, April 5The House ethics committee today heard testimbny that directly conflicted sworn statements in the last two days by Tongsun Park, the Korean businessman and lobbyist.

title: 5,500 POLICE ATTEND OFFICER'S FUNERAL; Koch, at Rites in Brooklyn, Urges Restoration of Death Penalty
description: About 5,500 police officers, some from as far away as Detroit, joined Mayor Koch, Police Department officials, family and friends yesterday to pay their respects to Christie D. Masone, one of two policemen killed in a Brooklyn shootout Sunday.

title: CurtissWright, if Victor on Proxy, To Offer $40 a Share at Kennecott
description: The CurtissWright Corporation officially opened its proxy fight yesterday for control of the Kennecott Copper Corporationmaking an offer that Wall Street analysts said would be highly attractive to many Kennecott stockholders.

title: Crafts Fair Celebrating 97th Birthday of Indian Potter
description: MARIA MARTINEZ, an American Indian who has led five generations of potters, has created a living tradition in American pottery. Mrs. Martinez was born in the 1880's and today her work is displayed in major museums throughout the country, several of her pots are owned by the White House, and a picture of one appears on a 1977 commemorative stamp.

title: Fraud Charged to Auto Dealer
description: CAMDEN, N.J., April 5 (AP)A car dealership pleaded guilty yesterday to Federal tonspiracy charges in connection with a scheme to roll back odometers in more than 200 automobiles. In a relat- ed civil action in Federal District Court, the dealer, Pete and Hitch Ford of Bridgeton, and its president, Marvin K. Hitchner Jr., agreed to repay those who bought vehicles with rolled back odometers after Jan. 1, 1977. Mr. Hitchner received a sixmonth sentence and was fined $5000 last; month sentence and was fined $5,000 last to $50,000 on the conspiracy charge.

title: News Summary
description: Israel may have violated its accord with the United States in its use of American military equipment in southern Lebanon, but no action is planned to deprive Israel of further arms supplies, Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance told Congress. The notice was sent in compliance with a new rule requiring the President to report promptly to Congress any possible violation of American arms exporting regulations. The letter added possible new strains on relations with Israel, but there seemed to be no inclination to carry the matter further. [Page Al, Column 1.]

title: Pullman Standard Reaches Pact
description: CHICAGO, April 5 (AP)Pullman Standard said today that it had agreed to a contract with 6,500 members of the United Steelworkers of America, ending a 27week strike at five railroad Car plants in four states. The company said the five plantsin Chicago, Butler, Pa., Bessemer, Ma., and two in Hammond Ind., would reopen soon. The strike began Oct. 1.

title: Hers

Hundreds of untutored men and women among the Puritans, pioneers and immigrants of this country wrote letters, diaries, memoirs and autobiographical novels touched with natural eloquence or crude power, and a fair number of these people proved to be Writers: Having told the story once, they discovered that they burned to tell it aeain. and vet again.

title: U.S.East German Protestant Talks
description: EAST BERLIN, April 5 (Reuters)East German and United States Protestant leaders began five days of discussions today at the former monastery of Chorin, north of here. The talks were proposed last October by a synod of the East German Protestant church federation.

title: Jazz: Sims and Quartet
description: EVER since Zoot Sims flashed across the jazz sky as a member of the Four Brothers saxophone section in Woody Herman's band 30 years ago, he has been one of the most consistently swinging performers in jazz. His consistency has focused on his faithfulness to his own straightforward way of playing (he has never been lured into dramatic showboating or fashionable experimental deviations) and his ability to pick up almost any group he happens to be with, even the most leadfooted, and give it wings on the strength of the airy, buoyant force of his attack.

title: Mugger Gets $170, Returns $100
description: SAN DIEGO, April 5 (UPI)A mugger returned $100 of the $170 he took from a 28-year-old woman on a city street when she pleaded that she needed the money to pay her rent. Lynnae DiMarzo told the police that a young man confronted her as she walked near a church, hit her in the eye and choked her to get her purse. When she made her plea for the rent money, the mugger gave her part of the money, apologized and left.

title: Justice Dept. Asserts Houston Judge Gave Illegally Soft Penalty
description: WASHINGTON, April 5The Justice Department today accused a Federal district judge of acting illegally in imposing sentences of only one year on three Houston police officers for their involvement in the drowning death of a MexicanAmerican in their custody.

title: Congressman Richmond of Brooklyn Says He Solicited and Paid Two Men for Sex
description: WASHINGTON, April 5(AP)Representative Frederick W. Richmond, Democrat of Brooklyn, said tonight that he had solicited sexual relations with two men with payment of money and now faces a criminal solicitation charge.

title: 1.M.F. Gold Saleat $177.92 an Ounce
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)The International Monetary Fund sold today 524,800 ounces of gold at an average price of $177.92 an ounce at its monthly gold auction. Successful bids ranged from a high of $180.26 an ounce to $177.61. The auction raised $70.6 million for the agency's trust fund for poor nations, bringing the total so far for this fund from gold auctions to $1.24 billion.

title: The Wildlife Trap.

It seems to us that such a split would seriously weaken ecological programs and could be harmful to fishing and hunting.

title: Film: 'Last Survivor':Hunger and Mushrooms
description: BEWARE of action movies in which, only 15 minuts into the proceedings, somebody shouts "We're saved Ro???! I see the plane [ship] [campsite] [S.W.A.T. 10am] right over there!" You can bet your buttons they aren't sale at all, and that something unpleasant is in the wind. In "The Last Survivor," a small planeload of Italians, whose speech is dubbed unconvincingly into British, gets lost on an island inhabited by Stone Age holdovers. Of course, these natives are restless.They're hungry, too. This viewer headed for the hills not long after she watched the locals, a little crude even by Stone Age standards, gnawing on a set of human arms and legs, which had presumably belonged to somebody else until only lately. "Scene of cannibalism photographed from real life," a subtitle said.When last scen, the survivor of the title had lost his friends in a variety of messy ways then wolfed down a mushroom that made him think trees could spin. Just before he grew dizzy and vomited green goo, the Stone Age natives had him surrounded. That left them about an hour of screen time to poke him with homemade implements and otherwise educate him in their Stone Age ways.

title: The Mishandled Bomb
description: Few episodes in the 15 months of the Carter Administration have been more disturbing than its handling the neutron bomb. To be fair to the President, he never fully embraced the new weapon, a replacement warhead for NATO nuclear artillery shells. He has always main- tained that more study was needed. But since last summer, when he first requested funds from Congress for its production, he has encouraged his Administration work toward getting other members of NATO to agree to its deployment as a deterrent against Soviet tanks. Now, however, on the eve of a formal NATO decision, he is reported to be on the brink of canceling the weapon without either consulting the allies or asking any concession from Moscow.

title: Film: 'Calm Prevails':By VINCENT CANBY
description: PETER LILIENTHAL'S "Calm Prevails Over the Country" is a German film made in Portugal about the gradual destruction of democracy in a South American country that resembles both Uruguay, where the German-born film maker lived for 20 years, and Chile. It's an intensely interesting film, very measured and clear at the beginning, full of the precisely observed details of daily life that in movies are the equivalent to life's small talk, and then, quite suddenly, a poetic parable of implications that extend beyond the political.The film will be shown at the Film Forum tonight through Sunday at 7:45 and repeated there next week Thursday through Sunday at the same time. Though "Calm Prevails" is not especially difficult, it makes no concessions to popular tastes and is thus a practically perfect presentation for the Film Forum, the most consistently successful showcase for offbeat films in New York.The film's central character is a remarkably resilient, intelligent old man, the owner of a small hotel in the capital city. This fellow, played with serene self-assurance by Charles Vanel, the veteran French actor who was 83 when the film was made three years ago, has lived long enough to have survived all sorts of political weather.At first he observes with passing interest the first signs of the state's suppression of the opposition. It doesn't immediately touch him. Then he's aware of the arrest of the children and grandchildren of friends. Finally his own grandchildren disappear.In the film's final sequence, there are no more able-bodied men left in the city. The old man makes some sandwiches, pays a young boy to take him to the city prison, where, after shouting a few vigorous denunciations of fascism to the guards, he enters the wails to rejoin his community.It should not spoil the film to be told its shape. In fact, I think it can increase one's appreciation for the manner in which the director works, beginning with the humdrum and escalating to moments that have the spirit of pure fantasy.Mr. Lilienthal's control of particular episodes sometimes is uncertain. An extended sequence about a jailbreak is total confusion in narrative terms. There's also a problem in that several of the younger men in the cast look so much alike that one can't always be sure who is supposed to be doing what or why.Mr. Vanel, though, is superb. It's very moving to see this fine old star, whom I first remember in Clouzot's "Wages of Fear," lending the weight of his presence and his experience to such a venture.
