description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP)The United States imported fewer color television sets and citizens band radios but more stereo sets last year than in 1976, the Commerce Department said today. The total value of all audiovideo products imported in 1977 increased by 9 percent to $3.89 billion for the year, the department said.

title: Old Books: in New Booths at Fair
description: Whether you are an avid collector with a strongly marked interest or a tyro still making up your mind over what to collect or simply a person who can't resist the attraction of books and manuscripts, you will find the 1978 New YorkInternational Antiquarian Book Fair a temple of delights. The rair which is being held at the Americana today through Sunday, has enlisted the efforts of 120 dealers. who, its sponsors say, are making available more than 50,000 items worth $G.5 million, Money aside, however, it is hard not to be drawn into the ambience of these offerings.

title: Ouster for Homosexual Conduct By Teachers Passed in Oklahoma
description: OKLAHOMA CITY, April 6 (AP)The Oklahoma Senate unanimously passed bill today that would allow school boards to fire teachers who engage in public homosexual conduct.

title: Nicolas Nabokov, 75, a Composer; Did Don Quixote, Other Ballets
description: Nicolas Nabokov, a composer and writer who organized three of the largest and most influential international music festivals in the nonCommunist world in the 1950's and 60's, died early yesterday morning at Mount Sinai Hospital of a heart attack following an operation. He observed his 75th birthday last Tuesday.

title: Economic Dilemmas for President: Inflation, Recession and the Dollar
description: A bewildering variety of national economic problems has bombarded an already uneasy public in recent weeks. Increased inflation, the falling dollar, the stalled energy bill, the record trade deficit, slower growth and host of other problems have sent the Administration into a new flurry of activity intended to calm growing fears that even worse troubles lie ahead.

title: News Summary
description: President Carter is leaning toward an indefinite delay in the production of the neutron bomb, according to Administration officials, who believe that the President will stick to his earlier opposition to producing the bomb. They said he has agreed not to cancel the bomb outright and has adopted formula for leaving open the choice of moving ahead at a later date. Mr. Carter is expected to make an announce ment of his stand today. [Page A1, Column 1.]

title: Kennedy and Carter Reach an Agreement On Health Insurance
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP)Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat.of Massachusetts, said, that he and labor leaders had reached an agreement today with President Carter on the general principles of national health insurance and on aiming for passage of health insurance legislation by 1980.

title: Appeals Court Lifts an Injunction Against Nazi Marchin Skokie, Ill.
description: CHICAGO, April 6 The United States Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit today lifted a 45day injunction against a proposed march by the National Socialist Party of America in the predominantly Jewish suburb of Skokie.

title: A ByrneLerner Rapprochement
description: TRENTON, April 6  Govemlr Byrne announced today that he would serve as chairman of a testimonial dinner for Harry Lerner, the Essex County Democratic chairman, with whom he had been feuding.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 6 (AP)Tracy Caulkins, a 15 - year - old schoolgirl, picked up her second American record in the 400yard individual medley, and Stephanie Elkins, 14, cracked the 200yard freestyle mark tonight in the . Amateur Athletic Union shortcourse swimming championship.

Is there some sort of message there?

description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 6 Israel, under mounting pressure to remove its troops from southern Lebanon, has informed United Nations officials that it intends to begin an initial twostage withdrawal next Tuesday.

title: AYear After the Flood, Pineville, Ky., Is Showing Optimism
description: PINgVTLLE, Ky., April 5One year ago today much of this quiet Appalachian town in southeast Kentucky was submerged in 14 feet of water that had just rushed over the flood wall of the Cumberland River, swollen by heavy spring rain and the thaw of mountain snows.

title: Rep. Richmond Enters Plea of Not Guilty in Sex Case
description: WASHINGTON, ApriL 6After publicly admitting that he had solicited seival relations with a man and a 16-year-old youth with payment of money, Representative Frederick W. Richmond, Democrat of Brooklyn, entered a formal plea of not guilty today at his arraignment in District of Columbia Superior Court.

title: Numbers, Please
description: MAPLEWOOD, N.J.A civilrights worker in Mississippi, Spiro T. Agnew and newspaper reportersthese and thousands of others have something in common: The Government once secretly obtained records of their private telephone conversations.

title: Theater: Multimedia 23 Skiddoo
description: LE PLAN K, a Belgian theater company, apparently has all the proper experimental credentials. The group has performed at Wroclaw, Shiraz, and the Beaubourg museum, in Paris, and its current American tour will end at the Baltimore arts festival. In its opening at the Washington Square Church on Wednesday, Le Plan K presented a multimedia performance piece entitled 23 Skiddoo, with text drawn from the work cf William Burroughs, Brion Gysin, Wilhelm Reich and the Marquis de Sade. The group comes to New York streaming praise From Mr. Burroughs, among others.

title: Auctions
description: DIAMONDS are everybody's best friend these days. At least that's what some experts and auction houses would have in- vestors think as these gems soar to dizzying price levels. In any case, the diamond market here and abroad is booming, and next week four of New York's auction houses are holding major jewelry sales, all of which are notable for the abundance of these sparklers.

title: World News Briefs
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 6 (AP)The new Executive Council announced today that several hundred political prisoners would soon be freed. The move was apparently intended to bolster popular support for an agreement that would lead to majority rule, with power shared by blacks and whites.

title: Schlee Leads Masters on 68
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 6  John Schlee, who imagined he was playing this or that hole in the Masters with every practice shot in recent weeks, turned fantasy into reality today.

title: Institutional Buying Helps Stocks To Outperform the Dow Average
description: Steppedup institutional buying and a better-than-expected wholesale price report enabled the stock market to advance moderately yesterday in continued heavy volume.

title: CURARE CASE EXPERT TELLS OF SUSPICIONS
description: HACKENSACK, April 6A Medical Examiner testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that while he had listed one of the patients the doctor is accused of murdering in 1965 as having died from a coronary occlusion, he had had a suspicion. while doing the autopsy that drugs might have been involved.

title: Deaths
description: GOODELMANAaron J., April 5, 1978. Beloved husband of Sarah (Hyman), father of late Amos Goode!. man, brother of Jane Horowitz, Claire Rothstein and Ida Goodelman, uncle and great uncle. Funeral services will be held at 10 A.M. on Sunday, April 9, 1978 at Park West Chapel, 79th Street and Columbus Avenue, New York, New York.

title: Music: Jochum and Philharmonic
description: THE Fourth is the sternest of the Brahms symphonies, and the granitic treatment it usally invites can be tremendously exciting. Last night it was presented in a mellower way by Eugen Jochum. who was conducting the second program of his engagement with the New York Philharmonic in Avery Fisher Hall this season, and it was just as satisfactory.

title: Town in Montana That Eats and Breathes Copper Is Sick
description: ANACONDA, Mont.As the parking lot was filling with campers and pickup trucksstandard commuter vehicles in this part of the worldthe Deer Lodge Valley was filling up with the luminous light of an early spring morning. It was time to change shifts at the huge copper smelter that perchas above this town of 10,000 in western Montana, and a pipefitter in a leather jack- et was taking a last puff on his cigar. This town, he said bluntly, is sick.

title: Sea Parley Settks Leadership Dispute; Some See a Setback
description: GENEVA, April 6A dispute that, has blocked the work of the United Nations Law of the Sea Conference for nine days was resolved early today but only after delegates gave up trying for a consensus and resorted insteadlo a vote.

description: NEW LONDON; Conn.If Lucille Showalter had been an ordinary person, she would have quietly buried her 20-year-old son, Kevin, killed by a hitandrun driver on Christmas Eve, 1973, while fixing a flat tire, and accepted the assertion of the authorities that the case could not be solved.

description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP)Consumer installment credit returned to normal levels in February after slumping the month before, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

description: CINCINNATI, April 6 Tom Seaver started his 11th consecutive seasonopening game today, far from the roar of jet planes over Shea Stadium and the winds that whip so briskly across Flushing Bay.

title: `Children's Free School Fights For Right to Keep Columbia Site
description: A small cooperative elementary school on Morningside Drive in New York City, now engaged in extended negotiations with Columbia University about its future, elicits echoes of 1968a year that was one of the most tumultuous in Amer- Urban Affairs lean history. One of  that year's hallmarks was the combination of pressures generated by idealists, community organizations, student activists and radicals of all stripes directed at a broad range of American institutions. Another piece of the story of 1968 was the response those institutions made to the demands for change.

title: House, Unhappy With Postal Service, Seeks Changes
description: WASHINGTON April 6The House by a 384 to 11 vote, today signaled its dissatisfaction with the United States Postal Service by approving a series of Government checks on the agency and by introducing a measure of private competition with the mail.

title: Art: A Throbbing Madness of Color

Surely not since the 1950's has there been an artist using so much of it as Alfred Jensen, 56 of whose pictures are at the New Museum (65 Fifth Avenue at 14th Street). Indeed. pound for pound, Mr. Jensen may have used more of it than any Abstract Expressionist, building up as he does crusty patterns in tube pigments that are rarely diluted or, mixed.

description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (UPI)  The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Alfred L. Atherton Jr. as Ambassador at Large for the Middle East. Mr. Atherton, a career diplomat and an expert on the Middle East, was approved by voice vote and without dissent.

title: Shelton Stars in Overtime as Knicks Win, 129-125 Knicks Lose Big Lead; Knicks Box Score; DETROIT (125); (KNICKS (1291))
description: The Knicks used 6 points and a key blocked shot from Lonnie Shelton in the fiveminute overtime last night to help them defeat the Detroit Pistons, 129125, at Madison Square Garden. The final home game of the regular National Basketball Association season, before a crowd of 10,720, left the Knicks with a 4139 wonlost record.

title: Virtuoso on Recorder
description: How does one become a virtuoso on the recorder, a whistle or endblown flute that was an important instrument from the 16th to the 18th century? One way is to be born in Amsterdam, where at least until 1940 playing the recorder, often treated as a pastime for children or amateur adults, was taken seriously enough to be decently taught. This happened to Frans Brueggen, probably today's bestknown concert artist on the recorder, who will give a program with Alan Curtis, the harpsichordist, in Alice Tully Hall on Sunday at 3 P.M.

title: Opposition in Manila Sounds Off on Eve of Election
description: MANILA, April 6In a raucous ges.ur.2 of protest against President Ferdinand E. Marcos's martiallaw ruse, tens of thousands of, Filipinos honked their car horns, shouted rnd banged cn tin cans tonigit on the eve of the election for an intzr;m national assembly.

title: Red Wings 6, Penguins 4
description: DETROIT, April 6 (AP)Paul Woods scored two goals to help the Detroit Red Wings gain a 64 victory over Pittsburgh tonight and erase the Penguins last hope for a playoff spot.

title: Leaving Regulation to the Regulators
description: On a ceremonial occasion the other day, Chief Justice Burger said some nice things about Appeals Court Judge David Bazelon. But now, in a decision involving nuclear power plants, the Burger Court has vented its true feelings about the liberal, activist Bazelon court. The unanimous opinion, written by Justice Rehnquist, has accused the Bazelon court of judicial intervention run riot and decisionmaking that borders on the Kafkaesque. The opinion will limit the ability of Federal judges to overturn regulatory decisions on procedural grounds. That will be salutary if it ends obstructionist legal tactics. But it places a heavy burden on regulators and legislators to confront problems whose neglect led to judicial intervention in the first place.

title: Administration Hits Farm Bill Cost
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 The Carter Administration today increased its estimate of the damage the economy could suffer from the new farm bill now before Congress.

title: Patient Care Found Deteriorating In 3d Day of NursingHome Strike
description: A New York State health official, re. porting that monitoring teams had found deteriorating care in the third day of a strike against proprietary nursing homes in the New York City area, said that 2,200 patients had been taken out of the struck homes, but that only about 150 of them appeared to have returned to their families.

title: Radio City Tower Accord Gained By Rockefeller Center and Carey
description: A plan to keep Radio City Music Hall open by subsidizing it with rents from 20story office tower to be built over has been agreed to in principle by New York State and Rockefeller Center, source close to Governor Carey said yesterday.

title: Martin: No Discord On Yankees Expected
description: If Billy Martin feels tense, his hands don't show it. An hour or so before the final game of spring training, the hands that have been a source of trouble in the past are busy but calm s the 49-year-old New York Yankee manager relaxes in his office at Fort Lauderdale Stadium.

description: TEL AVIV, April 6The Israeli military command here said tonight that Palestinian guerrillas in southern Lebanon had killed at least three Israeli soldiers who recklessly entered guerrillacontrolled territory during an unauthorized outing yesterday.

title: Stage: Camus Caligula
description: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y.  Men die and they are. unhappy is the tragic sense of life announced in Albert Carnus's play Caligula. The protagonist responds to this desolation by an act of. collusion.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: As dean of dance at the State University of New York at Purchase, Jacques d'Amboise has a clear view of his new role: He wants his students to have as much experience as possible working with professional dancers. Thus, he has invited the former ballerina Maria Tallchief, a friend from their clays together at New York City Ballet, to send her own company, the Chicago Lyric Opera Ballet, to spend a few weeks in residence at the State University. Besides teaching, the Chicago dancers are giving foqr public performances tonight at 7, next Thursday and Friday at 8:30 P.M. and a week from Sunday at 7:30 P.M. The program for each performance will include two works by Mr. d'Amboise and four ballets by George Balanchine, who is his mentor as well as Miss Tallchief's. Tickets are $5 ($15 for the April 16 performance, to be followed by champagne reception); call (914) 2535019 for reservations. From New York, take the Hutchison River Parkway to exit 28. Turn left on Lincoln Avenue; turn right on Anderson Hill Road and follow signs to the dance building.

title: Murdoch Trial Is Postponed
description: BRAMPTON, Ontario, April 6  One cocaine charge against Don Murdoch, the New York Rangers 21-year-old right wing, was dropped while his trial for simple possession of the substance was postponed in proceedings this morning in Provincial Court.

title: Screen: Jane Since Tarzan:From Limb to Limbo
description: A FAVORITE and rather tiresome assumption of a certain kind of sentimental comedy is that the only sane way to respond to the world is by being crazy. It is the small achievement of Walter Bockmayer and Rolf Buhrmann, who wrote and directed the new German film, "Jane Is Jane Forever" (Jane Bleibt Jane), that they can appreciate lunacy without mistaking it for a state of grace."Jane Is Jane Forever" is about a little old lady, Johanna (Johanna Konig), resident of a fairly luxurious home for the elderly, who firmly believes that she is Jane, the long-separated mate to Tarzan, who is pictured on her walls in the persons of Johnny Weissmuller, Gordon Scott and Lex Barker. Her deepest desire: to go back to Tarzan and to Africa, where, she knows, all her problems will vanish.The film, an entry in the Museum of Modern Art's New Directors/New Films series, will be shown at the museum today at 11 P.M. and again Sunday at 8:30 P.M.Johanna is something of a burden to the other women at the home. She sets out to re-create the African jungle in her tiny room, filling it with plants, outlawed by the house rules, and taking as her companion a South American parrot named Loretta. One day she contemplates buying a python, but thinks better of it as she watches it digesting a small white mouse.The thing about Johanna that sets her apart is not her delusion but her awareness that it is a delusion, which is of no importance to her in view of the satisfactions of being crazy. Though Miss Konig, who really looks too young to be senile, has a tendency to play the character for charm, the movie itself is comparatively austere. It contemplates Johanna without tears as if accepting something as inevitable as death, the film's real subject."Jane Is Jane Forever" is a small, sharp movie, sometimes funny but more often decently understanding in the manner of someone who appreciates the privacy of another's terminal illness. Like the newspaper reporter (Peter Chatel) who befriends Johanna, and who accepts her fantasies without ridiculing her, the movie never patronizes its subject.

title: Paris Whittles the Shape of Fall Ready-to-Wear
description: PARIS, April 6  As the first mannequins Cable striding down the runways of the first ready-to-wear shows here for next fall and winter, it was clear that French designers were determined to bring about a .major change in fashion for next season.

title: Thurmond's Years
description: MYRTLE BEACH, S.C.Charles D. Pug Ravenel was exuberint the other night at the conclusion of a joint appearance here with Republican Senator 3. Strom Thurmond.

title: Publishing: ACentennial For Johns Hopkins
description: AS everybody must know by now, Oxford University Press in England is this year cele- brating the 500th anniversary of its founding. America, too, has .a cel- ebratiOn coming, though on a more modest scale, as befits a nation that was just starting when the Oxford press was already 300 years old. The year 1978 marks the centennial of the Johns Hopkins University Prees, thus making it the oldest university press in the United States.

title: At the Craft Show, the Novel and the Ingenious
description: When Michael and Patricia Berrini had their first child four years ago, they were'so disappointed with the children's toys on the market that they decided to make their own. One thing led to another, and now the young craftsmen and their two children live in Norwood, N.Y., amid stuffed cats, dogs, birds, fabric scraps, silkscreen frames and sewing machines.

description: Paul Montgomery, retired executive vice president and director of McGrawHill Inc., died Wednesday at his home mi. Siesta near Sarasota, Fla., following an illness. He was 86 years old.

title: For a National Cigarette Tax
description: Fifteen years ago, cigarette bootlegging was strictly for amateurs. Vacationers on their way home from Florida saved a few dollars by stocking up in states like North Carolina with low cigarette taxes. But then came enormous increases in cigarette taxes in places like New York, pushing the price differential to as much as 21 cents a pack. Professional bootleggers now shuttle back and forth between the lowtax and hightax states.

description: What started out as a modest use of a communications satellite to distib- ute Madison Square Garden sports events live to cabletelevision systems around the country has developed, within a single year, into a small but growing, and already profitable, com- mercial network.

title: HELMUT LANGFELDER, LED WEST GERMAN AIR COMPANY
description: MUNICH, West Germany, April 6 (Reuters)Helmut Langfelder, head of West Germany's largest aerospace company, Messerschmitt-Bblkow-Blohm, was killed today in a helicopter crash in southern France, a company spokesman announced here.

title: Literary Body Honors 13 for Promise
description: Thirteen writers, including novelists, journalists, and poets, were named yesterday to receive 1978 literary awards from the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters. The awards are given for distinction in literature to writers who. without respect to their age, give promise of important work to come.

title: About Real Estate
description: They are mostly young, well paid and highly educated. Their median household income is $24,268. Only 17 percent of their households have children. As a group, they are fairly well satisfied with their housing. Among those who are dissatisfied, especially in Brooklyn. Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island, neatly a third intend to look for suburban housing next.

title: Carter Picks Envoy to South Africa
description: WASHINGTON, April 6  President Carter was reported today to have selected a career diplomat to be the new United States ambassador to South Africa at a time of tension between the two countries.

title: Deaths
description: AMSTERDAMMimi Levit on, we are Profoundly saddened by the passing of the beloved wife of Jack Amsterdam and sister of Harold LevIton, leaders In the Electrical Division of the U.J.A.Federation Joint Campaign. Her devotion to the cause of humanity and concern for the less fortunate are carried on by her family who have long been active In the work of U.J.A. and Federation. To the bereaved members of the family, we extend our deepest sympathy. LAURENCE A. TISCH, President U.J.A.Federation Joint Campaign HARRY R. title: ISRAEL PLANS START OF LEBANON PULLOUT
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 6 , Israel, under mounting pressure to remove its troops from southern Lebanon, has informed United Nations officials that it intends to begin an initial twostage withdrawal next Tuesday.

title: The Trib (1978)
description: The Trib tried and that, alas, must be its main reward. Whoever it was that invested in a new New York newspaper, sinking $5 million into the cause of informing and stirring the community, deserves the city's gratitude. Larger sums are regularly ventured hereabouts on office towers, department stores and other enterprises, but we have a natural sympathy forand interest inthose who risk their money on a newspaper. They would add to the flow of news, controversy and advertising, and they lead with their chins; when they fail, they advertise their own demise.

title: China's Out Visiting
description: HONG KONG - During the last several months, China's efforts to Improve ties with states on its Asian periphery have increased rapidly. This campaign reflects stronger leadership at home, Peking's perception that the time is ripe to stop Soviet attempts at influence in Asia, and general acceptance of China's peaceful intentions in Asia. A feature of the effort has been trips abroad by important officials, reportedly to be topped off by a visit to North Korea by Premier Hua Kuofeng in Aprilhis first ever abroad.

title: Art People
description: FOR a wild month of so, the sculptor Richard Serra, known for his monurnental works composed of steel plates, thought he was going to do a major piece for the Federal Government in Washington.

title: STEPHEN E. KELLY, 58, EXPUBLISHER,IS DEAD
description: Stephen E. Kelly, former publisher of some of the country's best knoWn and biggest magazines and president of the Magazine Publishers Association since 1969, died of cancer yesterday at Hark- ness Pavilion of the Columbia-Presby- terian Medical Center. He was 58 yeais old and lived in New York and South- ampton, L.I.

title: N.C.&K. to Acquire Ted Barash Agency
description: Ted Barash & Company, now 11 years old, is to be acquired by Norman, Craig & Kiumnel but will retain its name and its leader. It is being called a companion agency rather than a subsidiary.

title: Blumenthal, in Letter to Koch, Says Labor lmpasse Imperils Aid to City
description: Unions See Pressure on City pal pension funds that the city needed between now and June 30.

title: Moody's Gives New York State Highest InvestmentGrade Rating
description: ALBANY, April 6Moody's Investor Service today gave New York State's $3.97 billion spring borrowing its highest credit rating.

title: New Film Directors at the Modern
description: Believing she is Jane, Tarzan's mate, a whimsical widow munches bananas amid Tarzan posters, potted palms and a stuffed chimpanzee, as she awaits her jungle hero. A busload of migrant Turkish workers is conned by a swindler who drives them to Stockholm with promises of jobs and then takes their money and passports and vanishes, leaving them in the bus, which becomes their Kafkaesque prison. A 15yearold farmboy who is catapulted to stardom in one movie leaves the drudgery of his father's farm, intruding into the director's life with painful results revealed in a second film.

title: Lawyers for Houston ExOfficers Call Sentence Challenge Political
description: HOUSTON, April 6Lawyers for three former Houston policemen sentenced to a year in prison for their roles in the drowning of a young MexicanAmerican man today attacked a Justice Department challenge to the leniency of the sentences as politically inspired and without legal precedent or foundation.

title: Bankruptcy Court Tells Overmyer To Liquidate to Pay His Creditors
description: A bankruptcy judge declared yesterday that Daniel H. Overniyer's warehouse companies must be liquidated to pay creditors and that the United States At torney should investigate all alleged improprieties in the operations of the companies.

title: Film: Quickie King And Man of Steel:Creators at Work
description: "IN THIS FILM, we are combining the myth of Romeo and Juliet with high-speed car action and a plea for international weapons control in our time," says a young director, hard at work on a 10-day wonder for Roger Corman. Mr. Corman is the man whose New world Pictures gave work to directors like Martin Scorsese and Francis Ford Coppola before anyone else would hire them; even now, after having distributed films by Ingmar Bergman and Franois Truffaut, he is still widely regarded as the king of the action quickie."Roger Corman: Hollywood's Wild Angel" chooses to examine Mr. Corman and his work obliquely, compiling laughably lurid film clips with brief revealing looks at some of Mr. Corman's protgs, who have been forced by New World's tight budgets and breakneck pacing to take a fairly cavalier attitude toward the esthetic possibilities of the cinema. As one of them puts it, "The toughest thing about directing is getting up in the morning."Although Mr. Corman is briefly interviewed here his employees' recollections of his advice are a good deal more telling than anything he says himself. Jonathan Demme, who made films like "Caged Heat" for New World before directing "Handle With Care," explains that Mr. Corman likes to annotate each script he reads, scribbling things like "breast nudity possible here?"Another Corman protg remembers a tidbit that proved invaluable: Try not to stand up when you don't have to, Mr. Corman told him. And don't stop to congratulate your crew after each shot is completed. If chewing the fat takes a minute each time, and you knock off 30 shots in a day, you can save yourself all of half an hour that way.Christian Blackwood, who directed this profile as part of the Museum of Modern Art's New Films/New Directors series, has assembled an amusing series of excerpts and trailers ("The Student Nursesenter their course!"). He has also lined up interviews with some of Mr. Corman's best-known and most personable protgs, among them Mr. Demme, Paul Barthel, Allan Arkush, Joe Dante, David Carradine, Ron Howard. Peter Fonda and Mr. Scorsese.Also on hand are a number of actors and actresses who aren't likely to work again anywhere, ever. Mr. Corman doesn't seem to care who his directors hire, as long as the performers can drive, scream, bleed, make horrible jokes and work for peanuts.In view of its subject, and of Mr. Corman's oft-repeated emphasis on speed and economy, Mr. Blackwood's generally frisky film goes slacker than it should at times. And it does seem a shame that after Mr. Blackwood cites Mr. Corman's prescient qualities and paints him as a man with his hand on the pulse of America's youth, the film never grills this entrepreneur about the current zeitgeist. A film about a man so clearly ahead of his time ought to explore his notion of the mood of the moment.The sculptor subject of "Mark di Suvero: North Star," a film by Franois de Menil that shares the same bill, should have been a good match for Mr. Corman: Both men are playful, economical and quite purposeful about what they do. But Mr. di Suvero's work, huge metal sculptures, however eloquent they may seem when photographed from various angles and accompanied by Philip Glass's pulsating electronic score, loses something in scope and grandeur when captured on the screen. And Mr. di Suvero's observations about his work tend to undermine rather than amplify.Mr. di Suvero is clearly a man of enormous charm and vitality, but his conversation is every bit as vague as his work is streamlined. And Mr. de Menil's direction takes the sculptor's fuzziest observations at face value. "The artist has to reject whatever society is doing around him in order to become an artist," Mr. di Suvero says. And: "The United States is guilty of something like Chile#8212;that's incredible.""Do any of your sculptures make a political statement?" Mr. di Suvero is asked. He cites one called "Mother Peace," explaining that "if you really look carefully at it, it works in many different ways." Later, the art critic Barbara Rose asks, in an insinuatingly intimate, Rona Barrett-like tone, whether Mr. di Suvero is afraid he's crazy. "C'mon, I'm afraid I'm too sane," is his predictable reply.Mr. di Suvero's works are seen in many different settings, from bleak, industrial-looking cities to the Tuileries. However, the question of what relationship a large, outdoor work of art ought to have to setting is sniffed at rather than addressed. A few French people are shown to have mixed opinions about a huge sculpture in a public garden, and one American art commissioner sadly but smugly notes the general public's inability to understand contemporary avant-garde art.Footage of the 1975 opening of the Whitney Museum's di Suvero retrospective is much more revealing of what art loses in translation on its way to an audience, as well-dressed first-nighters view the show with an elitism fiercely incompatible with the work and all it stands for. The film's most piquant moment shows a woman reclining playfully on one of Mr. di Suvero's mobile pieces, drawling that it might be fun to have something just like this at the summer place in the Hamptons.

title: Reserve Report
Music: A Mature Ozolins
description: BETWEEN his debut here in 1966 and his return appearance in 1971, Arthur Ozolins had apparently developed substantially as a pianist. His technical equipment had never been in question, but the degree of his penetration into the works he played was. In his recital in Alice Tully Hall on Wednesday night, the pianist had matured even more. Now 32 years old, he gave concert that was consistently arresting.

title: Man, 27, Goes Berserk After Stealing a City Taxicab
description: A 27-year-old man described by the palice as a numbers runner went berserk in midtown early yesterday afternoon and ran down a pedestrian, scratched a truck driver's chest, hit a cabdriver's hand and stole his vehicle, then rammed into four other taxicabs, injuring four more persons. One person was reported in critical condition.

title: Blumenthal Says Labor Stalemate Perils Aid to City
description: Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal warned Mayor Koch yesterday that without a speedy and responsible settlement between the city and its unions, the loan legislation now pending before Congress would be in real jeopardy.

title: The Pop Life
description: Hes moves from label to label, selling at a bare level of respectability, and as he put it ruefully on the telephone the other day from Philadelphia, about his new album Final Exam: If this record stiffs out, I could be on a fourth label. Or there's the possibility that Clive [Davis. president of his current Arista] will continue to allow me to make records for his company.

title: A Tel Aviv Rally Protests Begin's Policy
description: JERUSALEM, April 6_Suddenly we found ourselves leading a kind of moveMent, said Pzali Resheff, a law student. We didn't really organize it wellit means people in Israel feel that neope have got to do something.

description: Preparatory Committee for Special Session on Disarmament10:30 A.M.

title: Miss Guthrie Gets a Car and Money for the Indy 500
description: A week Igo Janet Guthrie said on national television that no one wanted to sponsor a 40-year-old woman driver for the Indianapolis 500 this year.

title: Carlo Tagliabue, Italian Baritone; Sang at La Scala and the Met
description: Carlo Tagliabue, Italian opera baritone who sang leading roles at the Metropolitan Opera in the 193738 and 193839 seasons, died at Monza, near Milan, Wednesday night. He was 80 years old and had been in retirement 20 years.

title: MacLeish Decries Takeovers in Publishing
description: Archibald MacLeish, addressing some leading book publishers at the New York Public Library last evening, as he accepted the 1978 National Medal for Literature, said that the conglomerates taking over independent book-publishing houses have a high devotion to private profit at the expense of everything else, including the country's literature.

description: A bankruptcy judge declared yesterday that Daniel H. Overmyer's warehouse companies must be liquidated to pay creditors ,and that the United. States At torney should investigate all alleged improprieties in the operations of the companies.

description: Thursday, Argil 6, 1978

title: At the Movies
description: 'AS an adjective, 'French is often misapplied, Louis Malle was saying the other day. Take the French Quarter in New Orleans, where we filmed Pretty Baby. The architecture is actually Spanish.

title: Letter to Koch By Blumenthal
description: Following is the text of a letter sent yesterday to Mayor Koch by W. Michael Blumenthal, Secretary of the Treasury:

title: Children in Foster Care: Keeping in Touch With Their Natural Parents
description: On the surface, they hardly seem to be model parents, those people who entrust their children to foster care. They may be incapable of coping with responsibility, they may be physically disabled or mentally disturbed, they may be alcoholics or drug addicts.

title: Murray Hill Bar's Shift to a Disco Rejected
description: After pleas by community leaders and elected officials from the Murray Hill area, the Board of Estimate yesterday revened,a ruling by the Board of Standards and Appeals that would have permitted Uncle Charlie's South, at restaurant and.bar, to become a discotheque.

title: Ballet Hispanico at Henry St.
description: The Ballet Hispanico of New York will dance Jose Coronado's Mosaico Mexicano this weekend at the Henry Street Settlement Playhouse, 466 Grand Street. Performances are at 7:30 P.M. tonight and tomorrow, 3 P.M. on Sunday. Tickets are $3.50 ($2.50 for students, children and the elderly); Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted. Information: 7669334.

title: Art: An Abstract Study in White
description: SOME of the subtlest and most mysterious of Richard Pousette- Dart's abstract paintings are to be found among the big white pictures he produced nearly 30 years ago. That was a timethe late 1940's and early 50'swhen many of the painters of the New York School. of wnicn Mr. PousetteDart was a founding member, were occupied with the problem of the black and white painting, but even then this artist's work stood a little apart. On a spacious field of titanium white pigment, Mr. PousetteDart drew elaborate fretwork de signs-of interlacing lines in pencil. The effect was less like that of a black and white picture than of a dreamlike white space inhabited by delicate silvery traceries of light.

title: I.R.S. Inquiry on Nevada Tips
description: RENO, April 6 (UPI)  Workers. in Nevada hotelcasinos reported tips of SI4 million during the first nine months. of this year but should have reported. ak additional $70 million, Gerald Swanson;the Internal Revenue Service director for Nevada, said today. He said that his agency was using a computer to track. dealers, waiters and others who received tips to gee that they complied with the requirement they report to employers tips exceeding $20 each month.

title: Restaurants
description: WHATEVER the friagic forces are that combine to insure the success of a new restaurant they are operating full force on behalf of Hoexter's Market, a fivemonthold, jampacked restaurant on Third Avenue between 81st and 82d Streets.

description: Treasury Secretary W. Michael Blumenthal warned Mayor Koch yesterday that without a speedy and responsible settlement between the city and unions, the loan legislation now pending before Congress would be in real jeopardy.

description: Egg decorating, needlepoint, origami and calligraphy will be among crafts demonstrated at the Heritage Festival at Freehold Raceway in Freehold, N.J., indoors, rain or shine, on Sunday from 11 A.M. to 7P.M.

title: Pop: Teresa Brewer. and Her Guests
description: TERESA BREWER insisted introducing guests who uptaged her throughout her concert Wednesday at Carnegie Hall. Stephane Grappelli opened with a quietly dazzling set of violin improvisations; Dizzy Gillespie and the allstar big band that had been assembled for the evening stole the second half of the show, and during Miss Brewer's two sets there were vivid cameo appearances by Cootie Williams on trumpet, Johnny Mince on clarinet, and Al Grey from the big band's trombone section, among others.

title: House Votes, by 367 to 2, To Let Reserve Control Foreign Banks in the U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP)The House of Representatives voted by 367 to 2 today to put foreign banks that operate in the United States under the control of the Federal Reserve Board.

title: Magic Materializes at Public Theater
description: Visual Alchemy, a program of magic by Jeff Sheridan, will follow to night and tomorrow night's performances of Runaways by Elizabeth Swados (tickets for which are sold out) at the Theater Cabaret of the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater. Mr. Sheridan's performances are at'10:30 P.M. the next three weekends.. Admission is $6. Advance tickets at the box office,, they may be purchased at the door.

description: The singers Richie Havens and Mary Travers, formerly of Peter, Paul and Mary, can be heard tonight at 8 at Carnegie Hall, Seventh Avenue and 57th Street. Also on the program is Country Joe McDonald. Tickets, $6.50, $7.50, $8 and $8.50, are available at the Carnegie Hall box office, 2477459; through Ticketron, 9779020, and Chargit, 2317177

Also, a story hour for children 3 to 6 is scheduled for 11 A.M. Information: 3620634.

title: JOHNSON &
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, April 6Johnson & Johnson Inc. announced today that would construct a new $50 million worldwide corporate headquarters in down town New Brunswick.

title: Aaron J. Goodelman, Sculptor Who Illustrated Children's Books
description: Aaron J. Goodelman, a sculptor whose work is represented in institutions in this country and in Israel, died Wednesday at the Flushing Manor for the Aged. He was 90 years old last Saturday and lived in the Bronx.

title: Broadway
description: OTTO PREMINGER says he will produce and direct a new mystery play on Broadway next season. It is called Ricochet, and it is by Paul Nathan, a columnist for the magazine Publishers Weekly. Ricochet has a cast of six, and Mr. Preminger says they may be stars, but then again they may not. He also says he hopes to take the play out of town in September or October (and open it on Broadway shortly after that.

title: Deaths
description: SERGIMaria (nee DiTrapani) on April 5. 1978, beloved wife of the late Vincent J.. Mother of Frank. Sam and Connie Ballenbera, also survived by 5 grandchildren & 3 sisters. Funeral Saturday, 9:30 AM from Edw. H.C. Dunne Funeral Home, 29R 7th Ave. (nr 7th St. BklyIn Mass 01 Christian burial 10:15 AN'i St. Saviour Church. Entombment Holy Cross Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, donations to Methodist Hospital would be appreciated. Visiting 2.5 and 710PM.

title: Jersey Teachers Get More Time To Fulfill a Bilingual Requirement
description: TRENTON, April 6 (AP)Public school teachers who have failed to meet state proficiency requirements for teaching bilingual classes have been granted a reprieve by the New Jersey Beard of Education, which adopted a resolution yesterday extending an Aug, 31 deadline for meeting the requirements to April 1979.

title: Market Place
description: The efforts by foreign interests to make a substantial investment in Ma- rine Midland Banks suggest to some observers that many banks in need of capital may find it abroad.

title: Hunt of Cosmos Ailing
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 6Steve Hunt may miss the Cosmos game Sunday in Los Angeles against the Aztecs. The 21-year-old left wing has been bothered by an aching thigh muscle on his right leg since last Friday. He aggravated it last Sunday in the 7.0 victory over Fort Lauderdale in which he scored three goals and assisted on two others.

title: Curare Case Examiner Testifies He Suspected Drugs in Autopsy
description: HACKENSACK, N. J., April 6A Medical Examiner testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that while he had listed one of the patients the doctor is accused of murdering in 1965 as having died from a coronary occlusion, he had had a suspicion while doing the autopsy that drugs might have been involved.

title: Bob Hayes Is Arrested For Drugs
description: Bob Hayes, winner of two Olympic gold medals in 1964 and for 10 seasons a prominent pass receiver for the Dallas Cowboys, was arrested in North Dallas yesterday on drug charges. Hayes, 35 years old, was charged with three counts of the ale of cocaine. He was released on $30.000 bond.

title: HOUSING CHALLENGE SPURNED AT RUTGERS
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, April 6Dr. Edward J. Bloustein, president of Rutgers University, said today that he had anticipated the latest challenge o his administraion, a protest by some students over university housing plans, bu that the housing program will go forward as proposed.

title: Decorative Arts In Napoleon's Time
description: FOR eyes that hunger for the silk and silver conceits of the Napoleonic era, the new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art (through, July 30) provides a rare opportunity to gorge on the seldomseen survivals of that distant imperial epoch. Called The Arts Under Napoleon, this survey of ZbU meets is said to be the first such exhibition of the decorative arts of the Napoleonic period (17991815) ever organized in a New York museum.

title: ULLMAN SEEKS DELAY ON SOCIAL SECURITY
description: WASHINGTON, April 6Two senior House Democrats declared today that despite a call by House Democrats for cuts in Social Security taxes this year, Congress should take no action until 1979.

title: BIG BOARD PROPOSES RULE MINGLING 2 TRADING ROLES
description: Directors of the New York Stock Exchange approved in principle yesterday a rule that would establish a new category of memberthe registered competitive marketmaker. The rule must be submitted to the Securities and Exchange Commission for approval. ,

title: Opera: Domingo Sings Lead in Both `Cav and Paz Columbia Disk Delays Protested
description: PLACIDO DOMINGO celebrated the 1,300th and 1,301st performances of his career Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera by singing both tenor leads in the twin bill of Cavalleria Rusticana and Pagliacci, which was televised nationally by the Public Broadcasting Service. Many tenors include Turridu and Canio in their repertories, but few offer to sing the two of them in one eveningexcept for the indefatigable Mr. Domingo, who has already accomplished this feat about 25 times, in Vienna, at Covent Garden, in San Francisco and now at the Met.

title: Opposition in Manila Sounds Off on Eve of Election
description: MANILA, April 6In a raucous gesture of protest against President Ferdinand E. Marcos's martiallaw rule, tens of thousands of Filipinos honked their car horns, shouted and banged on tin cans tonight on the eve of the election for an interim national assembly.

title: Duryea Will Make Issue of Carey's Expected Veto of the Death Penalty
description: Chargi,ng that Governor Carey was weak on crime, Perry B. Duryea, Jr., the Assembly minority leader, said yesterday that he would make a big issue in the coming gubernatorial campaign of Governor Carey's expected veto of deathpenalty bill.

title: 2 Coast Businessmen Emphasize Strong Opposition to Controls
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The talk of the business world here, and seemingly everywhere else at the moment, is the upsurge in inflation this year and the danger that it will continue. Of particular concern in this area is what action

title: SON OF SAM SUSPECT IS FACING TRIAL SOON
description: A State Supreme Court justice In Brooklyn announced yesterday that jury selection in the trial of David R. Berkowitz for the murder last July 31 of Stacy Moskowitz would start one week from Monday it the suspect were found fit to stand trial.

title: Cleveland Voters Reject Tax to Bail Out Schools
description: CLEVELAND, April 6Voters here rejected by an overwhelming margin today a schooltax increase meant to raise $150 million over the next five years and keep public schools open.

title: CARTER SAID TO FAVOR DELAY IN PRODUCTION OF THE NEUTRON BOMB
description: WASHINGTON, April 6Administration officials said today that President Carter was expected to announce tomorrow an indefinite delay in producing the neutron bomb.

title: Patient Care Found Deteriorating In 3d Day of NursingHome Strike
Massachusetts U. Protest Ends
description: AMHERST, Mass., April 6 (AP)About 75 University of Massachusetts protesters voted early today to accept a series of housing policy compromises and ended their 17hour occupation of the universi ty's administration building. Student leaders said the key compromise reached was a measure aimed at guaranteeing, students a lease arrangement for univer1 sity housing.

title: EASTERN ACCEPTS $778 MILLION DEAL TO GET 23 AIRBUSES
description: Eastern Air Lines and the builder of the European A300 Airbus announced yesterday that they had signed a contract for Eastern to acquire 23 of the planes for $778 million.

title: 5 Men Are Charged in Sexual Blackmail Of Playboy  'Bunnies
description: Five men were accused yesterday of luring young women, including Playboy Bunnies', to a house in Sussex Conty where the women were allegedly drugged and videotaped in sex acts as part of a scheme to blackmail them.

title: Sabres 5, Bruins 2
description: BOSTON, April 6 (AP)The Buffalo Sabres took advantage of a rusty Gerry Cheevers in the Boston net to score three goals in the first period and went on to gain a 52 victory over the Bruins tonight. Cheevers recovered to play two strong periods in his first start since Feb. 21 as the Boston goalie tested his ailing right knee for the playoffs.

title: 3,% Rise in Air Fares Authorized by C.A.B.
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP)The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized United States domestic scheduled airlines today to increase their basic fares 3 percent, effective May 1. The board had said last fall that it would permit increases twice a year when necessary to take into account inflationary cost pressures.

title: Film: Homage to Garcia Lorca:In Museum Series
description: "TO AN UNKNOWN GOD" ("A un Dios Desconocido"), the second feature film by Jaime Chavarri, the Spanish director, is a handsome, densely packed, evocative movie that makes a lot of rather stern demands upon anyone who sees it. It's the sort of thing one should prepare for, like an uncut "Hamlet," a full-length "Die Meistersinger" or a "Blood Wedding" in Spanish.The film, which will be shown at the Museum of Modern Art today at 8:30 P.M. and on Monday at 6 P.M., is one of three that today begins the annual New Directors/New Films series at the museum. The series is jointly presented by the museum's department of film and the Lincoln Center Film Society.Like the recent films of Carlos Saura and Victor Erice, "To an Unknown God" recalls the legacy of nearly 40 years of the Franco dictatorship but it does this in terms that are so special, so private, that one attends the film as if it were a meeting of cabalists. The movie is full of secret signs and mysterious associations. Over it all hangs the ghost of Federico Garcia Lorca, the Spanish poet and playwright who was murdered in 1936 by the Falangists who despised his homosexuality as much as his left-wing politics.Though most of the film is the contemporary memoir of a middle-aged, homosexual magician named Jos (Hector Alterio), the film opens in Granada in 1936 when Jos as a small boy, was seduced by an older boy who was living in the elegant old house where Garcia Lorca's murder, this opening sec-unfamiliar with the circumstances of Garcia Lorca's murder, this opening section makes no sense whatsoever. As it is, one never is exactly sure who Jos's young male lover is, or what his connection is to the famous guest, who is seen once in a long, shot, much as Christ is sometimes glimpsed in Biblical epics.Jos appears to be a successful magician, at least in bookings, but his life is fastidiously lonely. Though his somewhat younger lover, Miguel (Javier Elorriaga), a worker on behalf of radical causes, is open-hearted and generous, Jos devotes himself to the memory of his lost youth. At one point he returns to Granada for a reconciliation with a woman who, like Jos is obsessed by the memory of Garcia Lorca as well as by the memory of the boy, now dead, whom they both loved.For some peculiar reason, English subtitles, which adequately translate most of the film's Spanish dialogue, are denied us in two key sequences in which Jos as he's going to bed, plays a tape containing (I think) Jos himself speaking Garcia Lorca's poetry. Perhaps Mr. Chavarri thinks it would be sacrilege to translate the poet's lines as mere subtitles. In any case we are denied key information and must make out as best we can by recognizing, on the tape, references to "Valt Vitmann" and the Spanish words meaning "sleep," "dream" and "death."Because of its Spanish origin, "To an Unknown God" has astonished a number of European critics for its frank, unhysterical treatment of homosexuality, but the truth is that Mr. Chavarri's particular preoccupations result in a movie that seems as self-interested, even arrogant, as poor, lonely Jos. "To an Unknown God" is lovely to look at, highly cultivated and poised, and very, very difficult to get to know.

title: CurzonPerahia Concert For Sunday Canceled
description: The concert that was to be given Sunday by the pianists Clifford Curzon and Murray Perahia in Alice Tully Hall at 7:30 p.m. has been canceled be- cause of Mr. Perahia's indisposition.

title: Federal Jury Finds Man Guilty In Child Pornography Trial
description: PORTLAND, Me., April 6 (UPI)A jury today found a Rhode Island man guilty in the nation's second Federal trial involving child pornography.

title: Teheran Announces It Has Broken Up A Soviet Spy Ring
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 6 (UPI) - Iran said today that it had smashed a Soviet espionage network that had included retired 85-year-old Iranian general. He was the second general in four months to be accused of spying for Moscow.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Rose 4.4%
description: WASHINGTON, April 6The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 17.2 billion tonmiles, up 4.4 percent from the yearearlier level. Carloadings in the same period totaled 461,611 cars, off 1.7 percent from last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage fell 1.2 percent from a year ago.

title: Jesse H. Riddle, Retired Adviser For Bankers Trust Company, 89
description: Jesse H. Riddle, a retired vice president and economic adviser for the Bankers Trust Company, died Monday at his home in the Gramercy Park Hotel in Manhattan. He was 89 years old.

title: Rangers Lose but Make Playoffs
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 6. LThe Rangers did themselves no favors tonight, but Detroit did. Although New York lost to the Philadelphia Flyers, 30, at the Spectrum, the Red Wings beat Pittsburgh, .64. to eliminate the Penguins from a playoff spot and put the Rangers in.

title: Poor CityTennis Courts Result in a Net Loss
description: New York has more municipal tennis courts than any other city in the world. So with the season set to open tomorrow, why is Martin Pearl of Brooklyn, an avid player, unhappy?

A Correction
description: The recipe for pretzels in The Living Section Wednesday incorrectly called for one ounce of powdered dry yeast. It should have read one package of powdered dry yeast, which weighs one-quarter ounce.

title: Suit Says High School Graduated A Pupil Reading at 2dGrade Level
description: NEWARK, April 6The mother of 23-year-bld Maplewood factory worker has filed suit for damages, charging that officials in the South-Orange-Maplewood school system failed to diagnose and treat her son for a visual disorder and that he was awarded a high school diploma though he could read only at a secondgrade level.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
description: Article 3 -- No Title

title: Sadat Is Said to Base Peace Hopes on a Commitment From Carter
description: CAIRO, April 6Egyptian officials are waiting for the Carter Administration to fulfill what wellplaced Cairo sources say is a pledge to step in with an American plan to move the Middle East peace negotiations forward if Israel and Egypt cannot break their deadlock.

title: U.S. Sues 2 Doctors and a Company Over Dispensing of Amphetamines
Dollar Sinks on News Saudis Might Raise Oil Prices
description: The dollar closed mostly lower yesterday in generally quiet foreign exchange trading in Europe and Tokyo, and slid more sharply in New York after it was announced that Saudi Arabia might agree to raise the price of oil, The Associated Press reported.

title: Villella to Get Arts Post
description: Edward Villella, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, is scheduled to be named next week as chairman of the city's Commission on Cultural Affairs. The announcement will follow several weeks of speculation in New York's cultured and social circles about the appointment.

title: Harold Comfort, Borden Executive
description: Harold Wesley Comfort, president from 1956 to 1964 of the Borden Company, the dairyproducts concern, died yesterday in his home at 736 Lake Avenue, Greenwich, Conn. He was 81 years old.

title: $3.79 Billion Sale Of State's Notes Is Going Smoothly
description: The largest taxexempt financing ever undertaken at one timeNew York State's sale of $3.79 billion in notesbegan yesterday after the Legislature approved the final portion of the State's budget and Moody's Investors Services, a key rating agency, gave the securities its top rating.

title: Bridge:
description: Sponsoring in bridge has been spreading markedly in the past decade, but it takes several different forms.

title: Estonians May Dislike Russians But Show Little Desire to Secede
description: TALLINN, U.S.S.R.The young Estonian teacher was invited to make three wishes. She was sitting across the table in a dark discotheque here, in the capital of Soviet Estonia, sipping a Cuban banana liqueur. _

title: SCHOOL BOARD TO END TEACHER ASSIGNMENT ON THE BASIS OF RACE
description: New York City's Board of Education has decided to end the controversial system of assigning teachers on the basis of race.

title: 3Day Renaissance Festival
description: WASSAIL! We are all invited to a weekend in another place and time. Tonight at 8 the second annual Renaissance Festival begins at Christ Church on Park Avenue at 60th Street, and for the next two evenings and Sunday afternoon the church and City College's Institute for Medieval and. Renaissance Studies will be offering a feast for all the senses. There will be music. There will be magic, and jugglers and actors. There will be colorful costumes (some of them in the audience, it is hoped). And with it all there will be mulled cider and rosepetal bread.

title: Girls Use of Cigarettes InJerseyRisingSharply
description: TRENTON, April 6 (UPI)The State Health Department says cigarette smoking has doubled among female teenagers in New Jersey in the last several years. A department spokesman said yesterday that in the 13-to-19 age group almost as many girls as boys were smokine.

title: Music: Comissiona Leads Mahler
description: THE Baltimore Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Sergiu Comissiona, came to Carnegie Hall last night with one of the longer and more difficult pieces in the literatureMahler's Das Lied von der Erde.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, Apr.

title: TAX-BREAK PROGRAM IS FOUND POORLY RUN
description: New York City Investigators say a program that has granted millions of dollars in tax reductions to apartment developers and owners is run so sloppily that it gives the appearance, at tittles, of being dominated by the applicant? for the benefits.

title: F.B.I. Aide Promoted To Associate Director
description: WASHINGTON, April 6 (AP)James B. Adams, head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation's investigative section since mid1974, was promoted .today to the secondranking position in the bureau by William H. Webster, Director of the F.B.I.

title: Music: All Mozart String Quartet
description: IF AN aura of tradition and presumed authority ever surrounded a concert, it did so on Wednesday night at the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A., where the Salzburg Mozarteurn String Quartet played an allMozart program. The group was composed of leading players or me mozarteum orchestra in Salzburg, the small Austrian town that gave Mozart to the world 222 years ago. It doesn't matter that he hated the town and struggled much of his life to escape from it; Mozart still belongs to Salzburg, where he is today the chief product of a thriving industry.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, APRIL 6, 1978

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly reported in The Times yesterday that the new age limit of 70 for mandatory retirement would become effective for employees covered by collective bargaining agreements with compulsory retirement provisions at the termination of the current contract or July I, 1980, whichever came first. The correct date is Jan. 1, 1980.

title: A Casino Gala Due at Yale Tonight
description: NEW HAVEN, Yale's Gothic Commons Dining Hall will be transformed tomorrow night into a glittering gambling casino complete with baccarat tables, croupiers, magnums of champagne, Flamenco dancers and 1,000 guests.

title: Lopez to Defend Crowns
description: LOS ANGELES, (AP)Danny Lopez will defend his world featherweight boxing championship on April 23 against Eduarto Prieto of Chile. Aileen Eaton, a promoter for the Olympic Auditorium here, said today that Lopez would make his third title defense since Nov, 6, 1976.

title: Transit Workers Are Torn on Pact
description: The transit workers contract, criticized in Congress as too generous, coming under sharp attack by the union's rank and file. The complaints center on two features of the pact: the single pay raise6 percent over 21 months, and an experimental program to hire parttime token sellers.

title: Four Killed in Georgia Crash
description: LAVONIA, Ga., (UPI)Four South Carolina men were killed yesterday when their pickup truck pulling a trailer overturned while trying to pass a tractortrailer truck on 185. They were identified as Jerry W. Clark, 28 years old, of Ware Shoals, S. C., and Jean Claude Subjobert, age unknown; Jim Grothaun, 46, and Peter Pettip, age unknown, all of Greenville, S. C.

title: PRESIDENT DECIDES TO DEFER PRODUCTION OF NEUTRON WEAPONS
description: WASHINGTON, April 7  President Carter announced today that he had decided to defer production of the controversial highradiation neutron warhead.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: NEW YORK, (AP)A Federal judge refused today to disqualify two New York law firms helping the Kennecott Copper Corporation in its proxy fight with the CurtissWright Corporation.

title: Rites for Stephen E. Kelly
description: A memorial service for Stephen E. Kelly, president of the Magazine pabUshers Association. who died Thursday. will be held Tuesday at 11:30 A.M. in the auditorium of the McGrawHill Building 1221 Avenue of the Americas, at 49th Street.

title: Mets Take Opener As Expos Bow, 31
description: Mayor Koch and a notably small group of 11,736 fellow citizens welcomed baseball back to New York yesterday hi Shea Stadium and watched Jerry Koosman pitch the Mets into their new era with a 31 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: Corco Loses $11 Million in Quarter
description: The financially troubled Commonwealth Oil Refining Company reported yesterday that it lost $11.1 million in the final quarter of last year, compared with a $26.7 million loss incurred in the 1976 fourth quarter. Corco, which has refinery opera- tions and petrochemical plants mainly in Puerto Rico, showed sales of $222 million in the fourth quarter, compared with $272 million for the quarter a year earlier.

title: Wife Tells How Soviet Defector Tried to Get Her Out
description: MOSCOW, The wife of a Soviet defector told Western correspondents today that she had tried four times to rendezvous secretly with a Western pilot near the Finnish border and fly out of the country to join her husband in Sweden but finally had to give up last weekend.

title: ACCORD ENDS STRIKE AT 69 NURSING HOMES IN THE NEW YORK AREA
description: 12,000 WORKERS RETURN TODAY Pact, With 20% Raise Over 3 Years, Comes as State Finds Conditions at Facilities Critically Bad

title: White Sox Top Red Sox With 2 Runs in 9th, 65
description: CHICAGO, (UPI)Ron. Blomberg, a free,agent pickup from the Yankees, tied the game in the ninth with a homer today and Wayne Nordhagen won it with a bloop double as the Chicago White Sox defeated the Boston Red Sox, 65. A record Comiskey Park daygame crowd of 50,754 watched the season opener for both teams.

title: Waldheim Criticizes Israeli Plans On Lebanon Pullout as Inadequate
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 7-Secretary General Kurt Waldheim today criticized as inadequate an Israeli plan for a twostage initial withdrawal from territory occupied in southern Lebason last mentli_

title: CABINETLEVEL AGENCY 1 FOR INDIAN AFFAIRS URGED
description: 1 WASHINGTON, (AP)An In; terior Department study group has recommended reshaping the Bureau of Indian Affairs and setting up a Cabinetlevel panel to look after the interests of American Indians.

description: Professor Emeritus at Columbia, 77, Had Just Completed New Book on the Lexicographer

title: Around the Nation
description: SEATTLE, April 7 (UPI)San Francisco leads the nation's major cities in incidence of heroin addiction, with Los Angeles close behind, the National Institutg of Drug Abuse says.

title: JAPAN FINDS PLIGHT IN GROWING EXPORTS AND LAGGING IMPORTS
description: TOKYO,As Japan began its new 1978 fi?cal year this month, it found itself in a serious predicament. Contrary to international commitments, its exports continue to expand vigorously while its imports grow only slightly.

title: Deaths
description: ARONSONEmma Rudolph. On April 6, 1978. Loving mother of Katherine, NIcken and Ruth Berner. Mother-inlaw of Dr. George Niddin and Jerome Berner. Also survived by Emily NIcklin Schleusener, David. Jane and Sarah Nicklin and Julie, Susan and Daniel Berner. Services Saturday 11 AM at the Fairchild Chapel, Garden City. Interment Friends Cemetery, Westbury. Donations to the New Utrecht Dutch Reformed Church of Brooklyn would be appreciated.

title: CAREY WAS WARNED ON ATTICA PARDONS
description: The special state prosecutor whose recommendations Governor Carey cited as his reasons for granting pardons in the, Attica Prison uprising specifically recommended against clemency for Cleveland Davis. the man accused of slaying two policemen last weekend.

title: JERSEY ANNOUNCES CLEANAIR STRATEGY
description: TRENTON, The New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection said today it would move to force industry in New Jersey to limit emissions into the atmosphere from eight suspected cancercausing chemicals and from gases that cause smog.

title: CORRECTION
description: It was incorrectly reported in The Times yesterday that the new age limit of 70 for mandatory retirement would become effective for employees covered by collective bargaining agreements with compulsory retirement provisions at the termination of the current contract or July 1, 1980, whichever came first. The correct date is Jan. 1, 1980.

title: ExJudge Is Given Liquidation Task
description: Harold R. ,Tyler Jr., a former Deputy Attorney General of the United States, was named yesterday to supervise the lsiquidation of the warehouse business of Daniel H. Overmyer, who charged that his company had been systematically looted during years of bankruptcy proceedings.

title: WILLIAMATIC TENSE SINCE DRUG ARRESTS
description: HARTFORD, April 7Less than three weeks ago, the industrial town of Willimantic, 30 miles east of here, was jolted by the news that 54 of its youngsters six of whom were only 9 years oldhad been arrested on charges of possessing and selling drugs.

title: Jazz: Lionel Hampton's Big Band
description: The pulsing riffs that have been driving force in Lionel Hampton's big band ever since he formed it in 1941 are still an essential part of the rhythmic foundation of the band's perform- ance at the Yankee Riverboat, Fifth Avenue and 34th Street, where it is playing through tonight. But there is now also a subtlety in the band's playing that was sometimes lost in the furor of its exuberant riffing in the past.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, APRIL 8, 1978

title: U.S. Says Israelis in Lebanon Used Cluster Bombs, Breaking Pledge
description: WASHINGTON, April 7Administration officials said today that Israel had apparently broken an unpublicized agreement with the United States when it used cluster bombsa devastating antipersonnel weaponagainst targets in southern Lebanon last month.
