title: Jury Gets Korean's Bribery Case
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP)A Federal jury began deliberations today in the trial of Hancho C. Kim, who is charged with plotting to bribe Congressmen to curry their favor for the Korean Government.

title: Defense in Curare Trial Contends Improper Practices Caused Deaths
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., The defense in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich sought to establish today that a series of sudden and unexplained! deaths at Riverdell Hospital was caused by improper practices at the hospital and not. by Dr. Jascalevich.

title: Rights Come First
description: After serving three years of a sevenaar sentence on a charge spreading hostile propaganda'specifically, criticizing President Tito's Government in articles published abroad,the dissident Yugoslav writer Mihail() Mihajlov was released from prison Nov. 24 under a general antnesty.that included 217 other political prisoners. Ile said afterward that was ready to return to prison rather than stop criticizing the regime. Two months later, he addressed a plea to the Belgrade conference on European security and cooperation, urging a reference to human rights in its final document. In the summary document closing the conference, last month, because of the Soviet Union's opposition there was no such reference. Following are excerpts from Mr. Mihajlov's request, translated from the SerboCroatian.

title: Poor Care Alleged in Curare Trial
description: HACKENSACK, April 7The defense in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich sought to establish today that a series of sudden and unexplained deaths at Riverdale Hospital was caused by improper practices at the hospital and not by Dr. Jascalevich.

title: Who Would't Love New York?; OBSERVER
description: Things to do on Saturday in New York: 1. Put on five suits of clothes and walk crosstown talking out loud to Yourself in Esperanto. 2. Put on a pair of brushedsuede trousers and get a $35 haircut.

title: Labor Facts and Fantasies
description: The leaders of New York City's labor unions, notably Victor Gotbaum and Barry Feinstein, had better heed rather than scoff at Treasury Secretary Blumenthal's warning that time is running out for negotiation of new contracts. The needed Federal loans. Mr. Blumenthal said, will never be approved by Congress if the city's labor costs are unsettled or excessive. The unions seem to believe they will gain something by waiting until the city becomes desperate for Federal cash. But delay will surely endanger the Federal loan that the unions need as much as all other New Yorkers.

title: Carter Move May Deepen Public's Doubts
description: WASHINGTON, April 7This week's highly publicized controversy over the neutron bomb has ended with a.fencestraddling, delaying compromise 1?5, President Carter that is unlikely to put the issue to rest and may only serve to deep- en the public's uncertainties about him.

title: I.C.C.URGED TO SPLIT SEABOARD COAST LINE
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP)The Interstate Commerce Commission's enforcement bureau has urged the I.C.C. to partly break up the Seaboard Coast Line Railroad as the only way to restore competition, the commission said today.

title: Marcos Party Far Ahead in Vote Amid Evidence of Fraud in Manila
description: MANILA, Saturday, April 8Amid evidence cf fraudulent ballot counting and police harassment of the opposition, President Ferdinand E. Marcos's New Society Movement appeared on its way today to an overwhelming victory here in yesterday's election for an interim National Assembly.

title: Consumer Notes
description: The State Department of Health has adopted regulations that for the first time detail the types of dented cans and damaged packages containing food that stores and supermarkets can offer for sale.

title: To Rescue the Regents
description: For more than a month of behind-the-scenes maneuvering, the New York State Legislature was unable agree on a candidate to fill an atlarge position on the State Board of Regents. One candidate was dismissed because he was from the wrong part of the state; a key lawmaker had promised that the appointment would go to a western New Yorker. A candidate from western New York looked promising, but was dropped when Buffalo's mayor objected to his probusing stand. To further complicate matters, the Legislature's Black and Puerto Rican Caucus insisted on a black appointment. The logjam could not be broken until a timely resignation created a second vacancybut that created additional demands. The new position had to go to a Catholic who had the endorsement of the Albany Democratic organizatiOn.

title: 3 Youths Seized in L.I. Vandalism
description: MINEOLA, L.I., (UPI)Three youths from North Merrick, LI., were, arrested yesterday and charged with shooting the windows out of 48 cars in Merrick and Seaford on successive nights. The damage caused by a .22 rifle. was in excess of $5,000, the Nassau County police said. The youths were identified as Robert S. Gilley, 18; Frank M. McNair, 17, and William A. Gomez, 18.

title: Minority Policemen Told at Rally to Seek Advances
description: Despite protests from some organizations and a bomb threat from an anonymous caller, the New York City Police Department yesterday held a special rally to urge officers from minority groups to prepare for and take the Civil Service examination for sergeant that will be held in December.

title: HOWARD OIL ADMITS GUILT IN OVERCHARGE
description: WESTBURY, L. I., April 7The Howard Oil Company pleaded guilty today in Federal District Court here to charges that it overcharged for its petroleum products in violation of Government price freezes.

title: `Much Ado at the McCarter Theater
description: PRINCETON, .N. J.Hero, in Much Ado About Nothing, is surely the greatest goose among all of Shakespeare's heroines. Claudio, who eventually gets around to marrying her, is one of his most despicable heroes.

title: Mets Take Opener As Expos Bow, 31
description: Mayor Koch and a notably small group of 11,736 fellow citizens welcomed baseball back to New York yesterday hi Shea Stadium and watched Jerry Koosman pitch the Mets into their new era with a 31 victory over the Montreal Expos.

title: Furniture Rentals Booming In Changed Style of Living
description: As living styles change in the United States, the furniturerental business is growing faster than ever before.

title: Trading in Resorts Class B Stock Suspended by S.E.C. for 10 Days
description: WASHINGTON, April 7 (AP)The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended trading in Resorts International Inc. Class B common stock for 10 days today, citing recent unexpected market activity in these securities.

title: FARAH BOARD DISMISSES MOST TOP. MANAGEMENT
description: The fourperson board of the Farah Manufacturing Company, the financially troubled El Paso slacks manufacturer, yesterday dismissed almost all of top reinstated as chairman 11 days ago. announcement was made by William F. Farah, son of the founder, who was reinstated as chairman ] 1 days ago.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, APRIL 8, 1978

title: Gulf &Western Unit May Buy Talcott Finance Operation
description: The Talcott National Corporation has reached tentative agreement to sell its factoring and business finance operations to a subsidiary of Gulf and Western Industries Inc., a joint announcement said yesterday.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: WEST EUROPE MOVES ON JOINT PARLIAMENT
description: COPENHAGEN, April 7Western Europe passed another milestone on its slow and difficult path toward unity today when government leaders finally agreed to hold the first direct elections for the embryonic European Parliament in June npvt year

title: Rudolf Weiss, 77, Actor Who Fled Austria After Nazi Invasion, Dead
description: Rudolf Weiss, who made his Broadway acting debut soon after Hitler's invasion of Austria cut short his distinguished career in Europe, died Thursday in Roosevelt Hospital following a stroke. He was 77 years old.

title: ACCORD ENDS STRIKE AT 69 NURSING HOMES IN THE NEWYORK AREA
description: A fourday strike by, healthcare worker:: that had affected 20,000 elderly people in nursing homes in the New York City area ended last night.

title: Leukemia Among the Young Worries Jersey Town
description: RUTHERFORD, N.J., James Cleffi, 9 years old, and Wesley Van Winkle, 12, were neighbors, occasional playmates and pupils at the Pierrepont Elementary School here. They died of leukemia within five months of each other more than a year ago.

title: Kidnappers With Submachine Guns Seize a Salvadoran Businessman
description: SAN SALVADOR, (AP)Kidnappers carrying submachine guns and pistols abducted a businessman from his offices near the American Embassy, the police reported today. Witnesses said Gustavo Cartagena, the owner of a construction company, was seized by at least six men in three cars last night.

title: Islanders Are Seeking Clincher vs. Rangers
description: The game will have no special significance in the league standing for the New York Rangers, but with victory today the New York Islanders could clinch first place in the Patrick Division and the Campbell Conference title when the teams meet at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Funseth, Trevino Lead Masters
description: AUGUSTA, Ga.,A year ago Rod Funseth, a 45-year-old California golf professional who finds the tour less fun than it was when he was younger, shot a 66 to share the 36hole lead with Tom Watson at 139, five under par for the Masters tournament.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, Aor. 8

title: Notes on People
description: The sculptor George Segal has been commissioned to create a memorial to the four students killed at Kent State University in Ohio in an antiwar demonstration in 1970. Mr. Segal, who lives in New Brunswick, N.J., visited the Kent State campus two weeks ago. He will receive a $100,000 commission for the memorial from the Mildred Andrews Fund of Cleveland. Mr. Segal said his sculpture would be symbolic and would not actually depict the incident in which Ohio National Guardsmen fired into a crowd of stone-throwing students.

title: Leaky Rooms at Hofstra Protested
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., In several small dormitory rooms in Tower F on the campus of Hofstra University, today, there were large puddles of water, the paint on the ceiling and walls was cracked and peeling, electrical wires were raised from the floors to avoid possible fires, and items of clothing were hanging up to dry.

title: Bombs Wreck Basque Power Lines
description: BILBAO, Spain, (Reuters)Bombs today wrecked four electricity pylons of a company hired to build controversial nuclear power station at nearby Lemoniz, in the northern Basque country.

title: CLEVELAND SCHOOLS IN FINANCIAL LIMBO
description: CLEVELAND, April 7The 110,000 children who attend public schools here went home for the weekend in considerable uncertainty about how much longer schools would be open. After yesterday's 2.-to-1 vote against an increase in school taxes, public school officials said today, only the state can salvage the school year for Ohio's largest school system.

title: Pretty Baby Film, About Prostitution, Banned by Ontario
description: LOS ANGELES, April 7 - Pretty Baby, a Paramount movie about a 12yearold prostitute, was banned yesterday by the Ontario Film Classification Board because of the Canadian board's disapproval of the picture's theme.

title: PROXMIRE CRITICAL OF WAGE INCREASES
description: WASHINGTON, Senator William Proxmire, chief Senate critic of proposals to extend Federal loan assistance to New York City, assail'd the city's projected level of employee waee increases today and suggested that the Administration withdraw support for longterm Federal loan guarantees.

title: Two Killed in Michigan Fire
description: ADRIAN, Mich., April 7 (UPI)Two persons were killed early today and 10 others were injured in a fire that swept a downtown apartment building housing prison workrelease prisoners, parolees and the elderly poor, the authorities said: They said that one of those killed, William Ennis, died of injuries suffered when he jumped from the burning building. The identity of the other person killed was not immediately released.

title: $70,000 in 196970, Seat Now Sells For 25 Cents on Pacific Exchange
description: A membership on the Pacific Stock Exchange in San Francisco has been sold for 25 cents, reflecting the depressed state of the stock market and widespread uncertainties over structural changes under way in the nation's securities industry.

title: Yankees Munson, His Knee Ailing, Will Start as dh
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., Thurman Munson, perhaps the most durable catcher in the American League the last eight seasons, will not catch tomorrow when the Yankees begin defense of their championship against the unstart Texas Rangers.

title: Not a Long Island Unto Itself
description: The TriState Regional Planning Commission is entrusted by Washington with seeing to it that Federal aid is used to attack basic regional problems with a minimum of inadvertent side effects. This recognition of regional interest that cuts across state and local boundaries was a major advance in national policy, won after years of conflict and waste.

title: Top Genoa Industrialist Is Shot and Wounded By the Red Brigades
description: GENOA, Italy, (AP)A leading/ industrialist was shot in the legs and hand on a Genoa street today by two gunmen using silencerequipped revolt/ ers, and soon after an anonymous Caller told a newspaper here that the Red Bri gades had struck again.

title: Knicks Defeat Kings and Stay Tied With Cays
description: KANSAS CITY,(UPI)Bob McAdoo and Lonnie Shelton scored 27 points each and Eatel Monroe had 25 tonight to lead the Knicks to a 12.5112 victory over the Kansas City Kings.

description: A bitter takeover contest ended yesterday when Airco Inc., the industrial gas producer, accepted an increased stock purchase offer from BOC International Ltd. and the Martin Marietta Corporation stepped out of the conflict.

title: Parking to Be Allowed At. All Broken Meters
description: Beginning Monday, New York City motorists will be entitled to park free for limited periods in spaces where meters are defective or missing.

title: A.L. Wallau 3d Marries Martha Ross Thompson
description: Martha Ross Thompson, a manager in the personnelrelations department at Citibank, was married yesterday to Alexander Lee Wallau 3d, a producer for ABC Sports, in New York.

title: Styles In the Streets Of Paris
description: PARIS,  Apart from the goingson of the highfashion designers arid their followers who deck themselves out in outlandish plumage at their swinging gettogethers, there was another look in the streets of Paris during the day: the sober, cleanedup look. It cuts across all ages and occupations; it has been adopted by schoolteachers and students, office workers and banking executives.

title: M.A.C. Says Stalled Labor Talks Pose a Fiscal Peril for New York
description: The directors of the Municipal Assist, anoe Corporation warned yesterday that the deadlocked New York City labor talks were creating a fiscal crisis as severe as the one that brought the city to the edge of bankruotcv three years ago.

description: There is no more important task in present conditions, one touching the destiny of every person on earth, than the task of achieving real disarmament.

title: Jerry's Name in the Lineup
description: A cold morning drizzle ended before noon, leaving brickred puddles on the grassless areas in front of the dugouts and around home plate in Shea Stadium. At that hour. a gray overcaschung low over the grandstand. Blobs of wet bunting drooped from the fence in front of the box seats. In the almost empty park, the thud of fungo bats against balls had a sepulchral note. Some years ago on opening day a bedsheet banner had appeared in these, stands as a salute to M. Donald Grant, chairman of the board of the New York

title: EMMETT GROGAN
description: Emmett Grogan, the author of the novels Ringolevio and Final Score, died on a subway Thursday, apparently of heart attack. He was 35 years old and lived in Malibu, Calif., and Montreal.

title: Japan Cycles Into a New Problem

title: Film Series: 'The Baker's Bread':West German Picture Shown At Museum of Modern Art
description: "The Baker's Bread" is as small-scale and modest as the West German village in which its story takes place. At the film's beginning, a young man arrives in town to begin his apprenticeship with a local baker, whose durable, family-run business is being threatened by the prosperity of a nearby supermarket and the prospect of a new shopping center. From then on, we watch the baker and his assistants worry about automation and begin to question the economic system that has made their kind of craftsmanship obsolete. We also watch the young newcomer evolve into a family member of sorts, and then become the gruff, blustery, lovable boss's right-hand man.Erwin Keusch, whose low-keyed but often compelling film is being shown as part of the Museum of Modern Art's New Films/New Directors series, occasionally jeopardizes the engaging plainness of his story to bring one character or another to the figurative podium, so that the obligatory speeches about the evils of modernization can he made. But for the most part the film proceeds as swiftly as a day in the bakery might go. Mr. Keusch's gift for being most communicative when his film seems to be saying the least is nothing to sneeze at, and his work is effective in eccentric, nicely unexpected ways.Mr. Keusch is the son of a baker; if you didn't know that before seeing his film, you would surely surmise it from the loving attentiveness with which he sketches bakery life. This is an absolutely spellbinding movie for anyone who likes watching dough rise, and even those who prefer to be on the eating end of the baking process may enjoy learning a thing or two. Werner (Bernd Tauber) the assistant, graduates during the course of the movie from simple kneading and sifting to inventing his own recipes. The camera doesn't dwell unnecessarily on his handiwork, but it follows his progress closely, as he takes ever-increasing pride in his work.Another baker, Kurt (Manfred Siepold), is meanwhile seen in the background, knotting pretzels in a split-second and performing other similarly magical feats. Mr. Siepold is a handsome fellow and a good actor, but if he doesn't actually bake for a living, it's a shame.When he isn't working or dragging himself out of bed hours before dawn, young Werner is pitching woo, but this aspect of his hero's life leaves Mr. Keusch strangely ill-at-ease. One affair, with a rich girl Werner meets when he delivers her birthday cake, seems present in the film solely to make a point about the class system, and the portion of the story that involves her has the feeling of an unexpected and unwelcome lecture. When Werner falls in love for real, the baking and spooning episodes are so clumsily integrated that the romance once again seems tacked-on.In another episode, a most disturbing one, Werner is pounced upon by a very attractive older woman who works in the shop. After they spend one night together, he becomes unaccountably hurtful and rude; she, even more unaccountably, decides life without Werner just isn't worth living. At times like this, Mr. Keusch's presentation of his young hero as a man of few words becomes problematic, and his trick of cutting away from tender moments almost before they happen makes his story hard to follow."The Baker's Bread" is being billed as a West German comedy, but viewers expecting belly laughs would be well advised to try to recall the last West German film they deemed even remotely amusing. In this case, let's just say that nobody dies, all ends reasonably well andhere's the funny partthe bakery crew one day confounds the manager of the supermarket by buying up all his breakfast rolls.

title: Redemption and Resurrection Are Themes of 'Barocco' Film
description: Behind the opening credits of "Barocco," Andr Tchin's second feature to be shown in New York (his first was "French Provincial"), we see a series of distorted close-ups of such exotic fauna as crocodiles, giant snakes and horned lizards so ancient they might have witnessed creationimages designed to make the flesh crawl with primal fears.It's something of a disappointment, then, that when the film begins, we are in a neon-bright, busy, commercial European city. It's actually Amsterdam, though the film never specifically says so, which is one of the smaller affectations of this would-be thriller that cares less about the fundamental mechanics of murder, blackmail and physical intimidation than it does about such weighty subjects as redemption and resurrection."Barocco" will be shown at the Museum of Modern Art tonight at 11 in the annual New Directors/New Films series, and again tomorrow evening at 6.Mr. Tchin, who was born in 1943, belongs to a second generation of French film critics associated with Cahiers du Cinema who followed Franois Truffaut, Claude Chabrol and others from criticism into film-making. On the basis of both "French Provincial," which was about nothing less than the rise and fall of the French bourgeoisie, and now "Barocco," Mr. Tchin remains more of a theorist than an artist.His films have a way of starting off very well and then slowly congealing into stiff, intellectualized attitudes that have less to do with art than with its interpretation. Only Mr. Chabrol, at the top of his form, and Wim Wenders, in his recent "The American Friend," successfully manage to fuse the two disciplines."Barocco" means to be baroque, but it's about as baroque as a pedant's laundry list. It's a schematic tale of murder and blackmail during a municipal election. Its focal point is a nice dumb-lug of a boxer, played by Grard Dpardieu, who is paid a handsome fee to say he had a homosexual affair with one of the candidates, and the boxer's girl, played by Isabelle Adjani, who originally persuaded the boxer to take the bribe so that they could flee to more exotic climates.Something goes wrong, however, and the boxer is murdered and Miss Adjani finds herself falling in love with the hood who murdered her lover. This is easy to understand. The hood is also played by Mr. Dpardieu, though "Barocco" would have us believe that the girl's love redeems the murderer and, in effect, resurrects him. Nonsense. The miracle is in the casting."Barocco" is a very classy looking movie, with lots of fancy camerawork in lots of fancy, ultramodern settings. In addition to Mr. Dpardieu and Miss Adjani, the cast includes such superior performers as Marie-France Pisier, who has some funny moments as a hooker, Jean-Claude Briarly, and Claude Brasseur. They are most attractive, lively people, but their material is dead.

title: 'Mother and Daughter,' Film of Elegant Conflict
description: As "Mother and Daughter" begins, a wealthy Italian family is seen eating breakfast in an outdoor setting, smoothing exquisite-looking honey over perfect toast. The villa is spectacular, and the sunlight is dazzling; the maid tending to everyone's tiniest need is young and pretty, and she seems to enjoy being a maid. In the garden, flowers bloom and birds chirp, and at table, father complains jovially that mother never remembers to serve grapes. Just then, the teen-age son reaches over and plucks a bunch of grapes out of a bowl, tossing them playfully at his sister. So there isn't any trouble in paradise, after all."Hah!" director Giovanna Gagliardo means to say. All this wonderfulness is merely a sham. The beautiful mother (Carla Gravina), who wears pearls to chop carrots in her elegant kitchen, has absolutely nothing of consequence to do, so she pads about the palazzo in a near-stupor, occasionally stopping to prepare an elaborate meal.Though the mother expresses little, she is actually engaged in an age-old struggle with her young daughter, whom the mother would like to keep dependent forever. We know this because the daughter is symbolically crippled, walking gingerly with a cane that has a silver handle.The film, which is part of the New Directors-New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art, more or less takes place on one day. But the daughter is sometimes crippled and sometimes not, sometimes an adolescent and sometimes a child; figments of the mother's memory or imagination wander in at will."Mother and Daughter" never lets a scene go by quietly when an intrusive blast of directorial technique will do, and so it becomes impossible for the viewer to care a fig about either the sleepwalking mother or her half-imaginary child. Miss Gagliardo's insights into the mother-daughter struggle are so slight, and her direction so over-bearing, that the results suggest what might happen if an infantry unit were called in to kill a bat.As a director, Miss Gagliardo is distressingly insensitive to the relationship between style and purpose. As an interior director, however, she is formidable. The film is gorgeously photographed, from sunny beginning to profoundly uneventful ending, and everything in the villa is bright and gleaming and just-so. One need only imagine that the setting is Beverly Hills rather than Italy, and that instead of listlessly chopping vegetables the mother is giving a few passionless flicks to her Cuisinart, to imagine just how ineffectual this numbingly glamorous parable really is.

title: The Trials of Italy

I feel a little abandoned, he writes. I am a political prisoner and your brusque refusal to enter into any kind of discussion about the fate of other, similarly detained persons, gives rise to an untenable situation. Time passes fast. Any moment could be too late.

title: Placing the Blame
description: When the Nlets sold only 11.735 tickets for the first game of New York's baseball season, M. Donald Grant blamed the press. It was the smallest crowd in the club's 17 opening days and the smallest for any New York opener in living memory. The chairman of the board said this was the result of newspapers ham- mering home the idea that the Nets were a lastplace team. It might have occurred to a deeper thinker that ner- haps it was the team's lastplace finish that created that idea.

title: BRIDGE

In both recreations the organ- izers of the knockouts do their best to arrange for a balanced draw by ranking or seeding the original entrants. But this is not easy to do fairly, and seeding by committee may be influenced by subjective impressions or partisan emotions.

title: North Sea Oil No Balm for Britain

After the optimism engendered by the first substantial North Sea oil receipts has come the dawning realization that North Sea oil can at best mean a fiveor sixyear respite during which Britain could, in theory, tackle its fundamental economic problems. These problems are as daunting as ever.

title: A Decrease in Thefts of Autos Is Reported in Massachusetts
description: BOSTON, April 8 (AP)  Automobile thefts in Massachusetts dropped nearly 25 percent in the last two years and 29.1 percent in the 10 cities with the greatest problem, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis said yesterday.

title: CRITIC'S VIEW; `New York's position in the arts is not a position that can be carved up, pork barrelfashion, and parceled out on a per capita (or any other) basis.
description: Questions concerning cosmopolitan cultureespecially questions about the relation of the capital to the provinces in the artswere once the exclusive preserve of artists, critics, teachers, historians, impresarios, adminis- trators and other professionals directly employed in the creation, evaluation and propagation of the arts. The public was not much consulted, and the Governmentexcept in a time of grave economic crisis, such as the Depression of the 1930'shad little, if any, involve- ment. Today, as we know, all this has changed utterly, and probably on an irreversible scale. As the spectral powers of Government loom more decisively in determining both the economic survival of the arts and their geographical dispersal, questions once confined to professional debate have been transformed into issues of public policy.

title: MAILBAG
description: To the Editor: Richard Gilman's requiem for Absurdist drama ['Out Goes AbsurdismIn Comes the New Naturalism, March 19] strikes me as quite premature. Similar requiems for the modernist novel surfaced around 1950, to be quickly followed by the modernistabsurdist work of Grass, RobbeGrillet, Cortazar and Marquez. The recent success of a few naturalistic plays on Broadway does not seem to me very pertinent. Broadway producers have failed to stage many naturalistic plays in recent years only because of the extreme scarcity of good ones, not because of the supposed domination of Broadway by absurdism. The vital center of absurdist drama in America has always been Off Broadway, where it continues to thrive.

title: Under O'Neal, the I.C.C. Has Started Rolling
description: WASHINGTON  For years, the Interstate Commerce Commission has been regarded as one of the worst of the regulatory agencies. Notorious for ignoring consumer needs while being overly cozy with the industries it supposedly regulates, it nonetheless stood by as one of its baronial clients, the railroads, hit the skids. Truckers charged that they were being neglected and the bus lines wondered why the I.C.C. ignored their sagging profits.

title: Taking a Chance on Turkey
description: Secretary of State Vance told Congress last Thursday that if only it would lift its restrictions on shipments of American arms to Turkey, the Turks and Turkish Cypriots would put forward new proposals for a Cyprus settlement. He may be right. But the issue is not whether there will be new proposals. Rather, it is whether the proposals will move Turkish troops back from the 40 percent of Cyprus they now occupy to a zone more nearly proportional to the 18 percent of the island's population that is Turkish. Secretary Vance is thus asking Congress to join him in betting that once the American restrictions are removed, the Turkish Government Prime Minister Ecevit will be able to make large concessions that could not be made while the limits remain.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: The Metropolitan Opera's revival of Donizetti's La Favorita, the Opera Orchestra's performances of Weber's Oberon and Rossini's Tancredi'all these set me thinking in terms of cycles. Before the war, after all, Donizettiand Rossini and Bellini, toowere all but unknown. It might be strange to apply the word unknown to the composers Lucia, II Barbiere di Siviglia and Norma. But Donizetti composed nearly 80 operas, and how many of them were in the repertory from, say, 1920 to 1955? Lucia, of course, and to a lesser extent Don Pasquale and L'Elisir d'Amore. That was all. Of Rossini's 39 operas, all but Barbiere seemed to be dead. Bellini lived only by Norma.

Loving father of Deborah, Kenneth III, William and Cynthia. Dear brother of Holt and Marjorie Reardon. Funeral from Vainieri Funeral Home, Kennedy Blvd corner of 60th St. North Bergen, N.J. Tuesday 1 at 11 AM. Interment George Washington Cemetery, Paramus. Parking on premises. Visitation Monday 2.4 and 79 PM.

title: Naysayers Are Notably Absent From Israel's Kitchen Cabinet
description: JERUSALEM  Ultimately Menachem Begin's kitchen cabinet consists of Menachem Begin alone in his kitchen, in the assessment of one of the Prime Minister's associates. It is not meant to say that Mr. Begin does not consult with others but it is meant imply that essentially the Prime Minister is a loner. And while he tries out thoughts on members of his en- tourage, and formally consults others, plus making much of apprising his Likud Party of his policies, Mr. Begin tends to keep his own counsel.

title: Consuelo Wilson and Seth Pierrepont, Business Student, Will Be Wed Aug. 26
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Louis Wilson Jr. of Bloomfield Hills, Mich. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Consuelo Diane Wilson, to Seth Low Pierrepont, son of Mr. and Mrs. Rutherfurd Stuyvesant Pierrepont of Hobe Sound. Fla., and Locust Valley, L. I. The wedding is planned for Aug. 26.

title: TV VIEW
description: While bystanders speculate about major personnel changes on all three network editions of the evening news, the more significant alterations are being made in other areas television journalism. Yes, it's possible that Harry Reasoner may leave ABC to join CBS for a role in a CBS Reports magazine format. And it's possible, as already announced, that John Chancellor will withdrawn from the anchor position on the NBC Nightly News to become something of a commentator-at-large. But, then again, the scheduled June move of Fred Silverman from ABC programming chief to NBC network president, may postpone or even cancel that Chancellor scenario. The business of waiting for Freddy has brought most of NBC to state of incipient paralysis.

title: Ideas &Trends; In Summary A Computer Has Come Up With A Drug for Cancer; Heroin for Pain?; Give the Divided Way; Ideas & Trends; There's a Lesson Here: College Costs Up Again; Listerine Must Now Come Clean; New Ground at The Abbey
description: One of the best ways of measuring the effectiveness of an anticancer drug is to count the number of malignant cells killed by one dose of the drug administered to a laboratory animal. Only a few drugs will kill as many as 100,000 cells per dose, and drugs that kill 10 million are rare. With the help of a computer, researchers at the University of California at San Francisco have designed a new drug, one dose of which kills hundreds of millions of cancerous cells in mice under some circumstances. ]tut the researchers emphasize that it has yet to be tried on human beings. and that sonic drugs effective for animals arc not so for man.

title: Optimism In the Far West
description: ECONOMIC SCENE

title: Candidates Seek New Slants To Get Attention and Votes
description: MIAMI, April 8When Air Florida Flight 41 arrives on Tuesday in Tallahassee, the state capital, the flight attendant will be prepared for the male chauvinist catcalls of the legislators who happen to be aboard the jet.

title: Consumer Satety Panel Revising Its Messages on Home Insulation
description: WASHINGTON, April 8 (UPI)The Consumer Product Safety Commission has agreed to revise its public service campaign on home insulation in the face of a suit by two home insulation companies.

title: What's Doing in SAN FRANCISCO
description: THE GOLDEN GATE - Like other 4ities with special sights (New York with the Statue of Liberty and the Empire State Building, Los Angeles with Hollywood and Disneyland, Chicago with its stockyardsor so it used to be), San Francisco has its special sights: Chinatown, the cable cars, Fisherman's Wharf. In addition, San Francisco has itself. Undoubtedly it is the most beautiful big city in the United States. Downtown there is the necessary quota of postWorld War II architectural high fashionmassive skyscrapers, massive dutdoor and indoor sculpture, spectacular lobbies and inner courts. But it can't top the older city, draped over a series of hills like a bright blanket.

title: Army Lacrosse Victor
description: Army defeated Hofstra, 84, yesterday for its fourth straight lacrosse victory. Army's Bob Finlay and Ken Curley scored twice, as did Hofstra's Kevin Huff.

title: Los Angeles Criticized Over Games
description: LONDON, April 8Los Angeles bid to stage the 1984 Olympic Games was criticized again today as the international sports federations lined up to oppose the city's plans concerning television revenue.

title: Chinese Ship Catches Fire
description: TOKYO, April 8 (Reuters)--A 4,939-ton Chinese freighter caught fire off western Japan today but all 56 crew members were rescued by a Japanese ship, the Maritime Safety Agency reported. The fire broke out shortly after midnight on the Tuan Chieh, bound for Yokohama from China.

title: SOCIAL SECURITY TAX GIVING LIFT TO G.O.P.
description: WASHINGTON, April 8Republicans around the country, from Ronald Reagan to Thomas Pauken, are making political capital out of higher Social Security taxes, and they are doing it even though a majority of the public favors the higher rates.

title: The Pitfalls of $25 Preferred Stock
description: INVESTING

title: ART VIEW
description: The Queens Museum stands on Flushing Meadow, among souvenirs of the World's Fairs of 1939 and 1964. Not five minutes walk away across open parkland, work is going forward on the big stadium that will be the center of the transplanted Forest Hills tennis tournament. The scene general is vast and countrified, with a brilliant marine light pouring down in fine weather. The museum building is not thing of beautythough a grant of $5 million from the City New York will help to put that rightbut it has historical echoes; it was here that the United Nations began its life New York City.

title: THE RISING TIDE OF OIL SPILLS
description: Observe the broken ship abovea large object lesson. The Amoco Cadiz. When she was still in one piece, she was as long as three football fields. A few miles from the Brittany coast of France the stormy night of March 16, she lost all her steering; her captain called for help, a tug came to her aid but was of

title: ANTIQUES
description: No wonder Marco Polo was impressed. If the embroidered silks and robes he brought back to Europe from China 500 years ago came close to resembling the glorious garments and stitched panels now on view at China House Gallery, 125 East 65th Street, the explorer had every right to rave.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: Richard Adams's latest best seller, The Plague Dogs, a bleak tale of man's inhumanity to animals, was written in a house high on a green hill on the Isle of Man, overlooking the sea. With three novels under his belt, Mr. Adams at last enjoying the literary life.

title: NaturalGas Leak May Have Caused; Sewer Explosions in South Bronx
description: A series of explosions along a sewer main in the South Bronx that sent 50 manhole covers flying and caused more than $500,000 damage to a new 17story apartment building may have been caused by natural gas that leaked into the sewers.

title: Slowness of Manila Returns Casts More Doubt on Conduct of Election
description: MANILA, April 8More than 24 hours after the polls closed in yesterday's election for an interim National Assembly, the Government's Commission on Elections said today that it still did not have official results for the critical race in Manila.

title: PEOPLE
description: In 1948 John E. Bierwlrth visited Presi. dent Truman to complain that taxes were awfully high and people ought to get some relief. Apparently Mr. Bierwirth wasn't fazed by the encounter  he told reporters later that Mr. Truman agreed with him. But earlier that year, when Mr. Bierwirth was offered the presidency of the National Distillers Products Corporation, of which he had been a director for the last six years, he wasn't so cool. I had butterflies in my stomach, he said. He went on to head the diversified chemical and alcoholic beverage company, now the National Distillers; and Chemical Corporation, for 26 years,. first as president and later as chairman.

title: Using Foot Power and the Right of Passage to See a Bit of Britain
description: Give me the clear blue sky over my head, and the green turf beneath my feet, a winding road before me, and three hours march to dinnerand then to thinking!

title: In Newark, the Sound of Jazz
description: NEWARK

title: Deaths
description: FASOLINOErnest, devoted son of Elsa and the late Francesco, dearest brother of Pasquale, Domenick, Elsa Moreno, Frances and the late Anna Vaden. Reposing at Village Chapels, 6767 Eliot Ave, Middle Village. Mass of the Resurrection Tuesday, 9:30AM; St. Margaret's R.C. Church. Entombment family mausoleum in St. John's Cemetery.

description: WASHINGTON

title: White Plains Clinic Fights to Stay Open
description: WHITE PLAINS

title: Betsy Bourne Is Wed To William D. Roche, Investment Banker
description: Elizabeth Ann Bourne, who is on the institutional sales staff of Stuart Brothers, corporate bond traders, was married yesterday to William David Roche, a corporate bond trader with Salomon Brothers, investment bankers.

title: SENATORS TO DEBATE IRRIGATED LAND LIMIT
description: WASHINGTON, April 8The initial round in a campaign to relax the 160acre limitation on Western land irrigated with Federal water will start Wednesday when a Senate committee begins hearings on this emotional issue.

title: Joan Little's Extradition Stayed Until April 24 by Appeals Court
description: MINEOLA, L. I., April 8 (UPI)Joan Little, who was to be returned to North Carolina today to face prisonescape charges, has received a stay of her extradition until April 24.

title: A Historian Looks at History On TV
description: History is bunk said the first Henry Ford. Millions of Americans still accept that idea. Historians proliferate but the subject remains unpopular with the people and their rulers. The his- torians of the next century may find that many of the mistakes made by this and preceding Administrations arose from either an ignorance of history or, if there was some smattering of knowledge, from a refusal to learn from it.

title: DINING OUT
description: NAME a restaurant Dzagheegner and people are bound to take notice. Dzagheegner (pronounced jhaH EEGneh) is a new Armenian restaurant in Greenlawn. Its name means flower, and on a recent weekday evening it was in full bloom.

title: INTERVIEW
description: IM only 37 years old and I still consider myself a young man, said Charles H. Thornton. I still want to try new things, push the state of the art, but things like this make me wonder if it's worth it.

title: JoffreyDoes 'Vivandiere,' 'JazzCalendar
description: Theatergoers who bewail the demise of the oldfashioned revue might rejoice at the realization that the revue format continues to flourish in ballet. Just as revues consist of a variety of sketches and musical numbers, so ballets are often composed of selfcontained comic, dramatic or lyrical scenes. All four works on the Joffrey Ballet's Friday night program at the City Center could be related to the revue tradition. These works suggested that choreographers must enjoy devising balletic revues, for they ranged from the Joffrey's most venerable relic to its newest productions.

title: E.P.A. Rule Waived for Boatmen
description: The politics surrounding something as mundane as marine sanitation devices remains confusing. But for the present the Environmental Protection Agency has waived a rule that would have required boat owners to install devices of a type that were not widely available.

title: Geraldine Ortner to Be Wed
description: Mrs. Philip T. Lombardo of Riverdale. the Bronx. and Pcint Lookout. L.L. has announced the engagement of her daughter, Geraldine L. Ortner, to Robert M. Hanlon. Jr., assistant dean of the Fordham Law School and son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Hanlon of Point Lookout. The prospective bride is the daughter also of the late Mr. Lombardo. and the widow of Bennett Ortner el New York and Chicago. The wedding is planned for May 6.

title: Domestic Car Sales Dip, Imports Climb
description: With a 13.9 percent decline in the final 10 days of March, sales of amestic new cars ended the first quarter down 4.9 percent from the yearago period.

title: Israeli Seamen End Pay Strike That Lasted Nearly 3 Months
description: TEL AVIV, April 8 (AP)Israeli seamen have ended a strike of nearly three months and have agreed to submit their wage demands to an arbitrator. The merchant fleet management, backed by tough Government policy against strikers, is holding to its original offer of a 20- to 25percent pay hike for some 2,000 seamen.

title: New Jersey/ This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets) - The Threepenny [Opera, in an Actor's CafTheater production. Thursday through Saturday, 8:30 P.M.; Sunday, 2 P.M. (through April 22). $2.90$4.90; students and the elderly, 51.9043.90. (201) 4297662. Westminster Theater.

title: The New Physiocrats
description: THE economics fraternity, writes Lester Brown, president of Worldwatch Institute, Washington research organization, has had trouble explaining, much less anticipating, the events of the seventies  perhaps because it has lost sight the fact that economic activity depends upon the productivity of the earth's natural systems and resources.

title: China Watch
description: FOR the Chinese to set off an open and explicit debate now about what was right and what went wrong in Mao's Great Leap Forward or Cultural Revolution would be to risk unraveling the ideology and legitimacy of the state. Yet Chinese politics revolve on exactly those questions. In the Chinese fash-

title: A Fairer Tax Share
description: WISELY or not, Connecticut grants a property tax exemption to certain categories of private, nonprofit institutions. The list of exemptions is long because, as any student of taxation knows, exemptions rarely die  instead they usually multiply. So it is no surprise to learn that churches, hospitals, cemeteries, scientific, literary, historical, educational and charitable organizations do not pay property taxes. We appear to have reached the point of cradle-to-grave property exemptions: We are born in taxexempt hospitals and buried in taxexempt cemeteries.

title: In and Around Nags Head: The Discreet Charm of the Outer Banks
description: Call it the 34-year-itch, midlife crisis, what your analyst will; we were abandoning our beloved mountains and streams of Vermont for an affair with southern beach. Still, it was a family af fair.

title: Picture Credits
Driving For Safety In Brookhaven
description: WHEN Dick Faria talks, he sounds like a tape recorder that needs to be slowed down. He waves his hands a lot and emphasizes every point. Mr. Faria is intense, and with good reason: He has little more than two years to reduce the number of people killing themselves on Brookhaven Town roadways.

title: Marie Martin, Robert Withers To Wed in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. William G. Martin of Radnor, Pa., and Royal Oak, Md., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Marie Margaret Martin of New York, to Robert Christopher Withers of Washington, son of Mrs. Casey Withers Humphreys of Minneapolis and James H. Withers of Pasadena. Calif.

title: Yonkers Teachers Get Half a Loaf as Their TwoYear Contract Is Cut Back to One Year
description: YONKERS, April 7After months of negotiations, a 15day strike and rebuffs by the city's Emergency Financial Control Board, the Yonkers Board of Education and the Yonkers Federation of Teachers last week agreed to reduce an approved twoyear contract to one year.

title: CIUME
description: Desmond Bagley is not one of the betterknown writers of espionage novels in this country, but he is a favorite in his native England, where his books do very well. Among his previous books published in America, Running Blind and The Freedom Trap attracted much favorable comment. But his latest book, THE ENEMY (Doubleday, $7.95) marks a considerable advance, and is by far the best of his work that has come this way.

title: For Planning Purposes, L.I. Wants to Be a Breakaway Province
description: Goveinor Carey gave a big push last week to a Long Island separatist movement that could, if it succeeds, weaken the already weak cause of regional planning in the tristate area. Reversing his position, Mr. Carey agreed to a demand of the NassauSuffolk Planning Board that it be permitted go directly to the Government for Long Island's share of the areas's annual $3 billion in Federal funds.

title: Huntington Composer Says She Hopes That Exclusively Women's Concerts Will Soon Become Passe
description: I think there is no doubt that women have been neglected in the field of composition up until very recently, Marge Richter said. All of us want to know why, and we just don't know why. What we do know is that things have changed a Ibt in the last five years, just as they he Ale in many fields.

title: Why America Needs New York as Its Cultural Capital
description: 1) Leonie Rysanek at the Metropolitan Opera in Die Frau ohne Schatten; 2) Peter Martins and Suzanne Farrell Raymonda Variations at the City Ballet : 3) Luciano Pavarotti in La Favorita at the Metropolitan Opera; 4) A bass player performing a John Cage composition at The Kitchen; 5) Detail from Picasso's Girl Before a Mirror at the Museum of Modern Art; 6) Henry Price in a student production of The Bartered Bride at the Juilliard American Opera Center; 7) Dale Andre in the May O'Donnell Dance Company's production of Pursuit of Happiness'': 8) Jason Robards in A Touch of the Poet; 9) Ruth Negri, a harpist, performing with the New York Philharmonic: 10) Mabou Mines players at the Public Theater

title: Nancy Kramer Plans To Be Wed in June
description: Nancy Kramer of Cambridge, Mass., a staff assistant in the office of fiscal services at Harvard University, plans to he married in June at Temple BethEl in Chappaqua, N.Y., to Steven Goldman, manager of financial reporting of Stop & Shop Companies, the supermarket chain based in Boston.

description: Los ANGELEs

title: The Transit Money Only Raised The Ante
description: At 3 o'clock in the morning a week ago yesterday, Mayor Koch decided that it was worth $18 million the city not to have a bus and subway strike, even though the contract he was approving for transit workers was far more than he could afford to pay their municipal counterparts.

title: Article 4 -- No Title

title: Debra Pedersen and John C. McKenzie Marry
description: Debra Marie Pedersen. daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jahn Edward Pedersen of Glen Cove, L.I., was married yesterday afternoon to John Craig McKenzie, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Coover McKenzie of Chambersbtirg. Pa.

title: Farrar, Straus Leaves Group Of Publishers
description: The split in the ranks of American publishers over the issue of publishing mergers in the book industry widened last week when Farrar, Straus & Giroux, one of the leading indenendent. houses in New York, withdrew from membership in the Association of American Publishers.

title: Ford Frick Dies at 83
description: Ford C. Frick, the third commissioner of baseball, serving from 1951 to 1965, died yesterday at the age of 83 in Bronxville. Page 36.

title: STUDENT SHIFTS VEX CONNECTICUT SCHOOLS
description: STAMFORD, Conn.  Minoritygroup students in Connecticut's public schools are slowly moving out of the big cities and into smaller communities, and the growing number of Hispanic students, in the smaller towns especially, is creating new educational concerns.

title: Two Nice People
description: S TimeLife film critic for many years, Richard Schickel, without being excessively puritanical, always took a stand for decency in the movies. So it is no surprise that turning to fiction he has written nice novel about nice people that poses the question: Can a man and woman in their early 40's, recently separated from their respective mates, make it together?

title: Boys and Girls High Wins Three Relays at Nanuet
description: NANUET, N.Y., April 8Brian Denman. named the indoor schoolboy track athlete of the year in New York State iust last week, opened the outdoor campaign in impressive fashion today at the windswept Nanuet Relays on t he high school's allweather track.

title: Benefit to Aid Camp NYDA
description: The Junior Division of Camp NYDA Is sponsoring a theater party at the May 2 performance of Denim at the Broadhurst Theater for the benefit of the camp for diabetic children in Burlingham, N.Y. Orchestra seats at $75, $60, $45 and $30 can be obtained from Adele Weinstock, 215 East 68th Steet.

title: Deaths
description: COMFORTHarold Wet Greenwich, Conn.April 6,1978. Husband of the late Lillian Whiteley Comfort. Father of Robert H., Richard W. and John Comfort. Memorial services at the Round Hilt Community Church, Greenwich on Monday at 10AM. Interment private. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the National Multiple Sclerosis Society, 205 East 42 Street, New York City.

title: Ballet Hispanico of New York Offers Varied Works
description: There ought to be a category of esthetics for the purely fun. If there were, Ballet Hispanico of New York would rank high. The company, which opened a sevenperformance seascn at the Henry Street Settlement Playhouse on Thursday, does not aim for great art. The company's director, Tina RamireZ, has assembled an impressive enough (and nicely varied) repertory of Spanish and modern dance works by such choreographers as Anna Sokolow, Geoffrey Holder, Donald McKayle and Tailey Beatty.

title: A Genial Elder Statesman of the Podium
description: with Pierre Boulez already gone, and Lubin Mehta yet to arrive on a permanent basis, the present New York Philharmonic season has offered a richer assortment of guest conductors than usual. In particular, the orchestra and its subscribers have been able to sample at some length the work of two of Europe's most esteemed elder statesmen of the batonRafael Kubelik and Eugen Jochum.

title: DINING OUT; The Milder Dishes of India; A Correction; *Sitar
description: TO FIND an Indian restaurant on the old Lincoln Highway (Route 27)  it is situated next to a Sunoco gasoline station and across from the SixMile Run Reformed Church of Franklin Park  is something of a serendipity. This is clean and quiet place, consisting of a single room, dozen tables, a few hanging brass lamps and colored paper balls, bright cloth hangings on the walls and eood white napery on the tables.

title: NEWS ANALYSIS
description: CLIFTON

title: Fewer Copies Asked for Grants
description: WASHINGTON, April 2 (UPI)Responding to President Carter's order that Federal paperwork be less confusing and burdensome, the Justice Department's Law Enforcement Assistance Administration has said that state and local governments applying for grants need file only two copies of their applications. Previously, applicants had to send up to 12 copies plus the original.

title: Levitt's Aides Find Pattern of Loafing By Park Workers
description: A systematic pattern of loafing on the job by employees of the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation cost the city more than $18 million last year, State Comptroller Arthur Levitt charged yesterday.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Realty News
description: Mitsukoshi (U.S.A.) Inc., a wholly owned subsidiary of Mitsukoshi Ltd., leading Japanese department store chain, has leased the former Charles of the Ritz space in the Ritz Tower on the northeast corner of Park Avenue and 57th Street.

title: Carey Urges Rise in Minimum Pay In State and Upgraded Farm Wage
description: ALBANY, April 7In response to the rising cost of living, Governor Carey has proposed legislation increasing the state's minimum wage to Federal levels and bringing the wages of farm workers in line with those of other employees.

title: Ade1phi Lacrosse Victor
description: GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 8Kevin Miller scored seven goals and led Adelphi to a 1610 victory over Loyola of Baltimore today. Miller, a freshman from Hicksville, L.I., scored five goals in the second half. Bob Mattia scored four goals for the losers, who are 43. Kevin Jules stopped 10 shots for Adelphi, now 22.

title: Amy Magida Becomes Bride
description: Amy Beth Magida, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Melville G. Magida of Stamford,. Conn., was married there last evening to Richard Kent Haskell Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Haskell of New Canaan, Conn. Justice of the Peace Loren Jaffee of Stamford. performed the ceremony at the Marriott Hotel.

title: Some Contamination Is Produced by Chlorination Process Itself
description: WASHINGTON  Is the water safe to drink?

title: Article 1 -- No Title
John Wayne Leaves Intensive Care
description: BOSTON, April 8 (Reuters)  John Wayne, who underwent heart surgery Monday, was moved from intensive care today to an intermediate care unit at Massachusetts General Hospital. A hospital spokesman said the 70-year-old actor's convalescence remains on target and, if there were no complications, he could be released within two weeks.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: It did my heart good to see the recent slew of letters [Opinion Page, March 12] protesting the closing of the Nassau County Museum of Fine Arts.

title: THE MARKETS
description: Despite the lingering worries of investors over inflation, interest rates, the dollar and the vigor of the economy, stock prices managed to move higher last week. For the present, at least, it seemed to indicate that these worries  and others  already had been built into the depressed level of the stock market. As result, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 12.2 points to finish at 769.58.

title: POLITICS
description: THERE is, says Joseph I. Lieberman, the State Senate majority leader, a rhythm to the legislative process. Controversial issues, ideas and bills arise from time to tithe. But it takes time for them to gain acceptance and enough votes to be approved.

title: Javits Briefed Begin About Worry in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON, April 8  Senator Jacob K. Javits, Republican of New York, said today that on a recent trip to Israel he told Prime Minister Menachem Begin and his associates that there had been no erosion of voting support for Israel in Congress, but that many of Israel's friends in the United States are worried.

title: Making Money on Memorabilia
description: LOS ANGELES  If it has a CocaCola trademark on it, chances are that Leonard Sidlow sells it.

title: Report on the Dollar: Subject to Variation, but Generally Shrinking
description: In Switzerland, a cup of coffee now costs 70 cents.

title: Wood, Field and Stream
description: CAMDEN, S. C.Bluewinged teal and widgeon wheeled overhead, their wings glinting in the late afternoon sun, and my companion, Fred M. Myers of Camden, put down his fishing rod, cupped his hands over his mouth and produced marvelous sounds.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: CONDOMINIUM, by John D. MacDonald. (Fawcett /Crest, $2.25.) John D. MacDonald's 6.3d novel is the story of a leisure world development Florida, from shady financing and construction mismanagement and residents rebellion to disastrous hurricane. It's jampacked with characters and technical details but lacks the pace of MacDonald's Travis McGee yarns. A best seller in hardcover.

title: Notes of a Nervous Neophyte Playwright
description: Afellow who's spent much of his life talking to himself on the typewriter grows accustomed to a certain soothing solitude, cloistering with few, excepting an occasional gentlemanly editor. It is not a bad way of life unless you lust for real money. I'm rapidly learning, however, that the solitary life is poor preparation for the theater with its passions, pitfalls, immediate due bills, and hectic hurlyburlys.

title: Claudia Blank Is Married
description: At the Hebrew Union College Chapel in Cliticinnati yesterday, Claudia Ellen Blank. a research a#sociate with the Metrdpolitan Transportation Authority Management Study in New York, was married to David Henry Marks, an associate with the New York law firm of Lord, Day & Lord. Rabbi Sheldon Blank performed the ceremony.

title: S. J. Heinle Fiance Of Nancy Donovan
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward Donovan of New York and Sea Girt, N. J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Louise Donovan, to Stephen Jude Heinle, son of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Heinle of Short Hills, N. J., and Sea Girt. A September wedding is planned.

title: Fires Sweep Dry Forests in South
description: ATLANTA, April 8 (AP)Damage in five states was estimated in the millions today as wildfires swept dry woodlands in the South, where it has not rained in nearly a month. The authorities suspected arson in many cases.

title: The Nation
description: More than once under Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, the United States Supreme Court has made plain its displeasure with judges who, in its opinion, usurp powers that belong to other branches of government. But rarely has that belief been expressed as forcefully as it was last week when the Court denounced judicial intervention run riot and reversed lowercourt decisions that have delayed the development of three nuclear power plants.

title: New Activist Tactics
description: WASHINGTON  Activist shareholders are developing an increased sophistication in filing resolutions on social, political and environmen tal issues, analysts of such proposals and officials of the Securities and Exchange Commission report, while the commission itself is showing greater leniency in the resolutions it will accept for shareholder votes.

title: College on L.I. Uses Soft Sell to Get Student Alcoholics Into Programs
description: A soft sell campaign to. entice the college alcoholic into selfhelp programs being offered by students and graduates of Nassau County Community College under way on the Garden City campus.

title: In Oyster Bay, a Builder Often Has to Spare Those Trees]
description: OYSTER BAY, L.I.Thirteen years ago, Marion Plunkett, an East Norwich woman who was several months pregnant at the time, plopped herself down in front of the pine and refused to budge until officials who were widening the road in front of her house promised to try to save the tree instead of cutting it down.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, APRIL 9, 1978

title: Jets Get an Early Start at Shea and a Tough Schedule
description: The Jets will be playing home games in Shea Stadium this season before all the leaves fall in nearby Flushing Meadow Park or before ice forms on Flushing Bay. The National Football League's schedule, officially announced yesterday, has the Jets playing three home games at Shea in September and October. This will be the first time the Jets will play at home before baseball's regular season ends. A fourth game will be.played at Shea before the World Series begins.

title: A Determined Lee Trevino Rides Again
description: AUGUSTA, Ga., April 8  He's teen the Don :tickles. of golf, but his meliners often had people laughing instead of appreciating how skillfully Lee Trevino played. He once threw a robber snake at Jack Nicklaus on the first tee of a United States Open playoff, then threw a 68 at him to win by hrec shots. He won Si million on the

title: Egypt Expects U.S. Move on Talks
description: CAIRO, April 8Egypt is expecting fresh diplomatic effort shortly by the United States to revive the stalled peace negotiations between Egypt and Israel.

title: The Maybe Bomb
description: WASHINGTONOf all the controversies that have swirled around Jimmy Carter during his first 15 months in office, several of the more sensitive and politically hazardous have dealt with nuclear policy. Whether he has been tilting with the French and West Germans about plans to sell nuclear technology to Pakistan and Brazil, or challenging the wisdom of the Clinch River Breeder Reactor at home, the result has been fierce argument and bruised feelings. The irony has been that the most heated debates on nuclear policy have been with allies rather than adversaries.

title: In the Rush For Office Space, Small Business Is Losing Out
description: In the gathering stampede for prime office space here, the small spaceuserthe oneman outfit, the doctor, the lawyer, the small businessmanis often being shoved aside these days.

title: LETTERS TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: It is nice to know that Fairfield County residents have about seven years to enjoy driving before all the region's major arterial highways will be completely congested. As one who commutes daily between Huntington and Greenwich, a distance of 38 miles, I find that my drive time has increased from 45 minutes to more than an hour over the last six years, with no improvements in sight.

title: Summer Job Forms Available Tomorrow
description: New York City will begin distributing applications tomorrow for 55,000 federally financed summer jobs for youths.

title: The World.

A pioneer in the shipping of containerized freight, the 47-year-old company last paid a dividend in 1959, and in 1975 it came perilously close to bankruptcy.

title: FILM VIEW
description: Because the popular cinema has profited so long and so well from its own, denatured kind romanticism, as represented by everything from Joan Crawford's early shopgirl films and Johnny Weissmuller's Tarzan adventures to something as recently lachrymose as Love Story, it's not always easy to identify as romantic the perversities that keep reappearing in the films of Louis Malle. The French director makes no attempt to disguise a style that is visually dazzling. It's simply that his subjects are bent from conventional shape, most dramatically in his new, splendid, perhaps most romantic film, Pretty Baby, which is about a 12-year-old prostitute in the New Orleans tenderloin of 1917. Romantic? Thoroughly, but it's also haunting and sad and uninhibited and wise.

Assertions of absolute preeminence are inartistic and silly, given the variety of styles and temperaments to consider. But on the basis of his absolutely superb recital at the. Aware of Oat, the seven private power companies that serve the state have proposed a bold plan that, they say,, would keep future price increases to a minimum. But the planto allow a radically new kind of utility consortium to take over construction and operation of all new private power plants has come under attack by consumer groups and has lately drawn fire from some quarters of the financial community.

Milk samples that showed traces were taken from farms around Jackson, Miss.; Montgomery, Ala.; Charleston, S.C.; Memphis; Cincinnatti; Little Rock, Ark.; Oklahoma City; St. Louis; Rapid City, S.D., and Dallas and Austin, Tex.

title: Talk With Vargas Llosa
description: RETURNING from the Sixth Conference on Writers of the Hispanic World at the University of Oklahoma, where he had been lionized for more than two weeks, Mario Vargas Llosa was thrown to the lions at City College, where he delivered the Jacob C. Saposnekow Memorial Lectures as part that school's Hispanic Week. No stranger to either ring or den, Mr. Vargas Liosa countered attacks on his work with the same characteristic frankness, lucidity and energy with which he accepted praise at Oklahoma.

title: New York City Failed to Review Yankee Expenses, Goldin Alleges
description: No New York City agency reviewed nearly $800,000 in maintenancecost vouchers that were submitted in 1976 to the city by the New York Yankees, according to investigators for City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin.

title: Adjunct Jobs: FullTime Insecurity
description: THE number of adjunct or parttime faculty members in Westchester institutions of higher learning has more than doubled in the last 10 years. These institutions now have 1,231 adjunct and 798 fulltime faculty members.

title: Joan Rivers 'Rabbit Test' Film Depicts First Pregnant Man
description: As Woody Allen's career demonstrates, there's no good reason why a stand-up comic with a nervous, staccato delivery can't adapt that style to fit the demands of a feature-length film, provided that the comedy stems from a consistent, genuinely funny point of view. Joan Rivers's nightclub routines abound with the same kind of self-deprecation and misanthropy in which Mr. Allen used to specialize, and her premise for "Rabbit Test"what would happen if a man became pregnant?sounds like it might be good for an hour-and-a-half's worth of bunny fluff.But like entirely too many comics before her, Miss Rivers has turned to directing without paying much heed to whether a whole movie constructed from one-liners is worth even the sum of its parts. In her case, it's notand the one-liners weren't all that sparkling to begin with.When it winds up on television, which is where a movie this visually crude belonged in the first place, "Rabbit Test" may improve slightly: Constant commercial interruptions may help distract attention from the movie's continuity problems, which are severe. And the coarseness of its comedy may not seem so insufferable to an audience willing to sit still for "Laverne and Shirley."Miss Rivers's jokes mostly have to do with racial stereotypes and the essential revoltingness of pregnancy, but a few of them are funny just the same. However, as a director, Miss Rivers is forever sandbagging her own scenes, throwing away a good chuckle in a sequence that desperately needs a punch line, or wasting something fairly subtle right after a broad, dopey joke about a urine sample. Whenever one does laugh, it's in spite of the movie, rather than because of it.At mechanically regular intervals, a variety of veteran performers wander by for wasted cameosthe cast includes George Gobel, Imogene Coca, Richard Deacon, Paul Lynde, Sheree North, Tom Poston and a lot of other players who are almost always funnier than they are here. Too many of them mimic Miss Rivers's breathless delivery, and in some caseslike Alex Rocco'sthe dialogue is so speedy it becomes almost inaudible.As for the world's first pregnant man, played by Billy Crystal, his predicament turns out to be a lot less curious than it sounds. Miss Rivers makes almost nothing of the role-reversal possibilities her premise suggests, and Mr. Crystal manages to convey neither astonishment nor acceptance of the impossible. He just becomes pregnant and has a baby, and that's the end of that. It's a lot easier to entertain the notion of a pregnant man than it is to understand why anyone would choose to end an alleged comedy with such a lead balloon."Rabbit Test," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains a number of bathroom jokes, mostly of an infantile nature.

title: Dr. Schnitzler's Diagnosis
description: FOR most of their lives, Drs. Freud and Schnitzler lived within easy walking distance of each other - two Jewish physicians (the latter also an established writer) with equally unsavory reputations, common friends and, above all, common enemies. Though they also professed great mutual admiration, the two never met face to face - which, the Vienna of their day, took some doing.

However, even though the aluminum may be anodized to minimize pitting and oxidation, most aluminum furniture, doors, windows and railings do lose their attractive luster when left outdoors without protection. Thus, even for purely esthetic reasons, some maintenance is often advisable.

title: IN BRIEF
description: The British are coming, Marine Midlane Banks annoutgced last week. The nation's No. 13 bark, ailing for lack of capital, said it had agreed to sell 51 percent of its common mock in two stages to the Hongkong and Shanghai Banking Corporation, a major British bank based in Hong Kong. The Britons would buy $200 million in newly issued Marine common and later would also make tender offer for 3.1 million shares outstanding. The merger is subject to approaval of Marine shareholders, the Federal Reserve Board and the New York State Banking Commission.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: IN an engaging new book called Spontaneous Apprentices: Children and Language (Seabury, $9.95), George A. Miller, a professor of psychology at the Rockefeller University, describes an experiment that didn't work. The experiment involved a dozen or so 3-year-old children, playing in a laboratory, being looked at and listened to by various scientists and machines. The scientists honed to leant something about the growth of vocabulary, or lexical development, in the minds of these spontaneous apprentices, with particular reference to concepts of color, time and space. They seem to have learned more about themselves than about vocabulary or children. After two years, the kiddie lab was closed.

title: Byrd Warns Against Overreacting To Panama Move on Treaty Change
description: WASHINGTON April 8Robert C. Byrd, the Senate majority leader, warned today against overreacting' to Panama's recent diplomatic maneuvering in response to Senate changes in the first Panama Canal treaty. He predicted that Panama's maneuvers would not affect prospects for approval of the second treaty.

title: Headliners
description: For four years, Gen. David C. Jones has gone about his job as Air Force Chief of Staff quietly and efficiently enough have avoided great public recognition. That may have helped commend him to President Carter, who named General Jones last week to be the next Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, subject to Senate approval. General Jones is unlikely to be as outspoken as the current chairman, Gen. George S. Brown, who embarrassed the last two Administrations by describing Congress as irresponsible, and asserting that Jews control American banks and newspapers and that Israel has too much influence in Congress. General Jones is more of a team player. He fully supported Mr. Carter's decision to cancel production of the Bi bomber and belongs to a new breed of top officers, made up more of systems analysts than military heroes.

title: A City's Guides Lead Way to the Old South
description: For two days last month my wife and had tramped the do-it-yourself walking tours detailed in the Junior League's Historic Charleston Guidebook. We had explored the cobbled gaslit lanes, admired hundreds of Georgian and Greek Revival facades, peeped through spiderweb iron grilles at hidden gar. dens, tiptoed through 18thcentury drawing rooms full of exquisite an. tiques. Now we wanted to see some of the Old South plantations a dozen miles out of town. But we had no car and we dislike commercial bus trips.

title: Laurie Chadbourne Pile Fiancee of David Barrett
description: Mr. and Mrs. Sterling Pile Jr. of Brookville, L. I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laurie Chadbourne Pile, to David A. Barrett, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester A. Barrett of Marion, Mass. The wedding is planned for June.

title: Andrew Fort Fiance Of Sharon V. Voros
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ernest L. Voros of Buck Hill Falls, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Sharon Virginia Voros, to Andrew Osmun Fort, son of Mr. and Mrs. Osmun Fort of Plainfield, N.J., and North Hatley, Quebec.

title: `Quite A While
description: THIS is the sort of book that academics hohum, but that interested citizens relish. Though R.W. Johnson is a respected Oxford professor, a Fellow in politics and sociology at Magdalen College, his book is not heavy with footnotes, not very theoretical and, in the main, offers nothing very new. But it witty (Portugal hanging onto its colonies is compared to a dying man insisting on his right to be a blood donor), provocative (Watergate was the best news Johannesburg had had in years), and daring (the United States pushed, pulled and cajoled a reluctant South Africa into invading Angola). In short, you are reading only one book on contemporary South Africa this year, make it this one.

title: HOME CLINIC

Thus, even for purely esthetic reasons, some maintenance is often advisable.

Seven of the victims were children and four were firemen who ran out of oxygen while searching for residents mistakenly reported missing.

description: SANTA ANA, Calif., April 7A baby rested in her mother's lap this week in a witness's chair in Superior Court here, looked out inquisitively at the crowded courtroom before her and gurgled softly. She was an exhibit in an unusual trial for murder.

title: Old Atoms in New Missiles Are Enough
description: The idea of ending the production of fissionable material for nuclear weapons and transferring substantial existing stocks to peaceful uses is one of the oldest arms control proposals of the nuclear age. Five Presi- dents have favored it. President Johnson announced unilateral cutback of 25 percent but reports that the Soviet Union reciprocated were never confirmed. President Nixon repeated the proposal in 1969, substantially easing requirements for onsite inspection, to which the Soviet Union had always objected. Against that background, Secretary Vance's desire to have an interagency panel reexamine the idea for submission to the U.N. General Assembly's Special Session on Disarmament next month deserved something better than kneejerk criticism from the Pentagon.

title: RURAL HEALTH CARE IS FOCUS OF PARLEY
description: DENVER, April 9When the American Medical Association held its 31st Annual Conference on Rural Health Care here last week, the primary emphasis was not on doctors.

title: Around the Nation
description: CLEVELAND, April 9 (UPI) - Ohio officials and a Federal district judge agreed today that Cleveland's public schools must stay open even though the school system lacks funds, and they vowed to come up with a financing method by the end of the week.BOSTON, April 9 (UPI)Preliminary reports from New England's six state capitals indicate the pricetag for cleaning up snow this winter.was more than $76 million.

title: Aide's Case Troubles D.C. Mayor
description: WASHINGTON, April 9Mayor Walter E. Washington, who is expected to run for reelection in the fall, has encountered the most serious scandal of his administration with the indictment of Joseph P. Ye'dell, a key adviser.

description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 9Somalia's official radio said today that army officers, influenced by foreign powers, had tried to overthrow the Government of President Mohammed Siad Barre but that the revolt was quickly crushed by loyal troops.

Dave Kingman, the 6-foot-6-inch slugger who had slammed 82 home runs for the Mets in two and a half seasons before being traded to the San Diego Padres last June 15, returns as a Cub outfielderfirst baseman. Tickets to each of the three games, which start at 2 o'clock, cost $4.50 and $5 for box seats, $3.50 and $4.50 for reserved seats and $1.50 for general admission. Today's game will be televised by WORTV Channel 9).

They will oppose the Cleveland Cavaliers Wednesday night at Richfield, Ohio in the first game of a two-of-three series. The second game will be Friday night at Madison Square Garden and the third, if necessary, Sunday afternoon at Richfield.

title: Stage: E.L.T.'s Shrew
description: THE Equity Library Theater production of The Taming of the Shrew, which is running at its showcase until next Sunday, starts like an orchestral overture in the old style, with a stately introduction. But as soon as the drunken Sly is cozened into thinking that he is lord and the traveling actors appear, the stage lights up, motley flashes everywhere. The players whirl hoops, turn somersaults, juggle colored balls and fill the stage with general merriment. This change in tone sets the key for the play, which from then on is treated as one long theatrical scherzo.

title: Havlicek in Last Farewell
description: BOSTON, April 9Hondol Hondol Hondol The tempo of the cries picked up today until they sounded like a thousand drums echoing through the ancient Boston Garden.

description: NEWARKIf Zbigniew Brzezinski 'Woody Woodpecker to his White House chumswants to observe what geopoliticians call a proxy war, he can turn his attention to the struggle for the Republican nomination to the Senate in the State of New Jersey.
