description: ROTTERDAM, Netherlands, April (AP)Topseeded Jimmy Connors beat fourthseeded Raul Ramirez of Mexico, 7.5, 75, in the final of a $175,000 tennis tournament today, The victory was worth $30,000 to Connors while Ramirez won $15.000.

title: Reds Roll To Fourth Straight
description: If precedent means anything, the Los Angeles Dodgers will have trouble in the defense of their Western Division championship. The Cincinnati Reds, the Dodgers archrivals, won their fourth game without a loss yesterday, pounding the Houston Astros, 93, at Riverfront Stadium in Cincinnati.

title: 5 Men Arrested in Marijuana Case
description: STUART, Fla., April 9 (UPI)Federal agents arrested five men late last night as an estimated five tons of marijuana was unloaded from a boat docked at Hobe Sound residence. The five men, three of whom were identified as Canadians, were being held on $200,000 bond. One of them was shot and wounded by Customs agents but was reported in stable condition today.

description: NEW BRUNSWICK,N.J., April 8 The place was New Jersey, to be sure 4,000 miles and 50 years from the Paris of literary legend - but the shades of Gertrude Stein, Isadora Duncan, Colette .and a host of other famous females: surely hovered for a moment or two over New Brunswick this week.

title: CBS Admits Deception On Tennis
description: The president of the CBS Broadcast Group, Gene F. Jankowski. went on the air yesterday to concede that a serves of televised tennis matches that have become the subject of a Federal Communications Commission investigation had been presented in a wrong and misleading way.

title: A Boy's Report to a 7thGrade Health Class On His Brother and What It's Like at Home
description: I have a braindamaged brother. His name is Noah. My brother is a 10yearold boy who can't talk, read, write and can't do most things a boy his age can do, such as throw or catch a ball. He goes to a special school and a special daycare center in the afternoon. He has black hair and charming smile. Noah stands about 54 inches tall.

April 9 (AP)-Hsieh Yungyo of Taiwan defeated Kuo Chihsiung, a fellow countryman on the seventh extra hole of a suddendeath playoff today in the final of the $35,000 Taiwan open golf tournament. Hsieh and Kuo each shot a finalround two-under-par 70 and finished with 72hole totals of 288.

David F. Segal's lighting is bright but not harsh; this is a daylight King Lear. Nancy Potts's costumes are functionalmostly in black and White. As director, John Houseman has set the stage for a Lear that should have simplicity and clarity.

The restoration of trading in the stocks and bonds followed publication of the final version of courtapproved plans for payments to Penn Central creditors.

description: CHICAGO, April 9An unusual partnership here between the city and private businessmen has been providing on-thejob training for close to 2,000 people year who are considered chronically unemployed.

description: Saudi Arabia does not intend to base the F15 fighters it hopes to acquire from the United States at Tabuk, an airfield only 125 miles from the Israeli frontier, according to a State Department memorandum.

title: New Dispute Over Caste System Causes Turmoil in India
description: PATNA, India, April 5A bitter new conflict over the ancient problem of caste has sent angry mobs raging through the :rutted streets of this northeastern city in recent weeks and has caused several killings in the hot, dry countryside.

title: The Farm Aid That Hurts
description: Senate and House conferees on the emergency farm bill looked duty squarely in the eye last weekand blinked. Succumbing to pressure from protesting farmers, the conferees voted for legislation that would cost the Treasury and consumers billions, generate inflation and increase the potential for food shortages. If the House and Senate tail to vote down this irresponsible aid package it is certain to be vetoed by President Carter.

description: ALBANY, April 7Having given out grants to more than a thousand institutions last year, the State Council on the Arts is discovering that it needs to acquire some oldfashioned political acumen. Its budget, as proposed New York Political Notes by Governor Carey, was slashed by the Legislature last month to teach them a lesson, according to one legislative source, and to encourage the council to De more Open about CUSCUSS1Dg Its criteria for grantgivingas well as to be more cooperative with legislators interested in getting grants for projects in their districts.

title: 600 FILIPINOS SEIZED IN A MANILA PROTEST OVER VOTE COUNTING
description: MANILA, April 9Six leaders of an opposition party and about 600 workers, students and nuns were arrested during a march through Manila today protesting the disputed election of a National Assembly.

title: Piano: Stephen Mayer Plays Own Work
description: STEPHEN MAYER'S piano recital Saturday afternoon at Town Hall ended with Beethoven's Sonata in A flat (Op. 110), in a performance that didn't always quite encompass the work's technical demands but demonstrated an appealing grasp of its basic idiom and a nice musicality. But the principal interest was Mr. Meyer's display of pieces by himself and Robert Jurgrau that incorporated quartertone passages, and of a way of playing such music without a specially designed quartertone piano.

title: Brezhnev Returns From Trip to Area Along China Border
description: MOSCOW, April 9 (Reuters)The Soviet leader, Leonid I. Brezhnev, returned to Moscow today after reviewing Soviet defenses on the troubled border with China and meeting with local industrial chiefs in Siberia.

title: Miss Quinlan Entering 3d Year in Coma, Unaffected by Court Ruling on Her Case
description: Karen Ann Quinlan, who lapsed into a coma three years ago this Friday and became the subject of a celebrated court case that set new guidelines for removing lifesupport systems from some terminally ill patients, is resting even more peacefully these days at the Morris View Nursing Home in Morris Township, N.J., according to her mother.

title: European Leaders Say Israel Must Withdraw On All Fronts
description: COPENHAGEN, April 9 (Reuters)Leaders of the Common Market agreed at a conference over the weekend that Middle East settlement must be based on compliance with demands that Israel withdraw from occupied Arab territories, authoritative sources said.

Kreitman performed the ceremony. The bridegroom is a son of Yvette G. Scharfman of Brooklyn, an assistant to Howard Golden, Borough President of Brooklyn, and the, late Dr. Ephraim Scharfman.

title: $1.2 Billion Land Banks Offer Set
description: The Federal Land Banks, Governmentsponsored farmerowned system to make rural real estate mortgage loans, plans to sell $1.2 billion of shortterm bonds Wednesday to retire $863.4 million of maturing securities and to raise $336.7 million of additional cash to make more farm loans. The offering will consist of $600 million of 21month bonds due Jan. 21, 1980. and $600.1 million of 54month bonds coming due Oct. 20, 1982.

description: PARIS, April 9These are hard times for Western European workers, and harder still if they happen to be women.

title: Brazil's Opposition Expects Little Democratization
description: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 9As Brazil enters its 15th year under an authoritar Ian military regime that was not intended to last more than two years, President Ernesto Geisel has dismissed as utopian the hope that this nation may become full democracy.

description: Francis J. Gerham, executive vice president of A. L. Burbank & Company, a shipbrokerage concern of New York City, died Friday in St. Luke's Hospital in Jacksonville, Fla. Mr. Gerham, who lived on Lincoln Avenue in the Town of Rye, N.Y., was 58 years old.

title: Fencing: Pesthy and Miss Vaccaroni Capture Titles
description: One of the most distinctive athletes in America is a 40-year-old college coach and teacher named Paul Pesthy, of San AntOnio, Tex., and whose main sport is fencing. Pesthy (pronounced Pest) yesterday won the epee title at the annual International Invitational Tournament of the Amateur Fencers League of America, a threeday event at the New York Athletic Club that involved 262 men and 48 women competitors from 13 nations.

title: Guerrilla Scare in Israel Sets Off Army Alert, but Hoax Is Suspected:
description: JERUSALEM, Monday, April 10Unconfirmed reports that a band of Palestinian guerrillas had landed along Israel's coast set off a major security alert early today.

title: Proven Reserves of Oil in U.S. Declined 1.5 Million Barrels in 77
description: The nation's proved recoverable reserves f crude oil stood at 29.5 billion barrels at the end of 1977, according to final estimates released today by the American Petroleum Institute, an indus- try group. The etimate represents a decrease of 1.5 billion barrels from yearearlier level, but the drop during 1977 was somewhat less than the 1.7 billion barrel decrease that occured in 1976.

description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 9Potential Senate candidates in both of Minnesota's major parties are breathing, a lot easier now that Muriel Humphrey has announced that she will not seek election Ito. the remaining four years'of her late husband's term.

description: The New York Mets continued to confound people. yesterday when they won their third straight game from the Montreal Expos, 65, in the first half of a doubleheader. The magic touch this time was supplied by Steve Henderson, who merely pinch ,hit a home run with the bases loaded.

title: Going Tough for Tilgrim's Progress Even in Hometown
description: BEDFORD, England  Commuters here, faced with cuts in train service, have tacked up a sign on their dingy station. Keep Bedford on the Map, it exhorts.

title: Jackpot of $165,000 Hit by Jersey Woman
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 9 (AP)Anne Cervinko of New Brunswick N.J, thought she had won 500 when the bells started ringing and the lights flashing Friday night, but then she found out the payoff was actually $165,000.

title: Teaching Is No Game of Chance
description: When the Board of Education rehired 3,500 teachers last fall it assigned them to schools through two separate lotteries: Whites drew their assignments in schools with mostly black teachers and blacks were distributed among schools staffed largely by white teachers. That distasteful routine was the reluctant response of both the board and the teachers union to complaints by the Federal Civil Rights office that previous assignment plans had resulted in racial segregation. Now that Federal judge'has voided the dual lottery (on procedural rather than constitutional grounds), everyone is in happy flight from it. The problem is that no one has yet come tip with a better solution.

description: Harlem residents suffer more from bad health than other New Yorkers and even more than residents of other predominantly black neighborhoods.

description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 9Somalia's official radio said today that army officers, influenced by foreign powers, had tried to overthrow the Government of President Mohammed Siad Barre but that the revolt was quickly crushed by loyal troops.

Funeral services Riverside Chapel, Amsterdam Ave and 76 St, Tuesday, April 11 at 1:30PM.

description: MONDAY, APRIL 10, 1978

title: Sporting Gear
description: The latest addition to Bally's television arcade of games is Tornado Baseball, and it offers far more than a chance to hit an electronic ball with an electronic bat. The defensive team is maneuvered by means of a control that provides much onfield mobility, and a wide assortment of pitches can be thrown. The team at bat must have. quick reflexes to counter such pitching, which, after all, is what real baseball is all rbout. The $25 sports cassette, which can be played on a color or black-and-white television set, also provides sound effects, and games of tennis, hockey and handball. There is one catch, however. To use the cassette on your television, you must have a Bally Computer Arcade control board, which sells for $300. Once this is purchased, you can use cassettes for educational exercises, card strategy and artistic scribbling. From Irving Kaye Company, 48 Union Street, Stamford, Conn. 06906; Bayside Home Games, 4129 216th Street, Bayside, Queens 11361; Blatt Bowling and Billiard Corporation, 809 Broadway, New York 10003; Tape City, 404 Park Avenue South, New York 10022, and The Game Room, Route, 46, Fairfield, N.J. 07006.

title: Chess:
description: They are still trying to put the arsenic back into the poisonedpawn variation. The way people such as Grandmaster Lajos Portisch of Hungary or Grandmaster Efim Geller of Russia have been licking their chops over the poisoned pawn in the last few years, one would think it was coated with honey.

title: Ford Motor Credit Plans Issue
description: The Ford Motor Credit Company, wholly owned financing subsidiary of Ford Motor Company, has disclosed plans to sell $300 million of notes next week. Moody's Investors Service upgraded the securities to Aaa from Aa, citing the improving profitability of the concern. The financing will consist of $150 million of notes due May 1, 1984, and $150 million due May 1, 1988, Goldman Sachs & Company, Ford's traditional investment banker, will manage the offering.

title: National League
description: AT ATLANTAThe Dodgers also stayed undefeated, but only through three games, as Steve Garvey got three hits, one of them a threerun homer that lifted Los Angeles from a 42 deficit to a 54 lead in the sixth. Rick Rhoden allowed the Braves all of their runs in the first three innings, then blanked Atlanta until the eighth when Robert Castillo relieved him. Tommy Boggs. a rookie who gave up the first five Los Angeles runs, was the losing pitcher.

title: Stage: Julius Caesar in Brooklyn
description: JULIUS CAESAR is the most public and political of Shakespeare's great plays. To carry the tragic themethe conflict not of unmixed good and evil but of two mixed goodsit is a play without villains.

title: A Festive Evening for the State Symphony
description: MORRISTOWN April 9Polish (lancers, diplomats and dignitaries were part of the New Jersey Symphony's Polon:tise Ball last night at the Governor Morris Inn here. The event was sponsored by the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra League. Thomas Michalak, the Polishborn music director of the symphony, was the duest of honor.

title: Newcomers to Coq d Or
description: THERE ARE only two roles in RimskyKorsakov's Le Coq d'Or that require an extensive amount of singingKing Dodon and the Queen of Shemakha. Nei- ther one is easy, and both were in safe rather then inspired hands on Saturday night at the City Opera as Richard McKee and Gianna Rolandi sang these parts for the first time with the company.

title: News Summary
description: The Philippine police arrested hundreds of demonstrators as they marched through Manila protesting irregularities in Friday's election for a National Assembly, which turned into a bitterly fought test of President Ferdinand E. Marcos's martial-law rule. Six leaders of the opposition People's Force Party were among the 600 arrested. The marchers violated a presidential decree against political demonstrations and face a trial before a military tribunal. Only 5 percent of the vote had been tabulated by a Government commission 48 hours after the polls closed. The delay was said to have been caused by a bomb threat and the need to be accurate. But one of the People's Force cr.ndidates charged that Marcos has the ballots and is trying to decide what to do with them, and that the election showed he doesn't have popular suoport more. [Page Al, Col. 6.]

title: New Swimmers Seek Olympic Gold
description: IN pursuit of a scoop of chocolate mint ice cream or a hot fudge brOwnie delight, Tracy. Caulkins is all smiles. When comes to chasing an Amefican record in swimming, however, don't bother looking for any emoticn from this 15yearold national champion.

title: Hamar Case: Did Bank Regulators Fail in Their Duties?; Operate in Secrecy; Transaction Is Disguised; Identity Confidential; Audit Deficiencies
description: WASHINGTON, April 9Two years ago, George D. Hamar, an investment. officer at the Virginia National Bank in Norfolk, called the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the agency that regulates national banks. After securing a promise that his name would be kept confidential, he reported what he considered improprieties in the management of his bank's trust accounts.

title: Rangers Snap Loss Streak at
description: It took a little doing, but the New York Rangers ended a fivegame losing streak, beating the Chicago Black Hawks, 32, last night before an appreciative Madison Square Garden crowd.

title: Adding 400 Police in South Bronx Proposed to Aid Redevelopment
description: Plans for a large anticrime effort in the Smith Bronxincluding the addition of about 400 police officers and supervisors, the introduction of new ways of patrolling and the gaining of community cooperationhave been draWn up by the Police Department and submitted to the city administration.

title: State Woman Wins A Top Vegas Payoff
description: LAS VEGAS, April 9 (UPI)A retired woman from New Jersey has won the largest Las Vegas slotmachine payoff thus far this year$154,981.

title: WALL STREET FEARS OVER MONEY SUPPLY ARE SAID TO WORSEN
description: Many of Wall Street's money market economists are beginning to worry that the nation's money supply is about to mushroom, touching off a sharp rise in interest rates this spring.

title: Dance: Royal Ballet Of Flanders in Debut
description: wHEN the Jot trey Ballet introduced a very interesting and draamtic young dancer to Net/ York last fall named Tom Van Cauwenbergh, it was just as interesting to learn that he came from Belgium and mare specifically from the Royal Ballet of Flanders, founded by his aunt. Jeanne Brabants.

title: Music: Sine Wave Tone
description: ALVIN LUCIER'S Music in Real and Imagined Spaces, which was presented at the Kitchen on Saturday night, had more to do with spaces than with music in any of the conventional senses of the word. Two of the three piece: employed a single sine wave tonE as their sound components. In Snares and Walker, the sine wave was tuned to resonate a snare drum, and then a dancer used her body to interrupt the flow of the sound to change the sound of the drum. In Ghosts, Mr. Lucier walked around the Kitchen in the dark with a soundsensitive light that emitted a faint glow whenever he encountered irregularities in the distribution of the sine wave tone.

title: Sadat Seeks U.S. Help on Deadlock
description: CAIRO, April 9President Anwar elSadat today underscored his conviction that peace could not be established in the Middle East without American help and expressed hope that the United States would move in to break the deadlock in the negotiations.

title: IV To Kill a Cop With Louis Gossett
description: AS FICTION huffs and puffs to keep up with fact, consider the case of To Kill a Cop, a fourhdur movie being presented on NBC tonight and tomorrow at 9 o'clock Two weeks ago, a plot about a cop-kill- er gang overseen by a former black revolutionary and an exinmate of Attica prison might have seemed farfetched. But last week, two Brooklyn police officers were slain in a gun battle by a former Attica inmate and his companion, one of whom had Palestine Liberation Organization propaganda in his car. The huffing and puffing continues apace.

title: Advertising,freedom of the press, and the message from Washington.; Advertising and freedom of the press are not mutually exclusive. With that in mind, the following editorial (reprinted from Barron's, April 3, 1978) should be interest to all thoughtful Americans.; EDITORIAL COMMENTARY; Getting the Message:Washington Has Launched a Drive Against Corporate Advertising;  Shirley Scheibla; Reprinted from BARRON'S, April 3,1978
description: WASHINGTON  A Senate Subcommittee has just launched. a hunting expedition .aimed against advertising which gives corporate views on controversial issues. It also includes ad campaigns designed to improve the corporate image. Specifically, the Senate Subcommittee on Administrative Practice and Procedure has subpoenaed mountains of material, much of confidential and some involving trade secrets, from four major oil companies, Exxon, Gulf, Mobil and Texaco, and their four advertising agencies. Benton & Bowles; Doyle. Dane, Bernbach; McCaffrey & McCall, and Young & Rubicam. The chief executive officers . of the eight firms have been ordered to appear, with the material, before the Subcommittee this Friday.

title: Steel Merger? Debate Grows In Youngstown; Political Considerations; Steel Merger? Debate Grows In Youngstown on Saving Mills; GrassRoots Project; Vast Sums Required
description: WASHINGTON, April 9Tomorrow in Youngstown, Ohio, a Washington economic consultant will outline to community leaders a grassroots equity capital approach to reopening a steel mill that shut down last fall and put 4,200 workers on the street.

title: Gypsies From 20 Countries Pay Tribute to Those Slain by Nazis
description: GENEVA, April 9 (Reuter)Some 130 gypsies from 20 countries stood in silent tribute today to the half million Romany victims of Nazi Germany.

title: With Hard Facts in Short Supply, Russians Make the Rumor an Art
description: MOSCOW, April 9Most of the fine arts in the Soviet Union suffer from political handicaps, but there is one field of creativity that flourishes mightilythe advanced art of the rumor.

title: John Ha.vlicek, Marathon Man
description: HAPPY FINE, who is employed by the Celtics to record their games play by play from courtside, maintains that John Havlicek played every minute like it was his firsthe didn't worry about how long he had been going or how much longer he had to go. And he took every shot like it was his first'he didn't worry about how many he had hit or missed, about whether or not he was hot. He didn't save himself, or doubt himself, or do anything but apply himself. That is hard to.believe, but that is what looked like for 16 years, and yesterday Havlicek played his last minute and took his last shot.

title: GEORGE LEVIN
description: GUATEMALA, April 9 (AP)Clemente Marroqufn Rojas, Vice President of Guatemala from 1966 to 1970 and publisher of the newspaper La Hora, died yesterday after a long illness, his family announced. He was 81 years old.

title: Deaths

David Barwise, Hilton Head, S.C., brother of Mrs Frederick M. Harris of Annapolis, Md., five grandchildren. Private services Tuesday from A. M. Runyon Funeral Home, Plainfield, N.J. Contributions in his memory to Good Samaritan Hospital, Flagler Drive, West Palm Beach, Fla., 33401.

title: in Paris, Adventurous Accessories:
description: PARIS, April 9 One word is sufficient to describe the look of the accessories that designers are showing here in their 197879 fallwinter collections: unbelievable. There are wildly tinted rare birds feathers stuck in hats and hair do's; huge overscaled brooches smoth ered in rhinestones and fake emeralds; lethallooking highheeled boots tied up at the ankles and trimmed in generous amounts of fake. fur; bracelets so big and gaudy that even a Lido. showgirl might wince; military hats bedecked with foothigh plumes and fistsized medalions; whole stems of cymbidium orchids that literally cover heads; shoes with heels that look like kingsized icecream cones, and big clownsized bows tied under necks. Fashion is show business here and accessories help to get the act across to the audience. And it works.

description: AT DETROITThe Tigers collected seven runs on seven hits and three bases on balls in the second inning to score their second victory. Tom UnderWood and two relief pitchers could not retire any of the first eight Detroit batters in the inning. Jack Billingham, the former Cincinnati pitcher making his American League debut, pitched 8 1/3 innings before he needed help from Steve Foucault.

description: Why did you let him into the house? a man in the brown suit shouts at hysterical woman in blue. A woman in brown steps between them, saying: Could you please calm down, please? Your wife has just been through a terrible experience. Try to show some understanding.

title: Decline of the IrishAmerican in New York .Politics
description: James McManus, a thirdgeneration Democratic district leader in the once Irish ghetto of Hell's Kitchen on the West Side, told a story to illustrate the decline of the once dominant IrishAmerican in the Democratic Party in New York City and, indeed, in city politics generally.

description: Karen Ann Quinlan, who lapsed into a coma three years ago this Friday and became the subject of a celebrated court case that set new guidelines for removing lifesupport systems from some terminally ill patients, is resting even more peacefully these days at the Morris View Nursing Home in Morris Township, accordin to her mother

description: Leon SJ. Hekimian's Half High, who ran in a claiming race at the Meadowlands as recently as last December, closed with a flourish in the stretch yesterday and won the $42,925 Gravesend Handicap at Aqueduct.

description: Harlem residents suffer more from bad health than other New Yorkers and even more than residents of other predominantly black neighborhoods.

description: On his first visit to New York City since the 1972 Presidential campaign, former President Richard M. Nixon yesterday praised the city as a place that still has excitement and then sped away from his hotel for what he said would be a drive in the country.

description: If you watched the Xeroxsponsored special, The Family Upside Down on the NBCTV Network last night, you saw history being made. Impressed?

title: U.S. Five Beats Soviet Team, 10782
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 9 (AP)Jack Givens scored 15 points to help the United States team win the World Invitation Tournament today with a 10782 victory over the Soviet Union national basketball team before 12,014 fans in Rupp Arena.

title: Byrne's Appointive Policies
description: TRENTON, April SThe appointment practices of Governor Byrne are beginning to come under criticism from his own party as well as Republicans after new indications, according to observers, that the Governor views conflict-of- interest laws not as guidelines, but as obstacles to be overcome.

title: ANTICRIE PROPOSAL OUT FOR SOUTH BRONX
description: A proposal by the New York City Police Department for a largescale anticrime effort as part of the city's redevelopment of the South Bronx has been deleted from the overall program because of a feeling at City Hall that it would not conform with Federal legislation.

description: Advertising majors at colleges and there are more of them all the timemust have more courses in economics, marketing and management in order to compete with business school graduates for the love of agency top brass.

title: City Teacher Benefits Questioned
description: State auditors charged yesterday that Mickey Mouse computations had been used by the city's actuary to determine how much the city pays for publicschool teachers retirement benefits.

title: Upturn in Industrial Construction Spurs Recovery of Steel Industry
description: A longawaited surge in demand for heavy structural steel and platea result of an upturn in industrial constructionhas broadened the recovery of the steel industry in the last few months.

title: Stuart Vaughan to Direct Own Play on Broadway
description: Stuart Vaughan, prominent as a director in the Off Broadway and regional theater, will make his Broadway debut next season with The Royal Game, a play he wrote, which will be produced by Vincent Curcio.

title: LON L. FULLER, 75, LAWYER AND HARVARD PROFESSOR
description: Lon L. Fuller, a professor emeritus at the Harvard Law School and the author of several books on sociology and the law, died Saturday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 75 years old.

title: The War of the Bureaucrats
description: Government doesn't work. So millions of Americansperhaps most of usfeel. Anyone who travels around this country and listens knows that people everywhere talk resentfully about the unresponsiveness, the ineptitude of Government. Faith in its ability to get things done is at a dismally low ebb.

title: 2 Appeal Cyprus Death Sentence
description: NICOSIA, Cyprus, April 8 (Reuters)Two Palestinians who were sentenced to death for assassinating Yousef an Egyptian editor who was a close friend of President Anwar elSadat, appealed the sentence today.

title: The Verdict on Women as Jurors: Numerous and Influential
description: Criminal defendants in Manhattan these daysgenerally malesare discovering that juries of their peers are largely female.

title: Amy Carter (I Like New York') At Music Hall With 200 Friends
description: Amy Carter had heard that Radio City Music Hall might shut down this month because of its financial difficulties, and she was keen on seeing show there. So yesterday accompanied by more than 200 schoolmates from Washington, the President's 10-yearold daughter traveled up to New York City by bus and took on the role of an unordinary tourist.

title: Argentina Names 158 Prisoners
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 9 (Reuters)Argentina has identified 158 political prisoners who were being held without trial, bringing the number so far named to 3,340. In December, the Interior Ministry said 3,607 people were being held under state of siege regulations and that all would be named eventually.

title: How Your Child Can Learn to Sail
description: IT happens every summer. Youngsters are drawn to the water, fascinated by the movement of boat, wind and waves. Perhaps this will be the summer for your child to learn to sail, to experience the excitement and the independence of being captain of all he or she surveyseven if only from a 10foot dinghy.

title: POLICEMAN DISMISSED FOR OVERTIME FRAUD
description: The commander of a New York City detective squad was dismissed just hours before his scheduled retirement on Saturday after a departmental trial found him guilty of unnecessarily accumulating and at times fabricating his overtime pay in a calculated scheme to inflate his pension.

title: Xenia, Ohio, Rebuilt After Tornado, Still Faces Problems
description: XENIA, Ohio, April 6Except for an occasional boardedup structure, a few aerial photographs in public buildings and the chilling recollections of residents, there are few signs of the devastation this city suffered four years ago when a roaring tornado cut a quartermile swath through the center of town, killing 34 people and causing $500 million in damage.

title: World News Briefs
description: HIATTSVILLE, Md., April 9 (AP)-Michael Vernon Townley was arraigned as a material witness today in the 1976 assassination of the former Chilean diplomat Orlando Letelier, the Federal Bureau of Investigation said.

title: Three Fires, Two in Upstate New York, Take 16 Lives
description: Three fires that roared through woodframe apartment buildings, two in upstate New York and one in Massachusetts, killed 16 people before dawn yesterday. Seven of the victims were children and four were firemen who ran out of oxygen while searching for residents mistakenly reported missing.

title: The World Golfer
description: AUGUSTA, GA, WFARING a green jacket as the Masters champion, Gary Player had been talking for perhaps 20 minutes about his golf career when he was asked, Where do you think you rank among the game's great players? Quickly, in that South African accent that always rises an octave when he's asserting himself, he replied, That's not for me to decide. That's for people who know what they're talking about when it comes to golf, that's for them to decide. He had shot recordtying 64 to win his third Masters title yesterday but during the previous 20 minutes in the interview room at the Augusta National Golf Club; he had presented his case. He had described himself as having the best golf record in the world, meaning the world, not merely the PGA Tour that dominates American golf. And with his sense of history, he had artfully dropped such names as Jack Nicklaus, Arnold Palmer and Ben Hogan into his discourse, as if he wanted to be thought of only on their glorious level. Sure, he was blowing his own horn. But as the oldest golfer, at age 42, to win the Masters, he had the right to remind people that he deserves to be rated among the best to play this game since one of those Scottish shepherds first threeputted.

title: 'Running Fence' Films Story of an Art Event:The Program
description: As befits a documentary about a work of conceptual art, "Running Fence" has as much to do with the reception that greeted Christo's construction of a 22-mile fence as it does with the fence itself. Early footage of community meetings in northern California's Marin and Sonoma Counties where the fence was temporarily erected, indicates opinion in the area was sharply divided, and tempers ran high.One woman feared that allowing Christo to build the fencewhich he planned to remove two weeks laterwould open the region up to "carnivals, rock concerts, motorcycle races, whatever." One man was heard to mutter, "I bet he can't even paint a picturehe's an idiot."A friendly looking older woman compared the project to a well-cooked meal: "Sometimes I go to a lot of work to prepare a masterpiece, and what happens? It gets eaten up." Later, in a local cafe, one waitress explained that the completed fence wasn't "pretty in the sense of pretty, but it looks different, and it's kinda nifty."Directed by Albert Maysles, David Maysles and Charlotte Zwerin, the film records the most intriguing reaction of all, that of a herd of sheep seen running beside the fence on a silent, misty morning. The sheep dash towards the barrier so impetuously that they seem about to collide with it; watching them, one can't help wondering what they make of this unexpected obstruction on familiar terrain.The fence is extravagantly lovely, standing 18 feet high and made of a gleaming white fabric that ripples in the wind, but do sheep really care about such considerations? Who can say? In any case, these particular sheep finally find the opening that has been left for them and blithely pass through, as a rancher looks on with a wonderfully knowing expression.There is a great deal of shouting and arguing in "Running Fence," but the hubbub is punctuated by wordless interludes like this one, brief sequences that suggest both the large issues and the tiny ones suggested by Christo's undertaking. Very deliberately, the film never explains either Christo or his intentions. But it demonstrates, wordlessly and at times almost magically, that what he hoped to accomplish was very like what he attained.Christo's Running Fence project, shown here in its planning, construction and completed stages, is about as ideal a subject as any documentary film maker could hope to find.Every participant in the process seems keenly aware of and vastly amused by his or her own role, and the camera becomes a welcome, openly acknowledged witness. The particular artfulness of the Haysles brothers and Miss Zwerin lies in their having taken the film beyond the golden opportunity Christo and his fence provided, and into the realm of keen, unerringly even-handed acuity. "Running Fence" presents its material clearly and impartially, yet it establishes and sustains a distinct point of view. The directors' influence is palpable, yet never meddlesome."Running Fence," which is being shown at the Whitney Museum, is 58 minutes longan ideal length, but a commercially unwieldy one, unless the film later turns up on television or on a double bill. In any case, for all the books and posters Christo's exhilarating and audacious project will spawn, this is the next best thing to having been there.

title: Actress is Slain at Michigan Audition
description: ii!GHLAND PARK, Mich., Tuesday, April 11 (AP)An aspiring actress who auditioned for the lead role in a play called Hammer was bludgeoned to death Sunday by the playwright with sledge hammer, according to a detective.

title: SMOKERS FACE CURBS IN JERSEY BUILDINGS
description: TRENTON, April 10Beginning July 1, New Jersey will have one of the most sweeping prohibitions in the county, against smoking in indo6r public places

title: Adding It All Up
description: I am to be automated soon, Everyone says it is one of the most up-to-date experiences you can have nowadays, in a class with wearing your shirt with no necktie and artificial chest hair cascading out over the second button.

title: Advertising
description: Julius Wile Sons & Company, which has been competing with Heublein's Harvey's Bristol Cream sherry with its own Dry Sack sherry, is now sending Cream Sack into the game. It is more expensive than Dry Sack but not as expensive as Harvey's.

title: Books of The Times
description: Ambrose Bierce, in The Devil's Dictionary, called an immigrant an unenlightened person who thinks one country better than another. Ted Morgan is an immigrant who thinks Ameri- ca better than any country. But on the evidence of his latest book, On Becoming American, it would be hard to call him unenlightened. Of course, Ted Morgan Is not your usual immigrant. Born 45 years ago in Switzerland and christened Sanche de Gramont, he grew up with just enough of the advantages to realize what a disadvantage they could be. Already a count and the scion of one of France's oldest aristocratic families, he could have taken for himself the freefloating family title Prince de Bidache, gone to Palm Springs, put his title up at the widows auction and settled back into a life of uselessness.

title: Deaths
description: BARTHGeorgina on April 9, 1978. Dear wife of the late Alexander. Mother of Albert and Richard Barth. Reposing Oelker A Cox Funeral Home, Main St, Mt. Kisco, Tuesday 2.4 & 7.9PM. Funeral Mass St. Patrick's Church, Bedford, N.Y. Wednesdav at 10AM. Interment Calvary Cemetery.

title: PANAMA SAID TO TELL U.S. IT WON'T ACCEPT TREATY RESERVATION
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Panama has reportedly warned the United States that it will not accept a reservation attached to one of the Panama Canal treaties already approved by the Senate and that its patience with the handling of the pacts is running out.

title: Met Audition Won Jointly By 2 Women
description: The annual Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions of the Air, held Sunday afternoon at the Opera House, were won jointly by Winifred Brown, soprano, and Wendy White, mezzo - soprano. Miss Brown, who is 28 and from Evanston, Ill., and Miss White, who is 25 and from Bloomington, Ind., will each receive $5,000 as equal winners of the Mrs. Frederick K. Weyerhaeuser Award.

title: Agreement on the Status Of Micronesia Reported
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP)United States officials and representatives of Micronesia have achieved a major breakthrough in long negotiations on the status of the Pacific Trust Territory, the State Department said today.

title: BADILLO THREATENS TO QUIT, BUT YIELDS
description: Deputy Mayor Herman Badillo threatened to resign yesterday after Mayor Koch took away some of his authority, then, after a long talk with the Mayor, agreed to stay on.

title: Government and Corporate Bonds Decline With Sale of $150 Million of Securities,
description: CDri:;rate and Government bond prices declinci fairly sharply yesterday as two large institutional investors decided to sell $150 million of securities from their nortfolio.

title: Tuna Boats Eye the Blues
description: Sport fishermen in the Northeast are becoming increasingly worried that commercial tuna fishermen may turn to bluefish as a means of business survival.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: LONDON, April 10(Reuters)British Airways asked the Department of Trade today for permission to buy 20 Americanbuilt Boeing 737's to replace its fleet of aging Britishbuilt Trident I and Trident II airliners.

title: Indiana Parents Ask Court To Declare Daughter Dead
description: MICHIGAN CITY, Ind., April 10 (APThe parents of 15-year-old Andra ?? nelli, convinced that their ??/ daughter is legally dead, went to Court today seeking permission to ct. her respirator.

title: Toledo Teachers Strike Adds to Ohio's School Woes
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, April 10The Toledo put,lic school system, already struggling to stay open with a barebones budget, was struck by its teachers and other employees this morning after lastditch efforts to resolve a pay dispute failed.

title: Consumer Spending Rose 1.9% in March
description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP)-Con sumers spent 1.9 percent more at retail stores in March than In February, but sales for the first quarter were slow, Commerce Department figures indicated tnelav

title: How to Court Business, Again
description: Mayor Koch has discovered that economic development is easier to talk about than to accomplish. Despite the current prosperity of parts of Manhattan, large areas of unemployment remain, industry continues to depart and no one knows how to improve matters. The Mayor, at least, had the courage to retract early missteps and bid farewell to his first Deputy Mayor for Economic Development, Robert J. Milano.

title: All in New Orleans to Sign Rematch
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 10 (AP)Muhammad Ali, predicting he would be the first to win the heavyweight championship three times, arrived today to sign for a rematch against Leon Sninks.

title: Abducted Belgian Industrialist Is Found Dead
description: BRUSSELS, April 10The body of a Belgian millionaire industrialist who was kidnapped March 7 was found early today in a garbage dump.

title: 2 Dead in Newark Fire
description: NEWARK, April 10 (AP)Two tenants died and three were hospitalized as a result of a twoalarm blaze here that officials said was highly suspicious. They had been trapped Sat- urday morning on the top floor of threestory wooden house. The dead were identified as Rena Gatewood, 46 years old, and Leroy Mitchell, 52.

title: BeverlyBrownDancensemble Presents 5 for Mixed Media
description: Beverly Brown, a soloist with the Erick Hawkins Dance Company for eight years, has become choreographer of extraordinary range and vitality in her own right. On Sunday afternoon at the American Theater Laboratory the Beverly Brown Dancensemble presented a concert of five works that were in turn lyrical, dramatic, funny and surprisingly sensual for one of her rather prim manner.

title: SOVIET CITIZEN, WALDHEIM AIDE, DEFECTS AT U.N.
description: WASHINGTON, April 10Arkady N. Shevchenko, the topranking Soviet official in the United Nations Secretariat, has defected from his country, spokesmen at the United Nations and the State Department announced today.

title: Grandmother Who Feared City Was a Jungle Greeted By Koch in City Hall Visit
description: Miriam Marquis of Sudbury, Mass., whose family feared that New York City was too much of a jungle for her and her granddaughter to visit, told Mayor Koch yesterday that their weekend visit had been the best time she had had in her 71year life.

title: City Aide at Center of Controversy After a Threat to Subpoena Koch
description: The chairman of New York City's Cornmission on Human Rights has threatened to subpoena Mayor Koch, and the Mayor let it be known yesterday that he would decide within a seek whether to dismiss the chairman.

title: The Perils of E.R.A.
description: The Equal Rights Amendment Is in trouble. After more than six years of battle to win ratification, E.R.A. Is still three states short of the necessary 38. Fearing failure, some proponents are pressing Congress to postpone the March 1979 deadline and give them another sevenyear try at ratification. They point out that the original deadline was get by Congress. not by the Constitution, and there- fore can be reset by Congress. Although the last seven constitutional amendments have all passed easily under a sevenyear deadline, some boosters contend that E.RA, is too complex and controversial to be decided upon a mere seven years.

title: U.S. and Japan Pressed on Tariffs
description: GENEVA, April 10The nine member countries of the West European Common Market demanded today that the United States and Japan offer more generous cuts in the tariffs they impose on imported industrial goods. The move was made Co insure the success of the socalled Tokyo Round of tradefreeing negotiations, under way here for more than four and a half years. The round consists of negotiations for the elimination of tra,;;. barriers.

title: When It Rains It Pours: Another Soccer League
description: The Americanization of soccer continued yesterday with the announcement of plans for yet another indoor league.

title: Bridge:
description: The semifinal stage of the New York grand national team champioship played at the Beverly East Club here Sunday proved something of an anticlimax.

title: Leader of Principals Group Terms New York Reading Test Travesty
description: The president of the Elementary School Principals Association said yesterday that the New York Citywide reading test given last month was an educational travesty and he urged his membership of 650 principals not to administer the test next year unless drastic alterations are made in the testing program.

title: Ethnic Friction Disturbs Tranquility of Indonesian City
description: UJUNG PANDANG, Indonesia, April 9I am the master of the town, so can change it, said the mayor of this city when asked why, since 1971, it no longer bears its time honored name of Macassar. But Col. Muhammad Pa- tompo, the mayor, added that a movement was afoot to restore the name that this capital of the island of Sulawesi, once known as Celebes, bore through its long history and which became fixed in English dictionaries since the days of Queen Victoria in the form of antimacassar.

title: Du Pont Accused of Seeking to Monopolize Pigments
description: WASHINGTON, April 10The Federal Track.. Commission, by a vote cif 3 to 1, accused E. 1. du Pont de Nemours & Company today of having attempted to monopolize the manufacture of titanium dioxide pigments, which are used as whiteners in a variety of products, including paint. paper, plastics and textiles,

title: Counting the Losses in Manila
description: Alas for Ferdinand Marcos, President of the Philippines. He could not have a fair election and still preserve the myth that he enjoys overwhelming popular support. Three times since he imposed martial law in 1972, Fill- pins have dutifully acclaimed him in nochoice referendums. In Friday's parliamentary election, however, voters in Manila could cast ballots for opposition candidates. So many seem to have done so that the Government election commission, which proclaimed a proMarcos landslide, has not dared to publish the results.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A flagman for the Long Island Railroad was struck and killed by a train while he was working on the tracks in Flushing, Queens, the police said.

description: Licut. Gov. Mary Anne Krupsak said last night that Rockefeller Center had agreed to a plan that would assure the continued operation of its Radio City Music Hall. but Rockefeller Center promptly dented any such agreement, and other sources close to the negotiations said that Miss Krupsak's premature announcement had left the parties further apart than before.

description: WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI)Trivel insurance bought at an airport may cost more than twice the same coverage purchased elsewhere, the director of a consumer group said today.

description: HOUSTON, April 10Carrol M. Lynn, former Chief of Police in Houston, was arrested here today by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and charged with obstruction of justice.

title: Can a Soap Opera Find Happiness in Brooklyn?; Diabotical Imagination'
description: It is 12:30 P.M., and many people on Berkeley Place in Brooklyn are tuning in the soap opera Ryan's Hope. It's a favorite in this brownstonelined neighborhood in Park Slope because many of its residents have appeared on the television serial as extras. 3-year-old boy-next-door named Jadrien Steele has a continuing role. And some of the soap's characters are based on kcal characters.

title: PARTY SEEKS TO END SWISS BANK SECRECY
description: BERN, April 10 (AP)Leaders of Switzerland's Social Democratic Party have completed a proposal to abolish bank secrecy for wealthy tax evaders and others seeking a haven for their money.

title: Long John Nebel, 66
description: Long John Nebel, whose all night radio talkshows attracted thousands of insomniacs and other night people for more than 20 years, died of complication from cancer yesterday at the New York Sheraton Hotel. He was 66 years old and had been living at the hotel for several months.

title: Governor Postpones Veto for Restoration Of Death Penalty
description: ALBANY, April 10Governor. Carey's office announced abruptly early this evening that Mr. Carey would veto the capital punishment bill tonight. Then, six hours later, minutes before midnight, the Governor's office announced just as abruptly that the veto would come tomorrow. not tonight.

title: Panama Pacts: A New Hazard
description: First seen in Panama as a triumph that would guarantee Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera a place in his country's history, the new Panama Canal treaties are now causing him the most serious political problems of his 10-year-old military regime.

description: WASHINGTON, April 10Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance opened an Administration campaign today to build support for a projected strategic arms accord with the Soviet Union by pledging that the United States would sign such an agreement only if It improved Western security.

description: To the Editor: Your March 31 editorial The Way Back From Cyprus contains a basic contradiction. On the one hand you admit that there were strong justifications for the intervention by Turkey in July 1974, but on the other you approve of the tendency which you detect in Congress to insist on concessions from Turkey before the arms restrictions are lifted.

title: Allan Sproul, Retired President Of New York Fed, Is Dead at 82
description: Allan Sproul, retired president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, who was widely regarded as one of the world's foremost central bankers died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in California. He was 82 years old.

title: Results Due Today In Amex Board Vote
description: The annual membership meeting of the American Stock Exchange was recessed yesterday after less than an hour while inspectors of election tallied the votes in a hotly contested battle for seats on the Amex board of governors.

title: `Grand Street Will Close in Boston
description: The Prince of Grand Street, a musical starring Robert Preston and budgeted at $900,000, will close in Boston next Saturday night. The closing notice went up backstage at Boston's Shubert Theater last night. The show was to have opened May 11 at the Palace Theater on Broadway.

title: BROADCAST LEADER SCORES F.T.C. ON CHILDREN'S ADS
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 10 (AP)A broadcast industry leader today denounced Federal proposals to limit television advertisements aimed at children.

title: `Apartheid Divides South Africans in Exile
description: In South Africa, they lived by the rules of apartheid, the whites controlling the government and the economy, living in big houses with lush lawns and swimming pools, the blacks barred from the better schools, confined to the lesser jobs, forbidden to ride the same buses as whites or sit on the same park benches.

title: American Film Ends Sunday
description: A History of the American Film, the Christopher Durang play at the Anta Theater, will close Sunday afternoon, after 21 performances and 19 previews. David Chambers directed the cast, headed by April Shawhan, Swoosie Kurtz, Gary Bayer, Brent Spiner and Joan Pape.

title: T.W.U. Warns: Strike Would Be Disastrous
description: The Transport Workers Union has warned its members by letter that rejection of their new contract would mean a strikeand to strike would he disastrous for our members and their families, for the union and for the City of New York and its people.

description: HACKENSACK. N.J., April 10 detective testified today at the trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that he had found only four vials of curare in the Riverdell Hospital pharmacy when he searched It on Nov. 8, 1966, and that the nharmacist had told him he was sur- prised there was any because Ile naa never received a request for the drug in the more than a year he had been there.

title: TV: Vietnam And Its Life After the War
description: As the video camera pans across placid street scene in Hanoi, Vietnam, the narrator says, It's hard to believe that this is the capital of the only country ever to defeat the United States in a war. Anyone looking for ideologi- cal bias in Vietnam: Picking up the Pieces, which can be seen tonight at 9 o'clock on Channel 13, might pounce upon that sentence as one neatly distilled bit of evidence. The programs young producers, just under 30 years old, are obviously veterans of the antiwar movement in the United States, and they have little or nothing of positive value to imply about the long and tortuous American presence in Vietnam.

title: Many in India, Born Into Debt  To Landlords, Will Die in Debt
description: PATLON, India, April 5Kishan Dhan, an illiterate farmer with hare feet and a floppy gray turban, was born into debt 42 years ago, and he expects to die just as firmly in debt.

description: ALBANY, April 10Amid charges and countercharges from constituents and dog lovers, the State Senate today considered what has been characterized as one of the most controversial issues of the legislative sessiondog licensing.

title: FOREIGN REPORTERS ACCUSED BY MANILA
description: MANILA, April 10The Philippine Government, apparently angered by widespread coverage in the foreign press of accounts of fraudulent ballot counting, announced today that it was investigatlong allegations of interference by foreign journalists in the disputed election last Friday for an interim National Assembly.

description: EAST HUNTINGTON TOWNSHIP, Pa., April 10A white Rabbit rolled off the assembly line here today, symbolizing the beginning of an era in which many foreign companies are expected to begin producing Made in America cars.

title: Harold Johnson, 60
description: Harold Johnson, a jazz trumpet player who played for many years with Duke Ellington's orchestra, died March 28 of an apparent heart attack while driving on the Long Island Expressway after performing in East Hampton, L.I. He was 60 years old and lived in the Bronx.

title: Alfred C. Middlebrook, 77
description: Alfred C. Middlebrook, retired member of the board of trustees of the East River Savings Bank in New York City, died last Thursday at his home in Clearwater, Fla. He was 77 years old. He had worked for the bank for more than 30 years as a securities investment officer.

title: 60 Migrant Laborers Arrested
description: RUSKIN, Fla., April 10 (UPI)Hillsborough County deputies arrested 60 migrant laborers today after the workers barricaded the entrance to a strawberry farm to protest what they called a lack of justice and fair treatment for Mexican Americans. The migrants said that sev- eral complaints filed with state and county officials alleging physical abuse by Ronnie Fulwood, owner of Fulwood Farms, had been dropped without serious investigation Tommy Dickens, a supervisor at thc, farm, said that the allegations were false.

title: Badillo Threatens to Quit as Koch Trims His Power Over Operations
description: Deputy Mayor Herman Badillo said angrily yesterday that he would resign unless Mayor Koch withdrew an order taking away some of his authority, but the Mayor stood by his order.

title: Connecticut Asks How to Spend Unexpected Surplus
description: HARTFORD, April 10It is an election year in Connecticut, and state lawmakers are currently preoccupied with a pleasant problem: how to disburse millions of dollars in unexpected surplus revenues.

title: Swan Wins as Hendersons Hit Homers
description: HOUSTON, April 10 (UPI)Ron Cey drove in two runs with a homer and single and Dusty Baker singled home a pair of runs tonight to help the Los Angeles Dodgers win their fourth straight game, with a 52 victory over the Houston Astros, who have yet to win.ST. LOUIS, April 10 (UPI)Mike Ty'0020;son's threerun homer capped a sixrun first inning that carried John Denny and the St. Louis Cardinals to an 112 rout of the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.

title: Wheat Futures Gain on Prospect Of Major Grain Sales to Chinese
description: CHICAGO, April 10(AP)Wheat fuures posted sizable gains today, spurred by growing speculation that China has emerged as a major outlet for American grains.

title: Rangers Triumph, 5 to 2Munson Back as Catcher
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., April 10Despite Dick Tidrow's presence on the mound as the starting pitcher and Thurman Munson's presence behind the plate as the starting catcher, the Yankees couldn't overcome the Texas Rangers and their handkerchief waving fans tonight. The Rangers won, 52, taking the seasonopening series, two game.: to one.

title: LEO MICHELSON, PAINTER WITH A LYRICAL STYLE
description: Leo Michelson, a painter whose rendering of landscapes, still lifes and portraits was similar to the work of the Impressionists, died yesterday in Yonkers. He was 90 years old.

description: The Exxon Nuclear Company, a subsidiary of the Exxon Corporation, said yesterday that it intended to sue the Gulf Oil Corporation and its partly owned affiliate, the General Atomic Company, on charges of fraud and antitrust N'iolations in connection with a uranium supply agreement of May 1973.

title: Around the Nation
description: COLUMBUS,. Ohio. April 11 (UPI)The Ohio Supreme Court refused today to take immediate action on a request by teachers in the bankrupt Cleveland city school system to close schools so they could obtain unemployment compensation.

title: Accelerating the Inflation Fight
description: This time, we are told, the President means what he says. He will fight inflationand not just with rhetoric. The first to feel the sting, lie announced yesterday, will be his own top appointees, for whom there will be no pay rise this year. The second will be whitecollar Fed- eral workers, for whom pay Increases in 1978 will be 5.5 percent, rather than the promised 6 percent. Thus, President Carter has begun what promises to be a most difficult effort to assert the public interest over the private, the long run over the short. On the success this mission could ride the success of his Presidency.

title: Key Argentine Aide Is Slain, and Leftists Claim Responsibility

title: Film: Turks in Sweden:Stockholm Saga
description: "THE BUS," a Turkish-Swiss coproduction filmed mostly in Sweden, is as sincere as a public-service ad on behalf of clean air but somewhat less engrossing. The film, which was written, directed and produced by Bay Okan, a leading Turkish actor who also stars in it, will be shown in the New Directors/New Films series at the Museum of Modern Art today at 6 P.M. and again on Friday at 9:30 P.M."The Bus" is about a group of Turkish workers who are swindled by a compatriot who smuggles them into Sweden, takes their money and then leaves them sitting in their bus in the middle of Stockholm.For three days they remain in the bus, the curtains drawn, suspecting the worst. At night they sneak out to go to a nearby lavatory, forage for food and explore the cruel city.One fellow is picked up by a homosexual and goes mad, as if that were the natural order of events. All are hungry and not one of them is more articulate than a Labrador retriever. Though it's a sad story, Mr. Okan never makes it seem especially moving, maybe because his pretentions as a film artist get in his way.He has a fondness for starting scenes by having the image swim into focus, as if someone were awakening with a hangover. The camera is fascinated by the usual oddities and ugliness of urban living and by horizontal panshots, which make you feel as if your eyeballs had come loose. Mr. Okan himself plays the immigrant worker who goes to spectacular pieces. The only other easily indentifiable role, that of the swindling bus driver, a fellow who in turn is swindled himself, played by Ogur Arlas. The performances are not great.The film is meant, I suspect, to ???are so dense, so naive and so faceless???tion of the innocent, but the workers are so dense, so naive and so faceless that it seems more to be an indictment of native ignorance.

title: DISCOVERIES!
description: Have you ever heard of a People Pillow? I hope not because then the news to follow wouldn't be news. Just so you won't be too surprised, I'll lead into it gradually  it's about a People Pillow. The pillow has appliqud portraits of you, your family, your friends, your favorite singers or movie stars  whatever and whomever you wish. You supply photographs of the people you want on the pillow, and a complete description with height, hair, eyes, style of dress (casual, formal, camp), glasses, hobbies, special interests, and assuming a check accompanied the photographs and description, you'll wait four to six weeks and then get a package. It will be your inchsquare pillow, on white, offwhite or beige background. The first four figures on the pillow will cost you $75 and there's an additional $5 charge for each extra figure, and a $3 charge for mailing. Write Susan's Accessories at 505 Dorchester Driver, River Vale, N.J. 07675, or telephone Susan Ginsburg at (201) 3911882.

title: Rough Justice for the F.B.I.
description: Over the months, it seemed to us that Attorney General Bell had to make one of two choices in the case John J. Kearney, the lowerlevel F.B.I. man indicted fully a year ago in the first felony case for official misconduct ever brought against an F.B.I. agent. The charges involved blackbag jobs, illegal wiretapping and mailopening in pursuit of antiwar radicals. That Mr. Kearney would have engaged in such illegal activity without approval from superiors is inconceivable. Yet he remained the only defendant, a solitary scapegoat. Attorney General Bell, in our view, either should have sought indictments also of higherranking F.B.I. officialsor abandoned the Kearney case. The Attorney General has now oddly settled for a kind of rough justice by doing both.

title: Music: Philadelphians
description: EUGENE ORMANDY had put together a 20thcentury program for the concert by his Philadelphia Orchestra in Carnegie Hall last night. There were Walter Piston's Toccata for Orchestra (1948), Prokofiev's Violin Concerto No. 1 (1923), Sibelius's Symphony No. 7 (1924) and Shostakovich's Symphony No.12 (1961). None of these works was problematic, of course, and what they did best was to show off the splendor of the Philadelphia sound. As such, the evening had its rewards. Beyond that, the listing promised more than it delivered.

description: The education scene reverberates with calls for return to basics, a demand aroused by the number of children who lag in reading and writing and by the many high school graduates who are inadequately prepared for college or work. In the elementary schools the dissatisfaction focuses on the Three R's; in the high schools, it challenges a policy that allows students to enroll in soft electives and to bypass the hard subjects, such as English, history, mathematics, science and foreign languages.

Colleen Dew- hurst, Charles Durntrig and Harry Hamlin, a young actor who will have the title role, will star in NBC's sixhour dramatization of Studs Lonigan, based on James T. Farrell's 1930's trilogy of Irish youth in Chicago. The play will be in three twohour parts on consecutive nights next season. Reginald Rose has written the script, his first for television in a decade, and James Goldstone is the director.

title: Music: Tribute to Nevin
description: REMEMBER Narcissus, The Rosary, Mighty Lak Rose? They were among the most popular pieces to be played or sung during the last decade of the 19th century and the first half of the 20th. As sheet music, they sold millions of copies. The Rosary was Ernestine SchumannHeink's favorite American song and omnipresent in her concert programs. Geraldine Farrar recorded Mighty Lak a Rose with Fritz Kreisler playing a violin obbligato.

Still Waters, a film by John Borden and Neil Goodwin, is part of public television's Nova series and is on Channel 13.

title: J. P. Morgan Earnings Advanced By 20.3% During First Quarter
description: J. P. Morgan & Company reported yesterday a 20.3 percent gain in firstquarter earnings compared with a year earlier. The hefty increase was attributed mostly to across-the-beard gains in the non-lending operations of the nation's fifth largest banking company.

title: Notes on People
description: AT the University of Denver, from which he received his bachelor's and master's degrees, Lowell Thomas was on hand for the announcement'that he had donated his 350acre estate in Pawling, N.Y., to his alma mater. The Dutchess County property will be sold eventually, and the proceeds will be used to finance a planned addition to the university's law school. A portrait of the 86-year-old journalist and pioneer broadcaster, which will one day hang in the Lowell Thomas Law Center, was unveiled Monday night. Mr. Thomas jokingly referred to it as a portrait of Boris Karloff.

title: Gerulaitis Edges Fillol
description: MONTE CARLO, April 11 (Reuters) Vitas Gerulaitis narrowly survived his firstround match against Jaime Fillol in a $175,000 World Championship Tennis tournament today. Gerulaitis won, 46, 63, 64, after three times being within a point of trailing 53 in the third set.

title: Ali, Spinks Sign for 2d Bout Sept. 15
description: NEW ORLEANS. April 11 (AP)Leon Spinks and Muhammad All signed today to fight again for the title on Sept. 15. They were obviously elated over the prospect of additional wealth.

title: News Summary
description: Israeli forces began withdrawing from part of southern Lebanon in the first move toward compliance with a United Nations Security Council call for complete withdrawal. The Israelis withdrew up to several miles from seven villages and were replaced by contingents of United Nations peacekeeping troops. The Israeli pullback was carried out without much ceremony and despite continuing skepticism in Israel that the United Nations force can prevent the return of the Palestine Liberation Organization. title: Passover: Special Food Of the Sephardim; Passover: Special Food of the Sephardim; Recipes for Passover; Turkish Charoset; Salmon in Rhubarb And Tomato Sauce; Spinach Pudding (Fritada de espinaca); 2 pounds fresh spinach; Matzoh Meat Pie (Megina); Leek Croquettes (Keftes de Prasa); Passover Nut Brittle (Ahashoo); Mark PodwaI
description: IF IT IS true that you don't have to be Jewish to eat. chopped liver, gefilte fish or matzoh balls, the converse I is equally true  you don't have to eat any of those foods to be Jewish. As a matter of fact, these dishes, which are the traditional favorites of the Ashkenazi Jews who emigrated from Eastern Europe, are rarely, it ever, served in the homes of the Sephardic Jews who originated in Spain and Portugal and who left during the Inquisition to settle in Holland, North Africa, the Balkans and the Middle East. At present, it is estimated that there are between 100,000 and 150,000 Sephardim in the United States, 50,000 of whom are in the New York area.

title: Columbials Left $12 Million Gift
description: A stockbroker who cut Columbia Uni versify out of his will in 1934 because he believed there were radicals on the faculty has left the university $7 million. His widow, a former chorus girl, has left it $5 million. Together, the bequests make up the second largest in Columbia's history.

title: Unanimity in Far West: Cut U.S. Spending Now
description: There is a remarkable unanimity in the business community of the Far West on the best way to tackle inflation, bolster the international value of the dollar and at the same time alleviate many of the nation's other eco- nomic problems. The message on those subjects from the region's nine states, which constitute about onesixth of the American economy, is unequivocal: cut Federal spending to achieve a declining budget deficit and start the process promptly, not in 1980 or later.

The Juilliard Quartet, for instance, was founded in 1945 and, of its original members, only its first violinist, Robert Mann, has endured.

description: In the beginning there was black and white television. Then color. Then large screen projection TV. Does it end there? Not on your one life to live.

description: The trustee for the bankrupt W. T. Grant company has filed a $10 billion suit against 22 former officers and directors of the retail chain, the Grant Foundation. the Connecticut Bank and Trust Company and I the Home Insurance Company. Judgments are being sought against Grant's former directors in amounts ranging from $100 million to $800 million.

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albums and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets: singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.

title: HOUSE PANEL BACKS PLAN TO REORGANIZE JOB AGENCY
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (A(P)The House Government Operations Committee today endorsed President Carter's plan to reorganize the Federal machinery for enforcing equal employment laws.

title: KOCH PROPOSES PLAN ON CITYOWNED FLATS
description: The Koch administration yesterday proposed a $70millionayear plan to deal with two of New York City's major problemsupgrading the sharply growing number of slumarea apartment buildings falling into city ownership and providing more career job opportunities for the poor.

title: House Science Panel Votes Reactor Funds
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)The House Science Committee today rejected President Carter's plans for killing the advanced nuclear breeder reactor project planned for a site on the Clinch River in Tennessee.

title: U.S. Gives Up Plans to Expand Use of Beaches at Breezy Point
description: The National Park Service said yesterday that it was abandoning plans to increase the peak summer use of beaches in Breezy Point, Queens, from 90,000 people a day to 200,000.

title: Budget Renovations: Investing in Space
description: ONE LIVES in a fashionable part of midtown. The other lives behind City Hall on a block lined with warehouses. One looks out her window at the Museum of Modern Art's sculpture Barden the other watches tugboats huffing up the Hudson. One owns a coop, the other has a loft. Locations notwithstanding, when it comes to redoing an apartment, both believe in budgets and the virtues of moving walls.

title: Carey to Offer a Plan for Westway Plus Transit Aid
description: Governor Carey said yesterday that he would offer Mayor Koch in about week an enticing plan for going ahead with the Westway project that would include extensive sums that we have not seen before for upgrading the city's masstransit system.

title: Stage: Goldberg's Family Business
description: DICK GOLDBERG's Family Business, which opened last night at the Astor Place Theater, is in the mode of naturalistic drama that  in spite of the onslaught of Peter Brook, Richard Foreman and their colleagues  remains constant on the American stage. The handsome, foursquare setting by lion Jensen of a middleclass Jewish home in Boston, the colloquial speech of the characters, the realistic emphases of the director, John Stix, all reinforce the idea of the theater as a slice of life.

title: Design Notebook
description: PASSING through Las Vegas is Route 91, the archetype of the commercial strip, the phenomenon at its purest and its most intense. We believe a carefeil documentation and analysis of its physical form is as important to architects and urbanists today as were the studies of medieval Europe and ancient Rome and Greece to earlier generations.

title: Washington & Business
description: WASHINGTONIn the litany of business complaints about Washington nothing excites more passion than the rising costs of complying with government regulations.

title: Reporter's Notebook: In Panama, A Subdued Sense of Helplessness
description: PANAMA, April 12The live broadcast of the debate in the United States Senate on the Panama Canal treaties sounds unreal here. While the Senate deals with Panama as it might any other security threat, a tiny country with a population and an economy smaller than those of Queens listens as its destiny is decided by others.

title: Wildlife Protection: A MatterofPerspective
description: NEW HAVEN, April 11The effort to protect endangered wildlife, popular in the cases of national symbols such as the bald eagle or spectacular beasts such as the bison, is coming under increasing challenge.

title: Promotion Campaignfor   NorthKorean Leader's Son Abruptly Ended
description: TOKYO, April I2As North Korea prepares to celebrate its most important annual holiday, the birthday of President Kim II Sung on April 15, diplomatic and intelligence analysts are debating the significance of a sudden end to the campaign promoting his eldest son.

title: A New Berkowitz Hearing Begins
description: In the same makeshift courtroom at Kings County Psychiatric Center where last October he heard himself pronounced fit to stand trial for murder, David R. Berkowitz listened attentively yesterday as a second competency hearing got under way.

title: Kurtenbach and Assistant Dismissed by Canucks
description: VANCOUVER, April 12 (AP)The Vrncouver Canucks began restructuring their National Hockey League team today by dismissing Coach Orland Kurtenbach and an assistant. Arnie Brown. General Manager Jake Milford said the coaches would not have their contracts renewed when they expire this summer.

title: Citing a Serious Problem at Post, Guild Postpones a Strike at News

That phone's been disconnected, he told the scared 15yearold girl who had just given him a bogus number. Nobody gets mad here, nobody yells, but we stay until we get the truth.

Brown, from Setauket, L.I., had three goals in the third period for the Scarlet Knights, who improved their wonlost record to 22. The Panthers are 23.

Also survived by three brothers, Alex Gelberg, Ferenc Gergely and Janos Gergely. Services Friday 10AM at Nassau North Chapels 55 North Station Plaza (opp.R.R. Sta.) Great Neck. LI.

title: Home Improvement

As a result, many homeowners are  for the first time in some casesinvestigating the measures that can be taken to cure this problem and prevent it from happening again.

description: DETROIT, April 12As several hundred bystanders chanted get the Nazis out! court and police officers today evicted the Detroit National Socialist Movement from its storefront heaquarters on the city's southwest side.

description: WASHINGTON, April 12President Carter succumbed to a case of spring fever this afterncon and broke his White House routine to take a relaxed, shirtsleeved stroll among the blossoming Japanese cherry trees that line the Tidal Basin.

description: The Senate Select Committee on Intelligence recommended yesterday that the National Security Agency, one of the main Government intelligence organizations, be given a formal role in the selection of private institutions and scientist; for Federal research grants in cryplography and cryptanalysis.

description: Ten years after the National Commission on Civil Disorders admonished the press to hire more blacks and to improve its coverage of minorities, twothirds of the nation's newspapers still have no minority employees. Four percent of the reporters and editors on daily newspapers are members of minority groups, as against 1 percent in 1968.

Angela Lansbury is now Anna Leonowens, Michael Kermoyan has been elevated from prime minister to Kingand the accent is very much on the I.

title: SENATE UNIT ASKS NO CUT IN SOCIAL SECURITY TAXES
description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (UPI)The Senate Budget Committee voted 8 to 6 today, to recommend that Congress not reduce Social Security taxes in the next fiscal year.

title: Letters
description: It was all too easy to empathize with Sylvia Simmons's complaint about the quality of American manufactured goods [Nothing Works Anymore, March 23]. All of us are familiar to the point of contempt with refrigerators that won't refrigerate, washers that refuse to agitate and all sorts of smaller tools and appliances that disintegrate in the hand.

description: WASHINGTON, April 12The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Joseph A. Califano Jr., announced a series of Government actions today to help control what he called the precipitous and corrosive rise in the cost of medical care in America.
