description: The Senate is now debating the Panama Canal Treaty, which is the second of two treaties dealing with the canal, with a vote scheduled next Tuesday.

title: 5 Bankers  Are Indicted in Fraud, Including Director Reported Dead
description: Five officials of the defunct American Bank and Trust Company have been indicted in Manhattan on charges of having misappropriated millions of dollars in bank funds and Irvine falsified business records to conceal illegal transactions.

title: Moret Taken To Hospital
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., April 12 (AP)Roger Morel who threatened to leave the Texas Rangers last week, stood trancelike for at least 45 minutes in the locker roomholding a shower shoe in his extended handbefore tonight's game with Detroit.

title: Vance Is Off to Africa and Soviet
description: WASHINGTON, April 12Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance left tonight on a long mission to southern Africa and the Soviet Union that Administration officials expected to produce no more than modest results in both crucial areas.

title: Gabriel Back With Rams And Former Coach Allen
description: LOS ANGELES, April 12 (AP)Roman Gabriel and George Allen, his former Los Angeles coach, were reunited today when it was announced that the quarterback had s;gned a contract with the Rams.

title: Recital: Brendel's Schubert
description: ALFRED BRENDEL, like Maurizio Pollini, has become a cult pianist, and last night his Carnegie Hall audience overflowed on to the stage, To many of his younger colleagues, and to many of the younger generation of critics, it is he more than anybody else who wears the mantle of. Artur Schnabel as the great exponent of the Viennese classicsMozart, Beethovn, Schubert.

title: OTC Looks to Bettors To Battle Surcharge
description: New York City's 250,000 offtrack horseplayers may soon be invited to do something most of them have been wanting to do for years: sign a petition against the surcharge on offtrack payoffs.

title: Council Bill Would Require Truth in Restaurant Menus
description: A bill requiring New York City restaurants to abide by strict truthinmenu regulations will be introduced in the City Council next Tuesday by Councilwoman Carol Greitzer, head of the Consumer Affairs Committee.

title: I.B.M.'s Earnings Up by 2.8% in Quarter; Burroughs Reports 18% Advance in Profits
description: The International Business Machines Corporation, the world's largest computer maker, yesterday reported a gain of just. 2.8 percent in firstquarter profils, the smallest quarterly increase in three and a half years.

title: Irene Cornell Named Recipient Of Two Awards From Press Club
description: Irene Cornell, a WCBSRadio reporter, was named yesterday as the recipient of two New York Press Club 1978 awards, making her the first person in the 25year history of the awards to win twice in the same year.

title: Bears Trade Chambers to Bucs For 79 FirstRound Draft Choice
description: Wally Chambers, an outstanding defensive lineman for the Chicago Bears until sidelined by a knee injury, was traded yesterday to the Tampa Bay Buccaneers for a firstround draft Choice in 1979 and a lesser player to be named later.

title: News Summary
description: International

title: Article 4 -- No Title
Sons and Fathers
description: How silent men are about their fear of other men! How strangely silent they are about their fathers! Talking tc most men today about their fathers Is like asking Telemachus about his father, Odysseus (who abandoned him for 20 years of Homeric adventure), like asking a son about an absent and overwhelming and overromanticized figure. Too many sons actually believe Freud's Oedipal formulation, believe that they wished to kill their own fathersnever the opposite. If you ask a man about his childhood, he often says: Oh, you want me to tell you about my mother! When men talk about their fathers in public, it is usually to praise them. Sons, like daughters, have lower emotional expectations of fathers than of mothers. Children often remember liking fathers more, unconsciously excusing their absences, their emotional distance, or their physical violence and being automatically grateful for the slightest paternal approval or attention. Very few sons remember being fondled, held or kissed by fathers on daily basis. Fewer admit of being humiliated, belittled or rejected. We are unused to attributing responsibility to men for how children grow up. Our outrage is reserved for the facts of maternal child abuse. We find it easier to deny, explain away, or at least understand paternal child abuse, or emotional and physical abandonment. As I looked for the positive aspects of the fatherson relationship, I discovered the same tragedy of lost opportunity that characterizes most motherdaughter relationships. How sad that men base an entire civilization on the principle of male legal ownership of children, and then never really get to know their sons or daughters well and never participate, for whatever reason, in daily, intimate fathering. protectionenough to give up their mothers. To please fathers, sons obey the incest taboo; sons dissociate themselves from maternal traits; sons deny their shameful dependency on maternal nurturance. Sons rebel against motherrule and submit, mindlessly, to fatherrule. More, they blame mothers for whatever guilt or anguish they feel about this. I began to perceive the many displacements of sons wounded by fathers: away from stronger men, away from envied and feared men, away from fathers, and onto weaker men, children and women. Men name mothers and other women when they talk about feeling castrated. It is women, men tell us, who are bitchy, belittling, dangerous and demanding. Not other men. Never their fathers.

title: Family Money
description: WITH shortterm interest rates on the rise, the nation's thrift institutions savings banks and savings and loan associations  are losing deposits. Savers in search of higher yields are taking their money elsewhere.

title: Personal Beauty
description: NOTHING strikes fear in a fatty's heart faster than the coming of spring. Warm weather means shedding layers of camouflage  allowing the world to see how overweight you really are. It you have tried every diet in print, you may still have one shot left: hypnosis.

title: Deaths
description: ABELDora (Friedsell), mother of Reuben, David and Sidney; motherInlaw of Marion and Edith; grandmother of Richard, Elizabeth, and Andrew: oreatgrandmother of Laura, Sarah, and Heather.

title: Justin J. O'Brien, at 82, Served In Paulist Fathers for 60 Years
description: The Rev. Justin J. O'Brien, a Paulist father, died yesterday in his sleep In the rectory of St. Paul the Apostle Church, 415 West 59th Street. He was 82 years old.

title: $55.6 MILLION BY FALL TO HELP SOUTH BRONX IS PLEDGED BY U.S.
description: The Carter Administration pledged yesterday to spend $55.6 million between now and Sept. 30 to help New York City rehabilitate the depressed South Brome part of the Bronx below Fordham Road, signaling the start of a sevenyear effort to reverse the trend of joblessness and deterioration that has blighted a third of the borough.

title: F.B.I. INDICTMENTS ANGER GROUP OF FORMER AGENTS
description: SAVANNAH, Ga. April 2 (AP)The president of a group of former Federal Bureau of investigation agents says his group will ask that an investigation he conducted to identify any officials in the Justice Department who were aware of illegal F.B.I. activities that led to the indictment of three former officials of the bureau. Frank L. Price, president of the Society of Former Special Agents, called the indictments politically inspired and said the society would insist that an early, full and unrestricted investigation be conducted to ascertain the identities of all higher authorities in the Department of Justice and other branches of government who had knowledge and approved of F.B.I. investigative procedures.

title: 8 Restaurants Listed as Violators Of New York City's Health Code
description: The New York City Health Department yesterday cited eight restaurants for health code violations and two others that had their final inspections. The businesses were listed as follows:

description: SYRACUSE, April 12 (AP)Consumed with grief, Depra Porpiglio had to be helped as she walked down the church aisle behind the coffin of her husband, Frank, one of four firemen who were buried here today.

description: WASHINGTON, April 12  Senator Jacob K. Javits expressed the belief today that a $600 million wage increase for New York City's municipal employees would be acceptable to Congress, which will soon be debating further Federal loan assistance to the city.

description: MURCHIEWilfred E., April 11, 1978. Beloved father of Lilla Guba and Polly Murchie. Grandfather of John, Stephen and Peter. Funeral private.

description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)The chairman of the House Banking Committee asked six major banks today to explain why they had extended almost $1 billion in credit to Chile since Augusto Pinochet seized power in 1973.

description: TRENTON. April 12Hartz Mountain Industries plan.; for a shopping, residential and commercial complex on 714 acres in the Hackensack Meadowlands hit a snag today when the state refused an immediate ruling on a proposed land exchange crucial to the development and insiead ordered a detailed environmental impact statement for the project.

description: COLUMBUS, OhioThere are two kinds of people in this citythose on the west side of the Olentangy River who can get the Qube, and those on the other side who cannot. As time goes on, this could make an increasing difference in how the two halves live.

description: BONN, April 12Chancellor Helmut Schmidt has made clear his feeling that relations between the United States and West Germany have come under heavy stress, but at the same time he says he welcomes President Carter's decision to defer production of neutron weapons.

title: Chianti Area Talks of Wine, The Weather and Terrorism
description: SAN CASCIANO, Italy, April 8At the Jolly Cafe in the hamlet of Mercatale, in Tuscany, the talk is about the price of wine (too low to make a profit) and the weather (too cold for the season). Rome is far away. But political terrorism, which is keeping the country paralyzed, is of concern even here.

title: U. OF NORTH CAROLINA FIGHTS FOR U.S. FUNDS

They were attemping to resolve differences that led to the announced cutoff of Federal funds over the university's failure to produce a satisfactory plan for further desegregation of its 16 campuses around the state.

title: Backgammon:
description: The North Shore Backgammon Club in Carle Place is a focal point for backgammon events on Long Island. Steve Kurzbaum, the club's director, runs tournaments every night of the week except Monday. On the last weekend in March, the club held, for the benefit of the Human Resources Center, a nonstop marathon playing session for a group of players. The object was to see who could last the longest. After 50 hours and 356 games, the three remaining players decided to call it ouits.

title: Cosmos Fullback To Be Suspended
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., April 12Bobby Smith, the right fullback of the Cosmos, will be suspended for 10 days without pay by Phil Woosman, the commissioner of the Ncrth American Soccer League.

Redford and others would appear in the state on his behalf as the campaign began attracting more man the usual complement of celebrities. Henry A. Kissinger will be in the state on May 16 for a $250aperson dinner in Short Hills for the Republican incumbent, Senator Clifford P. Case. Jeffrey Bell, Mr. Case's opponent in the June 6 primary, will gel help from Representative Jack Kemp, the conservative New York Congressman and former professional quarterback, on May 7 at a $100aplate dinner in Millburn.

Now boardedup stores line the business streets and apartment houses are burned out and abandoned.

description: Textron Inc., a conglomerate based in Providence, R.I., announced yesterday it would purchase up to 266,934 shares of the Allied Chemical Corporation's common stock from time to time on the open market beginning April 14.

description: PASADENA, Calif., April 12A large man with tousled hair raced from car to car near Ambassador College here one recent evening, placing packets of papers on the windshields of each automobile.

description: Three brothers accused of operating houses of prostitution in the Times Square area received prison sentences on Federal charges that they had harbored illegal aliens who worked as postitutes.

description: Anthony Ostroff, a poet, teacher and antiwar activist, died Sunday in Pacific City, Ore., after a heart attack that followed a hanggliding flight over the Oregon coast. Mr. Ostroff was 54 years old and lived in Portland.

description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 12 (AP)J.O. Tobin, returning to the track where he scored his greatest triumph last year, won the $53,100 feature race of opening day of the Hollywood Park meeting.

description: HANOVER, West Germany, April 12 (AP)The roof of a huge exhibition hail here collapsed today, slightly injuring one person. The police said scores of other occupants were unhurt.

title: Reporter's Notebook: In Panama, A Subdued Sense of Helplessness
description: PANAMA, April 12The live broadcast of the debate in the United States Senate on the Panama Canal treaties sounds unreal here. While the Senate deals with Panama as it might any other security threat, a tiny country with a population and an economy smaller than those of Queens listens as its destiny is decided by others.

title: Bridge:
description: The defending champions were unexpectedly dethroned last weekend In the national intercollegiates at Madison, Wis.

title: DeConcini Reluctantly Agrees To Soften New Treaty Proposal
description: WAS111NGTON. April 12Under pressure from the Carter Administration, Senator Dennis DeConcini agreed reluctantly today to soften a controversial reservation that he was proposing to the second Panama Canal treaty.

title: Give a Good Drug Law a Chance
description: Pharmacists are doing their best to undermine the new New York State law aimed at cutting drug costs to consumers. The law requires them to fill prescriptions with relatively inexpensive drugs unless the loctor specifies that a higherpriced brand name must be used. The inexpensive substitutes are to be chosen from a list of drugs, validated by the Federal Food and Drug Administration, that are therapeutically equivalent. This approach offers hope for providing safe and effective medicines at reasonable cost.

title: ExDeak Executive Fined $5.000
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 12 (AP)A former vice president of Deak & Company of California, a subsidiary of the world's largest foreigncurrency dealer, has been fined $5,000 for failing to file reports involving $11 million in cash transactions. Willie Beusch, 45 years old, of Millbrae, also secretarymanager of the San Francisco office of the parent firm, Deak & Company with headquarters in New York, was sentenced Tuesday by United States District Court Judge Robert Schnacke.

title: Thought That We Hate
description: WASHINGTONThe proposal by American Nazis to march through the predominantly Jewish town of Skokie, Ill., has aroused an intense debate about the limits of freedom in this country. Some 4,000 members of the American Civil Liberties Union resigned because A.C.L.U. lawyers argued against a ban on the march, and many more apparently let their memberships run out.

title: NATO PLANCE EXERCISE TO STRESS REALISM
description: By DREW MIDDLETON Special tone New York TimesLANGLEY AIR FORCE BASE, Va.Fighter and bomber aircraft from seven Air Force bases will land at Cold Lake, Alberta, on April 22 to open a new phase in the realistic training of American, Canadian and other NATO aircrews for war in Europe

title: Toyota and Nissan Raise Output And Exports to Record Levels
description: TOKYO, April 12 (AP)The Toyota, Motor Company and the Nissan Motor Company reported today that motor vehicle production and exports in the fiscal year ended March 31 rose to record levels.

title: Jim Walter Plan to Fix Homes Is Seen as a Victory

description: Assemblymanelect Charles R. Johnson yesterday credited a coalition of Liberal Party, labor and black groups, as well as the support of his predecessor, for his upset victory on the Liberal line in Tuesday's special election in the West Bronx.

title: Israel Tells of Soldier's Death
description: TEL AVIV, April 12The Israeli military command here. reported today that Palestinian guerrillas killed an Israeli corporal last night in the western sector of southern Lebanon that was occupied by Israel last month. The announcement said that the soldier had died in a clash, but it gave no further details.

title: EMERGENCY FARM AID IS REJECTED BY HOUSE IN A CARTER VICTORY
description: WASHINGTON April 12The House soundly defeated the controversial emergency farm aid bill today, relieving President Carter of having to veto it as he had promised.

title: Claire Raphael Reis Dies at 89; Leader in New York Cultural Life
description: Claire Raphael Reis, who had been active in musical circles for more than 50 years, during which she was an energetic champion of contemporary composers, died at her home in New York Tuesday, after a heart attack. She was 89 years old, and the widow of Arthur M. Reis, president of Robert Reis & Company, the men's clothing manufacturer founded by his father and now headed by Arthur M. Reis Jr. Mr. Reis Sr. died in 1947.

title: Questions for an Anniversary
description: How long has it been since the President proposed his national energy plan?

title: Holtzman Sharp, but Yanks Lose
description: MILWAUKEE, April 12For Ken Holtzman, it was like giving a party and having no one attend. For Rich Gossage, it was another loss in the battle of freeagent millionaires. And for the Yankees, the 53 loss to the Brewers today was their fourth in five names.

title: Bomb in Ankara Iniures 20
description: ANKARA, Turkey, April 12 (Reuters)At least 20 people, most of them students, were injured today when a bomb exploded near the Academy of Engineering and Architecture at a place where leftist students gather every morning to enter school under police escort. Six of the injured were in serious condition. Two previous bomb attacks on leftist students have killed five people.

title: News Summary
description: United Nations official who is from the Soviet Union and refused to return to Moscow this week is expected to leave his post, Moscow is pressing for the ouster of Arkady N. Shevchenko, the Under Secretary General who refused the Soviet order, declaring he had political differences with his Government. His position has always been filled by a Soviet citizen having Moscow's approval, and it is considered certain he could not remain if the Soviet Union objected. [Page A1, Column 4.]

title: Article 6 -- No Title
GARDENING
description: NOW THAT the crocuses and daffodils have bloomed and the forsythia is ready to burst, the gardeners sap is rising and they are eager to get started. City dwellers have to make do with whatever kind of growing space they can find. If a patch of ground is available anywhere, chances are some eager soul will try to fill it.

title: Ship Export Orders In Japan Fell in 1977
description: TOKYO, April 12 (UPI)Export orders for new ships during 1977 fell to the lowest level since 1963, the Japan Ship Exporters Association has announced.

title: If Music Be the Food of Detente, Play On, Pro Arte
description: THE arms negotiations may be deadlocked and the Middle East may be a mess, but one small corner of dtente has been doing fine in the last few weeks.

title: Living With Art In the Round
description: TODAY the round room, with its huge Leger mural, belongs to Harold Diamond, a private art dealer, and his wife, Hester, a former social worker who is now an interior designer. Their country house spreads expansively east and west of its 30foot round living room with a dance floor in the middle, overlooking the round swimming pool, prefabricated guest house, boccie court and 12 acres.

title: Council Bill Would Require Truth in Restaurant Menus
description: A bill requiring New York City restaurants to abide by strict truthinmenu regulations will be introduced in the City Council next Tuesday by Councilwoman Carol Greitzer, held of the Consumer Affairs Committee.

title: Israeli Radio and TV Journalists End Their Strike After 11 Days
description: TEL AVIV, April 12 (AP)Israel's radio and television journalists returned to work today, ending a strike that shut down most of the country's broadcasting for 11 days.

title: Floor Cloths: Keeping Design Underfoot
description: CANVAS floor cloths  the painted floors you can roll up and take with you  are a dream for anyone who loves the paintedfloor look but lives in rented or composite-tile-floored space.

title: For an Envious BBC
description: WASHINGTONWhy is it that most of public television's primetime blockbusters come from England? Isn't public TV in this country capable of Upstairs, Downstairs, Civilisation, The Ascent of Man, The Forsyts Saga and War and Peace? It isn't, In fact, public television here Is so decentralized, its structure so Byzantine, its decisionmaking so anarchistic and its funds so meager, it's a miracle you see anything at all when you tune in to your local Public Broadcasting System station.

title: TYCO LABORATORIES INCREASES STAKE IN CUTLERHAMMER
description: Tyco Laboratories, a small New Hampshire electronics ccmpany, told the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday that it had Increased its financial stake in CutlerHammer Inc., a leading Wisconsin electronics producer, to nearly $33 million, or 15 percent of the outstanding stock.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: DUTCH TREAT Tomorrow is a proud occasion for the ConcertParty chamber music series, with its traditional mingling by the artists and the audience over refreshments. At 8:30 P.M. the group presents its first event in a new, permanent homeSt. Peter's Church, 54th Street and Lexington Avenue. Admission is $6 at the door or by reservation, at PL 24907.

title: Soybean Futures Hit 2Week High
description: Speculation that Brazil will further reduce its soybean crop estimate lifted soybean futures yesterday to their highest levels in two weeks, The Associated Press reported.

title: New Jersey Briefs
description: The jury in the murder trial in Hackensack of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich was dismissed for the day yesterday without hearing any testimony after the prosecution requested in Judge William J. Arnold's chambers that a statement Dr. Jascalevich gave to the Bergen County Prosecutor on Nov. 11, 1966, be allowed as evidence.

title: Barred Brooklyn College Professor Conducts a Rally of 100 on Campus
description: A Brooklyn College instructor who was suspended and barred from the college because he allegedly led minoritygroup students in a chairthrowing fracas, yesterday defied the college's orders by addressing 100 of his supporters on the campus.

title: SOVIET PRESSES U.N. TO OUST SHEVCHENKO
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 12The Soviet Union is pressing for the dismissal of Arkady N. Shevchenko, the Under Secretary General who refused to return home to Moscow this week and declared he had political differences with his Government.

title: ExF.A.A. Head Assails Agency On New Landing System Choice
description: A former head of the Federal Aviation Administration has assailed the agency's role in the acrimonious BritishAmerican contest over choice of a new guidance system for aircraft landings.

title: Projects Are Listed In South Bronx Plan
description: Following are the projects for which Federal aid will be provided in the initial stage of the Southern Bronx rehabilitation program.

title: Advertising
description: How many companies spending hundreds of thousands of dollars distributing centsoff coupons through the mail consider the pure advertising impact of the coupons? And should they?

title: The Return of The Boomer
description: For three seasons, Ron Blomberg was the New York Yankees most invisible player. He did not put on a uniform last season following April surgery on his left knee. The year before, he appeared in only one game following April surgery on his right shoulder And in 1975 he did not play after June when he damaged his shoulder. I was on the team but off the team, he says now. The batboys were using my locker. The last two months of last season he seldom went to Yankee Stadium, then he joined the Chicago White Sox as a free agent for $600,000 over four years. This season he already has hit two homers as a 29yearold designated hitter. And today The Boomer will have locker at Yankee Stadium when the White Sox arrive for the World Series champions home opener. I never played in the new Yankee Stadium, he says. I'm looking forward to that. He's also looking forward to saying hello to some of his former Yankee teammatesbut not all.

title: Sports Today
description: Yankeees vs. Chicago White Sox. at Yankee Stadium, River Avenue and 161st Street. the Bronx, 2 P.U. (TelevisionChannel 11.2 P.M.) (RadioWINS, 2 P.M.)

title: Notes on People
description: CARMEN Franco, the only daughter of Francisco Franco, the Spanish dictator, denied in Madrid yesterday that she had tried to smuggle out of Spain 31 gold and jewelencrusted medals that had been given to her father. Mrs. Franco, who is the Marquesa de Villaverde but uses her maiden name, was stopped at the airport last Friday by customs agents who confiscated the medals. She flew on to Switzerland. Back home, she called a press conference to explain that she had been unaware that she needed a permit to take the medals out of Spain. What hurts me most, she said, is that people could think me stupid enough to take jewels out of the country in a purse for fraudulent reasons, to make money by selling them. She said she had intended to have the medals set in a Swiss clock for her mother, as a remembrance of her father. Asked about rumors that her father hid a fortune outside Spain, the 52-year-old marquesa replied, Unfortunately, we do not have as much fortune as they say, either outside or inside

title: Sound
description: THERE ARE TIMES when I want to be alone with Linda Ronstadt, but that is difficult to arrange. Once a wellappointed home included a music room or library where one could retire behind sturdy oak doors. But in this age of astronomleal rents, cardboard walls and doorless togetherness, many of us have to rely on earphones as a means to musical privacy.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Q&A
description: Q. Because some bricks were loose around the front windows of our house, we had a bricklayer replace them. He apparently used a mortar that had more sand than cement, and these mortar joints are now much lighter than the old ones, even though the repair is now over six months old. Would you advise us to have the repair done over, or is there a way to color the new mortar joints so they will match the old ones? L. F., Washington.

title: George Cory, 55, Wrote Music For San Francisco Hit Song
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 12 (AP)George C. Cory, who wrote the music for I Left My Heart in San Francisco, was found dead yesterday of a drug overdose in his apartment here. He was 55 years old.

title: TAX QUESTION DIVIDES VOTERS IN CALIFORNIA
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 12With a new poll showing voters closely divided on the issue, a campaign with a planned budget of more than $1 million is taking shape aimed at defeating an initiative that would make a major cut in local governments taxing authority.

title: Deaths
description: SMITHMildred C. of Smithtown NV on April 12.1978. Former officer with UL Company of Melville NY. Beloved wife of C. Otis Smith. Devoted aunt of Joan I. Hoffmann of Hauppauge NY, and Barbara A. Mandel of Westboro Mass. Dear mother of Edna and John Gall of Upper Brookville NY. Cousin to Edna and Charles Schumacher of Seachif NY. Service Friday 8PM at R.B. Hawkins Funeral Home Inc. 17 ManorRd. Smithtown NY (visiting Thursday and Friday 25 and 710PM). Funeral (prayers) leaves funeral home Saturday 9:ISAM to entombment at Lutheran Cemetery. Middle Village NY. Flowers or memorials to The Heart Furid requested.

title: GASOLINE STOCKS DROP BY 2.5 MILLION BARRELS
description: Gascline for the week ended April 17 fell by 2.5 million barrels to 263.2 from the previous week's 265.7 million barrels, the American Institute reported yesterday. The drop reflected an increase in automobile travel brought on by the warm weather.

title: Grenade Wounds Chad Official
description: NDJAMENA, Chad, April 12 (Reuters)Chad's Minister of Justice, Lieut. Mahamoud Abderaman, was wounded in the face in a grenade attack at his home last night. Officials said he had been injured only slightly. Lieutenant Abderaman, a member of Chad's Supreme MiIitary Council, was with friends nn terrace when the grenade was thrown by unidentified assailants.

description: THE Eliot Feld Ballet offered four works from its repertory Tuesday night at the Plymouth Theater. All were exquisitely constructed and beautifully danced. Mr. Feld is certainly a remarkable craftsman.

description: WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)  The United States has decided to relocate the 112 residents of Bikini Island against their will because of radioactivity on the Pacific Ocean atoll, the site of hydrogen bomb tests 20 to 33 years ago.

description: MINEOLA, L.I., April 12The Nassau County Commissioner of Social Services said today that his staff had confirmed charges that some social workers in New York City were being paid to refer former mental patients to adult homes in Long Beach.

description: MONTE CARLO, April 12 (AP)Topseeded Guillermo Vilas of Argentina ousted Jan Kodes of Czechoslovakia 64, 75, in the first round of the $175,000 Monte Carlo tennis tournament today.

McAdoo, wide open most of the. night, scored 41 points, making 17 of his 25 shots from the field.

description: WASHINGTON, April 12Joan Mon dale, known around Washington as Joan of Arts demonstrated to small, invited audience today that, she ever has to look for work, she'd made a fine docenta lecturerguide in museums.

description: WASHINGTON, April 12In an effort to break a new deadlock over natural gas pricing, energy conferees of the House and Senate continued today to negotiate intensively at the White House with Secretary of Energy James R. Schlesinger and for a time with President Carter.

The Kidde company received about $101.3 million from McClean to close the deal. Th's was in addition to about $9.6 million previously paid to Kidde in interest and deposit payments.

description: The people on the picket line at the NENA community health centerdoctors and clerical workers, nurses and techniclanssometimes feel as if they were on strike against themselves.

title: Man Freed After I.B.M. Theft
description: BOULDER, Colo., April 12 (AP)A former employee at an International Business Machines Corporation research laboratory here has been freed on $3,000 personal recognizance bond pending the filing of forfmal charges in connection with the alleged theft of 15 highly confidential I.B.M. documents. Authorities said John Salvati, 24, accompanied by his attorney, turned himself in to the police last weekend and was arraigned in Boulder District Court on Monday. Police said the documents had been offered for sale but have been recovered.

title: Hers
description: ONE afternoon last week I stepped onto the No. 3 bus on Fifth Avenue at 66th Street. The seat near the door directly opposite the driver was empty, and I dropped into it. At 59th Street the bus began to fill up. People crowded on, and, as I daydreamed, my eyes watched hand after hand drop 50 cents in the box and move beyond my fixed gaze. At 53d Street it seemed to me I saw someone get on without making the automatic gesture toward the coin box. As I looked up, an old man was settling himself heavily in the seat diagonally opposite me. I thought: He's old, can't stand on his feet while he's getting his money out. Yet I recall thinking this with surprise, as the man was expensively dressed in a soft dark coat and hat and bore himself with the jowly, wellfed dignity of a bank manager.

title: NEW RHODESIAN CABINET IS COMPLETED BY SMITH
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 12 (Reuters)Prime Minister Ian D. Smith today named nine white ministers who will serve with nine black nationalists in Rhodesia's interim Government.

title: Mets Drop Two Flies and 42 Game

But even without that pressure, the New York Mets' outfield defenses crumbled on two strategic occasions and thereby staked the Chicago Cubs to their second straight 42 victory.

title: Miss Navratilova Nears Evert Duel
description: HILTON HEAD ISLAND, S.C., April 12One year ago the diamond might have been out of place alongside her other baubles, bangles and beads. But now the jewel necklace seems to symbolize the new star status of Martina Navratilova.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
Catching Runaways Before the Street Gets Them
description: With a calculated display of exasperation, John Faugno, a plainclothesman, slapped the telephone into its cradle. That phone's been disconnected, he told the scared 15yearold girl who had just given him a bogus number. Nobody gets mad here, nobody yells, but we stay until we get the truth.

title: Reading Arbatov's Mind
description: WASHINGTON, April 12At the SovietAmerican summit of 1972, Georgi Arbatovnow the Kremlin's leading Americanologistwrote some of the toasts for the Russians, and I wrote some of the toasts for the Americans. Here is what I imagine is going through Georgi's head right now:

title: Sporting Goods Chain Plans to Revive Abercrombie
description: Abercrombie & Fitch, the sporting goods store, which closed last November after an 85year existence may reappear in a new form and under new ownership this fall in Beverly Hills, Calif., and year later as a new store in midtown Manhattan.

title: Senator DeConcini's Palm
description: It must be fun being Dennis DeConcini these days. He holds the Panama Canal treaties in the palm of his hand, as one commentator put it. Heady stuff for a freshman Senator from Arizona, Mr. DeConcini is the author of Senate reservations to the Panama Canal treaties, asserting the perpetual right of the United States to intervene in Panama with military force if Washington ever judges that necessary to keep the waterway open.

title: Stage: A Cavalier Tale
description: THE CLASSIC THEATER, now holding forth at the Loretto Playhouse, 20 Bleecker Street, has come up with a raritya world premiere of a play 300 years old. Thereby hangs a tale, and a complicated one it is, too. Suffice to know that when the play, The Country Gentleman, was written by Robert Howard in 1669, the Second Duke of Buckingham saw a chance of discomfiting a political opponent by inserting a scene or two to insult him. His opponent, William Coventry, a highranking bureaucrat, got wind of the coming insult and, though no swordsman, challenged the Duke to a duel. The trouble was that the Duke had just killed man In a duel, and the death of another would not go down well with Charles II or with the people, either.

title: Suspect in Burglary Sentenced
description: INDIANAPOLIS, April 12 (UPI)A man charged in the $800,000 burglary of the home of Marjorie Jackson the slain heir? was sentenced yesterday to four years in prison on an unrelated charge of confinement. Criminal Court Judge William Dougherty sentenced Douglas Green, 21 years old, in connection with the kidnapping and attempted rape of a gogo dancer. The confinement law partly succeeds Indiana's previous law on kidnapping.

title: Kook to Phase Out Cotton Trade
description: MEMPHIS, April 12 (AP)Cook Industries, once a leader among the world's largest commodity exporting concerns, says it is getting out of cotton merchandisingthe basis of its business since it was founded 59 years ago.

title: Two Creative Talents  Dovetailed
description: LET's be frank: Mary Ann and Sam Scherr have not yet managed to get it all together. There are the myriad paintings shrouded in brown wrapping paper lined up against the walls of the living room, bedrooms and halls in their newly acquired Upper East Side apartment.

title: STRICTER STANDARD URGED FOR AWARDING ATLANTIC OIL LEASES
description: WASHINGTON, April 12  The staff of the Federal Trade Commission recommended today that the Secretary of Interior apply a stricter standard to recent bids for offshore oil leases in the Atlantic made by several major oil companics. The staff said it may be appropriate to reject some of the high bids because of insufficient competition in the oil industry on the East Coast.

title: Net of Westinghouse Up 16% for Quarter On 8.2% Sales Rise
description: Operations of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation in the initial quarter this year resulted in a 16.1 percent increase in profits on a sales gain of 8.19 percent, both records. All three operating groups, as well as the broadcasting and credit subsidiaries, achieved higher earnings, Robert E. Kirby, its chairman, said in yesterday's report.

title: Goaltending Still a Dilemma As Rangers Meet Sabres
description: The New York Rangers are a team with no clear direction, and the goaltending controversy surrounding their first appearance in the playoffs in three seasons is only the most obvious symptom.

title: Jazz: Jenkins Ensemble

It was played by the Leroy Jenkins Ensemble, a quartet made up of four unusually virtuosic musiciansMr. Jenkins on violin, George Lewis playing trombone and synthesizer, Anthony Davis on piano and Andrew Cyrille on drums.

title: Pop: Crystal Gayle, Moving Out of Country
description: THERE were a number of things to admire about Crystal Gayle's opening performance Tuesday light at the Botton Line. But compared to her best recently recorded songs, it was still a disappointing set.

title: Fed Chief Asks Delay in Tax Cut To Trim Deficit
description: WASHINGTON, April 12The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board urged today that the Administration's taxcut package be delayed or scaled down to shave next year's budget deficit.

title: Stage: Vincent Price As Oscar Wilde
description: WHO breaks a butterfly upon a wheel? wrote Pope, and for Oscar Wilde, a century and half later, the answer turned out to be the Victorian law courts.

title: Arab Force Steps In as Fighting Intensifies in Beirut
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 12Fighting between Lebanese rightwing Christian neighborhoods and leftist areas intensified here today, and the Syriandominated Arab peacekeeping force intervened with heavy weapons in an attempt to halt the hostilities.

title: Bottle Deposit Bill Signed
description: HARTFORD, April 12 (AP)Praising an idea whose time has come, Gov. Ella T. Grasso today signed legislation that will require deposits on soda and beer containers sold in Connecticut starting in January 1980.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: Asarco Inc. and the Bendix Corporation said late yesterday they had reached agreement for Asarcoonce known as the American Smelting and Refining Companyto sell 3.8 million of its shares to Bendix.

title: Conferees Would Require Carter  To Set Standards on U.S. Judges
description: WASHINGTON, April 13  SenateHouse conferees agreed today that President Carter should he required to set standards and guidelines for the selection of more than 140 new Federal judges that Congress plans to authorize later this year.

title: Labor Chiefs Skeptical of Carter WageRestraint Plan
description: Some of the nation's most influential labor leaders are expressing deep skepticism toward President Carter's latest plea for sacrifices on the wage front.

title: Play About Joyce in Paris Is at Stageworks
description: James Joyce Is Leaving Paris, play by Tom Gallacher, an Irish playwright, opens tonight at 8 and can he seen for the next two weekends at the New York Stageworks, 15 West 18th Street.

title: Screen: Growing Up German at the Modern:Tyranny and Growth
description: THE title character in both of these films is a dark-haired youth of 15, slim, silent, finished with school, seemingly not very bright, and suffering under a father's tyrannical rule.In "Paule Paulander," the father is a pig farmer; in "The Main Actor," the proprietor of a rural junkyard. Reinhard Hauff, the director, in other words, seems to have scoured West Germany for unlovely settings, not picturesque villages and valleys or bright and bustling towns. The country is flat, the people coarse, the color photography dim. In short, we are mired in the "realism" into which young film makers are apt to stumble while seeking a shortcut to Parnassus. Or in this instance to the Museum of Modern Art, where the two films will be shown at 6 P.M. today and at 8:30 P.M. tomorrow as part of the New Directors/New Films series.The climax of "Paule Paulander" occurs when an outbreak of swine fevernot to be confused with swine fluruins the father and brings on an emotional breakdown. The youth knocks away the rifle that his father is threatening him with and clubs him briskly with a shovel. Leaving the stubborn old fellow moaning on a pile of dying piglets, he abandons the acres that his family has tilled for 300 years to seek his fortunes in the big city.In "The Main Actor" the youth is recruited to play the starring role in a film within a film, an unsparing quasi-documentary look into the horrors of rural life, as seen from the perspective of the film's director, who seems to be a socialist of some sort and it is hinted, a homosexual.Tired of dismantling old Volkswagens, encouraged by his father's kicks and cuffs, this youth abandons the junkyard. He follows the director to what may be the same city, possibly Cologne, where he turns out to be no happier.Mr. Hauff has made the mistake of stating his intentions in a credo distributed at the screening of the films instead of fulfilling them on the screen. For artistic ideological reasons that he fails to make entirely clear in the statement, he has amateur actors in "Paule Paulander" and professionals in "The Main Actor." Both perform at about the same level of plodding inadequacy, with the edge, perhaps, going to the amateurs.

title: Justice Dept. Files Brief Backing Grand Central s Landmark Status
description: WASHINGTON, April 13The Department of Justice has urged the United States Supreme Cour to uphold New York City's landmarkpreservation law and thus har construction of a 53story office tower above Grand Central Terminal.

title: I.C.C. Chairman Doubtful Conrail Will Make Profit
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)  The chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission said today that Conrail's revenue estimates are overly optimistic brio added that he did not believe the rail carrier could turn a profit within the next five years.

title: JAPAN'S STEEL FOUND HURTING U.S. MAKERS
description: WASHINGTON, April 13In a finding of major significance in restraining American imports of steal, the United Stales International Trade Commission agreed unanimously today that carbon steel plate from Japan injures domestic producers.

title: Management

title: Press Institute Names Chairman

Officials are especially concerned that the radioactive material could contaminate the Ganges.

title: Notes on People
description: Derek Humphry, the London newspaperman who described in a book how he helped his terminally ill wife, Jean, end her life, said yesterday that he would be questioned next week by the police about his actions. Mr. Humphry, who in Jean's Way admitted that he gave his wife a lethal mixture of painkillers and sleeping pills after they both agreed she could no longerbear the pain of her inoperable cancer, could face a 14year prison sentence if convicted of euthanasia. I knew what I wrote was a confession, he said yesterday, If the Director of Public Prosecutions decides to prosecute, I shall plead guilty and ask the court for mercy. My plea would be one of mitigation and justification.

title: Towns Employing Innovative Steps To Cut Vandalism in Their Schools

title: Opening of Atlantic City Casino Facing Week's Delay, to May 26

This would delay the opening by a week, from May 19 to May 26.

Suitably, the event is entitled Marathon '78.

title: They Would Hurt the Public Schools
description: Giving tax credits to all families with children in college, regardless of need, would be bad enough. But a still greater threat lurks in the companion proposal to give tax credits for private elementary and secondary school tuition as well. Here the issue is nothing less than the future of public education. Such rebates would put the Federal Government in the business of encouraging parents to withdraw their children from the public schools. It would turn back the clock more than a century to a time when the poor schools were the only instruments of public education.

The thought occurred to this listener, not for the first time, on Wednesday night at Alice Tully Hall, where the Guarneri and Vermeer string quartets joined forces to perform this miraculous creation by a 16yearold composer.

title: Allied Chemical Doubles Earnings On Strong Oil and Fiber Business
description: Sharp increases in earnings from international oil and gas operations and a strong performance in its fibers business offset poor results of chemicals and other divisions of the Allied Chemical Corporation, according to yesterday's firstquarter report.

title: Holocaust Study Aids and Spinoffs
description: Not long ago, a ninthgrade class in Miami Beach was discussing the holocaustthe term by which the annihilation of six million European Jews in World War II has come to be known. Suddenly and with visible anger, one student blurted out, Where was God? The teacher stared off for a moment and asked softly, Where was man?

title: Books of The Times
description: PERDIDO in Spanish means lost. There is a Spanish song, La Nina Perdida, about a father looking for his lost child. There is a Monte Perdido in northeast Spain, one of the peaks of the Pyrenees, which the French call Mont Perdu, perdu meaning hidden concealed, obscured. Both words derive from the Latin perdere, to lose. See perdition, a state of final spiritual ruin, loss of the soul. Perdido is also where Susanna Howard lives in Jill Robinson's remarkable, heartbreaking novel: a Hollywood mansion in which everything is hidden, concealed, obscured. It is from this Perdido that Susanna, the child, will set out to look for her lost father. When she comes back, Perdido will be gone.

title: Film: Witty 'Joseph Andrews':Misadventures Galore
description: HAVING had such a smashing financial and critical success with his screen version of Henry Fielding's "Tom Jones." Tony Richardson was, one suspects, a bit reluctant to make a film based on "Joseph Andrews," Fielding's second greatest novel, a work that originated as Fielding's answer to what he saw as the hypocritical pieties of Samuel Richardson's "Pamela."In the mid-18th century, "Pamela" enjoyed the kind of success that today is had only by the work of Victoria Holt and those other Gothic novelists who continue to sell the idea that virtue is its own reward, often accompanied by a large fortune.In "Pamela," which was published in 1740, Richardson told the inspiring tale of Pamela Andrews, a serving girl who tenaciously held onto her virginity until her employer, the rich Mr. Booby, came across with a marriage license. Several years later, Mr. Fielding turned this story wildly upside down in a novel about Pamela's brother, Joseph, a serving boy who is as innocent as his sister but not nearly as calculating, who must fight off all sorts of lewd advances and whose triumph is one of true virtue rather than greed.Not wanting to appear to be repeating himself, Mr. Richardson waited nearly 15 years before turning to "Joseph Andrews." The funny, stylish, infinitely cheerful film, which opens today at the Festival and other theaters, is well worth the wait. "Joseph Andrews" is not a sequel to "Tom Jones" in any literal sense, though it shares with that earlier movie its 18th-century period and its exuberant high spirits.In addition "Joseph Andrews" contains more great (and more greatly funny) character performances than any film I've seen in years. It's one of the few movies around now that truly lifts the spirits, not only because it is so good-humored but also because the humor is laced with so much wit and wisdom.Peter Firth, who was nominated for an Oscar for his performance in "Equus," is marvelously earnest and innocent in the title role. He is the calm eye that is the center of a hurricane of extraordinary characters who tumble around him in all sorts of adventures involving mistaken identities, coincidental meetings on country lanes, stolen babies, lust, true love, gypsies, highwaymen, evil squires, urban corruption and rural pleasures.Foremost in this cast of characters is the single-mindedly lecherous Lady Booby, Joseph's employer, played by Ann-Margret at the top of her magnificent form, a lady who goes after the unsuspecting Joseph with something of the purpose of a warped missionary. She looks great and she is enchantingly funny, but so is almost everyone else in a cast so big I really don't know where to begin, since I'm sure to leave out someone important. It's one of those films in which even the smaller roles are as beautifully and as memorably done as the larger ones.There is, for example, John Gielgud's brief and hilarious appearance as the doctor who is called in at one point to minister to Joseph's wounds but who examines, instead, a corpse, taking some while to realize that the patient is, in fact, "no more." There are also Beryl Reid as Mrs. Slipslop, Lady Booby's servant, a battered, flirtatious crone with the manners of a truck driver attempting to be dainty; the incomparable Michael Hordern as Parson Adams, the well-meaning clergyman who defends Joseph at all costs; Natalie Ogle, as Fanny, Joseph's virginal true love, and Karen Dotrice, who is most comic as the prissy and successful Pamela Andrews.There is in the entire film just one shot that I wish someone had cut out, but I won't describe it since it may go unnoticed by others. The film is otherwise an almost perfect blending of beauty, romance and adventure, of landscapes too lovely to believe alternating with the kind of gritty period detail that prompts one character to say of a street jam in the resort city of Batti, "The only things that move here are the bowels of the horses."Mr. Richardson, as the director, and Allan Scott and Chris Bryant, who wrote the screenplay, based on Mr. Richardson's screen story, have captured the particular, very special charm of Mr. Fielding's narrative style, which never holds onto one adventure for a second too long. Thus Joseph's escapades open, one out of the other, with the effortlessness of a dream. Even the flashbacks, which we see through what seems to be a fish-eye lens, move the narrative forward at a breakneck pace that never falters.The movie year, which has not been great so far, looks a great deal richer today.

description: IN just five and a half months since the restaurant's opening, Jim McMullen, on Third Avenue between 76th and 77th Streets, has managed to become one of the swingingest and most popular pubrestaurants on the East Side. No reservations are taken, and standbys are four deep at the bar almost any time of day, from Sunday brunch to Saturday night supper. Owned by the former proprietors of Harper, just two blocks away, McMullen's is handsomely, if simply gotten up, with naturalbrick walls and a dcor that is basically modern, but gets a few Art Nouveau accents via etched patterns on mirrors and a few carved wood panels in the dining room.

title: Broadway
description: MORTON GOTTLIEB has sold the movie rights to Tribute for $1 million. A pittance, you saythe movie right, 10 Annie were sold for $9.5 million. (AcWally, Mike Nichols and Lewis Allen were asking $10 million for Annie, but hard times set in, and they settled for $500,000 less.) Mr. Gottlieb's deal, however, is a preproduction deal; Tribute does not open on Broadway until June 1. It is in Boston now, and on May 1 it goes into Toronto, hut this does not count. Therefore, the $1 million that Paramount paid this week for the movie rights$350,000 down, with the rest spread over three years. plus 10 percent of the gross above the cost of the movieis apparently the most ever paid for a show before Broadway. Last Friday, filming was completed on Same Time, Next Year, which Mr. Gottlieb produced on Broadway and coproduced in Hollywood. He had sold those rights for $1 million, too, hut only after it opened on Broadway.

title: Film: Rare Chaplin, 'A Woman of Paris':A Gilded Cage
description: MARIE ST. CLAIR, the heroine of Charles Chaplin's radiantly beautiful "A Woman of Paris," is, at the film's beginning, locked inside her bedroom by her foul-tempered father. That same evening, after she has escaped by climbing out a window, her father reverses the trick and locks her out. A year later, fate has whisked Marie away from her simple country home and off to "the magic city of Paris, where fortune is fickle and a woman gambles with life." There, she is imprisoned, once again, but this time the cage is gilded and then some: Marie has become the expensively kept mistress of a very rich, very dapper, eternally bemused man. Almost obscenely wealthy by now, Marie isn't always happy, but she wasn't always happy as a simple country girl, either. Fate, as Mr. Chaplin understands it, works in endlessly ironic and enormously touching ways.The wisdom of "A Woman of Paris," which was first released in 1923 but often feels as if it were made just yesterday, really does seem boundless; so do the affection and generosity with which Mr. Chaplin presents his characters. The film, described by an introductory note from Mr. Chaplin as "the first serious drama written and directed by myself," has nothing of the Little Tramp about it, although the director does appear in a tiny cameo role as a railway porter. Consequently, it was a commercial failure in its day. After that, it stayed out of circulation for more than 50 years, until Mr. Chaplin prepared a new score and allowed the film to be screened at the Museum of Modern Art two years ago. Since then, the film has had the reputation of a lost masterpiece, and it more than lives up to its renown.The tale of a pampered woman who learns the hard way to value simplicity and honesty may not seem like big news, but Mr. Chaplin used that premise to string together an uninterrupted series of perfect vignettes. One of the best of these involves Marie (Edna Purviance), her lover Pierre Revel (Adolphe Menjou) and some pearls he long ago bestowed upon his mistress. Marie defiantly tells Pierre that she is leaving him to marry her provincial sweetheart, because all she really wants from life are a few children and the love of a good man. To prove her point, she rips off the necklace and flings it out a window. But when she looks out to find a hobo discovering the jewels, she races into the street and grabs them back. She is followed by a little dog, which appears just long enough to suggest a certain side of Marie's nature and is never seen again.Although "A Woman of Paris," which opens today at the Cinema Studio, is a drama in many respects, it is at times extremely funny; Mr. Chaplin gets some wonderfully witty milage out of the incongruity of upper-class pretensions and the bestial side of anyone's nature. The film's most dazzling sustained sequence takes place in a posh restaurant, where Marie and Pierre dine elegantly on champagne and truffles. As a title explains, "Note: truffles rooted up from the soil by hogsa delicacy for pigs and gentlemen." The moment is wry, but not satirical, thanks both to Mr. Chaplin's complex sympathies and the enormously alluring performances of Miss Purviance and Mr. Menjou, Mr. Chaplin never forgets that the most effective way of sending up a life of ease involves exaggerating, not deflating, its sense of easiness.The stirring tableau that ends the film's Parisian segment ideally exemplifies Mr. Chaplin's care, compassion and economy. Marie, having re-encountered her country lover after she began putting on airs, commissioned him to paint her portrait in an elegant white gown. Instead, he chose to depict her in a simple, dark dress he remembered her wearing before.Long after the portrait is completed, Marie happens to be wearing the white outfit on a night that ends in tragedy, and destiny leads her to a spot directly beneath the dark portrait, where she weeps so honestly that an enemy is moved to spare her life. Nothing could be less melodramatic than the manner in which Mr. Chaplin presents this small epiphany. And nothing could be more rich with the eternal promise of redemption.

title: The Pop Life
description: THE ordinary pattern for a popmusic careerif the word ordinary can he applied at all where the unusual is commonplaceis for a slow build, a peak and a gradual fade, with flickers of comebacks always a possibility. Maria Muldaur, who will open the show tonight for David Bromberg at Avery Fisher Hall, has followed a rather different pattern,

title: Canadian Tax Quarrel Has the Opponents Vying In Offering Quebec Relief
description: OTTAWA, April 14A sharp quarrel over differing tax policies erupted today between the Canadian Government and the secessionist provincial government of Frenchspeaking Quebec, with the two jurisdictions apparently vying in offering relief to Quebec's consumers.

title: 6.000 Stranded at French Resort
description: PARIS, April 13 (UPI)About 6,000 people have been stranded in the Alpine ski resort of Valloire since last Sunday by a snowslide, the Paris daily Le Figaroreported today. The snow collapsed a restraining wall built on one side of the only road from the community of 923 residents and about 5,000 tourists.

title: Publishing: Award For New Poet, 54
description: THE Walt Whitman Award for poetry administered by the Academy of American Poets is given annually for a collection of poems by a poet not previously published in standard book form. It carries with it a cash prize of S1,000 and pun lication by a major publisher. It is obviously a way or recognizing a young poet and perhaps launching a new career. This year's winner is Karen Snow for her book Wonders to be published by Viking early next year.

title: Art: David Levine's Bouquet of Noses
description: THAT the art of caricature hasn't flourished in the United States as it has in Europe may have something to do with the absence of a clearcut social hierarchy the irritant that can cause so many cultural pearls. Moreover, it seems that the pursuit of happiness, though rich in humorous side effects of a literary kind, is not conducive to the kind of misanthropy that makes an Honor Daumier or even a Max Beerbohm.

title: House Leaders Hold Up Ethics Bill So They Can Seek More Support
description: WASHINGTON, April 13The House leadership today pulled back a bill regulating the ethics of public officials as opposition mounted against a provision limiting the outside income that could be earned by members of Congress.

description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)The two married sons of President Carter who live at the White House are plannine to move out.

title: Grain and Soybean Futures Drop Following Rejection of Farm Bill
description: CHICAGO, April 13 (AP)Grain and soybean futures were pared today as speculators liquidated contracts after House rejection of emergency farm legislation and before the release of a report on farmers planting intentions.

title: Maris Returns and Finally Hears Cheers at the Stadium
description: Roger Maris ended one e of the strangest exiles in baseball history yesterday when he came home to Yankee Stadium after 12 years, took a standing ovation from a public that once had scorned him and heard Mickey Mantie proclaim over the loudspeaker: We're the world champions again after 15 years.

description: BANKRUPTCY PROCEEDINGS

title: News Summary
description: A reservation restating the United States policy of nonintervention in Panama has been proposed by Democratic leaders for the second Panama Canal treaty, which will be voted on in the Senate on Tuesday. The move, announced by Senator Robert C. Byrd, the majority leader, is intended to counter the adverse reaction in Panama to a reservation added to the first treaty, guaranteeing the canal's neutrality, which was approved by the Senate on March 16. That reservation, sponsored by Senator Dennis DeConcini, Arizona Democrat asserts the right of the United States to send troops to Panama to keep the canal open or to eliminate interference with its operations. [Page A1, Column 6.]

title: Recordings Heard in Curare Trial
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., April 13With the jury excused today the judge and attorneys in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich strained to listen to scratchy and muffled recordings macle of the first statements Dr. Jascalevich gave to the Bergen County Prosecutor a dozen years ago after vials of curare were discovered in his locker at Riverdell Hospital

title: Sugar Ray Leonard Wins His 10th fro Bout in Row
description: LANDOVER, Md., April 13Sugar Ray Leonard, the darling of Maryland's boxing community, scored his 10th succesive professional victory tonight before a record Capital Centre boxing crowd of 15,272.

title: Protests Threatened In World Cup Golf
description: DUBLIN, Ireland, April 13 (AP)The world Cup golf tournament, scneuuieu for Waterville, Ireland, in July, may In moved to another location after threats of disruption if South Africa is allowed to take part.

title: Tunnel Vision, Too
description: So the 50cent transit fare has been saved again. But what about the transit system? Governor Carey and Harold L. Fisher, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority chairman, whom he appoints, have once againfocused on postponing a fare increase without a whisper about the reality of transit finances.

title: An Overdue Spring Day Arrives and Gets Its Due
description: The first day of spring is one thing and the first spring day is another.

title: Stage: Jack Heifner Offers Two OneAsters
description: THE NATURE of women in Jack Heifner's plays is to talk interminably and say hardly anything. In Vanities, it was three girls who talked their way out of high school, through college and into womanhood.

title: Webster, Noah (17581843) A Clearly Defined Reputation
description: Noah Webster spent a lifetime (17381843) taming disorders of vocabulary and anarchies of usage, and when his American Dictionary of the English Language came out just 150 years ago, he considered his struggle victorioushe had domesticated English.

title: Candy That Tastes Like A Hot Dog
description: New York's American League baseball season was half an inning old when Reginald Martinez Jackson walked to the plate carrying a mahoganybrown bolt of mountain ash. To some of the 41.667 witnesses it seemed he had never been away. but actually it was his first visit to this particular swatch of reaI estate since last Oct. 18, the night he took three swings with that bludgeon and won the championship of North Amcria for the Yankees by hitting three home runs.

title: ARGENTINE PRICESROSE 95% IN MARCH
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 13Argentina's efforts to contain the world's most acute inflation rate have suffered a setback with the announcement of a 9.5 percent rise in retail prices last month.

title: Earl Wild Teaming With Morton Gould
description: Two artists whose paths have crossed often over the years will appear together at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon at 3 with the American Symphony Orchestra during especially busy times in both their careers.

title: Forthright Rumanian With Independent Spirit
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 Nicolae Ceausescu, the President of Rumania, was a bit nettled today by some pointed questions from reporters about his Government's treatment of ethnic minorities and about some other human rights issues.

title: CITICORP SUING INTERBANK OVER TRAVELERS CHECKS
description: Citicorp has filed a lawsuit against the Interbank Card Association, which sponsors Master Charge credit cards, asserting that Interhank's plan to issue travelers checks would result in illegal domination of the market.

title: Screen: Medusa Without Perseus:Life on the Couch
description: "THE MEDUSA TOUCH," the English suspense melodrama that opens today at the Loews State 2 and other theaters, is about a man who goes to see a psychiatrist not because he thinks the world is too much for him, but because he thinks he's too much for the world. The fellow, who's named ???Morlar and is played gloomily by Richard Burton, possesses telekinetic powers to make those of the characters in "The Fury" look frail indeed. On the merest whim he can??? by simply willing it, cause a 747 to crash, ruin a m???oon-landing and shake a thousand-year-old Gothic cathedral to its corner???.The movie was directed by Jack Gold from a screenplay by John Briley and it's fuzzy on a number of key issues that possibly could have made it fun, had they been sharper. Morlar is neither an evil character nor is he pathetic in the manner of someone who has a terminal illness. We see him as if he had some sort of antisocial disease, which, coupled with his bad temper, makes him unpleasant to have around.Lino Ventura, the veteran French stars plays the detective called in to investigate a near-fatal attack on Morlar, and Lee Remick plays the psychiatrist who relates much of Morlar's life, which we see in flashbacks.Mr. Gold, who directed "The Bofors Gun" some years ago, displays a gift for comedy in some of the sequences, especially when we see how Morlar, as a 10-year-old, got rid of his mum and dad while picnicking on the white cliffs of Dover, but there's not a single really scary shock-effect in the entire film. Among the good actors who assist Mr. Burton, Mr. Ventura and Miss Remick, are Harry Andrews, Michael Hordern and Marie-Christine Barrault ("Cousin, Cousine"). A job is a job."The Medusa Touch," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), includes some vulgar language and, at the end, a not-very-convincing disaster.

title: ANDERSON CAMPAIGN AIDE DENIES STATEMENT ON JEWS
description: ALBANY. April 13George P. Berlinger, a former state official and now a fundraiser for the Republican gubernatorial crmpaign of Warren M. Anderson, the State Senate's majority leader, was quoted by a newspaper in Binghamton today as saying that New York has a Democratic governor because the ... Jews all vote for Democrats and that Jews deserve what's happening to them in the stock market.

title: Chaplin on the Couch
description: Comedy is going up on the screen and down on the couch tomorrow afternoon as the Dalton School. And because everybody knows that comedy is no laughing Patter, the psychoanalysts who organized this session have dispensed with their customary 50minute hour and are dealing with comedy's complexities in a fourhour symposium.

title: Brokers Indicted; Fraud Is Alleged Over Oil Futures
description: Ten commodity brokers have been indicted by State and Federal grand juries in connection with a scheme that allegedly created $27 million in fraudulent tax losses through the rigging of the market for crude oil futures.

title: Cable TV Getting Test as Watchdog
description: For 30 years, households have been watching television. Now comes switch: Television will be watching the house.

title: Truce Is Announced In Beirut as Syrians Halt Rocket Attacks
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 13 (AP)Syrian peacekeeping forces and Lebanese Christian rightists announced a ceasefire today after five days of fighting here in which more than 100 people were reported killed.

title: CITY LABOR UNIONS CRITICIZED BY TOIA
description: Philip L. Toia, New York City's Deputy Mayor for Finance, told 200 leaders of the city's financial community yesterday that the labor unions were holding the city hostage because of $700 million in loans that .the pension funds are to make by midMay.

title: Tuition Credits Fail Every Test
description: Some sort of college tuition aid is bound to be forced through Congress this year. Despite evidence that incomes have actually been rising faster than college costs, plaints of middleclass parents have moved a majority in Congress to action. President Carter has wisely threatened to veto any automatic tax credit that incluaes help for those who need it least. But his resistance alone is not enough. There is still time, though not much, to design legislation that aims the aid at those who need it most in a program that provides for continuing Congressional supervision.

title: Music: Margaret Price Sings at Carnegie Hall
description: WHEN Margaret Price, the Welsh soprano, made her New York recital debut at Hunter College six years ago, she sang a number of items off the beaten repertory path and made an extraordinarily favorable impression. This was not altogether surprising. since the splendor of her voice and skillful use of it were already known here through orchestral appearances.

title: Indonesia Nickel Project Reflects 2 Worlds.
description: SOROAKO, IndonesiaIt takes two hours by jet from Jakarta to reach Ujung Pandang, the capital of South Sulawesi, on the island once known as Celebes. An hour and a half later. flying in a propellerdriven plane over mountain jungles. the Gulf of Bone and more mountain jungles, a modern industrial romplex surges suddenly into view out of the nearly roadIess wilderness.

title: Illinois Education Board Criticizes Chicago School Desegregation Plan
description: CHICAGO, April 13The Illinois Board of Education warned Chicago today that its dayold voluntary school desegregation plan was not likely to he accepted unless the city added compulsory standby measures that could be used if voluntary efforts failed.

title: MORE CANCER CASES REPORTED TO TOWN
description: RUTHERFORD, April 13Twentyfour cases of leukemia and Hodgkin's disease and eight other cases of similar blood cancers have been diagnosed among residents here in the last five years, the State Health Department reported tonight at a town meeting.

title: French Designers Show A Talent for Partying, Too
description: PARIS, April 12  The French designers have developed a talent that has very little to do with hiking hemlines or tailoring leather  the art of giving lively parties. During the sevenday stint of the 197879 fall French prtporter showings, there were at least three fourstar parties given by French designers.

title: Music: M.I.T. Symphony
description: DISCIPLINE seems to be the hallmark of the playing of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Symphony Orchestra. It was evident in its two previous appearances here, and was an admirable element in its concert in Avery Fisher Hall on Wednesday night. Still under the direction of David Epstein, the ensemble performed smartly in a program that included Stravinsky's Scherzo a la Russe, Kurt Weill's Suite from the opera Silbersee and Berlioz's Harold in Italy.

title: Iranians to Plan Everest Ascent
description: TEHERAN, Iran, April 13 (Reuters)Iranian mountaineers say they plan to be the first foreigners to climb Mount Everest from the Chinese side next year. Gen. Mohammad Khakbiz head of Iran's Himalayan Federation, said at a news conference that 20 Iranian and 20 Chinese climbers planned a joint expedition. General Khakhiz said the Chinese side of the mountain was more difficult to climb than the Nepal side because it had more ice and was steeper.

title: At the Movies
description: ONE of the complications of making movies in India, Satyajit Ray. the subcontinent's preeminent film maker, was saying the other day, is that the country has 14 major languages and scores of minor ones. Subtitling doesn't work very well because the great majority of the population is illiterate, or close to it. As a result. Mr. Ray went on, films are seldom exhibited outside the area in which the language of the soundtrack is spoken.

title: ANTITREATY FEELING IS GROWING IN PANAMA
description: PANAMA, April 13The Panamanian Government is under mounting domestic pressure to reject the new canal treaties even if a facesaving way can be found to soften the impact of a Senate reservation allowing United States military intervention in Panama to keep open the waterway.

title: Howard Baldwin, Headed Advertising At The New Yorker
description: Howard Baldwin, a former advertising manager of The New Yorker magazine, died Wednesday evening at the Nathaniel Witherell Nursing Home in Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Baldwin. who had been ill with emphysema for several years, was 83 years old and lived at 5 Sunset Road in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: SOVIET SAID TO WEIGH CUBA RHODESIAN ROLE
description: MOSCOW, April 13Western diplomats here believe the Soviet Union is talking with Cuba and its African allies in Ethiopia and Angola about stepping up support for black Rhodesian guerrillas.

description: DALLAS, April 13In the popular imagination, this city is inhabited largely by stereotypes, nouveauriche cil and cattle barons who say things like waal and howdy. People here know that that's not Dallas 1978.

title: TIMOTHY CRONIN
description: Timothy Cronin, an international vice president of the Transport Workers Union, died Wednesday of a heart ailment at Flower and Fifth Avenue Hospitall in New York. He was 68 years old and lived in Monsey, N.Y.

title: Soviet and Iran Sign Gas Pipeline Accord
description: The Soviet Union and Iran have signed an agreement to construct 300mile pipeline that would transport natural gas from the Iranian town of Qom, south of Teheran, to the Caspian

description: RUTHERFORD, April 13Twentyfour cases of leukemia and Hodgkin's disease and eight other cases of similar blood cancers have been diagnosed among residents here in the last five years, the State Health Department reported tonight at a town meeting.

title: Paul McGrath, Actor, Dead at 74; Host of Radio's Inner Sanctum
description: Paul McGrath, a major actor on the American stage for many years and the grimvoiced host of the Inner Sanctum mysteries on radio in the 1940's and early 50's, died in his sleep in London yesterday, according to friends in New York. He was 74 years old this week and lived in New York.

title: Pennsylvania Turnpike Fees Rising
description: HARRISBURG, Pa., April 13 (UPI)The Pennsylvania Turnpike Commission chairman, Jack Greenblatt, says that toll increases averaging 20 percent will go into effect sometime this year, perhaps as soon as July 1. The average cost per mile will go from 1.9 cents to 2.4 cents under the increases approved by the commission.

title: House Backs Larger Carter Staff
description: WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)The House voted today to give President Carter the authority to increase his staff, but Republicans teased him about his campaign promises to whittle down the number of White House employees.

title: Kick On, Rockettes
description: One recent midnight when the Radio City Music Hall was scheduled to turn into a pumpkin, something miraculous happened. It was announced that the theater would remain aglow for the foreseeable future, its orchestra slowly ascending from the netherworld at every performance, the Rockettes rhythmically pointing their toes skyward.

title: New Prayer Book of Reform Jews Ranges From the Talmud to Mailer
description: The Reform Branch of Judaism has published a new prayerbook for the high holy days that will replace an 1894 version.

title: JACK NASH IS REELECTED AS AMEX'S VICE CHAIRMAN
description: Jack Nash, president of Oppenheimer IBC Company Inc., has been reelected vice chairman of the hoard of governors of the American Stock Exchange. Mr. Nash, who joined the Amex hoard in 1972, was named vice chairman last January.

title: RADIO LINK REGAINED VITH VOYAGER CRAFT
description: American space engineers reestablished radio contact with Voyager 2 yesterday, ending a week's blackout and reviving hopes for the success of the unmanned spacecraft on its way to Jupiter, Saturn and the outer solar system.

title: The Man In The Middle
description: VIENNAOn his recent precedentshattering trip to East Germanythe first official visit to that Stalinesque regime by the head of a West European democratic Government Austria's veteran Socialist Chancellor Bruno Kreisky was practicing that special brand of dtente that he believes to he the surest road to peaceful coexistence: a sensational billiondollar trade deal with the German Communists, including provision for joint ventures in North Africa.

title: Harlem's Logan Hospital Struggles On
description: A sign on the wall of the emergency room at Arthur C. Logan Memorial Hospital bears a line that advises patients: Minimum ... charge before examination. But the space for an amount was covered long ago with scraps of white paper.

title: Rail Freight Traffic Rises
description: WASHINGTON, April 13The Association of American Railroads reported today that freight traffic on United States railroads during the latest week totaled an estimated 17 pillion tonmiles, up 14.2 percent from the yearearlier level, which included the Good Friday holiday, Carloadings in the sanie period totaled 463,205 cars, up 9.2 percent from last year. The American Trucking Associations Inc., reported intercity truck tonnage rose 9.1 percent from a year ago.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Dow Corning Price Rise
description: The Dow Corning Corporation will raise prices of some silicone surfactants by from 5 to 11 percent, effective April 24. The surfactants are used in the manufacture of urethane foam, which is widely used in insulation and in furniture and pillows.

title: Jazz: Lee Horwin Sings
description: JACK KLEINSINGER, whose Highlights in Jazz concerts in the last six years have been essentially jam sessions involving miscellaneous musicians brought together by Mr. Kleinsinger, tried a slightly different tack on Wednesday evening at New York University's Loeb Auditorium. He presented a cabaret singer, Lee Horwin, and the Eddie Hazel! Trio, a group led by a singer and guitarist who work in relatively subtle shades of jazz.

title: 40 Antiques Dealers To Show in Armonk
description: Forty antiques dealers, from New York, New Jersey, Connecticut, Massachusetts and Pennsylvania, will display their merchandise this weekend at the North Castle Historical Society's first antiques show, at the Byram Hills High School on Route 22 in Armonk, N.Y.

title: Carmine Galente, Alleged Mob Chief, Wins Parole Ruling
description: Carmine Galante, a reputed organizedcrime leader, has won a parole decision that will free him from prison in 60 days.
