description: A man and woman were shot fatally yesterday as they left a Bronx social club, apparently the accidental victims of a gunman who fired wildly after his intended victim grabbed his wrist.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, APRIL 14, 1978

title: 500 Years of Oxford U. Press
description: To celebrate 500 years of artful survival, the Oxford University Press has assembled a seemingly unbounded volume of exhibits and is giving the Pierpont Morgan Library at 29 East 36th Street the privilege of a first showing.

title: Pilots Who Hit Hanoi Meet to Remember and Forget
description: RAMSTEIN AIR BASE, West Germany  At 8 P.M. they agreed that Vietnam had been a dumb war. It was a onehandbehindyourback, moronic war fought all wrong. Too many good guys were gone after meeting the golden BB. Enough anger, disillusionment and confusion to asphyxiate a generation. Agreed? Agreed, quietly.

title: Jackson Belt Brings Yanks Home With a 4to2 Victory
description: Reggie Jackson's threerun home run in the first inning and an answering shower of Reggie candy bars from the Yankee Stadium stands made everything that followed anticlimactic yesterday as the Yankees trimmed the unappreciative Chicago White Sox. 12, in their home opener.

title: Italian Culture Week Begins Sunday
description: The week beginning Sunday and ending April 22 has been designated as the third annual Italian Culture Week in New York, with activities planned in all boroughs.

title: Three Bank Holding Units Report Higher Earnings for First Quarter
description: The Chemical New York Corperation the parent company of Chemical Bank, said yesterday that its operating earnings in the first quarter were 13.8 percent above those of a year earlier.

description: City to Fill Prescriptions

description: The 250 fans from the New York area who were shut out of Super Bowl tickets after buying a tour to New Orleans last January learned yesterday that they would get back some of their money for the wasted trip.

title: Art People
description: FORGET about the Midas touch, said a museum man the other day, chortling over the nearly $9 million that the Tutankhamen show has so far racked up in its museum tour of the United States. Everything that Tut touches turns to green cash.

title: STOCKS GAIN WIDELY IN HEAVY TURNOVER AS DOW RISES BY 8.92
description: Stocks surged higher across a broad front yesterday in the heaviest trading of the year with a strong rally that caught Wail Street by surprise.

title: Administration Would End Limit Of 160 Acres for Irrigated Farms
description: WASHINGTON, April 13The Carter Administration today proposed scrapping the current limitation of 160 acres a person on the ownership of federally irrigated land and instead permitting a family to own and lease up to 960 acres.

title: DelBello Says Grand Jury Found No Violation on Campaign Funds
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 13The Westchester County Executive, Alfred B. DelBello, said today that a Federal grand jury had found no violation of Federal criminal law after a fivemonth investigation of his 1973 election campaign fundraising.

title: Schmidt Declares He Hasn't Wavered On Neutron Position
description: BONN, April 13 (Reuters)West Germany told Washington six months ago that it was ready to accept the stationing of neutron weapons on its territory, Chancellor Helmut Schmidt said in Parliament today.

description: A cup of steaming coffee will soon replace the mustachioed smoker who used to puff away on a billboard 80 feet above Times Square:

title: JAPAN'S STEEL FOUND HURTING U.S. MAKERS
description: WASHINGTON, April 13In a finding of major significance in restraining American import of steel, the United States International Trade Commission agreed unanimously today that carbon steel plate from Japan injures domestic producers.

title: Vance Is Said to Get Agreement Of Rhodesia Guerrillas on Talks
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, April 13Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance was reported tonight to have received assurances that Rhodesian guerrilla leaders would accept the British  American proposal for convening a conference of all parties in an effort to avoid a fullscale war.

title: A U.S. Education Deputy Hails Montclair Schools
description: MONTCLAIR, April 13A Federal education official said today that he was very impressed with the school integration efforts here.

title: New York Countdown: To Move the Clock
description: A fatal deadline for New York City's financial rescue Is only days away but the principal actors in the drama are in repose. In a show of excessive confidence, arrogance, they are letting April slide by without any real bargaining over the next contracts for city employees. As a result, they are also losing the month for any effective lobbying in Washington for the desired longterm loan guarantees upon which economic revitalization seems to depend. Sympathetic members Congress warn that they will need all of May and June to act on a loanguarantee measure but that their work cannot begin until a labor contract of tolerable dimensions has been written.

title: DOLLAR UP IN EUROPE, TOKYO AND NEW YORK
description: The dollar rebounded yesterday in foreignexchange trading in New York, Europe and Asia, rising sharply against all major currencies, The Associated Press reported.

title: Joe Venuti Still Going Strong at 81
description: In his eighth decade, Joe Venuti, the jazz violinist, is bubbling with enthusiasm about a new musical citadel that he is storming. The familiar jazz side of Mr. Venuti can be heard at Michael's Pub this weekend and through May 6 (A $10 minimum; call PL 82272). But when he is not playing at nightclubs, Mr. Venuti is mingling with symphony musicians now. In fact, they follow him into his jazz performances.

title: The Times to Publish Business Day, A New Section, Starting May 17
description: The New York Times announced yesterday that beginning May 17 it would publish Business Day, a new, expanded and redesigned business, financial and economic sect on.

title: Kickback Inquiry Leads To Indictment of Buyer On Tax Evasion Charges
description: An 18month investigation into kickback schemes in the chewing gum, liquor and cosmetic industries resulted yesterday in what United States Attorney David G. Trager termed the initial indictment from a Federal grand jury in Brooklyn.

title: Illinois Abortion Law Rejected
description: CHICAGO, April 13 (Reuters)  A Federal appellate court has struck down an Illinois law that prohibits abortion without the consent of a woman's parents or spouse. The court also overturned an informed consent provision requiring that women seeking an aboriton must he told of the physical appearance of the fetus.

title: Jerrold Bryce, Investment Banker, Retired Chairman of Clark, Dodge
description: T. Jerrold Bryce, retired chairman of Clark, Dodge & Company, investment bankers, died April 3. He was 86 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: Around the Nation
description: COLUMBUS, Ohio, April 13 (UPI) State officials agreed today to advance the Cleveland school system nine months of basic state aid and thus enable the bankrupt schools to remain open through June.

title: APPROVAL OF CARTER DROPS TO 46% IN POLL
description: President Carter's public approval rating has dropped below 50 percent and, while he is still held in higher esteem than Congress as a whole, the gap between his standing and that of Congress, though still sizable, continues to narrow, according to the latest quarterly poll by The New York Times and CBS News.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
Rescue Strategy for the Music Hall Involves Many Ifs Over 16 Years
description: Behind yesterday's announcement that the show will go on at the deficitridden Radio City Music Hall was an elaborate rescue plan that even its authors reveal is shaky.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a typographical error, the wrong location was given yesterday for Oshman's Sporting Goods Inc., which has acquired the name and trademarks of Abercrombie. & Fitch. Oshman's has its main offices in Houston, not Boston.

title: Business and the Tax Revolt in California
description: SAN FRANCISCOThe chances of success for a substantial cut this year in California's high property taxes, in response to a citizens revolt, seem to he diminishing as the June 6 balloting on an enabling proposition approaches and the ?? smess community is quietly applauding. l'hat was the hope exby business leaders here in recent interviews, and it appears to be sus tamed in a public opinion poll this week. The poll, which showed a narrowing margin of approval among those who have already made up their minds on the centroversial JarvisGann initiative to slash the state's property taxes by some $7 billion a year and place restrictions on further advances.

title: Advertising
description: The top management is made up of a former marine and quarter miler with a business degree from New York University; a design man who speaks good Japanese, and a former Latin teacher who is also a doctoral candidate in Restoration English.

title: Ford Raises Dividend 10 Cents to 90 Cents
description: DETROIT, April 13 (AP)The Ford Motor Company said today its directors raised the quarterly dividend on common stock by 12 percent to 90 cents a share.

title: Joyous greeting for Yanks From Fans and Politicians
description: As Mayor Koch put it during the pregame ceremonies: My fellow Yankee fans, happiness is a world championship.

title: 2 U.S. Prosecutors Get Awards
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 13 (AP)Two prosecutors who conducted the case against former State Senator Henry Cianfrani of Pennsylvania have been named recipients of awards for outstanding performance by the Justice Department. Alan Lieberman, chief of the public corruption unit of the United States Attorney's office here, will receive the Attorney General's award for distinguished service, the Justice Department's second highest commendation. Gregory Magarity, the trial lawyer in the Cianfrani case, will receive the director's award for sustained superior service, the department said yesterday. The awards are to be presented in Washington next Tuesday.

title: Art: Flowers That Never Fade
description: WHAT could be more appropriate to the coming of spring in New York than an exhibition of flower paintings? Few observers would be found to cheer an exhibition of snow scenes say, in the midst of the February blizzards, but an April exhibition of flower paintings seems happy and right. Pleasure begets pleasure, and to the colorful array of blossoms now spilling out of the flower shops and supermarkets onto the sidewalk displays an exhibition of paintings on this subject seems a natural and felicitous accompaniment.

title: Jersey Youth Is Stabbed to Death During Fight Among TeenAgers
description: FRANKLIN TOWNSHIP, N.J., April 11 (AP)Alfonso Zimmerman, 17 yeas old, was stabbed to death during a fight among teenagers yesterday in this Somerset County community, authorities said.

title: U.S. Now Calls Inquiry Inadequate In New York Youth Job Program
description: WASHINGTON, April 13Secretary of Labor Ray Marshall conceded today that his department had inadequately investigated charges of abuse of the department's summer youth employment program in New York City, including its contracts with B'Nai Torah Institute.

title: Canadian Student Wins $50,000 Novel Prize
description: A 23yearold graduate student at the University of Alberta in Canada, Aritha Van Herk, has won the Seal Books First Novel Award of $50,000, it was announced yesterday at the Montreal Book Fair, now in progress. The winning manuscript was chosen from among 500 submitted. Miss Van Herk wrote the novel while working as a bush cook for a geological exploration crew high in the mountains of the Yukon.

title: Crafts Sale to Aid Dutchess S.P.C.A.
description: benefit the Dutchess County Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, will he held tomorrow and Sunday, indoors at the Dutchess County Fairgrounds on Route 9, Rhinebeck, N.Y.

title: PROSECUTOR TO DROP CORRUPTION CHARGES
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 13Criticizing overly stringent proof required in popolice corruption cases, District Attorney Carl A. Vergari of Westchester County said today that he would move tomorrow to dismiss several threeyearold indictments against five present or former Mount Vernon police officers.

title: About RealEstate
description: JERSEY CITY  The elements are in place for the emergence of a new colony of Soviet Jewish immigrants in downtown Jersey City, in the Van Vorst renewal area. The reconstruction of a string of empty brownstones on Barrow Street, for years a neighborhood blight, is to begin within weeks.

title: Opinion Survey Based On 1,417 Interviews
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News survey is based on telephone interviews conducted from April 3 to April 7 with 1,417 adult men and women around the United States,

title: Joffrey Ballet: Heptagon Premiere
description: FAITH and doubt are the subjects of Heptagon, a ballet by Oscar Araiz, which had its world premiere with the Joffrey Ballet Wednesday night at the City Center 55th Street Dance Theater.

title: New Face: Mary Lou Rosato
description: AT one point in Mother Courage, Bertolt Brecht's pragmatic battlefield merchant leans against her sagging canteen wagon and declares wearily, It's no life on the road, year in and year out; you go to wrack and ruin. Mary Lou Rosato, who plays Mother Courage in The Acting Company's production in repertory with King Lear at the American Place Theater through April 23, hears personal echoes when she speaks the line these days.

title: Scenic Route Is Series of Tableaux
A Reformed Approach to Welfare Reform
description: As the outsider candidate, Jimmy Carter promised to clean up one Washington mess after another. Disdaining stepbystep improvements, he pressed for a national energy plan, a major tax reform, a systematic revision of the Civil Service, a thoroughgoing overhaul of the welfare mess. Now, having learned in other areas now bruising structural reform efforts can be, the President seems to want to head off a Congressional fight over welfare. To judge from the conciliatory tone of Secretary Califano's recent testimony before the Senate Human Resources Committee, the Administration apoears ready to back off from its overarching welfare proposal for a more modest beginning. Given the bleak out look for passage of the original Carter bill, this midcourse correction in legislative strategy is prudent and responsible.

description: Here is a summary of the main lines of a short story in Barry Hannah's collection, Airships:

title: Economic Slump Puts Pressure On Panama to Accept Canal Pacts
description: PANAMA, April 14A deep economic recession, aggravated by years of uncertainty over the canal issue, has now become the main source of pressure on the Panamanian Government to accept the new canal treaties despite the reservation attached to them by the United States Senate.

title: Soviet Georgians Take to Streets To Save Their State Language
description: MOSCOW, April 14A Soviet plan to drop Georgian as the official language of the proudly nationalistic Caucasion republic of Georgia sparked demonstrations today in the street of the capital city of Tbilisi.

title: Full Employment, With a Different Focus
description: WASHINGTONSince the Employment Act of 1946, the United States has defined overall economic objectives in strikingly national terms. The HumphreyHawkins legislation, which calls for a reduction in the national unemployment rate to 4 percent by 19S3, continues this perspective.

title: Japanese Railroads Struck
description: TOKYO, April 14 (AP)Railroad workers staged a 24hour strike today affecting about 2.5 million passengers. Workers in seven other public sectorstelephone and telegraph, post, forestry, tobacco and salt, printing, mint, and alcoholalso walked out to back the transport workers. The strike was the first of an annual spring campaign by transport workers, this year for increased wages.

title: Israelis Finish 2Stage Pullback From Parts of Southern Lebanon

title: Subcommittee Approves Bill Extending Futures Commission
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (UPI)  A Senate Agriculture subcommittee approved today legislation that would extend the life of the Community Futures Trading Commission for six years and give the White House increased power to select the panel's chairman.

title: Newspaper Bares Its Conscience
The Indochina Debt That Lingers
description: The case for American help to the refugees of Indochina continues to be selfevident. After our involvement in Southeast Asia, no debate over who owes whom how much can be allowed to obscure the worst horrors experienced by many of those in flight. Perhaps half of those who fled in small boats from Vietnam drowned after they were ignored by passing ships or turned back from Asian ports. Thailand has even begun a program of forced repatriation of Laotians, some of whom face death or imprisonment as they return.

title: U.S. AMBASSADOR RESIGNS AFTER INQUIRY INTO FUNDS
description: WASHINGTON. April 14 (AP)Ambassador Robert A. Hurwitch, who returned from the Dominican Republic a week ago, resigned his post at the request of the State Department after an investigation into his use of embassy funds, department, officials said today.

title: Twins 14, Mariners 5
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 14 (UPI)Craig Kustcli drove in five runs with a single, double and triple today to lead the Minnesota Twins to a homeopening 145 victory over the Seattle Mariners.

title: Miss Lopez Leads by Stroke
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala., April 14 (AP)Nancy Lopez birdied the last three holes today to take a onestroke lead in the $60,000 Ladies Professional Golf Association Birmingham Classic with a sixunderper 66.

title: SHEARSON'S EARNINGS OFF 62.4% IN MARCH QUARTER
description: Earnings of Shearson Hayden Stone Inc. for the third fiscal quarter ended March 31 declined 62.4 percent to $1.1 million, or 25 cents a share, from $3 million, or 85 cents a share, the brokerage firm said yesterday. Revenues, however, rose 6.6 percent to $53 million from $47.7 million.

title: President of Angola Is in Soviet For Friendship and Rest Visit
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 14 (AP) President Agostinho Neto of Angola is in the Crimea for a stay of several days before resuming a tout of the Soviet Union, the official Angolan press agency says.

title: Television's Short Series Are HighStakes Gambles
description: LOS ANGELES, April 14The miniseries, a form of television programming that barely existed before 1977, now offers networks their biggest gambles and biggest rewards. The rewards were evident on Jan. 30, 1977, when people in 71 out of every 100 homes watching television had their sets turned to 'Roots on ABC. The other side of the gamble was equally evident last Feb. 13, when only 23 out of each 100 viewers bothered to look at King, NBC's expensive and highly publicized show on the life of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Rhodesian Guerrillas Meet Vance, Offer to Bargain on Peace Plan
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, April 14Rhodesian guerrilla leaders told Secretary of State Cyrus K. Vance and Foreign Minister David Owen today that under certain conditions the would accept key elements of the British American plan for a Rhodesian settlement, including the stationing of an impartial United Nations force to insure that free Plections are carried out.

title: Saudi Murderer Beheaded
description: NICOSIA. Cyprus, April 14 (AP)A Saudi man was publicly beheaded in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, today for murdering a fellow tribesman three years ago, the Saudi state radio reported in a broadcast monitored here.

title: Ballesteros, With 65134, Takes Lead by 3 Shots
Midi Garth's Dances Span 24 Years

Since then, she has gone her own choreographic way, influenced by various trends, but never succumbing to fashion merely because it is fashionable.

title: Stocks in Biggest Rise Since 1976
description: A wave of buying swept into the stock market yesterday, sending prices sharply higher in the heaviest trading in the history of the New York Stock Exchange.

title: International Minerals Profit Rises
description: Despite the coal strike, the sluggish domestic fertilizer business and lackluster petroleum coke sales, the International Minerals and Chemical Corporation reported yesterday profit increases of 9.6 percent for the third fiscal quarter and 10.9 percent for the nine months ended March 31.

description: MIAMI, April 14 (AP)Two antiCastro Cubans, believed by Federal investigators to hate information about the 1976 hombing assassination of former Chilean diplomat Orlando Letelier. were arrested here today on charges unrelated to the bombing.

title: Connecticut Is Farming in the Great Indoors
National Link Is Set By Midwest Exchange
description: The Midwest Stock Exchange, the last holdout, announced yesterday that it planned to join the national intermarket trading system. The systempromoted by the New York Stock Exchange and developed in conjunction with the other major securities exchangesallows brokers on one exchange to have their buy and sell orders displayed at all participating exchanges.

title: Notes on People
description: In a brief Chinese civil ceremony Yesterday, Leonard Woodcock, the chief of the United States liaison mission in Peking, was married to Sharon Tuohy a nurse on his staff. Mr. Woodcock, 67 years old, and Miss Tuohy, 35, were married a week after the former president of the United Automobile Workers learned that his divorce was final. He and his first wife had been separated 16 years. The Woodcocks plan a reception next week and a honeymoon in Tibet, if the Chinese authorities approve a visit there.

title: ExNursing Student Guilty of Sex Crimes In Westchester Case
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 14Alexander Verrone, a 29yearold former nursing student charged with sexual crimes against several young girls in Westchester County in 1976, pleaded guilty today to all charges of a 30count indictment.

Mixed Results in Philippines
description: MANILA, April 14After last week's bitterly disputed election for a new National Assembly, some Filipinos congratulated themselves that they had finally shown the courage to stand up to President Ferdinand E. Marcos after five and a halt years of his martial law rule.

title: IndiaPakistan Pact Signed
description: NEW DELHI, April 14 (Reuters)India and Pakistan signed an agreement today under which India will build a dam and a hydroelectric plant on the Chenab River in Kashmir. The agreement took eight years to negotiate because Pakistan feared the darn, 22 miles inside India, might affect the flow of water into its irrigation systems.

title: Royals 3, Indians 1
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 14 (UPI) Hal McRae homered and Amos Otis had a runscoring triple in the fourth inning tonight to help Paul Splittorff set a club record for consecutive victories as the Kansas City Royals defeated the Cleveland Indians, 31.

description: WASHINGTON, April 14The Civil Aeronautics Board proposed today that airlines be allowed to compete by reducing fares without prior approval for the first time since fares became regulated four decades ago.

description: NAIROBI, Kenya, April 14 (UPI) Ethiopia threatened today to invade Somalia unless it stopped all support of rebel guerrillas still fighting in the Ogaden area.

100 Lost on Boat in Burma
description: RANGOON, Burma, April 14 (AP)A boat carrying 200 passengers capsized and more than half of them are missing and presumed drowned, the stateowned Working People's Daily reported today. The accident occurred Saturday about 300 miles northwest of Rangoon on the Bay of Bengal.

title: Bolivia Treaty Sent to Senate
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)President Carter asked the Senate today to ratify a treaty with Bolivia permitting convicts to serve sentences in their country of citizenship. Both governments would have to agree to each request. Such treaties are in effect with Mexico and Canada.

title: PRESIDENT PROPOSES AN EDUCATION DEPT.
description: WASHINGTON April I4The Carter Administration asked Congress today to create a new Department of Education that would have a budget larger than seven of the 12 existing Cabinetlevel departments.

description: Joe Gordon, known as Flash to thousands of New York Yankee fans because of his spectacular fielding and equally, spectacular hitting, died yesterday in California. He was 63 years old.

description: By this time a year agoone week into the seasonthe Yankees were already working on episodes of what proved to be a seasonlong soap opera. Everything seems more peaceful now, but if there is a break in the quiet. it could come from Albert Waiter (Sparky) Lyle.

title: Ban on Real Estate Ads Urged
description: CHICAGO, April 14 (AP)The staff of the Illinois Housing Development Authority has recommended that developers financed by the state agency be banned from advertising in a new real estate section of The Chicago SunTimes that is not circulated in the inner city. The staff recommended that the authority tell the developers that if they advertise in the HomeLife section, the ads must be carried in editions and sections that do not exclude circulation to any racial or ethnic group.

title: Children's Fashions Grow Up to Be Annie Hall
description: It doesn't take long for fashion to filter down to the children's department. Leather jackets, shawlcollared blazers, vests, pegged pants and spencer jackets were among the uptotheminute styles that paraded down the runway Thursday at the Fashion Group's show of children's wear for fall. It all looked familiar, but the sizes had shrunk. Sometimes the clothes looked better that way.

title: Di Giuseppe and Catherine Malfitano In Saint of Bleecker Street Leads
description: When Gian Carlo Menotti's The Saint of Bleecker Street first appeared in 1954, it was not in an opera house but in a Broadway theater, the composer having made up his mind to reverse the flow of history and give opera back to the people. That was a worthy aim, if a quixotic one, and it was not long before tne wont was being done in opera houses under the usual subsidized conditions. Mr. Menotti is a talent, but not one big enough to accomplish that kind of counterrevolution in music.

title: Patents
A World War II Bomb Defused Near London
description: LONDON, April 14An army bombdisposal unit, after working all day,today deactivated a 2,200pound German bomb that had lain fused and alive near London probably since the 1940 blitz.

title: Nixon Upheld on Access to Papers
description: WASHINGTON, April 14 (AP)The Justice Department acknowledged today that regulations for public access to the papers and tapes of former President Richard M. Nixon had been adopted in an unconstitutional manner. Thee admission was contained in the Justice Department's answer to a complaint filed in Federal District Court by Mr. Nixon's lawyers.

title: Teacher Assignments by Race
description: The legal and political wrangling in recent months over the assignment of teachers by race and the collection of ethnic data in New York City schools might appear to he somewhat out of place in New YorkNew York, the multiethnic city; New York, the home of liberalism; New News York, where 70 percent of Analysis the children in public schools are from minority groups.

title: Wendy R. Broad Is Wed to Jonathon Lazear
description: Wendy R. Broad, a freelance editor, was married yesterday to Jonathon Lazear, publicity director of Jove Publications, the paperback subsidiary of Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. Justice Oliver Sutton of the Supreme Court of the State of New York performed the ceremony in his chambers.

title: American League Orioles 6, Brewers 5
description: BALTIMORE, April 14 (AP)  Lee May's tworun single capped a fiverun Baltimore third inning as the Orioles snapped a fivegame losing streak with their first victory, defeating the Milwaukee Brewers, 65, in their home opener today.

title: Stein Ladles Out More Criticisms of Koch
description: Borough President Andrew Stein of Manhattan turned up the heat in his simmering feud with Mayor Koch yesterday, denying he had apoligized for peppering the Mayor with unsolicited advice on how to run the city and adding a few inure salty suggestions.

title: Navy Seeking UBoat From Lake Michigar
description: CHICAGO, April 14 (UPI)Navy crews today started trying to raise a German Uboat that has lain at the bottom of Lake Michigan since 1921, Navy officials said.

title: Rumors of Peking Buying U.S. Grain Help Offset Prices
description: CHICAGO, April 14 (AP)A flurry of rumored and confirmed Chinese purchases of United States grain offset most of the pressure exerted on those futures this week by the defeat of the emergency farm legislation.

title: Control Board Says New York Can Pay CostofLiving Raise
description: The Emergency Financial Control Board yesterday approved costofliving payments of $105 each for 110,000 municipal employees in New York City, breaking a logjam that last month had threatened the negotiations for new Tabor contracts to replace those that expire June 30.

title: Five in Family Die in Fire
description: PLYMOUTH, Pa., April 14 (UPI)Five members of one family were killed and three other persons were injured today in an explosion and fire in a multifamily apartment complex. The police and firemen found the bodies of Francis Dinan, 47 years old, his wife Alice, 39, and Mrs. Dinan's children from a previous marriage, Biliy, 17, Betty, 16, and Kevin, 10.

title: A Pro and a Con
description: I have never had anything so skillfully placed under my thumb. I was reading a tabloid (which, I acknowledge, would make me seem fit bait for anything) and a card with a trinket attached was slippednay, appeared under my thumb. It was the reverse motion of a master pickpocket.

title: The Editorial Notebook
description: It seems that everyone but the authorities who accidentally discovered $600,000 in small bills in the suitcases of some visiting Colombians has a pretty good idea of what the money was for. The visitors to New York City might have been planning only to eat at the Palace restaurant or to take P. cab from midtown to Newark. More likely, though, the cash was destined for a Latin American cocaine connection. To the surprise of almost nobody, drugs, prostitutes, and gambling generate billions in revenues that are never recorded by Federal statisticians.

title: City May Have Authority to End The Surcharge on Offtrack Bets
description: Bernard Rome's campaign to repeal the surcharge on offtrack bets has been directed at the wrong legislators, according to lawyers familiar with the surcharge statute.

title: EXNEW YORK STATE AIDE GETS A YEAR FOR BRIBERY
C.A. B. UNVEILS PLAN FOR DEREGULATION OF AIRFARE CUTS
description: WASHINGTON, April 14The Civil Aeronautics Board proposed today that airlines be allowed to compete by reducing fares without prior approval for the first time since fares became regulated four decades ago.

title: Sports Today
description: AUTO RACING

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Service on the Staten Island Rapid Transit system was being restored overnighty as workers agreed to return after a day strike. The system's operating authority said normal train service was expected by morning.

title: THE POST AND GUILD WILL KEEP TALKING
Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Stein Ladles Out More Criticisms of Koch

description: LOS ANGELES, April 14 (UPI)Ron Cey drove in two runs with a single and double and Rick Monday hit his third homer of the season today to Pace Los Angeles to a 51 victory over the Atlants Braves in the Dodgers' home opener.

title: State Says Defense in Curare Trial Seeks to Bar Tapes
Lawyer Indicted on Adoptions
description: CAMDEN, N.J., April 14 (UPI)  A lawyer with offices in Marlton, N.J., and Willingboro, N.J., has been indicted for allegedly arranging the illegal adoption of babies. The indictment of the lawyer, Edward Kent, 52 years old, was announced today by Prosecutor Thomas Shusted of Camden County. The eight count indictment accuses Mr. Kent of acting as a middleman between the natural mothers and the adoptive pkents, which is against state law.

title: War of Attrition Hinted Over Nude Bathing on Coast
Ramirez Defeats Vilas in Quarterfinal
description: MONTE CARLO, Monaco, April 14 (AP)  Raul Ramirez defeated topseeded Guillermo Vilas, 2.6, 6.0, 63, for the first time in his career today in a raindelayed quarterfinal match of a $175,000 World Championship Tennis tournament. The match was interrupted three times by rain.

title: Lawyer Indicted on Adoptions
description: CAMDEN, N.J., April 14 (UPI)  A lawyer with offices in Marlton. N.J., and Willingboro, N.J., has been indicted for allegedly arranging the illegal adoption of babies. The indictment of the lawyer, Edward Kent, 52 years old. was announced today by Prosecutor Thomas Shusted of Camden County. The eight count indictment accuses Mr. Kent of acting as a middleman between the natural mothers and the adoptive parents, which is against state law.

title: Rhodesia to Halt Executions
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 14 (AP)Rhodesia's multiracial Government has ordered a halt to executions of political prisoners, including nationalist guerrillas, sources in the Government said today. The conciliatory move was made known hours after Rhodesia instated its first predominantly black administration. Nine black Cabinet ministers and nine whites were sworn in and are to serve until Dec. 31. when the first black government elected by universal suffrage is scheduled to take over under Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's internal settlement with three black leaders.

title: Imports in Britain Climb to a Record
description: LONDON, April 1.1When Britain published its 197879 budget Rst Tuesday it was agreed that one or the biggest risks in the proposed proelectron tax cuts was that deficits in the balance of payments would return. Today, the country learned that that has already happened.

title: Ellis Larkins Plays Jazz on an August Forster Piano
description: Ellis Larkins has found a piano that is properly responsive to his subtle touch in the glistening black August Forster instrument at the Carnegie Hall Cabaret, Seventh Avenue at 56th Street, where he has settled down for an indefinite stay.

title: Blue Jays 10, Tigers 8
description: TORONTO, April 14 (UPI)  Roy Howell had four singles, the final one in a sixrun sixth inning, as the Toronto Blue Jays won their home opener from the Detroit Tigers, 108, today.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, APRIL 15, 1978

title: Rangers Hold Key To Playoffs
description: The remaining seven National Hockey League playoff teams will be closely following the New York Rangers and Buffalo Sabres decisive game tonight in Buffalo, for the outcome will determine the four matchups in the quarterfinal round that begins Monday. Coach JeanGuy Talbot named John Davidson again as starting goalie.

title: CORRECTION
description: The caption under a picture of candidates for State Attorney General yesterday said the photograph was made at Brooklyn College. It was made at Brooklyn Law School.

description: A battle related to Federal sponsorship of scientific research at private universities, with hundreds of millions of dollars at stake, has reached the White House, and President Carter is expected to take a stand on the issues soon.

description: ST. LOUIS, April 14 (UPI)Jose Cardenal, a pinchhitter, walked with the bases loaded in the ninth inning, forcing in the winning run and giving the Philadelphia Phillies a 43 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight.

description: ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, April 14 (UPI)At noon today, a C130 transport dropped a wreath into the sea near an iceberg as a tribute to the British liner Titanic on the 66th anniversary of her sinking.

description: EAST WINDSOR, Conn.Agriculture in Connecticut is moving indoors.

title: GOING OUT Guide
The Dignity of Flight From Vietnam and Cambodia
description: As a member of Citizens Commission on Refugees, I recently interviewed Vietnamese and Cambodian refugees in watershort but otherwise Acceptable camps in Thailand. The images of the wars in Indochina that we have distilled as guides to our understanding do not properly reflect the most important quality of these refugees.

title: Priest Changes Life and Minds On Korean Isle
description: HALLIM, South KoreaWhen Patrick James McGlinchey arrived in Korea in 1954, he was a young, eager missionary fresh from seminary and Donegal and full of energy and ideas.

Also in the openingnight program, which is to begin at 7:30 P.M., will be a new production of George Balanchine's Theme and Variations in which the leading dancers will be Gelsey Kirkland and Mikhail Baryshnikov.

description: Sandra Lynn Helton and Norman M. Edelson were married yesterday in the Campus Center at Elmira College by Town Justice Henry M. Schurr of Big Flats. N.Y.

title: Carter and Aides Press Spy Case That May Test President's Power
description: WASHINGTON, April 15Top officials of the Administration, including President Carter, have been deeply involved in the direction of an espionage case that could determine whether the Government may continue to make searches, tap telephones and install listening devices in national security investigations without first obtaining judicial warrants.

title: Lois Spiegelman, Teacher, Bride of Andrew Gordon
description: Lois Elayne Spiegelman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Spiegelman of Millburn, N.J., was married yesterday to Andrew John Gordon, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jules D. Gordon of New York Rabbi Richard Marker performed the ceremony at the Faculty Club of Brown University in Providence, R.I.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: I must ask you to correct the article on the Westchester Chappel (Feb. 12) and the description of the American Printing History Association in that article. As they stand, they do serious damage to what are growing elements in the effort to preserve freedom of the press and the humanity of printing.

title: Head of U.S. Agency Honored by Florists
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI)The General Services Administration has been honored at a ceremony at which Rosalynn Carter was hostess for its work in brightening and beautifying Federal buildings throughout the nation.

title: Ideas &
description: Of course it all started with Columbus, but it accelerated in the 19th Century, when Government schools adopted English as the sole language of instruction for Indian schoolchildren. Now only four people, all old, can speak the Quapaw language of Oklahoma. One aged woman in Alaska knows Eyak.,About two dozen tribal seniors in northern Washington are fluent in Makah. But Makah has been given a fighting chance: with a 390,000 grant from the National Endowment for the Humanities, older and younger Makahs have started a project to save their language. The grant was delivered in person last week by Joseph D. Duffey, chairman of the National Endowment, to the chairman of the Makah Tribal council, which runs the 43squaremile reservation across the strait from Vancouver Island.

title: Susan E. Carr Bride of Robert Pickett
description: In St. James' Episcopal Church yesterday, Susan Earle Carr, an actress, was married to Robert B. Pickett, senior vice president of Booke & Company. international financial and public relations consultants. The Rev. Richard Downes performed the ceremony.

title: Dog Handlers Promote Sportsmanship
description: Fourteen hundred people from the 50 states and as far away as Singapore and Bogota, Colombia,have begun a big publicity drive to promote sportsmanship and educate the dog fanciers. All these crusaders wear Owner Handler Association of America pins in their lapels.

title: Banging on The Table
description: THIS is a book of pronouncements: Art is essentially and primarily moral  that is, lifegiving  moral in its process of creation and moral what it says; True criticism praises true art for what it doespraises as plainly and comprehensively as possibleand denounces false art for its failure do art's proper work. That sort of thing. John Gardner, the author of October Light and other novels and of The Life and Times of Chaucer, likes to set Homer, Dante and Tolstoy over against Freud, Sartre and Wittgenstein. In a world where nearly everything that passes for art is tinny and commercial and often, in addition, hollow and academic, I argue  by reason and by banging the table  for an oldfashioned view of what art is and does. As might well be imagined from the above, in On Moral Fiction it often difficult to distinguish the arguing by reason and the arguing by banging the table.

title: Columbia Crew Captures First Cup Race Since 63
description: The Columbia heavyweight crew won its first cup race in 15 years yesterday, defeating Massachusetts Institute of Technology in the second annual Alumni Cup regatta on the cold, smooth Harlem River.

title: Journalist Is Elected to Lead Quebec Liberal Party
description: QUEBEC, April 15Claude Ryan, a 53yearold journalist who seeks to reconcile Frenchspeaking and Englishspeaking Canada, was elected leader of the Liberal Party of Quebec today.

title: INTERVIEW New Haven Mayor's Other Constituency: the Arts

There, with his wife, Mary Ann, he attended a concert by a musical punster named P. D.Q. Bach, performance of the modern dance troupe Pilobolus, an art exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum entitled The Age of Spirituality and a Broadway show, Eugene O'Neill's A Touch of the Poet.

title: THEATER A Jerome Kern Revue, A Philip Barry Comedy
description: STAMFORD, Conn. FOR its final offering of the season, the Hartman Theater Company is honoring Jerome Kern with a musical revue built .around 33 of the composer's melodies. The songs selected are, for the most part, the bestknown out of a gigantic output of melody. The tribute to Kern is a fine idea; the execution at the Hartfordand it was thatis something else.

title: Miss Lane Engaged To C. K. Falkenhagen
description: Judge Merritt 1 a ne Jr. of the Sunerior Court. of Monmouth County, N.J. and Mrs. Lane of Middletown. N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Marearet lane, to Christopher Kime Falkenhagen. He is a son of Mrs. Walter A. Wallace of Miami and R. Robert Falkenhagen of Kenneth Square, Pa. The weddine is planned for August.

title: Three Faces of New York Rock
description: Lou Reed, Patti Smith and Television are all crucial forces in 1970's New York rockandroll, and all of them have new records out now. None is likely to sweep the top of the sales charts. But all three are fascinating, and suggest things about not only their creators but, implicitly, about New York rock in general.

title: Sophia Loren Faces New Charges in Rome
description: ROME, April 15 (UPI)  A Rom'e prosecutor filed new charges today agaihst Sophia Loren and her husband, Carlo Ponti, and also accused two other film stars, Ava Gardner and Richard Harris, of having illegally exported currency and art works worth $10 million.

title: A Boy, a Musket and History
description: THE boy held the Brown Bess musket on his lap and ran his hands over it, lovingly. He had never played with guns as a child, never played CopsandRobbers or CowboysandIndians.

title: Making Friends and Influencing People
description: STAMFORD THE four candidates for the Republican gubernatorial nomination may not agree on a lot of things these days, but they share a common task  trying to become better known outside their state legislative or Congressional districts.

title: U.S. MARINES IN JAPAN ASK FOOD HELP FOR FAMILIES
description: TOKYO, April 15 (UPI)United States Marine commanders in Japan have requested permission to open their mess halls to wives and children of Marines hurt by the decline of the dollar, a United States military spokesman said recently.

title: Putting Smokers in Their Space
description: A large number of people now prefer to be spared the nuisance of tobacco smoke, and a growing body of evidence suggests that being spared is good for their health. Therefore, the recent action by New Jersey officials requiring restaurants, hotels and public meeting places reserve space for nonsmokers seems sensible. New Yorkers might want to observe now New Jersey reacts.

title: 120 Tribes Form New Group To Block AntiIndian Moves
description: WINDOW ROCK, Ariz.Representatives of more than 120 Indian tribes agreed this week to set up a new coordinating group, the Native American Treaty Rights Organization, to deal with what Indians perceive as a very real threat: white backlash.

title: Management: G.E.'s Search for Synergy
U.N. Appoints Ecuador Diplomat An Assistant Secretary General
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 15Diego Cordovez, a career diplomat from Ecuador and a United Nations official since 1963, has been appointed Assistant Secretary General for Economic and Social Matters.

title: Top Drivers to Compete in the Trenton 200Miler
description: Next. Sunday's Gabriel 200mile race for United States Auto Club championship cars at Trenton (N. J.) International Speedway could he quite a shootout, if everyone who's supposed to he there shows up.

title: F.C.C. Preparing To Use a New Law On C.B. Violations
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)The Federal Communications Commission is preparing to use new legislation permitting it to enforce its rules against both licensed and unlicensed citizens band radio operators.

title: FollowUp on the News
description: With much fanfaneand stout opposition from the Transport Workers Unionthe New York Transit Authority began operating an automated subway train between Times Square and Grand Central in January 1962. In deference to the union, the train had a standby motorman, but except for infrequent breakdowns in equipment, he was there strictly for the ride.

title: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. Is Injured In a Diving Accident in Alabama
description: MOBILE, Ala., April 15 (AP)Robert F. Kennedy Jr., the 24yearold son of the late New York Senator, was slightly injured in a diving accident today, a hospital spokesman said.

title: Votes in Congress
Deborah L. Sulcer Plans June Bridal
description: The engagement of Deborah Louise Sulcer to David Crispia Sauvage has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Shipman Parr of Bay Head, N.J., and Boca Raton, Fla., stepfather and mother of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. Vivian Sauvage of Harrisburg, Pa., and the late Mr. Sauvage

title: ART VIEW
description: The writing of the history of art, especially the history of art recent enough to remain subject to the correction (or, as is sometimes the case, the falsification) of living witnesses, is a conundrum of considerable size. So much depends upon the perspectives and prejudices of the moment, and so many of these depend upon those networks of personal and political associationand business connections, toothat are an inevitable part of the lives of the artists who produce the art, of the dealers and museum curators who select it for exhibition, and of the writers who set down the history of both. The wonder is not that distortions occur in the writing of such art history, but that anything remotely resembling a coherent and persuasive chronicle ever sees the light of day. Everybody knows that a friendship or a love affair or a divorce, a move to the country or a decision not to, an altercation with a dealer or an affront to a critic or curator, can sometimes determine an artist's place in written history; yet, the history is written as if it were a completely objective account of objects and their attributes. The myth of objectivity is, I suppose, one of the fictions essential to the writing of such history, but it remains a myth all the same.

title: The Street Cars Call Desire
description: IF ever there was a misnomer, Old Country Road is it. Instead of a fine rustic scene, bucolic and soothing, Old Country Road is the major thoroughfare through what has come to be known as Downtown Nassau. The nature preserve and bird sanctuary that is planned on the grounds the Ethical Society will add one soft pocket of serenity, but as we plant scarlet oaks and construct a meditation garden, fastfood restaurants grow more tenaciously than summer crabgrass.

title: Boston Marathon: Food and Beer
description: Swigging beer, meditating, wolfing down lasagna, avoiding sensual pleasures, and even running are some ways the 4,800 entrants in the Boston Marathon will spend their day today as they prepare for the world's most famous foot race tomorrow.

title: DINING OUT A Touch of Nostalgia in Hoboken; *Helmers'
description: WHEN Prohibition went out, Helmers came in. And it came to stay. At Washington and 11th Streets in the heart of Hoboken, this corner restaurantbar has survived a halfcentury of urban change. Here's a place where nostalgia is what it used to be.

title: Boeing Gets Contract for Space Tugs
description: SEATTLE, April 15 (UPI)The Boeing Company was awarded a $265 million Air Force contract yesterday to build space tugs to be used in conjunction with the space shuttle. A spokesman for the company said that the contract will create about 1.500 jobs by late 1979.

title: SPOTLIGHT
description: There are still people in this industry who find a design talent and convince themselves that they have a business, says Frank Mori. They soon enough learn that they need business skills to develop and sustain that design talent in order to turn it all into a viable company.

title: Architecture
description: Some great suburban houses command their sites, but the house shown here is so understated that, from the front, it almost disappears. Such an effect was typical of the work of Eliel Saarinen, the great FinnishAmerican architect who died in 1950; he ways preferred to unravel his architectural mysteries slowly and never tried to dazzle with first impressions.

title: Rhodesia Talks Fail to Resolve 2 Key Elements
description: DAR ES SALAAM, Tanzania, Sunday, April 16The United States and Britain concluded a twoday meeting with Rhodesian guerrilla leaders early this morning in agreement on some aspects of a Rhodesian peace plan but in fundamental disagreement on key elements.

title: Recapturing Tradition At the Seder Table
description: WESTPORT EVERY week since January, Sam Brownstein, president of the Westport Congregation for Humanistic Judaism, has been busy in the basement of his home turning 20 large cans of frozen Concord grape juice into 15 gallons of wineenough, he says, for the community seder, the traditional dinner and service recounting the flight of the Israelites from Egypt, that he is organizing for Saturday, the second night of Passover.

title: Notes: A Swap With the Russians
description: Up to 2,000 more Americans than usual and an equal number of Russians will be visiting each other's countries next year if plans for a tourist swap devised by American Express and the United StatesSoviet Union Trade and Economic Council are carried out.

title: The Challenge and Joy and Anguish of Running a Marathon
description: The challenge of the Boston Marathon is not the distance. Not the 26 miles, that undulating ribbon of roads that takes me from Hopkinton to the Prudential Center. Nor is it the time, those three hours or more I spend in progressive discomfort until pain becomes a companion. Nor is it the fatigue or exhaustion or even the threat of collapse.

title: THE PURGE OF THE CHIEFS; THE PURGE OF THE CHIEFS; A new mayor, a new commissioner and a new reshuffle of the brass show that you can't take the politics out of the New York police force.; Jim Hannon; Joe Hoffman; CHIEFS; Dan Courtenay; The Night of the Mutiny; The Isolation of the Cop; Battle Plan; The Firing of Jim Hannon; The New P.C.; Battle Plan (Cont'd); The Battle; After the Purge
description: A visitor to Police Headquarters in lower Manhattan must first climb flight of stone steps, splendidly scaled, only four years old, but already crumbling. Stepping onto a vast plaza, the visitor is confronted with an arrogant, red ironwork abstraction that symbolizes New York's five boroughs.

title: MURDER CONFESSION PRESENTS AN ENIGMA
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 15Why a young computer expert would resign from his job in Chicago and return to California to confess the 14yearold unsolved murder of a Berkeley student is a question that is still unanswered in the trial of Joseph Otto Egenberger, who did just that, although the state complet. ed its case this week.

title: Ulster Peace Movement Leaders, Including Nobel Winners, to Quit
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 15The three founders of the Ulster peace movement, including two women who won the Nobel Peace Prize for 1976, said today that they were stepping down from the group's leadership.

title: High and Low Gossip
description: KATE SIMON'S first book, New York: Places and Pleasures, was a sprightly and often surprising guide to New York City as it was 15 years ago, in the middle 60's. Now she returns to New York, having guided her readers through Mexico. Paris, London, Rome and England, with an interesting and quite complicated effort: a social history of Manhattan  very social in the sense that her focus is on the very richest of New Yorkers  by watching Fifth Avenue stretch north from Washington Square to central Harlem during the last cent ury and a halfa process that included all of the avenue's growth and a fair measure of its deterioration.

title: Miss O'Connell Plans Wedding
description: Dr. and Mrs. Arthur E. Gillman of Rye, N.Y., and Stowe. Vt., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Gillman's daughter, Abigail Lee O'Connell, to Jaime Gonsalves Tenedorio, son of Mr. and Mrs. Antonio D. Tenedorio of Homestead Fla.

title: FISHINGFishing Season Off to Good Start
description: PACK up the tackle box and launch the boat. Fishing along the New Jersey coast is coming to life.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Terrible tale. Unless the bestlaid plans of one of the giant television networks go completely awry, millions of Americans will sit glued by their sets tonight, Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday evenings, watching a ninehour miniseries called Holocaust, the story of how two fictional families, one Jewish, one Nazi, responded to Hitler's final solution.

title: GETTING A UNE ON STEINBERG
Accountants Banish Ban on Advertising
description: The ad above is imaginary, but in the realm of possibility. Last week the American Institute of Certified Public Accountants ended a 50yearold ban against advertising of services by its members.

description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 15 (UPI)Hua Kuofeng, chairman of the Chinese Communist Party and Prime Minister, will visit North Korea early in May in his first trip aboard since he became leader of the party two years ago, Yugoslav newspapers reported today.

title: Oerter, the 1980 Olympics His Goal, Is Discus Victor
Bicyclers to Aid Muscular Dystrophy Fund
description: DARCY and Nick Maiale were living in New Jersey when they learned that their son, Jimmy, had muscular dystrophy. During her older daughter's visit to an orthopedist, Mrs. Maiale had mentioned that Jimmy, then 3 years old, seemed to have developed a peculiar gait.

title: Postscript to Form 1040
description: Here it is again, teasing twothirds of us with the promise of a refund. Pay too little, or too late, and they charge you interest, up to 9 percent. Pay too much, week after week, and you are .made to feel grateful a year later for a depreciated refund, without interest. The tax system may not be quite the disgrace that Jimmy Carter once held it to be, but it is certainly a distortion of the customary balance of power between the citizen and his government.

title: Dr. David Snyder Weds Dr. Barbara Scolnick
description: Dr. Barbara F. Scolnick daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Meyer Scolnick of the Bronx, and Dr. David Snyder, son of Dr. and Mrs. Julian Snyder of Newton, Mass., were married yesterday in the Jewish Community Center in Harrison, N.Y. Rabbi Israel J. Kazis, rabbi emeritus of Temple MishkanTefila in Chestnut Hill, Mass., performed the ceremony.

title: Goldin Criticizes Transit Authority For Letting Contractor Off Hook
description: The New York City Transit Authority has failed to assess $10.8 million in contract penalties for delays in the delivery of new subway cars, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin charged yesterday.

title: What They Are Saying
description: Nancy Lopez, the current 21yearold star of the pro golf tour, found it difficult to relax during a visit to her Roswell, N.M., home: You think about people who work and then play golf to relax. My work is playing golf and I can't do anything to relax. I can't swim because it's bad for my hands and grip. I can't play tennis because builds up my arms. All I can do is dance and lie around in the sun.

title: ExRepresentative Named to Head Lobby for Aid to New York City
description: Governor Carey named a former California Representative, Thomas M. Rees, a former member of the House Banking and Currency Committee, to head a task force charged with coordinating lobbying efforts in Washington for continued assistance to New York City.

title: Food; Creole Creation; Crubes farcis desiles (Stuffed crabs Caribbeanstyle)
description: Although the islands of the Caribbean are not generally considered a gourmet's paradise, there are numerous creole dishes in that area which merit special attention. One of the most tempting of foods to be found in restaurants on and around those sunbaked beaches is stuffed crab, generally flavored with small hot chilies that titillate and please the palate. On a minitour of the region quite recently, we found pleasure in the stuffed crab of two restaurants, L'Entrepont in St. Barthelemy and Le Fish Pot in St. Martin. The two versions varied widely in flavor and texture, so for the recipe on this page we produced a synthesis which, we think, captures the best of both.

description: BASEBALL

title: I Now, By the Virtue of the Authority Placed in Me . . .
description: WOODBRIDGE GONE with the horse and buggy is the oldfashioned, cinemainspired idea of awakening a justice of the peace in the middle of the night to get married  right away.

title: Rochester University Given a Lincoln  Letter
description: ROCHESTER, April 15 (AP)The University of Rochester has been given a letter in which President I incoln said he did not think his second inaugural address, calling for malice toward none and charity for all, would be popular immediately.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: Last night, with a performance of Tosca, the Metropolitan Opera dropped its curtain on the 197778 season. It was not one of the more stimulating or progressive Metropolitan Opera seasons. In a way it represented retrenchment, or a holding pattern. The house has been having fierce problems in recent years. most of those financial. But a few months ago Anthony Bliss, executive director of the Metropolitan, announced that he saw light at the end of the tunnel. Up to then the pressing issue had been mere survival. Presumably, now that things are being whipped into shape, more attention will be paid to artistic policy.

title: Medical Records: For Whose Eyes?
Assembly Gets Ready for the Last Act
description: HARTFORD THE General Assembly moved into the final stage of this year's session last week, when the deadline passed for the last of 25 legislative committees to propose new laws for consideration by the whole body.

title: Paperbacks: New and Noteworthy
description: THE DRAGONS OF EDEN, by Carl Sagan. (Ballantine, $2.25.) The Cornell astronomer and space scientist speculates on the evolution of human intelligence from the Big Bang 15 billion years ago to the day before yesterday. Many, many matters  childbirth, cloning, computers, dreams and myths among them  are treated sometimes naively, sometimes brilliantly. A best seller in hardcover.

title: China's Szechwan Province, Scene of Turmoil in Recent Years, Is Regaining Stability
description: CHUNGKING, China, April 14 (Reuters) China's Szechwan Province is noted for its hot food and peppery people, but politically it is cooling down.

title: Marriage Announcement 3  No Title
description: Adrienne Jill Maher Is Bride

title: Kathy Lewis Plans To Be Wed May 20
description: Kathy Ann Lewis, an assistant professor of management science at the Columbia University Graduate School of Business, plans to he married May 20 to Stephen Michael Corriher, an associate with Emory Ayers Associates Inc., New York management consultants.

title: ALBANY REPORTA 10Cent Issue Takes Its Toll
description: IT was not even a twobit issue, but it could have held up Governor Carey's $12 billion budget.

title: Mixed Salad
World News Briefs
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 15 (AP)The Lebanese Government charged today that Israeli troops remained in some areas of south Lebanon that they were supposed to have left under their twostage pullback plan.

title: INTERVIEW Exile's Road to Past Is a Cuban Revelation
description: ONE morning last February, as he slept in his home in Stony Brook, Roman de la Campa, professor of Hispanic studies at the State University Center at Stony Brook, became conscious of the ringing of his telephone.

title: WHY THE CRY OF THE BEATEN CHILD GOES UNHEARD
description: From the neighbor who overhears a young child's screams to the doctor who treats the bruises and lesions on his battered body, more often than not, adults who are in a position to help abused children don't. They are stymied by concerns as raw as the fear of personal harm or of lawsuits; as subtle as subconscious sympathy with the abuser. They are deterred by societal ethics that warn against involvement in another man's affairs, andhalted by their own uncertainty as to what does or does not constitute abuse. Factors twist together like the fibers of a rope and keep the helping adult from the hurting child. As a result, less than a third of the estimated one million American children abused each year ever reach the attention of childprotective agencies. If a greater amount of violent mistreatment is to be prevented, more must be understood about the dynamics of intervening, about why people don't come to the aid of such children.

title: Amadeus Quartet Is Guest of Chamber Music Society
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center had as its guest ensemble Friday night in Alice Tully Hall the distinguished Londonbased Amadeus Quartet. Its central contribution to the program was the String Quartet No. 3 (Op. 94) of Benjamin Britten, which was being given its United Slates premiere. One of the composer's final works, it was completed in the fall of 1975, but was not given its first performance until Dec. 19 of the following year, two weeks after Britten's death.

title: Letters
description: Grace and Fred M. Hechinger's article (Homosexuality on Campus, March 12) was the kind of objective, balanced report on this topic that is rare in today's pop media. Through the Hechingers sensitive depiction of the many, varied and individual paths the lonely, tortured young homosexuals tread, it is so much easier to understand the formerly baffling facade of challenge and militancy offered up as a plea for simple acceptance and understanding of honest and innocent differentness.

title: HOME CLINIC How To Apply A Smooth Finish
description: WHEN applying varnish or enamel, a smooth, glossy finish can only be achieved if the surface is smooth and free of dust or other particles, and the paint or varnish is properly applied with a good quality brush or padtype applicator.

title: We Ran Out of Controversy Bea Arthur Says Farewell to Maude
description: We've accomplished what we set out to accomplish. We brought good theater to television. I may be kidding myself, but I think we gave quality shows to television. Also, for the very first time we presented somebody who wasn't just a bubblehead out to get laughs. For the first time issues were dealt with, thoughts were exchanged. I think we made television a little more adult, I really do.

title: America's Offal Policy
description: WASHINGTONOffal and soybeans are at the heart of the Atlantic alliance.

title: Article 3  No Title
FISHING Inshore Flounder, Offshore Indifferent
description: IT'S the calm before the mackerel storm. Inshore, fine flounder fishing continues around the Island. Offshore, with the exception of the strong cod run off Montauk, fishing is in the doldrums.

title: BRIDGE Jerseyans Advance In Title Bridge Play
Real Estate Exhibit,
description: HASTINGSONHUDSON LOIS DEVORE of New Rochelle owns a house the Addams family would enjoy. Painted a sickly yellow, with black trim, the house has a wasp's nest in the living room, cobwebs everywhere and mice. The house is furnished, but the chair legs are broken and the cutlery is tarnished.

title: Who Will Tell Jimmy?; WASHINGTON
description: WASHINGTON, April 15President Carter has been calling his closest advisors together for what is billed as a hard reappraisal of his Administration's troubles, but who will tell him the truth? You can almost put dawn as a general rule in this town that Presidents often invite honest criticism from their aides, but seldom get it, and usually don't follow when they do.

title: Future Rents of 35,000 Apartments Now Under Controls Have Been Rendered Uncertain by Recent Rulings
description: The future rents in about 35,000 rentcontrolled apartments in New York City have been thrown into uncertainty because of recent legislative and judicial actions.

title: No Sad Songs For Patti Smith
description: SOUTH JERSEY is more like Detroithard core, says Patti Smith, the 31yearold poet turned rockandroller who almost singlehandedly led punk rock from the sidewalks of New York's CBGB's club to a national force in popular music.

title: Eileen Chiu Is Bride of Philip Graham Jr.
ART MAILBAG
description: To the Editor:

title: Donna Wilson To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald C. Wilson of Bethany, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Charlene Wilson, to Charles William Johnson, son of DeLois Cheney of Indianapolis and Lester M. Johnson of Elkhart, Ind.

title: Aide Sees Age Bias By Panel on Aging
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)A 67yearold professional Staff aide on the House Select Committee on Aging said today that the advisory panel was guilty of age discrimination in requesting his resignation.

title: Students at Princeton End Sitln Held to Protest Stock Portfolio
description: PRINCETON. N.J., April 15  More than 200 Princeton University students voluntarily ended a 27hour sitin inside the Administration building on campus this morning, declaring that they had made known their objections to the university's holdings in corporations that do business in South Africa.

description: WHEN applying varnish or enamel, a smooth, glossy finish can only be achieved if the surface is smooth and free of dust or other particles, and if the paint or varnish is properly applied with a good quality brush or padtype applicator.

title: Haywood Called Knicks Key for 76ers
description: The Knicks and the Philadelphia 76ers, who thrive on offense and scorn defense, meet today in the opener of the National Basketball Association Eastern Conference semifinal playoffs at the Spectrum in Philadelphia. It will he a fourofseven games series.

title: Ballesteros Extends Golf Lead to 4 on 73207; Where Is Nicklaus?; Watson Playing Consistently; Player Finishes in Control; N??cy Lopez Preservos Lead
BURNS ARE RANKED SECOND AS DEATH CAUSE IN NATION
description: ATLANTA, April 15 (AP)About 6,000 persons die from burns in the United Staes each year, mostly in house fires, and in lives lost burns were ranked second only to traffic accidents.

title: City Council Sessions Scheduled for the Week
description: The New York City Council will hold a regular meeting on Tuesday at 1:30 P.M. at City Hall.

title: Horse Show Calendar
description: TodayJunior Olympics, Thomas School of Horsemanship, Round Swamp Road, Melville, L.I. Military teams, junior, nonthoroughbred and special working hunters, ponies, equitation. 8:30 A.M.

title: GARDENING An Outdoor Spring Cleaning
description: SEVERAL balmy pleasant weekends in a row have made Fairfield County gardeners slightly more than euphoric. Everyone, seems, is out on these favored daysraking, pruning and cleaning up.

title: Carolyn Rose, Therapist, Wed to Kenneth M. Ferber
description: Carolyn Rose, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Rose of Westbury, L.I., and Kenneth M. Ferber, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Ferber, also of Westbury, were married yesterday. Rabbi Melvin Kieffer and Cantor Kalman Fleigelman officiated at the ceremony at the Terrace on the Park in Flushing Meadows, Queens.

title: At Home: Where's Grandma?
description: THERE are no grandmas anymore. You won't find them in the kitchen, demonstrating inscrutable wisdom of the stove. Your children aren't wearing sweaters, scarves or mittens knit by their indefatigable fingers. Grandma's mystical maternity, mellowed in wood, time or tradition, is no longer a family heritage.

title: Columbia Wins in Water Polo
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 15Columbia University won its opening two games today in the Ivy League waterpolo championship at the University of Pennsylvania's Sheerr Pool. Tom Young, Rick Rosenbaum and Glenn Neufeld were the scoring leaders for Columbia in a 19.3 triumph over the University of Pennsylvania B team and a 15.7 victory over Dartmouth.

title: Administration Expedited UraniuM Export to Europe To Evade Legislative Ban
description: WASHINGTON, April 15The Carter Administration speeded up approval for the export of 1,000 pounds of enriched uranium to three West European countries to avoid a ban on such shipments imposed by Congress, documents released this week show.

title: Koch to Initiate Festivities for Italian Culture Week
description: With plays, films, concerts, folk dances, art exhibitions and social gatherings ranging from sedate receptions to swirling festivals, ItalianAmericans this week will pay tribute to their heritage in a citywide series of celebrations associated with Italian Culture Week. to be proclaimed tomorrow by Mayor Koch.

title: Robelyn Schrade Is Fiancee
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert Warren Schrade of New York and Worthington, Mass., of the engagement of their daughter, Robelyn Reynolds Schrade, to David Frank James, son of Mrs. Edward Frank James of Gisborne, New Zealand, and the late Mr. James.

title: My Characters Are Trying To Be Somebody The Mighty Gents
LETTER FROM WASHINGTON Case Assails Lack Of Rail Progress
description: IN railroading, a slow order means slow speeds required by poor track conditions. Since its inception in 1971, Amtrak, the Governmentfinanced national railpassenger service, has been plagued by slow orders across the country, thus making a mockery of attempts at a truly highspeed service.

title: An Umpire For Government
description: NEARLY half the states in our country have established ombudsmen or citizens advocates willing to take on the bureaucracy for their residents in the 15 years since the idea was first discussed at a Judiciary Committee hearing in Connecticut in March 1963.

title: Pseudonyms Together
description: THE decline of Puritanism has had an odd effect on certain of our fellow Americans. There is a pseudonym named Elizabeth who reports in Cosmopolitanclear prose: Our evenings rarely varied. He ran my bath, undressed me, handcuffed my wrists. She and her friend, a fellow New Yorker.sometimes watch television together  he in an easy chair, she with her arms raised above her head and her hands tied to a hook in the wall. Elsewhere, a pseudonym named Katherine wonders if she is normal. She drives at night for three hours at a stretch screaming I want a lover, I want a lover!!! A friend of hers, another married woman of mature years, who even reads Family Circle, speeds all the way to Hastings so that a state trooper might flag her down. A pseudonym named Antony ponders like Hamlet the What'sitallabout blues (he has made love to many women, all pseudonyms; he complains of being lonely, even slowwitted  alarmed by the notion that Goethe must have known something I don't). Yet he has a friend, a pseudonym named Willie, who, in a variation on the theme of promiscuityamongjadedManhattanites, sleeps fully clothed two Saturday nights in a row beneath a friend's piano with a fully clothed pseudonym named Iris. They are all vaguely discontent, nagged by the suspicion that meaning in life has eluded them.

title: New York MapleSugar Harvest Ends, With Indications of a Fair
U.S. Trade Commission Ruling Opens Way for New Tariffs on Japanese Steel
description: The American steel industry, whose fortunes were ebbing at the beginning of the year, found the tide was turning last week.

title: HOME CLINIC How To Apply A Smooth Finish
description: WHEN applying varnish or enamel, a smooth, glossy finish can only be achieved if the surface is smooth and free of dust or other particles, and if the paint or varnish is properly applied with a good quality brush or padtype applicator.

title: Governor Appoints A Panel to Examine Future of New York
Caso, Once a Power in Nassau, Waits Forlornly for a Public Job
description: For 12 years he was at the pinnacle of governmental and political power in Nassau County. Now Ralph G. Caso is a man who still wants to be in public service, but no one is asking him.

title: Thousands in Israel Rally to Back Begin
description: TEL AVIV, April 15Tens of thousands of Israelis rallied outside City Hall here tonight in support of Prime Minister Menachem Begin and to show disapproval of a group of reserve officers who have been campaigning for greater concessions by Israel in peace negotiations.

title: The Inflation Strategy
JAPAN ASKS CURBS BY KEY INDUSTRIES ON MAJOR EXPORTS
description: TOKYO, April 15The Ministry of International Trade and Industry appealed to exporters today to reduce shipments of automobiles, steel, television sets, ships and other major products.

title: Gowdy to Be Honored By Basketball Hall
description: SPRINGFIELD, Mass., April 15 (AP) Curt Gowdy, the sports broadcaster, will receive the Basketball Hall of Fame's John W. Dunn award for outstanding contributions to the game, hall officials said today.

title: CITY PLANS IMPROVEMENTS FOR VAN CORTLANDT PARK
description: The Parks Department, prompted by the Bronx Borough Board, has agreed to expedite repairs and a cleanup of Van Cortlandt Park, the city's fourth largest.

title: MUSIC
description: FOR a good many years now, Sarah Caldwell and her Opera Company of Boston have been a powerful magnet, attracting and enthralling opera lovers from all around the country. Critics skip premiers at the Metropolitan Opera to see what daring theatrical magic Miss Caldwell will have conjured up next, international superstars turn down lucrative contracts to assay new roles with her, and operatic pilgrims by the busload travel hundreds of miles to attend the Boston performances.

title: Patricia Hopkins Birch Bride of Thomas Orafino
Jeanne M. Reardon, Iowa Alumna, Bride Of Arthur Fischer Jr.
description: Jeanne Marie Reardon and Arthuz Louis Fischer Jr. were married yesterday afternoon in the chapel of the Crescent Avenue Presbyterian Church in Plainfield, N. J., by the Rev. Charles Mead.

title: MAJORITY OF DERAILMENTS LINKED TO POOR ROADBEDS
An Urban Policy Memo, to Carter, Apparently Hidden From Cabinet
Newark Salutes
description: NEWARK AS if on cue, thousands of Japanese cherry trees in Branch Brook Park here are opening their buds to herald the start of the third annual Newark Cherry Blossom Festival.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON Census Finds Blacks Leaving State
description: WASHINGTON THE migration of blacks into such northeastern states as New York, New Jersey and Massachusetts continues, but Connecticut is having an opposite trend. Blacks are moving out faster than they are coming in.

title: Airlines at Heathrow Defy TicketSale Ban
Ideas &Trends
description: In January the president of Rockefeller Center set off an orgy of anticipatory mourning by asserting that there was no hope for the survival of Radio City Music Hall. When Alton G. Marshall announced that the theater was losing millions every year and that the Rockettes would kick their last on April 12, New Yorkers lamented that closing the grand Art Deco theater would be like tearing down the Statue of Liberty.

title: BRIDGE
description: Perhaps the most embarrassing situation that can happen in tournament play occurs when a knockout match is over and an appeals committee has to make a decision that could change the result of the match. An appeal has been lodged against a director's ruling, so a small group of experts is drafted by the tournament chairman for the thankless task. The committee disappears reluctantly into a side room and hears the evidence. The players huddle nervously in the corridor, waiting for the decision that will determine which group is eliminated from the event.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY If She Asked Him, He Could Write a Book
description: Now I know how Mr. Bombeck feels. And Mr. Jong. My wife has written a book. And a publisher has even published it.

title: 4 Young Men and a Woman Killed In a Fire After Schenectady Party
description: Four young men and a woman were killed in a fire that broke out M an apartment in Schenectady, N.Y., after an allnight farewell party for a friend who had enlisted in the Air Force.

title: Talks in Yonkers School Strike Adjourned Without a Settlement
description: Talks aimed at ending a fivedayold strike by nonteaching employees at 40 schools in Yonkers recessed last night without a settlement between the city's Board of Education and Local 9169 of the Civil Service Employees Association. The union represents 1,100 workers.

title: Baryshnikov Is a Cowboy In Feld's Santa Fe Saga
The World
description: MANILA  There Is a long tradition In the Philippines, a tendency for Filipinos to act out their political dramas for an unseen American audience that is assumed to be watching. In part, this may be a result of the Philippines heritage as a former American colony. But the tendency also arises from the often controversial role the United States still plays in the islands.

title: Article 1  No Title
ART Art That Beguiles As It Provokes
description: PAUL WALDMAN is a debunker of art myths, a scrappy iconoclast who challenges esthetic traditions with authority and verve. His paintings, for example, are an effective rebuttal to those classic distinctions many of us make between realism and abstraction. His figurative imagery can appear abstract, and he can endow the abstract with persuasive realist qualities. He negates the established differences between painting and sculpture: what is sculptural in his work can seem very painterly, while his twodimensional representations can seem to belong to a threedimensional realm.

title: POINT OF VIEW
Senate Panel Fails to Approve Carter Nominee for Judiciary
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)The Senate Judiciary Committee, In a tie vote yesterday, failed to approve President Carter's nomination of Robert F. Collins as a Federal judge.

title: MARKETS
