description: The stock market erupted In a rousing rally Friday in the heaviest trading in the history of the New York Stock Exchange. The Dow Jones industrial average soared 19.92 points to finish the week with a gain of 25.55 points to 795.13. The surge was the largest daily advance for the Dow in more than a year and a half.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Carter's Idea Is to Cut Back on Inflation.
description: WASHINGTON  It's been a trying 15 months for the frazzled Keyncsians in the Carter White House, as repeatedly they have found that the economy doesn't behave as expected.

title: Checks Sent to Retired Miners
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPIPension checks have been mailed to 80,600 retired United Mine Workers who did not receive monthly payments during the 110day miners strike. Trustees for the union's health and retirement fund said yesterday that the fund has obtained an $85 million loan to allow makeup payments for those missed in February and March.

title: Andrew Davis, the Model of a JetAge Conductor
description: Andrew Davis has been living the life of a jetage conductor lately, and with a vengeance. Since January, he has brought Mahler to the land of Chairman Mao, conducting eight concerts, several of them in an 18,000seat Chinese stadium. In this country his assignments have included nine concerts with the New York Philharmonic, five with the Cleveland Orchestra and four with the San Francisco Symphony. He has flown nearly 20,000 miles in 12 weeks, and on Saturday night the 34year old British conductor will arrive in Carnegie Hall to lead the Toronto Symphony, over which he has presided as music director for the past three years.

title: DINING OUT A Taste of Tokyo in Greenwich
description: There is nothing pretentious about Kagetsu, which is outfitted and furnished like the traditional mingei or folkart restaurants that can be found throughout Japan. The natural pine walls and posts, ricepaperlike panels and screens, carefully matched designs on chair backs and menus, and naturalmaple butcherblock tables all seem chosen for authenticity and attractiveness.

title: Miss Muldaur Extends Range Beyond Folk
description: The Maria Muldaur who opened the show for David Bromberg on Friday night at Avery Fisher Hall was a rather different Maria Muldaur from the one who last performed in New York, in 1976.

title: A DES Victim Tells of Anger, Awareness and Despair.
description: I AM a DES daughter, and I hate it. DES is diethylstilbestrol, a synthetic hormone given to women in this country from the early 1990's to the early 1970's, when doctors finally realized that the drug not only did not prevent miscarriages but also increased substantially the risk of cancer to the estimated six million children born of these mothers.

title: 2 Women Pin Down Apartment Intruder
description: A 72yearold woman and her 44yearold daughter battled a man who had broken into their apartment on Morningside Heights last night and held the intruder until help arrived, according to the police.

title: SHOP TALK A Source For Judaica
description: LAWRENCE AT certain times, in certain seasons, shopping is a ritual of celebration and tradition, guided more by sentiment than necessity. Jewish families preparing for Passover in suburbia, for example, go beyond the supermarket for their holiday provisions.

title: Future Events
description: April 21Imagine viewing art right from the pews in the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest! The Rev. Alanson B. Houghton, the new rector, wants all of the church to be a gallery for the 13th annual spring art festival at which parishioners and their neighbors in the Fifth Avenue and 90th Street area can show that they can paint and sculpture. The Fifth Avenue doors to the church open for the show from 6 to 8 P.M. tonight with some champagne to inspire bidding in the silent auction for the art on display. Tickets to the opening: S5 at the door, or from AT 93400. The next day, April 22, from noon to 6 P.M., and April 23 from noon to 2 P.M., admission to the show and sale is free. Heavenly Rest's aim is to encourage new artists and use proceeds of the festival for community projects supported by its churchwomen.

title: BEHIND THE BEST SELLERS
description: Robert Ludlum, 51, author of The Holcroft Covenant, used to work in the theateras an actor, voiceover on television commercials and producer. That experience helps him play his present role of bestselling novelist.

title: Late TV Listings
description: 11:30 A.M. (Channel 2) Face the Nation: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. of Tennessee, the minority leader.

title: The Farms of Suburbia
description: AFTER the Long Island Rail Road trains slide westward out of Huntington Station, they pass the kind of industrial backyards that so often abut railroad tracks. Unattracted by views of pressed car Mimes and concrete cesspool forms, must riders quickly immerse themselves in their newspaper.

title: East and West: Equally Odd Information About One Another
description: When you visit China, you should have no trouble telling the Chinese from the Westerners. The Chinese have red hair, blue eyes. The Westerners have red and white faces. The Roman writer Pliny offers the first description, a Chinese historian gives the second. EastWest misconceptions like this have been around for a long time.

title: R. Anne Davis and Gordon Auchincloss 2d, Partners in Writing Project, Are Wed
description: R. Anne Davis and Gordon Auchincloss 2d were married yesterday in Rumson, N. J., by Mayor John O. Teeter in his Borough Hall office.

title: For Window Guards, Resistance and Uncertainty
description: Last March 28, Corey Houston, 3 years old, chased the family cat out through an open window onto a ledge, reached for it and fell six stories to his death.

title: Kenneth Irvine, Banker, Weds Bettina Brown
Freedom Sought for Ulster Woman Accused of Killing Abusive Father
description: BELFAST, Northern Ireland, April 15 (Reuters)Women's rights groups have begun a campaign to free a 21yearold woman sentenced to seven years imprisonmnt for killing her father after having suffered years of sexual abuse by him.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Questions/Answers
description: Is there a way to get around using chemical sprays for fruit trees? The nectarines and apricots produced fruits last season but they were dry and mushy. Some fruit was scabby. I use dormant oil, but would like to avoid chemical sprays. Mrs. M.S., Fresh Meadows, N. Y .

title: Wine
description: JEREZ, Spain. They tell the story here about the time a few years ago when Henry Ford 2d was entertained by the Domecqs, the great sherry family, who live in a baronial style undreamed of in Grosse Pointe.

title: E.R.A., Of Course Just No Extension
description: We argued last week against extension of the sevenyear deadline, which expires next March, for ratification of the Equal Rights Amendment. Somehow that statement caused some readers to conclude that we have lost enthusiasm for the amendment itself. Quite the contrary. The amendment is needed, and we ardently hope for its ratification by the required three more states by that deadline. Sex discrimination is still deeply ingrained in our laws, in our customs and in our habits. A constitutional declaration, at last, of the equality of the sexes can be a major weapon in the effort to eradicate that discrimination.

title: Gayle Pearson Sets A July 29 Wedding To Stephen James
Treasure Hunter In the Wine Cellar
description: HARTFORD BACK in the early 1950's, when one had to be 21 years old to drink in New Jersey, Sandy McNally had to resort to subterfuge to buy his wine. Memorizing handful of names in Alexis Lichine's The Wines of France, the 18yearold freshman marched into a Princeton wine shop and asked: What have you got in a good pommard?

title: TV VIEW
description: The story is gripping, the acting competent, the message compellingand yet. The calculated brutality of the killers, the silent agony of the victims, the indifference of the outside worldthis TV series will show what some survivors have been trying to say for years and years. And yet something is wrong with it. Something? No: everything.

title: The Nation; In Summary Canal Treaty Is Far From Locked Up Energy Is Still One Long Haggle Pension Changes For Military? Spit and Polish, Hairwise; In Ohio, School May Be Out
description: Until last month, Dennis DeConcini had distinguished himself as a freshman Senator mostly by proposing a constitutional amendment, unlikely to go very far, which would limit members of Congress to a fixed number of terms. Not much of a wagon to hitch a star to. But on Tuesday the Senate will vote on the treaty that transfers control of the Panama Canal to Panama in the year 2000, and largely because of Mr. DeConcini not only is ratification in doubt but the Panamanians may be too angry to accept the treaty even if the Senate does approve it.

title: An Appeal for Initiative
description: DURING the spring of 1977 the members of the Westchester County Board of Legislators showed the ultimate expression of confidence in the public's ability to he partners in the legislative process. After a twoyear campaign Westchester became the first county in New York State to seek state authorization to allow its voters the right to propose laws and place them on the ballot, thus bypassing the county legislature.

title: New Study Shows Decline in Fertility Of Catholic Women
FILM VIEW
description: The interior monologue went something like this: No .... I'm not going to write anything about the Oscar show. It's impossible to say something that someone hasn't already said before, except maybe about ... The Oscars are too easy to knock over, like old people on upper Broadway. There's no sport in it anymore, not even for the hitandrun drivers, but then ... But then . . . Resolve evaporated.

title: Reporter's Notebook: Rangers Home In Buffalo Was Heartbreak Hotel
description: The New York Rangers had lost their previous I I games in Buffalo Memorial Auditorium, and they had often stayed at the Statler Hilton Hotel during the slump. But the Ranger general manager, John Ferguson, grows superstitious during playoffs. Last Tuesday the team stayed at an airport hotel.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Scales are those sneaky insects that do a splendid job of hiding themselves until they get hungry. When they start to feed, their cover is blown. Scales keep themselves alive by sucking the sap from plant leaves and stems. This type of dining causes dark brown spots or stipules in the leaves and on the stems. If many of them develop, rapid defoliation and weakening of the plant follows. When enough of this sort of evidence appears, gardeners begin to take notice and realize that their plants have company.

title: Marriage Announcement 6  No Title
description: Julia M. Bady Is Betrothed

title: DANCE VIEW
description: Just when it seemed the Joffrey Ballet was going to become the chief American repository for Frederick Ashton's ballets or the chief American repository for Leonide Massine's ballets or the main American repository for Kurt Jooss's ballets, it turns out to be the main American repository for John Cranko's ballets.

title: Torrijos Is Optimistic on Treaties
description: CONTADORA ISLAND, Panama, April 15Panama's chief of government, Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, today ex pressed confidence that everything will work out well with the Panama Canal treaties, which face a final vote in the United States Senate on Tuesday.

title: POLITICS A Ward System For North Salem?
description: WHITE PLAINS THE Town of North Salem in the upper reaches of Westchester is providing the only political battle in the county in this quiet season when the chief activity of the political parties is finding and assessing potential candidates for the many offices at stake in the November election.

title: 63 at Fort Wayne Rock Concert Held on Drug and Alcohol Charges
description: FORT WAYNE, Ind., April 15 (AP)Two members of the Bob Seger rock band entourage were Among. 63 persons arrest. ed by the Fort Wayne police last night on drug and alcohol charges at the Allen County Memorial Coliseum.

title: Assertions, Appreciations
description: I AM neither historian nor philosopher, says the poet Howard Nemerov in Figures of Thought, a volume of subtly linked literary essays, and this is not the occasion for a philosophical discourse or one on the history of mind. Flanks covered. scouts out. whereupon a critic is free to do what he pleases, including history and philosophy. There is, in fact, rather more of both in this book than in most such collections. At the core of the majority of the piecesthe subjects include Dante, Joyce, the nature of modern poetry and the sins of contemporary criticism  lies an assumption about the direction of the modern history of the mind. And it's when the essayist bends intensely to the work of explaining complicated moments, in that history  the emergence, for instance, of the poetic mode called Imagism, or of the occupation called English teachingthat he achieves his most admirable effects.

title: Back to the South Pacific
description: What mudstained, mosquitobitten United States marine, warily slogging along a steaming jungle trail on Guadalcanal in the South Pacific in World War II, could have imagined that this wild, hot, malariaridden island would have a tourist bureau in its future? Or that any veteran of the Solomons campaign, where the environment was as much an enemy as the Japanese, would ever want to go back?

title: Malle: Pretty Baby Could Be Called The Apprenticeship of Corruption
Best Sellers
description: The listings above are based on computerprocessed sales figures from 1. 100 book stores in every region of the United States.

title: Difficulties Make Trading Scarce in N.F.L. Market
description: Will the Tampa Bay Buccaneers accept the best of many offers from other teams and trade their upcoming No. I draft choice, the one ostensibly marked for Earl Campbell, the Texas running back and Heisman Trophy winner? That question has had top priority in National Football League circles for our months now, and nothing has happened.

title: Paperback Best Sellers
description: Massmarket paperbacks are softcover books sold at newsstands. variety stores and supermarkets, us well as in bookstores. This listing is bused on computerprocessed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across flu? United States.

title: Carter's Plan Puts
description: With pledges of money and promises of sustained effort, Federal and New York City officials last week announced the start of a sevenyear effort to rebuild the South Bronx, a ravaged area that has come to symbolize urban decline across the United States. The harsh reality, however, is that the South Bronx is only one of a score of devastated and deteriorating areas in the city. And one of the major challenges in dealing with these areas is providing decent housing for their residents.

title: Galileo
description: By luck, irony or impudence, actorproducer Laurence Luckinbill has hit upon the one right place in all the world to show us Bertolt Brecht's Galileo once again. A science lab. No, not a lab precisely, but a classroom, seats raked high so that green blackboards (has anyone ever called them greenboards?) and demonstration counters can be observed by one and all as they scribble their notes on the armrests provided for the purpose. The classroom is in Columbia University's Havemeyer Hall. It had been occupied by nurses taking exams before the audience could be admitted for the preview I saw, and the members of Mr. Luckinbill's youngish, bustling and remarkably cheerful New York Actors Theater dart about on the limited lecturespace uniformly dressed smocks.

title: 2 Key Issues Face Legislative Action
description: TRENTON

title: CHESS
description: Symmetrical, or nearly symmetrical, pawn formations have often been despised as leading to dull draws. That's why the great Alexander Alekhine, world champion from 1927 to 1935 and from 1937 to his death in 1996, took pains to avoid them.

title: Marriage Announcement 2  No Title
description: Arlene Hayman Married

title: Article 2  No Title
INTERVIEW
description: VALHALLA A VISITOR to the Mental Retardation Institute in Valhalla was stunned recently to see a group of children who were blind and deaf as well as retarded flock to a staff member, Hisako Cunningham, as she entered the room.

title: Fraud in Federal Aid May Exceed $12 Billion Annually, Experts Say
description: WASHINGTON, April 15Fraud in Federal aid programs has grown to the point at which, some experts say, its annual cost may exceed $12 billion. But many agencies have not yet established the mechanisms to detect, let alone prevent, fraud in their programs.

title: Even an Ayckbourn Can Misfire
CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: Shelves are overflowing with books that promise to teach you everything about one thing, such as love, death or macram. This book succeeds: 32 pages on popcorn  in color. Not only are there explicit instructions for popping, but a somewhat limited view of history: Columbus saw Indians wearing popcorn as jewelry, Americans use 500 million pounds of popcorn each year, archeologists found 5,600yearold popped corn in a bat cave in New Mexico. Maybe the cave was an ancient Loews.

title: The Turnpike Plays It Safe
description: EAST BRUNSWICK A MODERN, integrated radio system and a network of electronic traffic sensors have helped the New Jersey Turnpike, consistently among the nation's leaders in service and safety, to set records for both in 1977.

title: News Summary
description: SUNDAY, APRIL 18, 1978

title: BloodDonor Drive Is Stepped Up
description: The Greater New York Blood Program has stepped up its donorrecruiting activities in an effort to avert a repetition of the bloodsupply shortage that hit the metropolitan area last January.

title: Michael Dells Sherwood, Lawyer, Weds Nancy Hoy
description: Nancy Elizabeth Hoy, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Hoy of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday in St. Agnes Roman Catholic Church to Michael DeIfs Sherwood, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Ben Sherwood of Vestal, N.Y. Msgr. Robert J. Coll of Allentown, Pa., performed the cemnony.

title: Siberian Lake Now a Model Of Soviet Pollution Control
Heartland Chronicle
description: SINCE turning from journalism to fiction eight years ago, Ward Just has become one of the small number of American writers trying to maintain the imaginative connection between public and private so damaged by the discovery of The Novel and the retreat to The University. Novels about novels, he understands, are best left to be written by geniuses and read by students. The ordinary journalistic novel, bales of topical information punctuated by onesentence paragraphs and held together with rhetorical questions, is likewise a bore.

title: Fast Woman
description: Janet Guthrie is a slender physicist with a good deal of red in her lightbrown hair and with eyes that seem to change from blue to gray to hazel depending on how vigorously she defending auto racing as a sport and woman's place in it. She is taller than Cale Yarborough, comelier than Mario Andretti, lighter than .Buddy Baker, or Neil Bonnett or Butch Hartmann or Bobby Allison. Last May she became the first woman to qualify for the Indianapolis 500 by doing four laps at an average speed of 188.404 miles an hour, which was faster than the qualifying times of 15 of the 32 men who started. Her car conked out early but she is going hack next month for another try at the age of 40. and at various times she has driven faster than Clay Regazzoni or Richard Petty or David Pearson or Johnny Rutherford Why? she was asked at lunch with three male chauvinist pigs.

title: PEOPLE
description: This may be one small step for America, but it is one giant step for Volkswagen. With these words Toni Schmcker, chairman of Volkswagenwerk, last week heralded the first Volkswagen to come off an American assembly line, at the company's plant in New Stanton, Pa. The VW, a white Rabbit, is headed back to the company's museum in West Germany.

title: Latins Reviving Isolated Region At Land's End
Hartford Proposes to Enact an Ordinance Protecting Homosexuals
WORKING HOURS FOUND CUT BY NEGATIVE INCOME TAX
LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: INVESTING
description: When a Wall Streeter says he's going naked, it means he has every intention of soon wearing customtailored suits. He's talking about the highflying world of options trading.

title: Connecticut/This Week
description: AVONSpring classes and workshops begin Monday, Farmington Valley Arts Center, Inc., Avon Park North. Information and registration, 6781867.

title: GARDENING
description: SEVERAL balmy pleasant weekends in a row have made Fairfield County gardeners slightly more than euphoric. Everyone, it seems, is out on these favored days raking, pruning and cleaning up.

title: Headliners
description: The life story (is he alive?) of David Graiver, an Argentine financier, remains bizarre at every turn. Mr. Gralver was reported killed in a Mexican plane crash in 1976 but last week he was indicted by a New York grand jury for allegedly helping loot more than $30 million from the American Bank and Trust Company, which collapsed in 1976 in the fourth largest bank failure in United States history. The grand jury apparently believed they were not indicting a dead man, said District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau, although he declined to provide any evidence to the contrary. According to the indictments Mr. Graiver and four other bank officials siphoned off funds from American Bank and Trust to a Belgian bank owned by the Graiver family and then to companies  some of them dummies  also owned by the family. The Belgian bank has since collapsed. The Argentine Government earlier had charged that Mr. Graiver was a financial adviser for the Montoneros, a leftist terrorist group, and they have suggested that Montonero money was used by Mr. Graiver to seek control of American Bank and Trust. Eight relatives and former employees of Mr. Graiver were sentenced to long jail terms in Argentina for allegedly helping the guerrillas. The Graivers are Jewish and their prosecution raised charges of antiSemitism on the part of the ultraconservative Argentine military Government. Mr. Morgenthau said the aid of Interpol, the international police organization, would be invoked in the search for Mr. Graiver; meanwhile, the Manhattan grand jury that indicted him has been extended through 1979; it is expected to investigate the possibility of other crimes, on the theory that if Mr. Graiver is indeed still alive, the pilots who died in the plane crash have been murdered.

title: Pace at Roosevelt To Seedling Herbert
description: WESTBURY, L.I., April 15Seedling Herbert upset the heavily favored Senor Skipper at Roosevelt Raceway tonight in the $35,000 Old Country Pace and then had to survive a stewards inquiry.

title: Dead Financier Indicted in Fraud
description: David Graiver, an Argentine financier was reported killed in a privateplane crash near Acapulco in August 1976. Last week he was indicted on charges of misappropriating millions of dollars from the defunct American Bank and Trust Company of which he was a director. Four other officials of the bank were also indicted.

title: A Nighttime Small Claims Court
description: A NEW night court will open May 2 for Nassau County consumers and merchants seeking legal relief for small claims. But it will have to demonstrate that it needed to remain open.

title: Preserving History in Canterbury
description: CANTERBURY AFTER years of delay, controversy and financing problems, restoration of the stateowned Prudence Crandall house, site of the country's first school for blacks, is finally expected to begin this spring. By early 1979, the historical house should be open to the public

title: Any Volunteers?; Carter Program Asks for Wage, Price Restraints Justice Remembers L. Patrick Gray Americanization Of Mr. Shevchenko Badillo Almost Stepped Down
description: sur prise: to take unawares; to cause to feel wonder or astonishment. In economic terms, there was none of that in the antiinflation initiatives President Carter proposed last week.

title: NEW EVIDENCE LINKS CUBANS TO LETELIER
Miracle in the Kitchen, A Fortune in the Bank
description: STAMFORD WHEN a housewife turns some consuming interest into a profitable business, it is frequently called luck. But when a businessman does the same thing, it is called skill. In the case of Carl Sontheimer and his wildly successful Cuisinart food processor, it is skill with a certain amount of luck thrown in.

title: Campus Activist, President's Wife
Italian Sailing Ship Campaigning To Save the Seas From Pollution
Rep. Howard Suffers Heart Attack
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)Representative James J. Howard, Democrat of New Jersey, was convalescing today at Bethesda Naval Hospital after a mild heart attack. Dr. Freeman H. Carey said that Mr. Howard suffered the attack yesterday while undergoing tests. He entered the hospital Tuesday with chest pains, the doctor said.

title: JEWISH SECT WANTS JORDAN TO ALLOW PRAYER AT WALL
description: JERUSALEM, April 15A group of extreme Orthodox Jews who are fervent antiZionists plans to send a delegation to Jordan during the Passover holiday to seek permission from King Hussein to pass through his landnow in Zionist captivity in order to reach the Wailing Wall in Jerusalem's Old City.

title: The Nation
LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: It seems that every so often one of the flightier antiabortionists sees fit to equate the aborting of human embryos with the atrocities of Hitler's Holocaust [Behind the Abortion Vote, March 19]. How can the one even begin to suggest the other? For people to believe that it does is itself a kind of atrocity.

title: Dog Show Calendar
description: TodayPalisades Kennel Club breed and obedience match, New Jersey Boystown, Kearny, N.J.; entries from 9:30 A.M.; judging of working breeds and obedience 11:30 A.M.; all other breeds at noon.

title: 2 Killed and 4 Hurt in Air Crash
description: FORT IRWIN, Calif., April 15 (UPI) An Air Force C130 Hercules crashed before dawn today, killing two men and injuring four others. Two of the injured were hospitalized in critical condition, the other two were treated at the base for less serious Injuries. Their identities were withheld. The cause of the crash near a dry lake in the Mojave Desert on maneuvers was not immediately determined.

title: More Than 2 Feet of Snow Falls In Central and Southern France
description: PARIS, April 15 (AP)More than two feet of snow fell in parts of central and southern France today as an April cold snap, described by the French weather service as the worst in 30 years, gripped the nation

title: Fire Department in Boston Reports Gas Masks Reduce Smoke Injury
description: BOSTON, April 15 (AP)The Boston fire department's rule that firefighters should use gas masks has paid off, says Fire Commissioner Georee Paul.

title: MUSIC
Seven Places To Swing Into Spring
description: SPRING programs are set at nature preserves and conservancies in Westchester, and there is a sense of excitement, like that of a new musical season, in the air.

title: Medical Aides Find Bleak Job Future
description: LYONS NEW JERSEY's first class of physician assistants was graduated last year from Rutgers, the State University, but not one of the graduates has been able to practice the new healthcare specialty in the state.

title: Connecticut Has Its Ethics Laws, but Only on Paper
description: HARTFORD  Connecticut's General Assembly passed two ethics laws last year  one for legislators and state officials, the other for lobbyists  but the commission that is supposed to enforce both laws is so wrapped up in procedural issues and legislative and court challenges that it has had little time to look for violations.

title: The World
description: Marshall D. Shulman, the former head of Columbia University's Russian Institute, holds a unique place in official Washington. He has the dual titles of Ambassador and special adviser to Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance on Soviet affairs. As such he is the Carter Administration's ranking expert on the Soviet Union and has become deeply involved the formulation of Administration policy. He will he accompanying Mr. Vance to Moscow this week for an important round of negotiations aimed at narrowing differences in the .Strategic Arms Limitation Talks.

title: Union Accord to Cut Reactor Cost Reported to Carter
description: WASHINGTON, April 15President Carter is expected to announce next week an agreement between the building trades unions and contractors that is intended to reduce the cost of building atomic reactors.

title: Anne Bishop Is Fiancee Of Marvin Cheiten, Writer
DANCE MAILBAG
description: In her review in The Times on March 28 of the film version of the ballet La Sylphide, staged by Pierre Lacotte, Anna Kisselgoff raised questions about the stylistic and dramatic aspects of the production. She said they were out of kilter with what we know about Romantic ballet in general and La Sylphide in particular [and] that it is difficult to have confidence in the authenticity of the choreography itself. In the following column, Mr. Lacotte supports his artistic decisions, and Miss Kisselgoff replies.

title: School to Give Credit For Amusement Rides
description: BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, April 15 (AP)Students can earn academic credit by riding roller coasters and writing about the experience in a threeday course being offered this summer by Bowling Green State University.

title: Westway Plan Is Changed to Bypass the Wholesale MeatMarket Area
Volatile Gas Shipments in New York Raising Concern of Safety Officials
A Presumptuous Venture
description: The Nazi Holocaust is a historic fact of such awesome proportions that it still generally defies the probings of art. Full comprehension perhaps demands genius, and therefore great literature on the subject is understandably skimpy and usually rather fragmented in scope. When television, then, attempts to stuff 10 years of fanatical persecution and indescribable suffering into seven and one half hours (that is what's left of nine and one half hours after commercials and station breaks), it needs considerably more than the screenplay fashioned by novelist Gerald Green.

title: DINING OUT
description: THE VIENNESE COACH in Syosset is an old standby  sedate, wellbred and utterly professional. Like Vienna, it is gracious without style or excitement.

title: BOOK ENDS
THEATER Disappointing Tribute To Jerome Kern
description: STAMFORD FOR its final offering of the season, the Hartman Theater Company is honoring Jerome Kern with a musical revue built around 33 of the composer's melodies. The songs selected are, for the most part, the bestknown out of a gigantic output of melody. The tribute to Kern is a fine idea; the execution at the Hartford  and it was that  is something else.

title: U.N. Offers Help to Vietnamese At Oil Platforms Near Malaysia
description: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 15 (Reuters)  The United Nations High Commission for Refugees offered today to give temporary shelter to 261 Vietnamese refugees who boarded an oil platform's supply ship yesterday 135 miles off eastern Malaysia and refused to leave.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: Down with cash! Up with barter! chant the perfervid authors of this evangelical work. They don't really mean you should abandon money entirely. but they do think people should look more closely at chances to make an endrun around the cash nexus. Accordingly, they catalogue hundreds of ways that modern folk can swap what they have for what they want: houses here for houses there; babysitting now for babysitting later. They do not shrink from acknowledging sexual barter, both informal and organized in swingers magazines, On a higher plane, they mention a literary barter: the novelist David Milofsky traded his skills, worked as editor of the daily newspaper at the Bread Loaf Writers Conference in Vermont in exchange for free tuition, room and board.

title: The Great Panama Debate, and How It Grew
description: WASHINGTON  We have an opportunity, In an atmosphere free from crisis, to demonstrate how a large nation can work with a small nation, said Senator Charles H. Percy of Illinois. We can show our willingness to be responsive to the aspirations of a small nation while maintaining our ability to meet our responsibilities as a great power.

title: Mary O'Hara Returns to Singing
description: Mary O'Hara's life story is something only the most inspired press agent could ever hope to concoct. Born in Ireland and educated in a convent, she became a singing star at the age of 16. During the late 1950's, she toured Europe, Australia, Canada and the united States. singing in a striking, pure soprano and accompanying 11CFself on the Irish harp. She met, fell in love with and married Richard Selig, a young American poet, and they moved to New York, but soon a routine medical examination revealed that Mr. Selig had an incurable disease. Fifteen months later he died, and Miss O'Hara abandoned her career and entered a monastery, where she remained for 12 years.

title: Getting the Most out of Clothes
description: Before you can pull your wardrobe together, you must know what you already have. Set aside time for a review. Go through your closets and drawers and take out all your business clothes  suits, jackets, slacks, shirts and ties. Lay them out on your bed in separate piles.

title: Jane Wales, Aide At White House, Wed to Lawyer
Wright Is Convicted On Extortion Charge
description: City Councilman Samuel D. Wright was convicted yesterday of extortion and conspiracy to defraud the United States in a $5,000 kickback scheme.

title: Cornell Wins 34th Straight In Lacrosse
description: BALTIMORE. April 15Cornell is ranked No. I in the country in lacrosse and today showed No. 2 Johns Hopkins why this is so.

title: Music: Debuts in Review
description: Hanwon Choi, whose New York debut recital took place April 8 at Carnegie Recital Hall, is a young Korean violinist with a master's degree from Juilliard. She proved to be a formidable instrumentalist with plenty of temperament. From an interpretive standpoint, her playing was neither perfunctory, on the one hand, nor tremendously interesting, on the other.

title: RANGEL TOPS RATINGS FOR LIBERAL RECORD
description: WASHINGTON, April 15Representative Charles B. Rangel, Democrat of Harlem, has New York State's most liberal voting record in the current Congress, according to newly available ratings made by major liberal and conservative organizations.

title: Marriage Announcement 1  No Title
description: Alicia Fox Is Married

title: The New Migrant Militancy
description: HOUSTON  In Arizona a few months ago, several hundred farm workers brought in to handle the winter harvest suddenly climbed down from the t horny citrus trees, laid their heavy canvas bags on the ground and announced that they were on strike. They would not pick again, the hands declared, until the citrus growers provided a few amenities, such as latrines and some relief from the choking chemicals spewed by crop dusters.

title: Around the Nation
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)A strike by 53 physicians serving more than 100,000 patients under a health plan in the nation's capital and in neighboring communities forced the closing of clinics today for all but emergency services.

title: Farewell to a Master Builder
description: STONY BROOK ON a recent chilly evening, John Sampson Toll went for a walk near the student union building of the State University Center here. For a man whose face usually looks as though he's smiling even when he isn't, his expression that night was of a reflectiveness that seemed completely out of character.

title: SUTTON BIDS G.O.P. BUILD STRENGTH AMONG BLACKS
description: Percy E. Sutton, former Manhattan Borough President and a lifelong Democrat, urged the New York City Black Republican Council yesterday to build up its ranks with a vigorous organizing drive.

title: A Man of Many Words
Dancing Figures
description: EVALUATION of art by scorecard is nothing new. Variety, the trade paper, gives us the boxoffice gross on performingarts groups all the time. Still, it comes as a surprise thatthe longawaited authorized history of American Ballet Theater by a highly informed insider would read like a balance sheet tallying hits and flops, rather than as an artistic profile.

title: POLITICS The Stars Come Out To Raise Funds
description: IT'S going to be Jack Nicholson, Robert Redford and others vs. Brendan T. Byrne in the coming weeks as the fundraising efforts of Bill Bradley and Richard C. Leone to gain the Democratic nomination for United States Senator pick up steam.

title: 54% VOTED N 76 ELECTION
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (AP)Participation of eligible voters in the 1976 Presidential election dropped to the lowest level since 1948, largely as a result of the apathy of the new young voters, according to the Census Bureau.

title: For State's Welfare Recipients, Half a Loaf
description: NEW HAVEN BETTY Ann Conroy's apartment is painstakingly decorated. The livingroom end table and her daughter's dresser were retrieved through many trashing expeditions to neighborhoods where richer people throw away such things. The kitchen table was bought new, but only after months deliberation as to whether the family's welfare income was sufficient to afford it.

title: Charlotte Lyeth Is Fiancee of Michael Dively
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jervis Campbell Webb of Riverdale, the Bronx; Detroit and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Webb's daughter. Charlotte Dobson Lyeth, to Michael A. Dively, son of George S. Dively of Cleveland and Boca Raton, Fla., and the late Harriet Seeds Dively.

title: Dozens Killed and Over 100 Hurt When 2 Trains Collide in Italy
description: BOLOGNA, Italy, April 15 (UPI)  A VenicetoRome express train collided headon with a local train during a rainstorm today, and three cars pitched down a 60foot embankment, killing dozens and injuring more than 100, the police reported.

title: Trenton Central Captures Relay Carnival at Kearny
description: KEARNY, N.J., April 15Today was John Gregorek's 18th birthday and he celebrated it in the way he likes best: by winning a race. The St. Anthony's High School senior ran the onemile anchor leg in 4 minutes 19 seconds to give the Smithtown, L.I., school the victory in the distance medley at the ninth annual memorial relay carnival.

title: Helping to Cope With Problems Of MiddleAging
PUBLIC AUTHORITIES HELD UNRESPONSIVE
CORRECTION
description: In an article last Sunday about deteriorating water and sewer lines, a contention that San Francisco had ignored changing technology for 30 years was attributed to the city's public works director, S. Myron Tatarian. The quotation should have been attributed to Richard Sklar, the projects director for the city.

title: Rangers Ousted From Playoffs As Sabres Gain on 41 Victory
Malverne Dispute Enters a New Phase
description: MALVERNE THE Malverne school district, which over the last 15 years has grappled with the problem of racial integration, is again embroiled in a bitter dispute over the community's refusal to provide funds to bus black children.

title: Prof. Gail D. Hollister of Fordham Law Engaged to Edward G. Williams, a Lawyer
description: Gail D. Hollister an associate professor of law at Fordham University, and Edward G. Williams, who is with the New Ycrk law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, plan to be married in June.

title: Intruders Deface the Offices Of the Jewish Defense League
White Plains Groups Join Nestl Protest
description: WHITE PLAINS THE babyformula controversy marched into White Plains last week. Church leaders, housewives and children demonstrated at the Nestle subsidiary here protesting the Swiss conglomerate's promotion of infant formula in the developing countries of the third world.

title: HOBBIES AND CRAFTS
description: This book focuses on a talented individual and probes deeply into his art, his energies and his life. Peter Voulkos inspires superlatives and is often credited with being the most innovative, influential and significant force today in liberating clay from traditional forms and giving it sculptural validity.

title: France Widens Authority for Transplants From Dead
description: PARIS, April 15New regulations designed to meet the growing need for organ transplants from the newly deceased are being put into effect in France.

title: Pretoria Wary of West's Plans for Southern Africa
description: PRETORIA, South Africa, April 15 The Western push for internationally acceptable settlements in Rhodesia and SouthWest Africa is likely to get a skeptical reception when the British Foreign Secretary, Dr. David Owen, and Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance meet with Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha here tomorrow.

title: Bands Rock Round the County
description: IT begins in a tiny dressing room, where jeans and a Tshirt are exchanged for a clingy black leotard and tights. Sneakers are next, kicked aside for kneehigh silver kid boots with 6inch platform heels. Finally, fleshtoned base, blushon rouge, mascara and iridescent graygreen eye shadow, all specially formulated to stay fresh under hot stagelights  are carefully stroked into place, until the face staring back from the mirror is readya study of hollow cheeks, huge pale eyes and full pouting lips that will come alive when the music starts.

title: CAMERA
description: Summer workshops, tailored to fit almost any photographer, provide oneweek concentrated summer sessions in the art and craft of photography. They offer the student the chance to eat with, study with, and exchange ideas freely with today's ohotoheros. Energy and enthusiasm run high as students begin seeing immediate results from their hard work and long hours, with an almost total immersion into photography during the entire period.

title: A Dinner Theater For Classic Film Buffs
description: BRISTOL THE dinner theater, a flourishing fixture of entertainment around the state from Darien to East Windsor, is about to go to the movies.

title: SHOP TALK A Haven for Anglers In Fort Lee
description: FISHING is a sport that transcends considerations of age, sex or national origin, according to Ed Graser, resident expert at The Outdoorsman Ltd., a store at 2000 Bigler Avenue in Fort Lee. And in the spring, he noted, its adherents in search of bait, rod and reel quadruple  and then some.

title: The New Science of Fitness
description: The physicalfitness boom is one of the most highly visible patterns of change in the American way of life. Its effects are farranging: A new category of fitness books  the howtodoitbetter book  has emerged as a consistent best seller; health and sports clubs are bigmoney businesses; newsmedia coverage has increased dramatically, with a new focus on the amateur athlete; corporate employers, as well as insurance companies, are investing in programs to make the most of the health and therefore moneysaving benefits of inplant fitness routines. But for the man on his own, a howto book, a pair of running shoes, or an expensive membership in the most popular health club in town is not the ultimate solution to getting  and staying in shape. The untrained or unsupervised amateur can, in fact, cause more harm than good to his complex body systems. Every man's fitness routine must be developed for his individual requirements and capacities  an opinion shared by six members of the Sports Medicine Committee of the United States Olympic Committee, already in active preparation for of game of 1980.

title: McKINLEY KIRKPATRICK
description: WASHINGTON COURT HOUSE, Ohio, April 15 (AP)McKinley Kirkpatrick, a leading amateur harness horse driver, died today at a hospital following a sixmonth illness. He was 81 years old. Mr. Kirkpatrick made racing his hobby in 1940 at age 44 and raised four worldchampion standard breds during his career. He gained more than 380 victories as an amateur driver and his horses collected $330,000 in purses.

title: All the Fears
description: Everyone knows the running fanatics. They claim they achieve the ultimate high through longdistance running. They find running akin to the sexual experience.

title: Cosmos Are Now Source of Happiness for Chinaglia
description: It has been two hours since the Cosmos practice ended, but Giorgio Chinaglia is still in the locker room. He had remained on the Giants Stadium field longer than anyone, practicing his shooting against Erol Yasin, who will start in goal today against the Tulsa Roughnecks.

title: ART
IN BRIEF
description: American businesses continued to consolidate at a heady clip in the first quarter. Announcements of mergers and acquisitions by publicly held companies jumped 89 percent ahead of last year's firstquarter pace, according to the W.T. Grimm Company, a Chicagobased broker that was itself.acquired in January by Midas International, the muffler Maker. secondquarter takeover activity continues robust: Tyco Laboratories, a small New Hampshire maker of technological products, announced that it had increased to 15 percent its stake in CutlerHammer Inc., a Milwaukee electronics manufacturer that promptly won a court order temporarily blocking any further Tyco purchases. ... Pabst Brewing, fighting a bid from the APL Corporation, said it was discussing acquisition of Carling National Brewers.

title: Spencer Haywood's Strange Vibes
description: Skill or hustle, or both, is enough for most good basketball players, most good athletes, for that matter. But with Spencer Haywood of the New York Knicks, vibes seem to he more important than any other factor. Spencer Haywood's skill is obvious and he hustles. As a person, he's friendly and pleasant. But he's also sensitive, which is why the vibes are so important to his performance. Sometimes he appears as if he were out there playing on a different wavelength. There is static with his coach and teammates and the vibes are bad. But then he'll sit down for a talk with Willis Reed, the Knicks coach, and the vibes will be good. As the Knicks await for the opener of their Eastern Conference four of sevengame semifinal series with the 76ers in Philadelphia today, Spencer Haywood's vibes are good. How long they remain good may determine how long the Knicks last.

title: Commuters FightWith Honey
description: WHITE PLAINS ANYONE familiar with the strident and combative approaches some metropolitan area commuter organizations have taken to bring railroad problems to public notice would probably be struck by the contrast of the Upper Harlem Line Commuter Council.

title: SPEAKING PERSONALLY
description: ADULTS go back to college for a variety of reasons, chief among them being that there is nothing more interesting to do. For women with small children, resuming an interrupted education is often major juggling feat. They must juggle their children's schedules and the demands of the house and the spouse with the new demands of the programs and schools in which they enroll.

title: Artistry As Dissent
description: Articles about concerts are rarely printed on newspaper front pages. When the name of a performer does come up in the news, the occasion usually has little to do with art.

title: DINING OUT A Culinary Mecca in Cold Spring
description: WITHOUT any great public pronouncements, a gastronomic event of some import to Westchester diners occurred last December. Gieri Albin and Ans Benderer, the maitre d'htel and chef, respectively, of the wellrespected Stonehenge, took over the ownership of Plumbush in Cold Spring. An unspoiled Hudson River town known to us mostly as the home of Gus's Antique Bar (where fine German beer on draft used to be served in chilled mugs), Cold Spring may now become a mecca for serious gourmets.

title: A Punk Tests Polish Police In Crime Film
Presley Fans Ask for Holiday
description: WASHINGTON, April 15 (UPI)About 300 Elvis Presley fans demonstrated at the White House today, urging President Carter and Congress to declare the late singer's birthday, Jan. 8, a national holiday.

title: Jazz in Europe Is Alive and Swinging
description: After Ellington's CJam Blues, the leader may step to the mike and say, Merci, merci. Did you dig? or Are you digging ze sounds? It gives an American a start, but it's evidence that jazz is hot in Europe and the melody alive and well.

title: A Divided Freehold to Vote on Pool
description: FREEHOLD THEY trudged through three winter snowstorms to get hundreds of signatures on their Petitions. They confronted the Mayor, the Municipal Clerk and the Township Committee and demanded a vote, asserting that they had the right to approve plans for a $950,000 municipal pool scheduled to be opened this summer.

title: WHAT WILL HENRY DO FOR AN ENCORE?; KISSINGER; KISSINGER
description: Bunched together in the large, elegant foyer of Israeli Ambassador Simcha Dinitz's home in northwest Washington, a pool of reporters, cameramen and technicians waited, an unsatisfied lot entangled in cables. They had already shot or interviewed Prime Minister Menachem Begin, Vice President Walter Mondale, former Vice President Nelson Rockefeller, Senators Edward Kennedy and Charles Percy, among others. However, their professional instincts told them that they didn't have their story yet. Then, suddenly, it arrived.

title: Retirement: The New Law's Impact
description: Legislation extending the nation's mandatory retirement age to 70 is going to have a far more profound impact on our society than most people realize, said Reeve Darling, a Los Anseles management consultant. He was voicing a concern widely felt in industry and academia  despite assurances by proponents of the legislation that the impact will be minimal.

title: POSTWAR GROWTH OF NASSAU IS OVER
description: The postWorld War II growth of Nassau County, fueled in part by the phenomenon of Levittown, has come to a halt. This is largely because it has become almost completely developed, because much of the housing that is available is too expensive for young couples, and because, with a maturing of the population. the number of deaths is approaching the number of births.

title: European Women Are Being Lured to Prostitution in Mideast
description: VIENNA, April 15Police agencies and social workers in Central Europe are worrying about what they say is a striking increase in the number of young women who disappear and all too often turn up later as prostitutes in the Middle East.

title: 2 TAXRELIEF PLANS FOR COLLEGE COSTS ENACTED BY ALBANY
description: New York State has quietly introduced two major programs of incometax relief for 600,000 families sending children through college and millions more who intend to do so.

title: GARDENING A Touch of Gold For a May Garden
description: GOLD dust Basketofgold. Madwort. By whatever name, Alyssum saxatile, now Aurinia saxatitis, is a perennial treasure that adds an airy, elegant fluff of bright yellow bloom to my May garden. And the grayishgreen spreading foliage is ornamental the year round, except, of course, when it is buried under snow.

title: Bernadette Sullivan, Fashion Editor, Bride
Images of the Holocaust
description: The entry for Holocaust in the Encyclopedia Judaica accompanied by several pages of photographs taken in Europe in the 1930's and 40's: A congregation of Jews to sing Nazi songs in a BadenBaden synagogue. Jews in Vienna scrubbing a street under the eyes of the Hitler Youth. The synagogue in Landau on fire. The windows of a Jewishowned shop in Magdeburg smashed during Kristallnacht. Women and children, all wearing yellow stars, arriving at Auschwitz. Naked people lined up for execution at a mass grave in Lithuania. The heaps of corpses found by the British when they liberated the concentration camp at BergenBelsen.

title: Letters: West Germany Pays Homage to Handel
description: To the Editor:

title: Betsy Pitman Fiancee of Frederick Savage
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Vaughan Parker Pitman of Hollis, N.H., of the engagement of their dlughter, Betsy Jane Pitman, to Frederick van Cortlandt Savage, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Halsted Savage of New York and Minerva, N.Y.

title: New Jersey/This Week
description: BLOOMFIELD (Bloomfield College, Franklin and Fremont Streets)  The Threepenny Opera, in an Actor's CafeTheater production. Thursday and Friday ($3.50$4.50); Saturday ($4.50$5.50). 8:30 P.M. (201) 4297662. Westminster Theater.

title: Met Singers to Aid
description: FREEHOLD THREE artists from the Metropolitan Opera will be appear in a concert here next Sunday to benefit the Battleground Arts Center, a fledgling organization of cultureminded citizens that is kindling interest in the arts throughout Monmouth County.

title: Somali President Begins Talks With High Officials in Peking
description: PEKING, April 15 (Agence FrancePresse)  President Mohammed Siad Barre of Somalia began talks here today with Deputy Prime Minister Li Hsiennien, the Hsinhua press agency reported. It did not give details of the length or subject of the meeting.

title: Parole: A Sentence That Shouldn't End
description: THE Connecticut Commission on Alternate Methods of Sentencing Criminals has proposed, as a part of its determinatesentencing plan, the abolition of both parole decisionmaking and releasetoparole status. A bill to accomplish these objectives is now before the General Assembly. Regardless of the position one takes on abolishing the Connecticut Parole Board, I think it would be a mistake to eliminate parole supervision. And there is no need to keep the board in order to keep parole; we can simply add on, to the determinate prison term proposed in the legislation, a separate term to be served on parole.

title: U.S. Swimmers Take All 14 Events
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 15 (UPI)Tracy Caulkins led an assault on American and world records today and helped the United States swimmers sweep all 14 races and pile up a 11252 lead over the Soviet Union in the first day of a dual meet.

title: Unions Meet Resistance in Trying to Cut Workweek
description: Unions arc stepping up their longterm effort to reduce the workweek as a means of spreading employment but are running into stiffened resistance from management.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND Summing Up The Tax Season
description: A FRIEND of mine who lives in a suburban tax bracket south of Great Neck and north of Mineola telephoned me in a high state of excitement. He had just seen an accountant on the lawn and, for him, that meant that the season was really under way. The accountant, he said, had come out of his house but did not see a shadow, either his or that of an I.R.S. audit. The accountant breathed deeply and stayed out.

title: Home Style
description: It's hard to get a small business going in New York. Moving, for example. Dozens of small moversusually a van and three men, charging from $25 to $35 or so an hourcrop up each year. And frequently they shut down before their advertisements come out in the Yellow Pages.

title: Spontaneity Imitator
description: WHEN Moncure Conway took the ferry over to Brooklyn to visit Walt Whitman, in the fall of 1855, he remarked an unmade bed with a full bedpan under it, and the engraving of a satyr pinned to the wall. Years later, when Conway wrote about it, Whitman was irked, for by that time he no longer thought of himself as a child of nature, but as a reassuring, prematurely old man, the good gray father he thought America wanted. Something Conway doesn't mention is a large, nondescript trunk, maybe the one Whitman took with him to New Orleans on his trip there seven years before. But it was somewhere around, already serving as a repository for Whitman's past, a kind of substitute memory. In it, Whitman deposited his haphazard manuscripts, the articles he tore out of magazines, the pocketsized notebooks made of folded paper, which he pinned together and wrote in, in a large sprawling hand, sometimes only a line or two to a page, mingling names and addresses, book titles, scraps of poems, and anything else that drifted into this sargasso of written bits.

title: Cox's Ridge, $3.40, Takes Excelsior at Aqueduct
description: The dictionary defines Excelsior as lofty, high, noble, sublime, and Cox's Ridge was all those things and more yesterday in winning the handicap of the same name at Aqueduct.

title: A Liking for Police Found in Cities
description: Residents of the nation's cities are more satisfied with their police, fire and sanitation services than with any other aspect of city life, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: Gymnasts to Vie at Seton Hall
description: MONTCLAIR THE Montclair Y Starlettes, the national titlists in 1976 and 1977, will be the hosts for the 1978 National Y.M.C.A. gymnastic championships for men and women. The event will be held at Seton Hall University in South Orange Friday and Saturday.

title: Like Radio City The Standy Fights for Life
description: JERSEY CITY AFTER 50 years of continuous operation as a stage and movie palace, the Stanley Theater, a glorious example of the atmospheric movie houses of the 1920's, closed its doors Wednesday. But like Radio City Music Hall, it has friends who are fighting for its survival.

title: Jennifer Perkins To Be the Bride Of R. C. Speers
description: Mr. and Mrs. George Walbridge Perkins Jr. of Walbridge Farm, Millbrook, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jennifer Emily Perkins, to Randolph Charles Speers, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer Charles Speers of Salt Lake City.

title: Douglas Johnson to Wed Margaret Sawch June 10
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter Stephen Sawch of Westport, Conn., and Key Biscayne. Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Margaret Mary Sawch, to Douglas Gcnrge Johnson, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Rohert Johnson of New Canaan, Conn., and Stratton Mountain, Vt.

title: ECONOMIC SCENE
description: Nothing particularly startling emerged from last week's eagerly awaited Presidential message on the Administration's plans for fighting inflation. Consequently no dramatic reaction appeared immediately in the financial markets. There were some polite comments and some yawns. Some remarked ruefully that it was merely a replay of President Ford's 1974 pep talk on the same subject  but without the WIN (Whip Inflation Now) buttons.

title: Albany Gets a Bill on Cancer Drug
TERRORISTS IN ITALY SAY MORO WILL DIE
description: ROME, April 15The kidnappers of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro declared tonight that they had completed the trial of their prisoner and had sentenced him to death.

title: Koch Lends an Ear (but No Promises) at a Neighborhood Meeting in Northern Part of the Bronx
Looking Backwards
description: THIS photograph of a boy with his arm round the shoulder of his dog is not merely a photograph, David Galloway writes, it is a document, an event, an artifact, a unique moment in time, an investment, an occasion, and the sole but intricate collaboration among cartoonist, photographer, boy, and dog. It is therefore deserving of the closest scrutiny, and furthermore, requires it if we are to realize fully its nuances.

title: INTERVIEW
description: HE is, officially, Angelo R. Bianchi, the state's recently appointed Commissioner of Banking. But to his friends, he is Buddy Bianchi, and he is bringing the same sense of enthusiasm to his new position as he has had as a practicing lawyer for the last 18 years.

title: And It's All Yours For a Mere Million
description: TIRED of the old homestead? Feel like trading up? Then try this for a Sunday morning daydream. That legendary rich uncle has just left you a million dollars plus a dozen cases of Chateau Lafitte Rothschild 1961 and  Zut Alors! were is nowhere to store it except maybe next to all that junk in the basement and that is hardly the ideal spot. So you really need to move fast.

title: What Exactly Is the F.B.I. Doing Now?
description: WASHINGTON  On Feb. 3, 1977, less than a month after he took office, President Carter delegated to Attorney General Griffin B. Bell what he believed to be Presidential authority to order wiretaps and other electronic surveillance without judicial warrants.

title: Article 6  No Title
STAGE VIEW
description: It is undoubtedly repertory's business to cast actors against typethat's what the actors have come together for, to vary and extend their opportunities and tacticsbut I'm afraid there is such a thing as casting actors against all reason. If, in Shakespeare's Julius Caesar, Marc Antony behaves like a fiveyearold about to stamp his foot and break into tears if his friends and countrymen don't pay him a little mind, and if, in the same Julius Laesar, the thoughtful Brutus behaves as feverishly as Cassius normally does while Cassius assumes the marblestatue rectitude generally associated with Brutus, the production's apt to seem crybaby in tone and leave an audience crosseyed in the bargain.

title: Marriage Announcement 7  No Title
description: Laurie Sue Jablow Affianced

title: Malverne Once Again Embroiled In a Dispute Over School Busing
WESTWAY OPPONENTS ATTACK CAREY PLAN
description: Governor Carey's proposal to win Mayor Koch's support of the Westway with $600 million for masstransit improvements in the city was attacked yesterday by opponents of the highway for West Side Manhattan.

title: Volunteers Now Are Getting Choosier
description: There Are Fewer Women, Although More Men and Students Are Stepping Forward

title: POLITICS
description: FOR 12 years he was at the pinnacle of governmental and political power in Nassau County. Now Ralph G. Caso is a man who still wants to be in public service, but no one is asking him.

title: How an Olympic Gold Medal Almost Ruined a Young American Swimmer
description: Bruce Jenner won an Olympic gold medal in 1976, became an instant celebrity, made a fortune from commercials and endorsements, and thrived. Matt Vogel won an Olympic gold medal in 1976, became an instant celebrity and almost destroyed himself.

title: Defeat of School Levy in Cleveland Strikes Angry Blow at Busing Plan
description: CLEVELAND, April 14There is a sign on a storefront window on Dinison Street that sums it up for the people on Cleveland's West Side: We Beat the Levy! and Stop Busing.

title: Editors' Choice
description: FOR JERUSALEM, by Teddy Kollek with Amos Kullek. (Random House. $10.) Jerusalem's longtime Mayor on his life and the city with which he is inextricably linked.

title: The Region
description: And now, the emotionally charged and politically sensitive argument over the death penalty is back where it started, in New York's Legislature. Governor Carey, true to his word and his conscience, last week vetoed a bill restormg capital punishment, calling it the ultimate deception.

title: A 75Foot, $400,000 Fiberglass Commercial Fishing Boat Goes Into Use Off L.I. in an Effort to Cut Costs
description: GREENTPORT, I.I.American commercial fishermen fight a constant economic battle for survival. They have to compete with larger and betterequipped foreign fishing fleets, pay staggering rates for Marine insurance and expect costly repair and maintenance bills on their heats each year, all against a constantly fluctuating market price for their catch.

title: Spare That Parkway
description: With the approach of spring the hills and dales of Westchester will be covered by skunk cabbage, robins and road builders. This promises to be the Year of the Roadbuilder for Westchester [Feb. 26]. TheSprain Brook Parkway Extension as well as a dozen or so highway construction projects are being started. The authorities have cited a 50 percent increase in accidents on parkways between 1976 and 1977 as evidence of the need for modernization.

title: Moon Disciple, Family Meet in Cour
Ethnic Leaders React to the Impact of Holocaust
description: The NBCTV drama Holocaust' about the Nazi extermination of Jews, will be televised over four nights, starting tonight, but already reactions are being voiced by those who have seen it at advance screenings.

title: Joan Sealy to BeWedJuly 22
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert H. Sealy of Dayton, Ohio, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Deborah Sealy, to Kevin Hinsman Kiplinger, son of Mr. and Mrs. W. Bogert Kiplinger of St. Louis and Doxbury. Mass.

title: HIGHLIGHTS
description: Significant steps toward faster growth in two of the world's weakest economies were taken last week as Canada and Britain announced their budgets for the coming year. Of the two, Canada's program is far more stimulative, reflecting the more serious economic problems facing that country.

title: Beware Empty Land: Someone May Fill It; Who Owns That Idyllic Tract Next Door?; Beware Empty Land: Someone May Fill It
description: Only a gambler should buy a house next to empty landbut most people don't know that until they lose. One of the most common speeches made at public hearings in the suburbs, given in tones of bitterness andbetrayal, starts this way: We moved here because we liked the rural atmosphere. We don't want it to change.

title: MINERS DEATHS PUT SPOTLIGHT ON SAFETY
description: WASHINGTON, April 15The deaths of eight men in two underground accidents since the nationwide coal miners strike ended three weeks ago have focused new attention on the Federal mine safety program.

title: Sunday Observer
My Main Job Is to Care a Lot
East Berlin DraftJailing Protested
LETTERS TO THE NEW JERSEY EDITOR
description: At its Feb. 28 meeting, the Princeton Joint Commission on Civil Rights considered the implications of the Bakke case, the affirmative action suit now pending before the United States Supreme Court.

title: Sports Editor's Mailbox: Games for Boys and Men
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Second to Arrive
description: IN this book there is a passage that reached me well after I had put it down. It is about the sled dogs, and how their manager concluded that they became bored on those infinite, barely endurable marches, 1,500 miles at 510 miles per day, through iceblizzards. I never thought before about dogs getting bored. Trust the English to make this discovery. Mrs. Huxley, of course, was brought up in Africa, and indeed some of her keen and mellifluous books touch on animal life. In this book she proves yet again that there is no subject she cannot illuminate.

title: NO ROOM IN THE LIFEBOATS
description: The most striking aspect of Jimmy Carter's 1979 budget now before Congress is its similarity to the budgets of Richard Nixon and Gerald Ford. All three are premised on a new brand of economic realism that is imposing severe political strains on the country and is challenging some of our fundamental ideals. Austerity, lowered expectations and limits to what government can do have been the ascendant political slogans of the 1970's. Sluggish growth, inflation and high unemployment are no longer regarded as periodic problems to be remedied by swift government action but are now accepted by both parties as chronic conditions of our economic life.

title: Energy: Where Did the Crisis Go?; Energy: What a Difference a Year Makes A year ago, Carter sent his plan to Congress. How and why has it faltered? Congress Disposes
description: WASHINGTON  It is just a year since Jimmy Carter launched his national energy plan, under the banner, the moral equivalent of war. As it turned out, a more propitious year could have been chosen.

title: Government Problems in Finding Disposal Sites for Nuclear Wastes May Delay Building of Power Plants
Carol Conway Offers Dances At Marymount
description: Carol Conway is most readily identified with the school of Erick Hawkins, with whom she danced for a number of years. But the dances she presented Friday at the Marymount Manhattan Theater displayed little of the supple style and gentle impetus of the Hawkins style. With its abstract movemant cleansed of emotional attributes, its chattering electronic scores and its darting, hardedged choreography, Miss Conway's dance looked far closer to the Alwin Nikolais lineage.

title: Mrs. Ford's Illness Described
description: LONG BEACH, Calif., April 15 (UPI)  Alcohol as well as other drugs was a factor in prompting Betty Ford to seek help at a Navy rehabilitation center, the former First Lady's son, Steve, said yesterday.

title: Do Schools Give Taxpayers a Fair Return?
description: THE silly season for Long Island school budgets is nearly upon us, and taxpayers will soon be inundated with literature about why we must pass this year's budget.Despite declining enrollments and closing schools, we will be assured that our compassionate board has presented us with a barebones budget without frills, which will increase our taxes only a few mills or up to a few hundred dollars.

title: Figuring Out New Bargain Air Fares
description: Those who are planning summer vacations by air are probably already examining alternatives in price and degrees of frills. And it will take a lot of examining: the situation this year is far more complicated than last.

title: Wildlife Group Seeks to Capture Condors to Assure Their Survival
The Building Up of the Texas Rangers
description: An unfamiliar feeling struck Brad Corbett one night last week as he watched his Texas Rangers lose to the Detroit Tigers.

title: Neutron Issue Sparks Wide Dutch Protest
description: AMSTERDAM, April 13  In most Western European countries, the controversy over the neutron bomb has been largely confined to the highest levels of government. But in the Netherlands, the issue has sparked a widespread popular movement that has not abated, even after President Carter's recent decision to postpone production of the weapon.

title: GARDENING Rooting Out Winter Damage
description: WHEN the ground has thawed and the soil has dried sufficiently to be workable, the time has arrived for tree and shrub planting. As inmany areas of our lives, we demand instant results. When we plant a tree, we want shade immediately; so we buy the largest tree we can afford, plant it in a strategic spot and get out the lawn chair to sit in its shade.

title: Winning While Losing Along East 86th Street
description: The yellow and white chaser lights running circles at night around the Loew's Orpheum marquee on East 86th Street illuminate the discothques Wednesdays and the Corso, a Burger King and Kentucky Fried Chicken, Arthur Treachers Fish and Chips, and the streetwalkers who prowl the south side of the block between Second and Third Avenues.

title: Lightweight Racing Yachts Shown to Lack Durability
description: The 65foot ketch Flyer swept across the finish line off Portsmouth, England, at the head of the 15boat fleet that had raced around the world. At a time when some of the best offshore yachts have difficulty sailing off Florida without masts snapping and stays popping, Flyerowned and skippered by Cornelius Van Rietschoten of the Netherlandshad traveled 27,000 miles over a sevenmonth span with no major problems.

title: A Marathon Man From Red Bank
description: RED BANK IT is no coincidence that Dr. George Sheehan's latest book, Running & Being: The Total Experience, is scheduled for release this week. Tomorrow is the 82d running of the Boston Marathon, and Dr. Sheehan, the philosopher of the longdistance brigade, will be competing for the 15th time.

title: STATE'S EMPLOYEES GET DIFFERENT UNION
description: An A.F.L.C.I.O. union, the Public Employees Federation, has upset the Civil Service Employees Association, the incumbent organization, and won the right to represent 45,544 professional, scientific and technical employees in New York State agencies.

title: JAILED ILLINOIS FIREMEN REJECT CONTRACT OFFER
description: NORMAL. Ill., April 15 (AP)Firemen in this central Illinois community, most of whom have been jailed for the past two weeks for striking, voted today, 23 to 0, not to accept what a city spokesman described as the final offer for a union contract.

title: Article 4  No Title
Southampton Adds Groupie Rules
2Party System: A Republican Speaks Out
description: OF late, there has been much palaver about the beauties of our twoparty system, the apparent demise of half of the act and what should be done to revivify an elephant seemingly on a selfdestruct course. What is missing from the cures is the stuff that truly moves men to action: hard ideas and humane programs.

title: Judge Calls For Annex Of U.S. Court
description: WHITE PLAINS LFADERS of the Westchester County Bar Association and other lawyers who have been pushing for establishment of a branch of the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York in this city say they are greatly encouraged. by a recent declaration by the district , Chief Judge, David N. Edelstein, that it is absolutely and definitively necessary to have a branch north of the Bronx line.

title: INJURED ARE REPORTED IN SKI RESORT ACCIDENT
description: SQUAW VALLEY, Calif., April 15 (AP) A number of skiers were injured, some of them seriously, when a large tramway car plunged 30 feet toward the ground today at th Squaw Valley Ski Resort, according to the Placer County sheriff's office.

title: THE LITERARY VIEW
description: A GREAT university press is fundamental to a great university. There are readers in England who will never go to Yale, have never met a Yale graduate and could not even find New Haven on the map; but because of the Yale edition of Horace Walpole's letters those English readers have an exalted idea of Yale. In this country, equally, there are senior readers who have never been to Cambridge, England; but those seniors were reared on the Cambridge Modern History (190212), the Cambridge History of English Literature (190716) and the Cambridge Medieval History (191136). What they think of in the context of Cambridge, England is not King's College Chapel or the courtyard of Trinity College. It is the noble page, the amplitude of reference and the leisurely but allencompassing progress of those majestic series.

title: Message Is Clear, but How Will It Be Received?; Skirting the Mini Issue Big Shoulders Emphasized Stiffer Clothes to Come?
description: PARIS, April 14  Fashion changes because people get bored with the styles they are wearing and something comes along that catches their fancy or looks easier to live with. Designers, of course, try to hasten the process, and when they come up with something that is either pleasing or useful, they produce a new fashion.

title: Let the Students Govern
description: WHITE PLAINS CITY school districts in Westchester are taking few precautionary measures to insure their financial and educational integrity should the State Legislature fail to minimize the effects of a court ruling that could cost the school districts millions of dollars.

title: HealthCare Workers Consider Giving Nursing Homes More Time to Avert Second Strike
A Vegetable Garden's Fourth Dimension
description: For many gardeners calculating the arrivals and departures of vegetables is as frustrating as deciphering a train schedule the day before Daylight Saving Time goes into effect. As a result, seeds are thrown willynilly into the soil with harvest times left to chance. Along about July, vast patches of naked soil appear where earlybearing crops once thrived. Pea vines, old lettuce, shrunken beans are left to wither and decay, creating a superb haven for invading bugs.

title: Merritt Baker Fox Marries Ann Gellis
ANTIQUES
description: East or West of the Kremlin, the repository of the largest number of Peter Carl Faberg's imperial Easter eggs is the lobby of that capitalist publicationForbes Magazine.

title: Feld Teaches Dancers With a Difference
The Saint  An Opera That Mirrors Menotti's Soul
description: On Wednesday night Glen Carlo Menotti's The Saint of Bleecker Street will be televised live by the New York City Opera, When, in 1953, Menotti at the age of 42 began work on this, his most elaborate opera, the inner man felt the pangs of various subtle emotional stresses.

title: The Spanish Way of Business: A Tale of 3 Companies
description: ALMUSAFES, Spain  Along the verdant Valencia coast, one of the world's most modern automobile plants briskly turns out 1,104 Ford Fiestas five and a half days a week a product that in the space of a year has become Spain's largest single export.

title: Down to the Sea in Fiberglass
description: GREENPORT AMERICAN commercial fishermen fight a constant economic battle for survival. They have to compete with larger and betterequipped foreign fishing fleets, pay staggering rates for marine insurance and expect costly repair and maintenance bills on their boats each year, all against a constantly fluctuating market price for their catch.

title: HOME CLINIC
description: WHEN applying varnish or enamel, a smooth, glossy finish can only be achieved if the surface is smooth and free of dust or other particles, and if the paint or varnish is properly applied with a good quality brush or padtype applicator.

title: CRIME
description: What hath John wrought? John le Carr, that is. He has loosed imitators upon the world, all of whom write spy stories marked by turgid byzantine maneuvering. In these stories it is next to impossible to distinguish good from evil. In all these books somebody close to the top is going to be revealed as a double agent. In all of them the master spy is a short, middleaged figure in determined flight from James Bond. And all have an air of appalling seriousness.

title: Lines of Understanding Reopens For Those Uprooted From Cuba
description: One morning last February, as he slept in his home in Stony Brook, Roman de la Campa preformer of Hispanic studies at the State University Center at Stony Brook, became conscious of the ringing of his telephone.

title: Ephron Talking
description: Q. In your new book, Scribble Scribble, you talk about the reporter emerging from behind the byline, becoming famous as a personality  sometimes more famous than the people being interviewed. Do you think that reflects an important change in the role of the media?

title: VATICAN BIDS ROME SENATE REJECT ABORTION MEASURE
description: ROME, April 15 (Reuters)The Roman Catholic Church, angered that the lower house of Italy's Parliament has approved a bill that would legalize abortion virtually on request, today called on the Senate to stop the bill from becoming law.

title: LAYER IN INDONESIA SPEAKS UP ON RIGHTS
description: JAKARTA, April 15  In Indonesia, where President Suharto's Government reserves for itself a nearmonopoly of public expression only occasionally challenged by students or newspapers and quickly suppressed, Yap Thiam Hien speaks his mind.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY A Taxing Conversation
description: I HADN'T heard from my friend, Naomi the lawyer, for some time, but I wasn't too concerned because she has been up to her ears in separations, custody proceedings and other things like that. But the other day, she telephoned to say that she was upset. I could tell she was upset because she was talking in clipped words.

title: STAMPS
description: For the third time in less than five years, the United Nations is using its stamps to espouse the cause of independence for the land at the tip of Africa that it calls Namibia, and that the South Africans who administer it call SouthWest Africa.
