title: Realty News West Side Lease
description: The Seiko Time Corporation, the watch manufacturer, has leased the entire 14th floor at 555 West 57th Street in a major expansion and consolidation move.

title: What's Doing in BOSTON
LETTER TO THE CONNECTICUT EDITOR
description: The Connecticut Weekly featured, with its article on nuclear shipments [March 12], a strange and misleading photograph. Its caption stated that Richard T. Adams at Brookhaven Laboratories was holding in his hand a spent rod of nuclear material.

title: On Pleasures of Fishing for Connetquot Trout
description: OAKDALE, L.I.Settling on the top of a dead tree 30 yards away, an osprey watched me struggle to cast my fly in a near gale.

title: Meandering Maine's Brooks and Backwaters
description: May is iceout time in the rivers and ponds and brooks around 45milelong Moosehead Lake, New England's largest, up in northern Maine. Snow and ice on mountain ridges and slopes have melted and the rushing waters roil through torrential whitewater streams to make for some of the most exciting rafting in the world.

title: Genocide for Everyone
description: GERALD GREEN is a pro. Holocaust is his 18th book (of the earlier ones, perhaps The Last Angry Man is best known to readers), and it will come as no surprise that his latest is a slick product. The surprise is in the subject matter  theextermination of six million European Jews unaer Nazism during World War II, an area of human experience so suffused with suffering and agonizing ambiguities that one might suppose it unsuitable for massaudience appeal and treatment. Yet Mr. Green scripted the fourpart Big Event drama that begins tonight on NBCTV, and this paperback is his novelization of the teleplay.

title: Radio
description: 7:308 A.M., WABC: Message of Israel. Springtime, Freedom and the Family.

title: Lucy Capers Bride Of Leonard Joyner
2 Dead After Massachusetts Siege
Huntington Minutemen Welcome British
description: AT the command, Present arms! members of the Huntington Battalion of Minutemen, their tricornered hats set at rakish angles, snapped their muskets smartly in place last week and saluted the arrival of a group of visitors from their sister community, Huntingdon, England.

title: Ceausescu, Tito Tread Wary and Parallel Paths
description: BELGRADE, Yugoslavia  President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania and Yugoslavia's Josip Broz Tito are notsostrange bedfellows. The two, who dominate their countries and their region as do few other East European leaders, have for years played a curious counterpoint weaving into, out of and around the otherwise monolithic Soviet bloc ana involving a variety or international issues that fascinate both men. Mr. Ceausescu's visit to Washington last week, little more than a month after President Tito's, reflects the Rumanian leader's equal if not greater need for international independence and stature.

title: NUMISMATICS

description: MUS1C of Eastern Europe, c. 13501700 was the theme of the Waverly Consort's final concert of the season in Alice Tully Hall Saturday night. Here is en intriguing corner of musical history that has been virtually unexplored, even by scholars, and the Consort's necessarily brief overview of this neglected literature uncovered some fascinating surprises.

title: Carter LookAlike Discovers He's a Celebrity, Too

title: New Kansas Liquor Law Brings Confusion
description: TOPEKA, Kan., April 15Seventyeight years after Carrie Nation smashed her first saloon at Medicine Lodge, Kansans are burying her hatchet. At least they are trying to, but it is going down hard, with a lot of confusion.

title: Toward Korean Peace
description: MEDFORD, Mass.At the base of the whole Korcagate stormlet lies poor United States policy on Korea. Had policy been good, not even the manipulatory President Park Chung Hee and his henchmen would have felt called on to bribe Congressmen into supporting it. But policy is bad; and the feckless decision to withdraw United States troops from Korea has worsened it.

title: Laraine Marcus, Educator, Wed to Joseph D. Pacheco
description: Laraine Beth Marcus, an assistant principal in the foreign language department at Theodore Roosevelt High School in the Bronx, was married yesterday to Joseph D. Pacheco, principal of Public School 83 in Manhattan.

title: Aeros Top Nordiques In Overtime
description: HOUSTON, April 16(AP)Ted Taylor deflected in a shot by John Hughes 7 minutes 19 seconds into overtime today to give the Houston Aeros a 43 victory over the Quebec Nordiques in a quarterfinal game of the World Hockey Association playoffs.

title: Tension Grows Between Brzezinski and State Department
description: WASHINGTON, April 16On the long flight home from Africa on Air Force One earlier this month, Zbigniew Brzezinski, the President's national security adviser. finally got the opportunity to corner Hodding Carter 3d, the Stale Department spokesman, and to ask him question that had been troubling him for months:

title: Television
News Summary
description: MONDAY, APRIL 17, 1978

title: 20 of 146 Workers Asked to Quit Have Left The Post, Guild Unit Says
description: The New York Post has received not more than 20 resignations from 146 employees invited to resign with severance pay, Barbara Yuncker, chairman of the Post unit of the Newspaper Guild of New York, said last night. The union has had 450 news and commercial members at the newspaper.

title: New Jazz: Braxton
description: JOSEPH PAPP'S New Jazz at the Public series has moved from the Public Theater Cabaret into the Newman Theater in the same complex and gone from a Wednesday-through-Saturday schedule to a Friday and Saturday format. Unlike the Cabaret, which had tables and waitresses and was more like a large nightclub, the Newman is a conventional theater, and the presentations are now conventional concerts. This works to the advantage of the music, which is seen well and heard sharply and clearly in the new environment. Contemporary jazz has rarely if ever received such respectful treatment in a continuing New York venue.

title: Boston Program Seeks to Keep Youths in School
description: After the city of Boston, having expended thousands of professional manhours in preparing its submission and having enlisted a glittering array of local talent ranging from the Speaker of the House, Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., to Derek Bok, president of Harvard, was picked to receive $23 million over two years to run a Youth Incentive Entitlement Pilot Project, it fell to the city's Employ- ment ana Economic Policy Administration to operate the program.

title: A Lebanon Balance Sheet
description: The latest cycle of terror and counterattack in the Middle East is winding down, permitting a first assessment of gains and losses.

title: Penn Captures Water Polo Title
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 16  John Goepp scored four goals as Pennsylvania won the Ivy League water polo championship by defcat:rig Columbia, 75, today to finish the twoday tournament. at the Quakers pool with 30 wonlost record.

title: American Symphony: A New Gould
description: TWO CONDUCTORS, one pianist and a piano technician shared yesterday afternoon's American Symphony Orchestra concert. One conductor was Morton Gould, who led the Symphony No. 21 by Miaskovsky and the New York premiere of his own Sympnony or Spirituals. The other was David Gilbert, associate conductor of the New York Philharmonic, who took over the orchestra for both of the Liszt piano concertos. The pianist was Earl Wild. The technician was Joseph Vitti of the Baldwin Piano Company.

title: Sporting Gear
description: I'll be home soon. Ma, They're starting to throw curveballs. That old line, concerning a problem that rookies encounter during baseball tryouts, may become thing of the past with the introduction of the Major League Breaking Ball. The ball is the weight (five ounces) and the circumference (nine inches) of an official baseball, but a small section of it is sliced off, giving it a flat edge. This allows a pitcher to throw curves, screwballs, sinkers and risers without turning his wrist or contorting his arm during delivery. The ball does the work, because of its shape. The path of the bail depends on where the flat side is upon release. Major league coaches are raving over the device as an ad to hatters who have trouble with various types of breaking pitches. priced at $3 at J. C. Penney, Herman's, Morsan's and Modell's. The manufacturer is Pick Point Enterprises, Mirror Lake, N.H. 03853.

title: State Department Defers Comment
description: WASHINGTON, April 16A State Department spokesman said that the department had not yet been officially informed about the Israeli Cabinet statement and would not comment on it until it was informed about it.

title: O'NEILL DENIES HE TALKED WITH PARK ABOUT KOREA
description: HOUSTON, April 16 (AP)  House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Democrat of Massachusetts, said yesterday that he had never had any conversation with Tongsun Park concerning anything to do with Korea, and any talks I had with him never lasted more than two to five minutes. Mr. Park is the rice dealer and Washineton oartv giver.

The combined company would be known as the Kaiser Medusa Corporation with headquarters in Oakland, Calif.

description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., April 16Billy Martin of Clark, N.J., at an average speed of 81.6 miles per hour, won an offshore powerboat race today, defeating Berry Cook, the world champion.

description: But, more basically, the method seems both to reflect and to contribute to fundamental changes in how government now works, to shifts in power relationships and to a decline in the authority of the Presidency and Congressional leadership. It may also make it difficult to reverse any of these changes.

description: WHITE WAVE, the newest dance work by Nancy Meehan, presented Saturday night by the Nancy Meehan Dance Company at the New York University Theater, is the choreographer's second use of surf imagery in dance metaphor.

title: Commodities
description: WASHINGTON, April 16The House having killed the emengency farm bill last week, farmers will again be more dependent on the weather and foreign buyers than on the Government for their living.

description: LONDON, April 16A shortage of manpower has forced the withdrawal of more than 50 tanks from the British Army's frontline deployment in West Germany and has compelled senior officers to ask the Government for an additional 1,500 men for service there.

description: General Lucius D, Clay, the former commander of United States forces in Europe following World War II. died last night at his home in Cape Cod, Mass. He was 80 years old.

title: It 's Tryout Time for Fall TV Shows
description: This time of year, usually referred to as end -of-season in television, has become a time when new shows, many as "ministers" with brief runs and others as the traditional one-shot pilot productions, are interspersed among the returns and given trial runs to see whether they are worth seeing more of in the season that starts next fall.

First enacted in 1973 to repla all the fragmented ma manpowertraining programs that existed until then, was at that time the latest national jobtraining programsomething that had first appeared on the scene during Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal. One of the largest provisions of the act is Title I, which authorizes a broad range of jobtraining and placement programs.

title: TeenAgers Discuss Sexuality in the 70's
description: ROCHESTER, April 15  The program was entitled MAN 78, the acronym signifying Male Adolescent Needs, but it might have been more aptly called TeenAgers 78. Its organizers had expected the meeting to take a hard look at the sexual role and responsibilities of young males; instead, 176 teenagers and their leaders discussed virtually Every aspect of sex, from parental disapproval to homosexuality.

title: First U.S. Power Lift For Women

title: Opera: Premiere of Claudia Legare
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 15Several years ago the New York City Opera asked Robert Ward, composer of the successful The Crucible, to write a new work. For some reason the City Opera never got around to staging this commissioned opera. It has remained for the Minnesota Opera Company to present the world premiere of Claudia Legare. which took place tonight at the Tyrone Guthrie Theater.

description: Graig Nettles made a remarkable recovery yesterday from the flu and singled home a run as the Yankees defeated the Chicago White Sox, 30, behind the combined fivehit pitching of Dick Tidrow and Sparky Lyle.

title: Why Best Movies Bypass Music Hall
description: IN THE BEGINNINGon Jan. 11, 1933, to be precise  there was The Bitter Tea of General Yen, the first film attraction at the newly opened Radio City Music Hall. Later that year came King Kong, Little Women, and Flying Down to Rio. By the end of its first year, the Music Hall had shown 47 feature films, and the rest of the decade would feature classics like Twentieth Century, It Happened One Night, The Informer, Magnificent Obsession, The Petrified Forest, Bringing Up Baby, Young Doctor Kildare, Gunga Din, Ninotchka, Mr. Smith Goes to Washington and Stella Dallas.

description: Alan Stewart vigorously cross-examfined Cheryl Doyle last week in a custody dispute over two children in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Record Reactor Output Reported
description: RICHLAND, Wash., April 16 (AP)The nuclear reactor at the Hanford Nuclear Reservation became the first nuclear generating plant in the United States to produce 40 billion kilowatts of power, a spokesman for United Nuclear Industries said. This amount would take 72 billion barrels of oil to produce. The dualpurpose reactor began providing putoniurn for the Federa Government in 1964 and steam for power generation in 1966, Lyn Watso said yesterday.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: TOUCH OF THE POET Because the music is seldom performed locally, many New Yorkers don't realize that some verses by Lord Byron were once set to synagogue melodies by the 19thcentury composer Isaac Nathan, with the poet's collaboration. Such poems as On Jordan's Banks, The Harp the Monarch Minstrel Swept, 'She Walks in Beauty and The Wild Gazelle were turned into melodic solo and choral passages of background liturgical music.

description: Officials of the Empire City Pharniagists Association urged their 800 members yesterday to obey a court order requiring them to fill Medicaid prescriptions, but a number of the members made it clear after a meeting at the New York Sheraton Hotel that they did not intend to follow the leaders reauest.

title: Italy Pleads for Moro But It Offers No Deal
description: ROME, April 16Italian authorities made a desperate appeal today to the kidnappers of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro to spare his life on humanitarian grounds. But leaders of the governing Christian Democratic Party appeared to continue to rule. out any deal with the terrorists.

title: The Neon Woman By Eyen Is Staged
description: IN WOMEN BEHIND BARS Tom Eyen maliciously spoofed a mini movie genre: allwomen prison filmshow many of those are there? In his new scenario for the stage, The Neon Woman, which opened last night at Hurrah, a West Side discotheque, he narrows his sights to a sliver. This is a burlesque of bur- lesque, a travesty of ecdysiastic mur- der mysteries.

But the opponents still outnumber the backers, the agency declared in Washington.

title: Dr. Kathleen Muller Wed To William McEachern

description: WASHINGTON. April 16Blacks looking for apartronts to rent encounter crimination from rental agents three out of four times, a major study of housing discrimination indicates.

title: Joe Only Tried to Beat You
description: EIGHT mornings ago Joe Gordon got up to keep a golf date in Marysville, Calif. At 63, the finest of Yankee second basemen was living the good life in Sacramento, golfing, fishing, shooting, selling a little real estate when he felt like it. Still in pajamas and robe, he was having orange juice when he told his wife, Dorothy: I don't understand it but my shoulder is sore. Maybe a hot shower will take care of it. He came out of the shower white as ghost, and Dorothy got him to the hospital.

title: Advertising

description: ST. DAV1DS, Pa., April 15  The Pennsylvania Crime Commission has found a significant infiltration of organized crime figures at all levels of the resort business in the Pocono Mountains of northeastern Pennsylvania, according to Joan Weiner, the commission's acting executive director.

title: Letelier Inquiry Sees Chilean Link to Cuban Exiles

It will do no good to ask what the other six are, because six new wonders are proclaimed by publicity every week. But the Spanish pianist's achieve- ment with this work comes as close to standing by itself as anything you can hear in a lifetime of recitalgoing.

He finished with a 67 for a seven-under-par total of 281.

title: Sports Guide
description: The Rutgers Relays, at Rutgers Stadium in Piscataway N.J., open at 2:30 P.M. Thursday, though the first day's events are not relays at all but rather individual races, at distances ranging from 100 to 10,000 meters. There will be no admission charge for spectators. On Saturday, field events start at 11 A.M. and relay races at 1 P.M. Top college and club teams from the East are expected. Saturday's admission is $2 for adults, and $1 for students and for youths 16 and under.

title: Radio
'Far Road,' Japan Film, At Museum
description: THE style and subject of "The Far Road," a Japanese entry in the Museum of Modern Art's New Directors/New Films series, are nicely consonant. The film's story, which spans 30 years and follows the life of a railroad worker and his family, is of course deeply concerned with the effects of modernization upon postwar Japan.Accordingly, the film's direction incorporates standard elements of both Japanese and Western film technique. "The Far Road" is the first feature film directed by Sachiko Hidari, who also plays the railway worker's wife, and it is often quite successful in mingling incompatible scenes and ingredients without generating a sense of clashing moods.For instance, an opening episode shows the railway worker (Ichizo Takinogami) and his wife traveling by train to attend a ceremony, during which the worker will be awarded a medal for his many years of service. His wife, donning a kimono for the first time in ages, is nervous and shy, and the other wives in the audience look similarly ill at ease. Meanwhile, the few young children in the crowd wear Western clothes and squirm with boredom. These different generations seem every bit as bewildered as they are divided.After the ceremony, the whole family is shown back home, carousing over dinner and drinking beer. Then it turns out that the couple's stunning daughter (Yoshie Shimo) has brought her suitor home for the first time, an act that enrages her father beyond all reason. In his day, he howls, marriages were arranged by families and that was that. The daughter is frightened by his out-burst, and sorry to have defied his wishes. But, saddened as she is by the episode, she just doesn't understand it.Miss Hidari's film, which was sponsored by the Japanese National Railway Workers' Union, is full of change and upheaval, but it has an uneventful feeling. The railway scenes lend themselves to lovely blue-gray winter tableaux, as the smoke from the trains blends with falling snow, and the troubled history of the worker's family is of interest at times. But by and large "The Far Road" introduces a director of evident promise whose talents are more impressive than the material upon which she has concentrated them.

title: An Unneeded Nuclear Project
description: The Carter Administration's efforts to kill off the illconceived Clinch River breeder reactor project suffered another setback in Congress when the House Science and Technology Committee authorized $172.5 million to continue it as planned. The project involves building demonstration reactor in Tennessee that would breed more nuclear fuel than it consumes, thus stretching energy supplies. A worthy goalbut in the opinion Administration energy experts the reactor would too small and too outmoded to provide useful information. It would also breed weaponsgrade plutoniumthe kind of reactor fuel whose use Mr. Carter is wisely trying to curb. The Administration is not opposed to building breeders, if and when they are needed. But it does want.to slow the rush toward premature commercialization of dangerous breeder technology.

Living in the forests, they have kept their African culture nearly intact (pronounced Indian and European influences are present).

title: Film: Bolivian:Antonio Eguino's 4-Episode Feature Shown at Modern
description: This year's New Directors/New Films series, under the joint sponsorship of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the film department of the Museum of Modern Art, has not been much cause for celebration until now, with the showing of "Chuquiago." Antonio Eguino's fine Bolivian feature will be seen at the museum today at 6 P.M. and tomorrow at 8:30 P.M., to close the series."Chuquiago," the Indian name for the capital city that the Spaniards named La Paz, appears to be such an even-tempered film that one is well into it before recognizing the fury with which it is charged. Its dominant expression is of inscrutable calm, much the way Indians look to those of us who don't know them."Chuquiago" is the second feature to be directed by Mr. Eguino, who began his career as a still photographer and then became a motion-picture cameraman. The movie displays the ease of someone far more experienced, however. Its themes of rootlessness and casual corruption are the connectives for the four separate though overlapping stories that present us with a cross section of contemporary Bolivian society.The film opens when Isico (Nestor Yujra), a young Indian boy, is brought into La Paz and apprenticed by his parents to an old woman who works in the peasant marketplace. Isico, without particular direction except the need to eat and sleep, drifts into the life of a street boy, probably to become, one day, much like the drunken Indians who torment him as he moves about the city.In the second story, Johnny (Edmundo Villarreol) is an upwardly mobile Indian teen-ager, the son of hard-working parents whose Indian ways now embarrass him. Johnny drops out of school and into a life of petty crime, is conned by an agency that promises to find him work in the United States and is last seen running, though no one is chasing him.The film's third episode is both funny and scathing. It's about Carlos (David Santalia), a vain, middle-aged fellow who works in government office where bureaucracy has been raised to a kind of art. Carlos is well on his way to joining the middle class. He has five children, debts up to his ears and parrots the government political line, though he seems to have been a committed radical in his younger years. His aspirations now have to do mostly with appliances and being able to spend Friday nights on the town with his friends.The last episode is about a pretty, intelligent university student, Patricia (Tatiana Aponte), who takes one brave last stand against her conservative parents, loses the fight and winds up willingly accepting marriage with a young man who promises to be just like her fatherand possibly worse.Though each narrative is essentially bleak, the film makes its points with such humane wit that it's far from depressing experience. Mr. Eguino's achievement can be measured in the superb performances he has drawn from his actors, both professional and amateur, and in the remarkable economy with which he evokes an entire cultural and economic system in four briefly touched-on lives."Chuquiago" is a spare, vividly impressive work.

title: Don't Strangle CETA, Untangle It
description: It happened to Medicare and subsidized housing, and now it's happening to job creation. Whenever the Federal Government tries to solve in a hurry a major domestic problem with a major social program, some waste and even fraud result. The Labor Department's $11.8 billion jobs program known as CETA (Comprehensive Employment and Training Act) has recently been dogged reports of mismanagement and political manipulation. Some Congressional supporters are, consequently, hesitant about fully refunding the programand Labor Secretary Marshall has formed a special unit to root out corruption and waste. The crackdown is overdue; we hope it calms Congressional jitters. But other reforms are necessary if CETA's longterm goals are to be protected.

description: Baseball's once and only black manager, Frank Robinson, is now a coach with the Baltimore Orioles and, understandably, he hopes to be hired as a major league manager again. But becoming baseball's second black manager might be almost as difficult as having become baseball's first blact manager. I think baseball has backed off some now, he was saying before the Orioles opened a twogame series Yankee Stadium last night. There's no pressure for baseball to come up with a black manager now, nobody is kicking up

title: Meatballs for Caviar
description: Few persons of modest attainment hesitate these days about telling you how good they are. Turn on the electronics, open a paper, walk into an officeit doesn't matterin a few minutes on comes some character to thump his chest and treat you like fulllength mirror.

title: Writer of Novel on Africa Coup Said to Have Attempted Real One
description: LONDON, April 17  Frederick Forsyth, a millionaire author of novels of international intrigue, attempted to organize an attack on a West African government in 1972, then based one of his books on the project, The Sunday Times of London reported yesterday.

title: Supreme Court Told Group Favors `Pristine State for Grand Central
description: WASHINGTON, April 17A lawyer for the Penn Central Transportation Company, arguing today against the designation of Grand Central Terminal as a New York City landmark, told the Supreme Court that nothing is going to satisfy conser-

title: N.A.A.C.P. Seeks to Clarify Deregulation Stance
description: ATLANTA, April 17In an effort to dissipate continuing criticism of an earlier policy statement on energy, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People today attempted to clarify its stand on the deregulation of natural gas, denying it had ever endorsed or supported such a niove.

title: Byrne CarInsurance Reform Bills Are Introduced in State Assembly
description: TRENTON, April 17The Byrne administration's autoinsurance reform bills were introduced today in the State Assembly, although the Governor and chief sponsor of the legislation were out of the country.

title: Judge Frederick Bryan Dies at 73; Ended Ban on Chatterley Novel
description: Judge Frederick van Pelt Bryan, who struck down the Government ban on the novel Lady Chatterley's Lover in 1959, and presided over a wide range of cases in 22 years in Federal District Court in New York, died of a heart attack yesterday at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 73 years old and lived at 4426 East 89th Street in Manhattan.

title: He or She Or What?; IN THE NATION
description: Serious people, sooner or later, must deal with serious problems. So let us put aside small questions about Panama Canal treaties, income tax reform, the inflation rate, whether Jimmy Carter is in for a four- or eightyear stretch, and why the Soviets have more throwweight than we have launch vehicles, or vice versa. It past time to deal with the His or Her problem.

title: Vance and Owen, Ending Tour of Southern Africa, Fail to Break the Rhodesian Impasse
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia. April 17American and British mediators ended tour of southern Africa today having failed to break a deadlock in the Rhodesian dispute but with no outright rejection of their plan for an internationally acceptable transition to black majority rule.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
description: SIEGE CONTINUES: Police in Philadelphia escort woman away from house where radical group has barricaded itself in a yearlong confrontation with authorities. The supporter had attempted to deliver supplies to the group. The first of 25 members of Move surrendered yester. day, a month after food and water was cut off by police.

title: BANKAMERICA PROFIT SHOWS GAIN OF 23% FOR FIRST QUARTER
description: The BankAmerica Corporation, the nation's largest banking organization and parent of the world's largest bank, the Bank of America, reported yesterday that its earnings before securities transactions were up 23 percent in the first quarter of 1978, compared with the similar period last year.

title: To lie, or not to lief1 The Doctors Dilemma
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Should doctors ever lie to benefit their patientsto speed recovery or to conceal the approach of death? In medicine as in law, government, and other lines of work, the requirements of honesty often seem dwarfed by greater needs: the need to shelter from brutal news or to uphold a promise of secrety; to expose corruption or to promote the public interest.

title: Gold and Silver Futures Prices Fall
description: CHICAGO, April 17(AP)Gold futures plunged today to their lowest levels since early this year and silver contracts dropped the daily limit, as the stock market's rally and an improved dollar caused heavy liquidatton In precious metals.

title: Marshall Bartholomew, 93, Was Director Of the Glee Club at Yale From 21 to 53
description: Marshall Bartholomew, director of the Yale Glee Club for 32 years, who popularized and helped to raise the level of choral singing in this country, died Sunday night at a convalescent home in Guilford, Conn.

title: House Committee Rebuffs 2 Reforms In Carter Tax Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 17Frei dent Carter's tax bill got off to a shaky start in Congress today as the Ways and Means Committee rejected two out of three of Mr. Carter's revenueraising tax pronosals.

title: Yanks Lose, 64, as Hunter Still Struggles
description: No jury was needed last night to determine how Catfish Hunter had pitched; it was obvious to everyone at Yankee Stadium that he had pitched poorly for the second time in two starts this season, as the Baltimore Orioles whipped the Yankees, 61.

title: Books of The Times National Insecurities
description: After almost 30 years in the business, from The Sandhill (N.C.) Citizen to The New York Times, Tom Wicker has come up with three Laws of Journalism: (1) So human a creature as newspaper inevitably reflects the character or its community ; (Z) A reporter should write and his newspaper should print what they know; and (3) Be neither in nor out, but decide for yourself just where that is. In addition, as a Times columnist with more than 1,500 opinions notched on his typewriter, he tells us that his most important guideline is Don't be afraid to be wrong.

title: New York City Curbs the Use of Parks, Citing Cumulative Damage
description: In a major change of policy, the Parks Department has decided to ban the Taste of the Big Apple celebration, which drew 300,000 people to Central Park last year,1 because of deep and cumulative damage to the park.

title: Military Pensions That Make Sense
description: The escalating cost of military pensions alarms both foes and friends of the military establishment. Those determined to hold the line on military spending see the eightfold increase in pension expenditures over the last 15 years as a major scandal. Traditional allies of the Pentagon worry that rising costs will undermine plans to modernize expensive weapons systems.

title: U.S. FACTORY UTILIZATION ROSE TO 82.9% FOR MARCH
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)United States factories operated at S2.9 percent of capacity last month, up from 81.9 percent in February, recovering from downturn earlier in the winter, the Federal Reserve said today.

title: Rodgers Triumphs in Boston Marathon
description: BOSTON, April 17Bill Rodgers won the 82d Boston Marathon today in nearrecord time, but not before enduring what he called the most painful finish of his career.

title: MICHAEL LERNER,86, STORECHAINFOUNDER
description: Michael Lerner, a businessman-turnednaturalist and internationally known hunter of big game ad deepsea fish, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Miami. He was 86 years old. Until last summer he also kept a residence at the Westchester Country Club in Rye, N.Y.

title: Article 1 -- No Title
Soviet U.N. Official Is Reported To Have Met U.S. Agents in Past
description: WASHINGTON, April 17Arkady N. Shevchenko, the highranking Soviet United Nations official who refused to return home last week, had been in contact with intelligence officers of the Fed- eral Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency for several years, according to a former intelligence officer familiar with the matter.

title: Sire Stakes Championship Slated at Roosevelt
description: Roosevelt Raceway will be one of the two tracks that stages the first North American Sire Stakes championship races for 3-year-olds in November.

title: Mime: Kipnis
description: An Evening With Claude Kipnis, which opened Sunday night at the Roundabout Theater, is an evening of pure virtuosity. Indeed, this solo mime program is an evening of nothing but virtuosity, for Mr. Kipnis's sketches tend to he all manner and no matter.

title: ARBITRATION FOUGHT ON POLICEFIRE PAY
description: JERSEY CITY, April 17This city argued today that New Jersey's statute, providing for binding arbitration for setCling policemen's and firemen's wage disputes could be in conflict with the state's 5 percent cap, or ceiling on municipal budget increases.

title: Carey Signs Bill for Higher Grants In Tuition Aid for College Students
description: ALBANY, April 17More than 130,000 !college students will benefit under a bill signed by Governor Carey that increases Tuition Assistance Program grants to maximum of $1,800 and a minimum of $200 in the next school year.

title: Obituary 4 -- No Title
description: Deaths

title: WEST BERLINERS MOURNING DEATH OF LUCIUS D. CLAY
description: WEST BERLIN, April 17Thirty years ago, when Gen. Lucius D. Clay stepped to the window of his office at the United States headquarters here, lie looked upon a bustling thoroughfare bearing his own name. The man who masterminded the Berlin airlift was the first. American honored by this city in having a street named after him.

title: John Rendel of Times; Yachting and Dog Writer Covered 6 America's Cups
description: John Rendel, a member of the sports department of The New York Times for 15 years, who specialized in covering yacht races, dog shows and horse shows, died Sunday night at Blake Hospital in Bradenton, Fla., where he had lived in retirement since 1971. He was 72 years

title: Theater: Catsplay Is Restaged
description: At an indeterminate point in her 60's, Ersike Orban, a widow in Budapest, can look back without regret. She has had an adoring husband and a rewarding life. And now, like an invigorated adolescent, she is embarking on a newly burgeoning romance with her once and future lover.

title: 2 Killed, One Missing in Explosion At Du Pont Plant in New Jersey
description: Two workmen were killed, one was reported missing and another was seriously injured last night when an explosion ripped through a Du Pont. gunpowder factory in Carneys Point, N.J.

title: New Englanders Get TaxFiling Extension
description: ANDOVER, Mass., April 17 (AP)All New England and upstate New York residents who file Federal tax returns with the Internal Revenue Service Center in Andover have until midnight tomorrow to send off their returns, an I.R.S. spokesman said.

title: JOHN SINES
description: KNOXVILLE, Tenn., April 17 (AP)John Sines, a former University of Tennessee basketball coach, died yesterday in Palmetto, Fla. He was 62 years old. VII. Sines who had lived in Palmetto for 15 years, suffered a stroke in December and had been hospitalized for several weeks with a brain tumor.

title: Carter and Aides Conclude Session
description: WASHINGTON, April 17President Carter and his Cabinet returned to Washington from Camp David today after twoday session that one aide described as a frank assessment of the Administration's difficulties in presenting its programs to Congress and the public.

title: Two Ensembles Win Naumburg Awards
description: Two ensembles have been named winners of the Naumburg Chamber Music Awards for next year, the Emerson String quartet and the Aulos Wind Quintet. Each will be given an appearance in Alice Tully Hall, the quartet on March 27. 1979, and the quintet on Feb. 12. 1979.

title: N.C.A.A. Is Accused Of Professional Tactics
description: WASHINGTON. April 17  On the fifth day of public hearings into the conduct and operations of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, an Oklahoma City attorney, told members of a Congressional Subcommittee today: The N.C.A.A. is a massive, com- mercial, tax exempt empire which does not radica:ly distinguish itself from professional athletics.

title: 3 on The Times Get Pulitzer Prizes; Philadelphia Inquirer Wins Award
description: Members of The New York Times staff won three Pulitzer Prizes yesterdayfor international reporting, commentary and criticism in I977in the first such triple honor to any newspaper since the journalism awards began in 1917.

title: Former Stamford Leader Indicted
description: STAMFORD, Conn., April I7A politically prominent lawyer here who is partner of the State Senate's deputy majority leader, and a lawyer in Providence. R. I. were indicted today as a result of a Federal investigation of gambling in Connecticut, Rhode Island and New

title: 16 Food Outlets Cited for Violations By New York City Health Agency
description: New York City's Health Department cited 16 foodhandling establishments yesterday for healthcode violations. also announced that one establishment that had been closed for violations had been allowed to reopen. The names of the businesses were listed as follows:

title: Swirl of Parties Tries to Breathe Life Into EqualRights Cause
description: In the last two days, Judy and Jack Carter of Calhoun, Ga., turned into one of New York's most outgoing couples. The Ginger Man restaurant briefly changed its name to The Ginger Person. And Bess Myerson called Anita Bryant a loser.

title: Detroit Computer School Is Focus of Case Alleging Cheating in Federal Aid Programs
description: DETROIT, April 17Essie Lee Conway, a large black woman in a pink bathrobe who has been down on her luck longer than she cares to remember, answers the door in a grimy housing project shoved up against the railroad tracks of Rivercherding said, he approached the Wayne County Department of Social Services with a proposal to train 3,000 welfare recipients for jobs as data processing specialists. He wanted social workers to help him sign them up.

title: ABC News Changing Cast and Role of Anchors
description: The ABC Evening News With Harry Reasoner and Barbara Walters is destined for a change of title. This is because the principal cast will be different when Roone Arledge, president of ABC News and Sports, lays out his plans for the newscast at an ABC affiliates meeting in Los Angeles next month.

title: Californians Pressing For 1% Property Tax
description: Home owners in California have started a drive to limit property taxes to 1 percent of the market value of their real estate, and their revolt has raised questions about the soundness of bonds sold to finance urban renewal projects in the state.

title: Detective Testifies About Recording Reply By Jascalevich on the Finding of Curare
description: HACKENSACK. N. .J., April 17A detective for the Prosecutor's office testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that he had hidden in a closet and made a recording of what Dr, .Jascalevich had said to other doctors at Riverdell Hospital when they first told him on the night. of Nov. 1, 1966, that they had found curare in his locker.

title: GEORGE H. FONDE
description: Dr. George H. Fonde, former chairman for many years of the department of dermatology of Meadowbrook Hospital in Nassau County, died Saturday at Hilair Farms in Huntington, L.1. Het was 74 years old and lived on Lloyd Neck in Huntington.

title: Television
Koch Plan to Speed TaxPaying Put Off By a Council Panel
description: A balky City Council Finance Commit lee could not muster the votes yesterday to pass part of Mayor Koc's fiscal.pack1 agea speedup in collection of New York City realestate taxes.

title: Primavera String Quartet Performs at Tully Hall
description: Firstclass string quartets do not spring fullblown out of the forehead of Jove, so it was no surprise to discover that the Primavera String Quartet came into being three years ago. The group, composed of four women in their 20's, gave a concert last night at Alice Tully Hall in recognition of winning the 1977 Naumburg Chamber Music Award.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Quintet No. 4, Myslivecek; Concerto Comique in A. Corette; Pierette's Veil, Wedding Waltz, Dohnanyi; Two Sonatas, Scarlatti; Piano Concerto No. 2, Finale; Scharwenka; Estudio brillante, Terreca.

title: Long Says Welfare Revision Plan Must Lower the Assistance Rolls
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)Senator Russell B. Long, the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, said today ho doubted that Americans were ready to accept any welfare revision that raised the number of people on welfare.

title: Events Today
description: THE TWILIGHT DINNER by Lennox Prownt directed by Douglas Turner Ward; presented by the Negro Ensemble Company, at the St. Marks Piayhouse, 133 Second Avenue, 7:30.

title: About Newyork
description: Forty years ago. Wilford English and Dorothy Cook were married at night in a Georgia cotton field, exchanging vows very quietly as the sharecropping land of Sandersville cycled through another spring.

title: About New york
description: Forty years ago, Wilford English and Dorothy Cook were married at night in a Georgia cotton field, exchanging vows very quietly as the sharecropping land of Sandersville cycled through another spring.

title: Macchiarola, Koch Choice, Named Chancellor by Board of Education
description: Frunk .1. Macchiarola, Mayor Koch's choice for Schools Chancellor, was appointed to the $56,775-a-year post yesterday by the Board of Education.

title: Macchiarola, Koch Choice, Named Chancellor by Board of Education
description: Frank .1. Macchiarola, Mayor Koch's choice for Schools Chancellor, was appointed to the $56,775-a-year post yesterday by the Board of Education.

title: Pilot Safe as F15 Crashes
description: LONDON, April 17 (AP)An American F15 fighter crashed into the North Sea today and a Royal Air Force helicopter rescued the pilot, the United States Third Air Force said. It said the pilot, who had ejected without injury, was Capt. Richard S. Hauk, 31 years old, of West Orange, N.J. He was flying from the 36th Tactical Fighter Wing at Bitburg, West Germany.

title: The Legal Profession Is Absorbing an Influx of Women
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 16In the late 1950's, when Prof. Ruth Bader Ginsburg was a student at Harvard Law School, women were not looked upon as people who should be there,

title: FIRST BOSTON POSTS LOSS; PAINE WEBBER NET DOWN
description: The First Boston Corporation reported yesterday a loss of $685.086 for the first quarter of 1978, in contrast to a profit of $136,566, or 5 cents a share, in the yearago period. Revenues declined 6.3 percent to $16.8 million from $17.9 million a year earlier.

title: SANCTION FOR A STRIKE IS ASKED BY PRESSMEN
description: The New York Newspaper Printing Pressmen's Union No. 2, with 1,550 members on the city's three major daily newspapers, has voted to seek strike sanction from its international union, William J. Kennedy Jr., the local's president, said yesterday.

title: Warnings About Tainted Marijuana Alarming Users
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 17Warnings against the use of Mexican marijuana that has been sprayed with a herbicide that can physically damage humans have aroused alarm here and elsewhere in the nation.

title: Puerto Rico Line Suspends Flights After Suspected Sabotage Incident
description: SAN JUAN, P.R. April 16 (Reuters)An executive of Puerto Rico International Airlines announced today that coarse sand was found yesterday in an engine of one of its commuter airplanes and that the company suspected sabotage. All flights were suspended until further notice, he said.

title: Best of Pompeii in Boston Museum
description: Pompeii, A.D. 79 at the Boston Museum of Fine Arts reinforces a belief common to nearly all of us: that one day Nature will cry Enough! and gobble us up.

title: 2 in Japan Survive 10Story Plunge
description: ROBE, Japan, April 17 (Reuters)Two tecnage lavers who jumped from a 10story building's roof in a suicide pact suffered mincr injuries after crashing through the roof of a Shinto shrine, the police said. The two, both highschool students, had left a letter saying their re'ations had been opposed by their parents.

title: Panama: The Senate's Final Test
description: The Panama Canal debate has been going on for long that it may be useful, on the day that the Senate will- finally bring it to a close, to recall just what it has been about. Recent newspaper and television coverage notwithstanding, it is not about Jimmy Carter's man- hood. He will not be a hero if 67 Senators vote toaay in favor of the second of the two treaties or a goat the number is 66. Whatever happens, he will remain the President whose negotiators brought back a sound basis for righting this country's relationship with a small neighbor to the south. What is really on the line today the wisdom of the United States Senate.

title: The Outsider Who Is Schools Chancellor
description: In many ways, Frank J. Macchiarnla, the next Chancellor of the New York City school system, is a counterpoint to the man he will succeed Irving Anker. Mr. Macchiarola, a 37-year-old lawyer, political scientist and educator, yearold Chancellor when Mr. Anker retires in June after 43 years in the city schools. The job will be the city public school system, although he has become familiar with its workings as the elected chairman of a community school board in Brooklyn.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: MORE FOR LESS With Bertolt Brecht's The Life of Galileo well received as a new stage production at Columbia University. another drama at low prices starts a fiveevening engagement on the campus tomorrow. As an April salute to the 150th anniversary of Henrik Ibsen's birthday, a revival of 'The Master Builder is being presented by the Teachers College Theater with a professional cast directed by Trisha Whitehurst, who has transposed the work, written in 1892, to a contemporary time and setting.

title: Notes on People
description: Eugene lonesco, the Rumanianhorn French playwright, refused to preside at a meeting at an international writers conference that opened in Paris yesterday, saying he objected to the presence of certain Soviet and Eastern European writers. I do not wish to preside at a police meeting; the writers sent by the Soviet Union and its satellites are selected by the police, Mr. lonesco said, adding, I would have accepted taking part in this meeting if Soviet, Czechoslovak and Rumanian dissidents were represented, but they are in jail or were not invited. The conference, which is discussing the role of authors from small countries in world culture, was organized by the Greek writers association.

title: House Committee Rebuffs 2 Reforms In Carter Tax Bill
description: WASHINGTON, April 17President Carter's tax hill got off to a shaky start in Congress today as the Ways and Means Committee rejected two out of three of Mr. Carter's revenuerising tax proposals.

title: BUBBLEGUM MAKERS WARM UP FOR TEST ON BASEBALL CARDS
description: WASHINGTON. April 17The Supreme Court cleared the field today for a major contest between two bubblegum manufacturers over charges that one of them lhas illegally shut out competition in the vital areas of baseball cards.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A News Summary item in The Times yesterday incorrectly stated that United  Nations Security Council Resolution 242 calls for Israel's eventual with drawal from all occupied Arab lands. The 1967 resolution actually calls for withdrawal of Israeli armed forces from territories occupied in the recent. conflict.

title: Islanders Victors In Opener, 4 to 1
description: UNIONDALE, L. I., April 17Coach Al Arbour of the Islanders had a surprise for the Toroneo Maple Leafs tonight, and it paid off in a 41 victory for New York in the first game of their Stanley Cup hockey quarterfinal playoff series.BOSTON, April 17 (AP)Peter McNab scored two goals and assisted on one as the Boston Bruins posted a 61 victory over the Chicago Black HawksMONTREAL, April 17 (UPI)Yvon Cournoyer excelled with two goals tonight as the Montreal Canadiens took the first game in their quarterfinal series with the Detroit Wings, 62.PHILADELPHIA, April 17 (AP)With Rick MacLeish scoring a pair of goals and Bernie Parent stopping 24 shots, the Philadelphia Flyers defeated the Buffalo Sabres, 41, tonight in the Stanley Cup playoffs.was in the penalty box for interference.

title: Runaway Youth, 17, Is Indicted For a Jail Fire That Killed 42
description: COLUMBIA, Tenn., April 17 (AP)A 17-year-old runaway youth from Wisconsin, who is accused of starting the fire that killed 42 people in the Maury County Jail, has been indicted on 32 counts of manslaughter and two counts of arson.

title: Mikhail Sheyne in Piano Recital
description: Last season, Mikhail Sheyne, a Russianhorn pianist who made his New York debut in 1937 and has lived in this country for years, had to break off a recital at Alice Tully Hall because of a sudden indisposition. Sunday night Mr. Sheyne returned to Tully Hall for a recital that improved as it went along.

description: Brea

description: TUESDAY, APRIL 18, 1978

title: FourDay Strike Ended By Nonteaching Workers At Schools in Yonkers
description: WHITE PLAINS, April 17A fourday, strike by 1.103 noiteacIfng Yonkers: school employees ended early this morning when members of the Civil Service Employee Association Noninstruction

title: Savings Banks Post $350 Million Inflow
description: The nation's mutual savings banks had a $350 million net deposit inflow in March, according to preliminary figures released yesterday by the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks. In February, the hanks had a et inflow of $171 million, while in January they had a net outflow of $59 million,

title: World News Briefs
description: Special to The New York Times

title: STOCK MARKET SETS A RECORD IN VOLUME FOR 2D STRAIGHT DAY
description: Huge purchases of stock by foreign investors and by domestic institutions, reflecting a rally in the dollar abroad and hopes for restraining inflation at home, erupted yesterday in another record trading session on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Neier Is Quilting Post at A.C.L.U.; He Denies Link to Defense of Nazis
description: Aryeh Neier, who oversaw the great expansion of the American Civil Liberties Union in the early 1970's and then became its principal defender as membership dwindled in the last year as a result of its defense of American Nazis, will resign as the group's executive director in the fall.

title: Rutherford Cases Join a Long List Of Baffling U.S. Cancer Clusters
description: The 32 cases of leukemia, Hodgkin's disease and similar blood cancers that have occurred in Rutherford, N.J., in the last five years represent another in a long stream of cancer clusters that have baffled researchers in recent decades.

title: Du Pont Posts 38.9% Advance In Net, a Record
description: E. 1. duPont de Nemours & Ccmpany. the world's largest chemical enterprise, achieved a 38.9 percent rise in its firstquarter net income, a record for any quarter on a sales gain of 12 percent.

title: Several Are Injured In Blast at Du Pont
description: Several Are Injured In Blast at DuPont

title: Play: Best Little House in Texas
description: The Best Little Whorehouse in Texas is a musical on a milk diet. It takes a small, bright, wry idea and expands and dilutes it at the same time.

title: CBS: Davis A Free Agent
description: After facing Congressional displeasure and internal disagreement over whether a network should have a contract with a boxer, CBS yesterday made Howard Davis Jr. a virtual free agent even though he has a deal with them through 1980.

title: Sketches of Pulitzer Prize Winners in Journalism, the Arts and Letters
description: WILLIAM K. MARIMOW Public Service

title: Soviet Georgians Win on Language
description: MOSCOW, April 17In an extraordinary concession to local patriotic feeling, authorities in the Soviet Union's Georgian Republic have reinstated Georgian as the official state language after a protest in the capital city of Tbilisi.

title: Earle Eckel, a Founder Of Antique Auto Club And a Businessman, 87
description: At the age of 15, Mr. Eckel went to New York and bought his first car, a 1903 Oldsmobile, for $250. It took him three days to drive it home, but he became an ardent advocate of the horseless carriage, and operated an agency from 1913 to 1922, selling Stanley Steamers, Overlands, Cadillacs and Chevrolets.

title: American Assembly Consensus  About Corporate Governance
description: How should the private power of the corporationthe most important economic institution of American society governed?

title: KEY SENATOR YIELDS TO PARTY'S LEADERS ON PLEDGE TO PANAMA
description: WASHINGTON, April 17On the eve of a still uncertain vote on the second Panama Canal treaty, the Senate Democratic leadership won the agreement of a key Senator today on the language of a reservation that would assert the United States policy of nonintervention in Panama's internal affairs.

title: Rodgers Wins 2d Time In Boston Marathon
description: Aerial view of the start of the 82d Boston Marathon yesterday at Hopkinton, Mass., as 4,212 participants began the more-than-26-mile run. Bill Rodgers, right, won event In nearrecord time of 2 hours 10 minutes 13 seconds. Article, page 49.

title: 3 of 5 ForestProduct Companies Increase FirstQuarter Earnings
description: Profits for forestproduct companies showed substantial gains over the first quarter last year., reflecting strong demand and higher prices for lumber and plywood. Three of the five companies reporting yesterday showed gains.

title: Texas Lawyer Fights for Release of Rudolf Hess
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 13  In cramped and cluttered office on the banks of the Colorado River just outside of town, a former Texas prosecutor is working determinedly to win the freedom of a man imprisoned 6,000 miles away whom he has never met.

title: New TeenAge Discovery: Beauty Salons
description: This decade's teenagers look different from their 1960's counterparts. For one thing, their jeans are tighter and better cut. Girls own skirts as well as pants and think that highheeled sandals are sexier than sneakers.

title: TV's Story of Nazi Terror Brings High Ratings and Varied Opinions
description: The first installment of NBC's Holocaust, a television dramatization of Hitler's. nearextermination of European Jews, achieved high ratings in three cities Sunday night and a generally favorable reaction from many who saw it.

description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, krIl 19 KUNGSFIOLM (Ragthir, Cruiscs). Left Horta APr. 11; ? 9 P M. at W. 55th

title: Argentina Regime Frees Publisher Held a Year In Scandal Investigation
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 17Argentina's military Government released the newspaper publisher Jacopo Timerman from prison today after having held him for more than a year without charges.

title: Col. Stanley Grogan, ExC.I.A. Aide
description: Col. Stanley J. Grogan, a onetime newspaper reporter who helped organized the War Department's bureau of public relations, served as an Army spokesman in World War II and later spent 15 years as Deputy Director of the Central Intelligence Agency, died of can cer Thursday at a nursing home in Washington. He was 87 years old.

title: CASINO HEAD EXPECTS 'MOB' TO STAY AWAY
description: The chairman of the Board of Resorts International Inc., which plans to open the East's first gambling casino next month, said yesterday that infiltration by organized crime would be no problem.

title: 3 Auto Dealers in Bronx Indicted On Charges of Altering Odometers
description: Three wholesale usedcar dealers were indicted yesterday on Federal charges that they had rolled back odometers to reduce the mileage on thousands of used cars sold in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

title: Comdr. Edward Whitehead, at 69; Led Schweppes Tonic Campaign
description: Comdr. Edward Whitehead, retired chairman of Schweppes (U.S.A.) Ltd. whose familiar beard and dry English demeanor helped sell his company's tonic water to Americans, has died in Britain, the company announced today in New York. He was 69 years old.

title: Japan's Trade Surplus Soars to $14.13 Billion
description: TOKYO, April 17Japan continued today to report new record trade figures, announcing that it ended its most recent fiscal year with a current account surplus of $14.13 billion. 40 percent higher than the last official estimate.

title: Record Turnover of 63.5 Million Shares Reflects Institutions Return to Action
description: The intermarket trading system, an electronic network designed to eventually link the nation's six major securities exchanges, got under way yesterday not with a bang, but a whimper.

title: NEW MIDEAST TALKS URGED BY CEAUSESCU
description: President Nicolae Ceausescu of Rumania urged Israel and Egypt yesterday to take urgent, new steps to resume talks for a peace settlement in the Middle East.

title: George Gerdes Sings Folk With a Twist
description: George Gerdes, who was at. Kenny's Castaways thr .,ugh Sunday night, is a sinner and songwriter who has been arnind throughout the 70's. He even made two albums, but more recently he's been confined, if that's the word. to the coin anu coitege circuit, esaecially in the Northeast. llis talmIts are considerable, however, the climate of music is shifting in such a way that it would hardly be surprising if he surfaced again on the national scene.

title: Rumblings in Jerry Finkelstein's Law Journal Empire

title: Coast Legislators Apparently Doom Nuclear Plant
description: LOS ANGELES, April 17Californians misgivings about nuclear hazards have brought about the apparent demise of one of the nation's largest pending atomilc.power projects.

title: 4 TeenAgers Held in Rape of Girl On Roof of Brooklyn Apartment
description: Four teenagers were arrested yesterday and charged with raping a 13-year-eid girl whom one of the youths was taking home from a neighborhood party. A fifth youth was being sought.

title: GOPOLAN KRISHNA
description: BRIDGEPORT, Cnnn., April 17 (AP)Gopolan Krishna, an assistant minister at the Indian Embassy in Washington. died yesterday after collapsing while playing tennis, authorities said. He was 42 years old.

description: Dow Jones Industrial Average Is Up as Foreign Investors and U.S. Institutions Buy Heavily

title: Article 4 -- No Title
Corporation Affairs
description: PARIS, April 17 (UPI)Air France has canceled its options to lease 13 Boeing 737 jetliners because of a dispute over staffing with its flight personnel, the stateowned airline announced today.

title: Richard Lindner, Painter Known For Figures of Women, Is Dead
description: Richard Lindner, one of the foremost figure painters of the second half of this century and the creator of a private mythology as compelling as any modern art, died in his sleep Sunday at his home at 3 East 71st Street. He was 76 years old.

title: Detective Testifies He Recorded Talk On Curare Finding
description: HACKENSACK, April 17.A detective for the Prosecutor's office testified today at the murder trial of Dr Mario E. Jascalcvich that he had hidden in a closet and made a recording of what Dr. Jascalevich had said to other doctors at Riverdell Hospital when they first told him on the night of Nov. 1, 1966, that they had found curare in his locker.

title: News Summary
description: On the eve of an uncertain vote on the second Panama Canal treaty, the Senate Democratic leadership won the agreement of a key Senator on the language of a reservation that would assert the United States policy of nonintervention in Panama's internal affairs. Senator Dennis DeConcini, Arizona Democrat, said he had agreed to the wording because it does not do any violence to a reservation he plans to introduce that provides that the United States has the right to intervene militarily in Panama to keep the canal open. !Page 1, Column 6.1

title: The Economic Scene

description: April 18, 1978

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar Up in Europe, Japan and New York
description: The dollar rose against major world currencies yesterday in Europe, Japan and New York in what foreignexchange dealers said was an indication that the stock market and foreignexchange mar- kets were feeding on each other's successes, The Associated Press reported.

title: Ford Lifts SmallCar Prices 1.9%
description: The Ford Motor Company announced yesterday a 1.9 percent price increase on three of its smallcar models. The rise followed a recent 5.4 percent increase on the Japanese Toyota cars, the leading import.

title: Rutherford Cases Join Long List Of Buffling  U.S. Cancer Clusters
description: The 32 cases of leukemia, Hodgkin's disease and similar blood cancers that have occurred in Rutherford, NJ., in the last five years represent another in a long stream of cancer clusters that have baffled researchers in recent decades.

title: Reporter's Notebook: FiveDay Search for a Rhodesian Comnromise
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 17As Cyrus R. Vance's Air Force 707 was flying to Rhodesia early this morning, a groggy Dr. D- vid Owen wandered to the back of the Mane. The British

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A News Summary item in The Times yesterday incorrectly stated that United Nations Security Council Resolution 242 calls for Israel's eventual with. drawal from all occupied Arab lands. The 1967 resolution actually calls for withdrawal of Israeli armed forces from territories occupied in the recent conflict.

title: 3 on The Times Get Pulitzer Prizes; Philadelphia Inquirer Wins Award
description: Members of The New York Times staff won three Pulitzer Prizes yesterdayfor international reporting, commentary and criticism in 1977in the first such triple honor to any newspaper since the journalism awards began in 1917.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: A Connecticut judge dismissed drug possession charge against Linda Blair, the I9-year-old actress besi known for her role in the film The Exorcist after she agreed yesterday to spend nine months in drug rehabilitation program.

title: CASINO HEAD EXPECTS `MOB TO STAY AWAY
description: The chairman of the Board of Resorts International Inc., which plans to open the East's first gambling casino next month, said yesterday that infiltration by organized crime would he no problem.

title: Mets Revise Lineup, Top Cards, 62
description: ST. LOUIS, Tuesday, April 18--in marathon game that included more than two hours of rain delays, the Mats got productive results from a shakeup of their batting order and downed the Cardinals, 62, this morning before adrenched gathering of 6,371 at Busch Stadium.

title: USE OF CITY'S PARKS CURBED BY NEW YORK
description: In a major change of policy, the Parks Department has decided to ban the Taste of the Big Apple celebration, which drew 300,000 people to Central Park last year, because of deep and cumulative damage to the park.

title: American Ballet Theater Opens Its Season at Met
description: Through a quirk of ballet history, one of George Balanchine's signature works was not created for his own company but for American Ballet Theater, which opened its eightweek season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night with this splendid ballet, called Theme and Variations.

title: Advertising
description: Find out what people want and give it to them. That, broadly, is what marketing is all about.

title: Met's Board to Vote Today On 2 Aides to Run Museum
description: The board of trustees of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, f searching for more than a year for a two-man administrative teama president and a directorto fill the post vacated by the retirement of Thomas Floving, will meet this afternoon to vote on recommendaLions from its search committee.

title: Laker Airways, in Sale, Will Cut TransAtlantic Fares $57, to $183
description: LONDON, April 1-/H-Laker Airways, in a move that may start still another round of transAtlantic price cuts, announced today a sale on six roundtrip charter flights to the United States and Canada.WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)The Civil Aeronautics Board announced today an expansion of supersaver fares that will allow six airlines to cut their rates an additional 10 percent for night. travel under the restricted bargain packages.

title: For Some, Glory
description: BOSTON, April 17The race upstairs was obviously to the swift. But down below street level in a mammoth garage converted into an emergency field hospital, the accolades were going to the nurse who could deftly slip an intravenous needle into an unfeeling arm, and to the young doctors who could find the right spot for an injection of muscle relaxant when the cramps set in.

title: Article 6 -- No Title
description: THE FIRST STEP: Ground was broken yesterday for 26story office building of the Public Service Electric and Gas Company, the first major construction in Newark in six years. At the ceremony were Alton G. Marshall, president, Rockefeller Center; Anthony .1. Peters, chairman, Cushman & Wakefield Inc.; Robert I. Smith, chairman of the utility; Kenneth A. Gibson, Mayor; Robert V. Tishman, president, Tishman Realty & Construction Co.; Joel R. Jacobson, Department of Energy; and Earl Harris, City Council President.

title: Dr. Alexander Sandow, Researcher In Biology on N.Y.U. Faculty, 77
description: Dr. Alexander Sandow, research professor of biology at New York University, died yesterday at St. Vincents Hospital after a brief illness. He was 77 years old and lived at 29 Washington Square West.

title: Koch Details 60 Grant Projects Including a Mall on Times Square
description: The Koch administration yesterday proposed nearly 60 programs in housing. neighborhood revitalization and public services to he financed with $224 million in Federal community development funds recently granted to the city.

title: KEY SENATOR YIELDS TO PARTY'S LEADERS ON PLEDGE TO PANAMA
description: WASHINGTON, April 1On the the of a still uncertain vote on the second Panama Canal treaty, the Senate Democratic leadership won the agreement of a key Senator today on the language of a reservation that would assert the United States policy of nonintervention in Panama'' internal affairs.

title: Soviet U.N. Official Is Reported To Have Met U.S. Agents in Past
description: WASHINGTON, April I7Arkady N. Shexchenko, the high-ranking ? United Nations official who ? to return home last week. had been in contact with intelligence officers of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency for several years, according to a former intelligence officer familiar with the matter.UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 17The Soviet official here who refused a week ago to return to Moscow did so again last night.

title: Desai Says U.S.Indian Team Lost Atomic Spy Gear
description: NEW DELHI, April 17Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai said today that a joint IndianAmerican intelligence team had lost a nuclearpowered spy device in the Himalayas 12 years ago.

title: Hicks Traded to Steelers By Giants for 2 Players
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 17 (AP)Delvin Williams, the running hack who was displaced when the San Francisco 49ers acquired O.J. Simpson, was traded to the Miami Dolphins today.

title: Holocaust: Systematic Slaughter Of Six Million of Europe's Jews
description: Condemned by the Nazis as an inferior racebranded as Bolsheviks and plutocrats, conspirators and enemies, vermin and parasites. devils to he annihilated to allow salvation of the German soulsix million Jews died.

title: Article 3 -- No Title
FLOREAL RUIZ
description: BUENOS AIRES, Argentina, April 17 (AP)Floreal Ruiz, one of Argentina's most famous tango singers, died here today at the age of 69. Mr, Ruiz belonged to the generation of the forties, the decade when the music of Buenos Aires achieved unprecedented peaks of quality and popularity. He was the principal singer for the well known tango bands of Alfredo de Angelis, Anibal Troilo and Francisco Rotundo.

title: Mine Union Votes for Convention That Could Aid in Miller's Ouster
description: WASHINGTON, April 17 (UPI)The international executive board of the United Mine Workers voted today to hold a constitutional convention within 18 months, a move that could help dissidents seeking to push out the ailing union president, Arnold R. Miller.

title: U.S. Plans First Action in a 15Year Effort to Restore StripMine Lands
description: WASHINGTON, April 17The Agriculture Department today announced plans for the first Federal expenditures this summer to reclaim some of the 1.1 million acres of stripmined waste land abandoned by the coal industry before environmental protests in the 1960's brought about conservation controls.

title: Study of 40 Cities Indicates Blacks Still Face Strong Bias in Housing
description: WASHINGTON, April 17A national ;study indicates that only one out of four blacks is given the the same choice as .a white person in seeking an apartment, Patricia Roberts Harris, the Secretary of ,Housing and Urban Development, said i today.

title: F.R. LEAVIS, LEADER IN BRITISH LETTERS
description: LONDON, April 17 (AP)Frank Raymond Leavis the British critic is dead at the age of 82, his family said today. He died at his home in Cambridge on Friday after being bedridden for nearly year, his wife, Queenie, said.

title: Market Place
description: Robert C. Dunlop, retired chairman of the Sun Company and the only member of its board who also serves on the board of the Glenmede Trust. acknowledged yesterday that he had not been in a position to tell Glenmede that Sun was making a hid to take over Becton, Dickinson 8: Company until after the Sun board had actually put its plan in operation.

title: NEW YORK CALLED LAX ON DRIVERS LICENSES
description: WASHINGTON, April 17An insurance lawyers organization based here has Complained to GovErnor Carey that New York State may be illegally registering 18,000 to 20,000 drivers a year who have been suspended for serious violations elsewhere.

title: Panama Indicates It Can Now Accept Canal Treaties
description: PANAMA, April 17The Panamanian Government indicated today that a new Senate reservation renouncing any American right to intervene in this country's internal affairs should enable it to accept the new canal treaties and overcome domestic opposition to them.

title: U.S. ENVOY RETURNING TO MIDEAST FOR TALKS
description: WASHINGTON, April 17The State Department announced today that the special United States representative for the Middle East would return there this weekend for discussions in Egypt and Israel on possible next moves in the negotiating process.

title: State Senate Panel to Check on Reappointed Judges
description: TRENTON, April 17The Senate Judiciary Committee agreed today to subject state judicial reappointments to more scrutiny, and began designing a questionnaire to be be completed by judges up for reappointment.

title: Carter Writes to Italy Of Prayers for Moro
description: ROME, April 17 (AP)President Carter, in a message to the Italian Government, said today that he is praying for the safe and speedy return of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro. who has been threatened with death by his Red Brigades kidnappers.

title: LACK OF NEW MONEY FOR TRANSIT ALLEGED
description: City Council President Carol Bellamy and a coalition of 250 neighborhood groups said in separate statements yesterday that no new money was involved in the still-to-be-announced paskage of mass transit aid: promised by Governorl

title: Credit Markets Advance in Price for 3d Straight Session, But Trading Activity Slackens
description: The credit markets moved higher in price for the third consecutive session yesterday, but they lost much of the excitement they generated Friday in the wake of the Federal Reserve's report of an unexpectedly small increase in the money supply.

title: Rodgers Wins 2d Time In Boston Marathon
description: Aerial view of the start of the 82d Boston Marathon yesterday at Hopkinton, Mass., as 4,212 participants began the more-than-26-mile run. Bill Rodgers, right, won event In nearrecord time of 2 hours 10 minutes 13 seconds. Article, page 49.

title: Taxes &
description: The ink is barely dry on Governor Carey's signature approving the new tax law that cuts New York State income taxes for individuals across the salary spectrum, but it is already causing consternation in the business community.

title: Supreme Court Roundup
description: WASHINGTON, April 17The Supreme Court agreed today to resolve a dispute between judges and law enforcement officers that has sensitive implications for interstate cooperation and the criminal justice system.

description: Yankees vs. Blue Jays, at Toronto. (Radio WINS, 4 P.M.)
