title: N.A.A. C. P. Renews Dispute With Legal Defense Fund Over Use of Name
description: ATLANTA, April 18In a move likely to strain relations between the two organizations, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People will try to prohibit the NAACP Legal Defense Fund Inc. from using the N.A.A.C.P. name, according to sources within the association.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 19, 1978

title: First Aid for Epileptic Seizures
description: The Epilepsy Foundation of America recommends the following firstaid measures if you witness someone having a grand mal seizure:

title: About Real Estate
description: Management is on an even keel at the Brooklyn Navy yard, with occupancy at 97. percent, according to the Commerce Labor Industry Corporation of Kings. The organization's 12year experience as a nonprofit local develop- ment corporation is especially interesting at a time when economic development and community involvement are both getting emphasis in the city's strategy for revitalization in the South Bronx.

title: Moynihan Aid Plan For Thruway Seeks T o End Tolls by 96
description: WASHINGTON. April 18A plan to provide Federal aid for Ihe first. time to the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway was announced today by Senator Daniel Pat, rick Moynihan.

title: F.C.C. Hunts an Illicit TV Station That Pirated Some Notable Shows
description: SYRACUSE, April 18No one knows for sure how many people saw telecasts over the weekend of such fare as Deep Throat and Rocky on a station calling itself Lucky Seven. What is certain is that the programs cane over Channel 7, and there is not supposed to he any Channel 7 in Syracuse.

title: 2 Judges Testify on Missing Tape In Murder Trial of Dr. Jascalevich
description: HACKENSACS April 18Two Cuperior Court judge z rs witre7zes today in the murder trial of Dr, Mario E. Jascalevich in a hearing to determine whether statements the doctor gave to the Bergen couny Presecwor's office in 1966 should be adimitted in evidence.

title: Music: International Beat
description: LEARNING how to play the music of other culturesnot just the instruments but the musical materials and intangibles of traditional musical stylesis a relatively easy thing nowadays. One can study with master drummers from Ghana or Indonesian gamelan musicians at universities such as Wesleyan or the University of California at Los Angeles or one can go to other countries to learn.

title: House Group Questions N.C.A.A.'s Tax Status
description: WASHINGTON, April 18Representative John E. Moss asked the Justice Department today to reviev, the tax-exempt status of the National Collegiate Athletic Association. The association is a nonprofit organization that does not pay Federal income taxes.

title: A Changing Spain Lets Far Right's Symbols Fade
description: MADRID, April 18The far right in Spain appears to be languishing.

title: Jazz: Turning Point Plays
description: WHEN Tom Pierson, musical director of The Wiz, organized his jazz group, Turning Point, four years ago, his concept was an ensemble built around three keyboards. In actuality, it never got beyond two keyboards, and, when Ben Aronov, one of the two, left the group several months ago, Turning Point was down to the stand- and single keyboard, played by Mr. Pierson.

title: Wright Attends Council Meeting, Ruling on Ouster Issue Is Awaited
description: City Councilman Samuel D. Wright, convicted last weekend in Federal Court on kickback charges, attended a meeting of the Council yesterday amid some confusion as to when, or whether, he would have to forfeit the seat he has held since 1974.

title: Bargaining for New Postal Contract Opens Tomorrow
description: WASHINGTON, April 18Bargaining between the United States Postal Service and the unions representing 650,000 employees, which opens Thursday, will shape the largest single labor contract of the year.

title: Merrill Lynch Profits Plunge 97.1%
description: Merrill Lynch & Company, parent of Merrill Lynch Pierce Fenner & Smith, the nation's largest brokerage firm, announced yesterday that its first quarter net income declined 97.1 percent on an 18.2 percent increase in revenues.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: DETROIT, April 18 (AP)The price of Japanesebuilt cars climbed again today with Nissan U.S.A. announcing a 5.4 percent increase on Datsun cars and pickup trucks sold in this country. The latest Datsun increase averaged $265 per car and was identical to the price increase announced last week by Toyota.

title: Private Lives
description: IT IS NOW possible to divide the world into two classes of people. There are those who will permit me to make a fool of myself in public, and there are those who won't. This has been a trying week.

title: Fire Damages an Alexander's
description: A fire yesterday afternoon caused considerable damage to the third floor of the Alexander's department store in Rego Park, Queens, fire officials said. The cause of the fire was not immediately determined.

title: Rhodesian Impasse: U.S. Counts on Split Among Guerrillas
description: LONDON, April 18In the aftermath of his inconclusive African trip, Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance is pinning American hopes in southern Africa on somehow enticing Joshua Nkomo, the more flexible of the two Rhodesian guer- rilla leaders, to join in a negotiated settlement with the Salisbury Government even if Robert Mugabe, the other guerrilla leader, refuses.

title: Cooking School GuidE
New Chancellor Would Reward Schools That Improve Reading
description: Frank J. Macchiarola, the New York I City publicschool system's next Chancellor, said yesterday that he hoped to find a way to give extra money to schools that improved pupils reading scores.

title: Advertising
description: May Day will bring with itbesides the customary dancing about the Maypolea brand new ad agency called Herman & Rosner Enterprises. What sets it apart is that it will begin with $10 million in billings and will never have an account man.

title: Guyanese Visits Lenin's Tomb
description: MOSCOW, April 18 (AP)Prime Minister Forbes Burnham of Guyana laid wreath at Lenin's tomb today and visited Kremlin exhibits with members of his delegation, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, said.

title: Nazis in U.S.: Small Bands At War With One Another
description: CHICAGO. April 18American Nazis, despite much recent attention, do not appear to he more than a fragmented assortment of small, widely scattered bands of rightwing ideologues.

title: Study of Peru Brothel Gets Fleece Award
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)  A federally financed study of a Peruvian brothel was the winner of Senator William Proxmire's monthly Golden Fleece Award.

title: HOUSE PANEL DEALS CARTER'S TAX PLAN TWO MORE SETBACKS
description: WASHINGTON, April 18President Carter's income tax plan suffered two more setbacks today in the Ways and Means Committee.

title: Business Records
description: Tuesday, April 18, 1978

title: House Panel Rejects Plan to Give Surveillance Power to White House
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)The House Intelligence Committee today rejected a plan that would give the White House and the Attorney General the last word on whether electronic surveillance could ha used against foreign powers or agents operating in the United States.

title: Investigators Seek Cause of Du   Pont Blast in Jersey
description: CARNEYS POINT, N.J., April 18State and Federal investigators sifted through the ruins today of a Du Pont powder plant that blew up last night and killed three persons and injured a fourth. Twelve other workers on the shift scrambled to safety.

title: SOPHIA L, FAHS, 101; RELIGIOUS EDUCATOR
description: Sophia Lyon Fahs, who at the age of 82 was ordained a Unitarian minister after a lifetime as a religious educator and authcr, died Monday in Hamilton, Ohio. She was 101 years old.

title: Sponser in Senate Seeks to Delay  New York Legalese Ban for Year
description: ALBANY, April 18The Senate sponsor of the socalled plain language bill making legalese illegal for certain consumer contracts is moving to delay the effective date of the law for one .year because of major ambiguities.

title: Model Cities Plan Meets Snag in Suit By Harlem Group
description: Part of Mayor Koch's plan to restructure the Model Cities program has run into a snaga suit by the HarlemEast Harlem Model Cities Policy Committee that charges that community opinion not bein2 taken into account.

title: ExDiplomat to Head Met Museum
description: After more than a year's search, the trustees of the Metropolitan Museum or Art have elected the museum's first fulltime salaried president. He is William. B. Macomber Jr., a 57-year-old retired diplomat whose last post was Ambassador to Turkey from 1973 to 1977.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: The Koch administration has eliminted out-of-town :fitc. for summer youth jobs, Employment Commissioner Stanley Brettenoff cid. llecause spot audits had uncovered sectarian activity, a lack of real work, inadequate supervision and, in a ire: case'alleted kickbacks at upstate comps, most cf them in the Catskills.

title: Gains Seen in Railroad Mergers And End of Duplicating Services
description: The Interstate Commerce Commission announced a few days ago that it was considering the adoption of more liberal policy governing applications for mergers in the railroad industry and for cutting down on exces- sive rail capacity through such affiliations. Comment is due within 30 days and is likely to he positive on the part of many railroads, which have long advocated relaxation of the agency's tough and prolonged procedures.

title: Red SOX 7, Brewers 6
description: BOSTON. April 18 (AMCarlton Fisk's twoout, runscoring double in the ninth inning capped a rally that gave the Boston Red Sox their siNth straight victory, a 7G decision over the MILwaukee Brewers today. Luis Tiant. gained the victory in his 1978 debut.

title: Reagan Says: I Am Disappointed
description: TOKYO, Wednesday. April 19 (AMRonald Reagan, a leader of the fight against the Panama Canal treaties, said today, naturally. I am disappointed at the Senate's approval of them.

title: Corporation Earnings Reported for the Latest Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock E xchange,( A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) over-thecounter.

title: Gold and Silver Futures Advance
description: CHICAGO, April 18 (AP)Prices of futures contracts for precious metals struggled higher today, regaining some of the ground lost during the stock market's dramatic surge a day earlier.

title: Matthews Is Chairman Of MasseyFerguson
description: MasseyFerguson Ltd,, the big Torontobased producer. of tractors and agricultural, industrial and construction equipment, announced yesterday the appointment of A. Bruce Matthews as chairman. In addition, Alex E. Bar- ron was named chairman of the compaity's executive committee. Both posts had been held by John A. McDougald, who died last month.

title: Henry K. Chapman, Trial Lawyer; Held Legal Post in Albany in 20's
description: Henry K. Chapman, a trial lawyer ill New York City for half a century, died Sunday at Mount Sinai Hospital after long illness. He was 77 years old and lived at 1025 Fifth Avenue.

title: Opera: Debussy Oddity
description: FROM 1846 TO 1849, Edgar Allan Poe lived in the Bronx, a mysterious land lying somewhere to the north of Manhattan. That fact served as reason enough for the Bronx Arts Ensemble to present the New York premiere of a fragment from Debussy's unfinished opera, La Chute de la Maison Usher, which he based on Poe's The Fall of the House of Usher.

title: Deaths
description: CLARKE- Florence.April 17, 1978.Survived by daughter, Mrs. John J. Dowling, Jr. and daughterinlaw, Mrs. Lawrence J. Clarke Jr. & two grandchildren, Tom & Kelly Clarke.Also a sister, Mrs. Desmond T. Barry & brother Mr. Gerald T. O'Connor.Memorial Mass Saturday 10AM April 22 Most Holy Trinity Church, East Hampton. Interment private.Contributions may be sent to Guild Hall or Most Holy Trinity Church,East Hampton NY.

title: JUDGESHIP NOMINEES ARE NAMED BY KOCH
description: Mayor Koch yesterday announced the names of six lawyers he intends to make Criminal and Family Court judges, and, i!ndcr a system he announced last Thursday, he scheduled a public hearing for May 1 to receive comments en the nominees.

title: AUTO CREDIT UNITS PRICE NOTES TODAY
description: The credit markets, after a threeday rally, quieted down yesterday, with prices essentially unchanged on moderate trading volume in both the government and municipal markets.

title: Strawberries: Locals Are Better
description: Although strawberries have become virtually a yearround feature at greengrocers and restaurants, for the most part the specimens offered are mere symbols of the true and tender local springtime berries of yesteryear. Huge, orangeyred, often flat or looking like freakish mutations of three or four berries grown in a single mass, these berries for all seasons are generally tasteless and drily hollow inside. Their most notable features are their availability, and, usually, their astronomical price:

title: Critic of Income Tax Indicted on Not Filing
description: Irwin A. Schiff, an insurance agent and author of The Biggest Con: How the Government Is Fleecing You, a book published in 1976 that is critical of Federal monetary and fiscal policies, including the income tax, has been indicted for failure to file tax returns for 1974 and 1975.

title: Music: The Indianapolis Symphony
description: INDIANA sent a message to New York last night an expensive one delivered at Carnegie Hall. Costly and dazzling though the transmission was, the message itself was simple: The Indianapolis Symphony, with John Nelson as music director, is on the move and seeking a place for itself in the nation's musical limelight.

title: Mobil Breaks Ground in Virginia in Move From 42d St.
description: FALLS CHURCH. Va., April 18Gov. John N. Dalton of Virginia joined top executives of the Mobil Oil Corporation here today in ceremonially breaking ground for the new suburban office complex that will give 1,300 Mobil employees a $47 million change of scenery in 1980.

title: Recycling of Garbage Into Power Planned by Utility in Atlantic City
description: WOODM5RY. April 18 The Atlantic City Electric Company announced plans today for an SSO million generating plant that will recycle 1.500 tons of garbage a day into electricity for South Jersey.

title: ARNE H. KRISTIANSSON
description: Arne Henrik liristiansson, executive vice president of the Grancolomhiana shipping line, died Monday at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 51 years old.

title: Miss Navratilova's Bid For Citizenship Stalled
description: WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)Martina Navratilova's bid for immediate United States citizenship was stalled today when the House of Representatives declined to take up a bill that would have shortened the customary fiveyear waitine period for her.

title: Housing Starts Up 32% in March
description: WASHINGTON. April 18 (AMThe nation's builders increased new construction by 32 percent last month as the housing industry reCovered from its vinter slump. the Commerce Department said today.

title: Rubin Scores in Golf Tourney
description: SYOSSET, L.I., April 18Lillie Rubin, of the Mill River Country Club won low gross portion of the Nassau County Women's Golf Association Class A tournament at Woodcrest Country Club today with a score of 90 for 18 holes. Dotty Bass of Tam O'Shanter and Helen Siegel of Cold Spring tied for a low net at 72.

title: City Aides Draw Plans to Rebuild 15 BurnedOut Homes in Brooklyn
description: New York City officials are completing a proposal to rebuild Pine Street between Blake and Dumont Avenues in the East New York section of Brooklyn, much of which was destroyed in a fouralarm fire last month.

title: Two Oklahoma Papers Sold
description: McALESTER, Okla., April 18 (AP)Park Newspapers Inc. of Ithaca, N.Y., announced today the acquisition of the morning Daily McAlester Democrat and the afternoon McAlester NewsCapital. The morning paper has ceased publicadon, and the surviving paper will be called the McAlester News Capital and Democrat. Park now owns 27 newspapers and 21 television and radio stations.

title: America Learns the Touch of Friendship
description: Now basically I look like this American person, and when I was little I did all these American things. And you can't tell from looking at me that when had grown to man's estate, and Annapolis and then the Navy had spit me Out, went to live on the Continent of Europe, where people kiss, and touch, and eye each other promiscuously, and that I fell into these dissolute ways.

title: ITALIANS FAIL TO FIND MORO'S BODY IN AREA CITED BY ABDUCTORS
description: ROME, April 18Italian security forces on skis and in helicopters today staged a vain search for the body of Aldo Moro, the political leader, after his kidnappers had said in a statement that he was dead and that his body had been thrown into a mountain lake about 75 miles northeast of here.

title: Billy Hatfield and Earl McCoy
description: Since the early days of the London prize ring, fake fights, phony feuds and trumpedup grudges have inspired golden chapter in the literature of sport. Sonny Liston going in the water for Muhammad Ali, Jake LaMotta doing a dive for Billy Fox without leaving his feet. the infinite variety the artists who swooned for Primo Cameraperformances like these have dazzled readers and beholders over the years. Yesterday two masters at the art of dissembling, Billy Martin and Earl Weaver, went another round in the mock battle they nave been waging as long as they have managed baseball teams in the American League.

title: Police Got Wrong Identification For 2 Men Arrested at Concert
description: FORT WAYNE, Ind., April 18 (AP)Two persons identified as members of the Bob Seger band after arrests were made at a rock concert had no connection with the Seger group, the Fort Wayne police said today.

title: Church Shows Signs He Will Relish Foreign Relations Post
description: WASHINGTON, April 18Although he will not assume the chairmanship of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee for !another eight months, Senator Frank Church, Democrat of Idaho, is already grooming himself for the job.

title: 60 Minute Gourmet;
description: THE TWO basic and most desirable qualities in food are flavor and texture. One vegetable that yields a fascinating, different and admirable combination of both is endive, that white, pointed member of the chicory family that is a specialty of Belgium.

title: Notes on People
description: BILLY CARTER was listed in good condition at a Georgia hospital alter being admitted for what his physician. Dr. Paul Brow). described as a general checkup and health maintenance proce dures. The President's brother was admitted Sunday at the AmericusSumter County Hospital in Americus and is ex- pected to stay another day or two. was also learned yesterday that Mr. Carter underwent Xrays of his head last Saturday at McKeesport Hospital in Pennsylvania. A hospital administrator said there was no indication of a head injury. fie had been appearing a; a suburban Pittsburgh appliance store.

title: NEW OFFER BY CAREY ON WESTWAY IS SET
description: ALBANY, April 18As part of his effort to get Mayor Koch's approval for the Westway. Governor Carey will offer New York City new state funds that would add $200 million to the $600 million for mass transit disclosed last week, high state officials said today.

title: Dow Drops 6.85 to 803.27 As Traders Cash in Gains
description: The stock market, after three sessions of soaring prices and hectic trading, declined moderately yesterday as traders cashed in on some of their gains.

title: Agreement Reached For Nursing Homes, Averting a 2d Strike
description: Nursinghome workers and their employers reached a new agreement yesterday, averting what would have been the second strike in a month.

title: Team Canada Tops Sweden
description: GOTEBORG, Sweden, April 18 (AP) Marcel Dionne scored a goal and set up another as Team Canada opened its European hockey tour with a 51 victory over Sweden tonight. The Canadian team is made up of National Hockey League players whose clubs missed or were eliminated in the first round of the playoffs.

title: Corporate Use of Political Action Panels Growing
description: WASHINGTON, April 18Our efforts to remain a viable corporation, and to continue to provide those things to our shareholders, our customers, our employees and our communities which we have provided in the past, are dependent upon the political fabric of our country, the newly created Political Action Committee of Philip Morris Inc. says in draft brochure.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 19, 1978

title: Food Festival Considers New Site
description: Sponsors of the Taste of the Big Apple, the food festival that drew 300,000 last year to Central Park, said yesterday they were considering holding the event this year at Lincoln Center or the South Street Seaport.

title: G.T.&E. Net Up 20 .1% in Quarter; Republic Steel Operations in Black
description: The General Telephone and Electronics Corporation reported yesterday a 20.1 percent rise in firstquarter net income on a 12 percent gain in sales and revenues.

title: New Chancellor Would Reward Schools That Improved Reading
description: Frank 1. Macchiarola. the New York City puhlicschool system's next Chancel lor, said yesterday that he hoped to find a way to give extra money to schools that improved pupils reading scores.

title: Deaths
description: SCHELLCharles K. Suddenly on Monday, April 17, at home, RD 1, Addison, Pa. 13411. Retired engineer. Survived by his wife, Anna Mae Charlesworth Schell. son James of Washington, D.C., and daughter Elizabeth Lee Jackson of Washington, D.C. Memorial service will be held Saturday, I PM in the Addison United Methodist Church. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Heart Fund.

title: Wilhite of Lions Tops Gehrig Mark
description: Mike Wilhite eclipsed Lou Gehrig's Columbia record for home runs in a season when he connected yesterday for his eighth of the year. That mark, the only one Gehrig still held from his one season with Columbia in 1923, was tied by Bob Kimutis in 1976.

title: Steel Company's Head Is Kidnapped in Italy
description: MILAN, Italy, April 18 (Reuters)Four gunmen, one wearing a police uniform, kidnapped the owner of a steel company on his way to his office here today after stopping his taxi at a roadblock, the police said.

title: Best Buys
description: NEW GROUND was broken last week when the cost of feeding a family of four in New York City crossed the $80-a-week level for the first time.

title: Investigators Seeking Cause of Fatal Blast at Du Pont
description: CARNEYS POINT, April 18State and Federal investigators sifted through the ruins today of a Du Pont powder plant that blew up last night and killed three pesons and injured a fourth. Twelve other workers scrambled to safety.

title: The Saga of a Sauce
description: FAIR LAWN. N.J.

title: Israel Plans to Pull Bach Farther in South Lebanon
description: TEL AVIV, April 18Israeli and United Nations military commanders agreed today to schedule Israeli withdrawals from southern Lebanon by early next month to a line some six miles from the international frontier.

title: Big Board to Assist Order Routing
description: The New York Stock Exchange. in a move to facilitate the development of national market system for trading securities, has agreed to participate in creating a universal orderrouting system.

title: The Editorial Notebook When the Puppet Rebels
description: When South Africa began to create allegedly independent republics as homelands for each of its major black ethnic groups, the world reacted with derision to what were plainly intended as puppet states. It was inevitable, however, that sconer or later one of these puppets would attempt to assert real independence from Pretoria. That seems to be happening now in the Transkei, the 18monthold homeland for the Xhosa people, which has severed its only diplomatic linkto South Africa. Behind the break by Chief Kaiser Matanzima, Transkei's Prime Minister, lies a set of comicopera circumstances. Above all, he appeared to be scoring some political points inside his realm. But he has given a hint of other steps that may pose a dilemma for South Africa, and perhaps for the West as well.

title: Deaths
description: MUSTERMorris. The Board of DI. rectors and members of the Home Furnishing Association of New York are deeply grieved by the loss of our beloved Past President and Executive Secretary. His dedication and inspiration was a constant source of strength to our members and Association. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved and devoted wile, Gertrude, and his loving fami.

title: Issue and Debate
description: Beginning next June, seniors who want a diploma from public high schools in New York State will have to have passed statewide basic competency tests in reading and mathematics.

description: WASHINGTON, April 18The Supreme Court today refused to give broadcasters and recording companies the right to copy, broadcast and sell excerpts from the White House tapes that led to the resignation of President Nixon and the criminal conviction of four of his aides.

description: Al Rosen, president of the New York Yankees, said yesterday that a thorough review by the clubs fiscal experts had shown no evidence of impropriety in its financial dealings with New York City, which rebuilt and owns Yankee Stadium.

description: UPTON, N.Y.The argument in the United States about nuclear power and weapons proliferation usually asserts, or acknowledges, that the reprocessing of nuclear fuel and the subsequent use of plutonium do have proliferation risks, and then debates whether their economic value justifies those risks.

Stanleyand to watch him only once is to be on firstname basis foreveris a localtelevision phenomenon, the host of The Stanley Siegel Show, which can be seen each weekday morning from 9 to In o'clock on WABCTV.

title: Barter: A New Look For an Old Custom
description: A graphic designer will design anything from closet space to greeting cards, in exchange for help in marketing what he turns out. A singer will give voice lessons and voice therapy in return for dulcimer lessons, a working vacuum cleaner and various crafts. A woman wants to get rid of silver evening pumps and a stole; she'd like a rug shampooed, a floor scraped and waxed.

title: Valentine's Pinch Hit Defeats Cards

Strada Jr., said today that his Stamford law firm had been cleared in an Internal Revenue Service audit that covered a 525,000 payment from a Rhode Island gambling promoter, but he refused to discuss the details of charges against Isis partner.

description: CHICAGO, April 18Citicprp, the parent company of Citibank, New York's largest bank, reported today a 15.5 percent increase in firtquarter operating earnings to a record level, following two quarters of declines. The report was issued at an unusual annual meeting of stockholders here.

title: The Meaning Of Tragedy
description: WASHINGTON. April 18The tragedy of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro of Italy is a startling reminder of the fragility of all civilized nations. They are worrying these days about classic wars of invasion across national borders, and they debate endlessly over cruise missiles, Backfire bombers, and neutron artillery shells that can kill fleets of tanks: but in the last quarter of the century. the tyranny of desperate minorities may also he a major threat to world order.

title: $740,000 in State Funds to Assist In Restoring 22 Historic Buildings
description: TRENTON. April 18 (UPI)The Department of Environmental Protection has awarded $740.000 in matching grants to 22 state, municipal and private applicant,: for preservation of historic homes and buildings, it was announced today.

title: Illinois Firemen Locked Up Except When Fighting Fires
description: NORMAL, III., April 18 Yancy Wall, a blond 4-year-old boy, stood outside the Normal fire station this morning touching a finger to a glass panel beside a locked door. On the other side, Craig Wall, the boy's 28-year-old father, touched his forefinger to the same spot.

title: Soviet General Who Lost Citizenship Asks Asylum
description: Pyotr G. Grigorenko, a retired general and prominent dissident in the Soviet Union, formally requested political asylum in the United States yesterday.

description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation,. the Bankers Trust New York Corporation and Wells Fargo & Company told their stockholders yesterday that firstquarter earnings had increased.

title: Sheraton Narrows Ad Agency Field to 3
description: The Sheraton Corporation, the hotel chain that is looking for new ad agency, has just cut the field from 12 to threeCreamer Lois/FSR, Ted Bates & Company, and Schmalenberger & Nargassans in Boston, where Sheraton has its headquarters and where the office of Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn has been doing the advertising.

title: AM General Changes Its Plans For Transporting German Buses
description: HOUSTON, April 18 (AP)An official of a company importing West German buses for a transportation program partly underwritten by the Federal Government said the company probably would no longer use a Soviet shipping line to transport the buses to the United States.

title: W.H.A. Suspends 2 Players
description: HARTFORD, April 18 (UPI)The World Hockey Association fined three Birmingham Bulls players today from $100 to $500 each and suspended two of them for fighting during last Sunday night's game with the Winnipeg Jets. The W.H.A. fined Phil Roberto $500. Gilles BlIodeau $200 and Dave Hanson $100: Roberto and Bilodeau were given onegame suspension for Birmingham.

title: Sentence in Yablonski Case Cut
description: ERIE, Pa., April 18 (AP)Judge Edward Carney of Erie County Court has reduced the sentence of Albert Pass from three consecutive life terms to three concurrent life terms. The prisoner had been convicted of conspiring to murder Joseph A. Yablonski, an insurgent in the United Mine Workers, and his wife and daughter. The judge acted on a request by Richard Sprague, a special prosecutor.

title: Michael Tilson Thomas Accused of Having Drugs After Search at Kennedy
description: Michael Tilson Thomas, the 33-year-old conductor of the Buffalo Philharmonic Orchestra, was arrested at Kennedy International Airport late last month as he returned from London, and charged with carrying a small amount of cocaine, three marijuana cigarettes and three and a half amphetamine tablets.

title: 2 Judges Testify on Missing Tape In Murder Trial of Dr. Jascalevich
description: HACKENSACK. NJ, April 18Two Superior Ccurt judges were called as witnesses today in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich in a hearing determine whether statements the doctor gave to the Bergen County Proseautor's Office in 1956 should he admitted in evi dence.

title: Arbour's Shifts Bear Sweet Fruit
description: No one in the National Hockey League would deny that Coach Al Arbour of the Islanders must have ieen doing something right to transform a struggling expansion club into a top Stanley Cup contender in just five years.

title: Dutch Petition Asks Neutron Ban
description: THE HAGUE, April 18 (Reuters)A group campaigning against the neutron bomb presented a petition signed by more than one million people to the speaker of the lower chamber of the Dutch Parliament today. The Stop the Neutron Bomb group later said it planned to broaden its campaign to include all nuclear weapons. Nico Schouten, the group's secretary, said he hoped President Carter's decision earlier this month to postpone manufacture of the bomb would lead to abandonment of any plans to produce the weapon.

title: Daily News Sets Up A MidMay Target. Fora Guild Accord
description: The New York Daily News yesterday set midMay for the positive conclusion of negotiations with the Newspaper Guild of New York, which has 1,310 members on the newspaper.

title: Leadoff Clout in 9th Beats Orioles, 43
description: The Yankees played another game of agony and ecstasy yesterday. The ecstasy. as usual. was reserved for Reggie Jackson: he hit a leadoff homer in the ninth inning that gave the Yankees a 43 victory over the Baltimore Orioles. The agony, as usual, was for Don Gullett: he was placed on the 21day disabled list, his left shoulder still too sore to allow him to pitch.

title: GUERRILLAS IN TIMOR STILL FIGHT INDONESIA
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 15Twentyeight months after Indonesia's invasion of Portugal's former colony of Timor and 21 months after the region's integration as Indonesia's 27th province, Jakarta's military forces are still fighting an antiguerrilla war throughout the eastern half of the island. Western Timor has always been part of Indonesia.

title: The Transit Workers Fateful Vote
description: New York City's future is in the mail and will remain sealed until ballots sent in by members of the Transport Workers Union are counted next Tuesday. if the 33,000 members ratify the agreement their leaders accepted on March 31, the city can move to bargain with its other unions. If the membership votes for a strike, the city's transportation system will be thrown into chaos; so will the city's finances and dealings with other workers; will the union's treasury.

April 18A spot check of brokers and hankers here and on the Continent today uncovered a host of explanations for the spectacular gains in Wall Street earlier this week and a number of people, particularly in Britain. who thou2ht the turn had come at last. But caution was prevalent and there was little evidence that a mn,sive rush of in vestment money toward New York had begun.

title: A Roast by Any Other Name
description: When New Yorkers read a menu they know perfectly well that Mom never saw that homemade, farmapple pie and they may even know that the apples came not from any bushel basket with the crisp fragrance of fall, but from a can. Still, hope springs eternal in the human stomach. Even when fresh gifts from the bounty of the sea are clearly frozen and factoryprepared and bouquets of green vegetables are precooked and pre-packaged, most people do not lightly abandon their vision sunripened fruits and justcaught fish. New Yorkers dine on hyperbole and disappointment.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: You don't need to drink tea to have a tea cozy. As a matter of fact, if you end up with the one I'm going to tell you about, you may not be able to afford tea. The cozies come from the Soviet Union, are costumed in the court dress of 18th-century Russia, and are sufficiently attractive and interesting to be used as self-stand- Lug dolls. Everything is cotton, from the painted face to the quilted structure, and the height, should you be interested, is about 19 inches. There are several styles, cluding a tea drinker and a gossip, and Itlacy's Toy Department and Hammacher Schlemmer's second floor should have one or more to show you. title: Convoy to Economic Recovery
description: Prime Minister Callaghan of Britain appears to have won some support for his effort to compromise differences among the industrial democracies about how spur recovery from their worst recession since the Thirties. Without awaiting the economic summit next July. the major countries are each contemplating action in one or more of five fields: tax cuts and other stimulus, currency stabilization, energy conservation, trade liberalization and increased capital flow to the poor countries. This coordinated approach is long overdue.

title: TV : NBC Holocaust, Art Versus Mammon
description: VEN many of those who did not find television's Holocaust project objectionableas I did and still do after its conclusion last night on NBCTV, conceded that the commercial breaks and the commercials made them unPAW Dealing with this problem gets to the very heart of the electronic beast and a growing awareness of its inherent limitations. By now, most of us know unto tedium that commercial television is in the business of selling heads to advertisers. The more viewers delivered, the more that can be charged for commercials. For the overwhelming majority of broadcasting executives, the bottom line of the profit is paramount. Content is secondary, a means to the monetary end. Therefore, the medium's use or exploitation of serious material such as the Nazi holocaust must prompt profound reservations.

title: Film: Mama's Spaghetti:Five at the Forum
description: WE KNOW Martin Scorsese is in his parents' dining room because we can see his dinner plate, which he has evidently emptied, and because his hand occasionally reaches across the table to spear some salad. We also know he's on the premises because his parents, whose recollections of Scorsese family lore take up most of the 45-minute running time of "Italianamerican," at one point begin worrying about whether one of their famous son's teeth looks funny. But for the most part, Scorsese the Director prefers to keep Scorsese the Son safely off camera, and his parents prefer to behave as if they had just made the acquaintance of a very charming stranger.By deliberately attempting to limit his own influence, Mr. Scorsese backhandedly turns himself into the film's most important figure. His parents are a bit nervous, and they clearly aren't behaving the way they ordinarily might; to heighten the formality with which they present themselves. Mr. Scorsese invites them to tell stories they've told a hundred times before, but their carefully chosen words and expansive smiles speak volumes about the pride they take in their boy's success, and the momentousness they attach to his work. It's delightful to see how flattered they are by their Marty's making them a part of his professional life."Italianamerican" concentrates mostly on keeping up appearances, but there are occasional lapses and digressions, all of them welcome. Mr. Scorsese, sending his mother into the kitchen to make spaghetti sauce for the camera, uses a tone that would make a drill sergeant sound like the Easter Bunny by comparison. Later, the film's closing credits include Mrs. Scorsese's recipe.Of the five films on the Film Forum's "Scorsese's Italianamerican & Other Family Portraits," Mr. Scorsese's is the only one made in a spirit of affection."Album," an animated short by Linda Heller, concentrates on parental repressiveness, but Miss Heller's animation is so sweetly whimsical that the sting is minimal.Equally successful, and equally fish-eyed, is Lenny Lipton's "Happy Birthday Lenny." Footage of an apartment, presumably the director's, is interspersed with shots of lush tropical foliage and birds flying free. All the while, a woman sobs nonstop about her son's not being tidy enough, and about the various sacrifices she has made. The credits don't specify whose voice we're hearing, but if she isn't Mama Lipton, she must be the greatest actress in the world.Jan Oxenberg's "Home Movie" shows a group of lesbians merrily playing football, and Miss Oxenberg uses childhood films of herself, somewhat unpleasantly, to reinforce ideas about herself that came later in life, rather than to explore the attitudes that were evident years ago."A Visit to Indiana," by Curt McDowell, uses the strangely self-destructive technique of combining rough, almost unwatchable footage of an Indiana family with a sardonic voice-over conversation. The dialogue is funny, but it distracts attention from footage that is already hard to follow, and the prevailing spirit is so sarcastic it turns sour.

title: Film: Kirk Douglas in 'The Chosen':The Devil in Person
description: KIRK DOUGLAS, who has a weird son, a fellow with telekinetic powers, in "The Fury," has a son who is even more weird in "The Chosen," a nasty Italo-English coproduction about diabolism.In "The Chosen," the young man, who is played by Simon Ward is actually the devil who has apparently come to earth to build faulty atomic power plants. That, at least, is all I can make of the plot, which was put together by three people and then directed by Alberto De Martino, who seems to have studied "The Omen" the way other directors might study "Potemkin" and "Freaks.""The Chosen" sincerely flatters "The Omen" with such special effects as as-sorted cuttings and stabbings, the sight of a man as the top of his head is chopped off and of another who seems to be sliced in two. The Book of Revelation, which was called "Revelations" in "The Omen" and is in the public domain, is cited as the source material.The film opened yesterday at a number of theaters in the neighborhoods and on Broadway at the Forum, where the program was supplemented by a short called "The DiamondA Miracle of Nature," distributed by the Diamond Information Center, and by trailers for "Jennifer," "Here Come the Tigers," "The Incredible Melting Man" and "Youngblood."At one point I thought my foot had gone to sleep but it was only that my shoe was temporarily stuck to the floor by gum discarded by an earlier patron.

description: The Rockwell International Crrporation, the nation's leading maker of space vehicles, reported yesterday a profit increase of 20.2 percent to $43.5 million, or $1.23 a share. in the second fiscal quarter ended March 31.

description: Fausto Esteves, an assistant professor of romance languages at Lehman College, died Sunday of cancer at the Memorial SloanKettering Cancer Center. He was 60 years old and lived in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: U.S. to Start Series of Gold Sales Next Month to Shore Up Dollar
description: WASHINGTON, April 19(UPI)The United States will begin monthly auclions of gold in late May in an effort to cut the American trade deficit and shore up the lagging dollar on foreign exchange markets the Treasury Department said tonight.

title: Carter's Testimony, on Videotape, Is Given to Georgia Gambling Trial
description: MACON, Ga., April 19Testimony by President Carter was presented by videotape today in Federal District Court at the gambling conspiracy trial of a state senator and a former county sheriff.

description: WASHINGTONDeep in the part of the Pentagon reserved for the Joint Chiefs of Staff is a security door emblazoned with a military crest little known outside the building. Its heraldry includes two chess boards and a computer component.

title: Notes on People
description: ILL E. Brown of Baltimore got her flight wings yesterday from Texas International Airlines, which made her the first black woman who is known to have qualified as a pilot for a major United States airline. Miss Brown, who is 27 old, began fliOng as a teenager and later became a pilot for a local airline in North Carolina before becoming a first officer on Texas International planec. Yesterday she was promoted to the rank of copilot.

title: InterestRate Futures Decline Sharply as the Reserve Apparently Signals Tighter Credit
description: CHICAGO, April 19An action by the Federal Reserve Board, the nation's central bank, that could portend a policy shift toward tighter credit triggered sharp selloff in interestrate futures today.

description: WASHINGTON, April 19 (AP)Customs agents are being armed with experimental devices such as neutron scanners and vapor detectors to find drug smugglers along United States borders.

description: The Health Department has cited 12 more food businesses for failing a health code inspection and warned that they faced closing if violations persisted on second and final inspection. Following are the establishments:

description: WASHINGTON, April 19McGeorge Bundy, the White House national security adviser under Presidents Kennedy and Johnson, told a Senate committee today that new restrictions imposed on intelligence activities could hamper the Government in its efforts to attract recruits to the Central Intelligence Agency.

title: Design Notebook
description: THE GOODWIN Galleries of the Museum of Modern Art, the secondfloor space in which the museum's celebrated design collection is shown, are hushed and quiet. There would be nothing surprisinn in that. but for the fact that the Goodwin Galleries have been given over until June 18 to an exhibition of stereo equipment. We are not used to seeing stereo equipment as an object to look at instead of as an object to hear, but then again, this is not your average Sony.

description: TOKYO April 19The date for South Korea's elections this spring has not vet been determined. But the results have.

title: Joseph Patten, 73, Retired in 73 As Partner of Bear, Stearns & Co.
description: Joseph F. Patten, retired general partner of Bear, Stearns & Company, died Monday at his home on Johns Island, Vero Beach, Fla. He was 73 years old.

title: TEAMSTER FUND HEAD REPORTED FORCED OUT
description: WASHINGTON, April 19Daniel Shannon, who tried to clean up the tarnished image of the teamsters largest pension fund, today was forced to resign as the fund's executive director, sources close to the Chicagobased fund said.

title: Taking It Easy At High Point.
description: Taking It Easy At High Point.

title: Israel's Next President
description: TEL AVIV, April 19A popular and folksy Labor Party politician who does not want to be kept on a pedestal was elected by the Israeli Parliament today to he the country's fifth President. The new chief of state, Yitzhak Navon will he the first Israelihorn leader and the first from Israel's Sephardic majority to hold the largely ceremonial post.

title: Blazers and Knicks on Losing Trail
description: The Knicks, beaten by the Philadelphia 76ers by a total of 59 points in two games, are not the only playoff team with troubles. The Portland Trail Blazers, who two months ago were on their way to becoming the first National Basketball Association team in nine seasons to win successive championships, are having problems.

title: BYRON STRONGMAN MILLER, A FLORIDA REALTY MAN, 65
description: Byron Strongman Miller, who had been active in realestate development in the South Florida area and also served in various executive positions with the Episcopal Church in the United States, died in Manhattan last Sunday. Mr. Miller, who lived in Boca Raton, Fla., was 65 years old.

title: AIRLANDING PLAN OF AMERICANS WINS OVER BRITISH IDEA
description: MONTREAL, April 19The United States won a significant aeronautical victory over Britain today when an inter! national meeting here endorsed the Americanfostered concept for systems to guide planes when landing in bad weather.

title: Home Beat
description: Definitely, the scent is in the air. Not spring, you understand, but the pungent fragrance of la dolce vita. From Milan, Rome, Turin, the works of Italian designers have been pouring in. Ecco, bellissimo! The odor is heady, voluptuous  shall we say even, at times, outrageous?

title: CBS Postpones Episode On Youth Sex in Series
description: LOS ANGELES, April 19The scheduled episode of Another Daya twoweekold situation comedy on CBSTV will not be seen Saturday because of a sponsor's rejection of its theme of premarital intercourse.

title: KOCH BACKS WESTWAY; CAREY PLEDGESTO SAVE 50C FARE AND RAISE AID
description: ALBANY, April 19Mayor Koch today formally dropped his opposition to the Westway, the $1.16 billion highway he had labeled a disaster during his mayoral campaign last year. He did so in return for a pledge by Governor Carey to maintain the 50cent transit fare through 1981 and to make $800 million available for masstransit improvements in the metropolitan area.

Muscular Dystrophy Association record with profound sorrow the death of an outstanding scientist who played a key role in the fight against muscle disease. Dr. Sandow was a founding member and. for many years, head of the Department of Physiology at the MDA. sponsored Institute for Muscle Disease, and WAS a distinguished grantee of the Association for the past two decades.

description: TORONTO, April 19Rich Gossage, who has had difficulty pitching to home plate this season, solved that problem today but had trouble throwing to the first and second bases.

title: Ruling Awaited on Letting Company Stop Writing Jersey Car Policies
description: TRENTON, April 19 (AP)Judge Morton Greenberg of Superior Court says he will rule by Friday on whether Nationwide Insurance should be allowed to defy the State Insurance Commissioner, James J. Sheeran, and stop writing auto policies ; in the state.

title: The Changing Face of TV News Programs
description: Roone Arledge, president of ABC News and Sports, said yesterday that he was determined to make his evening newscasts radically different from those of NBC and CBS. His efforts follow by about eight months

title: Watergate Words Without the Music
description: The Supreme Court has done the seemingly impossible by impeding public access to the famous Nixon tape recordings that were used as evidence to convict the Watergate coverup conspirators. Our British and early American judicial heritage holds that trial documents belong to the people and should be available for the public to inspect and copy. In 1974, Congress passed law to expedite public access to Nixon Administration records which the former President was claiming the right to appropriate and even to destroy. These two elements, buttressed by the constitutional values of free press and a public trial, should have guided the Court to a ruling in favor of access. Instead, a 7-to-2 majority decreed that the tapes are not yet in the public domain.

title: HOUSE TOUGHENS BILL ON LOBBY DISCLOSURE
description: WASHINGTON, April 19The House today strengthened a bill that would force lobbyists to disclose publicly many of their activities, but then adjourned without taking a final vote. The bill is considered likely to pass tomorrow, but a tough amendment adopted today will certainly turn some votes against the measure.

Drinks. Music. Conversation. As if in trance, I unfold a paper napkin, methodically empty the table ashtrays into it, gather it into a snug package and look about for a wastebasket.

title: Salerno, 67, Given 6 Months in Prison In Gambling Case
description: Anthony Salerno, a 67-year-old Rambler described by law enforcement authorities as a major figure in organized crime, received his first prison sentence yesterday when a Federal judge sentenced him to six months in prison and fined him $25.000 on eambline and tax charges.

title: Sri Lanka Faces Tamil Dissension
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, April 19 (AP)The police will set up an antiterrorist unit to deal with militant Tamils who want a separate state in Sri Lanka, the Government announced. They have al..; ready murdered several policemen and made attempts on many others, a police spokesman said, This can't go on forever. The Tamils, from India, make up 22 percent of the population; the Sinhalese, 70 percent..

description: An expense account suimiateet Paul Revere for the first of his famous rides at the start of the Revolutionary War will go on the block Wednesday in the first auction of a multimilliondollar autograph collection of the late Philin David Sang of Chicago.

description: LAGOS, NigeriaOfficially, all political activity in this country has been banned for the last 12 years by a decree of the military Government. But in real life politics here is as strident, incessant and unavoidable as the tooting horns of the cab drivers.

description: WASHINGTON, April 19A spokesman. for the Department of Energy, which is responsible for nuclear weapons development, said today that the United States had tested its neutron bomb in Nevada. The spokesman said details about the tests were secret.

title: New Face: Morgan Freeman
description: MORGAN FREEMAN didn't look at alllike an actor who had justreceived some of the most enthusiastic notices of the season. For that matter, he didn't look at all like the character he plays in Richard Wesley's The Mighty Gents, which opened last Sunday at the Ambassador. Mr. Freeman's performance as Zeke,.the filthy, winesodden but wily derelict who comes into a final, awful collision with the aging members of a Newark street gang, was hailed as spectacular by The Times's Richard Eder. There were other raves for Mr. Freeman, but the play itself did not fare nearly as well and its future is uncertain.

title: A Road in Westchester Becomes a Bike Path

title: First Boston Names Buchanan, 43, as New President

Buchanan, 43 years old. has been named president of First Boston Inc. and of its operating subsidiary, the First Boston Corporation, one of the nation's largest investment banking firms. He succeeds Paul L. Mller, 58, who will continue with First Boston on a parttime basis in a senior advisory capacity.

title: Signs of a White House Move Against Big Trade Imbalance
description: WASHINGTON  Almost completely overlooked in the search for meaningful anti:inflation and dollarsupport initiatives. in President Carter's heralded newcourse address 10 days ago were two.scntences that may ultimately lead to more signifi:ant developments than anything else proposed in the message to the nation. The President disclosed in them that he had directed a cabinetlevel task force to consider possible. steps to increase United States exports, and report back to him within 60 days.

title: U.S. and Micronesia Trust Area Agree on Basis for Independence
description: WASHINGTON, April 20After nearly a decade of negotiations, the United States has reached a tentative agreement with Micronesian officials to end Americad control over the last remaining trust territory in the world.

title: Notes on People
description: Joseph A. Califano Jr., the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, has named John M. Pinney, an executive of the National Council on Alcoholism. to head the department's new Office on Smoking and Health. Mr. Califano said that Mr. Pinney, having worked to educate the citizens of this country to the dangers of alcohol, understands fully the equally urgent need for eduacting people, particularly teenagers and those who have not yet begun to smoke, to the dangers and problems associated with tobacco. The 34-yearold Mr. Pinney, a former Navy officer, will oversee financial aid for research on smoking and will be active in the $30 million antismoking campaign that Mr. Califano started on Jan. 11. A department spokesman said that Mr. Pinney quit smoking early this year before he knew that Mr. Califano, an exsmoker, was considering him for the post

title: Kidnappers Issue Photo of Moro Purportedly Showing He Is Alive
description: ROME. April 20The Red Brigades urban guerrilla group issued a photograph today purportedly showing that former Prime Minister Aldo Moro was alive and apparently in good health yesterday, at the very time that frogmen searched a remote mountain lake for his body.

title: SOVIET FORCES DOWN SOUTH KOREAN PLANE
description: WASHINGTON, April 20A South Korean airliner was forced down in the Soviet Union near the Arctic Circle by fighter planes today, officials of Canada and the United States reported.

title: Screen: Recapturing Day of the Beatles:Out of Sight
description: THE GIMMICK behind "I Wanna Hold Your Hand" is the fact that you never actually see the Beatles???; the genius of the film is the fact that you never miss them. Their likenesses turn up everywhere, plastered on record jackets and tacked on doors and walls, and their music is continually in the air.At the end of the movie, which revolves around the group's first appearance on "The Ed Sullivan Show," the sneakiness with which the neophyte director Robert Zemeckis skirts the issue is positively dazzling. The Beatles are both there and not there, and the paradox hardly even matters. This movie is about the fans and their hysteria, and so it's the shouts that count.The premise of the screenplay, by Mr. Zemeckis and Bob Gale, might have lent itself to a wittier and less broad treatment, but "I Wanna Hold Your Hand" plays it safe, quite successfully. If there's a tray full of food within camera range, rest assured that somebody will knock it over. If a stuck-in-the-elevator-on-the-eve-of-an-important-event routine presents itself, rest assured that its staging will be tried and true.However, Mr. Zemeckis's taste in routines of this sort is very sound, and midway through the movie he begins juggling them with such speed and dexterity that perhaps he belongs on the Sullivan program, along with such memorable actswhose names are dropped here by Will Jordan, doing his Sullivan imitationas "Topo Gigio, the Little Italian Mouse."In addition to Mr. Zemeckis's impressive new hand with old tricks, the film's assets include the fortuitous ambience of Beatlemania. In an atmosphere rife with weeping and screaming, a climate in which one fan can sweetly announce that she hopes Cynthia Lennon will die in a plane crash so that she can marry John, anything goes. Some routines work a lot better than others, but the whole film sparkles with a boisterous lunacy that's perfectly in keeping with the frenzy of the fans.Of course, such infectious high spirits don't come without calculation: This is a film that's quite meticulous about its innocence. Nobody gets hurt??? and the jokes stay clean. The principals are typecast straight out of anyone's high-school year-book: Best Looking (Nancy Allen), Best Personality (Wendie Jo Sperber), Most Earnest (Susan Kendall Newman), Class Weirdo (Eddie Deezen), Class Creep (Marc McClure), Town Tough Guy (Bobby Di Cicco) and Most Likely to Succeed No Matter Whose Arm She Has to Break to Do it (Theresa Saldana).The bad guys are stock characters, too: grownups, With a wicked??? wicked smile, one hotel chambermaid shakes a dark dustmop out a hotel window and snickers while the fanswho know a monton haircut when they see onego wild. When the adorably unhinged Miss Sperber who looks like a slackjawed baby elephant in stretch pants bowls over a little old lady, it's an old lady who has had the audacity to badmouth the Beatles. When one boy's father refuses to give the kid his Sullivan tickets unless his son gets rid of his Beatle haircut. Mr. Zemeckis makes the barbershop look like Death Row.When the adults in the film aren't being nasty, they're stupid, hilariously so. "How do I know which one's Ringo?" asks one technician in the control room for the Sullivan program. "He's the one who plays guitar another replies. "What guitar? There's three guitars," is the reply, while a title reading "JohnSorry Girls. He's Married" flashes on one monitor screen.And then there is Miss Allen's fianc, a stiff in the plastic furniture-cover business, who tells her proudly that "in a couple of hours you're gonna be Mrs. Eddie Lupus." They plan to elope, but fate has some other, wonderfully funny adventures in store for Miss Allen, who winds up doing even lewder things to one of the Beatles' bass guitars than she did to John Travolta in "Carrie."Miss Allen, who manages to seem years younger here than she did in "Carrie'" does some of her best acting with her legs, squirming and flopping about with girlish glee as she finds herself delivered, quite by accident, into the Beatles' actual hotel suite. Nobody else is around, and Miss Allen spends a few delightful moments savoring every last cigarette but???. Needless to say, when the Beatles arrive she never sees them. She hides under a bed, catches one glimpse of their boots and passes out in ecstasy."I Wanna Hold Your Hand," which is at the Rivoli and other theaters, is an A-plus B-movie, but it's a B-movie just the same. The fine points aren't fine, the clothes and makeup are anachronistic at times, the plot falters crazily in places, and a final car chase through the streets of New York very clearly takes place in California. The teen-agers appear to range in age from 16 to 30??? and one Beatle voice has an oddly American accent.Miss Newman, daughter of Paul Newman, plays a completely implausible Beatle-hater, a lover of folk music who would never have been caught wearing makeup in 1964, even though she has lipstick on here. When she complains about the Beatles in a record store, the proprietor sneers something unpleasant about "Jane" Baez??? but that's nonsense: "Jane" sold plenty of records in her day, too."I Wanna Hold Your Hand," which is rated PG (Parental Guidance Suggested), include one sequence involving a prostitute. However, the woman is merely seen rubbing mustard on her client's cranium.

title: The Right Kind of Veterans Preference
description: It did not take long for veterans groups and Federal employee organizations to open fire on President Carter's Civil Service reform proposals. When the President sent his plan to Congress recently, he said he wanted a Government that would respond to the needs of the American people and not be preoccupied with needs of its own. The employee interest groups are now busy telling congress that their needs come first. That is especially true of veterans who want to maintain preference they enjoy for Federal jobs and promotions. Without strong public support, Civil Service reform will again be blocked.

In a major legislative breakthrough, the state will now compensate cities for lost revenues on taxexempt properties owned by private universities and hospitals.

During the middle and late 1950's he was widely regarded as one of the most brilliant pianists in jazz. Nat Hentoff wrote that he probably has more command of the piano technically than any of his jazz contemporaries. In the liner notes to the first Newborn album, George Wein, who plays piano in addition to producing the Newport Jazz Festival and is not given to superlatives when discussing other keyboard artists, compared Mr. Newborn very favorably to the late Art Tatum.

title: Screen: Silver-Market Swindle:Swiss Laundry
description: IVAN PASSER'S "Silver Bears" is a chilly, cheerless comedy about the machinations of a Las Vegas syndicate chief and his associates who buy their own Swiss bank to launder illegal profits and, in the process, become enmeshed in a swindle involving the world's silver market, some secret silver mines in Iran and a greedy California bank.Peter Stone's screenplay is based on a novel by Paul Erdman, the author of the current novel "The Crash of '79" and himself no stranger to the arcane methods of Swiss-based wheeling-and-dealing. I suspect that Mr. Passer means the film to be a comedy about Western decadence, though "Silver Bears," in failing in the flat-footed way it does, becomes, instead, an example of it.It looks very much like the sort of picture made primarily to fulfill the obligations of an international movie deal designed to be somebody's tax write-off, a project that profits no one except the people who appear to lose money on it. This, I emphasize, is speculation based on the sloppiness of the film as art and on the extravagances of the production as a whole.The cast is headed by some very good actors, lots of boringly picturesque Swiss scenery and a number of exotic locales, including marketplaces in Morocco, which substitutes for Iran and where, apparently, poverty is pretty.Among the people who appear in the film are Michael Caine and Martin Balsam, who aren't diminished by the experience, and Cybill Shepherd and Stephane Audran (two of the screen's most glorious faces), and Louis Jourdan, David Warner and Tom Smothers. All of the roles are ridiculous, though poor pacing, foolish lines, unnecessary connective scenes and badly matched shots within scenes also work against them. I hope everyone was well paid.The film opens today at the RKO 86th Street Theater and other theaters."Silver Bears" which has been rated PG ["Parental Guidance Suggested"), includes some fleeting shots of nude old men, a couple of even more fleeting shots of a not-quite-nude young woman and some mildly vulgar dialogue.

With care, and luck, the effort should stimulate the city's economy, enhance its attractiveness and restore some of its confidence. That is no small opportunity for a bankrupt town.

title: Closing the Black Bag
description: Which would the late J. Edgar Hoover have found more astonishing, the sight of his successor standing before a Federal judge to answer criminal charges for conduct long familiar in the F.B.I.? Or the sight of several hundred F.B.I. agents demonstrating on the streets Washington? Both events occurred yesterday and both turned on the same phenomenon, the black bag jobagents slang for an investigation of questionable legality because it is conducted without a warrant. But far more important was another event involving blackbag jobs that occurred just a few hours later and a few blocks away. The United States Senate voted 95 to 1 for foreign intelligence surveillance bill that would eliminate warrantless electronic surveillance altogether.

title: Scientists. Suggest 10 Billion Stars In Milky Way May Have Planets

In an open letter handed to Western reporters. she asked Mr. Schmidt to bring up her case next month during a visit by Leonid I. Brezhnev, the Soviet leader.

First, the Brigades ideological descent from the Communist Party: The language in which their messages are couched indicates as much for it is identical to that of the little catechisms the party used to distribute among its militants 20 years ago. It is equally certain that today the Red Brigades no longer have any connection whatever with the Communist Party, although a few party leadeis have never been willing to speak out in condemnation of them.

description: Teresa Compos, a Juilliardtrained pianist who performed Thursday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, has obviously worked conscientiously to discipline her fingers. They are fast and agile, and when she negotiates a thicket of rapid notes the effect can he brilliant.

Spanish Red Party Drops `Leninist From Charter; Chief's Position Bolstered
description: MADRID. April 21 (AP)Spanish Communists voted today to make what appeared to be a decisive break with Sovietstyle Communism, dropping the word Leninist from their party statutes and declaring themselves simply Marxist, democratic and revolutionary.

title: Prescribing a Drugstore Compromise
description: The disturbing pharmacists boycott against Medicaid recipients in New York City has apparently been ended, and efforts are in progress to resolve the underlying issues. The boycott began early this month when hundreds of pharmacists refused to fill Medicaid prescrip- Lions because of a dispute with the state over reimbursement rates and paperwork. Some refused to comply even with a temporary court order to serve the poor. The right of individual drugstores to withdraw from Medicaid programs was never in question. But the legality of a mass defectionwhich the state calls organized and the pharmacists call spontaneousremain to be determined by the courts. In any case, it now appears possible to settle the matter in a way that will not further punish those whom Medicaid is intended to help.

title: A Discouraging Word Now Heard in Wyoming
description: CHEYENNE, Wyo.'It ain't the money that's going to ruin this state, said Ralph Hutsell, a grocery store manager in Shirley Basin. It ain't the coal companies. It ain't the uranium. It's the outsiders.

title: Futures Prices Off In Gold and Silver; Grain Also Drops
description: CHICAGO, April 21 (AP)Gold and silver futures declined to their lowest levels in months, as speculators responded to a brighter economic outlook this week by abandoning the traditional inflationhedge metals.

description: HARTFORD, April 21Dr. Edythe J. Gaines, the Superintendent cf Schools here, was dismissed by the Hartford Sthool, Board last night in a 5-to-4 vote against renewing her contract. .

title: TV Monitors to Fight Subway Station Crime
description: Closedcircuit television cameras will soon be installed in some of New York City's subway stations to discourage crime, Transit Authority officials said Yesterday.

title: A Test for the Cubans in Africa
description: A major test of Cuban intentions in Africa is now taking shape. Are the Cubans merely tools of an expansionist Soviet policy? Or is Fidel Castro acting on his own, in pursuit of his old dream of third world revolution? Or, as the Cubans themselves have claimed, is their role both independent and modest, consisting es- sentially of helping allied governments (Angola, Ethiopia) to repel foreign invaders? The way that Havana responds to the impending confrontation between the Ethiopian Government and the secessionist forces in Eritrea should do much to answer those questions.

title: Ex New York City Aide Is Guilty of Tax Elasion In Not Reporting Interest
description: Parry Stern, a former New York City assistant realestate commissioner. was ccnvicted yesterday of evading income taxes oS 323.120 on more than $56.000 he received as interest over a fouryear orriorl starting in 1971.

description: A spokesman for Mayor Koch said yesterday that the Mayor would make known next week his decision on where the proposed New York City Convention Center should be built.

title: INQUIRYWILLDELAY OPENING OF CASINO

title: Carter's Panama Visit Uncertain
description: WASHINGTON, April 21 (AP)The S;ate Department expressed surprise today at an assertion by the Panamanian leader, Brigadier General Omar Torrijos Herrera. that President Carter would visit Panama on May 12, but American officials did not rule out such a visit. title: A Theory of Devolution
description: Chimpanzees sometimes pick on each other, even humans do. So reports Jane Goodall, a naturalist who has spent the last 18 years studying chimp behavior at the Gombe National Park in Tanzania. In recent years, the community of 40 chimps whose harmonious existence Miss Goodall has celebrated began to break up, and some members of the original group took to terrorizing members of the splinter group. I had once thought, says Miss Goodall, that chimpanzees resembled humans only in their gentler traits, like holding hands, embracing and kissing. The horrifying thing is they bear a strong similarity to humans in other ways. We saw one community of chimps systematically attack and kill another.

title: Heart Transplant Patient Dies

Barnard and his team. The cause of the death was not immediately disclosed.

description: MOSCOW, April 21Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance and Foreign Minister Andrei A. Gromyko concluded two days of intensive negotiations tonight with both sides suggesting that progress had been made toward a new agreement limiting strategic arms.

description: WASHINGTON, April 21The Postal Rate Commission rejected a Carter Administration proposal today and tentatively voted, 3 to 1, to raise postage on firstclass letters to 15 cents from 13 cents, according to an official of the commission.

Jascalevich said today that the court should admit into evidence a 209page statement the surgeon gave in 1966 because it would show that he had falsely tried to explain away the smoking gun that was found in his locker.

By winning their first contest in the four-of-seven-game National Hockey League quarterfinal playoffs, the Leafs cut the Islanders margin to 2 games to 1.

title: Rendall Is Rodolfo In City Opera Debut
description: David Rendall, an English tenor, made his New York City Opera debut on Thursday night as Rodolfo in Puccini's 'La Boheme. Because he has done considerable singing in England and other parts of Europe and is featured in the part of Fer- rando on a recent recording of Mozart's 'Cosi fan tutte, the expectation was that Mr. Rendall might prove to be an especially strong addition to City Opera's roster of tenors.

title: Union of Civil Service Employees To Affiliate With a Longtime Rival
description: The Civil Service Employees Association, the largest public employee union in New York State, announced yesterday that it had affiliated with a longtime rival, an A.F.L.C.I.O. organization that has a national membership of nearly a million.

description: HOUSTON, April 21 (AP)Assistant Police Chief Carroll M. Lynn, charged with obstruction of justice after being arrested by the Federal authorities on April 10, was dismissed yesterday. Police Chief Harry Caldwell said that he had offered Chief Lynn an opportunity to resign but Chief Lynn opted not to take it.

Childress speed of 85.622 miles an hour was 16th fastest overall. Lennie Pond had won the pole position Friday on 58.730 m.p.h.

title: INTERVIEW

His name is Richard Hugo and about a year ago he.was appointed editor of the Yale Series of Younger Poets, a distinguished post formerly held by W. H. Auden and Stanley Kunitz.

title: GALLERY VIEW
description: One of the best ways to get a black eye in New York City is to go around calling people provincial. Most New Yorkers take off from Dr. Samuel Johnson's definition of that word ('rude, unpolished') and go on to add nuances of ignorance. obtuseness and out-of-touch- ness.

title: AROUND THE Garden
description: Japanese beetles are gaining on gardeners. The pesticides that kept them under control can no longer be used and the new ones are not as effective. In addition, recent summers have been rainy keeping the ground moist so there has been less desiccation of beetle eggs. In short, there may be population explosions in particular areas of the Northeast this summer.

title: SEA-AND-LAND MISSILE SOUGHT BY PENTAGON
description: WASHINGTON, April 23The Pentagon, apparntly at the urging of the White House, is proposing the development of a new strategic missile that would be deployed aboard submarines as well as from landbased mobile launchers.

title: Waiting It Out in Rhodesia
description: Secretary of State Vance and British Foreign Secretary David Owen did the only thing they could when they met this past week with the parties to the Rhodesian conflict: They listened, and made no promises. That was sensible, because the United States and. Britain. lack leverage to force a compromise between Prime Minister Smith and his newfound black partners the one hand and their black Patriotic Front challengers on the other. Yet Washington and London may well have the logic of events going for them. Once the two Rhodesian sides step close enough to the precipice, they may decide that talking is better than fighting.

title: ART
description: PRINCETON SOME of the scenes depicted on the Maya ceramic vases now on view at the Princeton University Art Museum are horrifying. They reveal a bloodthirsty, violent culture that made a high art out of the macabre and the dreadful.

title: CRIME
description: Stuart M. Kaminsky is a movie buff, and like all good cardcarrying members of the fraternity he dotes on the great prewar period in Hollywood, when they really made films and had stars. Last year he put his expertise to use in a privateeye story about Hollywood in the late 1930's, Bullet for a Star, which brought in some of the Hollywood greats, notably Errol Flynn and Humphrey Bogart. It was fun, all the more in that the starstruck Kaminsky never lost track of the amenities of the classic privateeye novel.

description: Old antagonisms and new injuries surfaced in Yankee Stadium yesterday when Manager Billy Martin chewed out his worldchampion Yankees and. then watched them go 12 innings to defeat the Milwaukee Brewers, 43.

description: To the Editor:

title: IS THE S.E.C.SELLING WALL STREET SHORT?
description: In October 1977, a seat on the New York Stock Exchange sold at a 34year low of $35,000. To investors who do not own a seat on the exchange but who have been battered by the volatile and unpredictable markets of the 70's, it may be some consolation to know that in 1969 the same seat on the exchange sold for a whopping $515,000. How can a seat on the New York Stock Exchangean institution nearly as old as our country, an institution that stands as a cultural artifact of capitalist society as, surely as the Pyramids stand for the pharaohssell for only 7 cents on its f omer dollar? That's an easy question. Nobody wants a seat on the New York Stock Exchange anymore. Because, in the opinion of many, its very existence may be in jeopardy. (If it's any consolation, a seat on the Pacific recently sold for 25 cents for the same reasonunits future.)

title: HUNGARIAN ECONOMY TO UNDERGO CHANGES

Foundation, Mr. Bowman, accused of misappropriating more than $100,000 from the fund in 197576, is to he sentenced July 7. Court officials said that nine other counts of grand theft would be dismissed at that time.

title: A Cardiac Patient's Own Account
description: Having a heart attack is a drag. I can attest to it, having survived two in two years, and now having a pacemaker to prompt my heart. Yet, at the age of 49, I see no merit in sitting around worrying and waiting for my heart to strike me down again. It makes a lot more sense, within the limits imposed by the dam age already done, to lead as normal and active a life as possible. And that includes vacationsespecially, sincecold weather puts an additional strain on the heart, winter vacations in sunny climes.

title: Hollywood Rediscovers the American Woman
description: After long neglect, Hollywood is fascinated with womentheir careers, their individual identities, their relationships with each other, their passions and, of course (but no longer exclusively), their relationships with men. After nearly decade of buddy films in which men have little or no need of females and of action pictures in which women characteristically do little more than wince when the men begin to shed blood, movies are again being produced with women as the pivotal characters. And they are doing well at the box office. While not all of the women who take center stage in these films are admirable and intelligent, a good many of them are, and thus for the first time since the late 1940's, screen heroines are the equals of those strong characters played by Rosalind Russell, Bette Davis, Joan Crawford and Katharine Hepburn.

They must be able to display imagination, and have the technical knowledge and ability to cope with the problems that are apt to arise in any situation. Since much of their shooting is indoors, and all of it is in color, many otherwise minor problems suddenly blossom into major ones.
