title: At Last, Action On GasPrices
description: A moment many thought might never come arrived last week. A year and day after President Carter submitted his energy program as the moral equivalent of war, leaders of the Congressional conference committee on energy trooped out of a marathon session of negotiations to announce that finally they had agreed to a plan for the eventual deregulation of natural gas prices. This time, they said, knowing there would be skeptics, they mean it. It was a significant breakthrough, but true to the spirit of a conference that began last October, it also underscored how much more work remains. First, the full committee must endorse the tentative settlement. Then it must take up new energy taxes, matters that are not as simple as they seemed before the deadlock over gas developed last December. Then the entire energy package, including elements settled months ago, must be voted on again by the full House and Senate, which had passed quite different bills. And then the President must say okay,. although his agreement to the parts already settled is a foregone conclusion.

title: Barnes Wins Spanish Golf By 2 on FinalRound 64
description: BARCELONA, Spain April 22 (Reuters)Brian Barnes shot a finalround 64 today to win the Spanish open golf championship by two strokes over Howard Clark, his British Ryder Cup teammate. Barnes started the round five strokes behind the overnight leader, Mark James of Britain, but holed eight birdies today to finish at 12-under-par 276. The results worth $12,500 to Barnes, was the reverse of last week's Portuguese Open. Clark, who shot a 70 today, won that tournament by a stroke over Barnes. James posted a 74 today and finished tied for fifth place with Severiano Bailesteros of Spain and Michael King of Britain.

title: Zarate Keeps W.B.C. Title With His 51st Knockout

Mr. Christie was in New York recently for a fundraising party given by Stewart Mott, and came away with barely enoughif all pledges materialize to guarantee a $60,000, lastminute saturation campaign of radio spots.

For the hero, I am convinced, is an extinct species relegated to the memory of my youthful idealism.

title: SPORTS
description: The Mets and the Yankees have returned; the N.B.A. and N.H.L. playoffs are under way; the Cosmos, sans Pele, are attempting to prove that English football can succeed in the United States; the Masters was just completed, and shortly it will be Kentucky Derby time. It's spring  the sports world's most active season has commenced. Reflecting this abundance of activity is a host of books geared for sports fans of various persuasions., There are no Roger Angelis, Muhammad Alis, George Plimptons or Bill Bradleys among the authors, but several of this season's books should make worthwhile additions to any sports library.

description: Golda Meir came to Milwaukee from the faroff Ukraine at the age of eight, speaking Yiddish. In two years she had organized an American Young Sisters Society to provide textbooks for needy children in her school. Her picture is in newspaper of the time (1908), with caption that stated President Goldie Mabovitz is in top row, fourth from the right. The paper went on to speak of a score of little children who gave their play time and scant pennies to charity ... on their own initiative. This was the first of Golda's many fundraising activities.

title: FRANK C. MOORE, 82, EXNEW YORK AIDE
description: Frank C. Moore, a fiscal expert whose 49 years of public service included terms as New York Lieutenant Governor, State Comptroller and chairman of the State University board, died yesterday of cancer. He was 82 years old and died at his home in Crystal River, Fla.

title: Adapting The Workplace To Computers
description: Once, if C. Carter Swoope, a junior account officer at Chemical Bank, had a question from one of the bank's clients, he might have had to ask a clerk to look it up for him. Sometimes, if going into the vault was required, it could have taken hours to get an answer. Now, he puts the caller on hold and finds it himself.

title: Ideas &Trends
description: It took a while, but Kansas is finally burying Carrie Nation's hatchet. Mrs. Nation enforced her prohibitionist views by chopping through saloon doors, and many Kansans shared her disapproval of drink and drinkers. Kansas was the first state to amend its constitution to outlaw liquor sales, in 1880 a ban that was not lifted until 1948.

title: ART VIEW; Tapies's Gifted Yet Easy. Victories; HILTON KRAMER; ART VIEW Antoni Tapies
description: It is now 25 years since the Spanish painter Antoni Tapies who was then 30 years old and all but unknown herehad his first New York solo exhibition at the Martha Jackson Gallery. To mark both this anniversary and the publication of a new book on the artist ('Tapies, by Sir Roland Penrose; Rizzoli, $25), the gallery has mounted an exhibition of some 50 recent works together with a small selection of earlier pictures. (It is on view at 521 West 57th Street through May 6.) Mr. Tapies's work made a very emphatic impression here from its first appearance, and both New York and in Paris (where he enjoyed the sponsorship that energetic dealer and critic, Michel Tapie), he was quickly established as one of the leading international painters of his generation. In recent years, however, there has been little critical discussion of his work on this side of the Atlantic. The present exhibitionand even more, perhaps, Sir Roland's monographtherefore provides a welcome opportunity to catch up on an artist who seemed to signify so much when he began exhibiting in the 1950's.

description: Most large philanthropies (Foundation Woes, The Saga of Henry Ford II: Part Two by Lally Weymouth, March 12) have sidestepped the thorniest of society's troubles and concentrated on fairly banal grants, grants which would make the existing order more bearable without disturbing its essence. Henry Ford II apparently wishes that the foundation bearing his family name had done likewise. But the world may some day honor the name of Ford more for its foundation than for its horseless carriages.

title: Japanese Rail Workers Strike
description: TOKYO, April 23 (UPI)Workers of major private railways in Tokyo and other major cities staked a oneday strike today in their campaign for higher wages. Employees of nine of the 13 major private railways carried out a stoppage while those of three others abandoned ticket offices and turnstiles. The walkout forced millions of travelers to stay home.

title: en a Damaged Heart Is Part of the Vacation Luggage
description: More and more people with heart conditions are traveling throughout the United States and even to exotic, faraway places. While it has not been unusual for businessmen to travel after heart attacks and with other cardiac ailments, cardiologists and heart surgeons are noting that a small but growing number of patients are traveling simply for pleasure, to vacation away from home.

title: Fashion
description: S ummer is almost upon us. Time now to think of ways to beat the heat. The easy way is with dresses like these natural  to breeze through the hottest day. This year, simplicity is the key; subtle details the bonuses. The classic shirtdress is updated. Now it's in looseweave fabrics such as silk gauze with wide sleeves and buttons lots of buttons, to do or undo. The caftan, always comfortable and instantly chic, this year is gauzier, deeply slit at the neckline and pulled into the waist with a thong and bead belt. Cool, cotton jersey drapes beautifully from shirred shoulders on a blouson top. And a belt's not just a belt. It's a silken cord knotted with pearly shells, the perfect accessory and all that's needed. Whatever the choice, the silhouette is soft, the look loose, the aim cool comfort.

title: MAILBAG; Of Ibsen, Absentees And Ushers; STANLEY WEINTRAUB; University Park, Pa.; KURT LICHTEN; Oradell, N. J.; THEATER MAILBAG; Of Ibsen, Absentees And Ushers; LOUIS H. CIVIN; To the Editor:; JOHN ATTER1DG; New York City; (MRS.) ELEANOR JACOBS
description: To the Editor: Harold Clurman has not read his Ibsen lately if he thinks Rebecca ... determines to die with Rosmer ['The Paradox of Ibsen: Famous but Unknown, April 2]. It is just the opposite. The only thing that can give him back his belief in his former power to inspire and ennoble others, he declares to Rebecca, is that she should expiate her guilt in driving Rosmer's late wife, Beata, to drown herself, by going the watery way of Beata in the Rosmersliolm millrace. Rebecca goes, and only then, caught up in her mood, does Rosmer determine to join her, and they go, arm-in-arm, to fulfill suicide

title: Road From Vietnam to New York Is a Creul One
description: TOKYO, April 23Nguyen Yen Linh is a 22-year-old Vietnamese refugee who went through three months of secret escape preparations, came under machinegun fire from pursuing Communist police and bailed for her life in a sinking boat.

description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI)Space agency engineers plan to resume radio contact with Skylab early Monday to prepare for a maneuver aimed at adding months to its life in orbit. The maneuver would enable astronauts to attempt to keep it from falling out of control to earth next year.

title: Indonesia Trying to Restore Its Relations With. China
description: JAKARTA, IndonesiaThe nonaligned and insular Indonesians main concern in foreign policy is to, normalize their frozen relations with China while insuring that Peking will not attempt to utilize the overseas Chinese minority to subvert President Suharto's Government.

description: ST. LOUIS. April 22 (UPI)The tiny amounts of cocaine and marijuana that led to the arrest of Leon Spinks on drug charges have a street value of about $1.50, a detective with the police department's narcotics bureau said today.

title: Group Shuns Death Penalty States
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP)The National Legal Aid and Defenders Association has announced that it will not hold any future annual conventions in states that have adopted the death penalty. The organization. which represents aproxi- mately 1,000 legal aid offices ana more than 2,000 members around the country, had previously decided not to hold conventions in states that have not adopted the equal rights amendment to the Constitution.

title: Lambertville's Music Man
description: LAMBERTVILLE THE name Musical Antiquities doesn't quite tell the entire story of Mark Osterman's shop here. He buys, sells and collects anything old that has to do with music. The items may include autographed pictures and music, playing cards with photographs of musicians on them or musical instruments.

title: 50% in Survey Back Government Curbs On Pay and Prices
description: The American public, increasingly pessimistic about the nation's economy, now supports having the Government bring back wage and price controls by a margin of 50 percent to 39 percent, with 11 percent undecided, according to the Gallup Poll.

title: Atherton, After Talks With Sadat, Reports Clear Understanding
description: HURGHADA, Egypt, April 23Alfred L. Atherton Jr., the United States special Mideast envoy, met with President Anwar elSadat for several hours here today and reported that they had reached a much clearer understanding of possible ways to resume the deadlocked peace negotiations.

title: Treaty Pilots Finally Reach A Safe Harbor
description: Nothing came easily, but all the loose ends were neatly knotted for President Carter in time for last week's Senate ratification of the treaty that gives control of the Panama Canal to Panama.

title: From Peach Orchards to Fine Food
description: THE Hunterdon County town of Ringoes was once known for its fine peach orchards. Now it is known for the fine food served by Edward and Doris Simpson in their restored 18th- and 19thcentury farmhouse, The Muirhead, which named for a stop on the Black River and Western Railroad.

title: BOOK ENDS
description: JUDGE JOHN SIRICA recently signed a joint paperback - hardcover contract to do a book with W.W. Norton and New American Li- brary, in return for a total advance of $555,000. The judge who sentenced the Watergate burglars has put off writing about the case until his retirement, according to George Brockway, chairman of the board of W.W. Norton, who said the competition for the book was keen. Evidently publishers feel there is still life in the Watergate genre. Eightyfive percent of the book will be about the Watergate case, Mr. Brockway says, and there will be two or three things new. Asked if the manuscript, which is due next spring, will be surrounded the kind of tight security that has attended H.R. Haldeman's and Richard M. Nixon's memoirs, Mr. Brockway says it depends upon whether there are customers for the serial rights, but as far as he, as publisher, was concerned, the more that's revealed in advance, the better since advance tidbits of news whet the public appetite - vide the Haldeman book and the recent furor over In His Image: The Cloning of Man.

title: Carey Gets His Way on Westway
description: Ed Koch should never have said never about the Westway. Last week. the Mayor, acknowledging that Governor Carey had made him an offer he couldn't refuse, said that the Westway shall proceed.

description: CLEMSON, S.C., April 22 CAP)Maryland captured seven first places today to help score 1821/2 points and capture its 23d consecutive Atlantic Coast Conference track and field chamnionshio.

title: A Bagged Candidate Wins Campus Election
description: ATHENS, Ga., April 22 (AP)Roger Strauss says he did not think he had the election in the bag. But after campaigning with a paper sack over his head, Mr. Strauss has become the president of the University of Georgia Student Government Association.

title: Prices Skyrocket on the Trivia Index
description: Loeb Rhoades, Hornblower & Company has a theory that the true measure of inflation must be taken by means other than the consumer price index even the supposedly more accurate consumer index that the Government intro- duced last month. Seven years ago the brokerage firm began to publish its own index to point up the ineluctable rises in littlenoticed everyday items usually not covered in any measure of consumer, prices.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: For several years many of us believed that the multinational infant formula companies were enticing third world women to bottle feed and that this was damaging the health of their children [See White Plains Groups Join Nestle Protest, April 16]. We, in our innocence, believed that if we got rid of the milk companies, child health would improve.

description: Despite the creation of a collegiate draft in 1972 and claims in subsequent years that the Americanization of soccer was working, until this year the North  American Soccer League had been as American as apple strudel.

description: LONDON, April 22 (AP)Basil Dean, an actor, author, theatrical producer, stage.iind film director and head of British armed forces entertainment in two world wars, died today. He was 89 years old:

title: Two Queens Youths Arrested After Synagogue Is Set Afire
description: Two Queens teenagers were arrested yesterday after they reportedly set fire to the Congregation Beth Jacob of Astoria, where they allegedly had stolen gold and silver religious articles.

title: The Politicizing Of Tom Stoppard
description: Tom Stoppard writes like mathematical philosopher who really wants to be clown. His verbal equations balance out on the side of absurdity and his logical calculations tend to be springboards to non- sense. His most famous playsRosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead, Jumpers and Travesties'have established him as a specialist in philosophical farce. He can use a syllogism like a custard pie and give logical positivism the status. But his intellectual frivolity has naturally made Mr. Stoppard suspect in the eyes of those who believe that great dramatists ought to be committed to more serious social and political issues. Critic Kenneth Tynan has described him as a cool, apolitical stylist, and to prove his point

title: Fighting Inflation at 30,000 Feet
description: The Senate gave President Carter's antiinflation effort a boost last week when it approved his airline deregulation plan by an 83-to-9 margin. Speedy passage of the bill in the House is not assured, however. Airline and union interests, opposed to any change in the status quo, have so far managed to keep it parked in committee.

title: IN BRIEF
description: United States real economic growth sputtered in the first quarter of 1978, declining by sixtenths of a percent to $1.36 trillion annual rate, according to the Commerce Department. The department's economists blamed the first decline since 1975 in the nation's inflation- adjusted gross national product on severe winter weather and the coal strike, which may have cut growth by as much as 3 percent. . .. The department had better news on housing starts, which posted a record 32 percent month-tomonth increase in March, and on personal income, which climbed 1.2 percent in March after two months of meager growth. ... American factories operated at 82.9 percent of capacity, according to the Federal Reserve, up from 81.9 percent in February

title: Gov. Ray Abolishing State Women's Panel
description: OLYMPIA, Wash., April 22 (AP)Dixy Lee Ray, the first woman to be Governor of the state of Washington, has said she will abolish the State Women's Council by Sept. 1.

title: W. JAMES ROSE

title: Suddenly, the Market Soars. Why?; Suddenly, the Market Soars. Why?; The unseen hand of the marketplace had already adjusted for many problems.
description: In just three days of frenzied trading that broke almost all previous volume records, the Dow Jones industrial average soared almost 60 points  close to percent  leaving many observers wondering why. What had made stocks take off so suddenly and so vigorously, after having languished for so long, at a moment when most of the economic and political pressures that had caused the previous slide were still in force? It seems clear that a peculiar confluence of technical, economic and even political forces fueled the rise that was sparked on Friday, April 14, by favorable monetary developments.

title: PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW

The subject matter itself is so appealing that it can make even a mediocre photograph interesting. There is, however, something quite special about the photographs that the 19tHcentury French photographer Edouard Denis Baldus made of these subjects. A selection of his work is on view at the Daniel Wolf Gallery, 30 West 57th Street, through May 13.

title: Oerter Continues Winning Comeback
description: WEST POINT, N.Y., April 22Five Shea Stadium track records were broken today in the first West Point Invitation. Seton Hall's 400meter relay team edged Manhattan College in 41.5 seconds to break the mark set by Manhattan last year. Two members of Seton Hall's 400 relay team, Calvin Dill and Ed Brown, came hack later to establish individual marks. Dill won the 100meter dash with a windaided 10,5 and Brown took the 900 meters in 97.4.

title: Mr. Davis Defends His Turf
description: Nothing touches more tender political nerves than Parks Commissioner defending his turf. Commissioner Gordon Davis has come out for the public as well as the Darks interest by barring the Taste of the Big Apple celebrationa promotional restaurant bash that produces food and garbage in equal partsfrom Central Park this year. He has also impounded a $2,500 bond posted by the March of Dimes for a recent Central Park to Battery Park walkathon that left both parks inundated with trash. Neither event ever had any reason to be the parks at all.

title: The $4-Billion-a-Year Cost of Dying

title: NEXT BRAZIL LEADER SEEN HOLDING COURSE

Joao Batista Figueiredo at his home in Brasilia recently to relay the good news. The general, who joined the party the Monday before and earned his fourth shr the Thursday betore that had just hen overwhelmingly endorsed as the party standardhearer for the indirect presidential election to be held by party delegates in October.

The Soviet Foreign Minister, Andrei A. Gromyko, visited Washington late September and he and President Carter agreed on the outlines and many of the details of a treaty that would curb the countries nuclear arsenals until 1985.

description: A major television news special not made by one of the networks or by the Public Broadcasting System with grant in its pocket is in itself news. Such a maverick pro- gram, not bearing the logo of ABC, CBS, NBC or PBS, is The 45 Billion Dollar Connection, which will be broadcast nationwide by 169 stations Thursday evening. In New York the hour show will be seen at 8 P.M. on WNEWTV, Channel 5.

title: Hatcher Reported Cool to FullTime White House Job
description: WASHINGTON, April 23Richard G. Hatcher hal offered to become a $1-ayear aide to President Carter while remaining as Mayor of Gary, Ind., White House officials and sources close to the Mayor reported today.

title: China, Russia and Japan
description: HONG KONG  The sudden appearance of a cluster 190 Chinese fishing boats around a small group of uninhabited islands claimed by both Japan and China has threatened set back one of Peking's cherished foreign policy objectives. Until the arrival of the boats around the Senkaku Islands days ago, China seemed about to win a complex triangular game among Tokyo. Moscow and Peking.

title: SOLAR ENERGY ADVOCATE OFFERS 50YEAR TIMETABLE
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (AP)A leading advocate of solar energy said today that the world could abandon its dependency on oil, gas, coal and uranium and derive 83 percent of its energy from the sun in the next 50 years.

title: New Housing and Parks - as Well as New Traffic -- Will Change the Ambiance of Lower Manhattan
description: The Westway, the political football that politicians, neighborhood crusaders, lawyers and others have been kicking around for nearly six years, appears to be inching its way toward the goal line. But nearly lost in the scrimmaging over its politics is the effect the completed $1.16billion highway and public works project could have on the quality of life midtown and lower Manhattan and along the riverfront.

title: Savaging the President
description: LONDON; April 23In Europe as in America, Jimmy Carter is the subject of much head shaking. The Economist of London leads this week's issue with a worried article about what it calls his insouciant Presidency. America's friends, it says, must hope that the giddy slide in his fortunes is coming to an end.

title: DANCE VIEW
description: See. America Dancing waswith apologies to Walt Whitmanone of Isadore Duncan's better lines. Yet even Isadore's prophetic vision probably could not have taken in the scope of dance activities scheduled the first National Dance Week, which will be proclaimed on various private and official levels throughout- the country for this coming week.

title: Britons Fight The Battle Of the Bulge
description: LONDON  In a rare show of unanimity, the Health Education Council, the Trade Unions Council, the British Heart Foundation, the army, Members of Parliament, the Royal Association for Disability and Rehabilitation and the television industry have fired a coordinated broadside calculated to change the bad habits of the British.

title: The Vicissitudes of the Moog
description: Before Robert Moog brought out his first synthesizer in 1964, electronic music had been a strange concept explored only by a few scientists.

title: Tour Earnings
Southern Comforts
description: BILOXI, Vicksburg, Mobile, Newark, Santa Fe, Richmond, Atlanta, Tuscaloosa: The names all appear in Barry Hanna''s striking book short stories, and the places are mostly Southern. Mr. Hannah's territory is the new American South, and the new economy of the South appears in one story as something like a frame of mind: The only thing we're sure about anymore is how much money we need. ... That's about as profound as I ever get. I've got a wife and two kids. Me and the wife drink a great deal in the evenings of Baton Rouge. We're happy. The great questions seemed to have passed us by.. I'm a radiologist. All day long I look for shadows. . .. Our children are beautiful and I've got stock in Shell. .. . Every man can be a king if he wants to.

title: Quebec's Language Law Puts Companies to Flight
description: MONTREAL  Bon debarras! Good riddance! An attempt has been made to obliterate the slogans painted on the Sun Life Assurance Company's 1920'sstyle head office in Montreal's Dominion Sauare. But it was only half- hearted, as if the $5 billionassets mutual insurance company, 12th largest in North America, were resigned. Another outburst of fury is expected at the annual meeting Tuesday, when policyholders will most likely ratify the board's decision to move to a new head office in Toronto.

title: 4 in Family Die in House Fire
description: MONTGOMERY, Pa., April 22 (AP)Four children died and three other family members were injured early today in fire at their house, the authorities said. The police identified the dead victims as Tammy Sue Wertz, 17 years old; Timothy Yohn, 14; Sterling Yohn, 13, and Llizabeth Sue Yohn, 9. Betty Yohn, 42, their mother, was treated for burns and shock. and Donald Yohn Jr., 19, was treated for minor burns. The fire apparantly started in the kitchen.

title: A Touch of Gold for an Ailing Dollar
description: The worst of the dollar's troubles may be over for a while. That was the consensus last week of European bankers and foreignexchange dealers after the Carter Administration announced a plan to sell 300,000 ounces of gold a month for the next six months, which would sop up excess dollars. The decision was taken to mean new resolve by the United States to protect the value of its currency.

title: Susan C. Fox, Michael Jarvis Plan Marriage
description: Mr. and Mrs. M. Warren Smith of New York and East Hampton, have announced the engagement of. Mrs. Smith's daughter, Susan Coutant Fox, to Michael Philip Jarvis, son of Mrs. Roger Gordon of Mission Vieio, Calif., and of Kaye Jarvis of Federal Way, Wash.

To reduce energy waste, and to make certain the unit will do its job efficiently and not fail when most needed, there are a number of simple preventive maintenance procedures that the owner should follow before the season arrives.

It is little different from spelldown neighboring villages like Ddyda and Bronllys, Brynmawr and Llangfrynack except for one thing. Glasbury happens to stand on what sports fishermen consider one of the finest salmon rivers in the British Isles.

title: Texas Calms Down
description: AUSTIN, Tex., April 21  Governor Dolph Briscoe is hinting these days that Attorney General John Hill, his principal opponent in the Democratic primary May 6, might favor a state income tax, since Mr. Briscoe thinks Mr. Hill looks mighty like a big-spending liberal.

title: THE MARKETS Some Days to Remember
description: Spontaneous combustion! That's how one Wall Streeter last Monday tagged the stock market's rally, looking over his shoulder at the eyepopping session the previous Friday, April 19, when the Dow Jones industrial average vaulted nearly 20 points on the breathcatching record volume of 52.28 million shares.

title: Israel's Latest Proposals
description: WASHINGTON, April 22  With Prime Minister Begin an I Foreign Minister Dayan of Israel coming here in the next few days, the Carter Administration is now studying very carefully the Israeli Government's latest formulation of its policy for breaking the present diplomatic impasse in the Middle East.

title: Mrs. Truman Ends Hospital Stay
description: KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 22 (AP)Bess Truman, the 93-year-old widow of former President Harry S. Truman, checked out of Research Hospital here this morning after a threeweek stay for a checkup and tests. Mrs. Truman was taken to her Independence, Mo., home by Secret Service agents. A hospital spokesman said she was listed in satisfactory condition while she was there.

title: Three Young Conductors at City Opera
description: he New York City Opera's reputation as this country's premier training ground and springboard for young operatic talent is well known and, certainly, well deserved. After all. many a career that began on the City Opera's stage has blossomed into international stardom, and operaphiles have come to have great expectations of each season's crop of City Opera debutantes. Yet, little recognition has been accorded an equally important aspect of the City Opera's operation: the opportunity has given young conductors, especially since the establishment, 10 years ago, of the Julius Rudel Award.

title: A Price War on the International Front
description: Although international air fares are set by agreements among the carriers and route awards are subject to diplomatic negotiations between governments, the fallingfare phenomenon has spread around the world.

description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Miller of New York and Hampton Bays, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Amy Paula Miller, to Walter Charles Dennison, son of Dr. Edwin W. Dennison of San Diego and Dr. Laura B. Dennison of Claremont, Calif.

title: Jay Ungar Brings Fiddling to the Fore
description: ONE of the most respected fiddlers in America, Jay Ungar, is often in the musical spotlight, accompanying wellknown artists in concert or performing with his wife Lyn Hardy at major folk festivals throughout North America.

title: Juliette. Gregg Is Married to Richard Orville Latimer
description: Juliette Gregg and Richard Orville Latimer were married yesterday afternoon in the West Side Presbyterian Church in Ridgewood, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Melvin Campbell.

title: American Reporters With Vance Protest Curbs at Brezhnev Talks
description: MOSCOW, April 22Reporters covering the visit here of Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance had a dispute with the Soviet Foreign Ministry today similar to one they had last year. The argument was over how many Americans would be permitted to look in on the start of Mr. Vance's meeting with Leonid Brezhnev, the Soviet leader.

title: BRIDGE
description: Those who complain that the bidding systems of the experts are too complex and artificial to understand should note that a change is on the way. In another decade the task of understanding what the experts are up to in the auction will cease to be merely difficult and become impossible. The key word in this insidious process sounds quite innocent. It is relay'.

title: A Vest With A View
description: I'm still not sure whether I'm making clothes or art, says Joan Steiner, the artful seamstress who created the roomy garments on this page. Whichever, they are certainly design originals: vests on which are sewn or embroidered detailed views of rooms of a house. They evolved, says Miss Steiner, by accident, about a year and a half ago when she found herself with a year's worth of financial resources and a desire to do something with my hands. Though without any formal training, she had always enjoyed drawing and needlework as hobbies. She started out making a few small softsculpture purses in the form of ice skates, a portable radio and a sandwich. A toaster muff, complete with popup toast, led her to her first vest, which featured a wellequipped kitchen, down to a halfroasted chicken in the wellpadded fabric oven.

title: Backers of Airline Deregulation Gird for Expected House Battle
description: WASHINGTON, April 23Proponents of deregulation of the airlines, after victory in the Senate last week, are turning their attention to the House, where the reform measure has been sidetracked.

title: Mortal Coils
description: ROME  The terrorists had threatened to execute him yesterday afternoon. The deadline passed, and the fate of former Prime Minister Aldo Moro was still unknown. So were the answers to most of the basic questions raised by the Kafkaesque drama that began with Mr. Moro's abduction more month ago. What sort of Italy, socially and politically, will emerge from the experience?

title: Aaron McDonald's Burgers Are Falling to Fast Foods
description: WACO, Tex., April 21The big red and white sign reads McDonald's Hamburgers, and beneath that is the legend Home of the Big Mac. But there are no golden arches, and the weatherworn drivein restaurant behind the sign surely has not come close to serving a million hamburgers, let along a billion.

title: RutgersNewark Takes East Volleyball Crown
description: UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., April 22Rutgers University at Newark gained its second consecutive Eastern Collegiate volleyball League crown today, defeating Army. 159, 1511. The Raiders will represent She East at the Regional Collegiate Athletic Association championships on May 5 and 6 in Columbus, Ohio.

description: HIMSELF!

title: DINING OUT; Inviting Bistro With French Flair; *Bistro 22
description: SOME weeks ago, we wrote of the difficulty rating a particular restaurant: It may not fully rate its two stars, but it cannot be left at one. This week, in the same quandary, we have to turn that around: Bistro 22 is better than one star. but cannot quite be given two. That illustrates how little leeway there is for a reviewer. So if there something'about a restaurant that appeals to you, we urge you to try it, regardless of stars.

title: Air Force Ends Dress Code Police
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)The Air Force has decided to slop the use of groom troopers, special teams to enforce military dress codes, Representative Les Aspin said today, releasing an Air Force letter that announced the move. title: HIDDEN CASH HELPS CAREY MEET CRISES
description: ALBANY, April 21Concerned over the decrease in revenues that its taxcut program will cause next year and over the unusual number of financial uncertainties in this year's budget, Governor Carey's administration is quietly, holding large amounts of money in reserve to soften what could be some serious fiscal blows.

title: Author's Query
description: Information from B17 crewmen who raided Hamburg on the 25th and 26th of July 1943 is needed for a book on this period of the bombing war. Readers who can help are requested to write. Eivine brief details.

title: What's Doing in
description: WHITE CITY - Two of the great rivers of Europethe Danube and the Savameet here in the capital of Yugoslavia, watched over by a huge white fortress, Kalemegdan, which stands at the spot where rival forces surging across Eastern Europe since Roman times have fought for the gateway to the Balkans. On a sunny day the stucco walls of the fortress and the urban buildings behind it glitter, though pollution from coalfired furnaces has somewhat detracted from the brightness that caused the early conquerors to call the place White City. It has been destroyed more times than anyone can count, each wave of Celts, Romans, Huns, Avars, Slays, Ottoman Turks and Austro-Hungarians leaving its mark on a city that is struggling, like Yugoslavia itself, for an independent identity.

title: A Problem That Won't Go Away
description: 'WE have lulled ourselves into the mistaken notion that we have turned the corner on drug abuse, said Dr. A. Africano, the director of the Drug Liberatiion Clinic Inc., a private nonprofit organization in Stamford.

description: A small staff of people within the Brooklyn Public Library system has been busy since January writing letters, hunting through bookstores and moving furniture in an effort to convert the ground floor of the Williamsburg Library into El Centro Hisnano de Informacion.

title: Anthony Boiardo Is Dead at 60; Called Key Jersey Crime Figure
description: Anthony (Tony Boy) Boiardo identified .by Federal authorities as a key figure in organized crime in New Jersey, died :Thursday in Montclair Community HoSpitifl of a heart illness, according to a hospital spokesman. He was 60 years old.

title: Say Goodbye to Phil Jackson
description: Long after his points and his rebounds for the Knicks are forgotten, his shoulders will be remembered, shoulders that gave Phil Jackson the appearance of havipg two wooden hangers stuffed under his skin. Strangers have asked him, Can touch your shoulders? as if they had been transplanted from a moose.

title: SHOP TALK
description: THE approach to a bargain is often unpredictable. Some people feel that if the price is low, something must be wrong. (Is it damaged? Discontinued? Or simply undesirable?) Others, confirming that the sale price is legitimate, will buy two or buy something else with the money saved.

title: Argentine Party Accepts Army Bid

title: Crash Kills Man
description: BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 22 (UPI)Two children were listed in fair condition today after a collision between a car and school bus that left one man dead and 27 other children injured. The dead man was identified as Frank Szilagyi, 36 years old, the driver of the auto. The police said that he was traveling at a high rate of speed when he apparently lost control of his car and struck the Bethlehem School District bus headon. The children were being driven home from school.

title: Farmers Mark Gains in Cattle and Losses in Wheat

title: `Amen Corner by Baldwin Staged by Arts Consortium
description: Although not all the...roles in James Baldwin's The Amen Corner are of the same weight, the strength of the revival now playing at the New York Arts Consortium (36 West 62 Street; 5819110) is in its unified effect. It is an orchestrated effort that sweeps the play along and that fits major and minor characters into an exposition of community life that is at once full of pathos and caustic humor, irritating. superstition and shrewd folk wisdom. The result is a production that turns all the facets of a Harlem, Biblequoting, churchfront congregation to the scrutiny of the spectator.

title: A church Goes Coop to Survive
description: Only 50 Episcopalians attend mass on a typical Sunday at All Angels Church on the Upper West Side, but the old parish hall probably bustles with as much vitality as it did a generation or two ago.

description: NORTH HILLS WHEN Dr. Lowell Kane was elected Mayor of this welltodo North Shore community last month on platform of strict restrictions on residential and industrial growth, one could almost hear the sighs of relief of his condominium neighbors and the residents of surrounding villages.

Hutchinson of Norwalk, Conn. and Robert Bosworth Hutchinson of Columbus, Ohio.

title: Disputed Practices of Undertakers Are Defended by Some in Business

After she died, the undertaker demanded $300 more and threatened not to bury the body until the family paid up. The funeral was conducted only after an assistant state attorney general, Theodore E. Garrison, reminded the undertaker that holding up a funeral under such circumstances was a violation of the state's Public Health Law.

They ran into a decision by Mr. Vance that neither he nor anyone else in the official party would provide any specific information.

title: Headliners
description: Many novelists have a commitment to their art, but Frederick Forsyth went too far. According to The .Sunday Times London, the author of The Day of the Jackal and other novels of international intrigue recruited a group of mercenaries try to overthrow an African government in 1972, then based book on the attempt. Thanks to literary license, however, the mercenaries who invaded the mythical Zangaro in The Dogs of War were more successful than those who actually plotted to overthrow the government of Equatorial Guinea. The expedition fizzled when Spanish authorities discovered the mercenaries intentions and sent them home.

title: The Extrayazant Whimsy
description: The choreographer James Waring once wrote, I like extravagance because it is clear that it is what it is. Extravagant he clearly was. The cast of one of his dances included a live goose. Music for another consisted of alternations of Bacn ana pop songs of the 1920's. Usually classified as a modern dancer, he preferred to call his works ballets and he utilized pointe technique extensively. He loved old movies and fairy tales, and he gave dances such whimsical titles as Tomato Expos and Pumpernickel and Circumstance.

title: Truths by Exaggeration
description: CATCHING up on periodical literature at my dentist's I came across a Saturday Review article by John Gardner in which he tasks most contemporary American novelists with a lack of moral seriousness. For my taste there was too much of the spirit of Malvolio in the piece, but I was interested see, for I had just finished my way through The World According to Garp, that Gardner had listed John Irving as a corner in the very uncrowded field morally serious fiction. This approach is echoed in the publisher's blurb for the new novel  rich, humorous and wise.

title: The World

The talks last week dealt with two of President Carter's most elusive foreign policy goals: a peaceful and equitable transition to majority rule in Rhodesia and a new agreement with the Russians limiting strategic nuclear arms.

title: .Andrea Walters Affianced

Church in Rockford, Ill Announcement of their engagement has been made by the parents of the prospective bride, Mr. and Mrs. George Walter of Rockford. Mr. David is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Hal David of Roslyn, L.I. His father, the lyricist who collaborated with Burt Bacharach Jr. en the Broadway musical Promises, Promises, is owner of the Jac Music Company in Great Neck, L.I. But now the judgment and perhaps even the future of the Jockey Club has been called into question by the club's encounter with CEMcontagious equine mctritis, or horse gonorrhea.

Thursday at Yankee Stadium. Then the Mets return to Shea Stadium against the Cincinnati Reds at 8 P.M. Friday and 2 P.M. Saturday and next Sunday.

Most of us had dreamed of going to China, few of us ever thought we would live long enough to do it. But we were lucky enough to be among the few thousand Americans to obtain travel visas since China reopened its doors to Americans.

(Tc these we may now add the myriad forms of modernday electronic keyboards, but that's another story.)

description: Swan Lake is one of the great ballets of all time, and New York is fortunate that American Ballet Theater once decided that the fulllength fouract version could endure in an American company's repertory.

title: Budget Problems Could Forestall Sales of National Forest Timber
description: WASHINGTON, April 23President Carter's suggestion that the rising cost of housing might be held in check by cutting more timber in the national for- ests brought cheers from the Forest bery ice and the timber industry, concern from the conservationists and questions from the Office of Management and Budget.

description: VINCENT CANBY

title: Brian De Palma: I Operate On the Principle of Escalating Terror
description: I don't think you can scare an audience unless you are serious. Brian De Palma was commenting on his latest film, The Fury, which is currently scaring not unimpressive numbers of willing victims in theaters around town. With such spinetinglers as Sisters and Carrie behind him, the 34-yearold director is considered by many to be today's master of cinematic horror. A purveyor of elegant apocalypses, as Richard Eder, then a film critic for The Times wrote in 1976 in his review of Carrie,'- Mr. De Palma has been compared to Alfred Hitchcock and, indeed, has taken on the solemn mantle of the auteur.

title: Some New York Legislators Are Pushing New Funeral Regulations
description: Even as the Federal Trade Commission staff prepares its recommendations for national rules for the funeral industry, some legislators in New York State want to push ahead with more regulations here.

title: After Columbia
description: BOSTONWe like to count by 10's, and I hope it has escaped no one's notice that 10 years ago, on April 23, a relative handful of students occupied several buildings at Columbia University and effectively shut the school down for the rest of the semester.

title: BACKPACKERS SEEK A TAX FOR TRAIL MAINTENANCE
description: LINCOLN, Me., April 22 (AP)--Warning that America's hiking paths .are being loved to death, a backpackers group has proposed a Federal excise tax on hiking equipment to pay for the maintenance and construction of trails.

title: Talk With John Irving
description: The Irving house in Putney, Vt., is a converted barn heated by a wood stove. The main room contains balconies, stairs, kitchen, a large oak table. Everything tilts or has been built with or against an ancient though sturdy tilt that the Ir. vings  John, Shyla and their two young sons  seem to live with in a very active and happy way. On the high walls are Shyla's paintings and photographs. Bookshelves contain hocks that look read. There is still a lot of snow in Vermont, and skis and their gear, both crosscountry and downhill, are in evidence. John Irving, an exwrestler, seems in as good shape as he was when a contender in. his weight class in college. He is 36 but looks younger.

title: Cornell Defeats Penn In Ivy League Lacrosse
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 22 (AP)Tom Marino scored three goals and assisted on two to lead undefeated Cornell over Pennsylvania. 156. today in an Ivy League lacrosse match. Cornell, now 73 overall and 40 in the Ivy League, took an early 21 lead and broke open the game in the second quarter with six straight goals in 10 minutes.

title: COURT UPSETS ARISE IN GOLDEN GATE TOLL
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 22The Golden Gate Bridge District illegally raised tolls last November and must cut them until $2.8 million has been returned to the commuters who use the bridge, fudge in State Superior Court has ruled.

In the pit, Julius Rudel led the orchestra in a marvelously alert superbly executed account of Mozart's masterpiece. On stage, the singing and acting merely skimmed the surface of the work.

title: INTERVIEW

description: MAPUTO, Mozambique, April 23 (Reuters)  President Samora Machel of Mozambique has reshuffled his Cabinet, the first major Government change since the country gained independence nearly three years ago.

title: DR. GILBERT'S TIPS FOR RUNNERS
description: (1) Check to find out which shoes are best for you. No one shoe fits everybody. No matter what the ads say, fit is still the most important factor. Along with fit, the running shoe has to provide shock absorption to reduce the effects of asphalt and concrete. Look for the shoe that has three soles.

Before coming to the United States in 1971, he received intensive training at the Tokyo studio of Michio Ti n a dancerchoreoeraoher who played a seminal role in early American modern dance. Among his American teachers Mr. Shimazaki counts Martha Graham and Merce Cunningham.

title: The Administration Seeks to Display a New Toughness
description: WASHINGTON  In the midst of a regular White house press briefing last week, Jody Powell, the Presidential press secretary, launched into a long, strident peroration about the urgent need to implement the President's proposed tax and civil service reforms. After he had been at it for several minutes, a reporter cut in to ask if the frustration in his voice was a reflection of the President's mood.

title: Lowered Benefits Starting for Some On Social Security
description: WASHINGTON, April 22 (UPI)The Social Security Administration said today that it had begun to carry out a 1977 law modifying the payment of benefits to millions of people in their first year of retirement or in semiretirement.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: In the early months of 1939, Marion Bauer sent me to see Oscar Thompson, the music critic of the New York Sun, who was editing the International Cyclopedia of Music and Musicians published by Dodd, Mead. Miss Bauer had been one of my teachers in the graduate school New York University, and she knew I was looking for job. Her recommendation was enough for Mr. Thompson, who promptly put me to work writing short biographies of musicians whose names began with M, N and 0.

title: Flight Attendants: An Old Stereotype Is Given the Air
description: The institutional desk and swivel chair hold no charms for them, and the boundary hours of 9 and 5 are a synonym for boredom. They prefer to be sur- rounded with a constantly changing stream of coworkers, galvanized by activity, and spelled by long periods of doas,youplease. They are attractive and goodtempered, but they will not tolerate bad manners, and, ironically, many of them are not too wild about flying.

title: GARDENING
description: NOW that spring is finally here, take a little time to really look at expanding leaf buds, all sorts of leaf buds. If you are gardener who takes a hohum attitude toward leaves as something to strip off flower stems cut for bouquets, or as nuisances that nearly inundate the lawn every fall, you are in for a surprise. All winter, their buds have been quiescent within their sheltering scales.

title: It Did Not Die, But its Metamorphosis Was Remarkable
description: Dad the Breadwinner, Mom the Homemaker, two Smiling Children, preferably with freckles. The model American family, right? Wrong. Recent studies show that this particular model accounts for only one out . every 16 American families.

title: Earrings: Light and Airy
description: There's nothing conventional about the light airy gold earrings Kristin Moore designs. Some of them are simply threaded through the pierced ear and held in place by gravity. When a fastening is provided, as insurance rather than necessity, it forms part of the design. And, except in the case of the plainest hoops, there's a right and a left. The swept back, for instance, is a 19karat tendril intended as an extension of the hair, yet women invariably try it on facing forward, connecting with the chin line.

title: TV VIEW
description: For many years I have admired, indeed venerated, Elie Wiesel for his touching, insightful and wise books on the Holocaust. Survivor, sufferer, prophet, teacher, he is an eminent and scholarly figure, and we must be grateful for his contributions. He not, of course, the only such expert, the Alpha and Omega of the Holocaust. Others have suffered, survived and written. My own tastes lean toward the sober, reflective historiansRaul Hilberg, Lucy Davidowicz, Gerald Reitlinger and Norah Levin, and to such eyewitnesses as Primo Levi ('Survival in Auschwitz'), Eugen Kogon ('The Theory and Practice of Hell') and Yuri Suhl ('They Fought Back').

title: ERA. REPLACES AIDE IN POLLUTION DISPUTE
description: Eric Stork, the Government's chief enforcer of pollution control standards for automobiles, has been. replaced by Michael P. Walsh, a newcomer to the Environmental Protection Agency whose work is expected to reflect a desire by the agency to get even- tougher about cleanair policly for cars.

title: Food
description: w hen talking about fried chicken, one could as easily say, It's as Austrian as Wiener Backhendl as, It's as American as Southern fried. In essence the two dishes are the same. The main difference, however, is that there are many ways of making Southern fried chicken while the preparation of Viennese fried chicken is more or less standardized and traditional. Generally, the Backhendl is breaded before it is fried to a luscious golden brown in a blend of butter and oil. When the Backhendl is to be eaten hot, it is frequently anointed, at the last moment, with hot melted butter. When served cold, this last glorification is omitted. (Cold Viennese fried chicken is a marvelous addition to a picnic basket, by the way.) Wiener Backhendl seems somehow to be ideal fare for spring dining, particularly when served with fresh asparagus spears and redskinned new potatoes. A cold sweet-and-sour sliced beet salad with onion rings is happily

That Americans went to war in Southeast Asia because we did not realize that monolithic Communism Stalin's Communismhad long since disappeared is part of the conventional wisdom by now. But how up-to-date are our perceptions of modern Europe?

title: The Fruits of Utopia In New Harmony, Ind.
description: Two of the most fascinating experiments in utopian life ever attempted in the United States both had their homes in the town of New Harmony in the southwestern corner of Indiana. Here along the neat grid of quiet streets of brick storefronts and frame houses you can still 'sense the simplicity and piousness of the first group, the Harmonists, originally from the German state of Wurttemberg, who had already established themselves in a community in western Pennsylvania when they moved west in 1814.

description: WASHINGTON, April 22The Italian Government's handling of the impact of the terrorist kidnapping. of Aldo Moro was described as exemplary this week by, a United States Government specialist in,crisis management who was called into the case by the Italians.

They were planning her funeral until Annette called to say that she was alive.

Some of the French novelist's personality may have eluded the British biographer, but the work, first published a dozen years ago, is indisputably monumental.

Named the California horse of the year in 1977 and runnerup to Forego for the Eclipse Award as the nation's top handicap horse, the 5-year-old Crystal Water retires with earnings of $845,672.

But the main issues of disagree- ment between the two powers remain far from resolution, and the restoration of Soviet confidence in the Carter Administration as a ne- gotiating partner appears far from complete.

title: Audio Development Is the Mother Of Musical Invention
description: Shakespeare unwittingly characterized the early aspirations of audio: Tis, as it were, to hold the mirror up to nature, That was the original goalfidelity to the natural sound. Now that this goal has at last been closely approached, however, a great many audio buffs, and professionals, are anxious to go even furtherto employ the new electronic technology not merely to copy nature, but to create a whole new world of sound and sound effects.

title: The Region
description: Corruption charges in Stamford are as familiar to its residents as mortgage payments. For three years there has been talk of bribery and larceny in city agencies, of criminal activities by police (committing burglary) and by firemen (permitting arson). Until last week, cleanup efforts had accomplished little. And even now the biggest broom is the Federal Government's.

title: Luther I. Bonney, Dean Emeritus At University of Maine, 93, Dies
description: CUMBERLAND CENTER, Me., April 22 Luther I. Bonney, dean emeritus of the University of Maine's Portland campus and a former professor of mathematics at Middlebury College in Vermont, died yesterday in a Yarmouth nursing home. He was 93 years old.

title: LETTERS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Adventure in Gotham: A Picnic on the Brooklyn Bridge
description: For those of us who live in rural Pennsylvania, a pleasure trip to New York City is a real adventure. Even one day in the city necessitates great advance planning and argumentso that each member of the group can feel that he or she got to choose an activity or a place to visit. Recently, four of us planned such an adventure.

title: Robert Green to Marry Jeri L. Chinman in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joel L. emnman of Hewlett Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jeri L. Chinman, to Robert H. Green, son of Mr, and Mrs. David Green of Riverdale, the Bronx. A June wedding is planned.

description: At first it appeared of benefit only to the University of Florida football team. Dr. James R. Cade, a university nephrologist, had come up with a new drink in 1965 that restored some of the body chemicals lost through sweat. It proved so successful that he formed a trust and sold the marketing rights for the drink--Gatorade--to StokelyVan Camp, Inc.

title: Carters Attend Baptist Services
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI)Presldent and Mrs. Carter attended Bible class and church services today at the First Baptist Church of Washington, along with a group of 30 ministers, from Scotland. The visiting ministers, including one from Plains, Scotland, met briefly with the President after the class to shake hands with him.

title: TV VIEW
description: With one of the most nonthreatening personalities in television, Fred Rogers has an extraordinary ability to make a lot of people nervous. The creator of Mister Rogers Neighborhood, the longrunning children's series on Public Television, is an apostle gentleness, constantly devising sermons on the theme that each one of us makes a difference in this world. In medium dominated by slick techniques, aggressive styles, hostile comedies and hysterical violence, this quiet man becomes somewhat perversely jarring. For some viewers, may appear to have taken one Valium too many.

title: Revised Offshore Rule Keeps Argument Afloat
description: The winds of change in offshore yacht racing are about to sweep away the current handicapping system and perhaps grand prix yacht racing along with it.

title: Connors Beats Vila, Faces org Today

title: Mr. Begin's Jewish Critics
description: The idea that a Government of Israel might be diplomatically unwise or chauvinistically greedy sticks in the throat of American Jews, and for good reason. To them, as to Americans generally, Israel is a moral creation, atoning for the slaughter of millions of European JAws the embodiment of a humane, ethical society. And in the face of unyielding Arab hostility, its governments have been judged unusually smart and farsighted. That image has been fading in recent months as Egypt acceded to Israel's dream of direct negotiation with its adversaries. But most American Jews still could not bring themselves to express public doubts about Prime Minister Begin's grudging response. They have feared diluting their political influence in the United States, on which Israeli security depends. They have feared contributing to the pressures on Israel from a Western world obsessed with the need for oil. So they have brooded in private, leaving only some of their leaders to complain to Mr. Begin behind closed doors.

title: Screen: Episodes From Drug Culture:Montreal Commune
description: "THE RUBBER GUN" is being advertised as "a strange movie, and it certainly is that: It's a drama that feels like a documentary, a series of episodes that at first seem entirely disconnected, a story so steeped in drug culture that it's hard to tell the characters' lucid moments from their idle muttersings. Strangest of all, "The Rubber Gun" is a movie that can be enjoyed even when it isn't understandable.The director, Allan Moyle, whose film was part of the Museum of Modern Art's New Directors/New Films series last year (it opens today at the Little Carnegie), is as careful to set and sharpen the film's mood as he is reluctant to explain it. His methods are irritating at first, but they are ultimately quite memorable.A prologue to the film introduces the principals, whose real names and screen names are the same, and presents them as Montreal's hippest bunch of drug-smugglers, members of a band that the narrator would very much like to infiltrate. This narrator, played by Mr. Moyle, is a shy sociologist, and his motives at first seem purely professional. But as the film progresses, he becomes more and more enmeshed in, and compromised by, what he sees.The central figure in the communal family Mr. Moyle so admires is an artist, glamourpuss and father hen named Steve Lack. Mr. Lack, who wrote the screenplay with Mr. Moyle and John Laing, and who co-produced the movie, presents himself as a young, high-adrenaline jokester, and his delivery is successful enough to make even the slangy or half-audible lines sound funny.But Mr. Lack also has his serious side, a side that is concerned with the commune's disintegration. The film means to use this family's breakup as a way of encapsulating the end of an era, and that's too tall an order. But it does succeed in careening unexpectedly from drug-haze episodes to important clashes of ethics and temperament, and Mr. Moyle's direction never turns maudlin or cute.Instead, his style suggests the probing and grittinss of John Cassavetes's films. Mr. Moyle's work is less passionate than Mr. Cassavetes's, but also a bit more crisp. In both cases, for every glowing moment there are a fair share of flat ones. And the technique is often much more overpowering than the material to which it is applied.

description: Annetta Herbert Rueff, a former Ziegfeld Follies beauty, died Saturday at the Mary Manning Walsh Home. She was 87 years old and had lived for many years at 102 East 22d Street.

title: JERSEY CITY MAYOR CITES WESTWAY FLOODING PERIL
description: Mayor Thomas F. X. Smith of Jersey City said yesterday that he is considering seeking an injunction against construction of the Westway because the landfill needed for the project on the Manhattan side of the Hudson River might cause flooding in New Jersey.

title: Air Force Ends Dress Code Police
description: WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP)The Air Force has decided to slop the use of groom troopers, special teams to enforce military dress codes, Representative Les Aspin said today, releasing an Air Force letter that announced the move. The Wisconsin Democrat quoted the letter as saying adherence to dress and appearance standards is an individual and command responsihlilty that may not be delegated to teams.

title: Labor Is the Theme In Brooklyn Church
description: With Victor Gotbaum, the head of New York City's biggest municipal-employee union, as the main preacher, a Brooklyn church yesterday heard sermons on the role of labor.

title: Disputed Practices of Undertakers Are Defended by Some in Business
description: In Manhattan, a workingclass family paid an undertaker $750 in advance for the funeral of a terminally ill daughter. After she died, the undertaker demanded $300 more and threatened not to bury the body until the family paid up. The funeral was conducted only after an assistant state attorney general, Theodore E. Garrison, reminded the undertaker that holding up a funeral under such circumstances was a violation of the state's Public Health Law.

title: PublicIssues Center Questions E.D.A.'s Job Figures
description: TRENTON. Apri1 23A nonprofit organization that studies government in New Jersy saw. in the current issue of its rnagaz n,g that the State Economic Developmta Authorify has been overstating its sucess in creating new jobs in the state.

title: Man Killed in crash of Small Plane
description: BENOIT, Miss., April 23 (AP)Donald Roegner, 56 years old, of Carlisle, Ark., was killed in the crash of a Cessna 172 after it clipped power lines upon takeoff from an airstrip here, the authorities in Bolivar County said today. They said Dennis Glover, 27, of Carlisle, and Ernest Kestler, 21, of North Little Rock, Ark., were in fair condition at Delta Medical Center in Greenville. It was not known which of the three was the pilot.

title: Budget Problems Could Forestall Sales of National Forest Timber
description: WASHINGTON, April 23President Carter's suggestion that the rising cost of housing might be held in check by cutting more timber in the national forests brought cheers from the Forest Service and the timber industry, concern from the conservationists and questions trom the Office of Management and Budget.

title: De Broca's 'Detective' On Screen
description: ANTOINE LEMERCIER (Philippe Noiret) is a professor of Greek at the Sorbonne. He is portly, fond of good food, middle-aged and a confirmed bachelor with a deep if wandering interest in pretty women as playthings. He also has a twinkle in his eye. Lise Tanquerelle (Ann Girardot) is a pretty divorce, with a pretty young daughter, a pretty, youngish mother and a pretty youngish aunt, and they all live together in a pretty sylvan cottage that seems to be in the center of a very pretty Paris. Lise, who is a detective with the Paris police, also has a twinkle in her eye.If Philippe De Broca's "Dear Detective" does nothing else (and it doesn't), it proves that so much prettiness can be poisonous and that two twinkles are one too many for any movie not intended to make the viewer throw up."Dear Detective," which opens today at the Sutton Theater, tries too hard to be pleasant. It has the manner of someone who grovels at one's feet. One's first reaction is not to smile but to kickwhich is the way I've felt about all of Mr. De Broca's recent films. There's nothing inherently wrong with pleasant movies except when they are as relentlessly phony as his have been."Dear Detective" pretends to be a comedy sympathetic to a liberated woman, the female detective, but it attempts to get most of its laughs by such things as having her worry about her hair, chase a suspected murderer with curlers still in place and deal with the professor's outrage when he learns she's a cop.Though Miss Girardot and Mr. Noiret have given fine performances in the past, neither has a single redeeming moment in this failed farce. Even glorious Notre Dame Cathedral, which the characters frequently drive, run or walk past, looks as if it had been baked in a bad ptisserie.

title: Iona Relays: All Strategy?; Miss Roland Wins Run
description: CHICAGO, April 23 (UPI)Beverly Roland of Peoria, Ill., a junior at Western Illinois University, defeated 3,000 competitors today in a 10,000meter race. Running under threatening skies, gusty winds and in cool temperatures, Miss Roland, 21 years old, finished with a time of 37 minutes 10 seconds. Kim Merritt, of Racine, Wis., the fourth woman to finish in the Boston Marathon last week was second, 30 seconds behind Miss Roland.

title: Fighting Inflation at 30,000 Feet
description: The Senate gave President Carter's antiinflation effort a boost last week when it approved his airline deregulation plan by an 83-to-9 margin. Speedy passage of the bill in the House is not assured, however. Airline and union interests, opposed to any change in the status quo, have so far managed to keep it parked in committee.

title: Mikus, 15, Takes A.A.U. Gym Title
description: HEMPSTEAD, L.I., April 23Fifteenyearold Jim Mikus of Reading, Pa., the smallest finalist, standing just feet, won the National Amateur Athletic Union men's allround junior gymnastci championship today,

title: Indonesia Trying to Restore Its Relations With China
description: JAKARTA, IndonesiaThe nonaligned and insular Indonesians main concern in foreign policy is to, normalize their frozen relations with China while insuring that Peking will not attempt to utilize the overseas Chinese minority to subvert President Suharto's Government.

title: Lynn Fontanne, at 90, Talks of Love
description: EVERYBODY called them the Lunts, and they were probably the greatest husband-andwife acting team the American theater has ever known, dominating the stage for nearly four decades. Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontannebrilliant, glamorous, inseparable, the epitome of the happily married couple.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 24, 1978

title: From Urban Renewal to Urban Action
description: Federal urban aid to build luxury hotels? That's one of the improbable highlights of the first Urban Development Action Grants made by the Department of Housing and Urban Development. The $400 million program provides funds for rehabilitating depressed urban areas. The luxury hotels, centerpieces of 14 of the 50 grants, have rekindled a controversy dating back to urban renewal: Should Federal aid be used to rebuild languishing central business districts or be devoted exclusively deteriorating neighborhoods? Given the precarious fiscal condition of cities, the choice should be clear. However critical the need to save neighborhoods, the longterm survival of citiesand their neighborhoodsdepends on the vitality of their economies.

title: Lebanese Christians and Moslems Agree on Several Major Issues
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 23Christian and Moslem political leaders reached an agreement todayCC that the Government says may help restore stability in Lebanon.

title: McAdoo, McGinnis: 2 Unhappy Players
description: In different locker rooms, in self-imposed isolation, two $500,000-a-year basketball players dressed silently at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

description: BISTRO BEAT Cabaret devotees are in for some surprises early this week, especially if they have been keeping a sharp eye on activities in modern dance and network television.

title: Casino Hotel Planners Rebuffed In W orld Hunt for Building Funds
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 23Stymied by the reluctance of United States banks and other lending institutions to invest in casinos, companies planning multimilliondollar casing hotels here have been avidly seeking foreign Investors to help finance their projects.

title: $40,000 in Clothing Stolen From Hilton
description: A young man who masqueraded as an assistant to a group of London fashion designers staying at the New York Hilton Hotel was being sought yesterday for the theft of designer clothing worth $40,000.

title: Earrings: Light and Airy
description: There's nothing conventional about the light airy gold earrings Kristin Moore designs. Some of them are simply threaded through the pierced ear and held in place by gravity. When a fastening is provided, as insurance rather than necessity, it forms part of the design. And, except in the case of the plainest hoops, there's a right and a left. The swept back, for instance, is a 19karat tendril intended as an extension of the hair, yet women invariably try it on facing forward, connecting with the chin line.

title: Major New York Banks Report Strong Rise in 3Month Profits
description: Many of New .York's big banking companies, in contrast to their results Of previous quarters. have reported strong earnings increases for the first three months of 1978.

title: Firebombings in Italy
description: MILAN, Italy, April 23. (Reuters)Five showrooms of the Italian Alfa Romeo oar company were firebombed here last night, the police said today.

title: New Questions On Carter Zeal For Cities Plan
description: Less than a month after the announce ment of the Administration's urban'policy, advocates of a vigorous and creative approach to the cites; having swallowea some of their disappointment with the program, are becoming concerned about recent clues to the Admihistration's attittide toward it. Although unusually circumspect in their comments to the press, both because of admonitions against loose talk delivcred'at Camp David last week and beoause.of an unwillingnessto jeopardize the program in Congress; some of those advocates think they detect signs OrlimitedWhite House enthusiasm.

title: Boxing: Page Captures A.A.U. Heavyweight Title
description: BILOXI, Miss., April 23 (UPI)Greg Page defeated Tony Tubbs for the sixth time in seven matches last night. to win the Amateur Athletic Union heavyweight boxing title.

Funeral, Tuesday, 9:15 AM, from the McLaughlin & Sons Colonial Home, Third Ave. at 97 St., Brooklyn. Mass of the Resurrection, 9:45 AM, St. Patrick's Church.

title: Golf: Player Wins 3d in Row
description: HOUSTON, April 23 (AP)  Gary Player worked his Sunday magic again today, rallying from a fiveshot deficit and winning his third consecutive American golf tour victory, this time in the Houston open.

description: ALBANY, April 24Jane P. Gilman, an upstate lawyer, today joined the swelling ranks of those seeking the Republican nomination for State Attorney General and promised an unorthodox campaign.

title: Assembly Panel Blocks Bill Giving Police Right to Order Blood Tests
description: TRENTON, April 24A bill that would allow police to order blood and urine tests on unconscious motorists was blocked in its initial State Assembly test today after opponents questioned its constitutionality.

title: Market Place
description: State laws governing corporations have long been belittled by reformers as ineffectual. Many reformers have been clamoring for a Federal corporation statute for major public corporations.

title: F. T. C. BARS CURBS BY COR AND PEPSI
The Editorial Notebook
Erie's Only Cab Service Ends
description: ERIE, Pa., April 24 (AP)The city's only cab company has gone out of business, blaming decreasing ridership and increased fuel and insurance costs. The Yellow Cab Company stopped service last night, idling 115 fulltime and parttime employees. Russell Robison, the owner, said the company was for sale.

title: Parks Supervisors Are Shifted in Move To Aid Productivity
description: Parks Commissioner Gordon J. Davis yesterday announced the transfer of 29 foremen and general foremen, putting poor performers into jobs where they will have to perform or else, and moving good performers to positions of higher visibility where there are more critical tasks, he said.

title: Proudfoot to Head Schlitz Marketing
description: The Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company, beset by intense competitive pressures in the beer industry, yesterday announced the appointment of the CocaCola Company's top United States marketing executive, Allin W. Proudfoot, as executive vice president for marketing.

title: Health Officials Give Holism a Checkup
description: WASHINGTON, April 24  A couple of years ago, it wasn't likely that any Government health official who wanted to be taken seriously would have darkened the doorway of a conference that offered music, touch and imagery as health methods and that opened with an eclectic blessing by a rabbi, an Indian medicine woman and a Chinese lion dancing troupe.

title: U.S. and Soviet Said to Resolve A Key Issue Blocking Arms Pact
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The United States and the Soviet Union have virtually resolved one of the three key issues blocking a new strategic arms agreement, but have made only limited progress so far on two other more difficult questions, American reporters were told today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. on SouthWest Africa. Listed to speak in general debate; Panama, Soviet Union, Tanzania, Canada, Jordan, Surinam, Guyana, Philippines, Rumania, India, Malta, Egypt, Austria, Brazil, Congo.

title: Lone Cry Wins Rights for Retarded
Labor Reported Relaxing Stance On City Accord
description: In the first movement in three weeks in New York City's collective bargaining, people close to the labor side said yesterday that the unions were willing to negotiate a contract that gave their members less cash than transit workers recently won.

title: Arafat Said to Heal Palestinian Split
description: BEIRUT. Lebanon, April 24Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, has overcome a flareup of dissension within Al Fatah, the principal guerrilla movement, according to Palestinian sources.

description: Jacques Lon Rueff, the distinguished French economist, died Sunday at his home in Paris. He was SI years old.

title: Organ Recital Demonstrates Classic Style
description: The undying though usually vain, hope that something unexpected will happen gives live concerts an appeal that recordings can never match. Every performance is, in a sense, a highwire act and the artist who does not at least appear to be taking chances leaves his end of the bargain unfulfilled. However, the kind of chancetaking that genuine improvisation represents began disappearing from classical music early in the last century, when the composer and the performer began to be separate people, and it survives now only in a few welldefended pockets.

title: Mighty Gents Closes
description: The Mighty Gents, a play by Richard Wesley about the adult survivors of a Newark street gang, which opened April 17 at the Ambassador Theater, closed Sunday after nine performances.

title: TERRORISTS IN ITALY OFFER TO EXCHANGE MORO FOR 13 IN JAIL
description: ROME, April 24The terrorists who kidnapped Ald6 Moro published a list today of 13 prison inmates they said must be released by Italian authorities in exchange for the freedom of the former Prime Minister. The Government ruled out such an exchange.

title: TIME INC, TO REVIVE LIFE AS A MONTHLY
description: Life, the weekly picture magazine that suspended publication in 1972, will be revived as a monthly magazine in October, Time Inc. announced yesterday.

title: Ottawa Paper Fails to Publish
description: OTTAWA, April 24 (UPI)The sevenmonthold (tabloid Ottawa Today did not publish today. Robert Essery, the publisher and executive editor, denied that the newspaper had folded but said there were financial problems.

title: PANEL FINDS NO COVERUP IN DISMISSAL OF MARSTON
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)Representative Joshua Eilberg, Democrat of Pennsylvania, was not under investigation when he called President Carter and asked him to dismiss David W. Marston as United States Attorney in Philadelphia, the Senate Judiciary Committee said today.

title: Dollar Steady in Europe
description: The dollar held steady against most currencies in foreign exchange trading in New York and overseas yesterday but climbed sharply against the yen, The Associated Press reported.

description: Pan American World Airways announced yesterday that it had reached an agreement to buy the 45 percent interest in its headquarters building that held by the estate of Erwin S. Wolfson. The purchase would give the airline company full ownership of the Pan Am Building.

description: DENVER, April 24Frank T. Cary, chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, reported today that I.B.M. now has the largest backlog of orders in its history and expects to add 10,000 people to its manufacturing divisions.

Haig Jr., the commander of North Atlantic Treaty forces, threatened to resign recently over the Carter Administration's handling of several defense issues, including the decision to defer production of the neutron bomb, according to Government sources.

description: Whoever presumes to write the history of 20thcentury music will have to deal, somehow, with John Cage. And perhaps one way of approaching that delightful but tricky subject will be to consider him as a concept rather than as a composer in any traditional sense.

title: No Dates for Garden State
description: HAMILTON TOWNSHIP, N.J., April 24The Garden State Park Racing Association was left without any racing dates for the year today when Atlantic City Race Course dropped plans for financial reasons to stage any Garden State days during its meet scheduled to start June 1.
