description: NEW DELHI, April 24Prime Minister Morarji R. Desai today criticized the decision last week of the United States Nuclear Regulatory Agency to block a shipment of enriched uranium fuel for the Americanbuilt Tarapur atomic power plant near Bombay.

title: News Agencies' Work Assailed at UNESCO Session
description: STOCKHOLM, April 24 (AP)Delegates to a UNESCO meeting on the flow of world news disagreed sharply today on how international news agencies cover developing nations and how their reporting could be improved.

title: TOUCHE BROKERAGE AUDIT IS RULED SUBJECT TO SUIT
description: In a decision that may broaden the legal liability of public accounting firms, a Federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled yesterday that Touche Ross & Company could be sued for its auditing of Weis Securities Inc., a defunct brokerage house.

title: Taking On Tower
description: ALICE, Tex.The heavens opened here the other night and, despite a wild thunderstorm that came with the rain, just about everybody in parched South Texas was pleased. One dejected exception was Chuck Barrcra, a leader in the MexicanAmerican community, who had worked for a week and a half to arrange a big rally and barbecue for Representative Bob Krueger.

In fact, Federal officials have delayed acting on a request for mortgage insurance, which would enable the needed construction funds In be raised in the private financial market.

title: GOING OUT  Guide
description: ALIVE AGAIN Having scored a hit last season with their revival of Elmer Rice's CounselloratLaw, the Quaigh Theater tonight is bringing back another famed drama of the Depression era, Sidney Kingsley's Dead End. This is an ambitious project for the Off Broadway company, with a cast of 32 players under the direction of Will Lieberson. Performances are Tuesday through Sunday through May 7 in the company showcase at the Diplomat Hotel, 108 West 43d Street (opposite Town Hall). Tickets (2219088) are $3.

title: Lower Fares Sought By National Airlines
description: National Airlines yesterday asked the Civil Aeronautics Board to approve a revised tare plan that would offer a new class of service and cut the price of the cheapest seat by 30 percent to 50 percent. Firstclass seat fares would also be reduced.

title: Oilers Acquire Top Draft Pick: Name Campbell
description: Earl Campbell will be drafted by the Houston Oilers as the opening selection in the National Football League's annual draft of college players next Tuesday. That determination was made yesterday when the Tampa Bay Buccaneers traded the first cnoice to the Oilers in exchange for Houston's first and secondround picks, Jimmy Giles, a starter at tight end, and the Oilers third and fifthround choices in the 1979 draft.

description: WASHINGTON, April 24The burning of pulverized coal to produce a jet of hot gas powerful enough to drive a turbine may someday become a major source of the nation's energy. Such fluidized bed combustion could also generate steam and drive additional turbines.

description: When most people think of boxers, they still think of Muhammad Ali; when boxing people think of boxers, they think of Roberto Duran, punch for punch the best boxer the world today.

description: DENVER, April 24 (AP)John Evans Sr., former president of the First National Bank and grandson of a Colorado territorial governor, died yesterday. He was 93 years old.

title: FIRSTCLASS STAMPS MAY NOT BEAR PRICE
description: WASHINGTON, April 24The United States Postal Service, surprised by a tentative decision of the Postal Rate Commission to authorize a 15cent stamp for letters, may resort to a stamp without a price on it when the postal rates change, postal officials, acknowledged today.

description: CHICAGO, April 24 (AP) Feminists appear to take the sexual initiative more frequently and get more sexual satisfaction than women with more traditional outlooks, a Vanderbilt University study has indicated.

title: News Summary
description: Aldo Moro's kidnappers demanded the release of 13 prisoners in exchange for the freedom of Italy's former Prime Minister. The Government flatly rejected the exchange. Mr. Moro, meanwhile, sent an impassioned plea to colleagues in the Christian Democratic Party to save his life by agreeing to an exchange of prisoners of war or guerrilla prisoners, if you like. His appeal, published in a Rome newspaper, asserted that We are almost at zero hour, seconds rather than minutes from the end. We are at the moment of slaughter. [Page 1, Column 1.1

title: SBHU Declines to Confirm or Deny Reports of Allstate Investment Plan
description: SBHU Holdings Inc. declined yesterday to confirm or deny reports that the Allstate Insurance Company, a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Company, was planning a sizable capital investment in, SBHU Holdings, parent of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, the New York securities firm.

title: U.S. Attorney Will Sue Criminals For Damages in a New Program
description: NEWARK, April 24 (UPI)United States Attorney Robert Del Tufo wants whitecollar criminals to pay back their illgotten gains.

title: United Technologies Reports 15.6% Gain in FirstQuarter Profit
description: The United Technologies Corporation reported a firstquarter profit gain of 15.6 percent on a sales increase of 8.2 percent.

title: 7 Auto Club Officials Killed
description: Seven officials of the United States Auto Club were killed in an airplane crash in Indiana. They were en route to Indianapolis from Sunday's race in Trenton. Among those killed was Frank DelRoy, the chairman of USAC's technical committee. Details, Page 18.

title: To Stop Subsidizing Repression
description: The House Banking Committee votes tomorrow on legislation to end all activities of the ExportImport Bank in South Africa. It should express its approval, and so should the full House. Although the proposed measure is not of great economic significance, it is one more step toward getting the American taxpayer out of the business of subsidizing South Africa's system of racial repression.

title: Sex Objects Finish Last
description: In their original forth, women's movies made women in the audience weep and men snore. In the end the woman got the man. He was usually George Brent. Brent was a natty dresser with natty hair and a natty mustache. Though he seemed vaguely engaged in one of the uptown professionslaw, medicine, architecturethe real point of his existence was to be got in the end.

title: Berkowitz Is Judged Competent
description: David R. Berkowitz, accused of being the .44caliber killer, was found mentally competent yesterday to stand trial in the murder last July 31 of 20yearold Stacy Moskowitz and the attempted murder of her companion, Robert Violante.

title: Dispute Imperils Research Projects at Berkeley
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 24A dispute over confidentiality between the University of California at Berkeley and Federal civil rights investigators threatens to cut off Federal financing for hundreds of research projects.

title: SOLARZ DEFENDS 16 TRIPS TO 41 LANDS AS VALUABLE
description: WASHINGTON, April 24Representative Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, who has taken 16 overseas trips to 41 countries in a little more than three years, according to official Congressional reports, said today that the Governmentpaid trips were valuable factfinding missions.

title: Jury Weighs Case of Doctor Accused in Infant's Death
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., April, 24After 14 weeks of testimony and a judge's admonition that murder can be committed by an act of omission, jurors today began deliberating the fate of Dr. William Waddill Jr., who is accused of killing an infant born after an unsuccessful saline abortion.

title: Rabbi Benjamin Schultz, Crusader Against Communist Infiltration
description: Rabbi Benjamin Schultz, the executive director of the American Jewish League Against. Communism from 1948 until its demise in 1960, died Saturday of a stroke at his home in Clarksdale, Miss.

description: It is strange enough these days for a government to shoot at an unarmed passenger plane, no matter how bizarre its flight pattern. It is even stranger, however, for the Soviet Union, having done so, to offer riot a word of explanation, accusation or regret four days after the incident.

description: An economist who has studied governmental financing of the arts contended yesterday that the National Endowment for the Arts had stumbled from one set of accidental decisions to another, thrown some money away and transformed arts activities in undesirable ways.

description: The Mets returned to New York last night for the first real test of the seasonsix games against the Pittsburgh Pirates and the Cincinnati Redsand promptly inflicted a series of injuries on themselves in the late innings of their opening performance, a 42 loss to the Pirates.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Eight dresses by the designer David Sassoon, part of his collection of 50 that was stolen Saturday by a man who had helped unload then, at the New York Hilton Hotel, were returned. A woman, who said she had bought the eight designs in the street for $500 brought them in when she heard they had been stolen. She was reimbursed by group of British designers who had offered to pay ransom for the return of the dresses.

title: WAC Directorship to Be Abolished
description: WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)Clifford Alexander Jr., Secretary of the Army. announced today that he was abolishing the directorship of the Women's Army Corns. The action follows a statement in which Defense Secretary Harold Brown told Congress that women had become full partners in our national defense and required no separate organization within the military. title: Notes on People

Mr. Foldes's appearances were a milestone in the current relaxation of Chinese policy concerning the arts, including renewed acceptance of Western classical music, which was banned in China for ideological reasons from 1966 until last year. Mr. Foldes is the first prominent American pianist who is known to have appeared in China in recent years. He played works by Europeans including Beethoven, who was until recently dismissed in Peking as merely a German capitalist composer.

title: Film: Chaplin Biography:'Gentleman Tramp'
description: "THE GENTLEMAN TRAMP," opening today at the New Yorker and other theaters, is an authorized documentary devoted to the life of Charlie Chaplin. The film, which was made sometime before the great man's death last year, carries the information that "every frame, from rough cut to final version, has been checked and approved personally by Charles Chaplin." Like all authorized biographies, it's somewhat too pious for its own good humor.The film was directed, written and edited by Richard Patterson, who worked with Peter Bogdanovich on the 1972. Oscar salute to Chaplin, footage of which is the true climax of the picture. Most of the film is devoted to scenes (many splendid ones) taken from 17 Chaplin comedies, including "City Lights," "The Gold Rush," "Modern Times" and "The Kid."There's an attempt to recapitulate highlights of Chaplin's lifeboth good times and badwith newsreel footage, as well as with still photographs, some of which are accompanied by lofty quotations from Chaplin's book, "My Autobiography." The quotations, read by Laurence Olivier, come off worse on film than they do on the printed page: "In Philadelphia I discovered Emerson," says Chaplin, meaning, I suppose, Ralph Waldo. As in "My Autobiography," there's also a good deal of nameor photographdropping, to prove that Charlie hobnobbed with swells of his time, including Lloyd George, Winston Churchill and George Bernar Shaw.Some of the film is dreadful, as when we hear a gossip-columnist, who sounds like Hedda Hopper, as she attacks Charlie, but a lot of the comedy footage is still fun, even if out of context. The nicest moments, though, are the home movies in which we see the elderly Charlie and his wife, Oona. They seem to have been a truly happy couple.

title: Film: Scorsese and the Band:Final Fling
description: MARTIN SCORSESE had the makings of a better-than-average concert movie at his disposal when he made "The Last Waltz," but the film is full of evidence that Mr. Scorsese had something more ambitious in mind. One exquisitely edited sequence of the Band performing "The Weight," filmed on a soundstage by cameras that sway and rotate with the music, infuses the interaction of a rock band with more joy and lyricism than any other rock film has ever approached. A guest appearance at the concert by the singer Van Morrison, now paunchy and balding but triumphantly galvanizing just the same, makes for a moment rich with both euphoria and regret.Mr. Scorsese's decision to train his cameras more closely on the musicians' faces than on their instruments leads to an unexpected examination of the physical and emotional costliness of their craft, and of the element of acting that's an integral part of any kind of live performance. Indeed, Mr. Scorsese manages to turn Rick Danko, the Band's bassist, into a veritable double for one of the director's favorite actors, Robert De Niro."The Last Waltz," which opens today at the Ziegfeld Theater, is Mr. Scorsese's record of a 1976 Thanks-giving concert given by the Bandand several of their most famous friends, like Joni Mitchell, Neil Young, Muddy Waters, Eric Clapton and Bob Dylanto mark the group's farewell to live performing.However definite the show's raison d'tre may have been, though, its spirit remains strangely ambiguous. Members of the Band, interviewed by Mr. Scorsese afterward in footage that is interspersed among the songs, speak about the performance almost noncommittally, and their offhandedness is contagious.If this wasn't a particularly sad or celebratory occasion for them, it can't mean much to the viewer either, unless the one approaches the film with a full set of memories of the principals in better days. A peculiarly myopic view of the aging process is also required, if one is to find "The Last Waltz" unusually stirring. The life of a rock star may be more draining than the life of a Maytag repairman, but when the film tries to milk too much from every last sign of wear and tear, it comes dangerously close to self-importance and self-pity.One of the Band's most fascinating idiosyncrasies has always been its combination of a strong group identity with the virtual anonymity of individual members. The group identity has also been powerfully visual, reinforced by album-cover photographs that make the musicians out to be woodsy and austere, so deliberately antiquated looking that they summon up an impression of simpler times."The Last Waltz" takes pains to introduce them as individuals, in interviews that are slack at times but occasionally very winning. Other group members explain, for instance, that in their early days the bashful organist Garth Hudson demanded $10 a week from each of them, ostensibly for music lessons. Only later, they realized that the classically trained Mr. Hudson was too embarrassed to tell his family he was working as a rock-and-roller, and was instead claiming to have found a few teaching jobs.The interviews are uneven, but their function is to amplify. On the other hand, the setting for the concertan elegant stage backed by drapes and candelabra  is mightily incongruous with the Band's group identity, and the mismatch is more disruptive than illuminating. A guest appearance by the very Las Vegasy Neil Diamond, one of whose albums was recently produced by the Band's leader, Robbie Robertson, is so jarring and unwelcome that the movie takes minutes to recover. And Mr. Scorsese's efforts to stir up a distinct visual style for the film, a style that might somehow have compensated for the curious lack of sentiment that marks all but the film's final half-hour, are so half-hearted and sporadic they become almost maddening.Just think of the rich visual eloquence with which Mr. Scorsese was able to invest a simple Checker cab in "Taxi Driver," and just notice that all he supplies here are a waltzing couple behind the credits and some smoke clouds. Given that, you can't help realizing that for all its impressive musical accomplishments, "The Last Waltz" is a great lost opportunity. There is a dazzling array of talent on display here, and the film surely has its memorable moments. But it articulates so little of the end-of-an-era feeling it hints atand some of Mr. Scorsese's accomplishments have been so stunningthat it's impossible to view "The Last Waltz" as anything but an also-ran.

title: Next Head of Queens College
description: By the time he takes over the presidency of Queens College in July, Dr. Saul Bernard Cohen says, he hopes to have mapped out a strategy that will help not only Queens College, but all the senior colleges of the City University, to get a larger share of state funds. The 52yearold Massachusetts geographereducator was selected for the job over a veteran member of the Queens faculty, a move that was interpreted by many students and some faculty members to signal a weakening of the college's ability to keep its distinguished academic position in the university and perhaps also of the university's determination to maintain high standards despite limited spending power.

title: Screen: 'F.I.S.T.,' Drama of Unionism:Stallone Returns
description: OF ALL THE STORIES of organized labor, the most fascinatingperhaps because it seems the most Americanhas been the rise to power and affluence of the corruption-riddled International Brotherhood of American Teamsters, whose one-time president, James Hoffa, disappeared in 1975 and is now presumed to have been the victim of a one-way ride ordered by his sometime gangland associates.Using material freely drawn from the Hoffa story, as well as from the recent history of the United Mine Workers of America, the director Norman Jewison has made "F.I.S.T.," a pop epic that covers 30 crucial years in the life of the fictitious Federation of Inter-State Truckers, from feeble beginnings to its emergence as an organization as powerful and corrupt as any of the industries it did business with."F.I.S.T.," which opens today at the Cinerama 1 and 2 and at other theaters, doesn't run especially deep but it runs long and, more important, it runs wide. It presents in the form of a diorama the story of F.I.S.T. from its origins in idealism and compromise, through its early successes, to the point in the late 1950's when a Senate committee, much like the one headed by the late Senator John L. McClellan, brought the nation's attention to bear on the union's extraordinary wealth, to the quixotic way in which that wealth was administered, and to its widespread underworld connections.Specialists in the history of the Teamsters may not be particularly pleased with "F.I.S.T." Being movie fiction aimed at the mass market, it sets its early scenes in the depressed 30's, with all of the poor-boy clichs so dear to hearts of movie makers. The central character, that of Johnny Kovak, is played by Sylvester Stallone with a combination of brute power and arrogance that are convincing, but with little of the shrewdness, charm and murderous cynicism that made Jimmy Hoffa so successful and such popular copy for so many years. Mr. Stallone's Johnny Kovak is a rat who's all heart.Yet once "F.I.S.T." disposes of the obligatory exposition that is the opening section of the picture, it becomes a compelling demonstration of a kind of power manipulation that is as integral to big capital as it is to big labor. The movie, which pictures the Depression in the golden glow of something sweetly remembered (as did "Bound for Glory"), becomes increasingly tough as it gains momentum and, at the end, genuinely tragic, not because of the fate of Johnny Kovak but because of the social and political implications. If this system doesn't work, which one will?The screenplay, written by Joe Eszterhas and Mr. Stallone, based on a story by Mr. Eszterhas, is not great. There is, for example, a key scene early-on, in which we are supposed to be witness to the manner by which Johnny Kovak mesmerizes the union brotherhood, yet the speech itself simply isn't very rousing. We may not believe the way Johnny works his way to the top, yet the machinations by which he consolidates his power and exercises it brings the movie to real life."F.I.S.T." is a big movie that benefits more from the accumulation of small, ordinary detail than from any particular wit or inspiration of vision. It's also played with great conviction by its huge cast.There's never any doubt that Mr. Stallone is the star, but the other actors Mr. Jewison has collected are not overwhelmed by the Stallone mannerisms.Chief among these are Melinda Dillon as the Lithuanian sewing-machine girl Johnny Kovak courts and marries; David Huffman as his boyhood friend, a fellow who shares Johnny's rise to the top but refuses to compromise; Tony Lo Bianco as the mobster who makes Johnny's earlier successes possible and who stays around to collect his debts; Kevin Conway as another boyhood friend who provides Johnny with his introduction to the mob, and Peter Boyle as the crooked F.I.S.T. president Johnny eventually succeeds.They're all excellent. Even Rod Steiger, whose recent performances have not been memorable, makes us pay attention to the crusading senator whose mission to expose crooked union practices may or may not be for the highest of motives. The vanity is always visible.Like "Fiddler on The Roof," "Jesus Christ Superstar" and "Rollerball," Mr. Jewison's last three films, "F.I.S.T." is a massive, essentially shapeless film, but because it's about a terrifically interesting, complicated subject, shapeliness doesn't seem especially important. There's not a moment in it to compare with the intensity of feelings contained in such documentaries as "Union Maids" and "Harlan County, U.S.A.," yet it's encouraging to hear Hollywood talking about such things at a time when play-it-safe is virtually industry policy."F.I.S.T.," which has been rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), contains some vividly accurate scenes of labor violence and some mildly vulgar language.

title: Books of The Times
description: IDON'T KNOW how I have kept my innocence all these years, but I was surprised to find that George Eliot, or Mary Ann Evans, as she was christened, shared with her commonlaw husband a moral coarseness and emotional vulgarity. Surely not the author of Middlemarch, Adam Bede and Silas Marner? These phrases, which sound as if they were coined by some envious contemporary of Miss Evans, belong instead to Marghanita Laski, author of George Eliot and Her World.

title: Model School Desegregation Plan In Dallas Is Upset by Appeals Court
description: DALLAS, April 25The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit has rejected the studentassignment section of a twoyearold school desegregation plan that had been viewed by districts around the country as a model for desegregation with minimal busing.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Some time ago, in an article on growing mushrooms in Kennett Square, Pa., the mushroom capital of the world, you made no mention of the fact that packaged in plastic fresh mushrooms are treated with a preservative known as sodium bisulfate to retard spoilage. Are all mushrooms treated with this?

title: PRESIDENT DEFENDS PROPOSAL TO REDUCE TAXES BY $25 BILLION
Kibbee Is Criticized By Rejected Candidate
description: Dr Nathaniel Siegel, who lost out Monday night in a bid to become president of Queens College, was sharply critical yesterday of the City University administration.

title: Lobbyists Lobbying Against a Bill Aimed at Lobbyists
description: WASHINGTON, April 25This afternoon on Capitol Hill messengers delivered two sets of letters to all members of Congress. One was signed by the Chamber of Commerce, the other by 13 environmental groups, but these odd allies were both conveying the same message. They were asking Congressmen to vote tomorrow against a bill that would require lobbyists to register with the Government and disclose many of their activities.

title: Grain and Soybean Futures Rally
description: CHICAGO, April 25 (AP)Grain and soybean futures raffled sharply today, partly in reaction to severe losses a day earlier. A pickup in export demand and rumors that Brazil might sharply cut its soybean crop estimate also stimulated buying.

title: Fed Expects Inflation Surge, Lets Interest Rates Rise
Northern and Southern Leaders Shun Fight Over U.S. Funds
description: WASHINGTON, April 25Gov. George Busbee of Georgia and Representative Michael J. Harrington, Democrat of Massachusetts, the leaders of rival factions in the economic competition between Sun Belt and Snow Belt states, announced today a cooperative effort to avoid a second Civil War over allocation of Federal funds.

title: Mrs. Hilson and Mr. Cronkite Anchor a Party
description: Mildred Hilson said she wasn't a bit excited  scared stiff would be more like it. So the evening was a tribute to her, but it was too, a charity benefit, and embarrassing wouldn't be the word if most of the people who bought tickets didn't even know her.

title: Announcement Welcomed at U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 25The five Western members of the Security Council today welcomed South Africa's acceptance of their joint proposals on SouthWest Africa.

title: Germans Offered Family Loans
description: MUNICH, West Germany, April 25 (Reuters)The Bavarian state government approved a program today to give a couple a $2,500 government loan as an inducement to get married and another on the birth of their first child. The program is designed to counter West Germany's decreasing birth rate, which is the lowest of any of the world's major countries.

title: Sell Bikers Island
description: On its face, it sounds like a proposal for an urban rummage sale: that New York City, financially beset, should sell or lease the cluster of jail buildings on Rikers Island to the state. But it is not a frivolous notion, not just another effort to save Boardwalk by peddling Mediterranean and Baltic Avenues. It is a proposal that would benefit all involved.

title: LEE JOHNSON, 741 DIES
description: Lee S. Johnson, a former president of the Sikorsky Aircraft division of the United Aircraft Corporation, died Sunday in Bridgeport Hospital in Connecticut of complications resulting from a fall at his winter home in Key Largo, Fla., in February. He lived in Fairfield, Conn., and was 74 years old.

title: Hollander Urges Tougher Standards for Teachers
description: TRENTON, April 25New Jersey's Chancellor of Higher Education, Dr. T. Edward Hollander, called the state's teach'er requirements trivial today and .recommended that no teacher be certified without some form of graduate study and three years of classroom experience.

title: Carter Rejects Plea To Delay Proposal On Jets for Arabs
description: WASHINGTON, April 25President Carter rejected today a new appeal by Congressional leaders that he indefinitely delay submission of his proposal to sell fighter planes to Saudi Arabia and Egypt as an inseparable part of a $4.8 billion Package also involving Israel.

title: Topics: Facing Facts
description: By announcing, without resort to euphemism, that she is addicted to alcohol, Betty Ford has once again shown her willingness to defy a national convention. The former First Lady, who reportedly has been relying on heavy medication to relieve the pain of arthritis and a pinched nerve, is now under treatment in a special ward of Long Beach Naval Hospital for the rehabilitation of patients addicted to both drugs and alcohol.

title: Bridge:
description: For enthusiasts below the expert rank, playing tournament bridge in North America as distinct from the rest of the world has plusses and minuses. They can play regularly in wellorganized tournaments and accumulate master points, but they hardly ever have the opportunity to face opponents of varied nationalities, languages and cultures.

title: Dance: Parson Weems By Erick Hawkins
description: ERICK HAWKINS has been so successful as a dance pioneer who sought to bring to his own art the spiritual concerns of Asian theater that it is possible to forget that he is an artist with deep roots in American lore.

title: COMPANY BACKS PLAN TO LEAVE MONTREAL
Top Canadian Company Backs Move. From Montreal to Toronto.
A Fair Deal for Micronesia
description: The United States has been under great international pressure to resolve the future status of Micronesia, a United States strategic trust and the last of the postWorld War II United Nations trusteeships. Now, afteralmost a decade of negotiations between Washington and representatives of the Micronesian peoples, an agreement has been reached that seems to meet the needs of both sides. It promises an end to trusteeship in accord with this country's oftstated commitment to human rights.

title: Personal Health
description: PERHAPS the most dramatic testimony to the sexual freedom of the 1970's has been the dramatic rise in the number of Americans afflicted with venereal diseases. Although the reported number of cases of V.D. seems to have peaked in the last few years and now may be slowly declining, gonorrhea  with an estimated 2.5 million cases last year remains by far the nation's most common and costly serious communicable disease, and a companion illness, genital herpes, is still increasing.

title: Too Gentle? Too Harsh?; FOREIGN AFFAIRS
description: CHICAGO  Pirandello would have liked it. I was hijacked by the friendly organizers of a recent international gathering into describing, before an audience including senior members of the Administration, the present sorry European view of Jimmy Carter. After the session a funny thing happened.

title: Eating: From Gatherers to Gourmands
description: PARIS Gourmets, said Baron James de Coquet, are like adventurers who keep digging in hopes of coming up one day with a diamond as big as the Ritz  perfectionists.

title: Ringo TV Special Has 2 Starrs
description: RINGO STARR was away perceived as the most modest and likeable or the Beatlesthe only one who might have preferred a pint of bitter or a gin and lemon to the more exotic substances from which the famous rock quartet came to derive its inspiration.

title: New Hampshire Court Curbs Obscenity Law
description: CONCORD, N.H., April, 25 (UPI)The New Hampshire Supreme Court today ruled that part of the state's obscenity law is unconstitutional, but allowed an obsceniyrelated indictment to stand against a distributor of Penthouse magazine.

title: Playboy Cuts Height of Hotel It Will Build in Atlantic City
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 25 (UPI)The Playboy Company will scale down the height of its Boardwalk casinohotel to 300 feet so it will not be a hazard to owflying aircraft.

title: Brzezinski Remark Stirs Fear of Security Breach.
description: WASHINGTON, April 25A remark by President Carter's national security adviser, Zbigniew Brzezinski, about the South Korean airliner forced down in the Soviet Union, has upset and troubled intelligence specialists who say that Mr. Brzezinski may have breached security.

title: SUPREME COURT BARS HIGHER PENSION COSTS FOR WOMEN THAN MEN
description: WASHINGTON, April 25Although women live longer than men on the average, an employer who charges women more than men to participate in a pension plan is committing illegal sex discrimination, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: IVAN NESTINGEN, 56
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)Ivan A. Nestingen, a former Mayor of Madison, Wis., and later an official in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, collapsed and died yesterday at his desk in his Washington law office. He was 56 years old.

title: Albany Committee Votes Bill Curbing Smoking in Public
description: ALBANY, April 25A bill that would in effect turn the law around by prohibiting smoking in public places except in designated areas has been unanimously voted out of the Assembly's Health Cornmittee, but its future appears uncertain. As the Public Health Law now stands, smoking is permitted except where signs expressly forbid it.

title: Cards Drop Rapp
description: MONTREAL, April 25 (UPI)Vern Rapp was discharged as manager of the St. Louis Cardinals tonight and replaced by a coach, Jack .Krol.

title: SEARCH FOR LAB DOGS CITED BY JASCALEVICH
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., April 25According to a statement read today at his murder trial here, Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich said late In 1966 that although he had not conducted animal experiments for two months he had gone out in search of experimental dogs on the day he had learned that the drug curare had been discovered in his locker at Riverdell Hospital.

title: For White Rhodesia, Pretty Bad and Getting Worse
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 25Last autumn, John Randall told a visitor to the tea estate he managed along Rhodesia's mountainous border with Mozambique that he would leave the country only at the point of a terrorist's gun.

title: F.C.C. Critical of ABC
description: The Federal Communications Corn mission called ABC careless and negligent in its handling of a televised boxing tournament last spring. Page B8.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: WASHINGTON, April 25Conrail, which is to go before Congress tomorrow to appeal for at least $1.3 billion in additional Federal help to balance its books, paid its senior executives $417,000 last year in bonuses and other extra benefits, a Congressman disclosed today.

title: P.L.O. Defies the Lebanese Ban on Arms
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 25The Palestine Liberation Organization said today that it would not disarm its guerrilla groups in Lebanon despite a joint call this week by Lebanese Christian and Moslem leaders for the prohibition of any armed presence other than the country's Iegal forces.

title: Transcript of the President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Matters
description: Before I became President I realized and was warned that dealing with the Federal bureaucracy would be one of the worst problems I would have to face. It's been even worse than I had anticipated.

title: A Business Made To Order, by Mail
description: THERE WAS NO personalized pewterlook door knocker ($4.98), no cocoa fiber mat underfoot saying Mi Casa Es Su Casa ($8.98), no hint that this Sutton Plare address was home to the First Lady of Mail Order Catalogues, until the lady herself appeared at the door.

title: Notes on People
description: ADRESSING pilgrims in Vatican City yesterday, Pope Paul VI deplored what he called the many painful experiences reserved for us by the events of the contemporary world and, today in particular by those in the beloved land of Italy, afflicted by too many episodes of hate and violence. Referring to Aldo Moro, the kidnapped former Italian Prime Minister, without naming him, the Pontiff told his audience of 1,000 Italians, Let our thoughts turn to one who is absent from this gatheringand you know well who that is. The Pope also said that the pilgrims piety inspired him with confidence and optimism.

title: Around the Nation
description: TOLEDO, Ohio, April 25 (UPI)Striking Toledo school employees today violated a court order by refusing to return to work and setting up picket lines at schools.

title: Stage: Early Dark, A Rustics Dreams
description: EARLY in her adolescence, Rosacoke Mustian, the awakening heroine of Reynolds Price's lyrical first novel, A Long and Happy Life, dedicates her love to the idealized image of Wesley Beavers, a plainspoken young rustic whose dreams are bounded by the amount of gasoline in his motorcycle. As we observe the limits of Rosacoke's world, we comprehend the undertow of family, tradition and environment.

title: N.Y.U. Gets Million In Professor's Name
description: The New York University Medical Center has received a $1 million grant from the Coles Foundation to establish a professorship in medicine honoring Dr, Frederick H. King, officials of the medical center said yesterday.

title: Brezhnev Bid Rejected by Carter
description: WASHINGTON, April 25President Carter today rejected a proposal by Leoid I. Brezhnev for a joint ban on neutrcn weapons.

title: Bonds of Bridge Authority Urged To Finance the Convention Center
description: Harold Fisher, chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, said yesterday that he favored the sale of bonds of the Triborough Bridge and Transit Authority to finance construction of a convention center the city planned in the Penn Central yards at 34th Street.

title: U.S. Says Saudis Did Not Supply Weapons of Guerrillas in Lebanon
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)The State Department has said that United Statesmade weapons used by Palestinian guerrillas during Israel's invasion of Lebanon in March were not supplied by Saudi Arabia, as the Israelis asserted.

title: U.S. Cancels Sale of Oil Leases Off the Southern Atlantic Coast
description: WASHINGTON. April 25 (AP)The Interior Department today canceled aproposed sale next year of petroleum leases in a 19millionacre area off the coasts of South Carolina, Georgia and Florida.

title: A Passover Festival At Coney Island Park
description: Astroland at Coney Island, Brooklyn, was turned into a Passover Festival for 10,000 Hasidic Jews for a twoday celebration of the holiday. They took over the park, rode the rides and ate at special Kosher concessions.

title: Acting Head of Alcoholism Agency Is Criticized by Several Groups
description: ALBANY, April 25John R. DeLuca, the Acting Director of the State Division of Alcoholism and Alcohol Abuse, was aegosed today by directors of several alcoholism programs of favoring political allies with grants of state money and of using fear tactics in threatening the rellabilitation programs run by his political adversaries.

title: News Summary
description: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 26, 1978

title: Salisbury Turns Down U.S.British Plan for Meeting
description: SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 25The black and white leaders in Rhodesia's transitional Government today effectively turned down a BritishAmerican proposal for a meeting between themselves and the Patriotic Front, the nationalist alliance that is challenging the Salisbury administration in a guerrilla war.

title: Chess:
Order From Ground Reported
description: MOSCOW, April 25 (AP)A Soviet jet fighter received orders from the ground to shoot at a straying South Korean airliner that ignored all previous signals that it was off course, Soviet sources said today.

title: TIMES CO. EARNINGS UP 32% FOR QUARTER
description: LAKELAND, Fla., April 25Firstquarter earnings of The New York Times Company rose 32 percent on a 19 percent increase in revenues, stockholders attending the annual meeting here were told today.

title: Yankees Set Back Orioles
description: BALTIMORE, April 25The thrill that can come only once in a lifetime to a rookie pitcher came Jim Beattie's way tonight. The lanky righthander earned a victory in his major league debut as the Yankees topped the Orioles, 43, after a tense finish.

title: Dollar Off Abroad, but Firmer in New York
description: The dollar slipped a bit against most major currencies overseas, then firmed a bit here, as foreignexchange dealers in New York, Europe and Asia waited for tomorrow's release of new United States trade statistics, The Associated Press reported:

title: Dividends
description: TUESDAY, APRIL 25, 1978

title: HAROLD A. OGUST, 61, HELD 4 NATIONAL BRIDGE TITLES
description: Harold A. Ogust, a major figure in the world of international contract bridge, died Monday afternoon at the New York Hospital. He was 61 years old and had been suffering from cancer.

title: The Farmer And Pot Cheeses
description: Pot cheese and farmer cheese are in some ways similar to cottage cheese, but basically are different products.

title: Gulf Oil Profit Off Sharply,    Cash Is Greatly Depleted
Lemon of Globetrotters Is Stabbed by His Wife On Street, Police Report
description: Meadowlark Lemon, the clown prince of the Harlem Globetrotters, was stabbed in the back by his wife at 53d Street and Second Avenue yesterday evening as Mr. Lemon was talking to two policemen, the police reported.

title: Wine Talk
description: THERE is a television commercial for Dry Sack sherry in which Frank Gifford, the former professional football star, seeks to convey the idea that drinking sherry is not only enjoyable but virile.

title: Pasta According to Hazan; Recipes for Pasta And Assorted Sauces; Homemade Pasta; Homemade Tonnarelli (A finely cut, squareshaped pasta); Sugo di Canestrelli (Pasta with scallops); Funghi Trifolati (Mushrooms with garlic. oil and parsley); Funghi Trifolati With Pasta; TonnareIli With Rosemary Sauce; Sugo alla Saffi (Penne with ham and asparagus); Salsa ally Cipolle; Pesce al Salmoriglio (Fish steaks with oil and lemon sauce)
description: There is probably not one person in a thousand in this country who knows that the countless sauces destined for pasta cannot, in the classic sense, be used arbitrarily with all pasta regardless of shave. size, color and texture.

title: Pirates Rookie Overcomes Mets by 21
description: As if things weren't bad enough, the Mets suffered the added misfortune last night of running into a 6foot4inch mountain boy with an exceptional fastball who was making his first visit to New York.

title: For White Rhodesia, Pretty Bad and Getting Worse
Badillo's Wife Given A State Job by Carey At $35,000 a Year
description: ALBANY, April 25Governor Carey today announced the appointment of Irma Badillo, the wife of Herman Badillo, Deputy Mayor for Management in New York City, as a new $35,000ayear special assistant.

title: ALBANY BILL SEEKS UPTODATE DOCTORS
description: ALBANY, April 25Doctors and dentists would be required to, keep abreast of developments in their fields through continuing professional education under a bill introduced today by the chairmen of the Legislature's Education Committees.

title: Italians Retrace Terrorist Route Of Normal Guy
description: ROME, April 25'I consider myself a politicomilitary prisoner. I belong to the Red Brigades Communist organization. I do not intend to answer your questions.

title: Transit Union Voids Vote on Pact
description: The Transport Workers Union, faced with a challenge to its balloting on a new contract, agreed yesterday to throw the votes out and hold a new referendum. The result of the new balloting is not expected to be known for a month.

title: Con Ed Net Up 2.7% For First Quarter On Increased Rates
description: Firstquarter profits of the Consolidated Edison Company rose 2.7 percent on a 2.2 percent gain in revenues. The gain was fed by higher rates and the ability to pass increased fuel and power costs to customers.

title: A Clinic for Those Who March To a Diffident Drum
Conoco, Texaco, Cities Nets Off
description: Six large United States oil companies reported mixed results for the first quarter yesterday. Earnings were off for the, Continental Oil. Company, Texaco Inc., the Phillips Petroleum Company and the Cities Service Company, while the Marathon Oil Company and the Shell Oil Cornpany reported higher profits than in the first quarter a year ago.

title: Football Giants: The Future Isn't Soon Enough
description: EAST RUTHRFORD, N.J., Aprl 25The Giants held a public screening of their 1977 highlights film today and; not surprisingly, the offensive line was edited out.

title: Atherton Ends 4th Mideast Swing
description: CAIRO, April 25In the three months that direct negotiations between Egypt and Israel have been suspended in deadlock, the most conspicuous diplomatic movement in the Middle East has been the travels of the Carter Administration's roving envoy, Alfred L. Atherton Jr.

title: Fort Dix on Pentagon List of Bases Facing Shutdown or Realignment
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The Fort Dix Army training base in New Jersey is on a new Pentagon list of military establishments described as candidates for closing or major realignment of personnel, to other bases, New Jersey Congressmen were told today.

title: High Aide in a Former Drug Ring Is Convicted With Two Associates
description: The top lieutenant in the former Elvis Eynum organization, the largest black distributor of heroin in the United States in the late 1960's and early 1970's, has been convicted with two aides of conspiring to receive and deliver 50 kilograms of heroin between March and November 1971.

title: More Oats for Gary's Horses
description: The dancing bears of the professional golf tour stop over in New Orleans this week to sample the cuisine at Broussard's and Brennan's and suffer through their weekly arithmetic lesson: If the sponsor gives us 200,000 apples and Gary takes 40.000, what's left for the rest of us, including ties?

title: The Senate and the Soviets
description: WASHINGTON, April 25Secretary of State Vance has come out of Moscow talking about a better atmosphere and some progress toward a strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union, but he is not telling us what was discussed or why he feels a little more confident.

title: Brezhnev Says Soviet, Too, Will Defer Neutron Output
Mystery Particle May Be Used in Test Message
description: A group of scientists expressed hope yesterday that, despite a lack of funds for longrange experiments, the first test message might soon be transmitted over a short distance using a beam of neutrinos, atomic particles capable of passing through the Earth without resistance.

title: Careers
description: Cash management might be described as a type of magic that involves putting money to work, fast and completely. The magic might involve a pushbutton on a computer system or a fast Call to a bank or investment dealer for immediate investment in securities, usually shortterm.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ETHEL BARTLETT

title: Degnan Rebuts Nevada Governor on New Casino Law
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 25The State Attorney General, John J. Degnan, accused Gov. Michael O'Callaghan of Nevada today of making unjust and uninformed criticism of New Jersey's new casino control law.

title: West Germans Seek More Important Role in NATO
description: LONDON, April 14West Germany seeking a more important role in the framing and execution of the military policies of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Best Buys
description: ANOTHER record high in the expense of feeding a family of four in New York City was established last week, when the cost of the 91item market basket used by the city's Department of Consumer Affairs climbed 1 percent, to $81.05.

title: Engineers Ban on Competitive Bidding Is Ruled an Antitrust Violation
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The Supreme Court ruled today that professional engineers had violated the antitrust lafws by their longstanding prohibition against competitive bidding between members of their national association.

title: EarlyMorning TV. Race Heats Up
description: IN TERMS of primetime television, the 10 percent of American homes with sets that look in each morning on the three network channels for a breakfast supplement of news, weather, comment or chitchat does not loom very large.

title: Palmateer of Leafs Excels in Loss
description: UNIONDALE. L.I., April 25The Toronto Maple Leafs were on their feet from the moment Dave (Tiger) Williams was sent to the penalty box with 5:44 left in regulation time until Bob Nystrom won tonight's game for the Islanders with a goal at 8:02 of the overtime period.

title: Chase Realty Trust In Trouble on Debt
description: The Chase Manhattan Mortgage and Realty Trust, with real estate and other assets of some $275 million, disclosed late yesterday that it is considering. bankruptey proceedings.

title: KOCH ALTERED CITY RULES FOR BROADCASTING POST
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday he had altered the job specifications for the head of the Municipal Broadcasting System so that Mary Perot Nichols could get the $40,000ayear job.

title: Good Places To Play. In the City
description: Take your child for a Saturday adventure this spring and discover the different playgrounds scattered around Manhattan, from the Lower East Side to the Upper West Side.

title: Damn Yankee Exiles Find It's Really Fun to Fight Back Against Texans
Transit Union Voids Vote on Pact
description: The Transport Workers Union, faced with a challenge to its balloting on a new contract, agreed yesterday to throw the votes out and hold a new referendum. The result of the new balloting is not expected to he known for a month.

title: The New Way to Brighten Up Those Old Statues Is a Blast
Senate Report on Eilberg Inquiry Is Called Misleading by Schweiker
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI) Senator S. Schweiker, Republican of Pennsylvania, charged today that a Senate Judiciary Committee report that concluded there had been no coverup in a Justice Department investigation of Representative Joshua Eilberg was misleading and contained outright falsehoods.

title: Cottage Cheese: For Connoisseurs
description: ALTHOUGH cottage cheese might seem to be a less worthy subject of connoisseurship than caviar, much the same sort of expertise is required in judging both foods. If cottage cheese seems less fascinating it is only because it is more plebian (and, let's face it, somewkat less fabulous tasting). Perhaps even more significant, cottage cheese has earned a bad name among gastronomes because the word is out that it is good for you.

title: Bronx Poverty Corporation Loses City Funds in Fraud Investigation
description: A $1.2 millionayear contract with the Hunts Point Community Corporation, one of New York City's largest antipoverty agencies, is being canceled because investigators have found evidence of possible fiscal fraud, Mayor Koch's administration said yesterday.

title: Recital: Janet Baker
BOND PRICES TUMBLE IN TAXFREE SECTOR
description: Taxexempt bond prices declined sharply yesterday after an institutional investorunnamed but presumed to be a fire and casualty insurance company  decided to sell a list of $37.7 million of longterm securities. The sale pushed interest rates on state and city bonds higher.

title: DISCOVERIES
description: You may have an old clawfooted bathtub that you absolutely adore but could stand some pizazz  or a new chest of drawers that. has no character, or a door that fooks , like a big nothing. If you engage the services.of Kathleen Deyo, the doors, draWers, bathtub or anything else around will never look the same. Mrs. Deyo, who was an art major at Syracuse University, handpaints things.and then appligs a sealer so that dust and dirt can be wiped off from time to time. She's done screens and blanket chests and old bathtubs and, for a $25 consultation fee, will give you an idea of what can be done and what it will cost. The consultation fee is deductible if she gets the job. Her charges, roughly, are $15 an hour, and decorating one side of a bathtub (one assumes the other side is against the wall) with garlands of lovely birds and flowers would he about $45. Mrs. Deyo can be reached at 42 Horsechestnut Road, Briarcliff Manor,,N.Y. 10510. Her telephone number is (914) 9418495.

title: 8 Units Lobby. For NewYork InWashinOton
Defendant Seen at Disadvantage In U.S. Trend to Smaller Juries

Marshall Defends Labor Dept. in Crime Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)Labor Secretary Ray Marshall sought today to persuade Congress that his department had achieved renewed vigor in trying to break the hold of organized crime on some labor unions, but he ran into a skeptical Senate subcommittee.

title: India's Crops Are Setting Record
60Minute Gourmet
description: MANY AMERICANS seem to look with disdain on dishes made with ground meats, relegating them to a low position in the hierarchy of foods that fit in the gourmet category. The foundation for this attitude probably lies in the fact that the dishes called hash are often made with meat of one sort or another that has been ground and served, so to speak, the second time around.

title: Federico Chavez, Paraguay Chief Overthrown by Stroessner in. 1954
description: ASUNCION, Paraguay, April 25 (AP)Federico Chavez, President of Paraguay from 1949 until he was overthrown in 1954 by the present head of state, Gen. Alfredo Stroessner, died here last night. He was 97 years old.

title: Radio
description: Music

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: An Ossining, N.Y., couple found dead last Sunday had apparently been despondent since their only child drowned last year, and had talked repeatedly of suicide, the Ossining police said.

title: Dance: Nureyev and Cynthia Gregory
description: THERE are times when a performance is less of a performance than a special occasion. Cynthia Gregory and Rudolf Nureyev provided this kind of exciting event Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House when they danced the leading roles in American Ballet Theater's Swan Lake.

title: Senate Votes TaxReduction Delay
description: WASHINGTON, April 25The Senate refused tonight to make room in its budget for a possible $25 billion tax cut on Oct. 1.

title: Technology
Market Preference for Slowdown Over Runaway Inflation
description: Not long ago, any one of three major changes in the economic environment would precipitate anguish in Wall Street. If there were indications of a move by the Federal Reserve System to tighten credit, or of an impending decline in general business activity or the likelihood that some proposed tax reductions might be postponed or even removed,

title: Koch Says Budget Will Actually Top the Current One
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that, despite what his top budget officials told reporters the day before, New York City's spending next year will go up, not down, from this year's level.

title: Rating the Brands
SUPREME COURT BARS HIGHER PENSION COSTS FOR WOMEN THAN MEN
description: WASHINGTON, April 25Although women live longer than men on the average, an employer who charges women more than men to participate in a pension plan is committing illegal sex discrimination, the Supreme Court ruled today.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ST. LOUIS, April 25 (UPI)Police said they stopped Leon Spinks last week because his car's headlights were off, but a witness to the arrest said the police are wrong.

title: VINCENT MARAGLIOTTI, 90, MURALIST AND DECORATOR
description: Vincent Maragliotti, an artist and muralist, died last Saturday in Harrisburg, Pa., where he had lived for the last 10 years. He was 90 years old.

title: Nets Crush Apples as Gerulaitis Loses
description: How serious is Vitas Gerulaitis about World Team Tennis, or is it just another cozy payday?

title: Mastering The Bistro Burger
description: The Bistro Burger is made with approximately onehalf pound of fresh, lean, unspiced ground sirloin.

title: A New Mother's Confessions of Ambivalence
description: Sometimes when I walk down the street with my child in her carriage and my husband beside me, I feel so detached from them that I want to turn around and face off in the opposite direction to be alone with my thoughts. At other times, in the same situation, I feel we are so close to one another that I want nothing more than to continue walking along in silence, sharing what is ours alone.

title: Bistro: The View From the Grill
description: I've been in the Hamburger Game for almost a year now and have achieved, almost, mastery of the subtleties and insights so necessary for survival, and maintaining sanity, when making hamburgers for a living. I am an artist, but, for now, flipping burgers pays the rent. work at the Corner Bistro, a saloon  a bar, if you will  in the Village, in the neighborhood where I grew up. The Bistro, which has been around for a long time, is typical in design: very heavy. brown and thick, with tin ceilings and the odor of beer, whisky and wood so ingrained it can be seen and tasted.

title: Anxious Italy Awaits Terrorists Reaction To Rebuff on Moro
A Week at an English Health Hydro
description: LIPHOOK, ENGLAND Forest Mere is a health hydro, not to be confused with a beauty farm. The latter resembles such American institutions as the Golden Door, La Costa and the Greenhouse. The former, more medically oriented, refers to guests as patients and to massages as treatments  and to itself as a hydro, an Anglicism for spa.

title: Carter Says New York Fiscal Aid Is a Major Goal of Administration
description: WASHINGTON, April 25President Carter today termed fiscal aid to New York City one of the major goals of our Administration and predicted that Congress would approve his proposed legislation.

title: HowTo Help From Uncle Sam
description: TROUBLED by mildew? Headaches? Leaky plumbing? Confused about firewood? Hair dye? Dog food? Gas mileage? Wondering how to donate body organs? Remove stains? Grow tomatoes? Exercise under water? Remodel a bathroom? Immunize a child?

title: 29,000 Indonesians, Held as Reds, Are Being Freed After Testing
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  We already knew that they all are Communists, said the major general who administered psychological tests to 29,000 political prisoners in 1976, The tests were only to determine the degree of their Communist inclination.

title: Talks Ended for Allstate to Buy Share in Smith Barney Parent
description: Robert A. Powers, chairman of SBHU Holdings Inc., announced yesterday the termination of preliminary discussions concerning an investment by the Allstate Insurance Company in SBHU Holdings, parent of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company, the New York securities firm. Allstate Insurance is a subsidiary of Sears, Roebuck & Company.

title: Spurs and Nuggets Triumph
description: SAN ANTONIO, April 25 (AP)George Gervin pumped In 27 points and Mike Green 18, leading the San Antonio Spurs to a 116105 triumph over the Washington Bullets in the National Basketball Association playoffs tonight.

title: Private Lives
description: THEY ARE very young, my friends. (Everybody all around me gets younger and younger; it is a deplorable trend.) They have lived together in Rochester for several years. Living together in Rochester is somewhat better than living alone in Rochester, but still no bargain. It seems always to be cold in Rochester; in midApril it was snowing in Rochester; Rochester is the second cloudiest city in America, behind Seattle. In massive, windowless buildings all over Rochester people are coating film. On the campus of the Rochester Institute of Technology, the art students must trudge a mile over the frozen tundra to achieve a dandy wind tunnel. It is dangerous to cross the frozen tundra with a large canvas; the wind picks you up like a sail and you are suddenly in Buffalo. My colleague Richard Eder suggests that a new school of American miniaturists will emerge, all of them former art students at R.I.T. who had to carry their paintings in their pockets.

title: Tough Talk on Taxes
description: President Carter spoke a few fighting words at his news conference yesterday and sounded refreshingly like his old campaign self. He pledged that he would neither abandon nor substantially alter his plan for a major tax cut this fall, accompanied by tax reform. Let critics wail, let lobbyists attack, let Congress cave in if its knees are too weakbut Jimmy Carter plans to fight.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 26, 1978

title: New Diagnostic Blood Test Is Developed for Horses
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 23 (UPI)Researchers at the University of Kentucky said today they had developed a blood test that was 100 percent effective in diagnosing contagious equine metritis in mares.

title: Hunk Anderson, Football Coach, 79
description: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., April 25 (UPI)Heartley (Hunk) Anderson, an allAmerica guard under Knute Rockne who later succeeded Mr. Rockne as Notre Dame's football coach, died last night at the age of 79 after. a long respiratory illness.

title: Students Plan March to Protest: Investments in South Africa
description: Students from four universities in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut announced plans yesterday for a June 16 march on Wall Street to press their campaign against American banks and corporations that invest in South Africa.

title: May 1 Proclaimed Law Day
description: WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)President Carter signed an annual proclamation today that designates May I as Law Day, U.S.A. In another proclamation, Mr. Carter designated the third week of May as National Architectural Barriers Week with the aim of increasing awareness of a need to make access to workplaces, churches, schools and other facilities easier, physically, for the aged and the handicapped.

title: China Is Quietly Moderating Worshipful Attitude on Mao
description: HONG KONG, April 25China appears to be in the process of subtly reevaluating and demythologyzing the accomplishments of Mao Tsetung.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: JUSTICE delayed is justice denied, goes the old saying. But here in the city, where delays of all sorts are commonplace, justice delayed sometimes turns out to be justice all the same, even though the punishment no longer fits the crime.

title: CORRECTION
description: An obituary of Rabbi Benjamin Schultz incorrectly reported yesterday that the American Jewish League Against Communism had ceased operations in 1960. The organization is still active, and Roy M. Cohn has been its president since 1962.

title: LAW ON HOMOSEXUALS REPEALED IN ST. PAUL
description: ST. PAUL, April 25In a turnout much larger than usual for an offyear election here, citizens voted overwhelmingly to repeal a fouryearold section of the city code that had prohibited discrimination on the basis of affectional or sexual preference.

title: Open Interest
description: (In bushels, 000 omitted)

title: NewCar Sales Increase by 2.5% For April 1020
description: DETROIT, April 25Sales of new cars were a slim 2.5 percent higher during the 10day midApril sales period than during the same period last year, American car makers reported today.

title: Menza Tells of Overtures to Aides To Get Him Out of Race for Senate
Peking Expected to Name Envoy, Now in Thailand, to U.S. Office
description: PEKING, Wednesday, April 26 (Reuters) China is expected to appoint its present Ambaassador to Thailand, Chai Tseinin, as the new head of the Chinese liaison office in Washington, informed diplomatic sources said today.

title: Isle of Man Whipping Condemned
description: STRASBOURG, France, April 25In a case involving Britain's Isle of Man, the European Court of Human Rights today condemned the practice of whipping with a birch rod as a punishment for a crime.

title: TV: Activists' Benefit
description: A BENEFIT is one thing and an hour television program is another, as is made clear by The Night of the Empty Chairs, which will be seen at 9 P.M. tonight on WNET.

title: Pilots of an Italian Airline Strike
description: ROME, April 26 (Reuters)Pilots of the Italian airline ATI struck for 24 hours today, demanding reinstatement of a pilot dismissed for refusing to fly with a passenger who had insulted him. All flights from the Rome airport by ATI, a domestic carrier associated with the national airline Alitalia, were canceled.

title: House, 259 to 140, Approves Bill Requiring Disclosure by Lobbyists
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The House of Representatives tonight approved a bill that would require lobbyists to disclose many of their activities. The vote was 259 to 140.

title: Financial General Reports Rise Of 26% in FirstQuarter Profits
description: RICHMOND, April 26 (AP)Financial General Bankshares Inc., a $2.2 billion bank holding comapny allegedly sought by Bert Lance, the former budget director, and some Arab associates, reported today a 26 percent increase in firstquarter profits.

title: Design Notebook
description: THERE, is an old saying in the theater that a set that brings applause is not a good set, for if it is gaining that much attention, it must be distracting the audience from the play. That would seem to be a potential danger at the St. James Theater, where the set for On the Twentieth Century, designed by Robin Wagner, is these days proving as much of a crowd pleaser as any of the actors.

title: Dollar Mixed in New York and Abroad
description: The dollar was mixed against most currencies in quiet foreign exchange trading in New York and overseas yesterday as the United States reported a somewhat improved trade picture, The Associated Press reported.

title: Moratorium Imposed On Radiation Units
description: NEWARK, April 26Officials of the Regional Health Planning Council, which serves as a state and Federal clearinghouse for healthrelated facilities in Essex, Union, Morris, Sussex and Warren Counties, announced today that they had imposed a oneyear moratorium on approval of any new radiation therapy units for the treatment of cancer patients in the area.

title: Koch Slated to Appoint Dr. Baden Chief Medical Examiner Today
description: Dr. Michael Baden, who has been deputy chief Medical Examiner of New York City since 1970, will be named by Mayor Koch today to succeed Dr. Dominick J. DiMaio as chief Medical Examiner.

title: The Rights of Man
description: STRASBOURG, Francelt was like going back in time and seeing the case of Marbury v. Madison argued before John Marshall and his colleagues. Or so it felt to an American as the European Court of Human Rights, for two days this week, heard a challenge to British restrictions on the freedom of the press.

title: Dodgers Win, 144, Chasing Reds Seaver in 4 Innings
description: How do you figure it? With the Cincinnati Reds off to one of their best starts, Tom Seaver has still not won game. He and three other Reds pitchers were pounded for 19 hits last night in the 144 Los Angeles Dodgers victory in Cincinnati. Seaver lasted only four innings.

title: Hynes to Handle Medicaid Fraud
description: ALBANY, April 26Governor Carey said today that he would expand the jurisdiction of Charles J. Hynes, the special nursinghome prosecutor, to include all Medicaid fraud in New York State.

title: Senate Sets Tentative Budget Limit
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The Senate approved a resolution today setting a tentative budget ceiling for itself of $566.1 billion for the fiscal year starting on Oct. 1.

description: To the Editor:
