description: (Inbushels.000 omitted)

title: Thermometer Sent Into Space To Record Earth's Temperature
description: A small satellite designed to take the earth's temperature, and thus perhaps locate mineral resources, monitor soil moisture, chart snowfields and detect ecological disturbances in coastal waters, was Successfully launched yesterday from Vandenber Air Force Base in California.

title: Israeli Demonstrators in a New Peace Rally
description: JERUSALEM, April 26Israeli demonstrators particpated in an afternoonlong vigil along the main highway leading from Jerusalem to Tel Aviv today to protest Prime Minister Menachem Begin's unwillingness to make territorial concessions on the Israelioccupied Arab lands of the West Bank of the Jordan River.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: SAILING TODAY TransAtlantic

title: Article 2  No Title
Rudolf Hess Marks 84th Year
description: WEST BERLIN, April 26 (Reuters)Rudolf Hess, Hitler's deputy until he flew to Britain in 1941, marked his 84th birthday in Spandau Prison here tody, the lone prisoner. Allied sources said he was in good health but had no visitors for the occasion. His wife spent an hour with him yesterday, double the monthly visiting time.

title: Judge Facing Reversal On LegalAid Effort
description: WATERTOWN, N. Y., April 25Long before Warren E. Burger, Chief Justice of the United States, began publicly picking on incompetent lawyers, Leon Schwerzmann Jr., the Jefferson County Surrogate, was complaining about the low quality of legal representation. He even quit the local bar association 17 years ago in disgust over lawyers.

title: Horowitz to Play May 7
description: Vladimir Horowitz will give a piano recital in Carnegie Hall on May 7 for an audience drawn primarily from outside the United States. Tickets were made available first to nonAmericans through travel agencies and musical organizations. Not until these were sold as completely as possible were the remaining tickets put on sale yesterday at the Carnegie Hall box office for local purchasers. By late afternoon, most of them had been sold About 1,100 seats were sold abroad.

title: Hers
description: REREADING the books of youth and early maturity, and feeling that one is reading them for the first time, is a common experience among contemporary feminists. The new consciousness is a kind of litmus paper; dip it into the most familiar of works and there suddenly stands revealed a new pattern, a previously hidden picture, a now decoded text.

title: DAYAN MEETS VANCE ON MIDEAST ISSUES
description: WASHINGTON, April 26,  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel opened talks with Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance today on ways to overcome the impasse in Middle East negotiations.

title: Chamber Music: Tribute to Bloch
description: ERNEST BLOCH's place in future musical history is pretty much assured through such Norks as Schelomo, the Sacred Service. Baal Shem and theConcerto Grosso No. 1. There is a lot more to his creative output than these works, however, but they are encountered sporadically and so a true perspective of the composer's importance is seldom possible.

title: Bonn Very Pleased By the Latest Talks On Arms in MoscOw
description: BONN, April 26After months of discord with the United States, West German officials expressed satisfaction today with reports that American negotiators had apparently succeeded in defending Bonn's interests in strategic arms talks last week with the Soviet Union.

title: Terrorists Wound Italian Politician
description: ROME, April 26Members of the Red Brigades, the terrorist organation, shot and wounded a Garistian Democratic politician in a suburb of Rome today, but remained silent about he fate of Aldo Moro, the political leader, whose slaying it threatened on Monday.

title: U.S. Sees a Soviet Effort To Offset World Reaction To Its Attack on Airliner
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  United States officials said today that the Soviet Union was apparently trying to offset unfavorable world reaction to its attack on a South Korean airliner last week by circulating a seemingly plausible explanation of the incident.

title: House, 259 to 140, Approves Bill Requiring Disclosure by Lobbyists
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The House of Representatives tonight approved a bill that would require lobbyists to disclose many of their activities. The vote was 259 to 140.

title: Associated Press Is Held in Violation Of U.S S. Bias Rules
description: The Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has determined that there is reasonable cause to believe that The Associated Press has violated Federal laws by discriminating against women and members of minorities in some of its employment practices.

title: U.S. Trade Deficit Shrank To $2.8 Billion in March
description: WASHINGTON. Aril 20 (AP) The United States recorded a $2.8 billion trade deficit in March, a solid improvement over February but still worse than the average for last year, the Government said today. A drop in oil imports was the major factor in the shrinkage of the deficit.

title: Solar Power Comes to West 105th Street
description: UP ON THE roof of a 12story cooperative apartment house on West 105th Street between West End Avenue and Broadway are four clusters of huge aluminum plates and, most days, an anxious army of tenants and technicians.

title: Around the Nation
description: SAFFORD, Ariz., April 26 (AP)John D. Ehrlichman, the Watergate conspirator, will be released from Federal prison tomorrow, after serving 18 months of an eightyear maximum term.

title: Advertising Reaching Two Kinds of Fedders Buyer
description: There is just as much difference between the people who buy central airconditioners and room airconditioners as there is between the units themselves.

title: BETTER ODDS URGED IN CASINO GAMBLING
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 26Albert W, Merck, one of five members of the Casino Control Commission, proposed today that the commission make New Jersey the state in which the casino patron has the best chance of winning.

title: U.S. Rests in I.B.M. Suit
description: The Government rested its case in the antitrust suit against the International Business Machines Corporation. The defense called a witness in a turning point in the trial, which began nearly three years ago. Page D3.

title: Capital's Hottest Game: Real Estate
description: WASHINGTON THERE'S A NEW way to tell who is in and who is out in this town, said John Fox Sullivan, publisher of the publicaffairs magazine National Journal, as he looked around the people at a cocktail party. People who are in talk real estate; people who are out talk politics.

title: Workers Warned of Asbestos Peril
description: WASHINGTON, April 26  Federal health officials today warned millions of American workers who have handled asbestos over the last 40 years that they were at grave risk of developing serious diseases, including cancer, because of their exposure to the mineral.

title: Bomb in Nablus Kills Two Germans
description: TEL AVIV, April 26Two teenaged West Germans doing humanitarian work in Israel were killed this afternoon by a terrorist bomb in the West Bank town of Nablus.

title: Auction Records Set By Revere Document
description: Malcolm Forbes, the publisher, set two autograph records at auction yesterday when he paid $70,000 for Paul Revere's exoense account. The figure was the nignest ever paia at auction for an American autograph or a handwritten American document, exceeding, among other things, the $54,000 paid at public sale in 1947 for the Gettysburg Address.

title: Close Votes Likely in Congress on Mideast Plane Deal
description: WASHINGTON, April 26Members of key House and Senate committees were sharply divided today over the Carter Administration's arms package for the Middle East.

title: Dividends
description: WEDNESDAY, APRIL 26, 1978

title: Books of The Times
description: IT'S TRUE that Alfred Kazin is an intellectuala New York Jewish intellectual, as the title of his latest autobiographical memoir nearly proclaims. It's undeniable that much of the content of New York Jew is filtered through the author's teeming mind. The big ideas and social upheavals are all here, as Mr. Kazin makes his way from the early 40's the point where his earlier mem. oirs, A Walker in the City and Starting Out in the Thirties, left offup to the present. How Mr. Kazin reacted to World War II is here: I could no more share [the] detachment from the war expressed by the old socialists I knew in New York . . . than I could believe in the global New Deal at The New Republic and the American Century of Fortune. He worked successively for the two magazines in the early 40's. I saw no alternative to defeating Hitler: I wanted to live. What he thought about the Depression that was ended by the warand only the waris here. What he thought of being a Jew in the aftermath of the holocaust; of McCarthyism, of literary academics in the 50's, of rampant Presidential power and the radical reaction to it in the 60's, of the sexual revolution and the celebration of Selfall are here, all reflected upon.

title: Indonesia's Oil Fails to Wash Away the Blight of Poverty
description: JAKARTA, IndonesiaConcrete office towers and imposing Government buildings have sprung up in this boomtown capital and in other cities of Indonesia, MercedesBenz automobiles are commonplace, and the initials of Pierre Cardin are worn like a badge of new riches by sleek men and women in public places.

title: Optimists Are Out in Force as 100,000 Books Go on Sale in Princeton
description: PRINCETON, April 26When the doors at the Borough Hall gymnasium opened at noon today, 400 people rushed through to get a first look at the 100,000 volumes on sale dueng the 47th annual Bryn Mawr book sale.

title: The Editorial Notebook Antitrust Out of Focus
description: At first glance, it seemed like the model of what private antitrust cases are supposed to be about. Berkey Photo, a tiny camera maker, was going bankrupt attempting to compete with Kodak. the industry giant. Berkey sought redress through a civil suit alleging monopolization by Kodak, and ultimately was awarded $113 million in damages and penalties by a jury. The huge sum gives Berkey a new lease on life and stands as a warning to other corporate predators.

title: Bus Strike Jams Jersey Patrons On Other Lines
description: The 7.30 P.M. Transport of New Jersey bus rumbled out of the Port Authority terminal in midtown Manhattan filled to capacity49 passengers seated, 19 standingleaving l4 frustrated commuters on the platform to wait for the next bus a halfhour later.

title: Sticht Promoted at R.J. Reynolds
description: J. Paul Sticht, president and chief operating officer of R. J. Reynolds Industries, Inc., has been elected chief executive officer, it was announced yesterday. Colin Stokes. who has served as chief executive officer since 1973, will remain as chairman and will assume the additional post of chairman of the executive committee of the board, a post previously held by Mr. Sticht. The company said the changes will provide for an orderly transition of executive management as Mr. Stokes, who is 64 years old, approaches the retirement age of 65.

title: SOUTHWEST AFRICA WARNS GUERRILLAS ON FIGHTING
description: WINDHOEK, SouthWest Africa, April 26 (UPI) The Government of SouthWest Africa warned black guerrillas today to halt all fighting while independence was under discussion, saying that new violence would be met with all possible force.

title: Homecoming Cheers Greet the Ambassador of Seventh Avenue
description: AFTER THE Boy Scout scene and the square dancing and the elegant loose clothes, the cheers rang out in Geoffrey Beene's showroom for Seventh Avenue's current international ambassador of fashion. Unlike the other fall and winter collections being shown this week, this one was not making its debut. It has already been presented in Milan and in Paris as part of the fashion festivities abroad. To the relief of Beene fans, the clothes held up on second and sometimes third viewing.

title: Soviet Conquers U.S. Sextet, 9 to 5
description: PRAGUE, April 26 (AP)Aleksandr Golikov scored twice in a fivegoal barrage in the third period that led the Soviet Union to a 95 victory over the United States in today's opening round of play at the world ice hockey championships.

title: Abolishing of Water Supply Board In New York City Gains in Albany
description: ALBANY, April 26The Senate unanimously passed today a bill abolishing the New York City Board of Water Supply, with Democrats who had expressed doubts about abolition voting for the Republicansponsored legislation.

title: Ballet: Kivitt As Siegfried
description: TED KIVITT has long been a stalwart of American Ballet Theater's roster of principal dancers, to which he was elevated in 1967. If his Siegfried lacked eloquence on Tuesday in Ballet Theater's Swan Lake at the Metropolitan Opera House, it was nevertheless a sturdy, dependable performance.

title: U.S. Facing World Soccer Ban Over Rule Deviations
description: GENEVA, April 26 (AP)The United States was warned today that its soccer players might be barred from all international competition, including the World Cup, unless the North American Soccer League changed its rules.

title: Gary Player, Winner Throughout the World, Keeps Improving Game
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 26Modesty has never been one of Gary Player's assets but instead of promoting himself the racehorse breeder from South Africa is letting his recent achievements speak for themselves. With good reason.

title: ALBANY BILL BACKED TO FREE CITY BANKS IN FOREIGN LOANS
description: ALBANY, April 26Legislative leaders and the Carey adminitration have agreed on a proposal that would free the international loan activities of New York City banks from state and city taxes and regulations.

title: Home Beat
description: Curious, to think that out of Denmark, home of strapping Danes, such delicacy is born. Take the ultimate stool. It's difficult, perhaps, to defend spending $395 on transient sitting  for stool repose, after all, represents a mere pause of the hip, as opposed to serious settling down.

title: Student,16,Is Fighting for Right To Run for Essex G.O.P. Panel
description: LIVINGSTON, April 26A 16yearold high school student with nine years of political activity behind him is fighting to get on the ballot here as a candidate for a seat on the Essex County Republican committee.

title: Fleeing Cities, a Company Finds Suburbs Encroaching; An Appraisal; Serious Questions Raised; Really That Different?; A Matter of Isolation; Suburbia Arrives at Rural Office
description: Surely no building in the United States has as dramatic an approach as the new headquarters of the JohnsManville Corporation on a 10,000acre ranch 22 miles southwest of Denver. Thelast few miles are traveled along acountry road that winds through a valley; the road makes a sudden turnoff through a mountain pass, then winds upward past great formations of redrock that sit beside the road like sculptures. Suddenly the road makes another turn, and there, set across the valley like a squaredoff aluminum spaceship come to rest in the foothills of the Rockies, sits the building.

title: F.A.A. Is Seeking to Strengthen Tire Requirement for DC10's
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)The Government is preparing an order to require that tires on DC10 airliners be strengthened to avert blowouts, which have Lauseci this type of plane to have several recent accidents.

title: Washington &
description: WASHINGTONA new system of sharedcost crop insurance that would combine most of the Government's disaster and drought loss plans was proposed yesterday by Secretary of Agriculture Bob Bergland.

title: Panel Approves Loan Guarantees
description: WASHINGTON, April 26A bill to provide 15year Federal guarantees for New York City loans was approved 12 to 2 by a House banking subcommittee today.

title: Abolishing of Water Supply Board In New York City Gains in Albany
description: ALBANY, April 26The Senate unanimously passed today a bill abolishing the New York City Board of Water Supply, with Democrats who had expressed doubts about abolition voting for the Republicansponsored legislation.

title: Calendar of Events for the Home
description: A twoday seminar entitled The Market Potential of Art and Antiques will be held on May 4 and 5, at the Doral Inn, cosponsored by the C.W. Post Center of Long Island University and the American Society of Appraisers.

title: S.E.C. ACCUSES LANCE OF FRAUD AS BANKER
description: WASHINGTON, April 26Two Federal agencies accused former budget director Bert Lance today of civil fraud and numerous violations of Federal banking and securities laws.

title: 8 Will Challenge Alydar In the Blue Grass Today
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 26Valor got the better discretion today when the trainers of eight undistinguished 3yearolds entered their horses in tomorrow's Blue Grass Stakes against Alydar.

title: AMERICAN IS CHARGED IN LETELIER SLAYING
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The United States Government today charged a 35yearold American recently expelled from Chile, with conspiracy in the murder of the former Chilean Ambassador, Orlando Letelier, who was killed when a bomb destroyed his car here in 1976.

title: Thieu, in Exile for 3 Years, .Lives in Affluent Isolation in London:
description: LONDON, April 26It seems so much longer. But it was only three years ago today that Nguyen Van Thieu, the President of South Vietnam during the last eight years of its anguished struggle for survival, flew into exile from Saigon to Taipei.

title: Tax Deductions Cited By Carter Confirmed
description: WASHINGTON, APRIL 26  The Treasury said today that two taxpayers had been allowed to take the large entertainment deductions that President Carter cited yesterday in a televised news conference.

title: House Unit Blocks Korean Pullout
description: WASHINGTON, April 26In a direct challenge to President Carter, the House Armed Services Committee voted today to prevent the Administration from withdrawing American ground forces from South Korea until Congress approves the transfer of American military equipment to the Seoul Government.

title: A Troubled Package for the Middle East
description: Members of Congress from both parties are telling President Carter that he faces almost certain defeat he persists with his proposed aircraft sales to Israel, Egypt and Saudi Arabia. They counsel delay. Yet, as a half dozen American Administrations have learned, no time is ever really good for selling arms to the Middle East. The Carter Administration is right to hold to the proposed sales and even more right to insist that they be tied together in a package.

title: Pop: Denise At Coriander
description: JOE DERISE has been through the mill as a pop singer. In the bigband days just after World War II, he played guitar and sang with the bands of Ray McKinley, Jimmy Dorsey and Claude Thornhill. In the 1950's, he put together an outstanding singing group, Four Jacks and a Jill, and for the last seven years he has been the conductor, pianist and arranger for a highly commercial singing group, the Diamonds.

title: Agriculture Secretary Could Raise Crop Aid Under Plan of Conferees
description: WASHINGTON, April 26A Congressional conference committee on agriculture today approved an amendment to the farm law that would give the Secretary of Agriculture authority to raise subsidy and price support levels on this year's wheat, corn and cotton crops.

title: Eric Donald Mackintosh, at 71, Led British Chocolate Company
description: LONDON, April 26 (AP)Eric Donald Mackintosh, former chairman of one of Britain's largest chocolate companies, John Mackintosh & Sons, was found dead today on the sidewalk outside the luxury Mayfair apartment building where he lived. He was 71 years old. The cause of death was not immediately known.

title: DAYAN MEETS VANCE ON MIDEAST ISSUES
description: WASHINGTON, April 26,  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel opened talks with Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance today on ways to overcome the impasse in Middle East negotiations.

title: Q&A
description: Q.We have an unheated garage below two of our bedrooms and we think it would be a good idea to put some insulation under these bedrooms. Since the joists are not exposed in the garage ceiling, what type of insulation can we install that would take up as little overhead space as possible, and how should it be attached?  J.R., Middletown, Conn.

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Laws Aiding Homosexuals Face Rising Opposition Around Nation
description: As voters in St. Paul, turning out Tuesday in larger numbers than usual for an offyear election, repealed that city's homosexual rights ordinance, antihomosexual organizations in other cities were accelerating their efforts to repeal similar measures.

title: Prices of Soybean Futures Decline
description: CHICAGO, April 26 (AP)Soybean futures dropped lower today, as reports of Brazil's meager harvest failed to generate enough buying to satisfy speculators.

title: $13.5 BILLION BUDGET IS PROPOSED BY KOCH
description: Mayor Koch yesterday proposed a $13.5 billion budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1, which called for continued austerity in city spending but projected a slower loss of city workers next year than the Mayor had previously forecast.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Report Tells of Some improprieties by F.B.I. Agents
description: WASHINGTON, April 26There was, fir openers, the young agent of they Federal Bureau of Investigation who was dismissed last year after he was caught trying to shoplift a bottle of liquor.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an error by the Pacific Coast Stock Exchange, the day's low for shares of the Exxon Corporation in trading Monday was stated incorrectly in the stock market tables yesterday. The correct figure was $48 a share.

title: Off Off Broadway Battling for its Life
description: OFF OFF BROADWAY, whose existence was threatened three years ago by Actors Equity, is once again battling for survival. Equity has suddenly, without previous consultation with the Off Off Broadway Alliance, proposed a new code and has scheduled it to be voted upon by its membership tomorrow.

title: Japan and Soviet Sign Whale Pact
description: TOKYO, April 26 (Reuters)Japan and the Soviet Union signed an agreement today to regulate their whaling operations in the northern Pacific this year, the Foreign Ministry announced.

title: Fleeing Cities, a Company Finds SuburbsEncroaching; Serious Questions Raised; Really That Different?; A Matter of Isolation; Suburbia Arrives at Rural Office
description: JEFFERSON COUNTY, COLO. Surely no building. in the United States has as dramatic an approach as the new headquarters of the JohnsManville Corporation on a 10,000acre ranch 22 miles southwest of Denver. The last few miles are traveled along a country road that winds through a valley; the road makes a sudden turnoff through a mountain pass, then winds upward past great formations of red rock that sit beside the road like sculptures. Suddenly the road makes another turn, and there, set across the valley like a square??off aluminum spaceship come to rest in the foothills of the Rockies, sits the building.

title: Capital Budget Focuses on Repairs
description: A $1.52 billion capital budget with a heavy emphasis on restoring New York City's physical plant was disclosed yesterday by Mayor Koch. It includes $25 million for the Sanitation Department that would pay for 365 new collection trucks plus 220 other pieces of equipment.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: Death

title: Globetrotter Star Out of Hospital
description: Meadowlark Lemon, the Harlem Globetrotters star, left Bellevue Haspital yesterday after being admitted overnight for treatment of a stab wound allegedly inflicted by his estranged wife. Mr. Lemon suffered superficial wounds of the back, according to a hospital spokesman. Willye Lemon, 40 years old, of Fairfield, Conn., was charged with assault In the attack.

title: Islanders Now Putting the Pressure on Leafs
description: I'd always heard how some teams could rise up and meet the pressure, said Glenn (Chico) Resch, the Islanders' goaltender, but I wasn't able to relate to it. Now I realize what they're talking about.

title: Death Penalty Gains in Bay State
description: BOSTON, April 26 (UPI)  The Massachusetts Senate has voted to reestablish the death penalty for some types of murder. The capital punishment bill, approved yesterday, would impose the death penalty for 11 categories of firstdegree murder. The measure included murderrap, murder of a police officer, murder with extreme brutality and murder for hire.

title: Burger Warns of Power News Conglomerates Hold
description: WASHINGTON, April 26Chief Justice Warren E. Burger, in a concurring opinion issued today that seemed to express his personal view on the power of the press, said that large media conglomerates had no special claim on constitutional liberties, including First Amendment rights of free expression.

title: Market Place
description: While most players are making money in the stock market at long last, short sellers badly miscalculated and have been bleeding profusely.

title: Balloon Data Indicate Vast Amounts of Antimatter Are in Milky Way
description: WASHINGTON, April 26Observations from an unmanned balloon drifting over Australia have indicated that vast amounts of antimatter exist within or surround the core of the Milky Way Galaxy, to which the sun and its planets belong.

title: COSTA RICAN JUDGE FREES VESCO ON FRAUD CHARGES
description: SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, April 26 (AP)A Costa Rican judge dismissed fraud charges today against Robert L. Vesco and six. associates, thus freeing the fugitive American financier to leave the country.

title: Treasury Outlines $4 Billion Borrowing Next Week
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The Treasury announced today that next week it would sell 10year notes and bonds maturing in 2000 as it borrows $4 billion to help pay off two issues of notes That are scheduled to mature May 15.

title: BLACKS IN CONGRESS SEEK CURB ON ABUSE OF U.S. AID
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)Congressional black leaders complained to President Carter today about the Government's efforts to stem abuse of Federal aid programs.

title: 2 Killed, 2 Hurt as Car Goes Out of Control in Downtown Newark
description: NEWARK, April 28 (AP)Two persons were killed and two others were critically injured today when a station wagon careened out of control in downtown Newark, ran across a major thoroughfare and smashed through the front of a clothing store near a busy bus stop, the police said.

title: Man Held in Threat to Carter
description: GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., April 26 (AP)The Secret Service said today that Floyd Marsh, 47 years old, was arrested last night at his home in Leslie and charged with threatening bodily harm to President Carter and sending threatening correspondence through the mail. The implied threats against the President were in a tape recording that reached the White House on Monday, agents said. Mr. Marsh was arraigned today and ordered held in $5,000 bond for a pretrial hearing May 4.

title: Money
description: NEW YORK (AP)  Money rates

title: Famed Statue of Boy Is Stolen in. Brussels
description: BRUSSELS, April 26The Manneken Pis, Belgium's most famous statue, was stolen last night for the third time this century. The twofoottall fountainstatue of a young naked boy urinating stood in a small square surrounded by 17thcentury houses near the center of Brussels.

title: ISRAELI TANKS REPORTED IN POSITIONS NEAR TYRE
description: SIDON, Lebanon, April 26 (Reuters)Israeli tanks took up positions near the southern port city of Tyre today after an exchange of automaticweapon fire between Palestinian guerrillas and Israeli occupation forces, witnesses said.

title: I .R.S Studies Stockholder Charge Of Kickbacks Involving Henry Ford
description: The Detroit office of the Internal Revenue Service has begun to check into charges raised in a stockholder suit that Henry Ford 2d, the chairman of the Ford Motor Company, and 19 company officers had engaged in a conspiracy to divert millions of dollars in company funds to themselves through kickbacks and other transactions.

title: Sound
description: SOUND has been television's stepchild. It has been treated badly, partly by technical shortcomings, but mostly by an attitude among television broadcasters that regarded sound as secondary. This goes back all the way to the early days when the only instruction ever given to the sound technician with his single microphone dangling from a fishpole was to keep it out of sight. It is curious that this policy of slighting Sound was never shared in the film Studios, where technical problems were similar, but the quality of the soundtrack had been a major concern since the beginning of the talkies.

title: A Cathedral for Cutthroats
description: Maple Leaf Gardens in Toronto has a reputation as hockey's cathedial. The parishioners sometimes are so quiet in their pews that the puck can be heard slithering along the ice. It also is cleaner than some cathedrals. You can eat off the floor, Toronto people always like to say, at least before the gates open. But the big gray downtown building always has been a cathedral where cutthroats are welcome, if not worshipped, as long as they wore the Maple Leafs blue and white uniforms. If you can't beat em outside in the alley, Conn Smythe, the builder of Maple Leaf Gardens, once said of the opposition, you can't beat em inside on the ice. Conn Smythe is 83 years old now and he no longer is financially involved in the hockey team he constructed. But his philosophy is still involved. His words are ringing like church bells through Maple Leaf Gardens, where the New York Islanders return tonight with a 32 lead in their fourofsevengame quarterfinal Stanley Cup skirmish.

title: Duran vs.Viruet Tonight: Streetfighters at Garden
description: An oldfashioned rumble between streetfighters, one from Panama and the other from the South Bronx, marks the return of Roberto Duran to Madison Square Garden tonight.

title: Jetliner Engine Catches Fire
description: MONTREAL, April 26 (UPI)  An Air Canada Boeing 747 carrying 253 passengers and a crew of 18 made an emergency landing at London's Heathrow Airport today after an engine caught fire, a spokesman at the airline's headquarters here reported. The jet, bound for Edmonton and Vancouver, landed safely after the engine was automatically shut down.

title: GARDENING
description: TOMORROW is a good day to think about trees. When J. Sterling Morton proposed Arbor Day more than 100 years ago, his goal was to set aside one day a year, usually the last Friday in April, for the public planting of trees.

title: GEORGI M. RATIANI, AT 60, A PRAVDA COMMENTATOR
description: MOSCOW, April 26 {Reuters)Georgi M. Ratiani, an ideological and political commentator of the Communist Party newspaper Pravda, has died of a heart attack at the age of 60, the newspaper reported today.

title: Punk Furniture Makes Itself Felt
description: THE 1950's gave us skinny ties, pegged pants and Elvis Presley. The 1970's, in a quantum leap forward, have so far given us skinny ties, pegged pants and Elvis Costello. The important difference is that what was then ?? as a fad is currently deemed a movement  pure punk. Now, another manifestation of the punk movement is upon us  punk furniture, designed by a young man named Richard Mauro.

title: Wanaque Getting New Water Plant
description: WANAQUE, April 26A groundbreaking ceremony today in a rocky, wooded section of North Jersey's watershed signaled the start of construction of what officials called the most modern, computerized potable water treatment plant in the nation.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: Eight harness drivers, each prominent in his country, will embark tonight at the Meadowlands track on a 35race series designed to produce a world champion.

title: ExNew Haven Mayor Found Dead
description: NEW HAVEN, April 26Bartholemew F. Guida, who was Mayor of New Haven from 1969 to 1975, was found dead this morning in a small, heavily littered wooded area behind a high school gymnasium, with a gunshot wound in the head.

title: Market's Volume Is Heavy Again As U. S. Trade Figures Aid Rally
description: Some welcome news on the United States trade deficitan albatross around the neck of the stock market in recent monthskept Wall Street's monumental rally rolling yesterday on heavy volume.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: A round of pricecutting on coffee accelerated yesterday when two more of the nation's major roasters lowered wholesale quotations on ground coffee. The General Foods Corporation, the nation's leading roaster, and Hills Brothers Coffee Inc., which ranks No. 3, cut the list price for their ground coffees by 10 cents to $2.93 a pound, effective immediately.

title: T.W.A. Shareholders Vote Down Slate of 10 Dissident Directors
description: OVERLAND PARK, Kan., April 26 (AP) A dissident slate of lOcandidates for the Trans World Airlnes board of directors was defeated overwhelmingly today at the company's annual meeting.

title: Fed's Independence
description: WASHINGTON, April 26In office less than two months, G. William Miller, whom President Carter appointed to replace conservative Arthur F. Burns as chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, has increased interest rates, adopted a contrary view on taxes and delivered fireandbrimstone sermons on the need for fiscal restraint. Mr. Miller is, in short, acting very much like the man he dislodged. Yet, unlike Mr. Burns, he seems to have evoked relatively little irritation in the White House.

title: Elitism in Arts and Humanities Units Is Debated
description: THE DEBATE begun last year when President Carter called for an end to any elitist attitude in the National Endowment for the Humanities was continued Tuesday evening at the Yale Law School with questions of possiblt pressure on the humanities and arts endowments, the quality of work and fears of an establishment grip on the two organizations.

title: Baryshnikov to Join City Ballet in July
description: After four years with the American Ballet Theater, Mikhail Baryshnikov will leave that company to join the New York City Ballet, which is directed by George Balanchine and Lincoln Kirstein.

title: JUSTICES, 54, ALLOW CORPORATE SPENDING FOR ISSUES ON BALLOT
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The Supreme Court ruled today that states cannot bar corporations from spending unlimited amounts of their money to influence the outcome of public referendums, declaring that the Constitution guarantees the corporations freedom of speech just as it does individuals.

title: Family Money: Personal Counseling
description: The hottest thing in money management these days is personal financial counseling. Accounting firms such as Touche Ross & Company and brokerage firms such as the E. F. Hutton Group and Merrill Lynch & Company are all fighting such wellestablished guardians of other people's cash as the United States Trust Company for a piece of the action.

title: Young, Hungry, Streaking A's A Surprise, but Fans Stay Away
description: OAKLAND. Calif.. April 26At 12:56 A.M. today, the Oakland A's took sole possession of first. place in the American League West by running their winning streak to seven games in sweeping a doubleheader from the Minnesota Twins, 53 and 43 in 14 innings.

title: REPORT ON EILBERG IRKS G.O.P. SENATORS
description: WASHINGTON, April 26A number of Senate Republicans, including both Senators from Pennsylvania, say that they are incensed by a report of the Senate Judiciary Committee that concluded the Administration had not covered up an investigation into Representative Joshua Eilberg, Democrat of Pennsylvania.

title: Backgammon:
description: The men on the backgammon board should be viewed as valuable resources, always in scarce supply. To get the maximum potential out of every position, you must use these resources efficiently. For example, it is important to avoid taking men out of play by stacking too many on a single point or making points too deep in your home board. A more subtle method for efficient use of your men is to strive to create natural formations with them.

title: AMERICAN IS CHARGED IN LETELIER SLAYING
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The United States Government today charged a 35yearold American, recently extradited from Chile, with conspiracy in the murder of the former Chilean Ambassador, Orlando Letelier, who was killed when a bomb destroyed his car here in 1976.

title: JUSTICES, 54, ALLOW CORPORATE SPENDING FOR ISSUES ON BALLOT
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The Supreme Court ruled today that states cannot bar corporations from spending unlimited amounts of their money to influence the outcome of public referendums, declaring that the Constitution guarantees the corporations freedom of speech just as it does individuals.

title: Appeals Court Reverses Conviction of Justice Tyler
description: The perjury conviction of Justice Andrew R. Tyler was overturned yesterday by an appellate court that criticized the prosecutor's office for having encouraged the judge to give false testimony to a grand jury.

title: Understated Style Revives A Typical West Side Apartment
description: TOM O'TOOLE, a relatively new name to know among New York's top interior designers, uses some unorthodox techniques to get to know his clients. When I go to taxe measurements, I look through the medicine cabinets to see how involved people are with status, said Mr. O'Toole, who is 40 years old, And I'll look in closets at blouses, ties, shirts to get an idea of someone's feeling for pattern, color, scale. Asked whether his clients know about his tactics, the sleuth laughed and said, of course.

title: S.E.C. ACCUSES LANCE OF FRAUD AS BANKER
description: WASHINGTON, April 26Two Federal agencies accused former budget director Bert Lance today of civil fraud and numerous violations of Federal banking and securities laws.

title: Court in a Reversal Rules States May Tax Handling of Ship Cargo
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The Supreme Court ruled today that states may levy a business tax on the loading and unloading of cargo from ships without infringing the right of Congress to regulate commerce or the constitutional ban on state duties on imports.

title: Shevcinenko Quits U.N.Post, Says He'll Stay in U.S.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 26Arkady N. Shevchenko has left his position as the topranking Soviet member on the United Nations staff and said today he intended to remain in the United States to be free to lead a normal and productive life.

title: News Summary
description: THURSDAY, APRIL 27, 1978

title: Top Pop Records
description: These are the most popular albUms and singles nationwide, compiled by Record World, a trade publication. Albums are determined by sales figures from major retail outlets; singles are chosen by combined sales and radio airplay. An asterisk indicates an especially fastselling record.

title: Talbot Still Rangers Coach, but for How Long?
description: JeanGuy Talbot's position as coach of the New York Rangers was said to be in jeopardy at various times throughout the season. Scotty Bowman, coach of the Montreal Canadiens and Fred Shero, coach of the Philadelphia Flyers have been mentioned as potential replacements for Talbot, who was in his rookie season as Rangers coach. Again yesterday, Talbot was reported to be out, and Bowman was reported to be in, And again yesterday, Bill Jennings, president of the Rangers, denied that such a move had been made.

title: Details of 1966 Car BreakIn Barred at Curare Trial
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., April 26The judge in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich refused today to allow the introduction of a complaint that the surgeon had made in 1966 about a mysterious breakin of his automobile while he was under investigation for the sudden deaths that had been taking place at Riverdell Hospital.

title: Disks: Serkin Birthday Concert
description: ON DEC. 14, 1977, Rudolf Serkin gave a recital at Carnegie Hall that consisted of the program listed above. What this album contains, however, is not the live rec??ing of that recital, as one might RUDOLF SERKIN on Television: The 75th Birthday Concert at Carnegie Hall. Sonata in E flat (London No. 59), by Haydn; Rondo in A minor (K. 511), by Mozart; Sonata in E flat (Up. 81 a), by Beethoven; Sonata in B flat (OpPosth.). by Schubert. Rudolf Serkin, piano. Columbia M234596 (two disks).be led to think, but a performance that the pianist gave the next day at Carnegie for an invited audience and televiion ??ame. as The cir??stances of the second recital no doubt help explain the extraordinary quietness of the audience: so little coughing and throatclearing can be heard that one might imagine most of the time that Mr. Serkin is playing in a studio.

title: Treasures of Mexico Shown in Washington
description: WASHINGTON THE National Museum of Anthropology in Mexico City offers one of the greatest museum experiences to be had anywhere in the world. In the daunting reaches of its immense galleries, oneenters into communion not only with vast numbers of extraordinary works of art from the preColumbian cultures of Mexican antiquity, but with the very spirit of the civilization that spawned them. The sheer scale of the place has something to do with the kind of exalted experience one has there, but so does the scale of the art that we encounter in it. In the end, we are likely to be more overwhelmed than delighted, as the unremitting power of primitive imagination casts its alien and irresistible spell.

title: Bridge:
description: The world of bridge suffered a great loss Monday when Harold A. Ogust died in New York after a long illness.

title: 16 Food Processors Are Listed For Health Code Violations
description: The New York City Health Department yesterday cited 16 food processors for health violations. The businesses were listed as follows:

title: Chilingirian Quartet Plays
description: THE Chilingirian String Quartet the name comes from the first violinist, Levon Chilingirian was formed in London in 1971 and won the 1976 Young Concert Artists international auditions. The group made its New York debut in March of 1977, and has returned this season for two American tours, one of which brought the players back to the 92d Street Y.M.Y.W.H.A. Tuesday night.

title: The U.N. Today
description: April 27, 1978

title: Smoother Flow 25c Subway Turnstiles Are Backing Up Traffic
description: Subway turnstiles at 10 of the busiest stations in New York City have been converted in the last two months to accept quarters instead of tokens, and the switch is causing wide confusion.

title: Saving the Cities, the People, the Land
description: AUSTINAs residents of the highly touted Sun Belt we have read with interest the attention paid to the rise of the Sun Belt and the decline of the Northeast. Northeastern cities are dying because they are no longer the nation's dynamic centers of economic growth while the cities of the South and Southwest are healthy because they are the recent recipients of the mantle of national economic leadership.

title: Music:Blend Of Tones By Niblock
description: PHILL NIBLOCK's music has been showing signs of settling into a circumscribed but wholly original world of its own. Most of the new pieces Mr. Niblock has presented over the last few years involve a very exacting quadrophonic mix of very long tones, usually tones that are pitched dose together so as to produce acoustic beating and other phenomena. A performer, usually David Gibson on cello or Arthur Stidfole on bassoon, often contributes more long tones live.

title: Ambitious Banker From Georgia
description: Bert Lance, the ambitious Georgia banker who emerged as a national figure less than two years ago, has been enveloped in controversy almost from the moment President Carter appointed him director of the Office of Management and Budget on Jan. 23, 1977.

title: Heart Transplant Patient Dies
description: MINNEAPOLIS, April 26 (UPI)Edwin Beeman, the state's second heart transplant recipient, died last night in the University of Minnesota Hospital. The cause of death was not immediately announced. Mr. Beeman, 46 years old, had received a heart belonging to a Minneapolis girl who died April 16, two days after a car accident.

title: Article 1  No Title
25% of Students Seeking U.S. Aid Being Rejected in Cheating Check
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)More than onefourth of the first students applying for Federal grants to cover college costs this year are being rejected by a computer programmed to catch cheating.

title: Australian Departure Reported
description: SYDNEY, Australia, Thursday April 27 Bert Lance appears to have left Australia. a spokesman for the Young Presidents Organization said this morning.

title: $13,5 BILLION BUDGET IS PROPOSED BY KOCH
description: Mayor Koch yesterday proposed a $13.5 billion budget for the fiscal year beginning July 1, which called for continued austerity in city spending but projected a slower loss of city workers next year than the Mayor had previously forecast.

title: EGYPTIANS SAY TERRORISTS AIMED AT PEACETALK SITE
description: CAIRO, April 26A terrorist group with international connections, uncovered by Egyptian authorities this month, plotted an attack against peace negotiators of Egypt and Israel, according to the Cairo prosecutor general.

title: NOT GUILTY VERDICT FINDS KILLER INSANE
description: MINEOLA, L.I., April 26Roy Slutsky, a 25yearold former mental patient, was found not guilty by reason of insanity in Nassau County Court today in the slaying last year of 16yearold Richard Lesser.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia, April 26 (AP)A Palestinian woman, the only surviving member of a group that hijacked a Lufthansa jetliner last October, was convicted ed of air piracy and terrorism and sentenced to 20 years in prison by a Somali court, the official Somali press agency reported today.

title: How Cable TV Gave Annie a Lift
description: Los ANGELES THE Academy Awardwinning Annie Hall had one distinct advantage over its four competitors. To see it, the majority of Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences voters had only to reach over and turn on their television sets.

title: Events Today
description: THE 5th OF JULY, a comedy by Lanford Wilson; directed by Marshall W. Mason; presented by the Circle Repertory Company at 99 Seventh Avenue South, 7.

title: Details of 1966 Car BreakIn Barred at Curare Trial
description: HACKENSACK, April 26The judge in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich refused today to allow the introduction of a complaint that the surgeon had made in 1966 about a mysterious breakin of his automobile while he was under investigation for the sudden deaths that had been taking place at Riverdell Hospital.

title: The Way It Is Not
description: WASHINGTON, April 26If you were watching the television network news last Monday night, on ABC or CBS, you would have learned that all the charges you have been reading in this space latelyabout President Carter firing U.S. Attorney David Marston after a call from Congressman Joshua Eilberg, who was under investigation by the prosecutor at the timewere just so much hot air.

title: Missing Parrot Stirs a Big Flap in Queens
description: Ever since George, a 3yearold scarlet macaw that could sing and dance, was reported stolen from Paradise Jungle, a pet shop in Queens, three detectives have been questioning neighbors and searching the trees. In addition, George's mate, Tara, has refused to eat, more than 50 customers have called to console the store's owner, Steven Kates, and Mr. Kates has called every single store in the five boroughs to see if anyone has tried to sell his prize bird.

title: Koch Budget Has Fewer Job Cuts
description: The only real surprise in yesterday's budget presentation by Mayor Koch was the disclosure of a decision to cut the city payroll by fewer jobs than had been planned.

title: NEW &
description: At first glance, it might be mistaken for an updated ceiling fan. No, it's a butterfly  a new lighting fixture with four plastic wings floating above the bulb. The wings come in three sizes, in solid white or white with green stripes (a rare species of butterfly?) and may be used with a ceiling or wall fix'eare or a table lamp base. Prices range from $9.25 for a set of four small white wings to $10.25 for the large striped ones. The pendant fixture to use with the wings is $12.50; the table lamp base, $30.95. All the variations can be found at Conran's, 59th Street and Third Avenue.

title: Carey to Seek Up to $50 Million To Reinforce Fight Against Crime
description: ALBANY, April 26Governor Carey, upder political pressure to toughen his anticrime program, said today that he wouldsee k to spend $20 million to $50 Million more this year and next to help judges, prosecutors and prisons handle the work brought on by the stiff new sentencing procedures the Legislature Was expected to approve soon.

title: U.S. RESTS ITS CASE IN I.B.M TRUST SUIT
description: The Government rested its case yesterday in its massive antitrust suit against the International Business Machines Corporation, more or less marking the halfway point in a trial that began nearly three years ago.

title: Will CreditTightening Lead to Recession?; The Economic Scene
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.Wall Streeters, far from worrying that the Federal Reserve may be tightening the reins on the economy too much, are blithely expressing the view that nothing would be so good for the market and the economy as a nice recessionstiff enough to reduce inflation and the trade deficit, although not so steep as to disrupt business plans for new investment or to wreck prospects for strongly rising profits in the next expansion. While private investors are free to advertise their desires for a recession of the appropriate size, however, the Federal ReServe and the Administration are not, even assuming that they were able to achieve such an acceptable recession.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an error by the Pacific Coast Stock Exchange, the day's low for shares of the Exxon Corporation in trading Monday was stated incorrectly in the stock market tables yesterday. The correct figure was $48 a share.

title: Mets Lose in 11th
description: Becalmed and apparently bewitched, the New York Mets lost their fourth straight game last night and also lost Tim Foli as their regular shortstop for at least two months.

title: About New York
description: The teacher offered his class a hard lesson: After weeks of lining up his friends, Richard Burton and Elia Kazan, the numbers would not work and so there will be no Burton as King Lear on Broadway this year. The economics is the thing as much as the play.

title: RELDANAND PRISONER GUILTY IN DEATH PLOT
description: HACKENSACK, April 26Robert Reldan, who is still awaiting trial in the murders of two Bergen County women in 1975, was found guilty with a fellow prison inmate today of conspiring to murder Mr. Reldan's wealthy aunt and her male companion.

title: No Time Out for the City
description: The decision of the Transport Workers Union to tear up all ballots and resubmit its new contract to the membership means that the transit settlement will be delayed for another month. If that delay means the loss of another month in which to persuade Washington to help New York avoid default, it would probably kill the city's hope of fiscal survival. No one engaged in the other municipal labor negotiations can afford that.

title: West Village, SoHo House Tour
description: ALOFT and house tour through SoHo and the West Village is planned on the for the benefit of the Village Cornmunity School, a small private school that provides scholarship aid for a quarter of its students.

title: Strauss Asks Help Of All Americans In Inflation Fight
description: Robert S. Strauss, in his first speech as President Carter's top inflation fighter, said yesterday that the Administration was asking each American to insure that he make some contribution to lowering inflation rates this year.

title: DICRAN SIMSARIAN, 87, OF NEW YORK LAW FIRM
description: Dicran Simsarian, a lawyer, active in national Armenian affairs and a leader of the Armenian community in New Jersey, dide yesterday of a heart attack at Englewood Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived at 1100 Arcadian Way, Palisade, N..I.

title: Notes on People
description: P RESIDENT Carter has named Evan S. Dobelle, 33 years old, the chief of protocol, to be treasurer of the Democratic National Committee. In his new post, Mr. Dobelle, formerly the Republican mayor of Pittsfield, Mass., will be the chief fundraiser for the Democratic Party, which is $2.8 million in debt. Mr. Dobelle became a Democrat in 1976. The President chose Mr. Dobelle's wife, Edith Huntington Jones Dobelle, also 33, to be the new chief of protocol. She will be the first woman to hold the post since Shirley Temple Black, who served during Gerald R. Ford's presidency. Mr. and Mrs. Dobelle will each earn $50,000 a year in their new jobs. The outgoing treasurer of the committee, Joel McClearly, is to join the White House staff.

title: SOVIET OFFICIAL IN PEKING TO RESUME BORDER TALKS
description: MOSCOW, April 26The Soviet Union and China are beginning a new round of talks on the border dispute that led to armed clashes in 1969.

title: Earthquake Felt in California
description: INGLEWOOD, Calif., April 26 (UPI)A weak earthquake shook the southern Los Angeles area late last night but apparently did no damage and caused no injuries.

title: PENTAGON PLANS CUTS IN 107 MILITARY BASES
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)The Pentagon today proposed streamlining the military base structure by closing, cutting back and combining operations at 107 installations throughout the country to save an estimated $337 million a year.

title: GASOLINE SUPPLIES DROP BY 4.4 MILLION BARRELS
description: The nation's gasoline supplies continued to fall during the week ended April 21, dropping to 255.8 million barrels from 260.2 million barrels the week before, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

title: Network Standards at Issue In Suit by Coast Attack Victim
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 26A quarrel more than three years ago among a group of chidren playing on a secluded beach near the Golden Gate Bridge has mushroomed into a court case where a television network's system of safeguards against the broadcasting of violence and bad taste is coming under close examination.

title: A Lawyer Helps Washington Get Savvy About Real Estate
description: WASHINGTON BENNY L. KASS, a lawyer, is the scourge of Washington real estate agents. He encourages home owners to sell their own homes and pocket the 6 percent that normally goes to the broker.

title: Rita Hauser Quits Republican Contest For Lefkowitz Post
description: Only a month after she announced her candidacy for the Republican nomination for New York State Attorney General, Rita E. Hauser dropped cut of the race yesterday with an attack on the Nassau County Republican chairman, Joseph M. Mareiotta. who had openly opposed her.

title: FORD BACKS ACCORD REACHED IN RHODESIA
description: Former President Gerald R. Ford said yesterday he strongly supported the Rhodesian settlement on black majority rule that was worked out last month by the Government of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith and three black leaders.

title: HEAD OF UNITED FRUIT CONFERS WITH TORRIJOS
description: PANAMA, April 26The president of the United Fruit Company asked Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera today whether he intended to nationalize the company's banana holdings here now that the Senate has approved the Panama Canal treaties.

title: Screen: Ship wrecked With 'The Sea Gypsies':In Alaska's Wilds
description: THE first fun filled minutes of "The Sea Gypsies," the latest attraction at the Radio City Music Hall, are enough to fill anyone with nameless dread. Television news crews flock to a Seattle marina, to interview a handsome young widower who plans to sail his yacht around the world, accompanied by his two cute blond daughters, their cute tawny mutt, Mushroom, and (unbenownst to anyone but all 6,000 of us in the audience) a cute young black stowaway named Jesse.Just before sailing time, who should arrive on deck but a cute female magazine reporter, who has been assigned to go along on the journey in place of an (undoubtedly) cute male reporter who has conveniently broken his leg. Is there any doubt as to how this will end? Can anyone seriously question the likelihood of Dad's falling in love with the reporter? Isn't it a sure thing that everyone will live happily ever after, off the profits from the movie sale of the best-selling book Step-Mom will write about the cruise?Miraculously, "The Sea Gypsies" turns into smooth sailing, and a very agreeable children's film, not long after the yacht pulls prettily out of the harbor. The obligatory storm sinks the boat, and the family is marooned somewhere on the Alaskan coast, amidst caribou, sea lions, and some of the loveliest snow-capped mountains in the world.Since it is summertime, the elements don't pose any severe problems for this Seattle Family Robinson, and so they can sleep in a lean-to and bask in the sunshine. Foraging, for food is a more difficult matter. Question: How can a Dad kill a caribou or a musk ox with only a homemade spear for a weapon? Answer: He can't, in a family movie like this one. The best he can do is come close enough to slaughter something, look into its limpid brown eyes, melt into a puddle of sympathy and then go out and catch fish, whose eyes aren't nearly so compelling. Parents who plan to take small children to see the film should note that G rating notwithstanding, the one sequence in which Dad does actually hunt some meat ends with the carcass's being torn apart, in close-up by a pack of wolves.The scenery is spectacular, the Alaskan birds and animals are well photographed, and the film's various lessons in survival are memorable and well worth learning. After a while, one develops an unexpected fondness not only for the principals but also for their pelican, Pinocchio, and for the pet sea lion who goes "arf-arf-arf" in moments of merriment.And the acting, while unexceptional, is more than competent. Mikki Jamison-Olsen is perky and agreeable as the reporter, and Robert Logan is a good-humored Dad; together, they're a fun couple. Shannon Saylor, as the younger daughter, is so precious she makes the sea lion look like Greta Garbo. But Heather Rattray, as the older daughter, and Cjon Damitri Patterson, as the stowaway, are spirited, personable child actors with a mercifully clear understanding that less is generally more.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: BRIGHT VICTORY This week marks the 40th anniversary of Geraldine Fitzgerald's first American stage appearance in Shaw's Heartbreak House, as presented on Broadway by Orson Welles. In a salute tonight to the distinguished actress's career, the public is invited to share in a party at Les Mouches, the club and discotheque at 559 West 26th Street, at 11th Avenue.

title: Schneider Leaves CBS to Set Up Consultancy
description: John A. Schneider, who until recently had been the top broadcasting executive at CBS Inc. and at one time seemed destined to become president of the corporation, yesterday announced his resignation to establish an independent consultancy.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Children wil not be allowed to enroll in New York City public schools this fall if their parents cannot prove that the children have been immunized against German measles, diphtheria, mumps and rubella, Chancellor Irving Anker announced. Under previous regulations, children could be enrolled without immunization, but had to be immunized within several months.

title: Rise in Xerox Sales Lifts FirstQuarter Profits 15.3% to $105.6 Million
description: Outright sales of the Xerox Corporation's duplicators and copiers jumped 37 percent, lifting profits 15.3 percent in the first quarter, the company reported. yesterday. Revenues climbed 13 percent.

title: Ban on Teacher Residence Laws Is Voted in Hartford
description: HARTFORD, April 26The Connecticut General Assembly today passed and sent to the. Governor a bill prohibiting towns and cities from requiring teachers to live in the communities where they work.

title: TV: Miss Cole, Oil, Runaway
description: AS SMOOTH and easy entertainment, The Natalie Cole Special may be geratly appreciated by the time it gets underway at 10 on CBS, but first the evening's schedule has two other items of unusual interest: a syndicated documentary, The 45 Billion Dollar Connection, and a new limitedrun weekly series, Operation Runaway.

title: BRZEZINSKI WILL GO TO CHINA ON MAY 20
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The White House announced today that President Carter's national security adviser; Zbigniew Brzezinski, would fly to Peking next month for the highestlevel talks with Chinese leaders since last summer.

title: Education Association Backs Plan On Probation Period for Teachers
description: TRENTON, April 26The New Jersey Education Association today endorsed a proposal that public schoolteachers be required to undergo a fiveyear probation before being granted a certificate to teach, and gave tenative approval to periodic evaluations to make sure that they remain competent.

title: Control Data Fined For Foreign Bribes
description: WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)The Control Data Corporation pleaded guilty today to three criminal charges that it made improper payments to unnamed foreign officials from 1967 to 1976 and was fined 51,381,000, the United Customs Service said.

title: TERMS SET ON BONDS BRITAIN TO SELL HERE
description: Terms of Britain's first public offering in the United Stateswhich the lead underwriter says is the largest issue of bonds sold here by a foreign country, aside from Canadawere set late yesterday afternoon.

title: Argentina Rejects Any Role by Parties In Political Talks
description: BUENOS AIRES, April 26The military Government said today that none of the major political parties would be allowed to participate in discussions on the country's political future.

title: Home Improvement
description: A GOOD quality exterior paint, designed for the type of surface on which it is to be used, is an important requisite for a goodlooking and longlasting paint job on the outside of any house. But the care taken in preparing the surface and applying the paint is, in many ways, even more important.

title: CHRYSLER REPORTS ITS BIGGEST DEFICIT FOR SINGLE QUARTER
description: DETROIT, April 26The Chrysler Corporation reported a $119.8 million firstquarter loss today, the biggest quarterly deficit in the company's history, and said results for the full year should be at breakeven levels.

title: Complaint Contradicts Lance on Overdrafts
description: WASHINGTON, April 26The cornplaint filed today in United States District Court in Atlanta by two Federal agencies sharply contradicts a number of assertions made by Bert Lance, the former Budget Director, in his testimony before the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee last fall.

title: Persevering Against Truancy
description: More than 100,000 New York City students skip school on any given day. That startling figure comes from a recent report by the New York Senate Democratic task force on truancy, which also found that more than a quarter of the city's high school students were out every day in 1976. Small wonder that a police study has concluded that twothirds of crimes committed by the young occur between 8 A.M. and 4 P.M. But another and perhaps greater crime is the loss in vocational preparation and job skills that is the consequence of absenteeism.

title: Judge Facing Reversal On LegalAid Effort
description: WATERTOWN, N, Y., April 25Long before Warren E. Burger, Chief Justice of the United States, began publicly picking on incompetent lawyers, Leon Schwerzmann Jr., the Jefferson County Surrogate, was complaining about the low quality of legal representation. He even quit the local bar association 17 years ago in disgust over lawyers.

title: Article 3  No Title
Film: 'The Foreigner':Sight and Sound
description: "I DON'T deserve this," the title character of "The Foreigner" is heard to say as he reclines in numb despair on his bed at the Chelsea Hotel. It is a thought likely to be shared by whatever audiences are attracted to the film, which is being shown through Sunday as part of the New American Filmmakers Series at the Whitney Museum."The Foreigner" deals with the "punk" sensibility as manifested at CBGB, the rock nightclub on the Bowery; the streets and lofts of SoHo and the leather bars of the West Village.The subject is not without interest, although punk seems to have lost some of its spark in the six months or so since the film was made. The trouble is that no one in the cast, which includes a couple of comely young women, has the least idea of how to act, the story is infantile and the photography, sound and editing are primitive in a way that stopped being amusing 10 years ago."The Foreigner" was written, produced and directed by Amos Poe, with the assistance, as a screen credit coyly notes, of a $5,000 personal loan from the Merchants Bank of New York. It seems Incredible that a museum that is exhibiting Saul Steinberg on the third floor should be showing the cinematic equivalent of kindergarten scribbles on the second.

title: 4A's Plans to Sponsor Executive Volunteers
description: PHOENIX, April 26A leading association in the advertising industry, a field constantly under the guns of Governmental regulatory agencies, voted today to get involved in legislative and Governmental activities for the first time.

title: Radio
description: 69 A.M. WKCR. It's Gonna Rain, Reich; The Death of Virginia Woolf, Namchub; Drumming, Reich.

title: JUSTICE TYLER WINS CONVICTION REVERSAL
description: The perjury conviction of Justice Andrew R. Tyler was overturned yesterday by an appellate court that criticized the prosecutor's office for having encouraged the judge to give false testimony to a grand jury.

title: News Summary
description: A conspiracy charge was made by the Uriited States against a 35yearold. American recently extradited from Chile in the murder of Orlando Letelier, the former Chilean Ambassador who was killed when a bomb destroyed his car in Washington in 1976. At a bail hearing in Federal District Court in Washington, a Government lawyer identified Michael Vernon Townley, who had lived in Chile since 1958, as an agent of the Chilean intelligence service. [Page A1, Column 5.]

title: Garrett Ties Homer Mark
description: TOKYO, April 26 (AP)Adrian Garrett. formerly of the California Angels and Chicago Cubs, tied the Japanese record of 15 home runs in one month today as his Hiroshima Toyo Carp played a 77 tie with the Hanshin Tigers. Sadaharu Oh is among three players who have accomplished the feat.

title: MONTREAL DEPLORES SUN LIFE PLAN TO GO
description: MONTREAL, April 26The decision by Canada's largest insurance company to move its headquarters from Montreal to Toronto was generally deplored today in business and political circles. Most of the blame was put on Quebec's government because it wants to make the province a separate, essentially. Frenchspeaking nation.

title: Corporation Earnings Reported for the Latest Quarter
description: See notes below for special items

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: ADA MAY WEEKS

title: Baryshnikov to Join City Ballet in July
description: After four years with the Americar Ballet Theater, Mikhail Baryshnikov will leave that company to join the New York City Ballet, which is directed by George Balanchine and Lincoln Kirstein.

title: Excerpts From Koch Message to Board of Estimate and Council on 1979 Budget
description: The executive revenue, expense and capital budgets which we are submitting to you today present the first lap of the financial course charted in the fouryear financial plan. Developed

title: Chamber Society's Plans
description: FOR its 10th anniversary season, starting next October, the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center has commissioned works by four American composers and will inaugurate a vocal chamber music series. Beverly Sills will be the guest artist on the first vocal program.

title: NOT GUILTY VERDICT FINDS KILLER INSANE
description: MINEOLA, L.I., April 26Roy Slutsky, a 25yearold former mental patient, was found not guilty by reason of insanity in Nassau County Court today in the slaying last year of 16yearold Richard Lesser.

title: Court Ruling on Pensions Is Held Unlikely to Affect Private Plans
description: The Supreme. Court's decision barring sexbased rates in employee pensions will apparently have little effect on private business.

title: After Repeal of Homosexual Bias Law, St. Paul Debates the Implications
description: ST. PAUL, April 26Donald Adams paused today in the bright morning sunlight, looked across the Mississippi River, sucked in a deep breath and proclaimed the good weather a sign that God was pleased with the city.

title: Laws Aiding Homosexuals Face Rising Opposition Around Nation
description: As voters in St. Paul. turning out Tuesday in larger numbers than usual for an offyear election, repealed that city's homosexual rights ordinance, antihomoszxual organizations in other cities werz accelerating their efforts to repeal similar measures.

title: Letters
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:

title: Bridge
description: The high spot of the year for most Long Island enthusiasts is the Long Island Regional championships, which attract most of the New York experts and others from as far afield as Boston and Washington.

title: Suspect in Bomb Death of Letelier Said to Agree to Aid U.S. Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, April 27A 35yearold American, who has been charged in the bomb slaying of former Ambassador Orlando Leteliee of .Chile, has agreed to supply information about the plot to United States auhorities, two Government sources here said today.

title: Revision in Test for Admission To Law School Leads to Dispute
description: An unusually high number of students who took a modified examination, widely used as a criterion for admission to law school, achieved high scores, calling the results into question, confusing admissions officers, upsetting applicants who took earlier versions and embarrassing the organization that prepares and administers the test.

title: CARTER ORDERS SALE OF URANIUM TO INDIA FOR POWER FACILITY
description: WASHINGTON, April 27President Carter overruled the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today and ordered the sale of more than eight tons of enriched uranium to India for its Tarapur nuclear power plant outside Bombay.

title: LEVITT ISSUES A REPORT THAT CRITICIZES GOLDIN
description: ALBANY, April 27State Comptroller Arthur Levitt issued a report today repeating a series of old criticisms he had made of his rival, City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin. But he said the review carried no political significance at all. despite the fact that Mr. Goldin is runnine hard for Mr. Levitt's job.

title: FORD NET OFF 3.4% ON RECORD SALES
description: The Ford Motor Company reported yesterday that earnings for the first quarter were down 3.4 percent. It attributed the decline primarily to a shift from more profitable big cars to smaller cars and to higher costs of materials and labor.

title: In SoHo, Revue of Songs. By Women Tunesmiths
description: Can you name five women songwriters? That is the question Vince Napoli has been asking his friends lately. It's not that he has been running around as a torchbearer for the feminist cause. Mr. Napoli has been testing the thesis of Womansong, his new musical revud for the Atlantic Players that begins previews tonight at the WardNasse Gallery in SoHo.

title: Gold and Silver Up In Futures Trading
description: CHICAGO, April 27 (AP)  Precious metals futures reversed their recent downtrend today, influenced by renewed weakness of the dollar and the stock market.

title: Some in Saratoga Hope Wheel of Fortune Bring a Returns to Casino Gambling
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.In the Victorian years, when Saratoga Springs was the queen of the spas, noted for its horse racing, mineral waters and social life, Richard Canfield, known as the prince of gamblers, transformed a gambling club into a luxurious casino. Saratoga remained wide open, even when gambling became illegal, until the late 1940's.

title: Private Schools Provoking ChurchState Conflict
description: ATLANTA, April 27So many churchsponsored grammar and high schools have been opened in the United States in the last decade that education officials in some states are now beginning to monitor their effectiveness, thereby precipitating a number of serious church.

title: UAL QUARTER PROFIT IS RECORD $17 MILLION
description: UAL, the parent company of the nation's largest airline, United, announced at its annual meeting in Chicago yesterday that the $17.1 million earned in the first quarter was the best such period in UAL's history.

title: Art People
description: AS a topic, education in art museums is vastly less sexy than, say, the exhibitions or the politics of these worthy institutions. Most lay observers and some professionals don't quite know what museum education is (in a nutshell, it can be defined as whatever museums do to heighten visitors enjoyment of art). Many museum education departments are low on the funding ladder, sometimes tucked away in basement quarters and not exactly overreported on.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: Yanks Get Strong Stint By Hunter
description: Manager Billy Martin, anxious to determine whether Jim (Catfish) Hunter, the righthander with the expensive arm, was ready to take his regular turn on the mound for the New York Yankees and received good reason last night to think affirmatively.

title: How to See the Five Boroughs by Pedal Power
description: The city will belong to its bicycle riders Sunday, from the Bronx to Staten Island, when several thousand cyclists are expected to take to the road in the American Youth Hostels Five Boro Bike Tour.

title: WEEKEND MOVIE CLOCK; MANHATTAN; BRONX; BROOKLYN; STATEN ISLAND; QUEENS; QUEENS (Cont'd); LONG ISLAND; LONG ISLAND (Cont'd); ROCKLAND; WESTCHESTER; FAIRFIELD
description: Below 42d Street

description: ARRIVING TOMORROW, April 79

title: Events and Openings
description: FM, directed by John A. Alonzo; stamen Michael Brandon and Eileen Brennan, at the Criterion and 86th Twin 2 Theaters.

title: Carter Backs a $500 Million Plan To Improve Mental Health Care
description: WASHINGTON, April 27President Carter pledged his support today for a $500 million program to improve mental health care in the nation.

title: Sports Today
description: Mets vs. Cincinnati Reds, at Shea Stadium, Roosevelt Avenue and 126th Street, Flushing Meadow, Queens, 8 P.M.

title: The Economic Scene
description: Thomas E. Mullaney discusses ways under consideration to case homebuilding costsincluding permission for the lumber industry to cut more timber in national forests. Page D11.

title: Lance Barred From Bank Control Without Offer to Sell Back Stock
description: WASHINGTON, April 27A Federal judge today temporarily barred Bert Lance, the former Budget Director, and eight of his associates from gaining controlling interest in Finanelal Gerral Bankshares Inc. unless the Lance group offers to sell back the stock it accumulated, in apparent violation of Federal securities laws, to the original sellers.

title: Burger and Press Freedom
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  Chief Justice Warren E. Burger has provided his friends and critics in the news media with a fasclinating outline of his personal reluctance to endow what he calls the institutional press with special privileges based on the Constitution's guarantees of press freedom. Ordinarily, the public has very little access to the philosophy of Supreme Court justices. other than the carefully delineated opinions they write, which are traditionally closely limited to the issues posed by the particular case before the Court. But yesterday Justice Burger supplemented a high court ruling an political free speech for corporations with a 2,000word essay cautioning corporations that are partly or wholly in the news business that their freedoms might prove to be narrower than they believe.

title: Flu Program Is Opposed
description: TRENTON, April 27 (AP)Dr. Robert Altman, director of epidemology for thState Health Department and opponent of a proposed $15 million fluimmunization program, said today that claims for damages resulting from the mass innoculations could be as high as $228 million.

title: Open Interest; (In bushels, 000 omitted)
description: THURSDAY, APRIL 27, 1978

title: NATO Worried About Its Flank
description: BAGNOI.I, ItalyTurkey and Greece represent the most important problem in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, bar none, said Adm. Harold E. Shear in an interview. And unless it is resolved there will be no viable alliance. no southern flank for NATO.

title: Obituary 1  No Title
description: GEORGE COX

title: Coup Is Reported in Afghanistan
description: BOMBAY, India, Friday, April 28President Mohammad Daud of Afghanistan was killed yesterday in a bloody and violent coup, according to reports reaching here from Kabul, the capital.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Staten Island Democrat Is Appointed by Mayor To Planning Commission
description: John P. Gulino, law chairman of the Staten Island Democratic County Committee, was named by Mayor Koch yesterday to fill a vacancy on the City Planning Commission.

title: Dollar Drops in Trade Deficit
description: The dollar fell sharply against major currencies in world foreign exchange trading yesterday following reports of a record United States deficit with Japan and further wrangling in Congress over energy policy, The Associated Press reported.

title: Jury Resumes Its Deliberations In Murder Case Against Doctor
description: SANTA ANA, Calif., April 27 (AP)A jury of nine men and three women returned to its deliberations today in the case of Dr. William Waddill Jr., charged with murdering a baby. The jury had listened for a day and a half to a reading of the defendant's testimony.

title: Carter Acts to Bolster White House Consumer Office
description: WASHINGTON, April 27President Carter, saying that the Federal Government must respond adequately to consumer needs when making policy, announced today a series of actions to strengthen the White House Office of Consumer Affairs.

title: Theater: 5 th of July Staged
description: YOU CANNOT build a serviceable bridge out of flowers unless you are an ant; and Lanford Wilson's vocabulary of freaks, sensitive and even charming as it may be, is not the right material to construct the history of a decade.

title: Trimming Cost of Home Building By Cutting Into National Forests
description: In each of the three housing booms in the United States during the last decade, a similar scenario unfolded.
