First, there was a surge in demand for new homes, then a sharp rise in the price of lumber products, and finally a Congressional or Administration investigation to determine whether programs could be developed to reduce home building costs. Each time, Washington perceived the same solution: increase timber supplies from the national forests, which contain slightly more than half of the country's softwood timber.

title: Aides Say Bell Hurt F.B.I. Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, April 27Four of the lawyers who originally headed the investigation into a series of breakins by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New York accused Attorney General Griffin B. Bell today of having seriously undercut their inquiry and of having hamstrung their efforts to pursue important leads.

title: Notes on People
description: With a cowboy hat perched at a rakish angel on his head, John Wayne left Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston yesterday. I feel great, the best I have felt in a long time, said the 70yearold actor, who later boarded a private jet at Logan International Airport and headed for his home in California. Mr. Wayne, who underwent surgery three weeks ago to replace a defective valve of the heart, was asked whether he were frightened at any time in his hospital stay. The movie hero's reply was, Ah, hell, sure.

title: Concern Rising Over Costs Of Kidney Dialysis Program
description: WASHINGTON, April 27Congressmen and Government officials have become increasingly concerned over the rocketing costs of a Federal program that is sustaining the lives of an increasing number of Americans, now about 40,000 people, who are suffering from acute kidney disease.

title: E.E.C. WARNS PARTNERS OF TRADE RETALIATIONS
description: GENEVA, April 27The European Economic Community announced today that it had formally informed its trading partners of retaliatory moves it would make if they failed to improve their offers of tariff concessions in the current round of world trade negotiations.

title: Dayan Meets Vance On Ways to Revive Middle East Talks
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel said today that he and Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance had exchanged some new ideas on how to break the impasse in the Middle East negotiations and that now the proposals had to be studied by their governments.

title: Where to Stop to Eat on Your Outdoor Stroll
description: Artgallery hopping being both a mental and physical exercise, it's vital to know where, along the way, to find some proper nourishment. From 57th Street to 86th Street along Madison Avenueor say, from the curent exhibition of the late American Constructivist Burgoyne Diller at the Washburn Gallery to the show of ceramic trucks and portraits by Dennis Clive and John Hegarty, respectively, at the Stone Gallerythere is a good range of dining possibilities.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a mechanical error, continuationpage numbers for the two main articles in The Home Section were given incorrectly yesterday. The two articles, which began on Page A1, were continued on Page A6.

title: For Children
description: WILDFLOWER WALK, nest trout lilies, spring beauties and other wildflowers, will begin at 10 A.M. on Saturday led by Mary Plant, who will Present a slide show first, narrated by her husband, Walter, a biology teacher, at the Bartlett Arboretum, 151 Brookdale Road, Slarniord. The free program is sponsored by the Bartlett Arboretum Association and the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources of the University of Connecticut, Call (203) 3226911.

title: Reversal in Tyler Case Rekindles Debate Over Special Prosecutor and the Judiciary
description: Twelve judges have been indicted in the last five years by grand juries under the supervision of the office of the special state prosecutor for corruption in New York City's criminaljustice system. Twelve judges have been cleared, nine of them before their cases reached the trial stage.

title: Hawkins Is Still Giving Message
description: How do you tell people? Erick Hawkins leaned forward in his chair as he spoke of his work and the often puzzled reception it has encountered over the years. The choreographer's fleeting sense of urgency seemed out of place in the serene setting of his Greenwich Village living room, a spare white rectangle decorated, as are his dances, with the simplest and most stylized of ornaments. The paradoxical play of emotions is evident in Mr. Hawkins's work as well. Audiences at the Roundabout Theater this weekend will witness both the cool, easeful abstraction and the need to communicate an esthetic unique in American modern dance.

title: New Battle Over Copyrights
description: The American Society of Authors and Journalists, which represents 500 of the major freelance writers of nonfiction, accused some of the nation's magazine publishing chains yesterday of trying to subvert the intention of the new Copyright Act, which went into effect last January, by turning them into hirelings or insisting that they owned no rights to the material they wrote.

title: Teachers Vote to Unionize
description: PROVIDENCE, April 27 (AP)The faculty of the Rhode Island School of Design has voted, 66 to 12, to unionize.

title: Dance: Murray Louis Has His Night at Beacon
description: IT was Murray Louis night on Wednesday at the Beacon Theater, where the Nikolais Dance Theater is appearing through tomorrow. True, the audience was treated to the new Gallery, Mr. Nikolais's comic and chilling view of a carnival shooting gallery. The remainder of the program was devoted to Mr. Louis, however, and it provided a kind of quick retrospective look at hi's work.

title: Weicker Disputes F.T.C.'s Head on TV Inquiry
description: WASHINIGTON, April 27  Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr., in an angry exchange with Michael Pertschuk, chairman of the Federal Trade Commission, has hinted that he might try to cut off the agency's appropriation if it does not call off its investigation of children's television advertising.

title: Art: Resurgence In El Barrio
description: OPENING tomorrow, Resurgimento inaugurates the new premises of El Museo del Barrio (through June 30). Now situated at 1250 Fifth Avenue (between 104th and 105th Streets), the museum occupies the ground floor of what was formerly the Heckscher Foundationa neoGeorgian pile that, if no longer in its prime, provides excellent space and a courtyard facing Central Park, now filled with blossoms.

title: Ehrlichman Leaves Prison, Saying He's a Better Man
description: SAFFORD, Ariz., April 27 (AP)John D. Ehrlichman, grinning broadly, walked out of Swift Trail Federal Priscn Camp today, 18 months after he was imprisoned there for his role in the Watergate affair.

title: Article 1  No Title
A Vietnamese Diplomat Accuses Cambodian Troops of Atrocities
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka, April 27 (Reuters)  Vietnam's Ambassador to Sri Lanka said today that Cambodia had stepped up its border attacks on Vietnam and he charged Cambodian soldiers with committing barbarous atrocities.

title: Koch Shows Net Worth As $106,890 on Dec. 31
description: Mayor Koch paid $18,298 in total income taxes last year on income of $53,605, and his net worth on Dec. 31 was $106,890.38, according to financial documents released yesterday by the Mayor's office.

title: Kleindienst and Fitzsimmons Linked to Teamster Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, April 27Frank E. Fitzsimmons, president of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, and Richard G. Kleindienst, the former Attorney General, are key figures in a criminal investigation under way as part of a nationwide effort by the Justice Department to clean up corruption in the teamsters union.

title: Article 2  No Title
Italian Pilots Continue Strike
description: ROME, April 27 (Reuters)  Italian pilots working for the domestic airline A.T.I, rebelled against their union leaders today and continued a strike in protest against the dismissal of a captain.

title: Music: Viktor Friedman
description: MUSSORGSKY'S Pictures at an Exhibition is a work that has attracted increasing attention from pianists in the last feW years, especially keyboard athletes who love to show how fast and furiously they can negotiate the welter of notes the composer packed into this unconventional set of pieces. Unfortunately, many performers achieve little more than displays of crackingly efficient technique.

title: Market Place
description: Shares of the Twentieth CenturyFox Film Corporation have risen by two and a half times since the smash hit Star Wars made its debut last May, and a string of other successful pictures has since kept the company healthy.

title: Abrams Enters the Race for State Attorney General
description: Borough President Robert Abrams of the Bronx yesterday announced his formal entry into the race for State Attorney General, a post that eluded him four years ago, when he was beaten by the incumbent, Louis J. Lefkowitz.

title: Apples Take A115 Sets, Trounce Loves, 3319
description: At halftime of last night's New York Apples  Indiana Loves team tennis match the Apples rewarded 12 lucky ticket holders by handing them a racquet and giving them a chance to return service against an Apple. The Apple was Ray Ruffels, the team's resident twist server. Ruffels spun each of the 12 an assortment of junk that could get him a spot in the Mets pitching rotation. Only three people got enough strings on the ball to send it back over the net and win a gift basket of such things as peanuts, cake and gelatin.

title: Music: Levine and Jacobs Play Pianos at Philharmonic Concert
description: TWO things were unusual about last night's New York Philharmonic program. One was the presence of the first book of the Brahms Liebeslieder Waltzes. Brahms composed these for vocal quartet or for chorus al lib, and piano four hands. Normally this work turns up on chamber music programs; by no stretch of the imagination can it be considered symphonic.

title: 51 Killed in Collapse of Scaffold At Power Plant in West Virginia
description: WILLOW ISLAND, W.Va., April 27Scaffolding inside the cooling tower of an unfinished power plant here tore loose this morning, dropping 51 workers 170 feet to their deaths.

title: Increase Is 2d in Bid to Curb Inflation
description: The Federal Reserve yesterday raised shortterm interest rates decisively for the second time within eight days in an acceleration of its drive to curb inflation.

title: Back in Utah, the Real World of Kennecott
description: SALT LAKE CITYIn boarcirocms and on Wall Street, the managements of the Kennecott Copper Corporation and the CurtissWright Corporation, a New Jersey aerospace concern, are slugging it out to see who will control the last of the independent American copper companies. They are engaged in the biggest proxy fight since the early 1960's, with the outcome to he decided at Kennecott's annual meeting May 2.

title: HOUSE SPEAKER PUTS NET WORTH AT $181,000
description: WASHINGTON, April 27Describing himself as a man of modest means, House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. reported today that his net worth was $181,000. This figure was $56,000 higher than the one Mr. O'Neill provided in December 1976.

title: PARKING RULES
description: Because of Passover. alternatesloe parking restrictions will he suspended today and tomorrow where the restrictions are normally in effect from A.M. to 11 A.M. or 11 A.M. to 2 P.M. They will also he suspended in areas where alternateday, alternateside parking is in effect from 8 A.M. to 6 P.M.; in the Manhattan garment center from 2 A.M. to 6 A.M., and at alternateday, alternateside parking meters from 8 A.M. to 9 A.M.

title: L.I. Police Mount a Gift Drive
description: MINEOLA, L. I., April 27The Nassau Ccunty Police Department is looking for gift horses to look in the mouth.

title: PARKING RULES
description: Because of Passover, alternateside parking restrictions will be suspended today and tomorrow where the restrictions are normally in effect from 8 A.M. to 11 A.M. or 11 A.M. to 2 P.M. They will also be suspended in areas where alternateday, alternateside parking is in effect from 8 A.M. to 6 P.M.; in the Manhattan garment center from 2 A.M. to 6 A.M., and at alternateday, alternateside parking meters from 8 A.M. to 9 A.M.

title: Jersey Bluegrass Rises From Ashes
description: Ten months after a fire almost destroyed it, the Englishtown Music Hall reopens tonight with a threeday bluegrass marathon.

title: Long Island Water Study Favors Smaller Sewer Systems in Future
description: HAUPPAUGE, LI., April 27A cornprenensive study of. Long Island's water supply and disposal problems has concluded that there may never be a need for another widearea sewer system such as is now being constructed in the southwestern corner of Suffolk County.

title: Some in Saratoga Hope Wheel of Fortune Brings a Return to Casino Gambling
description: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y.In the Victorian years, when Saratoga Springs was the queen of the spas. noted for its horse racing, mineral waters and social life, Richard Canfield, known as the prince of gamblers. transformed a gambling club into a luxurious casino. Saratoga remained wide open, even when gambling became illegal, until the late 1940's.

title: 110 Alydar Triumphs by 13 Lengths
description: LEXINGTON, Ky., April 27If the contestants had been football players instead of racehorses, it would have been a nocontract signal drill. In boxing, it would have amounted to nothing more than a harmless sparring session designed for conditioning rather than competition.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, APRIL 28, 1978

title: Management
description: The computer is a muscle and not A brain. Computers do not commit fraud but they can facilitate or cover un evidence of human fraud, W. Donald Georgen, a partner of Touche Ross & Company, the large accounting firm, commented recently. He was giving a talk entitled Would Equity Funding Happen to You?

title: Broadway
description: DORIS COLE ABRAHAMS will bring Molire in Spite of Himself to Broadway next season. The play by Mikhail Bulgakov is now at the Colonnades Theater on Lafayette Street, and after Richard Eder of The New York Times saw it there he wrote that it was a brilliantly theatrical study of power. It is about Molire and Louis XIV, and because It was written in 1929, it is also about Bulgakov and Stalin. Molire and King Louis are star parts. Therefore, Ivirs. Abrahams and Michael Lessac, who directed the play at the Colonnades and will now direct it uptown, will cast stars. They have a list. They are working on it now.

title: Dayan and Vance Exchange Ideas On Ways to Revive Mideast Talks; Begin Offered SelfRule Plan
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  Foreign Minister Moshe Dayan of Israel said today that he and Secretary of State Cyrus R. Vance had exchanged some new ideas on how to break the impasse in the Middle East negotiations and that now the proposals had to be studied by their governments.

title: Around the Nation
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 (UPI)Defense lawyers and prosecutors in the case of Patricia Hearst are under an order not to disclose the results of an appeal seeking to keep her from returning to prison for her robbery conviction. .

title: Duration of Animal Experiments In 1960's an Issue at Curare Trial
description: HACKENSACK, N. J. April 27The prosecution in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich called the controller of the New Jersey College of Medicine and Dentistry as a witness today in an effort to disprove the defendant's contention that he did animal experiments there in 1965 and 1966.

title: LANCE GRAND JURY REPORTED TO FOCUS ON HIS BANK LOANS
description: WASHINGTON, April 27A Federal grand jury investigating Bert Lance for possible criminal activities while he was a banker is concentrating on whether there was a pattern of fraud in his borrowings from a group of small northwest Georgia banks before he became director of the Office of Management and Budget, according to a source familiar with the proceedings.

title: HUDSON CALLED TEST IN RACE FOR SENATE
description: NORTH BERGEN, April 27The three major candidates for the Democratic nomination for United States Senator from New Jersey agreed today that the vote in Hudson County would play a big role in determining the winner.

title: Construction Unions and Employers Sign 3Year Pact in Philadelphia
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 27 (UPI)Philadelphia area contractors and union leaders today signed a threeyear agreement with a 3.9 percent increase in pay and benefits for workers in the building trades.

title: Twins End A's Streak at 8 by 61
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 27 (UPI)Gary Serum, making his first major league start, halted Minnesota's ninegame losing streak and ended Oakland's winning streak at eight games today when he pitched a fivehitter to lead the Twins to a 61 victory over the A's.

title: Big Board Reports on insiders
description: The New York Stock Exchange issued this week reports of changes in the shareeholdings of officers, directors and large stockholders in companies whose shares are listed on the exchange.

title: Screen: Mr. Smith Goes to L.A.:Airwave Nostalgia
description: THE CROWDS are massed beneath the windows, chanting their support for the strikers inside. The strikers are the staff of Los Angeles's hippest radio station, and they are standing up against corporate hypocrisy, standing up for hipsters everywhere, telling the Establishment where it can get off. The throngs are so fired with admiration that they are on the verge of rioting, when suddenly the much-beloved station manager, Jeff Dugan (Michael Brandon), makes a plea for sanity and brotherhood. The strikers will give up, he says sadly. But, he promises, "we'll give you what you want and if we can't do it here, we'll do it someplace else.""No you won't!" croaks someone in the audience. The someone proves to be the station's curmudgeonly old owner, and he has been so moved by his staff's honesty, integrity and general panache that he is now willing to let them do everything just as they please. Good vibes will prevail, and the profits will be damned. And so ends the sort of episode that one might have thought went out with Day-Glo paint and strobe lights."FM," which opens today at the Criterion and 86th Street Twin 2 Theaters, turns into a preposterously self-serving variation on 1960's themes. It also falls into another grand tradition, that of the 70's movie-in-search-of-a-Jello-mold. These days evidently, it is possible to bankroll a film merely by suggesting a suitably hang-loose environment: car wash, hippie newspaper office, hippie radio station, country music town, high school, drugstore, musty old attic, whatever.If this sort of thing were only being done by the George Lucases and Robert Altmans of this world, it might amount to something. But since "American Graffiti" and "Nashville," none of the bungled movies in this newly amorphous spirit have significantly broken ground.Instead, they wind up double-dealing, keeping up contemporary appearances with loud rock soundtracks while falling back on the hoariest movie devices. "FM" at various times comparesnot at all favorablywith "Mr. Smith Goes to Washington," a wide variety of soap operas, "Network" and "The Mary Tyler Moore Show."The film's premise has to do with the corporate co-option of hip enterprise. QSKY, a popular station evidently owned by a conglomerate, is under pressure to play more commercials and turn a bigger profit, and the station's personnel feel too responsible to their audience to let these changes take place without a fight. The problem is certainly a real one, for rock radio stations everywhere. But Ezra Sacks's screenplay manages, by taking this crisis so very, very seriously, not to take it seriously at all.One bone of contention, for instance, involves the staff's unwillingness to broadcast rock jingles advertising the new "fun" Army, jingles that turn up on real radio stations everywhere.Instead of sending up these ads gently or letting them work as automatic self-parody, Mr. Sacks insists on calling in the troops, quite literally, and machine-gunning a potentially stinging episode to death. His script introduces a giggling, unhinged, pot-smoking Army officer who merrily suggests that perhaps we went to Vietnam just to commandeer their marijuana supply.John A, Alonzo, the former cinematographer who directed the film, is still very much a cinematographer; he specializes in up-to-the-minute, very Robert Altman-ish, slow, pull-back shots that are slightly, piquantly out of kilter. The look of the film is convincing, and its soundtrack very well-chosen. The hair and costumes are particularly effective, rich with an amusingly studied casualness that seems apt. Mr. Alonzo has also assembled a number of gifted satirical actors to play the station's superstars. But his direction is so frequently slack, and Mr. Sacks's script so frequently dopey, that the players seldom have enough to do.Eileen Brennan plays the station's night-shift seductress, and her very tone of voice is enough to bring on a hoot or two. Mr. Sacks, however, gives her nothing more interesting to work with than the character's growing weariness with rock-and-roll. Michael Brandon, who was so appealing as the young groom in "Lovers and Other Strangers," delivers the script's jiviest lines in a seductively deadpan style. Martin Mull, who is more or less playing Ted Knight, has some very funny moments, one of them a wonderful pantomime battle with Mr. Brandon, a battle so full of earnest sensitivity and psycho-hooey that Mr. Mull ends up tearfully sucking his thumb."FM," which is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), is full of buxom, imbecilic women just dying to fling themselves at the station's superstars. Mr. Mull manages to catch most of them.

title: TERRY CARPENTER, 78, DIES
description: SCOTTSBLUFF, Neb. April 27 (UPI)Terry Carpenter, a millionaireturnedpolitician who was often called Terrible Terry because of his political gibes at political powers from Franklin Roosevelt to Richard M. Nixon, died today. He was 78 years old.

title: It's Also Boutiquesville
description: Fifth Avenue has its department stores and higherpriced European boutiques, but for sheer variety of places to browse and shop, there's nothing like Madison Avenue. It's the Faubourg St.Honore, Bond Street and the Via Condotti all rolled into one.

title: De Beers Surcharge On Diamonds Is Cut
description: De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd., the world's largest diamond mining and marketing concern, said it was cutting its surcharge on rough diamonds from 40 to 25 percent because there were signs that the current surge of speculation was subsiding.

title: Plan for Shift in Revenue Sharing From Townships to Cities Gains
description: TRENTON, April 27A controversial plan that could shift several million dollars in Federal revenue sharing from townships to cities in New Jersey cleared a Senate committee today.

title: Carter Proclaims Loyalty Day
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI)President Carter today proclaimed May 1 as Loyalty Day. Some things will remain constant, he said. Among these is the loyalt yof the American people.

title: Hungarian Trade Bill Gains in House
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (Reuters) The Ways and Means Committee of the Iioue of Representatives today approved Presiden Carters request to give Hungary ryesfavoredcation status in the form of low import tariffs granted to most of the Un:ted talcs trade partners. Both the full House and the Senate are expected to approve the bill, allow'ng Hungary t o join Poland, Yugoslavia and Rumania as the only Communist nations Rumnnia as he only Communist nations accorded low tariffs.

title: Women Get Day At Relays
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 27Kim Raison could not stop crying. She was excited and overwhelmed, and the tears dribbled down her face.

title: Faculty Seeks to Oust Brooklyn College Chief
description: More than 100 Brooklyn College professors called yesterday for the resignations of Dr. John W. Kneller and Dr. Donald R. Reich, the school's president and provost, in a continuing controversy betwesen the faculty and the administration over leadership. Dr. Kneller rebuffed the resignation suggestions.

title: TV WEEKEND
description: WHEN a beauty contest is one of the few items to loom prominently on the programming horizon, it is safe to conclude that this is not a banner weekend for television watching. The contest in this instance is the Miss U.S.A. pageant, and it will be carried live from Charleston, S. C., on CBS tomorrow from 10 P.M. to midnight. Bob Barker and Helen O'Connell are the hosts. Jack Jones is the singer. At some point in the festivities, the contestants promise to sing You're Never Fully Dressed Without a Smile.

title: TERRORISTS IN ITALY SHOOT AUTO OFFICIAL
description: ROME, April 27The extremist Red Brigades, in yet another terrorist attack, shot and wounded a labor relations official in Turin today while maintaining ominous silence about its prisoner, former Prime Minister Aldo Moro.

title: At the Movies
description: IN HIS 53d year, Rod Steiger is nearly as intense, communicative and opinionated as he was in 1954, when he established his reputation in On the Waterfront, which won the Academy Award for best picture of the year, and in 1967, when he won it himself for his role in In the Heat of the Night.

title: Lebanon Parliament Votes to Ban Militias And Guerrilla Moves
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 27The Lebanese Parliament voted today in favor of banning all private militia forces and all Palestinian guerrilla activity in Lebanon.

title: $2.1 Billion Capital Budget at Shell
description: HOUSTON, April 27The Shell Oil Company announced today that planned $2.1 billion in capital expenditures this year, 6 percent more than in 1977 and up 30 percent from 1976. Much of the money will go toward steppedup drilling in the lower 48 states, it said.

title: The Pop Life
description: IAN DURY, who will make his New York debut at the Bottom Line Tuesday and Wednesday nights, is a British rockandroller who is now in the midst of his first American tourwhich followed immediately on the heels of his first European tour. He has a fine debut album out, called New Boots and Panties, and he's been winning enthusiastic reviews as the opening act for Patti Smith and, most of the time, Lou Reed.

title: May Reopening Set For Apollo Theater
description: The Apollo Theater in Harlem, which was closed in 1976 after 42 years as a showcase for black entertainers, will reopen May 5 following extensive renovation of its public and backstage facilities.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a mechanical error, continuationpage numbers for the two main articles in The Home Section were given incorrectly yesterday. The two articles, which began on Page A1, were continued on Page A6.

title: U.S. GAINS IN BID TO SPEED A.T.&T. ANTITRUST TRIAL
description: WASHINGTON, April 27The Justice Department won an important victory today in its effort to speed up pretrial phases of the Government's civil antitrust suit against the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Art and Life in Nigeria
description: Robert B. Johnson, coowner of one of the largest private collections of Nigerian art in the world, stood on a ladder in Gallery 77 of the Americone Museum of Natural History the other evening, helping to mount an exhibition of more than 100 pieces from that collection.

title: 51 Killed in Collapse of Scaffold At Power Plant in West Virginia
description: WILLOW ISLAND, W.Va., April 27Scaffolding inside the cooling tower of an unfinished power plant here tore loose this morning, dropping 51 workers 170 feet to their deaths.

title: Germans Buy TV Holocaust
description: BONN, April 27West German television officials today disclosed that they had bought the Holocaust series on the Nazi extermination of the Jews for showing here by the end of this year or early next year.

title: Some Zairians Get Rich Quick, And a Few Are Brought to Justice
description: KINSHASA, Zaire  For nine days Zaire's former Minister of Justice, Manpuya Kanuk'a Tshiabo, traipsed up the steps of the supreme court buiading to sit in the dock.

title: Donald A. Roberts, 80
description: Donald A. Roberts, professor emeritus of English at City College and an authority on the works of John Milton and his 17thcentury contemporaries, died yesterday at Oak Bluffs in Martha's Vineyard, Mass. Professor Roberts, who had lived in Oak Bluffs since his retirement in 1963, was 80 years old.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Someone at the C.W, Post Center of Long Island University in Greenvale read the 1945 play Dark of the Moon and came up with the idea: Its mountain setting would be the theme of this year's American Arts Festival, opening today. The multimedia event, which continues through May 6, is a mix of music, art exhibits, lec ures, dance and, of course, performances of Dark of the Moon by Howard Richardson and William Bernoy. The play goes on ton??ght end tomorrow at 9; admission is $3. Beforehand, at 7 P M., there will be a Southern mountain dinner of barbecued spare ribs and fried chicken; the $12.50 tab includes a theater ticket. Tomorrow afternoon at. 4, the Country Dance Society will give a free demonstration of clog dancing. For information about other events, call (516) 2992395. From New York City, take the Long Island Expressway to Exit 39 north; continue to Northern Boulevard and turn right.

title: Dance for the Deaf: The Music Is Inside
description: Susan Davidoff, Miss Deaf America, teaching deaf youngsters movement yesterday at Public School 47 at 225 East 23d Street in Manhattan. The occasion was a demonstration designed to show that the inability to hear music need not deter people from learning dance. Miss Davidoff is almost totally deaf.

title: Injured Cordero Will Miss Derby
description: Angel Cordero, who won a trip to the Kentucky Derby by finishing second with Darby Creek Road at Aqueduct on Saturday, has suffered a broken back and will not be able to ride for two months.

title: Notes on People
description: With a cowboy hat perched at a rakish angel on his head, John Wayne left Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston yesterday. I feel great, the best I have felt in a long time, said the 70yearold actor, who later boarded a private jet at Logan International Airport and headed for his home in California. Mr. Wayne, who underwent surgery three weeks ago to replace a defective valve of the heart, was asked whether he were frightened at any time in his hospital stay. The movie hero's reply was, Ah, hell, sure.

title: Legion Post Greets Its Man From Soviet
description: GLASSPORI, Pa., April 27 (AP) Eightysevenyearold Charles Puka, who went to the Soviet Union to visit his sister and ended up fighting to leave the country, rejoined his old friends at American Legion Post 443 yesterday.

title: Art: Treasury Of Modern Works
description: THERE is something immensely agreeable about a good drawing exhibition. For one thing, the scale of the objects is unlikely to crush us under its weight. In a drawing, more often than not, the artist's voice tends to be intimate and confidentialmore like conversation than public speech. Like conversation, too. drawings often give us a glimpse of more possibilities than are ever fully realized on the spot. Of course there are drawings as finished and epigrammatic as a speech in an Oscar Wilde comedy, but a drawing that is quick and unfinished may also have much to say. It is in the sheer variety and pace of its many forms of intimate discourse that a good drawing show delights without overwhelming us.

title: People and Business BASF to Invest $700 Million In FiveYear U.S. Expansion
description: Matthias Seefelder, chairman of BASF of West Germany, announced here yesterday that his company, one of the world's largest chemical enterprises, would invest $700 million in expansion of its United States operations over the next five years.

title: BlueChip, Glamour Issues Hit Hard
description: The stock market, after its recent explosive rally, dropped sharply yesterday after the Federal Reserve Board further tightened its credit policy.

title: Israelis Said to Loot Old Tyre Tomb
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 27 (UPI)Israeli bulldozer operators digging to fortify positions near the port of Tyre unearthed an ancient Phoenician tomb and carried away statues, gold and silver treasures pottery and other artifacts, villagers said today.

title: A1 jarreau: A Jazz Singer With Soul
description: One of the special popmusic engagements this weekend is the appearance of the vocalist A1 Jarreau, with a repetory of what he calls combination music, tonight at the Capitol theater in Passaic, N.J. It is the last of Mr. Jarreau's current spate of local appearances, and his first metropolitan area performance since he won the Grammy award for the best jazz vocal performance of 1977.

title: Carter Tax Reform: Broad Public Support Lagging
description: WASHINGTON, April 27  In replying to a question at his news conference Tuesday, President Carter sought to equate his proposals for tax reform with frequent, lavish  and tax deductible business entertaining and, more general ly, with what he called special privileges written into the tax code to benefit people who are powerful and influential. The President's choice of entertainment as a symbol of the evils to be cured by his proposals presumably was related to the fact that it is the most politically salable item on his reform list. A Harris Poll earlier this year reported that Americans supported Mr. Carter's proposal to disallow deductions for entertainment by 75 to 15 percent.

title: U.S. Says Studies Find No Proof Companies Withheld Natural Gas
description: WASHINGTON, April 27Secretary of the Interior Cecil D. Andrus said today that a series of studies had produced no evidence that oil companies were withholding natural gas from offshore leases and only one instance where gas production could be significantly increased.

title: A Saturday Guide To Gallery Hopping; Saturday GalleryHopper's Guide to Art, Shops and Food; Who's Showing Uptown; American Genre; Primitive or Surrealist?; Motherwell at Knoedler; A Bit of Science Fiction; Big Horse & Company; Meditations in Stone; Black on White; After Hopper; The Way It Was; Louis at Emmerich
description: FOR anyone who can tell one work of art from another, there is no better free entertainment to be had this side of the Atlantic than a daylong Saturday prowl among the dealers ealleries in New York City.

title: Aides Say Bell Hurt F.B.I. Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON, April 27Four of the lawyers who originally headed the investigation into a series of breakins by agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in New York accused Attorney General Griffin B. Bell today of having seriously undercut their inquiry and of having hamstrung their efforts to pursue important leads.

title: Islanders Angered by Butler's Hit on Bossy
description: TORONTO, April 27His neck in a brace, his skates tied together to keep him from moving his legs and spinal column, Mike Bossy was wheeled out of Maple Leaf Gardens on a stretcher and was taken to Wellesley Hospital. He was the victim of a blow to the neck at 14:44 of the second period in the Islanders 52 loss tonight to the Toronto Maple Leafs.

title: Tenants Ousted by Sewer Blast Demand Faster Repairs
description: Tenants of the only building that was seriously damaged by explosions in a sewer line March 24 in the South Bronx protested yesterday against long delays in repairing the damage, which has made 52 families homeless for five weeks.

title: Rutgers Concert: It's the Conductor's Night
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, April 26When the Rutgers Glee Club gives its 106th annual spring concert Saturday night the evening will belong to Prof. F. Austin Walter.

title: Keeneland's Blue Grass Chart
York College Supporters Cite Tie to Area's Economy
description: Queens community leaders and elected officials are pressing the city and state to approve the longdelayed construction of a $60 million campus for York College, a project they believe will bolster the Jamaica section's sagging economic health.

title: Duran Wins on Decision Before 17,125 at Garden
description: Roberto Duran returned to Madison Square Garden last night, and 17,125 persons, the largest crowd to see a nontitle Garden fight since Muhammad AliJoe Frazier II in 1974, saw the world lightweight champion outrough Adolfo Viruet to win by a unanimous decision.

title: Authorities in Peking Promise 30 New Restaurants This Year
description: PEKING, April 27 (Reuters)Peking will get 30 more restaurants this year but there will still be fewer places to have a meal out than a decade ago.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Meets at 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M. on SouthWest Africa. Listed to speak in the general debate: New Zealand, Iran, Czechosiovakia, Somalia, Chad, Bhutan, Southern Yemen, Haiti, Laos, Peru, Mexico, Japan, Bahamas, Sudan, Congo, So Tom and Principe, Uruguay.

title: House Croup Backs Carter Trade Move
description: WASHINGTON. April 27Following intensive persuasion. by Vice President Mondale and Robert S. Strauss for the Administration, and lobbying by officials of the United. States Fastener Manufacturing Group for the industry, the House Ways and Means Committee today beat back an effort to overturn a freetrade decision of President Carter.

title: Books: From Palermo to Le Mans
description: ROBERT DALEY'S The Fast One is a love and castor oil autoracing novel that laps the Grand Prix circuit from Palermo to Le Mans, while triangulating the hearts of its three main characters, two racing drivers and a girl. The racing scenes are fast, noisy and colorful, though most of the novel's action occurs between races, in the bedrooms and restaurants of luxe hotels.

title: Music: Errante Clarinet
description: AN UNUSUAL concert of recent clarinet music was presented by R. Gerard Errante Wednesday night at Carnegie Recital Hall. The thrust of the program, entitled The Extended Clarinet, was to explore multiphonics, glissandos, fluttertongueing, and other relatively nontraditional playing techniques.

title: Cabaret: Belated Debut
description: WHEN Lewis Friedman created Reno Sweeney, the West 13th Street nightclub, in 1972, he started the trend toward cabaret that blossomed in the next year or two. While he was owner of the club, he frequently served as piano accompanist to young singers who performed there and, after he sold Reno Sweeney in the summer of 1976, he continued to work with young performers, helping them to develop their acts, managing them and accompanying them.

title: Islanders Routed, Leafs Tie Series
description: TORONTO, April 27The Islanders lost the sixth game of their National Hockey League series tonight to the Toronto Maple Leafs and looked like a thoroughly beaten team. Besides being outscored, 52, which tied the quarterfinal playoff at three games apiece, the Islanders Bryan Trottier suffered a possible broken jaw; Mike Bossy was carried off the ice with a sprained neck, and Ed Westfall reported lame before the game.

title: WALTER E. NALLIN, 60
description: Walter E. Nallin, chairman of the department of music of Baruch College, died Wednesday at the Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 60 years old.

title: President to Select An Aide as Liaison To Political Groups
description: WASHINGTON, April 27President Carter plans to promote Tim Kraft, who ran his field organization in the 1976 Presidential campaign, to the senior White House staff as the Administration places increases emphasis on its political operation.

title: Dreyfus Drops Plan For Merger Fund
description: The Dreyfus Corporation, a leading fund manager, announced yesterday that it was withdrawing a proposal to establish a fund to invest in the stocks of companies that were potential takeover candidates.

title: Obituary 2  No Title
description: AGNES FINN

title: About Real Estate
description: B. J. Kelleher remembers. The ExLax people bought an old brewery on Atlantic Avenue in the Boerum Hill section of downtown Brooklyn in 1925. Over seven years they put up three buildings as additions to it.

title: Radio
description: 78 A.M., WNCN. Scherzo No. 4, Chopin; Symphony No. 10, (K.74), Mozart; Flight of the Bumblebee, RimskyKorsakov; Arise, get up, my dear, Morley; FantasieImpromptu in C sharp minor, Chopin; Le Coucou, Daquin.

title: Presidential Overtones
description: HOUSTONHere's how the United States Senate campaign in Texas this year might affect Presidential politics, and vice versa:

title: Drug Tests Urged To Find Addiction Among Servicemen
description: WASHINGTON, April 27The White House, saying that the use of hard drugs among servicemen was increasing at serious rate, urged Congress today to reinstate a program of random testing of military personnel for heroin addiction.

title: Federal Reserve Statement
Armco Nearly Quintuples Its FirstQuarter Earnings
description: The Armco Steel Corporation, a leading steel producer, turned in one of the best performances in the industry with firstquarter earnings almost quintupled to $30.2 million, or 96 cents a share, from $6.1 million, or 15 cents a share, in the initial three months last year.

title: New York's Givers and Takers
description: In a sense this city has been almost too frequently treated simply as a place of opportunity, a place to which people from abroad and from this country gravitated in order to find new opportunities and greater affluence.

title: Connecticut's House, 89 to 52, Approves Amended Blue Law
description: HARTFORD, April 27The Connecticut House of Representatives voted 89 to 52 tonight for a blue law banning Sunday shopping, but with an amendment exempting store owners who are Jews or SeventhDay Adventists.

title: CARTER ORDERS SALE OF URANIUM TO INDIA FOR POWER FACILITY
description: WASHINGTON, April 27President Carter overruled the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today and ordered the sale. of more than eight tons of enriched uranium to India for its Tarapur nuclear power plant outside Bombay.

title: Business Records
description: Thursday, April 27, 1978

title: Spain's Uncommon Communists: They Experiment With Democracy
description: MADRID, April 27This is a historic congress, rasped Santiago Carrillo, the secretary general of the Spanish Communist Party, as cheering delegates rose to their feet last weekend at the end of five days of deliberations. because it is our first congress in legality and because it has been a profoundly democratic congress, such as we have never had before in our history.

title: LANCE GRAND JURY REPORTED TO FOCUS ON HIS BANK LOANS
description: WASHINGTON, April 27A Federal grand jury investigating Bert Lance for possible. criminal activities while he was a banker is concentrating on whether there was a pattern of fraud in his borrowings from a group of small northwest Georgia banks before he became director of the Office of Management and Budget, according to a source familiar with the proceedings.

title: Public TV to Begin News Show for All of JerseyNorth and Southon May 8
description: All New Jersey is divided, for television purposes, into two parts, but an unusual now news venture that starts May 8 will try to put the state together as a single .unit looking neither west to Philadelphia stations, as southern NeW Jersey does, nor east.to New York City. as northern New Jersey does.

title: The New York Post Reassigning Some on Staff Who Won't Resign
description: The New York Post has begun to redeploy some members of its staff who refused its offer that they resign with severance pay so The Post could reduce its news and commercial staff of 450 Newspaper Guild members by nearly a third.

title: Belgian Calls Carter Decision On Neutron Weapon Unrealistic
description: BRUSSELS, April 27 (AP)Foreign Minister Henri Simonet says President Carter's decision to delay production of neutron weapons in hopes of gaining concessions from Moscow is obviously not too realistic.

title: Ballet: Premiere of Tetley's Sphinx
description: IN HIS new ballet, Sphinx, Glen Tetley has tried to be complex about Oedipus. The end product, however, is simple, and it was put on view in New York for the first time Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House by American Ballet Theater.

title: Lidia Vitale, Designed Packaging For Popular Household Products
description: Lidia Vitale, who designed packaging for popular household products, died Wednesday of cancer at Doctors Hospital. She was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Commodity Price Index Fell By 3.7 From WeekAgo Level
description: The commodity spot market price index of foodstuffs and industrial materials fell to 225.5 from 229.2 last week.

title: News Summary
description: FRIDAY, APRIL 28, 1978

title: Opening a Door for Namibia
description: South Africa's acceptance of the Western plan for bringing independence to Namibia was a prudent response, doubtless evoked by diplomatic pressure and the fear of an escalating guerrilla war. The plan provides a fair path to majority rule for the former German colony that South Africa has run for a half century. Now it remains for SWAPO, the SouthWest Africa People's Organization, to make the tough political decision to embrace the plan.

title: Test for Tainted Marijuana Unreliable, Expert Says
description: The chemist who devised the test for paraquat contamination in marijuana that was widely reported last weekend, with incorrect instructions in many cases, said yesterday that the test was not intended as a reliable means of determining whether a sample of marijuana was safe to smoke.

title: Film: Return of the Native:Bad Vibrations
description: THAT lump on Susan Strasberg's back in "The Manitou" isn't benign. It isn't malignant, either. Worse. It turns out to be the rapidly growing fetus of an Indian medicine man who lived 400 years ago. How come? Don't ask.Surgeons try excision instead of exorcism only to have their scalpels turn in their hands. When they focus a laser on the enlarging protuberance, the beam goes out of control and burns holes all over the operating room.So, despite all the efforts of medical science, the medicine man is reborn, hideously deformed by the X-rays used in the diagnosis. Hunched over Miss Strasberg's corpse, he begins tuning up his malefic vibrations, and San Francisco, where the story takes place, begins to tremble again. The city and, for all we know, the world, seems to be on the verge of destruction until . . .The conflict in "The Manitou," which opens today at Loews State 2, the Orpheum and other theaters, isn't so much between good and evil Indian spirits as it is between seasoned performers, among them Tony Curtis, Stella Stevens, Burgess Meredith, Michael Ansara and Miss Strasberg, and an absurd penny-dreadful script and a cheapjack production. It's another knockoff in the cycle of supernatural horror films that began with "The Exorcist."Regrettably, "The Manitou" is also the film epitaph of William Girdler, the producer, director and co-author of the screenplay. Mr. Girdler, who had had a hand in several other movies aimed at the drive-in trade, was killed last January at the age of 30 in a helicopter crash in the Philippines while scouting locations for his next production."The Manitou" is rated PG ("Parental Guidance Suggested"), probably because of its generally disagreeable subject matter.

title: StreetfightersBeebe to Duran
description: As Roberto Duran and Adolfo Viruet approached last night's tryst in Madison Square Garden, everyone who talked or wrote about the match referred to the principals as streetfighters. Today they are professionals who punch people only in the line of business, but there was a time when fighting was second nature to them, like breathing out and breathing in. Viruet grew up in the asphalt jungle of the Bronx, Duran among the hovels of Panama City's slums. New York first aot to knQW the product of those slums in June 1972, when Duran challenged Ken Buchanan for the lightweight championship of the world. It was Roberto's second visit to the city, but he had merely flashed through town the first time, pausing a minute or two to dispose of Benny Huertas in a serniwindup. Against Buchanan he was a savage who started hitting the champion in the first round and was still hitting him after the bell rang to end the 13th. He whipped Buchanan to a souffle, added a vicious shot south of the border after the bell and walked away, teeth still bared in a snarl while the little Scot lay writhing, limbs twitching convulsively.

title: Stolen Statue StandIn Also Gone in Brussels
description: BRUSSELS, April 27 (AP)A plaster copy of the Manneken Pis was stolen from a square here today one day after it was put up, acording to the police.

title: An In Crowd and Outside Mob Show Up for Studio 54's Birthday
description: Outside it was chaos: Pushing, shoving mobs squashed against the barricades at the front and back entrances, shouting and pleading to be let in by the harried sentries at the door.

title: Paper Links I.R.A. To Foreign Leftists
description: BELFAST, Northern llreland, April 27 (Reuters)The police said today that they had uncovered a document linking the Provisional Irish Republican Army with leftwing groups in several countries.

title: Various Corporations Disclose Their Sales and Earnings Results for the Latest Quarter
description: CORENCO (A)

title: The Steep Cost of Substitute Dollars
description: Treasury Secretary Michael Blumenthal may face some wkward moments this weekend at the International Monetary Fund's meetings in Mexico City. At issue a proposal being pressed by the fund's managing director, H. Johannes Witteveen, to substitute the I.M.F.'s own international currencyknown as Special Drawing Rightsfor some of the dollars now being held by foreign governments. The general concept is a good one, but attempting to swap S.D.R.'s for dollars now would threaten the fragile structure of international finance.

title: Rose Hustles Toward 3,000th
description: Pete Rose took time out from the world yesterday and drove down the interstate to Keeneland Race Course to watch the big horses pursue one another on the road to the Kentucky Derby. Then he rejoined the Cincinnati Reds, packed his baseball gear and prepared to fly to New York today to resume his own great. pursuit: 11 more hits to reach the elite level of 3,000.

title: West Germans, Births Down Ponder Future, or Lack of It
description: BONN; April 27The television documentary was called Are the Germans Dying Out? The answer, aftet 40 minutes of graphs, statistics and convoluted discourse, was yes.

title: World News Briefs
description: MOSCOW, April 27 (UPI)  Leonid I. Brezhnev says that President. Harry S. Truman broke American promises to help the Soviet people recover from the devastation of World War II in an attempt to force them to their knees.

title: U.S. AudioVisual Spending Assailed
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP)The White House today released the results of a yearlong study that concluded the Government spent at least $500 million a year on audiovisual activities marked by waste and Questionable procedures.

title: Two Killed in Mine CaveIn
description: CASTLE GATE, Utah, April 27 (AP)A cavein at a coal mine killed two miners and injured a third this morning, Carbon County sheriff's officers said. The cavein was at the Braztah Corporation's No. 3 mine near Castle Gate. No other injuries were reported, and it was believed all other workmen were safely out of the mine.

title: Advertising
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., April 27A new militancy toward government is surfacing in the American Association of Advertising Agencies, the leading organization in its industry. While for more than a decade annual meetings have included remarks on the horrors of regulation, for the first time there are signs of a united fightback attitude.

title: SouthWest African Is Seeking Changes In West's Proposal
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 27Sam Nujoma, the leader of the SouthWest African People's Organization, asked for changes today in a Western compromise plan for the independence of SouthWest Africa.

title: Stage: Sam. Shepard's Seduced
description: PROVIDENCE, R.I.More than most of his contemporaries, Sam Shepard is definably an American playwright. The land, the people and, particularly, our legends and myths are at the root of his theater. Cowboys, rock stars, gamblers, gangsters and jazzmen populate his worldand almost all of them are in pursuit of some variation of the American dream.

title: Building Contracts Up By 23% Last Month
description: As conditions in the construction markets returned to normal, March contracts were 23 percent higher than their yearearlier value, the F. W. Dodge division of the McGraw Hill Information Systems Company reported yesterday.

title: Koch Proposes a 3Phase Program To Get Congress to Vote Loan Aid
description: WASHINGTON, April 27In a major lobbying effort today, Mayor Koch offered a threestage failsafe plan in the hope of convincing Congress that it had nothing to lose by approving nearly $2 billion in Federal loan guarantees to New York City even before the city's wage negotiations were completed.

title: CurtissWright Net Off 23% in First Quarter
description: The CurtissWright Corporation reported yesterday that its firstquarter profits tumbled 23 percent to $3.4 million. from $4.4 million a year earlier.

title: GENERAL SUMMONED AGAIN AFTER CRITICIZING CARTER
description: WASHINGTON, April 27Maj. Gen. John K. Singlaub, embroiled in controversy 11 months ago for criticizing Presiden Carter's decision to withdraw ground troops from South Korea, was called to Washington again today to explain reported remarks critical of the Panama Canal treaties and Mr. Carter's decision to postpone production of the neutron warhead.

title: STATE DRAFTS PLAN FOR SOLAR ENERGY
description: NEWARK, April 27The State Department of Energy recommended today a legislative, administrative and educational program for the use of solar energy.

title: Metropolitan Briefs
description: Including last week's addition of $350,000 in Federal transportation funds, about $890,000 has been raised for the renovation of the Union Square subway station, said Manfred Ohrenstein, minority leader of the State Senate. Part of the total was raised by local businesses, while therest came from the Federal Government and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: Ballet: Joffrey's Ashton Night
description: THROUGH his choreovranhy for England's Royal.Ballet, Sir Frederick Ashton has fashioned a witty and elegant British NeoClassical style, a style that seems decidedly blueblooded. Yet, outside England, the company that has done the most of late to stage his works is the Joffrey Ballet, a company often associated with redblooded American brashness.

title: House Panel Weighs Court Ruling On Corporate Spending on Issues
description: WASHINGTON, April 27Representative Frank Thompson Jr., chairman of the House Administration Committee, said today that he and committee lawyers were studying yesterday's Supreme Court decision allowing political spending by corporations in referendum elections to determine whether that decision weakened Federal laws against corporate expenditures in behalf of political candidates.

title: Thomas to Attend Georgia
description: ATHENS, Ga., April 27 (AP)Jeff Thomas, a 6footlinch, 170pound guard from Sheepshead Bay High School in Brooklyn, sikned a basketball grantinaid to attend the University of Georgia today. Thomas averaged 24 24 points, 9 rebounds and 6 assists per game during his senor year.

title: Yes Throw Money at Problems
description: BOSTONEvery sustained wave of technological progress and economic development everywhere has been fueled by greed, profiteering, special privileges and megalomania.

title: New jersey Briefs
description: An Essex County grand jury will be asked to determine if deathbyauto charges should be lodged against a 70'yearold man whose car went out of control in downtown Newark and killed two persons, according to the police.

title: Private Schools Provoking ChurchState Conflict
description: ATLANTA, April 27So many churchsponsored grammar and high schools have been opened in the United States in the last decade that education officials in some states are now beginning to monitor their effectiveness, thereby precipitating a number of serious churchstate conflicts.

title: Safety Violations Called Numerous At Site of Collapse
description: WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP)Government inspectors in 13 visits in 1973 found numerous safety violations at West Virginia power company construction site where 51 workers died today, the Labor Department reported.

title: The New Diplomacy
description: WASHINGTON, April 27The conduct of American foreign policy seems very strange these days. There is a great deal of running around and popping off, with everybody minding somebody else's business, but with very little coherence or visible control.

title: Appellate Court Asks Investigation Of Tyler's Conduct as State Judge
description: The New York appellate court that overturned Justice Andrew R. Tyler's perjury conviction on Wednesday said yesterday that it would ask the state body that disciplines judges to investigate Justice Tyler's conduct during the time he was on the bench.

title: Dividends
description: THURSDAY, APRIL 27, 1978

title: Benjamin Levine, 89
description: Benjamin (Ben) Levine, who retired as secretary and office manager of the Metropolitan Amateur Atheletic Union 11 years ago after a 65year career with the A.A.U. died Wednesday night at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington after a long illness. He was 89 years old.

title: Topics Matters of Taste
description: The news from Morganton, N.C., evokes literary parallels; if not Shakespeare (How sharper than a serpent's tooth it is to have a thankless child) then surely Walt Kelley (How sharper than a chile's tooth it is to have a thankless serpent). Naomi Mildred Anderson had her pet boa constrictor in the back seat of her car. An 18yearold youth came along and, for reasons unknown, took a halfinch bite out of the snake's tail. Owner promptly swore out a warrant against biter; she was determined, the magistrate said, to get some type of justice. But what ought that to be? A literary solution might be apt. The teenager might be ordered to do penance in the form of an essay, taking as his text the words of Eve: The serpent beguiled me, and I did eat.

title: Afghanistan at a Glance
description: GeographyA rugged and landlocked country nearly the size of Texas (250,000 square miles), Afghanistan is a historic crossroads of Asia. It shares its longest boundaries with the Soviet Union on the north and Pakistan on the south and adjoins Iran on the west and China on the east. There are 28 provinces. The climate ranges from bitter winters in the Hindu Kush Mountains of the northeast to 120degree summer heat In the southwest lowlands.

title: Lance Language
description: Only recently, the vocabulary of the Bert Lance case contained words like proud, as in Jimmy Carter's Bert, I'm proud of you. Or guilt by accumulation, as in Senator Eagleton's denunciation of Mr. Lance's critics. Or even censorship, as in Mr. Lance's own recent threatened prescription for what he regards as unfair reporting.

title: Trevino Posts 65 to Lead By a Stroke
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 27Would ?? Trevino feel bad if he broke Gary Player's string of consecutive victories at three?

title: U. S. Studying Possible Connection Of the Italian Terrorists to Prague
description: WASHINGTON, April 27The United States Government is investigating whether there is a link between Sovietbloc agencies and the Italian terrorist group that kidnapped Aldo Moro, the former Prime Minister, intelligence officials said today.

title: Coup Is Reported in Afghanistan After Heavy Fighting in Capital
description: BOMBAY, India, April 27The Government of Afghanistan was overthrown today by insurgents in the military after hours of fierce fighting, according to reports from Kabul, the Afghan capital.

title: SPAIN LIFTS 40YEAR RULE BARRING CONTRACEPTIVES
description: MADRID, April 27 (Reuters)The Spanish Parliament voted last night to lift a 40year ban on the sale and advertisine of contraceptives.

title: Books of The Times
description: TO. HAVE written Exile's Return, The Literary Situation and A Second Flowering; to have rescued William Faulkner from critical neglect; and to have been the first editor to publish John Cheever constitutes a career for which no man of letters need apologize. And Malcolm Cowley, at age 79, isn't exactly apologizing. His prose, as always, is lean and sinewy. His moral metronome, as usual, ticks away. His acumen and liberal sympathies are, as ever, manifest. There are fine moments of humor and anger throughout And I Worked at the Writer's Trade.

title: Fire Pension Board to Seek Data On Earnings of Disabled Retirees
description: New York City's Fire Pension Board, deadlocked for more than a year by union reluctance to question retired firemen receiving disability pensions about possibly illegal outside earnings, agreed yesterday to conduct such a survey.

title: Halston, Anthony Lead a Dazzling Array of Fashion
description: Halston made the fashion world safe for fullbodied fox scarves, complete with heads, tails and feet, matched exactly to coats, suits and dresses in such colors as wine, green or silver gray.

title: Restaurants
description: MADISON AVENUE between 63d and 64th Streets has suddenly become one of the city's more promising minirestaurant rows. A few weeks ago we reviewed the very good and handsome Woods, and now there is an equally good, chicly gotten up French style caferestaurant. Le Relais. just two doors away.

title: Publishing: After 40 Years Still a Book Lover
description: THE 14th New York International Antiquarian Book Fair (not to be confused with one held earlier this spring) is showing its wares at the Hotel Plaza this weekend. And occupying two booths at the Plaza will be Hacker Art Books, presided over by sevmour Hacker. a dealer whose specialty is art books only. From a cluttered corner in his cluttered but inviting shop at 54 West 57th Street, Mr. Hacker took time out to talk to a visitor about his business, which is now rounding out its 40th year.

title: Brzezinski Urges Japan to Assume Wider World Role
description: Zbigniew Brzezinski declared last night that the United States intended to remain militarily and politically strong in the AsianPacific area and called on Japan to assume a more positive international role commensurate with its vastly expanded economic strength.

title: PETER LAZAROS, PERJURER ACCUSED IN BANK SWINDLE
description: PONTIAC, Mich., April 27 (UPI)Peter Lazaros, a selfdescribed Mafia tipster who has been called by law enforcement officials a oneman crime wave, died yesterday in the Oakland County Jail int:rmary. He was 44 years old. Mr. Lazaros, a convicted perjurer who had been in failing health since 1973, was jailed on April 13 to await trial on 10 counts of fraud for various bank swindles and schemes defrauding private citizens.

title: U.S. Says Studies Find No Proof Companies Withheld Natural Gas
description: WASHINGTON, April 27Secretary of the Interior Cecil D. Andrus said today that a series of studies had produced no evidence that oil companies were withholding natural gas from offshore leases and only one instance where gas production could be significantly increased.

title: Duration of Animal Experiments in 60's an Issue at Curare Trial
description: HACKENSACK, April 27The prosecution in the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich called the controller of the New Jersey College of,Medicine and Dentistry as a witness today in an effort to disprove the defendant's contention that he did animal experiments there in 1965 and 1966.

title: Obituary 3  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Auctions
description: UNTIL recently photographs were treated as stepchildren in art auction houses. If they were sold at all, they were usually afterthoughts in book sales. This is no longer true.

title: Corporation Affairs Crane Discloses a 10% Purchase Of Stock in MorrisonKnudsen
description: The Crane Company, the principal holding of Thomas Mellon Evans, the financier, has disclosed in a report to the Securities and Exchange Commission that on April 17 it ourchased 229,300 shares, or about 10 percent, of the MorrisonKnudsen Company, the Boise, Idaho, engineering concern. Based on the McrrisonKnudsen price of $38 a share on that date, the total value of the transaction was about $11.5 million.

title: TURKS' EASTERN TIES WORRYING THE WEST
description: ANKARA, Turkey, April 26A flurry of visits between Turkish leaders and high officials of Communist countries has caused apprehension among Western diplomats that the contacts may harbinger a shift by Turkey away from the North Atlantic alliance.

title: Music: Remembering Lieberson
description: SUCH a protean personality as Goddard Lieberson, the longtime .head of Columbia Records who died last May, presents a problem for ??. The tributes, both written and spoken, that were ??fered in his memory at a Remembering Goddard Lieberson concert last night at Carnegie Hall touched on many of his achievements, and reminded the gathering of what a gap his death created in the American musical community.

title: Determining When a Killer Is Again Sane
description: On Oct. 4, 1971, Laurence Lublin killed his wife in the bedroom of their home in Wyandanch, L. I., stabbing her 82 times with a sewing awl. He then drove to a nearby overpass on the Long Island Expressway, presumably to jump off and kill himself.

title: Determining When a Killer Is Again Sane
description: On Oct. 4, 1971, Laurence Lublin killed his wife in the bedroom of their home in Wyandanch, L. I., stabbing her 82 times with a sewing awl. He then drove to a nearby overpass on the Long Island Expressway, presumably to jump off and kill himself.

title: Spring Helps the Goldfinch
description: TRENTON, April 27 (AP)The arrival of spring brought new life to New Jersey's state bird, the American goldfinch. The New Jersey Agricultural Society said today that survival of the goldfinch was threatened during the winter when snow buried weeds used by the bird for food.

title: Resettled Cypriot Turks Don't Want Greeks
description: KARAOGLANOGLU, CyprusUntil the Turkish invasion of Cyprus in 1974 this village of redroofed white stucco houses set in large orange and lemon groves about two miles west of Kyrenia was known as Agios Giorgios (St. George, in Greek). The invasion changed everything, sending the ethnic Greek inhabitants as refugees to the south.

title: CLASHES REPORTED AFTER AFGHAN COUP
description: NEW DELHI, April 28Sporadic fighting between rival military units continued in Afghanistan today, following yesterday's bloody coup in which President Mohammad Daud was apparently killed.

title: World News Briefs
description: Special to The New York Times

title: Corporation Earnings Reported for the Latest Quarter
description: For periods as shown. (N) indicates stock is listed on the New York Stock Exchange,(A) the American Stock Exchange and (O) overthecounter.

title: Ambush of Rhodesian Leaves Void in Her Town
description: MARANDELLAS, Rhodesia, April 28 Almost all the 155 white civilians killed in the Rhodesian war have been memorialized in the condolence columns of The Rhodesia Herald. In Anne Holland's case, the messages appeared for days after she died, more than 80 in all, suggesting that she had made a special place for herself among the people of this quiet market town.

title: Mrs. King Leads Apples Over Loves by 2714
description: ST. LOUIS, April 28 (UPI)Billie Jean King powered the New York Apples to a second straight victory over the Indiana Loves, 2714, tonight in a World Team Tennis match.

title: Ford Unhappy Over Move
description: NEWARK, April 28 (AP)  Former President Gerald R. Ford, here to speak at a political fundraising dinner, called General Singlaub's retirement unfortunate, adding, I feel it's extremely important for senior military officers to speak their own mind, to speak as their conscience tells them.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: ARLINGTON, Tex., April 28Saying I feel fine; I'm ready to come back right now, Roger Moret worked out today for the first time since going into a catatonic state in the Texas Rangers' clubhouse on April 12.

title: Two Main Eritrean Independence Groups to Merge
description: AGORDAT, Ethiopia, April 25 (Delayed) Eritrea's two main independence groups have agreed to fight together to end Ethiopian rule and establish an independent country. The agreement ends nearly 10 years of bitter teucing, and means that more than 40,000 guerrillas are now under a joint command to prepare for what they hope will be the final push against Government forces.

title: Private German Rocket Base in Zaire Stirring Rumors
description: KINSHASA, ZaireAn unusual contract in which Zaire has given a West German rocket company sweeping rights and almost exclusive dominion over a vast region of remote bushland has aroused a storm of speculation in southern Africa.

title: Corporation Affairs
description: A struggle for control of CutlerHammer Inc. escalated yesterday, when Federal District Court in Milwaukee denied the company's request for an injunction prohibiting Tyco Laboratories, a small New, Hampshire electronics company, from buying more CutlerHammer shares.

title: Golden Gate Bridge's 638th Suicide
description: SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 (UPI)A man believed to be in his late 20's leaped to his death from the Golden Gate Bridge yesterday, becoming the 638th known suicide from the bridge. The body was not found.

title: S.E.C. Postpones Requirement On Firm Bid and Ask Quotations
description: WASHINGTON, April 28The Securities and Exchange Commission has postponed a requirement that stock exchanges put out firm quotations on bid and ask stock prices with the size of the lots being offered.

title: 3 EXPORT SALES AIDES SUSPENDED BY SCHLITZ
description: MILWAUKEE, April 28 (AP)Three officials of the Jos. Schlitz Co. export sales department have been suspended after an investigation by the company into possible illegal activities, a lawyer for the brewery said today.

title: French Seeking New Role in Africa With, Troop Aid
description: PARIS, April 28France's decision to send troops to Chad to help the Government against Libyanbacked rebels is part of a forward policy that President Valery Giscard d'Estaing has pursued in Africa for the last two years to bolster French influence in former colonies as well as in other African countries.

title: Weekly News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times in the last week.

title: Market Surges Despite Increase In Interest Rate
description: The stock market shrugged off the normally depressing news of rising interest rates yesterday to move ahead with sharp gains. Trading volume remained heavy but was below Thursday's turnover.

title: GOING OUT Guide
description: AWAY WE GO Some provocative walking tours are scheduled for this spring weekend. Today and tomorrow at 2 P.M., a guided 90minute trek will salute the landscape architect of Central Park, Frederick Law Olmsted. The tab is $2. The tour leader is Marshall Wershaw, formerly of the Museum of the City of New York. The meeting place is the entrance to the Dakota Apartments, Central Park West at 72d Street.

title: News Summary
description: SATURDAY, APRIL 29, 1978

title: Letter: On SecondHand Smoke
description: To the Editor:

title: Quebec Tax Clash Hurts Trudeau
description: MONTREAL, April 28The Government of Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau has suffered a defeat in a political clash with the separatist government of Ouebec over a tax issue.

title: Lawyr, 25, Wnts Jb, Phila.
description: PHILADELPHIAThe interview was not going well. I looked up on the wall and saw diplomas from Central High School, Temple University and University of Pennsylvania. No, they were not going to offer a job to a short, curlyhaired white suburban kid with two outofstate universities on his resume.

title: Consumer Notes Law Sponsor Sees Conservation In LowCost Power for the Needy
description: A sponsor of legislation that reduces utility costs for lowincome families who use minimal amounts of gas and electricity while requiring industry to assume a larger stare of the costs, said yesterday that the new law could result in greater conservation efforts by the companies.

title: Ellen Ann Goldstein Wed to Emil Pavone
description: Ellen Ann Goldstein of New York and Emil A. Pavone of Northport, L.I., were married yesterday afternoon. Village Justice James J. Kelleher of Northport performed the ceremony at his home.

title: Doctoring Admissions for the Rich
description: American folklore has long celebrated the poor boy who makes it through medical school and becomes a famous doctor by the sweat of his brow and the scrimping of his family. Now there is a new twist that makes those sacrifices look like peanuts. Many professional schools appear to have set up underground box offices that sell admissions to the highest bidders. Richard Lyons of The New York Times reports millions of dollars in contributions or pledges made by parents before their children are admitted, suggesting a system of buying acceptance rather than competing for it. Underthecounter payments of as much as $250,000 for a place in medical school have been uncovered. There also have been admission deals involving politicians with control over public funds for professional schools.

title: Obituary 4  No Title
description: Deaths

title: SEOUL SAYS CREW OF JET WILL BE FREED BY SOVIET
description: SEOUL, South Korea, Aapril 28 (AP)The pilot and navigator of a Korean Air Lines jet downed in Soviet territory April 20 will be freed by Soviet authorities tomorrow, informed South Korean Government sources said today.

title: Fisher Prize Broadcast May 12
description: The winner of the Avery Fisher Prize for young instrumentalists will be announced in a ceremony at Avery Fisher Hall on May 12 that will be broadcast live on radio station WQXR from 2:05 to 3 P.M. Robert Sherman, program director of the station, will be host of the program and will interview the winner, who will also perform at that time.

title: Lance Puts Bank in Spotlight
description: LONDON, April 28Until it retained Bert Lance as an adviser on possible United States investments, only a handful of Americans had ever heard of the sixyearold Bank of Credit and Commerce International.

title: Toward Harnessing Stars Energy
description: Two current developments are bringing substantially closer the day when soientists, using superpowerful laser pulses, hope to harness the energy of stars.

title: Around the Nation
description: CONCORD, N.H., April 28 (AP)The New Hampshire Supreme Court today ruled that the Portsmouth Clamshell Alliance would not have to post a $10,000 bond to use the National Guard armory in Portsmouth for a dance tomorrow night.

title: Koch Asks White House Aid to Get Proxmire to Set CityAid Hearing
description: Mayor Koch asked the White House yesterday to try to get Senator William Proxmire, chairman of the Banking Committee, to schedule hearings on New York City's loan legislation before contracts with the municipal unions were signed.

title: Connecticut Passes Bill on Taxing Businesses for LitterCleanup Cost
description: HARTFORD, April 28The Connecticut General Assembly today gave final approval to and sent to the Governor a bill that allows the taxing of businesses to pay for $3 million year in litter cleanup in the state. The bill, which passed in the House today by a vote of 88 to 59, has been one of the most controversial before the Assembly this year.

title: Television
description: Morning

title: More Speeders Caught
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 28 (AP) There has been a 30 percent increase in the number of speeders caught on the New Jersey Turnpikethe result of the I addition of 28 mobile radar devices, according to the state police. Capt. William J. Burke of Troop D said yesterday that there were 1,409 speeding violations last March, 671 of Which were radardetected. Speed violations the previous March totaled 1,081, with 256 being detected by radar.

title: Convention Site AtWest 34th St. Chosen by Koch
description: Hailing the single largest economic development project in New York City's history, Mayor Koch and Governor Carey yesterday disclosed their plans for a $257 million convention center in the Penn Central yards at West 34th Street.

title: Personal Investing
description: When the American Savings & Loan Association of Utah sold $50 million in mortgagebacked bonds last week, it showed that hardpressed thrift institutions were fighting hard to recapture deposits they had been losing to higher yielding money market instruments.

title: Methodists Fight to Hang On to Greenwich Church
description: The Rev. Wilfred Hansen is not likely to forget his first Sunday as the pastor of the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich, Conn., two weeks ago. Two church members physically barred him from the pulpit, and when a church official tried to announce his appointment, the organist drowned him out with thunderous chords.

title: OPEC Investments In U.S. in 4 Years Put at $38 Billion
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)Nearly all of the money Americans paid to oil exporting countries in the last four years returned to the United States in bank accounts and investments, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Atlantic Communications Broken By Largest Solar Flare in Years
description: WASHINGTON, April 28  Federal scientists reported the detection of a major solar flare this morning and said they expected it to disrupt communications worldwide this weekend.

title: Obituary 8  No Title
description: Deaths

title: Sports Today
description: BASEBALL

title: Almost the Way It Works
description: In the beginning God sent a Creation bill to the Congress. It proposed a crash program under which everything from light to man would be created in six days. It ran into trouble almost immediately in the Senate Finance Committee.

title: 3 Jockeys Suspended
description: Three jockeys, including one of the top 10 riders at Aqueduct, were suspended ,yesterday by the State Racing and Wagering Board for allegedly using drugs.

title: BUILDERS SAY CENTER WILL REVIVIFY AREA
description: Although major builders and developers yesterday generally expressed optimism that the West 34th Street convention ,center would rejuvenate the area surrounding it, none said they had any definite plans to invest there.

title: Issue and Debate Labor Law Changes That Aid Unions
description: WASHINGTON, April 27One of the most bitterly fought battles over labor legislation is now approaching a climax as a bill to revise the national labor law moves toward the floor of the Senate.

title: NORMAN ARMOUR JR., 58, WAS IN FOREIGN SERVICE
description: Norman Armour Jr., a former assistant chief of protocol in the State Department, died Wednesday at Columbia Presbyterian Hospital after a long illness. He was 53 years old.

title: Shipping/Mails
description: ARRIVING TODAY, April 29

title: No Excuses for the Islanders
