description: In other years, the New York Islanders could rationalize their elimination from the Stanley Cup playoffs. Until now, they always were ousted by a team that was considered superiorthe Montreal Canadiens in the semifinals the last two years, the Philadelphia Flyers in the semifinals three vears ago. Like a small child who loses a sweater at a playground, the Islanders always were given the benefit of the doubt. As a team, the Islanders are still only a 6yearold. But a 6yearold has outgrown the right to be excused and has earned the right to be spanked. If theIslanders lose to the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight at Nassau Coliseum in the decisive seventh game of their Stanley Cup conflict, they will have only themselves to blame. No excuses, please. No complaints. No alibis. When the Islanders finished first in the Patrick Division of the National Hockey League, they surrendered the privilege of copping out if they should lose in the quarterfinals to the Maple Leafs, a thirdplace team in the Adams Division behind the Boston Bruins and the Buffalo Sabres.

title: SALES OF 33 RETAIL CHAINS INCREASE 13.4% IN MARCH
description: Sales in March of 33 leading retail chains had an average gain of 13.4 percent over the like 1977 month, achieving the best yeartoyear monthly sales gain of 1978, according to a survey by Chain Store Age, a trade publication.

title: STUDENTS BLOCK ROADS IN NIGERIAN PROTESTS
description: LAGOS, Nigeria, April 28 (Agence FrancePresse)  Secondary school students blocked major roads in Lagos today and wrecked government vehicles in an intensification of Nigeria's twoweekold education crisis. The Government accused a major student organization of seeking its overthrow.

title: Editorial Cartoon 1  No Title
Mondale, Alter a Debate, Will Include Manila on Trip
description: WASHINGTON, April 28Vice President Mondale is scheduled to leave tomorrow on a 12day trip to the Philippines and four other Pacific nations despite a heated debate in the Carter. Administration over whether he should visit Manila so soon after the disputed elections there.

title: Jascalevich Termed Upset in Request for a Lab Dog
description: Medicine and Dentistry testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that the surgeon was anxious, upset and animated when he requested a research dog on Nov. 2, 1966.

title: ExPresident Ford Helps Kean Repay Campaign Favors
description: NEWARK, April 28Former President Gerald R. Ford returned a political favor tonight when he appeared at a $100aperson fundraising dinner for former Assemblyman Thomas H. Kean of Livingston.

title: Both Sides in Panama Canal Debate Say Radio Broadcasts Aided Them
description: WASHINGTON, April 28From Feb. 8 to April 18 the words flowed in a steady stream, and every one was broadcast by National Public Radio. The result? Both sides in the Panama Canal debate think their cause was aided, and a lot more people know that public radio exists.

title: U.S. IS WEIGHING APPEAL ON MEDICAID FILE RULING
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI)The Justice Department is considering appealing a Federal judge's ruling this week that could open confidential Medicaid and Medicare oversight files to the public.

title: Carter Shifting Policy on Water To Allow States More Authority
description: FORT MORGAN, Colo., April 27The Carter Administration, which stirred bitter opposition in the West a year ago with a list of water projects that the President proposed to abandon, is evolving a policy that would give elected officials from a region more authority in deciding which projects would be built. The policy marks a drastic change from the position of a year ago.

title: Party Unity and Big Campaign Treasuries Raising Hopes of Republicans in Texas
description: DALLAS, April 28  Two years after one of the bitterest FordReagan Presidental primaries in the nation, the Texas Republican Party has largely put the divisions of 1976 behind it and the combination of relative unity and unusually fat campaign war chests is causing Democrats concern.

title: The Buck Stops There
description: ALBANYThe New York State Senate sits in one of the world's most beautiful rooms. Its full, graceful proportions, its solid but intricate woodwork and its deep red motif harmonize

title: F.A.S.B. Suspends Certain Rules Of Reporting for Nonpublic Units
description: The Financial Accounting Standards Board, the private sector's top authority on accounting rules, yesterday suspended certain rules governing the financial reporting required of nonpublic enterprises.

title: A SelfDestructive Postal Cycle
description: Tucked into the Constitution's list of the powers of Congress is the inconspicuous, To establish post offices and post roads, and there is a further charge to make all necessary and proper laws for carrying into execution the foregoing powers. In 1970, Congress revised the law setting up a Postal Service, in the belief that private business techniques could make the mails more efficient. The result has indeed been more efficient management but no escape from the spiral of higher rates, cutbacks in service, the loss of customers to alternate delivery servicesand demands for still higher rates.

title: Another Moro Letter Is Received by Paper
description: ROME, Saturday, April 29 (AP)Former Prime Minister Aldo Moro has written a new letter from captivity pleading with his Christian Democrat Party to agree to an exchange of prisoners to save his life, the Rome daily Il Messaggero reported today.

title: JASCALEVICH UPSET A WITNESS TESTIFIES
description: HACKENSACK, N.J., April 28A doctor at the New Jersey College of Medicine and Dentistry testified today at the murder trial of Dr. Mario E. Jascalevich that the surgeon was anxious, upset and animated when he requested a research dog on Nov. 2. 1966.

title: Iri Manila, No Enthusiasm
description: MANILA, April 28President Marcos and his Government are cautious and unenthusiastic about Vice President Mon. dale's projected visit. They expect few results in view of widening difference ?? on the issues of human rights and military bases.

title: Abrahams to Transfer $1.5 Million From Bermuda to Boston Bank
description: BOSTON, April 28(AP)Alan H. Abrabams, who as James A. Carr is suspected of swindling millions of dollars from investors, agreed in United States District Court today to transfer $1.5 million from his account in Bermuda to a Boston bank.

title: G.M. RAISING PRICES 1.4% ON MOST CARS, EFFECTIVE MONDAY
description: The General Motors Corporation announced yesterday a price increase of L4 percent, or an average of $100 at retail, on most of its 1978 models, effective next Monday. The increase averages $50, or 1.1 percent, at wholesale.

title: Musicians Take Note Of EllinOon's Birthday
It's Now OneGame Series for Islanders
description: With quarterfinal elimination a possibility for the first time in three seasons, the New York Islanders play the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight in Nassau Coliseum in the seventh and decisive game of their playoff series. Each team has won all three games on its home ice, but as Billy Harris of New York said. They've beaten us more easily on their ice than we've beaten them on ours. We've gotta get our act together.

title: Yugoslav's Sentence Reduced
description: BELGRADE, April 28 (Reuters)The Croatian Supreme Court cut in half a sevenyear sentence given a flight controller convicted of criminal negligence in the September 1976 collision of two airliners in which 176 people died, Yugoslav officials said today, The court ruled there had been mitigating circumstances.

title: Bell and F.B.I. Indictments
description: WASHINGTON, April 28Last week in Indianapolis, in a tense confrontation with some agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Attorney General Griffin B. Bell was asked rather pointedly what he expected to accomplish by prosecuting three former bureau officials on charges stemming from a hunt for radical fugitives six years ago.

title: VillanovaExtends Penn Relay String
description: PHILADELPHIA, April 28For a moment, as Ray Flynn challenged Don Paige for the lead on the last turn, Villlanova's string of distance medley titles at the Penn Relays seemed in ieopardy today.

title: PARKING RULES
description: Because of Passover, alternateside parking restrictions will be suspended today where the restrictions are normally in effect from 8 A.M. to 11 A.M. or 11 A.M. to 2 P.M. They will also be suspended in areas where alternateday, alternateside parking is in effect from 8 A.M. to 6 P.M.; in the Manhattan garment center from 2 A.M. to 6 A.M., and at alternateday, alternateside parking meters from 8 A.M. to 9 A.M. All other parking regulations will remain in effect.

title: EXCHANGE OF A SOVIET SPY FOR AMERICAN IS FORECAST
description: WASHINGTON, April 28A New York Congressman said today that he expected an exchange within a few days of a convicted Soviet spy for a young American who was imprisoned in East Germany for trying to help East Germans flee abroad.

title: Georgia Youth Gets Second Term In the Burning of Black Churches
description: WASHINGTON, Ga., April 28 (AP)Roy Keith Palmer, 17 years old, pleaded guilty today to burning two predominant1 ly black churches in Wilkes County last December. He was sentenced to six years in prison.

title: Black Justice Minister Dismissed By Rhodesia's Transition Regime
description: JOHANNESBURG, April 28Rhodesia's transition Government tonight dismissed Byron R. Hove, a black who was appointed joint. Justice Minister two weeks ago,but one of Prime Minister Ian D. Smith's, three black associates on the Executive Council later condemned the dismissal and demanded that it be revoked.

title: ROBERT EMIL SCHULZ, 49
description: Robert Emil Schulz, an illustrator and painter, died Tuesday of a heart attack at his home in Stockholm, N.J. He was 49 years old.

title: I.M.F. SEES A DELAY FOR CURRENCY PLAN
description: MEXICO CITY, April 28The world's leading finance ministers, meeting here this weekend, are expected to withhold a final decision on a controversial International Monetary Fund plan to change the composition of international currency reserves.

title: Schmidt Attacks U.S. Attitudes on Oil and Economics
description: BONN, April 28  West German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, using the word irresponsible, today attacked American attitudes on oil policy and world economic leadership.

title: PARKING RULES
description: Because of Passover, alternateside parking restrictions will be suspended today vThere the restrictions are normally in effect from 8 A.M. to 11 A.M. or 11 A.M. to 2 P.M. They will also be suspended in areas where alternateday, alternateside parking is in effect from 8 A.M. to 6 P.M.; in the Manhattan garment center from 2 A.M. to 6 A.M., and at alternateday, alternateside parking meters from 8 A.M. to 9 A.M. All other parking regulations will remain in effect.

title: Nationwide Insurance to Appeal Ruling That It Must Insure Cars; Judge's Ruling Disturbing; Company Plans Appeal; Higher Rates for Safe Drivers?; Allstate Ordered to Explain
description: TRENTON, April 28Nationwide Insurance Company said today that it would appeal a court ruling that a company licensed in the state could not stop renewing automobile insurance without permission of the State Insurance Commissioner.

title: Bread From the Waters
description: WASHINGTONThe Nixon and Ford Administrations were, In retrospect, a period of great prosperity for publicinterest groups of the left. American liberals, faced with antiballistic missiles, supersonic transports, new nuclear schemes and the rest, learned to donate $15 a year, and later $20, to a plethora of new small independent institutions.

title: SOVIET NAMES SUCCESSOR TO DEFECTOR AT THE U.N.
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 28 Moscow has proposed Mikhail D. Sytenko, a senior diplomat, for the post of Under Secretary General to replace Arkady N. Shevchenko, who declined to return home and has since left the staff here.

title: John Meehan Dances in 2 Ballets
description: With some stiff competition from one Russian and several young American dancers, John Meehan performed as he were the man of the hour in two very different ballets presented by American Ballet Theater on Thursday at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Kazan, on Greek Visit, Relives Heritage and Charts Future
description: ATHENSSpeaking mostly in English to a crowded theater full of Greek movie buffs, gathered for the opening of a weeklong festival of his films, Elia Kazan, born Elias Kazanjoglou 69 years ago, told a story about his Anatolian Greek grandmother. The first thing she dtd on emigrating to tne unitea States and entering the door of her new home in New York was to make a pot full of yogurt. Because the Kazanjoglous ate yogurt three times a day Mr. Kazan said, T tasted my connection with the old country at every meal.

title: BILLS ON SUGAR, MEAT TERMEDINFLATIONARY
description: WASHINGTON, April 28The President's Council on Wage and Price Stability has warned that two bills now before the Senateto raise sugar prices and change regulation of meat importswould be inflationary.

description: FRIDAY: APRIL 28, 1978

title: Canada, Czechs Win
description: PRAGUE, April 28 (UPI)Marcel Dionne scored two goals to help. Canada even its wonlost record at 11 today with a 62 victory over East Germany in the world ice hockey championship.

title: Weibring, Rookie, Leads Golf by Shot on 64133
description: NEW ORLEANS, April 28Nearly every tournament on the PGA Tour has a Cinderella who breaks out of anonymity with a hot round and then goes back to his pumpkin.

title: Creation of an Island Off Jersey For Industrial Plants Is Urged
description: WEST ORANGE, N. J., April 27 (UPI)An independent consulting concern says New Jersey could clean up its unsightly industries by building an island 15 miles offshore to house power plants, wastetreatment facilities and refineries.

title: J. P. Stevens Settles With Labor Board On Antiunion Acts
description: The J. P. Stevens Company and the Nationaal Labor Relations Board announced in Washington yesterday an agreement under which the board has dropped its request for a sweeping injunction to stop allegedly illegal antiunion tactics. Basically, without admitting guilt, the company agreed not to engage in such tactics and to rehire 11 workers.

title: New Status for South African Area
description: CAPE TOWN, April 28 (AP)The black tribal homeland of Venda near the Rhodesian border will become independent of whiteruled South Africa in late 1979, Prime Minister John Vorster announced today.

title: Cardinals Pick Ken Boyer
description: The St. Louis Cardinals yesterday named Ken Boyer, who pliayed 11 years for the team, as their manager. Details Page 18.

title: Flood Is Up for A's  on Radio
description: OAKLAND, Calif., April 28Curt Flood, whose unsuccessful antitrust suit in 1970 helped pave the way for the freeagent revolution in baseball, returned to the game today as a broadcaster for the Oakland A's, the team that has suffered the most from free agency.

title: Carey Aide a Principal in Inquiry
description: ALBANY, April 28Attorney General Louis J. Lefkowitz today ordered an inquiry into whether the State Police Superintendent, william J. Connelie, had done a special favor for Raymond B. Harding, a special assistant to Governor Carey, after Mr. Harding was stopped for driving with a suspended license.

title: Chase Lifts Prime Rate From 8 to 8 Percent
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank and several other major banks raised their prime lending rate yesterday to 8 percent from 8 percent, bringing their basic interest rate for commercial loans to its highest since early 1975.

title: Union Bars Off Off Broadway Code
description: Actors Equity's proposed codes controlling the payment of actors working Off Off Broadway which the theater alliance says threatened the existence of Off Off Broadwayfailed to pass at yesterday's membership meeting of Equity in the Majestic Theater.

title: Dollar Is Mixed Abroad And Broadly Higher Here On AntiInflation Moves
description: The United States dollar, finding a measure of strength from American antiinflation moves, had mixed success yesterday in foreign exchange trading overseas but was broadly higher in New York, The Associated Press reported.

title: Onlookers Relive Horror at Plunge Of 51 on Scaff old
description: WILLOW ISLAND, W.Va., April 28Gravediggers were at work at the little Baptist Church on the road south from here early this morning while the survivors of yesterday's fatal scaffold collapse stayed at home to search their memories of what they had seen.

description: WASHINGTON, April 28The Carter Administration, facing a strong fight in Congress over its proposed sale of planes to. three Middle East countries, softened its language today about treating President Carter's plan as a package.

title: ARTIFICIAL KIDNEY HAILED AS DIALYSIS REPLACEMENT
description: CHICAGO. April 28 (UPI)A new type of artificial kidney has been developed that uses no water and could be worn as a backpack, researchers told the American Society of Artificial Organs.

title: For West European Communist Parties: Crises of Identity
description: PARIS, April 23A wave of intense argument is sweeping through the major West European Communist parties. While the issues are similar, the challenges to the established leaderships are coming from opposite directions.

title: Around the City, They're Brushing Up On the Travolta Look
description: In the 50's, the gang that hung out at the bowling alley wore its hair in Elvis Presley's wellgreased D.A. The 60's brought a legion of Beatle imitators,. hair grew long and parents and teachers fulminated.

title: Agnes de Mille Offers a Repeat Of Conversations About Dance
description: Agnes de Mille has done it again. Fortunately. After a hugely successful evening at the Joffrey Ballet last November, which she called Conversations About the Dance, she went ahead and repeated the program Thursday night at the City Center.

title: General Who Attacked Carter Plans Agrees to Retire
description: WASHINGTON, April 28Maj. Gen. John K. Singlaub, the outspoken officer who lost his command post in Korea last year for opposing the Carter Administration's troop withdrawal plan there, agreed today to retire from the Army after another attack on President Carter's policies.

title: WindBlown Oxides Trigger Reaction Deadly to Fish in Adirondacks
description: ALBANY, April 27  The snows are melting rapidly in the northern Adirondack Mountains, filling the streams and lakes with fresh, sparkling waterand a deadly poison for fish.

title: Champ to Star Faye Dunaway and Jon Voight
description: LOS ANGELES, April 28 M.G.M.'s The Champ, which went hopefully into production eight weeks ago without either a male or female star, now has both. Faye Dunaway was signed yesterday afternoon, for $750,000, according to rumors, to costar with Jon Voight in the remake of the 1931 tearjerker about a downattheheels former professional fighter and his son.

title: Soft Dance Style, Leisurely Pace In a Program by Hawkins Troupe
description: Thursday night's program by the Erick Hawkins Dance Company at the Roundabout Theater contained several pleasures and one big problem.

title: Ken Boyer To Manage Cardinals
description: ST. LOUIS, April 28 (AP)  Ken Boyer, manager of the Rochester Red Wings of the International League and a former major league player, today was named manager of the St. Louis Cardinals of the National League.

title: Phillies Top Padres, 32; Sizemore Breaks Hand; National League Giants 5, Pirates 4; Dodgers 7, Cardinals; Expos 6, Astros 3; Cubs 4, Braves 3 (10 innings ); American League Royals 7, Brewers 6; Orioles 6, White Sox 4; Rangers 5, Red Sox 4 (11 innings); Indians 6, A's 2
description: The Philadelphia Phillies beat the San Diego Padres, 32, in Veterans Stadium last night, but it was a costly triumph. Ted Sizemore, the Phillies second baseman, fractured two bones hi his left hand and was placed on the 21day disabled list.

title: Carter Shifting Policy on Water To Allow States More Authority
description: FORT MORGAN, Colo., April 27The Carter Administration, which stirred bitter opposition in the West a year ago with a list of water projects that the President proposed to abandon, is evolving a policy that would give elected officials from a region more authority in deciding which projects would be built. The policy marks a drastic change from the position of a year ago.

title: Clinton Residents Deplore Choice of 34th St. for Convention Center
description: Residents of the Clinton section of west midtown Manhattan, who fought against and then for, a convention center, said they saw yesterday's announcement that a center would be built 10 blocks south of their neighborhood as another sign of the city's indifference to their deteriorating community.

title: Patents Weather Radar in Color from RCA
description: WASHINGTONThe RCA Corporation has developed the first weather radar to provide pictures in full color to airplane pilots. The new equipment, called Primus 400, lets the pilot detect storm conditions as far as 300 nautical miles ahead.

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

title: Begin to Be Guest At Gracie Mansion
description: Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel will stay at Gracie Mansion as the guest of Mayor Koch next week during his fourday stay in New York in what is believed to be the first overnight visit by a head of a foreign government to the Mayor's official home.

title: Notes on People
description: The Klansman, a publication of the Ku Klux Klan, has named Mayor Frank L. Rizzo of Philadelphia its Racist Hero of the Month and Mr. Rizzo is fighting mad about it. I reject the K.K.K and all it represents, he said. It is foreign to everything I was ever taught. I have consistently taken stands for racial and religious equality. The April issue of the Klan magazine said that recently the Mayor stated publicly what Klansmen have been saying for decades and that Mr. Rizzo has shown the courage of his convictions and should be applauded loudly by all white people. Last March, Mr. Rizzo told a group of whites that he opposed construction of a public housing project in their neighborhood and that ethnic Americans were not getting a fair share in American society. He later said that whites have to join hands to get equal treatment, but added that his statement was not a slur on nonwhites.

title: Books of The Times Portrait of Saul Steinberg
description: I was attracted to this book because I don't always understand Saul Steinberg and it makes me feel left out when almost everyone I know acts as if he does understand him. I can think of no one who has said in my hearing:

title: Liberty State Park Selected as the Site For the New Jersey
description: ATLANTIC HIGHLANDS, April 28A special state commission chosen by Governor Byrne ruled today that Liberty State Park in Jersey City would be the home of the battleship New Jersey, the most decorated in the nation's history, if she were made available by the Navy.

title: Carter Will Visit Panama in June
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)President Carter will visit Panama June 16 and 17 to exchange the diplomatic documents that will give it control of the Panama Canal, the White House said today.

title: 1977 Babies Expected To Live for 73 Years
description: Babies born in the United States last year will live an average of 73 years, a record, says an insurance company report.

title: NORTHWEST AIRLINES IS STRUCK BY PILOTS
description: MINNEAPOLIS, Saturday, April 29 (AP) Northwest Airlines, the nation's seventh largest air carrier,. was struck early today by its 1,550 pilots, who are members of the Air Line Pilots Association.

title: U.S. Task Force on Health Is Coming to Study Harlem
description: Joseph A: Califano Jr., Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, announced yesterday that he would send a task force into Harlem. to take a look at what can be done to solve its health problems.

title: POST OFFERS GUILD MORE SEVERANCE PAY
description: The New York Post will offer up to two months of added severance pay to about 115 editorial and commercial employees whose resignations have been sought in an economy move, under an agreement reached yesterday with the Newspaper Guild of New York.

title: JOHN F. X. MASTERSON, FORMER MAGISTRATE, 73
description: John F. X. Masterson, who was twice appointed by the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia to terms as a city magistrate, died Thursday at New York Hospital atfer a long illness. He was 73 years old.

title: Farm Prices Up 4%, Continuing Advance 7th Month in a Row
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)Prices that farmers receive for raw products entering consumer marketing channels rose 4 percent in April, the seventh consecutive monthly increase, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: Girl Who Fled Slurs Rejoins Her Family
description: SUCCASUNNA, April 28 (UPI)A 14yearold Koreanborn girl who, authorities said, fled to New York City because of racial taunts by her classmates at Roxbury Township High School has been reunited with her family.

title: Honda Raises Prices 5.2%
description: DETROIT, April 28 (AP)The United States price on Honda cars will go up 5.2 percent, or an average of $229 per car, beginning May 1, the Honda Motor Company announced today.

title: New York's Stake in Racing
description: In addition to its other charms, thoroughbred racing brings millions of dollars to the budgets of New York State and local governments, $186 million last year. But declining track attendance may endanger this sum in the future. The average daily attendance at New York tracks has dropped from 30,000 to 15,000 over the past decade. A bill now before the Legislature would seek to stimulate attendance by reducing the tax bite on the betting take. Though somewhat circuitous, this seems a reasonable approach to the difficult problem of satisfying state and local governments, horse owners and track managers, all dependent on the betting public's money.

title: Family Planning in India: New Focus in the Cities?; Range of Services Offered; Motivation vs. Lack of Quality; Question of New Delhi Support
description: HYDERABAD, India  Pramila David and her husband, Lessell, both of whom are physicians trained in the United States, are trying energetically to lend a new credibility and impetus here to what many experts ruefully term a lost cause in this country of 650 million family planning.

title: Figueroa's FiveHitter Conquers Twins, 3 to 1
description: BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 28With Ed Figueroa tossing a fivehitter, the Yankees maintained their longstanding domination over the Minnesota Twins tonight on a 31 victory that put the New Yorkers over the 500 mark for the first time this season.

title: Soybean Futures Climb In May Contract Only
description: Soybean and grain futures played a catchup game this week, but only a single contract managed to overcome the first session's severe price setback. Tightsupplies and good demand for immediate delivery, combined with reports of a sparse soybean harvest in Brazil, nudged Maydelivery soybeans to $7.22 a bushel, a few cents above the price a week ago.

title: High Court Says Phone Company Has No Obligation to Trace a Call
description: TRENTON, April 28The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled today that telephone companies were not required to trace calls to a telephone being tapped by law enforcement officials.

description: 6 A.M., WNYCAM. Sancta or Immaculata Virginitas, Gabrieli; Crucifixus, Lotti; Mass for Three Voices, Byrd.

title: Tanker Aground Off Rhode Island
description: CRANSTON, R.I., April 28 (AP)A 700 foot Texaco tanker carrying 5.5 million gallons of gasoline ran aground today on the sandy bottom of Narragansett Bay, but the Coast Guard said the vessel was undamaged. A Coast Guard spokesman said that three commercial tugboats would attempt to pull the tanker free at high tide.

title: Passman Accused Of Tax Evasions In New Indictment
description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)Former Representative Otto E. Passman was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of failing to report $143,000 in income in 1972 and 1973 arising from the Korean payoff scandal.

title: State Acts on Radioactive Trash
description: ALBANY, April 28The state's Commissioner of Energy today directed the operator of a nuclear storage facility in West Valley, N.Y., to reinforce the soil covering trenches that contain lowlevel radioactive trash to prevent the contamination of nearby water supplies.

title: Mets Change Lineup But Lose Again, 51
description: The New York Mets went to great lengths last night to locate the new offense that was supposed to enliven their new era. They revamped the lineup, they tried a suicide squeeze bunt, and Lee Mazzilli even switched to contact lenses.

title: CONSUMER PRICES UP BY 0.8% FOR MARCH
description: WASHINGTON, April 28The national annual inflation rate approached 10 percent last month, the Labor Department said today. The report had the immediate effect of raising Social Security and welfare benefits for one out of every six Americans, beeginning this summer.

title: About New York
description: Forget, for now, about San Gennaro a perfectly good saint and a good feast, too, that crowds the streets of Little Italy every fall. Soon it will be the time of San Antonio DiPadova, the honored saint each spring of a smaller, subtly different sort of festival that people around Mott and Grand Streets know better as Joe DePalo's feast.

description: WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)An officer of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation pleaded not guilty today to charges that he lied to a Senate subcommittee investigating I.T.T.'s role in Central Intelligence Agency activities to influence elections in Chile in the early 1970's.

description: WASHINGTON, April 28The Carter Administration, facing a strong fight in Congress over its proposed sale of planes to three Middle East countries, softened its language today about treating President Carter's plan as a package.

title: Harvard Students End Protest
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 2S (AP)One hundred and fifty Harvard students ended their protest late today against the university's refusal to divest itself of tecks in companies that do business in South Africa. The students blocked the entrance of University Hall from midnight last night to 5 P.M. today. The blockade followed athreehour march by about 4,000 students yesterday.

title: Atlantic City Hotel Union Accepts Contract With 13 to 44% Raises
description: ATLANTIC CITY, April 28 (AP)Members of the local hotel workers union have approved a new twoyear contract, which features raises between 13 and 44 percent in the first year plus an additional 10 percent for those who will work in casinos.

title: Judge and 2 Others Lampooned At Boat Jumpers Annual Dinner
description: LODI, April 28The Boat Jumpers, Bergen County's version of the Circus Saints and Sinners, held their 22d annual dinner tonight at the Cottage Inn here. roasting and toasting a judge, a restaurateur anda truckingcompany executive as well as most of the politicians in the county.

title: SANDY DENNY DEAD
description: Sandy Denny, a key member of Britain's pioneering folkrock band, Fairport Convention, and in the late 1960's that country's leading woman pop singer, died in London Wednesday from a brain hemorrhage ater falling down stairs at a friend's home. She was 30 years old.

description: SATURDAY, APRIL 29, 1978

title: SouthWest Africa Plan Is Attacked
description: UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 29The Western plan for bringing independence to SouthWest Africa by the end of the year was attacked in the General Assembly today by the head of the black nationalist group that the United Nations recognizes as the authentic representative of the people of the territory.

title: Fire Damages Retirement Home
description: MIAMI BEACH, April 28 (Reuters)Thirty elderly people were left homeless after a threealarm fire, thought to be electrical in origin, damaged a South Beach retirement home, the Granada Hotel, here yesterday. Several elderly victims and one fireman were treated for smoke inhalation.

description: An unemployed actor was charged in Manhattan yesterday with fraudulently obtaining monthly publicassistance payments from the government while he had $120,000 in the bank and additional cash at home.

His name wasI'll call him Robertoand ee had paid a coyote $300 to smuggle him across the border in a panel truck.

description: LONDON, April 28 (Reuters)Sir Philip Neame, who commanded British, Australian and Indian troops against the Axis forces in North Africa in the early stage of World War II, died today at the age of 89, with the retired rank of lieutenant general.

Mendelevich for the Soviet Union and Leslie H. Gelb, director of the State Department's office of political and military affairs.

title: Five Novels
description: When the Great Plague of 1665 reaches Wapping, a suburb of London, three men  two brothers and a cousin  flee to the countryside, where they become the leaders of a band of exiles. This incident is borrowed from Daniel Defoe's Journal of the Plague Year'; alas, instead of just retelling the story, both author and illustrator get tangled up in the process of explicating it. Weighed down by interpolated background information and a misplaced loyalty to Defoe's prose style, the dialogue has all the urgency of a planning session for a routine business trip to Sussex. Charles Mikolaycak's illustrations, described by the jacket copy as panoramic murals which flow with filmic progress . . add to the stiffness through their emphasis on swirling drapery and classical physiques. Most children would find a straight, nonfiction account more inviting.

title: Students Are Bullish About the M.B.A.
description: ADECADE ago, a master's de. gree in business administration was widely regarded as a surefire ticket to the executive suite, and the most certain path this side of medical school to a sixfigure income.

title: Campus Vacations: For Body and Mind; A Survey of Campus Vacations That Exercise the Mind and Body; Photographs by Hugh Smyser (top); Robert J. Iz zo Cower left
description: Last summer, while her husband and three children spent their customary vacation week in the mountains, Patience Powell of Takoma, Wash. went back to the University of Washington campus for the first time since she'd graduated in 1961. She lived in a dormi- tory with a bathroom down the hall, ate breakfast in the cafeteria, spent much of each day in lectures, seminars and discussion groups. And she found the week so exhiliarating that she actually seems sorry that a longplanned tour of Europe will prevent her from returning to Seattle this summer.

title: The Messy Charm Of Don Quixote Challenges Baryshnikov

The latest person to say it is Mikhail Baryshnikov, who has staged the work afresh for American Ballet Theater. His version, which received its premiere in, Washington on March 23, will be presented for the first time in New York on Tuesday at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: South Africa Will Yield on Namibia
description: It had been a long time coming and when it did arrive last week, South Africa's agreement to selfgovernment for SouthWest Africa came only because no better alternative was left. Pretoria conceded that the territory, called Namibia by Africans, should be granted independence according to plan devised by five Western nations. South Africa has ruled the land since 1920 under a League of Nations mandate but that was revoked 12 years ago.

title: Grounded Tanker Reaches Dock
description: PROVIDENCE, R. I., April 29 (UPI)--A tanker carrying 127,000 barrels of gasoline arrived at a Texaco dock here today, eight hours after she ran aground in Narrangansett Bay. A Coast Guard spokes. man said that apparently none of the 5.2 million gallons of fuel spilled into the bay after the tanker struck bottom Friday two miles from its destination. The tanker was headed to the Texaco dock here from Bayonne, N. J. There were no injuries.

title: IN BRIEF
description: The trade deficit turned 22 last week, which is to say that with the release of the March figures, the United States has reported a trade deficit in each of the 22 months since May 1976. Last month's red ink  $2.8 billion  was a decided improvement over February's record $4.5 billion deficit, but it was 'still the fifth largest on the Commerce Department's books. Imports of oil fell to $3.1 billion, a $900 million drop that the department said was aided by increasing Alaska oil production. Steel imports also declined during March, when the Treasury Department's trigger pricing system for imports of the metal went into effect. ... Free trade won an hardfought first round when the House Ways and Means Committee rejected by a vote of 21 to 16 an attempt to overturn President Carter's decision to deny import relief to the American manufacturers of metal fasteners. The President had overruled an International Trade Commission recommendation that tarrifs on nuts and bolts be increased 20 to 30 percent to protect domestic manufacturers.

title: Cuban Students team on the Farm
description: J11 OSE MACEO PreUniversity adjoins a 7,500acre citrus cooperative farm on Cuba's Isle of Pines. Openair walkways connect the prefabricated classroom, dormitory and dining areas, and neat rows of grapefruit trees are planted just beyond the building line.

title: Oyster Bay Is Joining the Trend To Convert Garbage Into Energy
description: It was perhaps inevitable that a society that in recent years has generated between 136 million and 145 million tons of garbage a year would one day find some better way to use this waste than as underpinning for golf courses. The Supreme Court ruled last week that an employer whose pension plan charges women more than men is committing illegal sex discrimination.

I., and Naples, Fla., was married last evening at the St. RegisSheraton to Craig Michael Fisher, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester Fisher of New York and Palm Beach, Fla. Long- wooed, but never won, the novel passenger is the transAtlantic traveler, until now the missing element in the airport's long quest to come of age, justify its name as an international airline facility and realize its potential as the metropolitan area's third major airport.

description: Ruling that a key prosecution witness had acted as a police agent when she elicited a prejudicially incriminating statement from her sister, a State Supreme Court justice in Queens has grant ed ,a mistrial for, two accused lesbian lovers indicted for the murder of one I of their husbands.

title: Wednesday Is Sun Day
description: On the East Coast, people will climb mountains watch the sun rise over the Atlantic. On the West Coast they'll gather to watch it set over the Pacific. And between others will race cars powered by it, dance to or simply soak up its rays. These observances on Wednesday, Sun Day, are meant to spark a political movement that will lead the United States into the solar era just as Earth Day, eight years ago, dramatized the environmental movement. The effort is timely. The Carter Administration has done little to spotlight tile potential of solar energy since the President stood coatless in a solarheated reviewing stand during his inaugural.

The novel is written in the form of a journal by a film maker who is floating in a French village and drafting a script for a movie about the Brooklyn neighborhood where he was reared. So it is also a novel about a Jewish boy and a cynical film man and a hopeful artist. Both the real world and the world of art trouble this person.

In the first place, it's a play in three acts, a form virtually unheard of in these twoact, or even intermissioniess, times. In the second place, it's a play in three good acts, which more or less unthinkable.

This brightly written book about Sir Edmund Backhouse (18731999) begins as a conventional biography (he was the scion of an English Quaker family, Oxfordeducated), turns into a tale adventure and intrigue (he consummated many tricky business deals in China during its gaudy decadence), ends as an expos of a respected mandarin (he forged a famous diary, wrote several obscene memoirs).

title: Adam Woolfil  Woodfin Camo
description: The marvel of Panama, they say, is the canal. But the country is also blessed with some delightful islands, ranging from elegant, sophisticated Contadora, 33 miles from the mouth of the canal in the Pacific, to the primitive San Blas Islands in the Atlantic, where the Cuna Indians used coconuts as currency until recently and women wear gold rings in their noses. Bridging the extremes, Taboga Island, also in the Pacific, is quiet, pleasant and a favorite weekend retreat for Panamanians.

title: ARCHITECTURE VIEW
description: The word has finally come: After three city administrations considered five different locations over a 10year period, New York has decided to build its new convention center on the site of the Pennsylvania railyards at 39th Street and the Hudson River. A few clear facts have emerged from the confusion and delay. The first is that there is no longer any question about the need for the convention center. If New York is to be competitive with other cities, it must build one now. The direct and indirect economic benefits of conventions and trade shows range from increased hotel and restaurant business to the spinoffs of entertainment and tourism and the service industries that are so essential to this city's vitality and financial wellbeing. At least half a dozen other cities have large, new and sometimes dramatically handsome convention facilities that put New York out of the running.

In several magazines, a fourpage, fullcolor advertisement praised the special relationship between Riyadh and Washington.

title: PEOPLE

Schlitz Brewing Company announced the appointment of Mr. Proudfoot as its executive vice president for marketing. Clearly this is a challenging post, since the 129-year-old brewer is trou- bled by competitive pressure. Schlitz, formerly America's second largest brewer, has been overtaken by Philip Morris Inc.'s Miller Brewing Company. (AnheuserBusch Inc. remains No. 1.)

title: Lettter T 0 T H E E D I T 0 R
description: As a psychologist working on a book about risktaking, I was intrigued by Tito Gaona's dilemma and John Culhane's attempt to analyze it (Trapeze: The Quest for the Impossible Quadruple Somersault, March 19). The four somersaults are not the risk for Tito; he has flown them innumerable times. But [at this writing] Tito has not yet been caught in public. Being caught is the risk. Here two elements seem to be operating dynamically. Tito has a fantasy that he will injure the catcher. His focus on this loss and the anxiety it produces prevents him from letting himself be caught. But this fantasy is linked subtly to yet another. A successful catch, as Culhane points out to Tito (who largely agrees with the interpretation), may lead to separation from his family and a confrontation with a decision to marry. Tito sees independence from family and involvement with a woman as a loss. As he turns into the fourth somersault, Tito enters the fear zone (which clouds the gains), touches the catcher and falls to the net. But my money is on Tito. One of these days I feel he will break through the fear zone, let go, that is, get caught by his catcher  and possibly by a

title: Solomon, Barazzutti Gain Tennis Final at Las Vegas
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev. April 29Harold Solomon and Corrado Barazzutti, two selfcohfessed baseline players, gained the final of a $250,000 tennis tournament on the outdoor courts at Caesars Palace today in tricky wind conditions. And when they meet tomorrow for the $50,000 first prize there is an excellent chance that they will run over whatever time slot ABC has allotted for the national telecast (1:30 P.M., New York time, on Channel 7).

title: Speedreading: Will It Make You Speedier?; If You Want to Try It,
description: HARRIET A. HEUSER, who runs an insurance agency in Manhattan and is studying to become a charter life underwriter, found that speedreading enabled her to read more for business and pleasure and taught her good study habits.

title: Concrete Bridge Spanning L.I.R.R. Tracks in Greenport Being Repaired With Unlikely Material Plastic
description: GREENPORT, severely deteriol rated concrete bridge along Route 25 that spans the Long Island Rail Road tracks here is being repaired with an unlikely materialplastic.

title: SOVIET FREES LAST 2 IN KOREAN PLANE CASE
description: MOSCOW, April 29 The pilot and navigator of a South Korean passenger jet that was fired on and forced to land on April 20 after violating Soviet air space were pardoned and allowed to leave for Western Europe today.

title: Doctor Links Indian Art to Drugs
description: WASHINGTON, Aug 29 (UPI)A New York doctor says that some of the finest rock paintings of the early American Indians may have been produced under the influence of hallucinogenic plants.

title: Illiteracy in the U.S.: Why John Can't Cope
description: AHIGHSCHOOL graduate on Long Island sues the local school system because he cannot read above the thirdgrade level. The chief _ personnel for the Navy reports $250,000 damage to a diesel engine because a sailor who worked on it could not read the maintenance manual.

title: Legal Help From an ExD.A.
description: STONY BROOK

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: Isaac Bashevis Singer picks up here where his previous memoir, A Little Boy in Search of God, left off: with the young author in the tenacious arms of his much older lover (and landlady), Gina, and with him trying, through a bit of starvation, to duck the draft. Here again, we are in the world of prewar Yiddish Warsaw, which, we know, is about to be obliterated by history. And we are also, of course, in the exhilarating good company of Mr. Singer, churning with restless skepticism, moral passion and erotic preoccupation.

title: Unauthorized Adoration
description: JOHN HUSTON  Hemingway hero as movie director  has made his reputation largely by operating within the studio system, and occasionally by outwitting that system. Some of his films have become popular classics ('The Maltese Falcon, The Treasure of Sierra Madre, The Asphalt Jungle and The African Queen'). Others have gone down as major disappointments ('Moby Dick, Freud and The Bible'). More than most American directors, Mr. Huston is responsible  for his successes as well as his failures. The chief question mark in his career is The Red Badge of Courage. One would have liked to have seen Mr. Huston's version before it was emasculated by studio hands.

title: Inmates Sue to Have Prison in Jamesville Closed
description: SYRACUSE, April 29Prisoners at the rathesville Penitentiary, charging that the fadility is alternately too hot and too cold because insulation was not invented:rat the time it was built, filed a classaction. suit this week in Federal District Court here in an attempt to close it.

title: Cannes Is Also a Marketplace for Worldwide TV
description: CANNES, FranceThe breeze that sways the palm trees and stirs the beach sand is still cool here at this time of the yearcool enough to keep Cannes elderly yearround residents in fur coats and tailored gabardines, and to dissuade bikiniclad starlets from strolling on the corniche.

title: DANCE  VIEW
description: The relationship between man and his universe has never been a favorite subject fot American ballet. Yet it is obviously a preoccupation that Ns not died elsewhere, judging from a. number of premieres in New York this month by choreographers who work abroad. The foremost examples of the genre are the recent works by two restaent cnoreographers of the Dutch National Ballet, with which Rudolf Nureyev has been appearing at the Minskoff Theater. In addition, Heptagon, a world premiere by Oscar Araiz for the Joffrey Ballet, gave further proofseen earlier with the Royal Winnepeg Balletof the Argentine choreographer's interest in social commentary.

title: Elizabeth Hale Married To H. J. Reid, Engineer
description: Elizabeth Hale, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. L. Gordon Hale Jr. of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married yesteray afternoon to Harry Joseph Reid, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward A. Reid of Glen Rock, N.J. The Rev. Richard E. Ryder performed the ceremony in the First, Congregational Church of Chappaqua. The Rev. Alfred Moore assisted.

title: Racial and Social Conflict Disrupting Brooklyn College
description: Outside, around the grassy quadrangle of the Brooklyn College campus in the heart of the Flatbush section, most students sunned themselves, a few chased Frisbees and one blew swing through a clarinet.

title: Julie Dolan Plans Marriage on Aug. 20 To Arthur T. Smith
description: Mr. and Mrs. James T. Dolan of Southport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Julie St. James Dolan, to Arthur Tremaine Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chard P. Smith Jr. of St. Louis. The wedding is planned for Aug. 20.

title: LETTER FROM WASHINGTON `Young Turks Find A Hero in Maguire.
description: FOR Representative Andrew Maguire of Ridgewood and a score of allies in the House who have been called Young Turks, although they're now getting on toward 40, it was pure frustration. It was like swat- ting a mule (or the Democratic donkey) smartly between the eyes with a 2-by-9 and getting only a sleepy blink of the eye in response.

title: Ronnie Goldberg, a Teacher; Engaged to Michael Becher
description: Mr. and Mrs. Albert Goldberg of Freeport, L.1., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ronnie Goldberg, to Michael R.S. Becher, son of Fay Becher of Brooklyn and the late Rabbi Szaul Becher. A September wedding is planed.

title: Westchester/This Week
description: BALDWIN PLACE  Two Gentlemen of Verona. Theaterparty performance for singles; Thursday, 8 P.M. $10.50. 1365. Friday and Saturday, 8 P.M.; next Sunday, P.M. $5.50, Saturday $6.50. Reservations. Mahopac Farm Playhouse, Rte. 6.

title: Repairing a Bridge While Traffic Flows
description: GREENPORT

title: Chicagoans Critical Of Losing Library To Cultural Center
description: CHICAGO, April 29The rising voice of criticism has disrupted ,the traditional quiet at the Chicago Public Library, which, With SO branches, 2,000 staff members, a seven million volume collection and a $34 million annual budget, ranks as the second largest in the country. Only New York City's is larger.

title: INVESTING
description: Retail stocks in recent years have suffered the fate of wallflowers at the disco, drawing partners only when the real beauties were already dancing their feet off.

title: Jane W. Simmons Bride of Frank Lees
description: Jane Wilson Simmons, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Wilson Simmons of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday afternoon to Frank Lees, a field specialist with Tektronix Inc. in Poughkeepsie, N.Y. The Rev. Joseph Bishop performed the ceremony in the Rye (N.Y.) Presbyterian Church.

title: Illiteracy Is a Growing Global Problem
description: 0NE adult in three in the world cannot read, write or do a simple sum in writing. according to estimates by the United Nations. While this represents a reduction in percentages over the last quarter of a century, the total number of illiterates in the world rose during the same period, and women and children are falling behind on both counts.

title: Around the Nation
description: AUGUSTA, Kan., April 29 (A)The pilots of a BT13, a World War IIvintage trainer, and a small private aircraft, Cessna 152, were killed today when their aircraft collided in air as they tried to land simultaneously at Augusta Muncipal Airport. The BT13 pilot, John Forst, 67 years old, had been flying for years and the other, was Charles Canon, 30, relatively new, according to an official of the city of Augusta.

title: The Exacting Art of Lieder Singing
description: German lieder is in some ways the most exacting of all musical forms. It requires singers of unusually refined vocal and interpretive sensibilities as well as audiences willing to concentrate closely on a subtle blend of poetry and music. In general, this field has been the province of Germanspeaking singers, and there have never been many of them at any one timetoday, only Dietrich FischerDieskau, Elly Ameling and Hermann Prey can offer an entire evening of lieder and expect to fill the hall.

title: FOOD A Neglected Seafood: Squid
description: SQUID, one of the least popular of the Island's mollusks, is a lowcalorie, highprotein seafood that hardly deserves such neglect.

title: Miss Brennan, W. A. Hastings To Wed July. 29
description: Dr and Mrs. Edmund J. Brennan of Waterbury, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Patricia Eileen Brennan of ondon, to William Al?bott Hastings, also. of London. He is a son of the Rev. Dr. and Mrs. William Bradford Turner Hastings of Greenwich. Conn. The couple will be married July 29 in Waterbury.

title: Financing Casinos
description: ATLANTIC CITY EVER since New Jersey voters authorized casinohotels here in 1976, a score of companies has announced plans to build such establishments, only to find themselves stymied by an inability to obtain longterm mortgage financing for their multimilliondollar projects.

title: Cost of Living in Austin, Tex., Rated Lowest in 40 Cities in U.S. Survey
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (AP)Dollar for dollar, a family of four lives better in Austin, Tex., than in any other metropolitan area in the United States, according to a Government survey of 40 cities.

title: Surviving The Odds
description: By Dale Fife.

title: Georgia Pugh Wed To Milton Howard
description: Georgia McEldowney Pugh and Milton Bryan Howard were married yesterday at the Unitarian Church in Pomona Valley, Calif., by the Rev. Evert Howard, the bridegroom's cousin.

title: Discipline Without Shutting the Door
description: ONATHAN had always been problem student  raucous, uncaring and disobedient  his teachers at Spring Valley High School in Columbia, S.C., would say. Now there is a new Jonathan  disciplined. wellmannered, even studious.

title: Nicaraguan Government Agrees To Student Protesters Demands
description: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, April 29 (AP)President Anastasio Somoza Debayle will meet demands of protesting students and hunger strikers, including the transfer two imprisoned guerrillas from solitary confinement, a Government spokesman said today.

title: 20 Years for SANE
description: DOROTHY ELDRIDGE remembers one period when New Jersey SANE floundered for a little while and another time that was a low point, and she recalls many occasions when SANE members were sworn at or baited and often called Communists.

title: ART VIEW
description: HILTON KRAMER

title: Root for Rhubarb
description: Rhubarb is forever  practically. Once planted, the handsome perennial vegetable will produce succulent red stems for pies, stews and fruit compotes for years and years. But long life for the future depends on proper planting.

title: Egyptian Newspaper Tells of Plot To Assassinate Jordan's Premier
description: CAIRO, April 29 (AP)A band of suspected terrorists arrested here earlier this month had plotted to assassinate Jordan's Prime Minister on a trip to Switzerland, the newspaper Al Akhhar reported today.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to tile following events may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicatea:

title: L.I. Men's Indoor Tennis Champion Says Graduate School and Marriage Not the Game Get Priority
description: BRIGHTWATERS, L. I.As a tournamenttennis player, Dave, Oberstein does not quite fit the mold. He has no burning desire to Lecome a nationally rankig star, nor visions of charging to victory on the center court at Wimbledon.

title: WESTMESTER JOURNAL
description: James, Feron

title: VERY REV. PAUL T. LUTOV, RUSSIAN ORTHODOX PASTOR
description: The Very Rev. Paul T. Lutov, the former pastor of the Russian Orthodox Church of St. Nicholas in Washington, died Friday at Providence Hospital in Washington. He was 78 years old.

title: On His Honor, It's An Honest Budget
description: It's a renaissance budget, Ed Koch proudly said last week, to show that the city was making a new beginning with new Mayor  and perhaps to show that its accounting procedures were at last moving out of the Hall of Mirrors.

title: dale Loves Me
description: ONE night last September I returned home from College Board preparation course, my head reeling with theorems and dangling participles. opened the top door of my refrigerator only to be crushed under an avalanche of college catalogues and applications.

title: U.N. Sea Law Meeting in Geneva End 5 Weeks of Procedural Work
description: GENEVA, April 29 (Reuters)The United Nations Sea Law Conference, which is to set international rules for navigation and exploitation of the oceans, finally completed its procedural work last night after five weeks of its scheduled eightweek session here.

title: LETTERS TO THE WESTCHESTER EDITOR
description: Lticien Greif wonders about luncheon gettogethers for mental stimulation, and how to go about forming a club [April 16]. It's a cinch, the way a batch of us began the Writers Round Table in the Larchmont / Mamaroneck area. We gather every six weeks or so for rousing, informative talk. Soundingoff eases frustrations, sends each back more readily to the sweetsad isolation of writing.

title: Federal Help for State's Urban Areas
description: THE Carter Administration revealed two surprises and great deal of political courage few days ago when it gave the House Ways and Means Committee a tentative list of communities eligible for special Federal incentives to attract private, investment as part of the President's new national urban policy.

title: Louise Hickok, George Snyder, Lawyers, Wed
description: St. James Episcopal Church in Goshen, N.Y., was the setting yesterday morning for the marriage of Louise Loring Hickok, daughter of William Orville Hickok 6th of Goshen and the late Elizabeth Chace Hickok, to George Brian Snyder, son of Mrs. Paul Snyder of Oakwood, S.I., and the late Mr. Snyder.

title: North Jersey Fears Westway Floods
description: JERSEY CITY NORTH JERSEY environmentalists, who for more than four years have opposed the construction of the Westway in Lower Manhattan, have been joined by Mayor Thomas F. X. Smith of Jersey City in a renewed attack on the proposed $1.16 billion highway. They fear that the project might cause flooding here and in Hoboken and Bayonne.

title: Newark Lacking Cobalt Machines
description: NEWARK THE only operable radiation machine for treating cancer patients in Newark is at United Hospitals. However, the machine is 21 years old and has a relatively weak source of radioactive cobalt, which is suspended over a patient by means of a steel arm that has broken at least once and had to be welded.

title: 4 Children Die in Fire in Maine
description: CORNVILLE, Me., April 29 (AP)Four stepbrothers who were trapped in an upstairs bedroom died when fire swept through their home early today, the authorities said. The victims were identified as Kevin Pilvinis, 5 years old; Mark Pilvinis, 11; Peter Liguz, 13, and David Taylor, 14. The cause of the fire, which started in a shed attached to the house, is under investigation.

title: Retired Ship Studied As Home for Elderly
description: BERKELEY, Calif., April 29 (AP)The University of California is studying ways to develop the retired cruise ship Mariposa into a floating home for the elderly.

title: Norwegians Watch Over Ruined Lebanese Village
description: IBL AS SAQI, Lebanon, April 25 The villagers came back here to look at their shelledruined houses, the demolished church, the fields and the gardens cordoned off by yellow tape as a warning against mines and unexploded shells. And then they went away.

title: Sherley Shevlin Engaged To Samuel W. Meek 3d
description: Mrs. Thomas H. Shevlin of Palm Beach, Fla., and Nanyuki, Kenya, has announced the engagement of her daughter, Sherley Shevlin. to Samuel Williams Meek 3d, son of Mr. Meek Jr. of Palm Beach, and Mrs. H. Lawrence Parker of Bedford, N.Y.

title: Out of the Service;
description: Headliners

title: MilkCarton Toys
description: TEANECK IT took Marjorie Weinberg a decade to invent a toy that satisfied all her goals. She was adamant that the final product amuse small children for hours by stimulating both their imaginations and intellects, that it use waste materials found around the home and that it cost parents a minimal amount of money.

title: Allison Erenstein Engaged To John Charles Jacobsen
description: The engagement of Allison Lee Erenstein to John Charles Jacobsen has been made known by her parents, MT. and Mrs. Morton Bruce Erenstein of Florham Park, N.J. Mr. Jacobsen is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert B. Jacobsen of South Orange, N.J.

title: PAPERBACK TALK
description: Fantastic legacy. On June 11, 1936, Robert E. Howard, 30, the loner son of a Cross Plains, Tex., physician, heard that his mother had lapsed into a terminal coma. Distraught, he shot himself with the revolver he always carried with him to take care of unseen enemies. Little notice was paid to the tragedy outside of his central Texas hometown, although Howard had been able to eke out a living  $12,000 over years  writing fantasies, Westerns, pirate stories, detective and adventure yarns for the pulps.

title: Nixon, in Memoirs, Admits CoverUp on Watergate
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon admits in his memoirs that he was participant in the Watergate coverup and that he misled the American people about his role in it. But he says his actions were the result of a series of misjudgments or tactical errors as he found himself drawn into the scandal that drove him from office.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL.
description: HAVING given casino gambling to Atlantic City, legislators are now expected to lower the state tax on thoroughbred race tracks in New Jersey.

title: This Time They Are Playing Politics, Not Violins
description: 13 ERN, Switzerland-- Traditionally, the wandering Gypsy tribes of the world  the Romany nation, as they call themselves  have reacted to discrimination, harassment and persecution with passive resistance. But a new assertiveness now appears to mark change in the selfperception of the Gypsy people. Last week, for example, British Gypsies threatened to block highways unless they receive better treatment from local authorities, and did block four Foreign Office parking spaces with a house .trailer to drive their point home. And earlier this month, a world congress of Gypsies, meeting in Geneva, seemed to show tbat on an international level this widely scattered group is ready to become the latest entry in the human rignts movement. A new Romany CoOrdination Committee established terni3orary headquarters in Bern, and is setting up working groups to help press the demands that Gypsies in various countries are beginning to make.

title: GARDENING Planters on the Prowl
description: IT'S hunting season for gardeners - the time when serious planters spend hours driving up and down the back country roads to the nursery or greenhouse that offers a particular tree. shrub, perennial or herb. How much easier it would be if plants were gathered for sale in one place where garden shopping could be accomplished in a morning or afternoon and the sponsoring organization could add some dollars to its coffers.

title: Convention Centers In Other Cities
description: A convention center is, essentially, a container for crowds. Most are massive, blind, concrete boxes that breed not life, but parking garages. New designs for Berlin and San Francisco depart from the big, sealed container to create street scale and life. The San Francisco building will be partly underground; the Berlin center, to be completed next year, is a dynamic international complex that is more advanced than anything in this country. Buffalo's new convention center is the kind of conventional blockbuster that New York should avoid. It takes skillful connections to the surroundings and dramatic and elegant structural systems to turn a convention center into an architectural and urban event. A.L.H.

title: ASSEMBLY VOTES BILL TO LEGALIZE LAETRILE
description: ALBANY, April 27Following the Senate, the Assembly overwhelmingly voted this week to permit doctors to prescribe the controversial cancer drug Idetrile. The cancerstricken sponsor of the Assembly bill said he would move to override an expected veto by Governor Carey.

title: GARDENING Transplanting Time Is a Time for Care
description: THE transplanting season is upon us. Flower and vegetable plants possessing cold-hardiness can be planted out any time now, but it is still a critical stage in the life of a seedling or a rooted cutting.

title: House Tours
description: The following chronological listing, compiled by Ruth Rejnis, is a selection of notable house tours in the metropolitan area through the summer.

title: 9.9% IS AVERAGE INCREASE IN 1978 LABOR CONTRACTS
description: WASHINGTON,. April 29 (Reuters)Major collective bargaining settlements in the United States in the first quarter of 1978 were more costly than lastyear, the Labor Department says.

title: 12 Demonstrators at White House Are Arrested by Secret Service
description: WASHINGTON. April 29 (AP)Unifornted police officers of the Secret Service arrested 12 persons today as they trion to demonstrate on the White House grounds, the service reported.

title: Miss Marcus, Wharton 78, Sets Nuptials
description: Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Marcus of New York have announced the engage- ment of their daughter, Wendy Karen Marcus, to Albert Monroe Greenfield 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Greenfield Jr. of Glenmoore, Pa. The wedding . is Planned for June.

title: The Mystique of Sports: Is It Really Big Bucks and Big. Bull?; Pigskin to President; A Saturation on Television
description: By the age of 11, girls normally give up the game of jacks. Men Would never do that. No ,matter how simple the game or sport they play as little boys, men don't, give it up. They carry their games into manhood, where they glorify them, sell tickets to them and make bie business of them.

title: Cholera Cases Said to Declics
description: GENEVA, April 29 (Reuters)Tnte World Health Organization says that 7,000 fewer cases of cholera were reported in the world last year than in 1076. But 34 countries reported outbreaks the disease in 1977, compared with 25 in 1976 and 29 in 1975. The number cases reported in 1977 was 58,661, against 65,734 in 1976 and 90,467 in 1975.

title: New Solution for Waste: Turn It Into Energy
description: IT was perhaps inevitable that a society that in recent years has generated between 136 million and 195 million tons garbage a year would one day find some better way to use this waste than as underpinning for golf courses. But few, no matter how visionary, could have predicted that communities in the tristate area might one day be competing to get one another's garbage.

title: So Sorry, Wrong Wimber
description: WHEN the calls started, dismissed them as routine wrong numbers, petty annoyances. Even before the calls increased to constant, a pattern formed: Without salutation, the callers read off numbers or ordered me to come up with numbers.

title: At Yeshiva, Study For Study's Sake
description: IN an era of vocationalism in higher education, Yeshiva University has revived a centuriesold academic designation that will not help a student get a job or earn money. It is called tHe chaver program, and in the words of Dr. Norman Lamm, president of the university, it is a course of study simply for the sake of study.

title: Carter, Si!
description: RIO DE JANEIROIt seems that underdeveloped countries, starting with Latin America's, have a better understanding of President Carter's human rights policy than the United States.

title: Kelly B. Hartman Is a Bride
description: The marriage of Kelly Bill Hartman, A drama teacher, to George Sterghiou took place yesterday in St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan, Conn. The. Rev. Alfred H. Whisler performed he ceremony. The bride is a daughter of John W. Hartman, chairman of Bill Communications, publishers of business magazines, and Mrs. Hartman of New Canaan. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Spifos Sterghiou of Kifissia, Greece.

title: Aldeburgh  Benefit Concert Given
description: Benjamain Britten, the late English composer, and Peter Pears, the English tenor, founded the Aldeburgh Festival over 30 years ago, developing it into a major musical center. In recent years it has been getting support from the American Friends of the Aldeburgh Festival. On Friday night this organi- zation and the Oratorio Society of New York presented a benefit concert for the festival in Carnegie Hall, appropriately devoting half of it to works by Britten and the other half to the Mozart Requiem.

description: By Stefan Kan& r.

title: The Odd Man Out
description: WASHINGTON In the jigsaw puzzle of world trade Japan is coming increasingly to be recognized as the piece that doesn't fit. The reasons stem from the essential structure of the Japanese

title: Linda F. Joy To Be aBride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Fessenden Joy of Glen Ridge, N.J., of, the engagement of their daughter, Linda Fessenden Joy, to Elliot Arthur Baines Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Baines of Woodbridge, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: High Court, Congress on Campaign Contributions, Lobbying
description: There were two major developments last week that affect the way American business operates in the political forum.  In a decision with broad implications for corporate political activity, the Supreme Court ruled that states cannot bar corporations from spending unlimited amounts of their money to influence the outcome of public referendums.

title: Jessica Weiss, Script Aide, Bride of Carl Teitelbaum
description: Jessica Weiss, a film script supervisor, was married yesterday to Carl Teitelbaum, a movie cameraman. Rabbi Dennis Math performed the ceremony at the Town Tennis Club.

description: Irvin Molotsky

title: maple Leafs. Beat Islanders 2-1, In Overtime to Capture Series
description: UNIONDALE, LI., April 29The Islanders dream of winning the Stanley Cup came to a suddendeath end tonight. With one swing of his stick at 4 minutes 13 seconds of overtime, Lanny McDonald of the Toronto Maple Leafs scored to beat the Islanders, 21, and eliminate them from the National Hockey League playoffs, four games to three.

title: MUSIC VIEW
description: HAROLD C. SCHONBERG

title: LESTER LEVENTHAL
description: Lester Leventhal, president of the Globe Book Company in New York, died Wednesday after suffering a heart attack while playing tennis. He was 58 years old and lived in Fort Lee, N.J.

title: BOOK ENDS; Heart Doctor; Art and Politics; political reasons, whether or not one is famous.; Interviewer Interviewed; Canadian Find; Reading Clubs (cont.)
description: THERE seem to be a lot of doctornovelists about, including Dr. Christiaan Barnard, the South African heart surgeon, whose new novel, In the Night Season, written with collaborator Sigfried Stander, has been published by PrenticeHall.

title: Unusual Vegetables Challenge the Planter's Expertise
description: Tired of the same old peas and carrots or lettuce and tomatoes? There are many unusual, easy-to-grow vegetables and even fruits that you can plant this year to add variety to the garden and table. The fruits include Alpine strawberries, ground cherries, and garden huckleberries.

title: National Park Camping
description: The new edition of Camping in the National Park System, which lists the services and facilities found in 100 National Park areas from Alaska to the Virgin Islands, is now available to the public.

title: Primaries Open and Closed
description: DURING the current Democratic primary contest for the United States Senate nomination, there has been a great deal of discussion about closed vs. open priMerles. Listening to the candidates discuss their feelings about the subject is a little like hearing a debtite on How high is up?

title: Court Restricts Arrests of Suspects In Their Homes Without Warrants
description: Criminal suspects cannot be arrested in their homes by Federal agents without a warrant, except in extreme circumstances, according to a unanimous decision in Manhattan by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

description: FRESH AIR FUND MEANS

title: Kathryn Posin Presents 4 Dances
description: Kathryn Posin is a puzzling choreographer. On the strength of the four works presented by the Kathryn Posin Dance Company on Friday at the American Place Theater, her dances take off from a classical ballet foundation and suddenly reverse gears, blunting that impulse toward controlled abandon with contortions that, while they are stylish, effectively inhibit movement.

description: HARTFORD

description: The movies are currently offering a crash course the history of rock and roll. In the beginning, according to American Hot Wax, rock was the music of teenage rebellion, and adults were scandalized. By the mid1960's, as 1 Wanna Hold Your Hand would have it, rock was capable of gener-

title: County in Nevada Gets Navy Land
description: WASHINGTON, April 29 (Reuters)President Carter has signed legislation transferring about 2,620 acres of public land to Mineral County, Nevada, for fair market price. The land, no longer required by the Navy, would have been routinely transferred to the Bureau of Land Management. But the land would have been costly for the bureau to manage and Mineral County had asked for it, the White House said on Tuesday.

title: Composing for Breton Bird Calls
description: In recent years Nova Scotia, and especially Cape Breton Island, has become something of a summer spa cum rural retreat for a good many New Yorkarea experimental composers and artists. Daniel Goode, a clarinetist and composer who teaches at the Livingston College of Rutgers University, first went to Cape Breton six years ago, and has since become an expert in the indigenous music of the area.

title: Black Group Clings To Mormon Church Despite Restriction
description: SALT LAKE CITY, April 29 (AP)The only organized group of black Mormons is dwindling in size, but its few active members express deep devotion to church that denies them full blessings.

title: TV VIEW
description: JOHN J. O'CONNOR

title: POINT OF ViEW
description: In 1977 Japan's surplus on current account  the difference between its sales of goods and services to foreigners and its purchases from them  reached record $11 billion. In anticipation of the strain this imbalance .vould place on the international monetary and trading system, American and Japanese officials began urgent discussions on how best to reduce it.

title: Grace Paley: Short Story of Success
description: FOR Grace Paley, the author of two critically praised shortstory collections, The Little Disturbances of Man and Enormous Changes at the Last Minute, the distance between GreenWich Village, her home for the last 30 years, and the Bronxville campus of Sarah Lawrence, where she teaches in the English department, bridges years of street savvy, peace activism, occasional writing, childrearing and survival.

title: Iran Looks to Sun to Conserve Oil
description: The Shah of Irah, who wants to reduce his country's dependence on oil, has ordered that solar heating equipment be used in a $500million housing and office complex that is to rise on the western outskirts of Teheran.

title: Three Women, Two Men.
description: It is surely a sign of the times that of the five American biographies just released for teenagers, those dealing with three unorthodox women are far superior in interest, treatment and sheer readability. The

title: A Home Between Sea and Sky
description: ANUMBER of pleasure boats originally intended for casual cruising are being used by their Westchester liveaboard owners as permanent waterborne residences. At least seven such yachts, with fulltime occupants aboard, spent the cold hard winter months tied into slips at the New Rochelle Municipal Marina. Equipped with special heating units and protected by canvas or plastic covers, the floating homes fared well, in spite of heavy snowfalls, and are currently being spruced up for spring.

title: Sports News Briefs
description: PRAGUE, April 29 (AP)Mats Ahlberg scored three goals and Bengt Lundholm two as Sweden routed East Germany by 101 today in the world icehockey tournament. Earlier Czechoslovakia, behind four goals by two brothers, Marian and Peter Stistnv. won its third game with an 82 decision over West Germany.

title: Food
description: The salad dressing known in America as French dressing is not the one most commonly used in France. That salad dressing is sauce salade, consisting of approximately three parts oil to one part vinegar, with salt and pepper to taste. What Americans call French dressing is a creamy concoction which coats the greens in a way that the basic French dressing does not. It is made of oil, vinegar, a trifling amount of egg yolk, plus a touch of heavy cream to thin it. It is, in fact, made like a mayonnaise. The heavy cream tends to give a smoothness to the dressing, and it also prevents the dressing from breaking down or separating once it is made. Our version has a touch of finely chopped garlic for flavor and a bit of lemon juice.

title: The. Fierce Dedication of The Demon Drummers

title: Glimpses of Old
description: They numbered among the world's first photojournalists  those intrepid men who headed east for imperial China in the 1860's. Their names are unfamiliar to many of us in the 1970's: Felice A. Beato, John Thomson, P. H. Egerton. But their work, as well as the work of many other pioneer photographers in that vast land, is as important to a portrait of an era as Henri CartierBresson's was in revealing the deeply divided China of the 1940's. A collection of more than 200 of the finest of those early photographs of China has been brought together, for the first time, in The Face of China As Seen by Photographers & Travelers 18601912, which is being shown at the Philadelphia Museum of Art through June 25. An impressive selection of the photographs in the exhibition is reproduced in a book by the same name, to be published in May by Aperture Inc.

We live in a society that trusts children to grasp the most sophisticated visual ideas but is reluctant to expose them to challenging language or unduly stimulating syntax.

They were supported by 84 percent of the proxy votes cast.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND When He Flies, the Fish May Go Along

At any rate, my own hangup is easily refuted by any number of Long Island Sunday air aces who have taken up flying and, in a few cases, even made business out of it.

title: Teaching Teacher a Lesson

Breathy novels about drugs, sexual liberation and subproletariat gang warfare let off scotfree the majority of young readers, who are virtually all middleclass, who deny drugs are a problem, and who are amazingly prudish about other people's sex lives.

title: Peabody Is Leading Fight Against StripMining Law
