title: Ring, Court and Board
description: Since 1969, when he won the heavyweight boxing title from the late Sonny Liston, Muhammad Ali has been America's preeminent sports figure. His surprising splitdecision loss to upstart Leon Spinks tarnished his ring image, but he remains the nonpareil luminary in the boxing world because his celebrity stature has been nurtured as much by the controversy he has aroused outside the arena as by his exploits within it. In these two biographies the full spectrum of Ali's careerfrom pugilist to pacifist and propagandist  is covered; and although both detail the important events of his life, each emphasizes a different facet.

The move yesterday fol- lowed Canada's announcement in December that it was withdrawing Government backing for trade with South Africa, step widely regarded as more symbolic than substantive.

title: All God's Creatures
description: What's a noun of assemblage for animal book'? Gaggle? Clowder? Swarm? A bibliopleth of bestiaries? Whatever. They've been so numerous for so long now it's hard to imagine how an author or illustrator is to come up with a new approach. Tom Walther has made a good attempt in A SPIDER MIGHT (Sierra Club/ Scribner's, cloth, $7.95; paper, $4.95), which offers free verse of a sort, about what a spider might do (and actually does), along with pen-and-ink drawings of children doing the same improbable things (sprouting plumes, eating one's weight in a day). He follows up those teasers with workmanlike identification sketches. It's an ingenious approach, but I wonder ... The verse isn't catchy, the drawings are stilted, and a reader ready for the comparatively heavyweight second half might well be put off by the

title: How to Begin Debating SALT
description: There will be time enough in the weeks ahead to pick over the arms agreement that Presidents Carter and Brezhnev now have in sight. Before the Senate is finished weighing another SALT, or strategic arms limitation treaty, we shall all be counting missile tonnages and warheads in our sleep. or nightmares. We shall be debating what connections to make between a regulated competition in arms and unregulated competition for influence in Africa. We shall throw human rights into the stew of controversy, and wheat deals. It will be royal debate. It would be a more wholesome debate we took time first to rediscover the underlying American consensus about relations with the Soviet Union. A wise Administration would now promote such a discussion, to find a basis for evaluating SALT and also some coherence for its assorted diplomatic ventures.

description: Does the wardrobe shape the weekend or the weekend shape the wardrobe? If the clothes are chosen well, few basics will work no matter what the weekend brings. Here is a simple formula that will make weekend packing cinch, and everything rolls up easily in one bag.

title: Joan Herrick,BankAide,Wed
description: Joan Alexandre Herrick, daughter of Mrs. David Taylor Harris of Greenwich, Conn., and Walter Russell Herrick of West Hartford, Conn., was married yesterday in the Round Hill Community Church in Greenwich to Frank Edward Barnes 3d, son. of Mrs. Paul Keller of Smithfield, N.C., and the late Dr. Barnes Jr., a surgeon. The Rev. George D. Langdon, retired, of Salisbury, Conn., performed the ceremony.

title: The World; In Summary; `Peace Now Isn't Yet a Serious Challenge to Begin; Repackaging a Package?; Cabal in Kabul Proves Fatal; Reassuring Asian Hearts and Minds; Voting With Their Feet in Quebec; Thomas Butson, Barbara Slavin and Michael Wright
description: It wasn't the raising of the Pentagon in 1967 or any of the other early mobilizations against the Vietnam War in the United States. But a demonstration by several thousand primarily middleclass Israelis who flanked the Tel AvivJerusalem road for 15 miles last week under the banner Peace Now did represent a growing sentiment that the Government of Menachem Begin must show greater flexibility in the search for peace.

title: Koch Asks Decentralization Review
description: Citing a decline in the quality of education and high administrative costs per pupil, Mayor Koch asked the State Legislature yesterday to initiate a bipartisan review of New York City's decentralized system of community school boards.

title: Seattle Police Seek Owner of Money
description: SEATTLE, April 29 (UP1)The police here have been looking for the owner of a flight bag containing nearly $200,000 in currency and gold coins. The bag and money were found April 15 on a sidewalk next to a telephone booth in the north end of Seattle, and the police speculated that the money might be connected to some sort of illegal activity.

title: Northernette Triumphs in Top Flight
description: A crowd of 26,589 was treated to te thrilling threehorse finish yesterday at Aqueduct as Peter Brant's Northernette captured the $80,550 Top Flight Handicap.

title: 9 Killed in Greek Road Accident
description: ATHENS, April 29 (Reuters)Nine persons were killed and 60 injured in road accidents today as many Athenians left the city today for Greek Orthodox Easter celebrations. Police authorities estimated that more than half the three million people of Athens left to spend Easter with relatives in the provinces.

title: Schubert Sung by Hermann Prey

One of the mare notable observances took place Friday night at the Metropolitan Museum of Art where Hermann Prey, with Michael Krist at the piano, sang the composer's sone cycle Die schone MuHenn.

title: Aldo Moro Prepares To Let the Will Of God,Be Done
description: The Red Brigade kidnappers of Aldo Moro, tightening further the screw of apprehension surrounding the fate of the former, Italian Prime Minister, allowed him to write another letter to his family and colleagues last week. The tone was bitter and resigned, implying that Mr. Moro expected to die soon. If all is decided, let the will of God be done, he wrote.

title: Wiesel Answers Green
description: BOSTON First of all, I would like to thank Gerald Green [In Defense of Holocaust, April 23] for taking the trouble to assuage my fears. If I am to believe him, thanks to his deluxe version of the Holocaust, my ecstatic publishersRandom House and Pocket Bookswill be happily busy selling more of my books than ever and an exulting Anti-Defamation League Lecture Bureau will from this moment on, be swamped with requests for my appearances in front of wider audiences than [I] ever envisioned. Students will clamor for [my classes] (now they merely register for them), and Mr. Green will rejoice. In short, the Messiah is about least for

title: Exiles Still Face, and Adjust To Siberia's Inhumanity to Man
description: MOSCOW  For three centuries or more the vast, brooding wilderness of Siberia has held a terrifying fascination for :Russians, both as a challenging frontier of great mineral Wealth and as a dreaded place of exile. In a push to harness the resources, cities have been built on the permafrost. Pipelines, roads and railroad spurs intersect across the emptiness, and the riches are being released from the frozen land. But Still the endless wastes of swamps and forests are ootteu with tiny villages so remote and so backward that they are Considered fitting only for those sentenced to exile.

title: Teaching the Unteachable
description: THE neatly groomed black youth sitting in a classroom corner at the Argus Learning Center reading a book on the Rev Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. had been arrested four times for armed robbery when he was 15 years old, his teacher said. And the young woman sitting acrgss frarn him sketching the basket of frun., the teacher added, was a runaway  she's spent the last two of her 16 years in detention centers.

title: Roman Karmen,7 1 ; A Top Film Maker In the Soviet Union
description: Roman Karmen, one of the Soviet Union's foremost film makers, has died, was reported yesterday by Tass, the official Soviet press agency. He was 71 years old.

Karlson, founder and director of the Joint Schools Committee for Academic Excellence Now, an organization that helps students from poor communities enter college, died Wednesday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. She was 60 years old and lived at 545 West 126thStreet.

Ohio. The Rev. Paul R. Miller performed the ceremony in the Prayer Garden of the Presbyterian Church of Wyoming. The bride's previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: 6 Dead in Plane Crash in England
description: SNODLAND, England, April 29 (AP)A light plane pn ping through fog on flight from Amsterdarn crashed into bill toilay ncr this town 35 miles southeast of London. killing all six persons aben rd. the police reported, The dead are believed to have been a party of Dutch people who hired the plane to fly to Biggin Hill. an airfield 20 miles from the site of the crash, a police official said.

title: Argentina Expects World Soccer to Test Its Image

The delighted visitors, thanks to their newfound friend, order a big steak and wine as the camera pans to a fatherly figure at a nearby table who says: We must make our guests feel that Argentina is a great home where they are welcome.

description: EDGEWATER 'Cu make my son a tennis ion? is a question that Silverman, who has a reputation as New Jersey's Mr. Junior Tennis, has heard over and over again from doting, overanxious parents.

title: Solo Choreography Emphasized At the James Waring Festival
description: As a choreographer, James Waring could make interesting people look extraordinary. The second program of the James Waring Festival, Friday night at the Judson Memoriai Church, emphasized solo choreography. title: News Summary
description: Byron R. Hove, the black minister dismissed Friday by Rhodesia's transitional Government for refusing to retract remarks critical of the whitedominated judiciary and police, left the country to resume his law practice in London. He had been a Government official for two weeks. In a departing statement, Mr. Hove said that the recent accord with black leaders was a device by Prime Minister Ian D. Smith to cheat blacks of any real power in the nation's future. Bishop Abel Muzorewa, the black leader who sponsored Mr. Hove for the Government post, scheduled a meeting of his United African National Council in Salisbury today to prepare a response to the dismissal. Mr. Hove said he would be surprised if the party did not renounce the accord. [Page 1, Column 6.]

title: Two Orphans Without Mothers
description: Katherine Paterson has a rare gift for creating unusual characters who are remarkably believable. She accomplishes this with sure, swift strokes, making even minor characters multifaceted. Her fine talent works against this story, however, because too much is attempted in one book.

title: Trial for Accused Drill Sergeant
description: SAN DIEGO, April 29 AP)A drill sergeant at a Marine Corps recruit depot will face a special courtmartial Monday on charges of striking and slapping recruits, a Marine spokesman said. Sgt. Norman G. Satchell, 23 years old, of Philadelphia, is accused of abusing seven recruits. Also on Monday, the general courtmartial of another Marine drill instructer, Sgt. Allen G. Connor, 23, of Brooklyn, who is charged with firing blank shots at a recruit at Camp Pendleton, is scheduled to resume.

description: WASHINGTON. April 29 (UPI)The Federal Bureau of Investigation said yesterday that 14 state and local law en forcement officers were killed in the line of duty over the first three months of this year. The number was 12 for the same period last year.

description: WASHINGTON, April 29The Carter Administration's drive to make analyses prepared by the intelligence community more relevant to White House needs is raising questions in Administration and Congressional circles over whether the Central Intelligence Agency is able to exercise Independence on sensitive policy issues.

title: Article 2 -- No Title
What's Doing in
description: THL VALLEY  Flowing south out of Vermont and New Hampshire, the Connecticut River begins a leisurely sweep through the part of the Massachusetts countryside that is called the Pioneer Valley. Here, from the 17th century on; settlers were attracted to the lush riverbottom land, where they established the farms that to this day supply surrounding cities with every form of produce from asparagus to zucchini (including choice tobacco). The forested foothills of the Berkshires punctuate the region the river winds its pastoral way beneath Mount Holyoke, Mount Tom and Mount Sugarloaf. Modern highwaysnotably the Massachusetts Turnpike and Interstate 91cross the region, but it is along the winding back roads that the visitor reallysenses the valley.

title: CRIME
description: Halfway through DOWN AND DIRTY by Frank King (Marek, $8.95) the reader pauses and starts wondering where the author is heading. On one hand, the book is an example of bigcity verismo. A veteran homosexual officer in the New York Police Department has been uncovered and is kicked off the force. Mr. King proceeds to take a look at the homosexual world of New York, with all its desperation and sadness, as seen through the eyes of a policeman who is far more literate and sensitive than most.

Were it not for the enthusiastic performance of the stock market and the new strength of the dollar for most of the last two weeks, the current mood of the business and financial worlds would cer. tainly be much more dour than it has appeared to be recently.

description: In its second New York appearance of the week, the Westminster Choir appeared at Alice Tully Hall on Thursday night to sing all six of J. S. Bath's motets. Because these are short works, the undertaking was not as formidable as those unfamiliar with the pieces might assume. In fact, the entire concert, including intermission, was easily contained within two hours.

He had exhibited nine times, won prizes at the National Academy of Design and the Chicago Art Institute and had attracted the interest of no less a patron than the Bostonian Mrs. Jack Gardner, besides counting among his friends such artists as Abbott Thayer and John Singer Sargent.

description: UNIONDALE, L.L, April 29The power. struggle between the New York Islanders and the Toronto Maple Leafs in their quarterfinal playoff series was as much a struggle between two arenas of fans as it was between two hockey squads.

Miss Kaiser is a daughter also of the late Jerome A. Kaiser, who was president of the Ramapo Litho Corporation in New York, of which her grandfather, Samuel Greenberg, is chairman.

description: Here is a letter of friendly advice. Be serious, it says. What it means, of course, is, Be solemn. description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29A frontrunning colt named Batonnier put himself in line for a Kentucky Derby assignment today with an easy sixlength victory in the $10;000 Stepping Stone Purse at Churchill Downs.

title: Easy to Read, the Best and the Worst
description: EVERY morning, the local librarian arranges them on the kindergarten table, and she still does a brisk trade in the old favorites  The Cat in the Hat by Dr. Seuss and Little Bear by Elsa Hohnelund Minarik. I have seen Maurice Sendak's drawings of Little Bear and his friends hanging in both the playrooms of children and the living rooms of their parents. Twentyone years ago those two books introduced a new genre for children, the easytoread books that beginners read by themselves. This month Little Bear, with hardcover sales in the thousands each year, appeared in paperback. Leafing through my son's battered copy, I feel a twinge of envy as I remember my own first texts, the labels on the canned goods in our kitchen. They gave me an eclectic vocabulary: spinach, green beans, registered trademark, net weight. But the mysterious redhaired girl peeking out of her blue hood on the label Richelieu's golden corn had it all over those pallid playmates, Dick and Jane.

title: U.S. Backs Program to Curb Wild Currency Shifts
description: MEXICO CITY, April 29 The United States said today it supports new international mechanisms to control wild fluctuations of world currency markets at time of continuing uncertainty over the real value of the dollar.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: There was no major nineteenthcentury American writer of fiction, and indeed few in the second rank, who did not write some science fiction or at least one utopian romance. This startling statement appeared in the introduction to the first edition of H. Bruce Franklin's Future Perfect, which was published in 1966. Mr. Franklin, a maverick scholar whose MarxistMaoist sympathies have made him a controversial figure on a number of American university campuses, offered as evidence a superb selection of stories by, among others, Hawthorne ('The Birthmark, The Artist of the Beautiful, Rappaccini's Daughter'), Melville ('The BellTower'), Thomas Wentworth Higginson ('The Monarch of Dreams') and of course poe.

title: Last'Week's Change on Namibia Was a Tactical Retreat

At home, the Government seemed capable maintaining white dominion indefinitely. Looking beyond their borders, the ruling Afrikaners could see a swath whiteruled buffer states, offering a formidable shield against the decolonization process that had begun to hand power to blacks further north.

title: Camps That Keep Families Together

At the next morning, the routine resumes with breakfast and another songfest and activities including volley ball, riding, sailing and swimming, tennis and arts and crafts. title: The Plumbat Affair
description: WASHINGTONIn 1968, a merchant ship vanished for several days on the high seas en route from West Germany to Italy. When it reappeared, it had acquired a new name and flag, a new captain and crew, and its cargo of 200 tons of uranium, in drums mislabeled Plumbat, had disappeared. For nine years, the case of the phantom uranium ship remained one of the world's bestkept secrets, confined to a select group of nuclear officials, diplomats and intelligence agents. Its code name was The Plumbat Affair.

title: MOVING ON
description: A friend of mine, woman who had just turned 30, called not long ago and without prompting said, Did you read the other day about the 90-year-old woman who had married when she was young and had children and then started to hate her husband and being a mother and housewife, and is now divorced and discovering life and is so happy with herself? She drew a breath. God, I'm sick of women like that. I've heard all that a hundred times. Why doesn't someone ask younger women what it's like now? That woman's experience isn't my experience or my friends'. We didn't grow up in the 50's and wear our hair in curlers and read idiotic magazines and live to marry a man. We've had all the career opportunities opened up to us and being a woman has even helped. We've had more of a chance to make our lives. She paused and chuckled. We're on top now. We're like men in

title: Small Wonders In Greenwich
description: GREENWICH

title: SCHOOL SUPPLIES UNIT FACES ITS 4TH INQUIRY
description: The Queens District Attorney's office is: investigating purchasing and contract practices in the ofteninvestigated Bureau of School Supplies, which in the last th'ree years has been accused by some of its employees of bidrigging, theft of dcicuments, conspiracy and misconduct.

title: Joanne W. Young, a Lawyer Is Wed to Bruce E. Foreman
description: Joanne Wheeler Young, daughter of Col. Mason J. Young Jr. U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Young of Newport News, Va., and Bruce Edward Foreman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Foreman of Matawan, N.J., were married yesterday. The Rev. Richard T. C. Peard performed the ceremony in St. Margaret's Episcopal Church in Washington.

title: LETTERS TO THE LONG ISLAND EDITOR
description: I infer from Helen Barabino's letter [April 16] that Catholics should not vote according to their religious beliefs  indeed, that they should be legally restrained from doing so. Perhaps, in order to totally satisfy her, Catholics should be forbidden to hold public office.

title: COSTA RICA THREATENING TO SEIZE U.S. TUNA BOATS!
description: WASHINGTON;. April 29 (AP)Costa Rica has notified the United States of its intent to announce on Monday that it will seize any unlicensed tuna boats within 200 miles of its toast, a spokesman for the State Department said today.

title: Puerto Ricans Torn by Dispute Over Statehood
description: SAN JUAN, P.R.Economic and political frustrations are pushing Puerto Rico toward another plebiscite on the nature of its relationship with the United States, a vote that seems destined to intensify the sharp divisions of the socially compressed island.

title: George Cukor: lust Being Witty and Stylish Isn't Enough
description: HOLLYWOOD At 78, George Cukor is about to direct Katharine Hepburn for the 10th time in his 50th filma TV version of The Corn Is Green for Warner Brothers. And at 78, he will be honored tonight at Avery Fisher Hall by the Film Society of Lincoln Center for what Francois Truffaut recognized years ago when he wrote, Cukor is an extraordinary director, who out of five films will make one masterpiece, three that are good and one that is interesting.

title: The Brain's Division of Labor
description: FOR ages thinkers have spoken of the duality of the mind. We are double within ourselves, wrote Montaigne, and Goethe spoke of the two souls in my breast. Likewise, successful teachers have always known that different students learn in different ways.

title: English Amateur
description: Edited by Lawrence Gowing. Illustrated. Volume I. 19301937, 335 pp. Volume II. 19371958, 320 pp. Volume III. 19551967, 388 pp. New York: Thames and Hudson. Distributed by W. W. Norton. $24.95 each.

title: POLITICS
description: WHEN John V. Lindsay travels to Kings Park to make a speech, he's running for something other than a Long Island Rail Road train, even if he doesn't say so.

title: Employee Revenge Is Suspected In Burning of Municipal Trucks;
description: The destruction of five large trucks of the city's Department of Highways in fire and damaging of 12 others was reported yesterday to be an apparent act of revenge by employees who had been disciplined for failing to put in a full day's work.

title: Kentucky DerbyWeek: 7 HighPriced Days in May
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 29It started this afternoon, with mint juleps being peddled by vendors for the first time ever on an opening day at Churchill Downs. They were priced at $2.50, and customers at the race track could keep the souvenir glass.

title: FISHING The Season Starts Jumping
description: HE whole gamut of spring fishing is starting to come alive around the . Island. Certainly the best bets this week are mackerel off the South Shore and in the Sound, along with flounder in the bays and harbors.

title: Highs and Lows of HiLos
description: Observe the phenomenon of the hilo. No, it's not a new adult board game, nor does it have anything to do with weather reports. It refers to a special kind of children's book designed for the millions of preteens and teenagers in school today who haven't progressed much beyond the Run, Spot, run stage of reading.

title: Profits From the Sun
description: The nation will celebrate the sun Wednesday with fairs, concerts, speeches and demonstrations, all to ballyhoo the potential of solar power as an alternative energy source. Sun Day, as the celebration is called, will be rich dreams of a solar future. What may be missed in the .excitement, though, is the reality of a solar present.

title: Carter Turns to Asia
description: WASHINGTON, April 29--The Carter Administration is now making conscious effort to emphasize and improve its relations with the countries of Asia. In the next few weeks, Prime Minister Fukuda of Japan will be in Washington, Vice President Mondale will be touring Southeast Asia, and Zbigniew Brzezinski, the President's National Security Adviser, will confer with the new Chinese leaders in Peking.
